<Species>In this review, old methods using classical instruments including Deschamps needle are also useful as well as special wound devices designed for port site closure.</Species>

<Species>Elashry et al. described a prospective randomized study demonstrating that the Carter-Thomason device was faster and resulted in fewer port-closure-related complications among eight different techniques tested [8].</Species>
<Species>Insertion of a SURGICEL plug into the muscular layer of trocar wounds has also been proposed by Chiu et al [9].</Species>
<Species>Alternatively, tangential insertion of a trocar through the abdominal wall might be effective in reducing the size of fascial defects.</Species>
<Species>Moreover, recent publications have demonstrated that radially expanding type trocars could be useful to avoid the necessity of closing the fascial defect [10].</Species>
<Species>Symptoms of trocar-site herniation vary depending on the severity of bowel obstruction.</Species>

<Species>Mild symptoms such as slight nausea and vague abdominal pain, both of which are most frequently seen in the early normal postoperative course after abdominal surgery, could be the first and only complaints at the early stage of this complication.</Species>
<Species>Thus, the diagnosis may be delayed.</Species>
<Species>In our case, mild abdominal pain with general malaise might have been symptoms related to the early stage of the onset.</Species>
<Species>Abdominal CT showing the enlarged duodenum also suggested that leakage from the duodenal stump occurred due to the obstruction of the distal bowel.</Species>
<Species>Thus, severe complication might have been avoided, if early diagnosis had been made.</Species>
<Species>Although the benefit of Roux-en-Y is apparent</Species>
<Species>[11], the duodenal stump could be vulnerable to leakage due to increased intrabowel pressure.</Species>
<Species>Therefore, careful management of the postoperative course is warranted, especially after procedures involving division of the bowel such as LADG.</Species>

<Species>Moreover, special attention should be paid in patients with risk factors for port site hernia such as obesity, aggressive manipulation through the port sites, and prolonged surgery.</Species>
<Species>Conclusion Port-site herniation is a potentially dangerous complication after laparoscopic procedures.</Species>

<Species>Careful management of the postoperative course is recommended especially for patients with risk factors such as obesity and extensive manipulation of the trocar during prolonged surgical duration.</Species>
<Species>Competing interests The author(s) declare that they have no competing interests.</Species>
<Species>Authors' contributions TI, NF, HT and TK performed the first and second operation.</Species>
<Species>TI and KK were responsible for the postoperative management.</Species>
<Species>TI, HT, TW, and KN were involved in editing the manuscript.</Species>
<Species>All authors read and approved the final manuscript.</Species>
<Species>Consent Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report and any accompanying images.</Species>
<Species>A copy of the written consent is available for review by the Editor-in-Chief of this journal.</Species>
<Species>The role of the muscarinic system in regulating estradiol secretion varies during the estrous cycle: the hemiovariectomized rat model</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Abstract There is evidence that one gonad has functional predominance.</Species>

<Species>The present study analyzed the acute effects of unilateral ovariectomy (ULO) and blocking the cholinergic system, by injecting atropine sulfate (ATR), on estradiol (E2) serum concentrations during the estrous cycle.</Species>
<Species>The results indicate that ULO effects on E2 concentrations are asymmetric, vary during the estrous cycle, and partially depend on the cholinergic innervation.</Species>
<Species>Background Estradiol secretion is regulated by pituitary [follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormones (LH), prolactin, and adrenocorticotropin (ACTH)].</Species>
<Species>The effects of these hormones are modulated by neurotransmitters released by the intrinsic ovarian innervation near the follicular wall.</Species>
<Species>Acetylcholine produced by the follicle may be one of the neurotransmitters participating in modulating the effects of pituitary hormones on the follicle</Species>
<Species>[1-3].</Species>
<Species>Evidence suggesting that one gonad has functional predominance in mammals and birds have been published [1,4-8].</Species>

<Species>In previous studies we have shown that unilateral ovariectomy (ULO) modifies progesterone and/or testosterone serum concentrations, and that the effects of ULO depend on both, the stage of the estrous cycle when ULO was performed and the ovary (left or right) remaining in situ [9-11].</Species>
<Species>Asymmetry in ovarian functions has been explained by differences in the ovarian innervation participating in modulating the effects of gonadotropin on the ovarian follicles [1,6].</Species>

<Species>Kawakami et al [12] showed that electrical stimulation of the medial basal pre-chiasmatic area, the ventro-medial hypothalamus, and the areas in the mesencephalon of hypophysectomized and adrenalectomized female rats resulted in a significant increase of estradiol (E2) and progesterone (P4) plasma concentrations in the contra-lateral ovarian venous blood.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In turn, stimulating the dorsal hippocampus, the lateral amygdala, and the mesencephalic areas resulted in lower E2 and P4 concentrations.</Species>
<Species>Ovarian denervation of rats in proestrus stage blocks E2 secretion induced by stimulating the medial basal pre-chiasmatic area.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In addition, the electrochemical stimulation in proestrus day of the medial basal pre-chiasmatic area of untreated rats increased E2 and P4 concentrations in serum.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>This effect was not observed when stimulation was applied to the pre-optic supra-chiasmatic area.</Species>

<Species>According to the authors' interpretation of the results, the efferent neural system connecting the brain and the ovaries is supplementary to the brain-pituitary-ovarian hormonal mechanisms regulating ovarian steroid secretion, and the system may be required for adjusting ovarian responsiveness and sensitivity to gonadotropins</Species>
<Species>[12,13].</Species>
<Species>Gerendai et al.</Species>
<Species>[14] described a multi-synaptic neural pathway between the central nervous system and the ovaries, with the vagus nerve being one of the main neural pathways.</Species>
<Species>In ULO treated rats, bi-lateral sectioning the vagus nerve (ventral or dorsal) results in lower compensatory ovarian hypertrophy.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The effects of sectioning the left vagus nerve depend on the remaining ovary in situ: rats with the left ovary in situ had a larger proportion of ovulating animals, compensatory ovarian hypertrophy and number of ova shed.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In turn, rats with the right ovary in situ showed a decrease in all parameters studied [15].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Based on available information, the present study aims to analyze if changes in E2 secretion by the left and right ovaries vary during the estrous cycle, using the unilateral ovariectomized animal as a model of study.</Species>
<Species>We also investigated if, throughout estrous cycle diestrus 1 (D1), diestrus 2 (D2) and proestrus (P), the cholinergic system modulates E2 secretion in an asymmetric way.</Species>
<Species>For this purpose, we analyzed the effects of injecting ATR at 13.00 h to rats on D1, D2 or P with or without unilateral or bilateral ovariectomy.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Materials and methods The study was performed with virgin adult female rats (195-225-g body weight) of the CIIZ-V strain from our own stock.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Animals were kept under controlled lighting conditions (lights on from 05:00 to 19:00 h), with free access to food (Purina S.A., Mexico) and tap water; following NIH Guide parameters for the care of laboratory animals.</Species>
<Species>The Committee of the Facultad de Estudios Superiores Zaragoza approved the experimental protocols.</Species>
<Species>Estrous cycles were monitored by daily vaginal smears.</Species>
<Species>Only rats showing at least two consecutive 4-day cycles were used in the experiment.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>All surgeries were performed under ether anesthesia, between 13:00-13:15 hours.</Species>
<Species>Rats were sacrificed by decapitation one hour after treatment.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Experimental groups Rats were randomly allotted to one of the experimental groups described below.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Animals from different experimental groups were treated simultaneously and sacrificed one hour after surgery.</Species>
<Species>The number of animals used in each experimental group is presented in Tables 1, 2 and 3.</Species>
<Species>Control group (N = 48).</Species>
<Species>Non-treated cyclic rats sacrificed at 14:00 h on D1 (17 rats), D2 (19 rats) and P (12 rats).</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Ether anesthesia (N = 24): Groups of rats, on specific stages (D1, D2 or P) of the estrous cycle, were anesthetized for 10 min and sacrificed one hour later.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Unilateral peritoneal perforation (sham operation) (N = 53): A unilateral incision was performed 2-cm below the last rib; affecting skin, muscle, and peritoneum.</Species>
<Species>The ovaries were not injured or manipulated.</Species>
<Species>After surgical procedures the wound was sealed.</Species>
<Species>Bilateral peritoneal perforation (sham operation 2) (N = 27).</Species>
<Species>A bilateral incision below the last rib, including skin and muscle, was performed.</Species>
<Species>The ovaries were not injured or manipulated.</Species>
<Species>After surgical procedures the wound was sealed.</Species>
<Species>Unilateral ovariectomy (ULO) (N = 50): A unilateral incision below the last rib, including skin and muscle was performed, and the right or left ovary was extirpated.</Species>
<Species>The wound was subsequently sealed.</Species>
<Species>Bilateral ovariectomy (N = 23): A bilateral incision below the last rib, including skin and muscle was performed, and the ovaries removed.</Species>
<Species>The wound was subsequently sealed.</Species>
<Species>Blocking the cholinergic system To analyze the effects of blocking the cholinergic system, groups of animals were injected with atropine sulfate (ATR, Sigma Chem.</Species>
<Species>Co. St. Louis, Mo.).</Species>
<Species>ATR was injected one hour before surgery at doses known to block ovulation: in D1, 100 mg/kg body weight (b.w.); in D2, 300 mg/kg b.w.; and in P, 700 mg/kg b.w.</Species>
<Species>[16].</Species>

<Species>One hour after ATR treatment, rats were randomly allotted to one of the following treatments: unilateral peritoneal perforation, bilateral peritoneal perforation, ULO, or bilateral ovariectomy.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>All animals were sacrificed one hour after surgery.</Species>
<Species>For control purposes, untreated rats, on D1, D2 or P, were injected with ATR in the same dose as in their corresponding treatment group.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The animals were sacrificed two hours after treatment.</Species>
<Species>Autopsy procedures Animals were sacrificed by decapitation.</Species>
<Species>The blood of the trunk was collected in a test tube, allowed to clot at room temperature for 30 minutes and centrifuged at 3,000 rpm for 15 minutes.</Species>
<Species>Serum was stored at -20oC, until E2 concentrations were measured.</Species>
<Species>Hormone assay Concentrations of E2 in serum were measured by Radio-Immuno-Assay (RIA); using kits purchased from Diagnostic Products (Los Angeles, CA).</Species>
<Species>Results are expressed in pg/ml.</Species>
<Species>The Intra- and inter-assay variation coefficients were 6.9% and 10.8 %, respectively.</Species>
<Species>Statistics Data on hormonal concentrations in serum were analyzed using multivariate analysis of variance (MANOVA) followed by Tukey's test.</Species>
<Species>Differences in serum hormone concentrations between two groups were analyzed by Student's t-test.</Species>
<Species>A probability value of less than 5% was considered significant.</Species>

<Species>Results Effects of ether anesthesia and unilateral or bilateral perforation of the peritoneum In the control group, animals sacrificed on P showed significantly higher E2 serum concentration than animals sacrificed on D1 or D2 (D1: 55.3 + 8.0; D2: 59.1 + 7.9; P: 158.4 + 1.8).</Species>
<Species>Compared to the control group, ether anesthesia treatment did not modify E2 serum concentrations (D1: 62.9 + 8.4; D2: 69.5 + 12.0; P: 164.1 + 17.6).</Species>
<Species>Since ether anesthesia did not modify E2 serum concentrations, treatment results are compared to their respective control group.</Species>

<Species>The effects on E2 serum concentrations of unilaterally or bilaterally perforating the peritoneum depended on the side of the peritoneum and the stage of the estrous cycle when perforation surgery was performed.</Species>

<Species>Perforating the left peritoneum on D1 resulted in lower E2 serum concentrations (55%), while bilateral perforation, or perforating the right side of the peritoneum, had no apparent effects (Table 1).</Species>

<Species>Perforating the right side of the peritoneum on D2 day resulted in E2 concentration increases (184%), while perforating the left side resulted in a decrease (51%) of E2 serum concentrations.</Species>
<Species>Bilateral perforation had no apparent effects on hormone concentrations.</Species>
<Species>Perforating the peritoneum on P phase (left, right or bilateral) resulted in hormone serum concentration decreases (Left 30%;</Species>
<Species>Right 50%; Bilateral 41%).</Species>
<Species>Results are summarized in Table 1.</Species>

<Species>Effects of unilateral or bilateral ovariectomy When surgery was performed on D1, no significant differences in E2 serum concentrations were observed between rats with ULO (animals with intact left or right ovary in situ) or perforation of the peritoneum (Figure 1).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Animals with the left intact ovary in situ showed significantly higher E2 serum concentrations than animals with the right intact ovary in situ (61.5 + 9.4 vs. 17.3 + 4.3, p < 0.05 Student's t test).</Species>
<Species>Compared to animals with unilateral perforation of the peritoneum, animals with right ULO (left ovary in situ) performed on D2 had lower E2 serum concentrations (55%).</Species>
<Species>Such differences were not observed in rats with left ULO (Figure 1).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>As in rats treated on D1, E2 serum concentrations were significantly higher in animals treated on D2 with the left ovary in situ (right ULO) than in animals with the right ovary in situ (49.5 + 10.8 vs. 26.0 + 6.9).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In animals treated on P, right ULO (left ovary in situ) resulted in higher E2 (180%) serum concentrations than in animals with unilateral peritoneum perforation.</Species>

<Species>ULO performed on the left side (right ovary in situ), resulted in significantly lower (45%) E2 serum concentrations compared to rats with a unilateral perforation of the peritoneum (Figure 1).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>As observed in rats treated on D1 or D2, when the intact left ovary remains in situ, estradiol serum concentrations were significantly higher than in animals with the intact right ovary in situ (142.0 + 14.1 vs. 61.5 + 6.0).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Compared to animals with a bilateral perforation of the peritoneum, bilateral ovariectomy resulted in significantly lower E2 serum concentrations, regardless of the stage of the estrous cycle surgery performed (D1 74%; D2 73%; P 84%).</Species>
<Species>Results are summarized in Table 2.</Species>

<Species>Effects of blocking the cholinergic system Injecting ATR on D1 or P resulted in E2 serum concentrations decreases (84% and 67%, respectively), and had no apparent effects on E2 serum concentrations when injected on D2 (Table 3).</Species>

<Species>Figure 2 shows that the effects of blocking the cholinergic system of rats with unilateral perforation of the peritoneum depended on both, the side (left or right) and the phase of the estrous when surgery was performed.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Injecting ATR on D1 or D2 resulted in a significant drop in E2 serum concentrations in animals with sham treatment on the right side.</Species>

<Species>Blocking the cholinergic system of rats with left side peritoneum perforation on D1 or P resulted in a drop in E2 serum concentrations (52%; 47%, respectively), while the same treatment performed on D2 resulted in a significant E2 concentrations increase (157%).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Figure 3 shows the effects of blocking the cholinergic system of rats with ULO.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>ATR treatment on D1 or P stages performed on rats with the left ovary in situ resulted in a significant drop of E2 serum concentrations (65%; 62% respectively).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Such effects were not observed in rats treated on D2.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>When ATR treatment was performed on rats with the right ovary in situ on D1, E2 serum concentrations were lower (48%) than in ULO animals.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Blocking the cholinergic system on D2 resulted in E2 serum concentrations increase (159%).</Species>
<Species>When the treatment was performed on P, no significant differences in E2 serum concentrations were observed.</Species>

<Species>Compared to bilateral treatment, perforation of the peritoneum or bilateral ovariectomy, ATR treatment on D1 resulted in significant E2 serum concentrations decreases, 90% in bilateral peritoneal perforation and 60% in bilateral ovariectomized animals.</Species>

<Species>Blocking the cholinergic system on D2, to rats with bilateral perforation of the peritoneum or bilateral ovariectomy resulted in E2 serum concentrations increases (159% and 253% respectively), while injecting ATR to animals treated on P had no apparent effects (Figure 4).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Discussion</Species>

<Species>The results obtained in the present study suggest that the ability to compensate the secretion of E2 by the missing ovary is different between the right and left ovaries and varies during the estrous cycle.</Species>

<Species>Similarly, our results suggest that the cholinergic system participates in regulating E2 secretion by the ovary, and that such participation varies depending on the ovary remaining in situ and the stage of the estrous cycle when the surgical procedure was performed.</Species>
<Species>Previously, we suggested the existence of a neural pathway arising from the peritoneum that participates in regulating E2 [9], P4 [10] and testosterone secretion [11].</Species>
<Species>In the rat, the sensory information arising from the peritoneum is sent to the nucleus tractus solitarius and stimulates neurokinine-B receptors [17].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Since perforating the peritoneum unilaterally on each day of the estrous cycle changed E2 serum concentrations, we think that each side of the peritoneum sends different neural information through the superior ovarian nerve (SON) to the ovary and the central nervous system, perhaps reaching nuclei related to the vagus nerve.</Species>

<Species>A study analyzing the distribution of sensory neurons innervating the peritoneum showed that when tracer was placed on the area where the peritoneum covers the abdominal wall, labeled neurons were observed only in the ipsilateral dorsal root ganglia [18].</Species>
<Species>The authors suggest that most of the parietal peritoneum receives sensory nerves from dorsal root ganglia, and visceral peritoneum from both, the spinal and vagus nerves.</Species>
<Species>According to Stener-Victorin et al.</Species>

<Species>(19) repeated electro-acupunture treatments in rats with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCO), induced by a single injection of estradiol valerate, resulted in lower nerve growth factor (NGF) concentrations at the ovarian level than in non-electro-acupunture treated PCO rats.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>In our experiments, perforating the peritoneum affected the same somatic segments employed by Stener-Victorin et. al.</Species>
<Species>[19].</Species>
<Species>We presume that peritoneum surgery resulted in an increase of NGF concentrations at the ovarian level, which in turn induced hyper-androgenism, as observed in women with PCO [20].</Species>
<Species>Previously, we showed that the unilateral perforation of the peritoneum results in a significant increase in testosterone serum concentrations [11].</Species>

<Species>Because E2 serum concentrations did not increase after left or bilateral perforation of the peritoneum, we suppose that the neural information originating from the peritoneum inhibits the mechanisms regulating aromatase activity within the follicle.</Species>
<Species>One of the ovaries' sources of catecholamines arrives through the SON.</Species>
<Species>In the ovary, the SON fibers are mainly distributed in the peri-follicular theca layer, and in close relation with the cells of the theca interna [21,22].</Species>

<Species>Sectioning the SON of rats in P results in a sudden drop of P4 and E2 concentrations in the ovarian vein effluent [23], while the same procedure on estrus did not modify E2 concentrations [24].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Therefore, it is possible that perforating the peritoneum modifies the type and/or rate of information arriving to the ovary via the SON.</Species>

<Species>Another possibility is that perforating the left side of the peritoneum results in an increase release of ovarian gamma amino butyric acid (GABA), and a subsequent increase of E2 concentrations.</Species>
<Species>According to Erdo, et. al.</Species>
<Species>[25] and Laszlo, et. al.</Species>
<Species>[26], injecting GABA into pseudo-pregnant rats increases E2 concentration in the blood.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Present results indicate that injecting ATR, before unilateral or bilateral perforation of the peritoneum, to rats in D1 or P, results in lower E2serum concentrations; leading us to think that some of the neural fibers present in the peritoneum are muscarinic.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>It is also possible that blocking the cholinergic innervation, by ATR treatment, results in lower adrenaline and norepinephrine release by the adrenal medulla.</Species>

<Species>Our results, and those of others, suggest that stimulating on D2 the sensory receptors located on the left side of the peritoneum triggers an E2 secretion inhibitory mechanism, that the sensory pathway arising from the right side has a stimulatory effect, and that both are mediated by the cholinergic muscarinic system.</Species>

<Species>Previously, we showed that injecting ATR to rats in D2 results in increases of P4 serum concentrations originating from the adrenals [8], without having apparent effects on testosterone serum concentrations [11].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Since P4 and androgens are precursors in the synthesis of E2, we presume that this mechanism may explain the increase in E2 serum concentrations observed in rats with peritoneum perforation previously injected with ATR.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Another possibility explaining the differences on E2 secretion regulation during the estrous cycle is that the effects of the cholinergic system take place through changes at the celiac ganglion level.</Species>

<Species>According to Aguado and Ojeda [23], acetylcholine inhibits P4 secretion in the celiac ganglion-SON-ovary preparation obtained from rats in D1 or D2, while the preparation obtained from rats in P resulted in only a moderate stimulation.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Since there is evidence that fibers from the vagus nerve innervate neurons in the celiac ganglion [27], we presume that the cholinergic system modulates the sympathetic post-ganglionar activity and the secretory ability of the ovaries through the SON.</Species>

<Species>Conclusion Based on the differences in E2 serum concentrations in rats with ULO, present results suggest that the capacity to release E2 by the left and right ovaries varies during the estrous cycle.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We presume that the left ovary releases more E2 than the right one.</Species>
<Species>As previously proposed, another possibility is that neural communication between the ovaries modulates E2 secretion.</Species>
<Species>Purinergic signalling in the subretinal space: a role in the communication between the retina and the RPE</Species>
<Species>Abstract The retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) is separated from the photoreceptor outer segments by the subretinal space.</Species>

<Species>While the actual volume of this space is minimal, the communication that occurs across this microenvironment is important to the visual process, and accumulating evidence suggests the purines ATP and adenosine contribute to this communication.</Species>
<Species>P1 and P2 receptors are localized to membranes on both the photoreceptor outer segments and on the apical membrane of the RPE which border subretinal space.</Species>
<Species>ATP is released across the apical membrane of the RPE into this space in response to various triggers including glutamate and chemical ischemia.</Species>
<Species>This ATP is dephosphorylated into adenosine by a series of ectoenzymes on the RPE apical membrane.</Species>

<Species>Regulation of release and ectoenzyme activity in response to light-sensitive signals can alter the balance of purines in subretinal space, and thus coordinate communication across subretinal space with the visual process.</Species>
<Species>Introduction The retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) lies between the outer segments of the photoreceptors and the choroidal blood supply (Fig. 1).</Species>
<Species>The RPE combines the functions of epithelial and glial cells, providing a barrier while also supporting the neural photoreceptors and modulating their function.</Species>

<Species>Tight communication between photoreceptors and the RPE is critical to coordinate the multiple levels of interaction, and the purinergic contribution to this communication is becoming apparent.</Species>

<Species>The relevance of this purinergic input is emphasized by the many functional effects of P1 and P2 receptor stimulation and by the multiple mechanisms in place to regulate subretinal levels of purine agonists.</Species>

<Species>As the dynamics of ATP release and extracellular conversion into adenosine will modify agonist availability, the modulation of these processes can exert a temporal control on purinergic signaling.</Species>

<Species>The following review will outline the main interactions between the RPE and photoreceptors, describe the effects of stimulating purinergic receptors on both sides of subretinal space, and summarize how levels of ATP, ADP, and adenosine are manipulated in this microenvironment.</Species>
<Species>Fig. 1Schematic illustration of the key components of purinergic signaling in the subretinal microenvironment.</Species>
<Species>Stimulation of P2 receptors on the RPE can enhance transepithelial fluid absorption while P1 receptors can modulate phagocytosis.</Species>

<Species>ATP released through CFTR and other Cl    channels can stimulate P2 receptors or be converted to ADP, AMP, and adenosine (Ado) by a series of ectonucleotidases present on the apical membrane of the RPE.</Species>

<Species>By controlling the balance of extracellular purines available to stimulate these receptors these mechanisms can control levels of endogenous purines available to activate the receptors.</Species>

<Species>While theoretically possible, it remains to be determined whether these subretinal purines can actually stimulate photoreceptors Purines and subretinal space RPE-photoreceptor interactions across the subretinal space The outer segments of the rods and cones are responsible for the initial stages of vision, converting photon energy into a series of enzymatic reactions that close the light-sensitive channels on the photoreceptor plasma membrane, hyperpolarize the cells, and reduce the release of glutamate from the synaptic terminals [1, 2].</Species>
<Species>Efficient photoreceptor function depends upon both short-term and long-term support from the RPE.</Species>

<Species>The critical nature of these interactions is evident from the rapid degeneration of photoreceptors in the absence of a healthy RPE layer and by the RPE localization of defective gene product in some forms of hereditary photoreceptor degeneration [3].</Species>
<Species>The apical membrane of the RPE is separated from the plasma membrane of the outer segments by an extracellular space of only 10-20 nm [4].</Species>
<Species>Although small, this subretinal space contains a highly structured matrix which ensheathes the outer segments and extends to the RPE [5, 6].</Species>
<Species>The presence of enzymes within this interphotoreceptor matrix emphasizes that this extracellular space itself is functionally active [7, 8].</Species>
<Species>This intimate anatomical relationship between photoreceptors and the RPE reflects multiple functional interactions.</Species>
<Species>For example, the RPE accepts, recycles, and exports central components of the phototransduction process [9].</Species>
<Species>The outer segments are continuously resynthesized, and the phagocytosis, degradation, and processing of shed outer segment tips by the RPE cells is central to this renewal</Species>
<Species>[10].</Species>
<Species>The ion channels and transporters on the apical membrane of the RPE help regulate the ionic composition of the subretinal space [11].</Species>
<Species>As extracellular levels of ions can modify the ionic driving forces across the photoreceptor plasma membrane, these RPE transporters can influence the state of neural activity.</Species>
<Species>The transport of fluid and ions from the apical membrane to basolateral membrane of the RPE is also one of the main forces keeping the retina attached [12].</Species>
<Species>The control of photoreceptor activity by light gives a rapid temporal dependence to some interactions between the photoreceptors and the RPE.</Species>

<Species>The volume of subretinal space increases in response to light [13], linking small changes in the ionic composition of the subretinal space with activity of the RPE transport mechanisms which maintain this volume [14, 15].</Species>
<Species>Other processes are controlled on a diurnal cycle.</Species>
<Species>The shed tips of the outer segments are phagocytosed by the RPE soon after the onset of light</Species>
<Species>[16, 17].</Species>
<Species>These processes can both be modulated by purine levels in subretinal space, indicating purinergic regulation is important over multiple time scales.</Species>

<Species>Purinergic receptors on photoreceptors A2 adenosine receptors were localized to both the inner and outer segments of photoreceptor outer segments over a decade ago by Blazynski and colleagues [18], with more recent reports emphasizing their functional role.</Species>

<Species>A2 agonists inhibit the L-type Ca2+ channel on rod outer segments [19] and can inhibit the synaptic release of glutamate from rods, suggesting changes in adenosine levels in subretinal space could modulate light sensitivity [20].</Species>

<Species>The A2 agonist DPMA and the adenosine deaminase inhibitor EHNA reduce mRNA for opsin in rods, suggesting that endogenous levels of adenosine can downregulate opsin message at night [21].</Species>
<Species>EHNA and the A2A receptor agonist CGS21680 also increase the survival of chick embryonic photoreceptors in culture [22], indicating a long-term neuroprotective role for adenosine.</Species>
<Species>P2 receptors are also present in the photoreceptors.</Species>
<Species>mRNA for the P2X2 receptor is expressed in the photoreceptor cell bodies, with immunohistochemical localization of the protein to outer segments [23].</Species>

<Species>In situ hybridization indicates the photoreceptor layer has the highest level of P2Y2 receptor of any region in the rabbit retina, although staining was not pronounced in monkey [24].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>P2X7 receptors have recently been localized to photoreceptor synaptic terminals, with evidence for ecto-ATPase activity in the synapse, and functional evidence suggesting ATP augments transmission of the light response by rods [25].</Species>
<Species>It was suggested that ATP might be co-released from photoreceptors with glutamate, although this remains to be tested directly.</Species>
<Species>Purinergic receptors on the RPE Stimulation of P1 receptors can have a considerable impact on RPE cells.</Species>
<Species>A2 receptors have been recognized on cultured and fresh RPE cells for some time [26, 27], with in situ hybridization confirming the presence of A2A receptors in rat RPE [28].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Stimulation of A2 receptors reduces the rate of rod outer segment phagocytosis by RPE cells [29], while application of adenosine to the apical membrane of chick RPE cells increases the basolateral Cl- conductance, the transepithelial potential, and the c-wave, and decreases the hyperpolarization of the basal membrane in response to light [30].</Species>

<Species>Although adenosine alone does not increase intracellular Ca2+ levels [31], adenosine acts synergistically with ATP to elevate Ca2+ levels in human RPE cells by stimulating both A1 and A2A receptors [32, 33].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Stimulation of A1 receptors with high doses of NECA increases the active transport of fluorescein across the RPE, while activation of A2A receptors decreases this transport, and by extension, transport of the ions that underlie fluid movement [34].</Species>
<Species>Stimulation of A1 and A2A receptors produces analogous increases and decreases, respectively, in the absorption of subretinal fluid blebs.</Species>

<Species>This is consistent with the negative coupling of the A1 receptor and the positive coupling of the A2 receptors to adenylate cyclase, as increasing cAMP inhibits the transport of fluid across the RPE towards the choroid</Species>
<Species>[35-37].</Species>

<Species>The agonist 2-Cl adenosine reverses the deficit in phosphoinositide metabolism found in diabetic RPE cells [38], suggesting effects on metabolism in addition to transport and phagocytosis.</Species>
<Species>Multiple P2 receptors have been localized to the RPE.</Species>
<Species>The P2Y2 receptor was initially characterized in cultured human RPE [31], with subsequent reports localizing transcript for P2Y1, P2Y2, P2Y4, and P2Y6 in the rat RPE/choroid</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>[39] and for P2Y1 and P2Y12 receptors in ARPE-19 cells [40], and functionally identifying a P2X receptor in rat RPE cells [41].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>ATP, ADP, and UTP induce numerous effects on RPE physiology [32, 33, 42, 43].</Species>
<Species>While these effects likely involve multiple different receptor types, the contributions of the P2Y2 receptor have been explored in most detail to date.</Species>

<Species>The P2Y2 receptor has been specifically localized to the apical membrane of fresh bovine RPE cells, and addition of ATP to this membrane transiently elevates Ca2+, activates a basolateral Cl- conductance, inhibits an apical K+ conductance, and increases the apical to basolateral flow of fluid [43].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>This increased absorption of fluid from the subretinal space suggests P2Y2 receptor stimulation could reduce the excess fluid that accumulates in retinal edemas, and several reports have supported this theory.</Species>
<Species>ATP, UTP, and the P2Y2 receptor agonist INS37217 decrease the size of subretinal fluid blebs when injected into subretinal space of rats [44].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In both normal and rds +/- mice with experimentally induced detachment, INS31217 improves the ERG recovery and decreased cell death</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>[45].</Species>
<Species>INS37217 also reduces subretinal blebs in rabbits [46].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Injection of another P2Y2 agonist, INS542, increases the active transport of fluorescein across the RPE, consistent with this upregulation of ion and fluid transport across the tissue [47].</Species>
<Species>Together these experiments emphasize the clinical potential of treating retinal edema with P2Y2 agonists.</Species>

<Species>Regulation of purine levels in subretinal space While synthesized purinergic agonists may prove useful in treating some ocular disorders, the endogenous activation of P1 and P2 receptors in the subretinal microenvironment will ultimately be determined by availability of agonists.</Species>

<Species>These levels are largely controlled by the release of ATP into the subretinal space, its conversion into other purines including adenosine, and the manipulation of adenosine by enzymes or transporters.</Species>
<Species>Recent work has increased our understanding of both the stimuli that initiate changes in subretinal purine levels and the mechanisms that mediate these changes.</Species>
<Species>Release of ATP by the RPE At least some of the ATP capable of stimulating the purinergic receptors on RPE cells is released from the RPE itself.</Species>
<Species>The resulting autocrine stimulation ensures local delivery, and control, of purines to initiate the physiologic changes in the RPE.</Species>
<Species>The release of ATP by RPE cells is triggered by multiple stimuli including osmotic stress, bFGF, UTP, NMDA, glutamate, and ATP [39, 40, 48-51].</Species>

<Species>The ATP release following activation of NMDA receptors by glutamate may have the most interesting implications for communication across subretinal space, given that glutamate confers the light signal from photoreceptors to the rest of the visual system.</Species>

<Species>Glutamate and the specific receptor agonist NMDA triggers ATP release from ARPE-19 cells, with the release inhibited by NMDA antagonist MK-801, and by DCKA, which inhibits the glycine B binding site on NMDA receptors [51, 52].</Species>

<Species>Although NMDA raises intracellular Ca2+ levels, this increase is prevented by eliminating ATP with apyrase, indicating autostimulation through released ATP is responsible for this Ca2+ signal.</Species>
<Species>NMDA also triggers a release of ATP when applied to the intact bovine</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>RPE eyecup [51].</Species>

<Species>The NMDA receptors and the ATP release sites have been functionally identified to the apical membrane of the bovine RPE, suggesting the neurotransmitter interactions could amplify the signal from any glutamate reaching subretinal space.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The ability of both UTP and ATP to stimulate release of ATP from the RPE supports the theory that the system acts to amplify signals.</Species>
<Species>When applied at greater than 1 uM, ATP triggers a secondary release of ATP peaking 10 min after the initial stimuli [40].</Species>
<Species>UTP also initiates a release in extracellular ATP with a similar delay [48].</Species>

<Species>The rise in ATP triggered by UTP is inhibited by the Cl- channel blocker NPPB, and UDP is much less effective at triggering release than UTP; both observations suggest the P2Y2 receptor contributes to the increase in ATP more than diphosphokinase, although influence from the enzyme cannot be ruled out</Species>
<Species>[53].</Species>
<Species>Recent evidence suggests that ischemia may lead to the release of ATP from RPE cells.</Species>
<Species>Chemical ischemia triggers a substantial ATP release from cardiac myocytes [54], while changes in oxygen levels trigger ATP release in central chemoreceptors [55].</Species>
<Species>We found that exposure to sodium cyanide led to a rapid release of ATP from ARPE-19 cells (Fig. 2).</Species>

<Species>As hypoxic and/or ischemic challenge may lead to changes in the expression of growth factors in RPE cells during certain ocular disorders such as macular degeneration [56], and as purines can induce expression of VEGF in other cells [57], this ATP release may contribute to growth factor signaling by the diseased RPE.</Species>
<Species>Fig. 2Chemical ischemia triggers ATP release from ARPE-19 cells.</Species>
<Species>ATP release was measured in the bath directly from cells plated in 96-well plates to which the luciferin- luciferase reaction mixture was added [51].</Species>
<Species>Left Levels of ATP in the bath after addition of 5 mM NaCN to the cells.</Species>
<Species>Measurement began 1 min after addition of NaCN or control solution to wells.</Species>
<Species>Right Levels of ATP measured at the peak, 3 min after addition of NaCN (n = 12).</Species>
<Species>Levels were normalized to concurrent levels in control (n = 14).</Species>
<Species>Symbols and bars represent mean + SE, *p < 0.001</Species>
<Species>The particular conduit for ATP release varies with the stimuli.</Species>

<Species>The release in response to hypotonic challenge is largely dependent upon CFTR, as it was prevented by the specific CFTR inhibitor CFTR172 in addition to the more general blocker glybenclamide [50].</Species>

<Species>While the precise mechanisms by which CFTR contributes to this release are not yet known, a role for CFTR in ATP release into subretinal space is consistent with the reduction of certain ERG components in cftr -/- mice</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>[58] and with the ability of apical ATP to activate conductances associated with these ERG components [43].</Species>

<Species>The release of ATP is also largely blocked by the vesicular transport inhibitor brefeldin A, suggesting the two processes occurred in series whereby ATP efflux follows the insertion of vesicles containing CFTR into the plasma membrane.</Species>
<Species>Although the Ca2+ chelator BAPTA blocks this ATP release [50], raising Ca2+ alone with ionophore ionomycin does not itself initiate release [48].</Species>
<Species>This necessary but not sufficient contribution of Ca2+ also supports a role for vesicular insertion.</Species>
<Species>In contrast to the release following hypotonic challenge, the ATP release in response to NMDA does not involve CFTR</Species>
<Species>[51].</Species>
<Species>Release is blocked by NPPB, however, suggesting another type of anion channel could serve as a conduit for ATP release.</Species>

<Species>The presence of parallel mechanisms coexisting on the same cell for ATP release triggered by either agonists or by cell swelling has also been reported in astrocytes [59] and may reflect the multiple roles of purinergic signaling within a given tissue.</Species>
<Species>As both stimuli lead to release across the apical membrane into subretinal space, both are expected to influence signaling in the microenvironment.</Species>

<Species>Interconversion of purines in subretinal space The interconversion of nucleotides and nucleosides each capable of stimulating distinct receptors makes the purinergic signaling system of particular interest in a confined region such as the subretinal space.</Species>
<Species>The main enzymes responsible for dephosphorylating extracellular ATP on the RPE cells have been analyzed and a basic understanding of their regulation has begun.</Species>
<Species>This section first describes the enzymes that act on ATP and ADP, followed by enzymes which convert AMP into adenosine.</Species>
<Species>The dephosphorylation of extracellular ATP by RPE cells involves enzymes from multiple families [40], as found in airway epithelial cells [60].</Species>
<Species>Degradation of ATP by the apical membrane of the fresh bovine eyecup and by ARPE-19 cells is inhibited by ARL67156 or bgmATP.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Message for eNPP1, eNPP2, and eNPP3 is present in ARPE-19 cells, consistent with the preference of bgmATP for members of the eNPP family</Species>
<Species>[61].</Species>
<Species>The cells also express NTPDase2, and NTPDase3, although the intermittent presence of NTPDase1 likely reflects a regulated process [40].</Species>
<Species>Ecto-alkaline phosphatase has no effect on ATP degradation in RPE cells, in contrast to its considerable contribution in airway epithelium [62].</Species>
<Species>The putative contribution from diphosphokinases to interconversion of subretinal purines is presently unknown.</Species>
<Species>Extracellular AMP is rapidly dephosphorylated into adenosine in subretinal space.</Species>

<Species>The production of adenosine from ATP at the apical membrane of the bovine RPE eyecup is inhibited by the ecto-5   -nucleotidase inhibitor abmADP, confirming a role for this enzyme [63].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The enzyme is localized to rat RPE and ARPE-19 cells immunohistochemically.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Degradation of 5   AMP is highest near the subretinal space of rat retina [63], although localization in mouse indicated larger amounts of ecto-5   -nucleotidase at the tips of adjacent Muller cells [64].</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Levamisole does not inhibit the dephosphorylation of 5   AMP by the RPE, consistent with the absence of substantial ecto-alkaline phosphatase in subretinal space.</Species>
<Species>The presence of light may alter the levels of adenosine in subretinal space.</Species>
<Species>Epinephrine is released at the onset of light [65] and stimulation of the RPE with epinephrine can decrease activity of ecto-5   -nucleotidase</Species>
<Species>[63].</Species>

<Species>While norepinephrine and phenylephrine lead to similar decreases in enzyme activity, prazosin and corynanthine block the effects of norepinephrine, implicating the a1 epinephrine receptor in the inhibition of ecto-5   -nucleotidase</Species>
<Species>[63].</Species>
<Species>The kinetics of inhibition are consistent with cleavage of the nucleotidase from its GPI anchor.</Species>
<Species>The phagocytosis of rod outer segments is maximal shortly after light onset [16], and this phagocytosis is inhibited by adenosine [29].</Species>

<Species>The ability of epinephrine released by the illuminated retina to reduce ecto-5   -nucleotidase activity and consequently adenosine levels may relieve this inhibition and enhance the rate of phagocytosis at light onset.</Species>

<Species>Physiologic effects of subretinal purines on the RPE and photoreceptors The number of purinergic receptors on both photoreceptor and RPE membranes suggests purines make multiple contributions to the physiology of the outer retina.</Species>
<Species>Our increased understanding of how agonist levels in subretinal space are controlled has begun to indicate how and when this contribution may occur.</Species>

<Species>Future research will involve applying these findings from isolated systems to intact RPE-photoreceptor models, and pursuing the role of defective purinergic regulation in ocular disease.</Species>

<Species>While it is unlikely that ATP released across the apical membrane of the RPE can diffuse to these P2 receptors in the outer plexiform layer given the ecto-ATPase activity in the synaptic clef [25], stimulation of receptors elsewhere on the photoreceptor membrane is possible.</Species>

<Species>It would be interesting to determine whether ATP released from the RPE and converted to adenosine by ecto-nucleotidases can actually modulate the response to light by stimulating the A2A receptors on photoreceptor outer segments.</Species>
<Species>The impact of purinergic signaling on chronic ocular diseases is also of interest, such as the role of ischemia-driven ATP release in VEGF production.</Species>

<Species>While the small size of subretinal space can complicate pharmacologic manipulation within the intact RPE-photoreceptor complex, molecular approaches may provide new insight into how endogenous purines in subretinal space affect the physiology, and pathophysiology, of both RPE and photoreceptors.</Species>

<Species>Peculiarities of carcinogenesis under simultaneous oral administration of benzo(a)pyrene and o-cresol in mice.</Species>

text: <Species>Abstract A modifying influence of ortho-cresol (o-cresol) on the carcinogenic effect of benzo(a)pyrene (BaP) with combined oral administration to CC57Br mice had been found.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>During simultaneous administration of o-cresol (1 mg) and BaP (1 mg), the incidence of tumors, the multiplicity of tumors, and the degree of malignancy all increased, but the latency was shortened.</Species>
<Species>When o-cresol was administered before or after BaP (in identical doses), the carcinogenic effect was weakened.</Species>

<Species>When o-cresol (10 mg) and BaP (5 mg) were administered simultaneously, the incidence of malignant tumors was similar to controls receiving BaP only (13.8%), indicating inhibition of carcinogenesis.</Species>

text: <Species>During simultaneous administration of o-cresol (1 mg) and BaP (1 mg), the incidence of tumors, the multiplicity of tumors, and the degree of malignancy all increased, but the latency was shortened.</Species>
<Species>When o-cresol was administered before or after BaP (in identical doses), the carcinogenic effect was weakened.</Species>

<Species>Introduction Numerous experiments have shown a modifying influence of different chemicals on benzo(a)pyrene (BaP)induced carcinogenic effects.</Species>
<Species>Both enhancing or weakening effects have been seen (1-12).</Species>
<Species>In some experiments ubiquitious environmental carcinogenic and toxic chemical pollutants were used (13-17).</Species>

<Species>The stimulating effect of phenol, nitrogen oxides, and sulfur dioxide upon BaP's blastogenic action on the respiratory tract and phenol on the digestive tract (forestomach) have been reported (12-18).</Species>
<Species>We have established the relationship between the doses of carcinogenic and toxic agents and their modifying effects (17,18).</Species>
<Species>The maximal enhancing effect was observed after BaP (2.5 mg) and NO2 (0.87 mg/m3) were exposed to rat respiratory tract.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The effect weakened with decreasing dose.</Species>
<Species>At concentrations at the MPC level (MPC BaP, 1 ng/m3, MPC NO2, 0.04 mg/m3) no effect was seen.</Species>
<Species>Phenol at 1 mg orally to CC57Br</Species>
<Species>mice enhanced the BaP (1 mg) effect, but no effect was seen at 0.02 mg.</Species>

text: <Species>Phenolic compounds showed either enhancing or inhibiting effects on carcinogenesis depending on their chemical structure (16,18-25).</Species>

<Species>This report presents the results of combined oral administration of BaP and artho-cresol (o-cresol) in mice, 'Ukrainian State Medical Center for Environmental Health, Kiev, Ukraine.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Address reprint requests to N. Y. Yanysheva, Ukrainian State Medical Center for Environmental Health, Popudrenko St. 50, 253660 Kiev-94, Ukraine.</Species>
<Species>chemicals commonly found in ambient water because of their industrial use (coke chemistry, oil processing, shale processing, and other industries) (27-30).</Species>
<Species>Materials and Methods The experiment was conducted on CC57Br female mice weighing 12-14 g. Animals were divided in 15 groups.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>This experiment included three types of sequential combinations for the introduction of compounds: a) simultaneous BaP and o-cresol administration; b) BaP after o-cresol (stage 1); and c) BaP before o-cresol (stage 2).</Species>
<Species>Appropriate controls were included (Table 1).</Species>
<Species>The chemicals were administered twice per week (for a total of 10, 20, and 40 doses) using a syringe and a needle with a soldered olive on its tip.</Species>
<Species>BaP (1 or 5 mg) or o-cresol (0.02, 1, or 10 mg) was placed in triethylene glycol (TEG) and administered as 0.1-mL water solutions.</Species>

<Species>The evaluation of o-cresol's modifying effect on the incidence of tumors, especially malignant tumors, the tumor latency period (tl), and the average time (ta) of the appearance of tumors, as well as the multiplicity index, M (the average number of tumors per animal for tumor-bearing animals) was recorded.</Species>

<Species>Because the M could be identified at the initial stage of carcinogenesis by the third month after the beginning of the trial when neoplasms began to emerge, moribund animals were killed by ether inhalation if they did not die spontaneously.</Species>
<Species>The experiments with large chemical doses (BaP, 5 mg; o-cresol, 10 mg) lasted for 30 weeks.</Species>
<Species>Some animals were killed after the 1st, 3rd, 5th, and 10th procedures for the YANYSHEVA ET AL.</Species>
<Species>evaluation of initial stages of carcinogenesis; others were killed at 26 and 30 weeks.</Species>
<Species>The stomachs were distended with formalin solution and the mucosa examined macroscopically.</Species>
<Species>All tumors ></Species>
<Species>1 mm in diameter were recorded.</Species>
<Species>Organs and tissues were fised in 10% neutral formalin solution, embedded in paraffin and routine histological slides prepared.</Species>
<Species>Microscopic data were processed according to Mostkovoy (30).</Species>
<Species>Results</Species>
<Species>The data from this study demonstrate the modifying influence of o-cresol on BaP-induced carcinogenesis with combined oral exposure.</Species>
<Species>The combined exposure and BaP alone caused benign and malignant epithelial tumors of the forestomach.</Species>
<Species>The benign neoplasms were papillomas, and the malignant neoplasms were invasive carcinomas.</Species>
<Species>The combined administration of BaP and o-cresol showed different results depending on doses and sequential combinations of both chemicals.</Species>
<Species>As shown in Table 2, the simultaneous administration of BaP (1 mg) and o-cresol (1 mg) affected all parameters of carcinogenesis that were measured.</Species>

<Species>This included a significant increase in the incidence of tumors, shortening of the time to the appearance of the first tumor, and the mean time of tumor development as compared to animals that received 1 mg of BaP alone and had tumors.</Species>
<Species>One hundred percent of the mice that received 5 mg of BaP alone had tumors.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Shortening of the time to appearance of malignant tumors was also observed: the mice with forestomach cancer died between 23 and 26.2 weeks after the beginning of experiment, but the controls survived to 58.5 weeks.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Muliple small metastases in the lungs and mediastinum were found in 42.8% of mice, which signifies a high degree of malignancy.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>o-Cresol at 0.02 mg did not modify carcinogenesis in comparison to the control.</Species>
<Species>o-Cresol administration before or after BaP did not modify tumor incidence or the multiplicity index as compared to control, but the latency period was longer (Table 2).</Species>
<Species>When o-cresol was administered after BaP (stage 2), there was an absence of malignant tumors.</Species>
<Species>Besides the quantitative aspects, other peculiarities of carcinogenesis in mice simultaneously administered BaP and o-cresol should be noted.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The combined chemical administration resulted in diffuse verrucosa vegetations over the forestomach surface, especially near the greater curvature.</Species>
<Species>Highly aggressive malignant neoplasms developed earlier with more metastases as compared to control.</Species>
<Species>Many mice were emaciated, and the tumors could be Table 1.</Species>

<Species>342 CARCINOGENESIS OF BaP AND o-CRESOL 343 palpated through the abdominal wall.</Species>
<Species>At autopsy, enlargement of the stomach with tuberculous white superficial vegetations were observed.</Species>
<Species>The forestomach and glandular part of the stomach was often obliterated by tumor masses.</Species>
<Species>The stomach was often adhered to the pancreas, liver, and mesentery.</Species>
<Species>Hemmorrhage and inflammation were found in tumors foci.</Species>
<Species>When o-cresol was introduced before BaP, the tumors were more frequently found closer to the small curvature of the stomach between the forestomach and esophageal entrance.</Species>
<Species>Over the large curvature less prominent mucosal folds were observed.</Species>
<Species>Microscopically, a decrease in mucosa papillae, epithelial atrophy (one to two cullular layers), decreased keratonization, and nuclear pycnosis were observed.</Species>

<Species>With the simultaneous administration of large doses of o-cresol and BaP, the final carcinogenic effect (30 weeks after the first dose) was similar to BaP alone but differences were observed at the earlier stages (after the 1st, 3rd, 5th, and 10th exposures).</Species>
<Species>In the BaP control, multiple forestomach epithelial proliferative and hyperplastic changes were found after the third dose.</Species>
<Species>Multiple papillomas occurred (9-15 in each mouse).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The stomach's mucosal folds appeared thickened diffusely, then papillomas appeared and finally merged together.</Species>
<Species>Approximately half of the tumors were malignant.</Species>
<Species>The neoplasms filled almost the whole forestomach cavity and infiltrated the wall with tuberculous vegetations, which were visible on the serosal surface.</Species>
<Species>Thmor infiltration in the liver, pancreas, and wide dissemination of peritoneum were also observed.</Species>
<Species>In mice simultaneously administered BaP and o-cresol, the proliferative alterations of forestomach epithelium were seen after the third dose.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>However, they occurred as the single foci at damaged mucosa and even in the later stages were not diffuse.</Species>
<Species>Adjacent to the hyperplastic foci, the mucosa was atrophied with decreased keratonization.</Species>
<Species>The epithelial cells also showed cytoplasm coagulation and nuclear pycnosis.</Species>
<Species>Edema, inflammation of the mucosa, submucosa microabscesses, and erosion were seen.</Species>
<Species>There were fewer papillomas per mouse (four to eight in each mouse) than in the control group.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Even in the late stages the papillomas were isolated and elevated on the atrophied mucosal folds.</Species>
<Species>In the final experiment the papillomas prevailed as compared to the previous experiments.</Species>
<Species>Only 4 out of 29 mice (13.8%) developed malignant tumors.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Neoplasms were smaller and appeared as single verrucosa vegetations 5-10 mm in diameter.</Species>
<Species>Thus, the toxic dose of o-cresol inhibits the carcinogenic process of induced forestomach tumors by decreasing multiplicity, frequency, and percentage of malignant tumors.</Species>
<Species>Discussion Our results and the literature suggest a hypothesis on modifying carcinogenesis mechanisms.</Species>

<Species>The primary effect of the toxic agents, including carcinogenic agents, may relate to cellular membrane damage with the subsequent increased permeability (31-35), which may be the mechanism of the o-cresol.</Species>
<Species>With simultaneous introduction of o-cresol at low toxic doses and BaP there may be increased carcinogen penetration to the target cells.</Species>
<Species>In addition, membrane damage may alter other cellular systems responsible for energy and xenobiotic detoxication.</Species>
<Species>Damage of these processes may activate free-radical reactions, glycolysis, or alter carcinogenic metabolism, which promotes the oncogenic effect.</Species>

<Species>The o-cresol effect on these systems was confirmed by our previous investigations on cytochrome P450, ferrosulfuric nonhemic proteins, and semiquinon radical content affected by the combined action of BaP and o-cresol (36).</Species>
<Species>Another effect was obtained with BaP exposure after o-cresol.</Species>

<Species>The atrophic alterations in the stomach induced by 2.5 months of o-cresol administration might decrease the natural conditions of retention (muscosal folds, frontier torn), and thus shorten the contact of BaP with the forestomach.</Species>
<Species>In our opinion, this explains the decreased carcinogenic effect seen after o-cresol exposure.</Species>

<Species>Considering the toxic effect of o-cresol at low toxic doses (1 mg) after BaP and the effect of a super toxic dose (10 mg) simultaneously with BaP administration, it is possible that the inhibition of carcinogenesis in both trials was related to the toxic effects of o-cresol.</Species>
<Species>Cytotoxicity may not only hamper tumor growth, but also promote the regression of inducible and spontaneous neoplasms (37-39).</Species>
<Species>There is also a possibility that BaP damages metabolic systems and decreases resistance to carcinogenesis.</Species>
<Species>Conclusions The data obtained demonstrate that simultaneous administration of BaP modifies the induced carcinogenesis depending on the dose and the sequence of administration.</Species>

<Species>Administered with BaP (1 mg), a low toxic o-cresol dose (about minimally effective) produces an enhanced cocarcinogenic effect reflected in the incidence, frequency, multiplicity, and degree of malignancy of forestomach tumors.</Species>

<Species>o-Cresol administration at low toxic doses before or after BaP at the same dose level (1 mg) and its administration at super toxic doses (10 mg) with the BaP optimal dose (5 mg) may inhibit carcinogenesis.</Species>
<Species>Simultaneous introduction of a noneffective o-cresol dose (0.02 mg) with the BaP (1 mg) does not change its carcinogenic activity.</Species>
<Species>Controlling both chemicals in the environment is the most effective measure of preventing potential risk and is undoubtedly of paramount significance.</Species>

text: <Species>Abstract A patient required mitral valve replacement following ineffective antibiotic treatment of enterococcal endocarditis caused by Streptococcus faecium.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Endocarditis had relapsed despite therapy with ampicillin and tobramycin for six weeks.</Species>
<Species>A second relapse had occurred following treatment with penicillin and gentamicin.</Species>
<Species>Initial failure of antibiotic therapy may be related to the known lack of in vitro and in vivo synergy between penicillin and tobramycin against S. faecium.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Effective therapy of enterococcal endocarditis requires considerations of bacterial speciation, determination of high-level aminoglycoside resistance, and preferably adequate antibiotic synergy studies to assure effective therapy.</Species>

text: <Species>Effective therapy of enterococcal endocarditis requires considerations of bacterial speciation, determination of high-level aminoglycoside resistance, and preferably adequate antibiotic synergy studies to assure effective therapy.</Species>
<Species>INTRODUCTION</Species>

<Species>Enterococcal endocarditis requires special therapeutic considerations because the responsible organisms are relatively penicillin-resistant streptococci which require synergistic combinations of antibiotics to achieve acceptable cure rates [1,2].</Species>
<Species>The group D enterococci include three main species S. faecalis, S. faecium, and S. durans.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>S. faecium cause a minority of all cases of enterococcal endocarditis, in those instances in which enterococci have been speciated [3], but they have been more resistant both to penicillin and penicillin-aminoglycoside combinations than S. faecalis</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>[4,5,6].</Species>

<Species>We describe a 64-year-old man with S. faecium endocarditis in whom a six-week course of ampicillin and tobramycin, followed by additional courses of penicillin and other aminoglycosides, failed to eradicate the organism from the patient's mitral valve.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>This case is of interest because therapeutic failure of ampicillin and tobramycin in S. faecium endocarditis has not been reported previously, but might have been predicted on the basis of previous in vitro and in vivo studies [6].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Although the need for both a penicillin derivative and an aminoglycoside in the therapy of enterococcal endocarditis is widely known, it is important to distinguish between the differing efficacies of penicillin-aminoglycoside combinations for treating various species of enterococci such as S. faecium.</Species>
label: Species

<Species>CASE REPORT</Species>
<Species>A 64-year-old male was in good health until December 1980, when he noted intermittent night sweats, malaise, fever, and fatigue.</Species>
<Species>He received oral erythromycin for 14 days with transient improvement of symptoms.</Species>
<Species>However, after completing therapy, symptoms reappeared and he noted a 15-pound weight loss with low-grade fever (99-100.5?F) during the two months preceding admission.</Species>
<Species>There was no previous history of rheumatic or congenital heart disease.</Species>
<Species>In March 1981, the patient was admitted to his community hospital where evaluation revealed a new apical systolic murmur radiating to the axilla.</Species>
<Species>There were no petechiae, Janeway lesions, Osler's nodes, Roth spots, or splenomegaly.</Species>

<Species>The hematocrit was 34.8 percent, WBC count 9,300 cells per cu mm with a differential count of 67 segmented forms, 9 bands, 15 lymphocytes, 7 monocytes, 1 eosinophil, and 1 basophil.</Species>
<Species>The erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) was 62 mm per hour (nl < 10 mm per hour) and the serum rheumatoid factor titer was 1:320.</Species>
<Species>Chest films and electrocardiogram were reportedly normal.</Species>
<Species>Group D streptococci grew from three sets of blood cultures.</Species>
<Species>Enterococcal endocarditis was diagnosed and he was treated with six weeks of parenteral ampicillin (12 grams per day) and tobramycin (3 mg per kg per day).</Species>
<Species>Resolution of symptoms occurred within several days after antibiotics were begun.</Species>

<Species>Serum bactericidal titers against the organism, obtained during peak antibiotic levels, were 1:8 or greater on several occasions, and blood cultures were negative while the patient was receiving antibiotics.</Species>
<Species>M-mode echocardiography demonstrated left atrial enlargement but no definable abnormalities of the mitral or aortic valves.</Species>
<Species>Intravenous pyelogram, oral cholecystogram, cystoscopy, liver-spleen scan, and upper and lower gastrointestinal series were normal except for a few sigmoid diverticuli.</Species>
<Species>Flexible signoidoscopy demonstrated both a small perianal fissure and hemorrhoids.</Species>
<Species>Blood cultures two weeks after therapy were negative.</Species>
<Species>Second Admission (June 19-August 4, 1981)</Species>
<Species>In June 1981, he again noted intermittent fever, night sweats, and fatigue.</Species>
<Species>Group D streptococci grew from three sets of blood cultures and he was admitted to the West Haven VA Medical Center for recurrent endocarditis.</Species>
<Species>On examination a somewhat louder apical systolic murmur was noted.</Species>
<Species>The ESR was 50 mm/hour and rheumatoid factor titer was 1:320.</Species>
<Species>Serum complement levels were normal and cryoglobulins were not detectable.</Species>
<Species>Chest films, EKG, and urinalysis were normal.</Species>
<Species>Cardiac M-mode echocardiogram revealed a globular mass attached to the posterior mitral valve leaflet with prolapse into a slightly enlarged left atrium.</Species>
<Species>A twodimensional echocardiogram confirmed mitral valve prolapse and suggested a posterior leaflet vegetation.</Species>
<Species>Gallium citrate scan was negative.</Species>
<Species>Three separate morphologic colony variants were isolated from blood, each identified as S. faecium by Dr. R.R. Facklam (Center for Disease Control, Atlanta, Georgia).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The patient received intravenous penicillin (20 million units per day) and gentamicin (3 mg per kg per day) for six weeks with improvement.</Species>
<Species>Peak serum bactericidal titers of 1:8 or greater were achieved against two of the colony variants; however, against the large colony morphotype, a titer of only 1:2 was obtained.</Species>
<Species>An enlarged left atrium with intermittent fluttering and prolapse of the mitral valve was noted on echocardiography three weeks into therapy.</Species>
<Species>Multiple blood cultures taken while the patient was receiving antibiotics were negative, as were those obtained 48 and 72 hours after discontinuation of antibiotics.</Species>
<Species>244 S. FAECIUM ENDOCARDITIS Third Admission (August 12-October 4, 1981)</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Withing a week following discharge, the patient again developed fever, nocturnal sweats, and malaise.</Species>
<Species>S. faecium (large colony morphotype, and poorly growing small colony morphotype) grew from six sets of blood cultures obtained on admission.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Penicillin (30 million units/day) and gentamicin (3 mg/kg/day) were again administered, initially achieving peak serum inhibitory and bactericidal dilutions of 1:16 and 1:8 against the organism, respectively.</Species>

<Species>However, the organism had a lowlevel resistance to streptomycin (MIC < 125 /Ag/ml), and streptomycin (2 grams per day) was substituted for gentamicin two weeks into antibiotic therapy.</Species>
<Species>Repeat echocardiograms showed irregular and shaggy densities of both mitral valve leaflets with partial prolapse.</Species>
<Species>Cardiac catheterization demonstrated marked mitral valve prolapse with mitral regurgitation.</Species>
<Species>A radiolucent filling defect was noted, suggesting a coronary artery embolus at the origin of the left anterior descending (LAD) artery, causing 75 percent occlusion of the lumen.</Species>
<Species>The patient underwent mitral valve replacement, receiving a number 31 porcine Hancock bioprosthesis and bypass graft to the midportion of the LAD.</Species>
<Species>The mitral valve was thickened with several ruptured chordae of the posterior leaflet noted, but no vegetations.</Species>
<Species>The aortic valve appeared normal, with no visible septal or ring abscesses.</Species>
<Species>The occlusion in the LAD was not approached to avoid embolizing distal fragments.</Species>
<Species>Histopathologically the mitral valve showed mild fibrosis and myxoid degeneration without inflammatory changes.</Species>
<Species>Bacterial and fungal stains were negative but S. faecium grew from fragments of the resected valve.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Following surgery the patient received six additional weeks parenteral penicillin and streptomycin.</Species>
<Species>Repeat blood cultures on this regimen and following therapy were negative.</Species>
<Species>Evaluation six months following discontinuation of antibiotics showed no evidence of recurrent endocarditis.</Species>
<Species>LABORATORY EVALUATION</Species>
