text: <Species>Remarkably, 					 shares with other FMDV clones and populations, notably, MARLS and C-S8p260p3d (the two viruses showing the highest virulence for BHK-21 cells; Figure 2A; Tables 1 and S1), three amino acid substitutions in 2C: S80N, T256A, and Q263H.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In addition, MARLS and CS8p260p3d include replacement M283V in 2C, relative to C-S8c1 [27,28].</Species>

<Species>To test whether any (or a combination) of the three shared amino acid substitutions in 2C contributed to the increased virulence of FMDV, each of the mutations was introduced individually into plasmid pMT28 by site-directed mutagenesis, as described in Materials and Methods.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Transcripts of the three mutants, termed pMT28 (SN), pMT28 (TA), and pMT28 (QH) (Figure 4), were used to transfect BHK-21 cells, and the viruses obtained were tested with the BHK-21 cell killing assay.</Species>
<Species>Viruses having any of the substitutions in 2C have a virulence intermediate between that of C-S8c1 and 					 (Figure 6A).</Species>

<Species>To test whether the combination of the three substitutions in 2C could produce an additional increase of virulence, the three mutations were introduced in pMT28 to rescue the triple mutant pMT28 (SN, TA, QH) (Figure 4).</Species>
<Species>The results (Figure 6B) show that the virulence of the triple 2C mutant is similar to the virulence of the individual 2C mutants.</Species>
<Species>The 2C mutations did not significantly affect the infectious progeny production (Table 2).</Species>

<Species>A testable prediction of this result is that the introduction of the wild-type 2C-3A-coding region in the genetic background of 					 should produce a virus with lower virulence than 					.</Species>

<Species>Indeed, the results with such a chimeric virus (Figure 5D) indicate that the presence of the 2C- and 3A-coding region as the only genetic region of the pMT28 in the genetic background of 					 resulted in an FMDV with a 2.4- to 4.8-fold lower virulence than 					.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We conclude that mutations in 2C contribute to virulence of FMDV for BHK-21 cells. 				 </Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Thus, a virus that evolves towards low fitness levels due to the operation of Muller's ratchet may nevertheless maintain its capacity to kill the same cells in which it displays low fitness.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In FMDV, the enhanced capacity to kill BHK-21 cells was multigenic, including participation of non-structural protein 2C with three amino acid substitutions acting in a redundant fashion.</Species>

<Species>In conclusion, the results provide a molecular interpretation of why fitness and virulence of an animal virus can follow disparate evolutionary trajectories, culminating in two unrelated traits.</Species>
<Species>Discussion</Species>

<Species>The capacity of a virus to kill cells is probably influenced by several steps in the virus life cycle, including receptor affinity (which may trigger signalling pathways and alter cell functions) and intracellular viral replication that may lead to metabolic alterations such as transcriptional or translational shut-off [29].</Species>

<Species>A parallel increase of virulence and fitness as a virus improves its adaptation to a host cell type is expected, since a key parameter that should contribute to the fitness level of a cytophatic virus is the accumulation of infectious particles and its release from cells, which are events often associated with cell killing.</Species>

<Species>This expectation was fulfilled in our experiments (increase of both fitness and cell killing following large population passages of C-S8c1 [Figure 2]), and also in other virus-host systems.</Species>

<Species>In a comparison of two genetically divergent isolates of the whispovirus white spot syndrome virus, whose virulence for the shrimp host Penaeus monodon was measured by in vivo cumulative mortality rates, virulence correlated with competitive fitness in vivo [30].</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The onset of type 1 diabetes by coxsackievirus B strains was linked to the viral replication rate and to the infectious dose [31].</Species>
<Species>In engineered alphavirus replicons, a direct correlation between the level of RNA replication and cytopathogenicity was observed [32].</Species>

<Species>At an epidemiological level, a greater replicative fitness of historical versus current human immunodeficiency virus type 1 (HIV-1) isolates was taken as evidence of HIV-1 attenuation over time, assuming a direct connection between fitness and virulence [33].</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>In vivo, viral fitness may vary among specific organs, and virulence may be affected only when fitness for some specific target tissues is affected</Species>
<Species>[34].</Species>
<Species>Replicative fitness is, however, but one of several factors which influence the progression of a viral infection in vivo.</Species>
<Species>In a comparative analysis, R5-tropic and X4-tropic clones of HIV-1 showed similar replication capacity in mitogen-activated T cells.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>However, X4 clones were transferred more efficiently than R5 clones from dendritic cells to CD4(+)</Species>
<Species>T cells, a fact that can contribute to the competitive advantage of X4 viruses in AIDS patients [35].</Species>
label: Species

Species

text: <Species>[36].</Species>
<Species>Deviations of a positive correlation between viral fitness and virulence were observed also in the plant viruses cucumber mosaic virus</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>[37] and barley stripe mosaic virus</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>[38].</Species>
<Species>A study of the effect of lysis timing on bacteriophage fitness revealed that a strain with an intermediate lysis time had the highest fitness [39].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The time of transmission may also affect virulence.</Species>

<Species>Nuclear polyhedrosis virus transmitted early to its host, the moth Lymantria dispar, was more virulent than virus transmitted late, although the latter was more productive because the virus could use more host tissue for replication [40].</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>In a study of the susceptibility of North American and non-North American breeds of Lymantria to several isolates of the fungus Entomaphaga maimaiga, mortality was scored in all cases.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>However, virulence of the fungus, quantitated by the time of death of Lymantria, was, in some cases, inversely proportional to fitness, quantitated by fungal reproduction in the moth [41].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In all these cases, the molecular basis of the lack of positive correlation between fitness and virulence is not understood.</Species>

<Species>Model for a Lack of Correlation between Viral Fitness and Virulence The results with FMDV clones H5 have documented that both fitness-enhancing and virulence-enhancing mutations can be incorporated in the viral genome in such a fashion that subsequent fitness-decreasing mutations associated with bottleneck (plaque-to-plaque) transfers produce only minimal effects on virulence (Figure 2).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The dissection of accompanying molecular events, achieved through quantification of virulence of recombinant and mutant genomes (Tables 2 and S1), provides an interpretation of the lack of positive correlation between virulence and fitness.</Species>
<Species>Multiple fitness-decreasing mutations occur in the course of plaque-to-plaque transfers, distributed throughout the FMDV genome [11].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In contrast, determinants of virulence for BHK-21 cells are multigenic, but concentrated mainly in some FMDV genomic regions.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Similar multigenic but discrete virulence determinants have been described also in other virus-host systems [42,43].</Species>

<Species>To decrease virulence, mutations occurring randomly in the course of plaque-to-plaque transfers should affect specific genomic sites, and this will occur with a lower probability than fitness-decreasing mutations, which can hit any of the multifunctional picornaviral proteins and regulatory regions [11].</Species>

<Species>This model is reinforced by the observation that three amino acid substitutions in 2C (S80N, T256A, and Q263H) had a similar effect in enhancing FMDV virulence, and the three mutations in the same genome had an effect comparable to each mutation individually (Figure 6; Tables 2 and S1).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>It is not clear what the basis of the contribution of 2C to virulence for BHK-21 could be.</Species>
<Species>2C is involved in RNA synthesis and contains a nucleotide-binding domain, although none of the substitutions found in 					 and 					 lie within such a domain.</Species>

<Species>An unlikely triple reversion would be required to eliminate the virulence-enhancing effect of the three mutations in 2C. We propose that a higher robustness of the FMDV genome with regard to virulence for BHK-21 cells, rather than to replicative fitness in the same cells, underlies the different trajectories followed by fitness and virulence upon subjecting the virus to repeated bottleneck transfers.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Obviously, we cannot exclude that parameters of the virus life cycle, other than fitness as measured in our experiments, could correlate with virulence for BHK-21. 				 </Species>

<Species>The comparative analysis of FMDV clones and populations shows that shifts in virulence can occur even through the evolution of a single viral clone (C-S8c1), with its restricted genetic diversity prompted by different replication regimes in the same host cells, which also have a clonal origin (see Materials and Methods).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We conjecture that the demonstration that fitness and virulence can follow different evolutionary courses has been possible thanks to the consequences of the extreme passage regimes to which the viral populations were subjected: competitive evolution of an ample mutant spectra during repeated large population passages, and accumulation of deleterious (with regard to fitness, but not with regard to virulence) mutations upon plaque-to-plaque transfers (predominance of genetic drift and operation of Muller's ratchet)</Species>
<Species>[12,15].</Species>
<Species>Implications for Models of Virulence It must be emphasized that fitness and virulence are relative values that pertain to a defined physical and biological environment.</Species>
<Species>Virulence determinants of FMDV, identified here for BHK-21 cells, need not apply to virulence for the natural animal hosts of FMDV [44].</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>However, the observation of a lack of correlation between fitness and virulence in a FMDV clone is relevant to current models of attenuation and virulence, since it shows that more virulent forms of a virus need not have a reproductive advantage, and that viral virulence is not necessarily a byproduct of viral fitness.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Even if virulence is regarded as an unavoidable consequence of parasite adaptation [45], virus de-adaptation (fitness loss) need not entail a decrease of virulence.</Species>

<Species>Most current definitions of virulence include both the ability of the pathogen to multiply and to cause harm to its host; some authors, however, assume a direct relationship between fitness and capacity to produce disease [46-48].</Species>

<Species>In relating the results with FMDV to general models of virulence in host-parasite systems, it must be considered that in the FMDV system, evolution of the host BHK-21 cells could not influence FMDV evolution, because clonal cell populations with a controlled passage history were supplied in constant numbers at each infection event (see Materials and Methods).</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Therefore, changes in host density, or mobility, as well as pathogen survival in the external environment, all of which are relevant parameters in virulence models [48,49], cannot play a role in our system.</Species>
<Species>A consistent finding in serial passage experiments is that virulence of a parasite increases with passage number in a new host [50].</Species>
<Species>The results with FMDV infecting BHK-21 cells cytolytically imply that the increase of virulence can be conditioned to the history of passage regimes undergone by a virus.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The invariance of BHK-21 cells in the course of serial cytolytic passages of FMDV is in contrast with the parallel system consisting of BHK-21 cells persistently infected with FMDV C-S8c1 [25], in which the cells are passaged and coevolve with the resident virus [51].</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Host-virus coevolution has generally favored a decrease of viral virulence in the field, a classical example being myxoma virus and myxomatosis in rabbits [52].</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Our comparison of FMDV clones did not provide evidence of clones with high fitness and low virulence, which, with regard to natural hosts, is an aim of biomedicine to obtain vaccine strains.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Yet, the existence of specific mutations that differentially affect fitness and virulence opens the way to engineer candidate vaccine strains unable to kill the host, while maintaining replicative competence.</Species>
<Species>Virulence is, however, a feature of the host-parasite relationship [46], and the mutations needed to impair virulence are expected to be host-dependent</Species>
<Species>[53,54].</Species>
<Species>Materials and Methods Cells, viruses, and infections.</Species>

<Species>The BHK-21 cells used in the present study were cloned by end-point dilution, followed by preparation of a cell stock from a single cell; they were passaged a maximum of 30 times before being used for FMDV infection [25,51].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Procedures for cell growth, infection of BHK-21 cell monolayers with FMDV in liquid medium, and plaque assays in semi-solid agar medium were carried out as previously described [11,19,25,27].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Mock-infected cells were handled in parallel in all infectivity and plaque assays to monitor absence of viral contamination.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The FMDVs used in the present study (Figure 1) are (i) the reference clone C-S8c1, which has been assigned a relative fitness of 1.0</Species>
<Species>[11].</Species>
<Species>(ii) MARLS, a monoclonal antibody escape mutant isolated from population C-S8c1p213 [55]; MARLS has a fitness of 25 relative to C-S8c1 [24].</Species>
<Species>(iii) C-S8p260p3d, a standard FMDV virus rescued by low MOI passage of C-S8p260.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The latter is a virus that evolved by passage of C-S8c1 at a high MOI, which resulted in dominance of two defective FMDV genomes (both including internal deletions) that were infectious by complementation, in the absence of standard virus [22,24,28]; C-S8p260p3d has a relative fitness of 20 [24].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>(iv) REDpt60, obtained after 60 successive plaque-to-plaque transfers of RED (a monoclonal antibody escape mutant isolated from population C-S8c1p100)</Species>
<Species>[20]; REDpt60 has a fitness of 1.9 relative to C-S8c1.</Species>
<Species>(v) C-S8c1p113, a viral population obtained after 113 serial cytolytic passages of C-S8c1 at a high MOI in BHK-21 cells (2 x 106</Species>
<Species>BHK-21 cells infected with the virus contained in 200 ul of the supernatant from the previous infection).</Species>
<Species>(vi) Clone 					, a biological clone isolated from population C-S8c1p113</Species>
<Species>[11]; its relative fitness is 26 (unpublished data).</Species>
<Species>(vii) Clone 					, obtained after 95 successive plaque-to-plaque transfers of 					 [11]; its relative fitness is 0.11</Species>
<Species>[23]. 				 </Species>
<Species>Cell killing assay.</Species>
<Species>The capacity of FMDV to kill BHK-21 cells was measured as previously described [18,22].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The assay consists in determining the minimum number of PFU required to kill 104 BHK-21 cells after variable times of infection.</Species>
<Species>The assay was performed in M96 multiwell plates with monolayers of 104 BHK-21 cells per well infected with serial dilutions of virus.</Species>
<Species>At different times postinfection, cells were fixed with 2% formaldehyde and stained with 2% crystal violet in 2% formaldehyde.</Species>

<Species>Results are expressed as the logarithm of the number of PFUs needed for complete cell killing (as judged by cell staining with crystal violet, with series of control wells with known numbers of cells) as a function of time postinfection [18,22].</Species>
<Species>Determination of relative fitness of 					. 				 </Species>
<Species>The relative fitness of FMDV 					 was determined by growth competition in BHK-21 cells as previously described [7,10,11,24,56].</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>FMDV 					 was mixed with appropriate proportions of 					, which was used as reference virus.</Species>
<Species>This virus has a fitness 8.5-fold higher than that of the reference clone of C-S8c1 in BHK-21 cells [7,10,11,24,56].</Species>
<Species>Four serial infections were carried out at MOI of 0.1 PFU/cell.</Species>

<Species>The proportion of the two competing genomes at different passages was determined by real-time reverse transcription (RT)-PCR, employing primers 5531wtnew and 					, which are able to discriminate FMDV 					 RNA from 					 RNA.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The nucleotide sequences of the primers will be provided upon request.</Species>
<Species>The fitness vector obtained for 					 corresponded to the equation y = 0,0206e1,1074x; R2 = 0.9507.</Species>
<Species>The antilogarithm (base e) of the vector slope is the fitness of the assayed virus relative to the reference virus [56]. 				 </Species>
<Species>cDNA synthesis, molecular cloning, and nucleotide sequencing.</Species>
<Species>Viral RNA was extracted by treatment with Trizol as previously described [57].</Species>

<Species>Reverse transcription of FMDV RNA was carried out with avian myeloblastosis virus reverse transcriptase (Promega, http://www.promega.com) or Transcriptor reverse transcriptase (Roche, http://www.roche.com), and PCR amplification was performed by using either Ampli-Taq polymerase (PerkinElmer, http://las.perkinelmer.com) or an Expand High Fidelity polymerase system (Roche), as instructed by the manufacturers.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>The FMDV genome-specific oligonucleotide primers used have been previously described [22,58].</Species>
<Species>In all RT-PCR amplifications, negative amplification controls, including all reaction components except template RNA, were run in parallel to monitor absence of contamination.</Species>

<Species>Chimeric viruses containing selected regions of 					 in the genetic background of C-S8c1 (Figure 4) were obtained by replacing the corresponding DNA fragment of pMT28 by a cDNA copy of 					 RNA, using specific restriction sites.</Species>

<Species>To obtain pMT28/ 					 (436-2046), a chimera that included nucleotides 436 to 2046 of 					 (the residue numbering of the FMDV genome is as in [11]), 					 RNA was amplified by RT-PCR using primers NR2 and JH2, and the cDNA was digested with Hpa I (position 436) and Xba I (2046), and ligated into pMT28 DNA digested with the same enzymes.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>To obtain pMT28/ 					 (2046-3760), 					 RNA was amplified by RT-PCR using primers 2R1New and pU, and then the cDNA was digested with Xba I (2046) and Avr II (3760).</Species>
<Species>To obtain pMT28/ 					 (3760-5839), 					 RNA was amplified by RT-PCR using primers 3R2New and 3CD1, and then the cDNA was digested with Avr II (3760) and Rsr II (5839).</Species>
<Species>To obtain pMT28/ 					 (5839-7427), 					 RNA was amplified by RT-PCR using primers 5531 wt new and C-Not-Pol, and then the cDNA was digested with Rsr II (5839) and Bam HI (7427).</Species>

<Species>To obtain pMT28/ 					 (436-3760), 					 RNA was amplified by RT-PCR using primers NR2 and JH2, and then the cDNA was digested with Hpa I (position 436) and Xba I (2046), and ligated into pMT28/ 					 (2046-3760) DNA digested with the same enzymes.</Species>

<Species>To obtain pMT28/ 					 (3760-7427), 					 RNA was amplified by RT-PCR using primers 3R2New and 3CD1, and then the cDNA was digested with Avr II (3760) and Rsr II (5839), and ligated into pMT28/ 					 (5839-7427) DNA digested with the same enzymes.</Species>

<Species>To obtain pMT28/ 					 (2046-7427), 					 RNA was amplified by RT-PCR using primers 2R1New and pU, and then the cDNA was digested with Xba I (2046) and Avr II (3760), and ligated into pMT28/ 					 (3760-7427) DNA digested with the same enzymes.</Species>

<Species>To obtain pMT28/ 					 (436-7427), 					 RNA was amplified by RT-PCR using primers NR2 and JH2; the cDNA was digested with Hpa I (position 436) and Xba I (2046), and ligated into pMT28/ 					 (2046-7427) DNA digested with the same enzymes.</Species>

<Species>To obtain 					/2C-3A(pMT28), pMT28 was digested with Bgl II (4201) and Rsr II (5839), and a DNA fragment including wild-type 2C-3A-coding region was inserted into pMT28/ 					 (436-7427) DNA digested with the same enzymes.</Species>

<Species>DNA ligation, transformation of Escherichia coli DH5a, isolation of DNA from bacterial colonies, and characterization of DNA by restriction enzyme digestion were performed by standard procedures [59].</Species>

text: <Species>The primers used for molecular cloning and site-directed mutagenesis are described in Table S3. 				 </Species>

<Species>To obtain FMDV C-S8c1 containing the mutations found in gene 2C of 					, plasmid pMT28 was subjected to site-directed mutagenesis using an oligonucleotide including the required nucleotide replacement, and 3R2New or 3CD1 as external oligonucleotide primer (Table S3; Figure 4).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>A DNA fragment termed A was obtained by subjecting plasmid pMT28 to site-directed mutagenesis using primers (reverse) mutSNu, mutTAu, and mutQHu (to introduce mutations S80N, T256A, and Q263H, respectively) and an external oligonucleotide primer (3R2New, forward).</Species>

<Species>A DNA fragment termed B was obtained amplifying pMT28 with primers (forward) mutSNd, mutTAd, and mutQHd (to introduce mutations S80N, T256A, and Q263H, respectively) and an external oligonucleotide primer (3CD1, reverse).</Species>
<Species>DNA fragments A and B, including the desired mutations, were recombined by shuffling PCR using equimolar amounts of DNA fragments and two external primers (3R2New and 3CD1).</Species>

<Species>The DNA with the desired mutation(s) in the 2C gene was digested with Avr II (genomic position 3760) and Rsr II (position 5839), and cloned into pMT28 to generate pMT28 (SN), pMT28 (TA), and pMT28 (QH).</Species>

<Species>To obtain pMT28 (SN, TA, QH), plasmid pMT28 (SN) was subjected to site-directed mutagenesis to introduce mutation T256A in a similar way as described above, and then, plasmid pMT28 (SN, TA) was subjected to site-directed mutagenesis to introduce mutation Q263H. All chimeric viruses and mutants were analyzed by nucleotide sequencing using Big Dye Terminator Cycle Sequencing kit (Abi Prism; PerkinElmer) and sequencer ABI373 as previously described [58].</Species>
<Species>Sequences were analyzed using DNASTAR 4.0 (http://www.dnastar.com), GeneDoc, and GCC (University of Wisconsin).</Species>
<Species>Each sequence was determined at least twice, with products obtained using different oligonucleotide primers. 				 </Species>
<Species>DNA from pMT28 or its recombinant and mutant derivatives was linearized with Nde I and transcribed with SP6 RNA polymerase as previously described [22,27].</Species>
<Species>Transcript RNA integrity and concentration were estimated by agarose gel electrophoresis, in parallel runs with known amounts of standard C-S8c1 RNA.</Species>
<Species>BHK-21 cell monolayers (70% confluent, about 1 x 106 cells) were transfected with RNA transcripts (1 ug RNA) using lipofectin as previously described [59].</Species>
<Species>Virus was collected from the culture supernatant at 72 h post-transfection.</Species>
<Species>The virus obtained by transfection was passaged twice before using it in biological studies.</Species>
<Species>RNA was extracted and sequenced to ascertain that the virus maintained the genomic structure and mutations of the initial transcript.</Species>
<Species>Consensus genomic nucleotide sequences of FMDV clones were obtained by RT-PCR amplification of virion RNA using specific primers [7,22,28].</Species>

<Species>Identification of a human peripheral blood monocyte subset that differentiates into osteoclasts</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Abstract Increased bone resorption mediated by osteoclasts causes various diseases such as osteoporosis and bone erosion in rheumatoid arthritis (RA).</Species>
<Species>Osteoclasts are derived from the monocyte/macrophage lineage, but the precise origin remains unclear.</Species>

<Species>In the present study, we show that the purified CD16- human peripheral blood monocyte subset, but not the CD16+ monocyte subset, differentiates into osteoclast by stimulation with receptor activator of NF-kB ligand (RANKL) in combination with macrophage colony-stimulating factor (M-CSF).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Integrin-b3 mRNA and the integrin-avb3 heterodimer were only expressed on CD16- monocytes, when they were stimulated with RANKL + M-CSF.</Species>
<Species>Downregulation of b3-subunit expression by small interfering RNA targeting b3 abrogated osteoclastogenesis from the CD16- monocyte subset.</Species>
<Species>In contrast, the CD16+ monocyte subset expressed larger amounts of tumor necrosis factor alpha and IL-6 than the CD16- subset, which was further enhanced by RANKL stimulation.</Species>
<Species>Examination of RA synovial tissue showed accumulation of both CD16+</Species>
<Species>and CD16- macrophages.</Species>
<Species>Our results suggest that peripheral blood monocytes consist of two functionally heterogeneous subsets with distinct responses to RANKL.</Species>
<Species>Osteoclasts seem to originate from CD16- monocytes, and integrin b3 is necessary for osteoclastogenesis.</Species>
<Species>Blockade of accumulation and activation of CD16- monocytes could therefore be a beneficial approach as an anti-bone resorptive therapy, especially for RA.</Species>
<Species>Introduction Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is an autoimmune disease characterized by chronic inflammation and proliferation of the synovium in multiple joints.</Species>

<Species>A large number of inflammatory cells, including T cells, B cells, macrophages and dendritic cells, accumulate in the affected synovium, and these inflammatory cells, together with fibroblast-like synoviocytes, express various cytokines, such as tumor necrosis factor alpha (TNFa), IL-6 and receptor activator of NF-kB ligand (RANKL), which are known to induce differentiation and activation of osteoclasts.</Species>
<Species>The inflammatory synovial tissue, known as pannus, invades the articular bone and causes focal bone erosion, which is the hallmark of RA.</Species>
<Species>Histopathologically, osteoclasts are present at the interface of the pannus and bone.</Species>
<Species>Interestingly, the deletion of RANKL or c-Fos gene, which is important for osteoclastogenesis, results in minimal bone destruction in mouse models of arthritis [1,2].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Furthermore, other studies indicated that inhibition of osteoclastogenesis by osteoprotegerin, a decoy receptor for RANKL, limits bone destruction in experimental models of arthritis.</Species>
<Species>These studies suggest that osteoclasts are involved in focal bone erosion in RA [3].</Species>
<Species>Osteoclasts are derived from the monocyte/macrophage lineage.</Species>
<Species>It is reported that osteoclast precursors reside in human peripheral blood monocytes [4,5].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>A marked increase of the circulating osteoclast precursors was demonstrated in patients with erosive psoriatic arthritis as well as in arthritic TNFa transgenic mice [6,7].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>It was also shown that peripheral monocytes differentiate into osteoclasts when seeded on RANKL/osteoclast differentiation factor-producing RA synovial fibroblasts [8].</Species>
<Species>In addition, RA synovial macrophages thought to originate from peripheral blood monocytes were shown to differentiate into osteoclasts [9,10].</Species>
<Species>Monocytes are therefore involved not only in synovial inflammation, but also in bone remodeling as potential precursors for synovial macrophages and osteoclasts.</Species>
<Species>Human peripheral blood monocytes consist of two major subsets, CD16+ and CD16-, comprising 5-10% and 90-95% of the monocytes, respectively.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>These two subsets exhibit different chemotaxis activities and potential of cytokine production [11,12].</Species>

<Species>Moreover, activation of the Toll-like receptor induces distinct subsets, CD1b+ dendritic cells and DC-SIGN+ (dendritic cell-specific C-type lectin ICAM-3-grabbing nonintegrin) macrophages from CD16+</Species>
<Species>and CD16- monocytes, respectively [13].</Species>
<Species>It has not been revealed, however, which monocyte subset develops into osteoclasts.</Species>

<Species>In the present study, we determined the human peripheral blood monocyte subset that differentiates into osteoclasts, and revealed that each subset exhibits a different response for osteoclastogenic stimuli.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Materials and methods Purification of peripheral blood monocytes Peripheral blood monocytes from healthy donors were collected using Ficoll-Conray (Imuuno-Biological Laboratories, Gunma, Japan) gradient centrifugation.</Species>
<Species>Negative selection of monocytes was performed using MACS microbeads (Miltenyi Biotec, Auburn, CA, USA) according to the protocol supplied by the manufacturer.</Species>
<Species>The purified monocytes were separated into two subsets, CD16+ and CD16- monocytes, using CD16 MicroBeads (Miltenyi Biotec).</Species>

<Species>Flow cytometry analysis using FITC-conjugated mouse anti-CD14 mAb (MY4; Bechman Coulter, Fullerton, CA, USA) and phycoerythin-conjugated mouse anti-CD16 mAb (3G8; BD Biosciences, San Jose, CA, USA) showed that the purities of the CD16+ and CD16- monocytes were more than 90% and 92%, respectively.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>For the other experiment, monocytes were purified using CD14 MicroBeads (Miltenyi Biotec), and then stained either with FITC-conjugated mouse anti-CD33 mAb (MY9; Bechman Coulter) or phycoerythin-conjugated mouse anti-CD16 mAb (3G8).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Cell sorting of the stained cells was performed using a FACS Vantage cytometer (BD Biosciences) or a MoFlo cell sorter (Dako, Glostrup, Denmark).</Species>

<Species>Osteoclast differentiation Purified CD16+ and CD16- monocytes (5 x 104 cells/well) were incubated in 96-well plates in aMEM (Sigma, St Louis, MO, USA) with heat-inactivated 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS) (Sigma) or with Ultra-Low IgG FBS (IgG < 5 ug/ml; Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA, USA), and where indicated with M-CSF + RANKL (Peprotech, Rocky Hill, NJ, USA).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>For the other experiments, varied numbers of CD16+ monocytes (1 x 103, 2.5 x 103, 5 x 103) were mixed with CD16- monocytes (5 x 104 cells/well), and were cultured in 96-well plates in aMEM with heat-inactivated 10% FBS.</Species>

<Species>The medium was replaced with fresh medium 3 days later, and after incubation for 7 days the cells were stained for tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) expression using a commercial kit (Hokudo, Sapporo, Japan).</Species>

<Species>The number of TRAP-positive multinucleated cells (MNC) in three randomly selected fields examined at 100x magnification or the total number of TRAP-positive MNC per well was counted under light microscopy.</Species>

<Species>Resorption assay Monocytes were seeded onto plates coated with calcium phosphate thin films (Biocoat Osteologic; BD Biosciences) and were incubated with RANKL (40 ng/ml) + M-CSF (25 ng/ml) for 7 days.</Species>
<Species>The cells were then lysed in bleach solution (6% NaOCl, 5.2% NaCl).</Species>
<Species>The resorption lacunae were examined under light microscopy.</Species>
<Species>Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay Purified monocytes were cultured in 96-well plates where indicated either with RANKL or M-CSF for 24 hours.</Species>
<Species>Concentrations of TNFa and IL-6 in the culture supernatant were measured with an ELISA kit (BioSourse International, Camarillo, CA, USA).</Species>

<Species>For experiments of matrix metalloproteinase (MMP)-9 and TRAP-5b, culture supernatants were collected on day 7 and the concentrations of these enzymes were measured using an MMP-9 ELISA kit (Amersham Biosciences, Piscataway, NJ, USA) or a TRAP-5b ELISA kit (Suomen, Turku, Finland).</Species>
<Species>Reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction Monocytes (1 x 106 cells/well) were cultured in six-well plates with M-CSF alone or with M-CSF + RANKL for 3 days.</Species>
<Species>Total RNA was extracted using RNeasy Micro (Qiagen, Valencia, CA, USA).</Species>
<Species>The RNA was then treated with DNase I (Qiagen).</Species>
<Species>The oligo(dT)-primed cDNA was synthesized using Superscript II reverse transcriptase (Invitrogen).</Species>
<Species>The amount of cDNA for amplification was adjusted by the amount of RNA measured by an optical density meter and also by b-actin or GAPDH PCR products.</Species>

<Species>One microliter of cDNA was amplified in a 50 ul final volume containing 25 pmol appropriate primer pair, 10 pmol each of the four deoxynucleotide triphosphates, and 5 units FastStart Taq DNA Polymerase (Roche, Manheim, Germany) in a thermal cycler (PTC-200; MJ GeneWorks, Waltham, MA, USA).</Species>
<Species>The PCR conditions were 25-40 cycles of denaturation (95oC for 30 s), annealing (60-62oC for 1 min) and extension (72oC for 1 min).</Species>
<Species>The sequences of the primers are presented in Table 1.</Species>
<Species>The PCR products were separated by electrophoresis through 2% agarose gel.</Species>
<Species>Western immunoblot analysis Purified monocytes were cultured for 3 days in the presence of 40 ng/ml M-CSF with or without 25 ng/ml RANKL.</Species>

<Species>Cells were lysed in RIPA Lysis buffer (upstate, Lake Placid, NY, USA) containing protease inhibitors (Roche) for 15 min at 4oC. A total of 20 ug protein was boiled in the presence of 6 x sodium dodecyl sulfate sample buffer, and was separated on 7.5% or 10% sodium dodecyl sulfate-polyacrylamide gel (ATTO, Tokyo, Japan).</Species>
<Species>Proteins were then electrotransferred to a polyvinylidene fluoride microporous membrane (Millipore, Billerica, MA, USA) in a semidry system.</Species>
<Species>Membranes were incubated in 10% skim milk prepared in phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) containing 0.1% Tween 20, and were subjected to immunoblotting.</Species>

CD16- monocytes (8 x 104 cells/well) were incubated in 96-well plates in optimem (Invitrogen).</Species>

<Species>Immunohistochemistry Synovial tissue samples were obtained during total knee joint replacement surgery from four RA patients.</Species>

<Species>Double immunofluorescent staining for CD68 and CD16 antigens was conducted on optimal cutting temperature-embedded sections of frozen synovial samples.</Species>

<Species>The samples were incubated in 5 ug/ml proteinase K (Roche), 50 mM ethylenediamine tetraacetic acid, 100 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.0, for 15 minutes at room temperature followed by a wash in PBS.</Species>

<Species>Results Induction of osteoclasts from CD16- peripheral blood monocytes To identify the monocyte subset that differentiates into osteoclasts, we examined osteoclast formation from CD16+ and CD16- human peripheral blood monocytes.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The monocyte subsets were purified using magnetic beads.</Species>
<Species>Incubation with M-CSF alone did not induce osteoclast formation from either subset (Figure 1a).</Species>

<Species>Culture with M-CSF + RANKL induced a significant number of TRAP-positive MNC from the CD16- subset, whereas only few CD16+ monocytes differentiated into TRAP-positive MNC (Figure 1a,b).</Species>
<Species>We then assessed the bone resorptive ability by culturing cells on calcium phosphate-coated plates with M-CSF + RANKL.</Species>
<Species>Resorption lacunae were detected only in the CD16- subset (Figure 1c), indicating the TRAP-positive CD16--derived MNC possessed the osteoclast phenotype.</Species>
<Species>Similar results were obtained using purified monocytes by FACS sorting (purities: CD16+, 96%; CD16-, 97%).</Species>
<Species>The number of TRAP-positive MNC induced were 36 + 3 cells/well and 348 + 13 cells/well from CD16+ and CD16- monocytes, respectively.</Species>

<Species>To exclude the possibility that the anti-CD16 antibody used for isolation of CD16+ monocytes inhibits osteoclast formation, we separated the two subsets, CD33low monocytes and CD33high monocytes, using anti-CD33 mAb and a fluorescent cell sorter, since it was reported that CD33low monocytes correspond to CD16+, and that CD33high correspond to CD16- monocytes [15].</Species>
<Species>On average, the CD33low population contained CD16- (10.2%)/CD16+ (89.8%) monocytes, and the CD33high population contained CD16- (86.3%)/CD16+ (13.7%) monocytes.</Species>

<Species>Culture with M-CSF + RANKL induced TRAP-positive MNC from CD33high monocytes, whereas no or few CD33low monocytes differentiated into TRAP-positive MNC (CD33low vs CD33high, 2 + 1 vs 192 + 71 cells/well; n = 3).</Species>
<Species>TRAP-5b and MMP-9 in the culture supernatants, both of which are known to be produced by osteoclasts, were measured by ELISA.</Species>
<Species>The concentrations of both enzymes were significantly higher in the culture supernatant of CD16- monocytes than in that of CD16+ monocytes (Figure 1d).</Species>
<Species>These results suggest that the CD16- peripheral blood monocyte subset, but not the CD16+ subset, differentiate into osteoclasts by incubation with RANKL + M-CSF.</Species>

<Species>CD16+ monocytes do not affect the osteoclastogenesis from CD16- monocytes To examine whether CD16+ monocytes affect osteoclastogenesis from CD16- monocytes, varied numbers of CD16+ monocytes were mixed with CD16- monocytes (5 x 104 cells/well), and were cultured for 7 days in the presence of M-CSF + RANKL.</Species>
<Species>The number of TRAP-positive MNC was not altered by the presence of CD16+ monocytes (Figure 2).</Species>
<Species>The results indicated that CD16+ monocytes did not hamper or enhance the osteoclastogenesis from CD16- monocytes.</Species>

<Species>Differences in cytokine production by RANKL-stimulated or M-CSF-stimulated CD16+ and CD16- monocytes To compare the biological response of CD16+ and CD16- subsets with either RANKL or M-CSF stimulation, we measured the amount of TNFa and IL-6 production after exposure of cells to various concentrations of RANKL or M-CSF with an ELISA.</Species>
<Species>Without RANKL the CD16+ subset produced a significant amount of TNFa and IL-6, whereas the CD16- subset produced undetectable levels (Figure 3a).</Species>
<Species>RANKL stimulation increased TNFa production from both subsets in a dose-dependent manner, although the CD16+ subset produced more TNFa than did the CD16- subset.</Species>
<Species>RANKL stimulation also enhanced IL-6 production from the CD16+ subset, but not from the CD16- subset.</Species>
<Species>M-CSF stimulation increased TNFa and IL-6 production from both subsets, although the CD16+ subset produced more than the CD16- subset (Figure 3b).</Species>
<Species>These results suggest that CD16+ monocytes also respond both to RANKL and M-CSF stimulation, although such stimulation does not result in differentiation into osteoclasts.</Species>
<Species>CD16+ monocytes were also noted to express higher amounts of inflammatory cytokines compared with CD16- monocytes with or without RANKL or M-CSF stimulation.</Species>

<Species>Comparison of expression levels of molecules involved in osteoclastogenesis between CD16+ and CD16- monocytes Diverse molecules are involved in RANKL/RANK and its costimulatory signal transduction pathways</Species>
<Species>[16].</Species>

<Species>The different response to RANKL + M-CSF stimulation between the CD16+ monocyte subset and the CD16- monocytes subset might be explained by the expression profiles of these molecules.</Species>

<Species>We therefore examined the mRNA levels of the following molecules: receptor activator of NF-kB (RANK), the receptor for RANKL; c-fms, the receptor for M-CSF; tumor necrosis factor receptor-associated factor 6 (TRAF-6), the adaptor protein for RANK; c-Fos and nuclear factor of activated T cells c1 (NFATc1), transcription factors that are essential for osteoclastogenesis; DNAX-activation protein 12 (DAP12) and Fc receptor g chain (FcRg), adaptor proteins known to deliver costimulatory signals in RANKL-induced osteoclastogenesis; signal regulatory protein b1 (SIRP-b1), triggering receptor expressed on myeloid cells 2 (TREM-2) and osteoclast-associated receptor (OSCAR), transmembrane receptors that associate with either DAP12 or FcRg; and av and b3, integrins known to be expressed as the avb3 heterodimer on osteoclasts.</Species>

<Species>The mRNA levels of RANK, c-fms, TRAF-6, DAP12 and SIRP-b1 under the baseline condition (no stimulation) varied between the donors; however, we did not find consistent differences in the mRNA levels of these molecules between the CD16+ monocyte subset and the CD16- monocyte subset among three to six donors (Figure 4a).</Species>
<Species>The mRNA levels of other molecules, apart from integrin b3, were similar between the two subsets under the no-stimulation condition.</Species>

<Species>Although the mRNA levels of RANK, c-fms, DAP12, FcRg, TREM-2 and OSCAR increased in response to M-CSF alone or M-CSF + RANKL in both subsets, the expression levels were not significantly different between the two subsets.</Species>
<Species>Expressions of TRAF-6, c-Fos and SIRP-b1 mRNA did not change following stimulation with M-CSF + RANKL.</Species>
<Species>Of note, the expression of NFATc1 mRNA was enhanced by M-CSF + RANKL treatment only in the CD16- subset.</Species>
<Species>Furthermore, expression of integrin av in both subsets was enhanced by M-CSF with or without RANKL; however, the expression level was greater in the CD16- subset.</Species>
<Species>It was noted that integrin-b3 mRNA was detected only in the CD16- subset and was increased by M-CSF + RANKL stimulation, but not by M-CSF alone.</Species>
<Species>The protein expression of RANK under the baseline condition was weakly detected in both subsets, and the levels were varied between donors by western immunoblotting.</Species>
<Species>The protein expression of c-fms was weakly detected in unstimulated CD16+ monocytes, but not in CD16- monocytes (Figure 4b).</Species>
<Species>Flow cytometry analysis of c-fms in fresh monocytes, however, showed that both subsets express the molecule on the cell surface (Figure 4c).</Species>

<Species>Expressions of both RANK and c-fms were upregulated by M-CSF alone and by M-CSF + RANKL, and we did not find consistent differences in the protein levels of these molecules between the two monocyte subsets.</Species>

<Species>The profiles of expression levels of molecules involved in RANKL/RANK and its costimulatory pathways are similar between the two subsets, except for NFATc1, integrin av and integrin b3.</Species>

<Species>We therefore assumed that the distinct induction of NFATc1, integrin av and integrin b3 in response to RANKL stimulation among the two monocyte subsets might explain the differences in their abilities to differentiate into osteoclasts.</Species>
<Species>RANKL stimulation induces avb3 expression on CD16- monocytes</Species>
<Species>The integrin-b3 subunit binds to integrin av only and is expressed as the heterodimeric protein avb3 on monocytes and osteoclasts [17].</Species>
<Species>We examined the expression of avb3 on CD16+</Species>
<Species>and CD16- monocytes by immunofluorescent staining.</Species>
<Species>Neither unstimulated nor M-CSF-stimulated monocyte subsets expressed avb3 (Figure 4d and data not shown).</Species>
<Species>After 48 and 72 hours of treatment with M-CSF + RANKL, avb3-positive mononuclear cells were observed in CD16- monocyte cultures but not in CD16+ monocyte cultures.</Species>
<Species>At 96 hours, both avb3-positive mononuclear cells and multinucleated cells were present in the CD16- monocyte culture.</Species>

<Species>The results indicated that avb3 was selectively expressed on CD16- monocytes in the presence of M-CSF + RANKL, and the expression was revealed before the cells differentiate into typical multinucleated osteoclasts.</Species>
<Species>RANKL activates ERK and p38 kinases only in CD16- monocytes Since ERK and p38 MAPK are essential in RANKL-induced osteoclastogenesis</Species>
<Species>[18-20], we next examined whether these kinases were activated differently in CD16+ monocytes and in CD16- monocytes.</Species>
<Species>Purified monocytes were precultured with 25 ng/ml M-CSF for 3 days to enhance RANK expression, and were then treated with RANKL.</Species>
<Species>The RANKL treatment induced phosphorylation of both ERK and p38 MAPK in CD16- monocytes at 5 minutes postexposure, although the p38 MAPK phosphorylation was weak.</Species>
<Species>Both phosphorylations declined to a basal level within 20 minutes (Figure 5).</Species>
<Species>In contrast, ERK and p38 MAPK were not detectably phosphorylated in CD16+ monocytes with RANKL.</Species>

<Species>siRNA targeting integrin b3 inhibits osteoclastogenesis from CD16- monocytes The integrin-b3 cytoplasmic domain is essential for activation of intracellular signals from avb3 heterodimers</Species>
<Species>[17].</Species>
<Species>We therefore examined the involvement of avb3 in RANKL + M-CSF-induced osteoclastogenesis in human CD16- monocytes using siRNA targeting the integrin-b3 subunit.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The integrin-b3 siRNA or control randomized siRNA were transfected into CD16- monocytes.</Species>
<Species>At 48 hours post-transfection, we determined the integrin-b3 mRNA level and avb3 heterodimer protein expression.</Species>
<Species>The integrin-b3 mRNA level was reduced in the integrin-b3 siRNA-transfected monocytes compared with control siRNA-transfected monocytes (Figure 6a).</Species>
<Species>The avb3 heterodimer expression was evaluated by immunofluorescent staining.</Species>
<Species>The number of avb3-positive cells was significantly decreased in integrin-b3 siRNA-transfected monocytes compared with that in control siRNA (Figure 6b).</Species>
<Species>After 7 days of incubation, the number of TRAP-positive MNC was counted.</Species>
<Species>Transfection with integrin-b3 siRNA significantly reduced the number of TRAP-positive MNC in a dose-dependent manner compared with control siRNA transfection (Figure 6c).</Species>
<Species>In addition, the use of siRNA directed toward a different site of integrin-b3 mRNA also inhibited osteoclast formation from CD16- monocytes (data not shown).</Species>
<Species>On the other hand, siRNA that targeted lamin, which was used as a negative control, did not inhibit the induction of osteoclasts (data not shown).</Species>
<Species>These results indicate the importance of integrin b3 in RANKL-induced osteoclast formation from CD16- peripheral blood monocytes.</Species>

<Species>Cyclic RGDfV peptide inhibits the osteoclastogenesis from CD16- monocytes Integrin avb3 recognizes a common tripeptide sequence, RGD (Arg-Gly-Asp), which is present in bone matrix proteins such as vitronectin and fibronectin [21].</Species>
<Species>Cyclic RGDfV peptide (Arg-Gly-Asp-D-Phe-Val) inhibits binding of the RGD-containing molecules to avb3 [22].</Species>
<Species>To investigate the role of ligand binding to the avb3 heterodimer in the osteoclastogenesis, we examined whether cyclic RGDfV peptide inhibits the formation of osteoclasts.</Species>
<Species>Cyclic RGDfV peptide significantly reduced the number of TRAP-positive MNC in a dose-dependent manner (Figure 6d).</Species>
<Species>The results imply possible involvement of ligand bindings to avb3 in the osteoclastogenesis.</Species>
<Species>Knockdown of integrin b3 did not affect the expression of NFATc1 mRNA</Species>

<Species>In the next step, we determined whether integrin-b3-siRNA-induced inhibition of the osteoclastogenesis reflects downregulation of NFATc1, which is a key transcription factor in osteoclastogenesis [23].</Species>
<Species>For this purpose, we compared NFATc1 mRNA levels between integrin b3 and control siRNA-transfected monocytes.</Species>

<Species>Interestingly, integrin-b3 knockdown did not alter the NFATc1 mRNA level (Figure 7), suggesting that signal transduction mediated by integrin b3 does not affect the expression of NFATc1. Detection of CD16+</Species>

<Species>and CD16- macrophages in synovium of RA patients RA synovial macrophages are derived from peripheral blood monocytes, and their recruitment into the synovium is facilitated by various adhesion molecules and chemokines [24].</Species>
<Species>To analyze CD16 expression on synovial macrophages, RA synovial tissues were double-stained for CD16 and a macrophage marker, CD68.</Species>
<Species>CD16-/CD68+ macrophages were widespread in the synovium.</Species>
<Species>Although less frequent, CD16+/CD68+ macrophages were also observed both in the synovial intima and subintima (Figure 8).</Species>
<Species>The presence of two subsets of macrophages, CD16+ and CD16-, in RA synovium indicates that both CD16+ and CD16- peripheral blood monocytes are recruited into the synovium.</Species>
<Species>Discussion Human peripheral blood monocytes are a heterogeneous population, and they are divided into two subsets based on the expression of CD16.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The CD16+ and CD16- monocyte subsets show functional differences in migration, cytokine production and differentiation into macrophages or dendritic cells [11-13,15].</Species>
<Species>We focused on the heterogeneity of the monocytes, and the primary question addressed in this study was which monocyte subset could be the source of osteoclasts.</Species>
<Species>The results demonstrated that CD16- peripheral blood monocytes, but not CD16+ monocytes, differentiated in vitro into osteoclasts by treatment with RANKL + M-CSF.</Species>

<Species>To investigate the molecular mechanisms of the different response to RANKL and the differentiation into osteoclasts between CD16+ and CD16- monocytes, we examined the expression of molecules known to be involved in osteoclastogenesis.</Species>
<Species>The expression profiles of integrin av, integrin b3 and NFATc1 were different between the two subsets.</Species>
<Species>Integrin avb3 heterodimer was expressed only on RANKL and M-CSF-stimulated CD16- monocytes.</Species>
<Species>It is known that avb3 expressed on osteoclasts is important in bone resorption as well as in attachment of osteoclasts to the bone matrix</Species>
<Species>[25].</Species>

<Species>It was recently reported that bone marrow macrophages of integrin-b3-deficient mice could not differentiate into mature osteoclasts in vitro, suggesting that avb3 is involved not only in activation, but also in differentiation, of osteoclasts in mice [26,27].</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The authors also showed that avb3 and c-fms share a common intracellular signaling pathway, including the activation of ERK and the induction of c-Fos [27], both of which are essential for osteoclastogenesis</Species>
<Species>[28,29].</Species>
<Species>In addition, it was reported that echistatin, an avb3 antagonist, inhibited osteoclast formation of mouse bone marrow cells [30].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In accordance with these reports, our data showed that knockdown of integrin-b3 expression resulted in downregulation of the avb3 heterodimer, and abrogated osteoclastogenesis from human peripheral blood CD16- monocytes.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We also showed that blocking of adhesive ligands to bind to avb3 by RGDfV peptide inhibited osteoclast formation from CD16- monocytes.</Species>
<Species>Taken together, the process of ligand binding to avb3 may be involved in the osteoclastogenesis.</Species>
<Species>Blockade of avb3 could therefore be a therapeutically beneficial approach to modulate osteoclastogenesis.</Species>
<Species>Indeed, integrin avb3 antagonists effectively treated osteoporosis in mice, rats and humans, and protected bone destruction in rat adjuvant-induced arthritis in vivo [31-34].</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Of note, it is reported that patients with Iraqi-Jewish-type Glanzmann thrombasthenia who are deficient in integrin b3 do not develop osteopetrosis because of the upregulation of a2b1 expression on osteoclasts, although the bone-resorptive ability of the osteoclasts was decreased in vitro</Species>
<Species>[35].</Species>
<Species>The function of avb3 in vivo in osteoclast formation and resorptive function could therefore be partially compensated by other integrins.</Species>
<Species>Although all the multinucleated osteoclasts expressed avb3 (Figure 4d)</Species>
<Species>[36], a small number of M-CSF + RANKL-stimulated mononuclear CD16- monocytes expressed avb3 (Figure 4d).</Species>
<Species>Multinucleated osteoclasts are formed by fusion of osteoclast precursor cells [37].</Species>
<Species>It was reported that avb3 is involved in the migration of osteoclast precursors [30].</Species>
<Species>The avb3-positive cells could therefore be forced to migrate by the ligands and may fuse with closed avb3-negative cells.</Species>
<Species>Alternatively, only avb3-positive cells may be fused with each other.</Species>

<Species>It is possible to consider that signaling from CD16 by anti-CD16 mAb-coated magnetic beads, which were used for the cell separation, or by IgG contained in FBS might inhibit osteoclastogenesis from CD16+ monocytes.</Species>
<Species>We therefore separated the two subsets using anti-CD33 mAb and a fluorescent cell sorter, and stimulated the cells with M-CSF + RANKL.</Species>
<Species>The results showed that CD33low monocytes, which correspond to CD16+ monocytes, still could not differentiate into osteoclasts.</Species>

<Species>CD16 is a heterodimer consisting of FcgIIIa and Fcg, and has low affinity for the Fc region of IgG. Aggregation of CD16 by immune complexes leads to transmission of activating signals via the immunoreceptor tyrosine-based activation motif in the g chain</Species>
<Species>[38].</Species>
<Species>We also assessed osteoclastogenesis from the two monocyte subsets using IgG-depleted bovine serum.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Even in the IgG-free medium, CD16- monocytes but not CD16+ monocytes differentiated into osteoclasts (data not shown).</Species>
<Species>We could therefore exclude the possibility that signal transduction through CD16 inhibits osteoclastogenesis from CD16+ monocytes.</Species>
<Species>NFATc1 is a key transcription factor in osteoclastogenesis [16].</Species>
<Species>In the present study, stimulation with M-CSF + RANKL increased the NFATc1 mRNA expression in the CD16- subset only, similar to integrin av and integrin b3.</Species>
<Species>The differences in NFATc1 induction might therefore also explain the difference in osteoclastogenesis between the two monocyte subsets.</Species>
<Species>It is of interest that knockdown of integrin b3 did not lower the mRNA level of NFATc1.</Species>
<Species>This result supports the notion that NFATc1 is located upstream of integrin-b3 expression [39].</Species>
<Species>It is also possible that parallel activation of two signaling pathways mediated by integrin b3 and NFATc1 contributes to osteoclastogenesis independently or cooperatively.</Species>
<Species>Further studies are needed to determine the mechanisms of integrin b3 involvement in RANKL/RANK-mediated osteoclast differentiation.</Species>
<Species>It has been demonstrated that MAPK families, ERK and p38 MAPK, were activated by RANKL-induced intracellular signalings in osteoclasts and osteoclast precursors [18,19].</Species>
<Species>In addition, these kinases are involved in the differentiation of osteoclasts [20].</Species>
<Species>We showed that RANKL stimulation induced phosphorylation of ERK and p38 MAPK only in CD16- monocytes.</Species>
<Species>It is suggested that differential activation of these kinases may partially explain the distinct properties of the two monocyte subsets upon RANKL stimulation.</Species>
<Species>Our results showed that CD16+ monocytes produce higher levels of inflammatory cytokines including TNFa and IL-6 compared with CD16- monocytes.</Species>

<Species>These results are consistent with the previous report showing that CD16+ monocytes produced larger amounts of TNFa upon lipopolysaccharide or lipopeptide stimulation than did CD16- monocytes [40].</Species>
<Species>Interestingly, we showed that stimulation either with RANKL or M-CSF upregulated the TNFa and IL-6 production by CD16+ monocytes.</Species>
<Species>A marked increase of CD16+ monocytes in peripheral blood is reported in inflammatory diseases, such as infection, malignancy, Kawasaki disease and RA</Species>
<Species>[41-44].</Species>
<Species>Taken together, CD16+ monocytes may be an important source of inflammatory cytokines.</Species>

<Species>In mice, peripheral blood Ly-6Chigh monocytes, which are thought to correspond to human CD16- monocytes, increase in inflammatory conditions, and these cells are recruited into sites of inflammation [45].</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>In contrast, Ly-6Clow monocytes, which are thought to correspond to human CD16+, migrate into noninflamed tissues [12].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>These data on mouse monocytes seem to be in contrast to the data on human monocytes, which show expansion of CD16+ monocytes in inflammatory conditions where they produce larger amounts of inflammatory cytokines.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>At present, it is not clear whether mouse monocyte subsets, Ly-6Clow/Ly-6Chigh, represent human monocyte subsets, CD16+/CD16- monocytes, and whether the biologic functions of mouse monocytes are analogous to those of human monocytes.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>In mice, blood monocytes newly released from the bone marrow are exclusively Ly-6Chigh and the level of Ly-6C is downregulated while in circulation [45].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>It is thus suggested that in mice the two monocyte subsets differing in Ly-6C expression represent different stages in the maturation pathway.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In the human, transition from CD16- monocytes to CD16+ monocytes is observed upon culture with IL-10, M-CSF and transforming growth factor beta in vitro</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>[42,46].</Species>
<Species>Similar to mouse monocytes, therefore, human peripheral blood CD16- monocytes may also maturate into CD16+ monocytes.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>It is reported that a significant number of RA synovial cells in the intima express CD16, suggesting that CD16+ cells are synovial macrophages [47].</Species>
<Species>We confirmed that both CD16+ and CD16- macrophages accumulate in the RA synovium by double-color immunohistochemical staining for CD68 and CD16.</Species>
<Species>A number of chemokines are abundantly expressed in the RA synovium [24,48].</Species>
<Species>Among these cytokines, MCP-1, MIP-1a, SDF-1, RANTES and fractalkine can induce migration of CD16- monocytes in vitro ([11,12] and unpublished data).</Species>
<Species>On the other hand, migration of CD16+ monocytes is induced only by fractalkine.</Species>
<Species>These chemokines therefore seem to play an important role in recruitment of CD16+</Species>
<Species>and CD16- monocytes from the circulating pool into the RA synovium.</Species>
<Species>The osteoclast inducers are also produced in the RA synovium.</Species>
<Species>RANKL is expressed by synovial fibroblasts and activated T cells [49-51], while M-CSF is expressed on RA synovial macrophages and fibroblasts [52,53].</Species>
<Species>TNFa and IL-6, which are mainly expressed on RA synovial macrophages and fibroblasts, respectively, could also enhance osteoclast differentiation [54].</Species>
<Species>Collectively, it is probable that the recruited CD16- monocytes/macrophages differentiate into osteoclasts in the RA synovium, and contribute to bone destruction.</Species>
<Species>On the other hand, CD16+ monocytes/macrophages might also be involved in RA pathogenesis by producing inflammatory cytokines including TNFa and IL-6.</Species>
<Species>Since TNFa and IL-6 enhance osteoclast formation [54,55], CD16+ monocytes/macrophages may also contribute to osteoclastogenesis in RA synovium.</Species>
<Species>Conclusion We have shown that human peripheral blood monocytes consist of two functionally heterogeneous subsets with distinct response to osteoclastogenic stimuli.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Osteoclasts seem to originate from CD16- monocytes, and integrin b3 is necessary for the osteoclastogenesis.</Species>
<Species>The blockade of accumulation and activation of CD16- monocytes could therefore be a beneficial approach as an anti-bone resorptive therapy, especially for RA. Abbreviations DAP =</Species>

<Species>Further studies on partially purified calf thymus DNA polymerase a.</Species>

<Species>Abstract Attempts to prevent the urea conversion of a 200-230,000 molecular weight DNA polymerase alpha to a 150-170,000 molecular weight form by the inclusion of protease inhibitors have not been successful.</Species>
<Species>No other method has been found capable of dissociating a 50-70,000 fragment or subunit from the DNA polymerase subunit.</Species>

<Species>Addition of this 50-70,000 subunit to the polymerase subunit does not aid the binding of the enzyme to DNA, but does have an effect on the utilisation of synthetic template-initiator complexes by the polymerase subunit.</Species>
<Species>Volume 6 Number 10 1979 Nucleic Acids Research</Species>

<Species>Further studies on partially purified calf thymus DNA polymerase a Keith McKune and Andrew M.Holmes* Biochemistry Department, Strathclyde University, The Todd Centre, 31 Taylor Street, Glasgow, G4 ONR, UK Received I June 1979 ABSTRACT Attempts to prevent the urea conversion of a 200-230, 000 molecular weight DNA polymerase a to a 150-170, 000 molecular weight form by the inclusion of protease inhibitors have not been successful.</Species>
<Species>No other method has been found capable of dissociating a 50-70, 000 fragment or subunit from the DNA polymerase subunit.</Species>

<Species>Addition of this 50-70, 000 subunit to the polymerase subunit does not aid the binding of the enzyme to DNA, but does have an effect on the utilisation of synthetic template-initiator complexes by the polymerase subunit.</Species>
<Species>INTRODUCTION</Species>

<Species>In mammals DNA polymerase a is thought to be the replicative enzyme, but due to low levels of activity, even in tissues actively making DNA, and to enzyme heterogeneity it has been found difficult to purify However, small samples of DNA polymerase a have been highly purified 2, 3, 4, 5 from several sources and partially characterised Heterogeneity has been observed in DNA polymerase a from a var 6 7 iety of sources, including rat liver and spleen , Hela cells, baby hamster 8 9, 10 11 kidney cells , mouse myeloma , Drosophila embryos and calf thymus 1,6, 12, 13 .</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We have previously observed several species of calf thymus DNA polymerase a differing in size and charge .</Species>
<Species>In order of elution from DEAE cellulose they are enzyme A1 (200-230, 000 molecular weight), A2 (200-230, 000), B (100-110, 000) and C (150-170, 000).</Species>
<Species>A poly (dA).</Species>
<Species>oligo (dT)10 preferring enzyme, enzyrrme D (140-150, 000 molecular weight) elutes just after enzyme B. The A enzymes seem identical in all properties except their charge.</Species>
<Species>5.0-5.</Species>

<Species>5S enzymes, analagous to B, have been observed to C Information Retrieval Limited 1 Falconberg Court London Wl V 5FG England 3341 Nucleic Acids Research arise as the result of proteolytic action ' , similarly the B enzyme above 14 ,but the relationship of the other observed species is not clear, nor is the problem of which, if any, of these species is the replicative enzyme, although circumstantial evidence has implicated a DNA polymerase a to be 15 the replicative enzyme in adenovirus infected KB cells We have previously shown that several of these enzymes are inter 16 convertible .</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In particular, mild urea treatment can convert both A enzymes to C enzyme, with the loss of a subunit or fragment of 50-70, 000 molecular weight.</Species>
<Species>The C enzyme retains DNA polymerase activity, but does show differences compared to A enzyme in heat sensitivity and sensitivity to N-ethylmaleimide.</Species>

<Species>Highly purified samples of A and C enzymes when subjected to sodium dodecyl sulphate polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis have shown a corre lation of DNA polymerase activity with a polypeptide band 155, 000 molecular weight .</Species>
<Species>Contaminating material of 50-70, 000 molecular weight appeared to obscure the putative 50-70, 000 subunit in gels of A enzyme.</Species>

<Species>The conclusions drawn were that DNA polymerase a is a 155, 000 molecular weight polypeptide (C enzyrrme) which can and does associated with material of 50 70, 000 molecular weight to give A enzyme, and that enzyme B is a proteol 14 ytic degradation product .</Species>
<Species>The relationship of enzyme D to the others is not clear.</Species>

<Species>It is possible that during the enzyme isolation procedure proteolytic action may have taken place on a 200-230, 000 molecular weight enzyme releasing 155, 000 and 50-70, 000 fragments which remain in association until urea treatment separates them.</Species>
<Species>It is also possible that urea treatment itself renders the enzyme susceptible to contaminating proteases.</Species>
<Species>Further experiments to ascertain whether or not this is the case and, if so, to prevent it, have been carried out.</Species>
<Species>A enzyme can be reconstituted from C enzyme formed by the action of urea on A enzyme by concentrating it with the 50-70, 000 molecular weight material.</Species>

<Species>The A enzyrme obtained in this manner is highly purified, as is the C enzyme formed by the urea treatment, and has been used in attempts to show differences in synthetic template-initiator complex utilisation 3342 Nucleic Acids Research b y the se two enzyme s .</Species>
<Species>MATERIALS AND METHODS Calf thymus was obtained from 10-16 week old calves and frozen at -20?C until required.</Species>
<Species>Chromatographic media and chemicals were obtained 6 from sources previously referred to .</Species>
<Species>Radioactive deoxynucleoside tri phosphates were obtained from the Radiochemical Centre, Amersham, Bucks.</Species>

<Species>Synthetic oligo and polynucleotides were obtained from P. L. Biochemicals Inc., except for poly (dC) which was a gift from Dr. I.R. Johnston and pre 17 pared from oligo d(C)5 as described .</Species>
<Species>N-a-p Tosyl-L-lysine chloromethy lketone HCl and phenylmethylsulphonylfluoride were obtained from Sigma and Trasylol from Bayer.</Species>
<Species>Except where indicated all buffers contained 20% w/v glycerol and 1 mM dithiothreitol.</Species>
<Species>Standard linear phosphate gradients were run between 0.03 M and 0.25 M potassium phosphate, pH 7.8.</Species>
<Species>Gradient salt concentr 2 ations were measured using a conductivity meter as described .</Species>
<Species>Urea was prepared as a 4. 8 M solution in 20% w/v glycerol, stirred with Amberlite MB3 and filtered.</Species>
<Species>Dithiothreitol was added to a final concentration of 1 mM before use.</Species>
<Species>6 DNA polymerase was assayed using activated DNA as described except that the buffer was 50 mM tris HC1, pH 7.8.</Species>

<Species>One unit of DNA polymerase activity incorporates ln mol [ H] dTMP into an acid insoluble form in one hour at 370C. Assays using synthetic template-initiator complexes were carried out at 30?C in 0.</Species>
<Species>12 ml.</Species>
<Species>The template-initiator complexes 6 were prepared and assays processed as described .</Species>
<Species>All assays contained 1 mM dithiothreitol, 62.</Species>
<Species>5 p.g bovine serum albumin, 1 ,ug template-initiator complex, enzyme protein and the relevant [ H] deoxynucleoside triphosphate at 0.1 mM and 12-15 cpm/pmol.</Species>

text: <Species>These assays were carried out at either pH 6.4 in 20 mM sodium-potassium phosphate, or at pH 7.8 in 50 mM tris HCl and contained either 10 mM MgCl2 or 1 mM MnCl2 as indicated.</Species>

<Species>Preliminary purification of DNA polymerase a to Fraction IV was as 6 described , the purification steps being phosphocellulose chromatography, ammonium sulphate precipitation and gel filtration on Sepharose 6B. 3343 Nucleic Acids Research Enzyme obtained from the DEAE cellulose step is referred to as Fraction V enzyme.</Species>
<Species>Samples were prepared for sodium dodecyl sulphate polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis and scanned as previously described2 RESULTS AND DISCUSSION (a) Interconversion Studies</Species>
<Species>A enzyme was routinely converted to C enzyme by incubating 200500 units/ml of Fraction V A enzyme in 2.4 M urea in 0. 02</Species>
<Species>M potassium phosphate, pH 7.8, for 60 minutes at 0?C.</Species>
<Species>The mixture was then loaded on to a DEAE cellulose, washed with 0. 03</Species>
<Species>M potassium phosphate pH 7. 8, and enzyrme eluted either with the standard phosphate gradient or batchwise.</Species>
<Species>Under these conditions usually about 50-60% of recovered activity was enzyme C (Fig 1 a).</Species>
<Species>Overall recovery was 70-80%.</Species>
<Species>A enzyme was recon 14 stituted essentially as described .</Species>

<Species>The flow through material from the DEAE cellulose column after the urea treatment was loaded on to a 1 x 0. 8 cm phosphocellulose column, washed with 0.03 M potassium phosphate, pH 7.8, and the protein eluted with 0.25 M potassium phosphate, pH 7. 8.</Species>

<Species>This material, the putative subunit, was vacuum dialysed with the C enzyme produced by the urea treatment, rechromatographed on DEAE cellulose and enzyme eluted batchwise (Fig 1 b).</Species>
<Species>Recovery from this procedure was usually 50-70% A enzyme.</Species>
<Species>Overall recovery was 30-40% of the C enzyme dialysed.</Species>

<Species>If the material eluted from the phosphocellulose by the 0. 25 M potassium phosphate was heated to 90?C for 5 minutes prior to vacuum dialysis with the C enzyme the recovery from the DEAE cellulose column was significantly higher (60-70% of the original C enzyme activity), but all recoverable DNA polymerase activity was C enzyme.</Species>

<Species>This, together with the fact that the 60 minute treatment with urea has, on occasions, given rise to a 50% increase in DNA polymerase activity prior to loading on to the DEAE cellulose column, would indicate that A enzyme is less active on activated DNA than is C enzyme.</Species>
<Species>If the DEAE cellulose flow through material came from urea treatment of A2 enzyme then A2 was produced on reconstitution; if from A1 then A1 was produced.</Species>
<Species>Although the mild urea treatment of A has been used to prepare C of 3344 Nucleic Acids Research b 120 180 C</Species>

<Species>3345 Nucleic Acids Research high specific activity it is possible that conversion of the 200-230, 000 molecular weight enzymes to a 155- 170, 000 species maybe due to unfolding of the molecule to allow limited attack by contaminating proteases.</Species>
<Species>Accord ingly the urea conversion of A to C was investigated in the presence of certain protease inhibitors.</Species>
<Species>The presence of the serine protease inhibitor phenylmethylsulphonyl-fluoride in the incubation and chromatography buffers did not affect the conversion of A2to C (Fig 1 a).</Species>
<Species>Likewise trasylol and Na-p Tosyl-L-lysine chloromethylketone HC1 had no effect.</Species>
<Species>However, protease action could have occurred earlier in the purification procedure and the urea could be separating two fragments.</Species>
<Species>Usually the DEAE cellulose profile shows that the majority of the enzyme activity is present as A enzyme (Fig 2).</Species>
<Species>In this instance A1 and A2 have not been separated.</Species>

<Species>When the temperature of the material in the original blending procedure was kept below 0?C or phenylmethylsulphonylfluoride, N-a-p Tosyl-L-lysine chloromethylketone HCl or trasylol was included in the isolation buffers the DEAE cellulose profile was similar.</Species>
<Species>The A enzymes were still capable of conversion by mild urea treatment to C enzyme, indicating that if protease activity is involved then it is not susceptible to these inhibitors.</Species>

<Species>?C for 30 minutes, there was a marked decrease in the amount of A enzyme with a concomitant increase in the amount of B and C (unpublished observation).</Species>

<Species>The presence of phenylmethylsulphonylfluoride, N- a-p T osyl- L-lysine chloromethylketone HCl or trasylol under these conditions only had a marginal effect on the appearance of C enzyme, but did reduce the amount of B enzyme.</Species>
<Species>Heating the enzyme to 37?C after the phosphocellulose step had no effect on the DEAE cellulose elution profile.</Species>
<Species>Attempts to convert A enzyme to C using trypsin have not been successful.</Species>

<Species>A enzyme activity is lost without the appearance of any other species (unpublished observation), although 14 the action of trypsin on C enzyme can give rise to small amounts of B Although the conversion of A enzyme to C does not appear to be the result of serine protease action, proteases other than serine proteases 18 could have been responsible .</Species>

<Species>Also, the fact that A enzyme can be recon stituted from C plus the flow through material from the DEAE cellulose after urea treatment does not necessarily mean we are dealing with two subunits as fragments produced by proteases mray be reassembled to give active enzyme 9 .</Species>

<Species>However, the fact that a 200-230, 000 molecular weight polypeptide band has never been observed in sodium dodecylsulphate polyacrylamride gels of highly purified A enzyme , or even cruder fractions of A enzyrre (unpublished observation), may be significant.</Species>
<Species>One might expect some of the enzyme not to have been attacked by whatever is responsible for cleaving the molecule, if, indeed, this does happen.</Species>

<Species>It would appear, therefore, that the A enzyme consists of subunits of 155, 000 and 50-70, 000 molecular weight with the small subunit having a slightly different charge in the case of A and A2.</Species>
<Species>It has also been concluded that the heterogeneity in the 1 ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~3 mouse myeloma DNA polymerase a fraction is not due to proteolysis .</Species>

text: <Species>However, the 50-70, 000 molecular weight subunit has not yet been identified.</Species>

<Species>Sodiurrm dodecylsulphate polyacrylamide gels of reconstituted A enzyme have shown polypeptide bands at 150-160, 000 and 50-70, 000 molecular weight (Fig. 3), but the ratio of staining intensity of the bands does not correspond to a 1: 1 relationship.</Species>

<Species>The ratio of the two bands is variable but is usually between 1:2 and 1:3, indicating, perhaps, that more than one subunit of 50 3347 Nucleic Acids Research TOP 123 4 5 6 Figure 3 Scan of a 5% sodium dodecyl sulphate polyacrylamide gel of reconstituted A2 enzyme.</Species>
<Species>1500 units of reconstituted A2 enzyme were subjected to polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis under non-denaturing conditions.</Species>

<Species>The gels were sliced, enzyme extracted and assayed and the peak fraction of DNA polymerase activity from three gels were pooled, subjected to sodium dodecyl sulphate polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis on a single gel, stained and scanned at 2 volt sensitivity as described2.</Species>

<Species>The molecular weight standards were: (1) bovine serum albumin dimer (134, 000), (2) ,3 galactosidase (130, 000), (3) phosphorylase a (94, 000), (4) bovine serum albumin (68, 000), (5) pyruvate kinase (57, 000) and (6) lactate dehydrogenase (35, 000).</Species>

<Species>The proportion of the lower molecular weight polypeptide band is higher in the reconstituted A enzyrrme than in the C enzyme preparation from which it was formed, but even the C enzyme contained some material in the region.</Species>

<Species>Breakdown of material from 155, 000 to 50-70, 000 may be partly responsible for the contamination, but the presence of phenylmethylsulphonylfluoride in samples in preparation for sodium dodecylsulphate polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis has not been successful in preventing it.</Species>

<Species>The human KB cell DNA polymerase a, equivalent to the C enzyme, has been reported to consist 4 of subunits of 76, 000 and 66, 000 molecular weight , but at no time have we observed polypeptide bands at 76, 000 and 66, 000 rising and falling with enzyme activity in any gels of calf thyrrmus enzymes A1, A and C (and 2 unpublished observations).</Species>
