<Species>Dynein Modifiers in C. elegans: Light Chains Suppress Conditional Heavy Chain Mutants</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Abstract Cytoplasmic dynein is a microtubule-dependent motor protein that functions in mitotic cells during centrosome separation, metaphase chromosome congression, anaphase spindle elongation, and chromosome segregation.</Species>
<Species>Dynein is also utilized during interphase for vesicle transport and organelle positioning.</Species>
<Species>While numerous cellular processes require cytoplasmic dynein, the mechanisms that target and regulate this microtubule motor remain largely unknown.</Species>

<Species>By screening a conditional Caenorhabditis elegans cytoplasmic dynein heavy chain mutant at a semipermissive temperature with a genome-wide RNA interference library to reduce gene functions, we have isolated and characterized twenty dynein-specific suppressor genes.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>When reduced in function, these genes suppress dynein mutants but not other conditionally mutant loci, and twelve of the 20 specific suppressors do not exhibit sterile or lethal phenotypes when their function is reduced in wild-type worms.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Many of the suppressor proteins, including two dynein light chains, localize to subcellular sites that overlap with those reported by others for the dynein heavy chain.</Species>

<Species>Furthermore, knocking down any one of four putative dynein accessory chains suppresses the conditional heavy chain mutants, suggesting that some accessory chains negatively regulate heavy chain function.</Species>

<Species>We also identified 29 additional genes that, when reduced in function, suppress conditional mutations not only in dynein but also in loci required for unrelated essential processes.</Species>

<Species>In conclusion, we have identified twenty genes that in many cases are not essential themselves but are conserved and when reduced in function can suppress conditionally lethal C. elegans cytoplasmic dynein heavy chain mutants.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We conclude that conserved but nonessential genes contribute to dynein function during the essential process of mitosis.</Species>
<Species>Microtubules and microtubule-dependent motor proteins segregate chromosomes during mitosis and also promote cellular organization in nondividing cells.</Species>

<Species>An essential motor protein complex called cytoplasmic dynein powers many aspects of microtubule-dependent transport, but it is currently unclear how dynein is regulated such that it can execute different processes.</Species>
<Species>We have performed a genome-wide screen to isolate genes that are involved in dynein-dependent processes.</Species>
<Species>We determined that 20 of the 49 genes we identified specifically influenced the viability of dynein mutant strains but not the viability of other C. elegans mutants.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Many of the proteins that specifically influence dynein localized to subcellular sites where the dynein heavy chain has been reported by others to be found.</Species>
<Species>Additionally, we identified four dynein components that appear to negatively regulate the force-generating dynein heavy chain.</Species>

<Species>The identification and initial characterization of this group of genes represents a route to identify genes that are not themselves essential but do participate in essential processes.</Species>

<Species>Introduction The microtubule motor called cytoplasmic dynein has roles in diverse cellular processes including meiotic and mitotic spindle assembly and function, neuronal transport, and organelle positioning [1].</Species>
<Species>Cytoplasmic dynein is composed of a dimer of heavy chains (HCs), along with several accessory chains (ACs: intermediate, light intermediate, and light chains).</Species>
<Species>Other dynein-interacting proteins, such as dynactin and LIS1, are likely present at substoichiometric levels and further modulate dynein function.</Species>

<Species>The HCs contain both ATPase and microtubule binding activities and are sufficient for microtubule-based motility in vitro, moving toward the minus, or slow-growing, end of microtubules [2].</Species>
<Species>The dynein ACs provide cargo docking sites and often are encoded by multigene families in any one species [reviewed in 1,3].</Species>
<Species>In C. elegans, a single gene called dhc-1 encodes a cytoplasmic dynein 1 HC, while 11 other genes encode five classes of predicted dynein ACs</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>[3,4].</Species>
<Species>The early C. elegans embryo is an excellent system for investigating gene contributions for essential cellular processes, including cytoskeletal functions [5].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The C. elegans dynein HC DHC-1 is essential and required for multiple microtubule-dependent events during early embryogenesis [6-9].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Depletion of DHC-1 by RNA interference (RNAi) in early C. elegans embryos produces defects in female meiotic divisions, migration of the oocyte and sperm pronuclei after fertilization, and centrosome separation during mitotic spindle assembly</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>[6].</Species>

<Species>Analysis of fast-acting dhc-1 temperature-sensitive (ts) mutants has further revealed that dynein is required for chromosome congression to the metaphase plate during mitosis, as well as for mitotic spindle positioning [10].</Species>
<Species>While many requirements for cytoplasmic dynein are known, our knowledge of the molecular mechanisms that target and regulate dynein remains limited.</Species>
<Species>Clearly, the multiple ACs can couple the dynein HC to particular substrates</Species>
<Species>[</Species>
<Species>11], including vesicles, nuclei, viruses, kinetochores, and rhodopsin [see table in 1].</Species>
<Species>However, reducing the function of only four of the eleven dynein ACs in C. elegans produces lethal phenotypes [12].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Thus, it remains unclear how ACs influence the different essential requirements for dynein.</Species>

<Species>Another potential route for dynein regulation involves the phosphorylation state of the different dynein chains, which in some cases confers distinctive functional properties to the motor.</Species>
<Species>While many examples of dynein phosphorylation exist, and cell cycle dependent changes in phosphorylation have been described</Species>
<Species>[13-15], few if any studies have demonstrated a requirement for such modification during mitosis.</Species>

<Species>Large-scale forward genetic screens have identified genes with requirements similar to those for dynein, but many of these encode core components of the microtubule cytoskeleton and few are known to directly influence dynein itself</Species>
<Species>[12,16].</Species>
<Species>Genes that do influence dynein function might also have other essential roles, leading to pleiotropic mutant phenotypes that obscure their relationship to dynein [17-19].</Species>

<Species>Moreover, redundancy within the multigene dynein subunit families, and also perhaps between the different ACs, may complicate the identification of single gene requirements that are important for dynein function.</Species>

<Species>Thus far, reducing the function of individual genes has not provided substantial insight into the mechanisms that regulate and mediate the many different requirements for cytoplasmic dynein during mitosis.</Species>
<Species>To identify potential regulators of cytoplasmic dynein, we have used a sensitized genetic background to conduct a genome-wide screen for modifiers of dynein function in C. elegans.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Other groups have successfully used RNAi modifier screens to identify genes that function in particular pathways</Species>

<Species>[20-23]; we have used RNAi to screen for genes that, when reduced in function, suppress the embryonic lethality associated with a temperature-sensitive (ts) allele of the dhc-1 dynein HC gene.</Species>
<Species>Using the dhc-1ts genetic background, we found 49 genes that, when depleted, suppress the partial loss of HC function.</Species>
<Species>Twenty of these genes suppress conditional dynein HC mutants but not other conditional mutants with unrelated defects.</Species>
<Species>Finally, we show that some of these dynein-specific suppressors encode proteins that may overlap with the dynein HC in subcellular localization.</Species>
<Species>Results To identify dynein suppressors, we used three different conditional and recessive dhc-1 mutants that were identified previously [7].</Species>

<Species>These ts alleles of dhc-1 (or195, or283, and or352) produce similar defects at the restrictive temperature of 26 oC, including incomplete mitotic spindle assembly in one-cell embryos and embryonic lethality [7].</Species>
<Species>We sequenced the dhc-1 locus in the three mutants.</Species>

<Species>The independently isolated or195 and or283 alleles each change a conserved serine to leucine at codon 3200, within the coiled-coil region of the microtubule-binding stalk domain (Figure 1A and 1C).</Species>
<Species>The or352 allele replaces a conserved glycine with aspartic acid at codon 2158, in the ATP-binding walker</Species>
<Species>A motif of the second AAA ATPase domain (Figure 1B and 1C).</Species>
<Species>As both missense mutations affect conserved residues, they may prove useful for engineering ts alleles in other organisms.</Species>

<Species>The temperature versus viability curves of the dynein ts mutants feature a steep central transition zone ideal for modifier screening because subtle changes in temperature produce large changes in embryonic viability (Figure 2A).</Species>
<Species>To identify genes that, when reduced in function, can suppress conditional dhc-1 mutants, we developed a high-throughput RNAi-based screen (Figure 2B).</Species>
<Species>To reduce gene function we used a library of 16,757 bacterial strains that each express a dsRNA corresponding to exon-rich gene sequences [17,19].</Species>

<Species>We then tested over 99% of the bacterial strains in this library for RNAi-mediated suppression of dhc-1(or195) embryonic lethality at 23 oC, after raising synchronized L1 larvae to adulthood on dsRNA-expressing bacterial lawns in 48-well agar plates.</Species>
<Species>This screening procedure should work to identify nonessential and essential suppressor genes, because RNAi does not always fully reduce gene function</Species>
<Species>[24,25], and even if RNAi does produce lethality, cosuppression could restore viability.</Species>
<Species>Nevertheless, essential genes may be missed due to earlier requirements that produce strong larval arrest, sterile, or embryonic lethal phenotypes.</Species>
<Species>Using this screening procedure, we identified 49 bacterial clones that consistently increased embryonic viability at the semipermissive temperature.</Species>
<Species>The dsRNA-producing plasmids were then sequenced to verify gene identity.</Species>

<Species>Quantification of embryonic viability using dhc-1(or195) animals showed that the RNAi-mediated depletion of suppressor gene function increased viability to 5%-100%, compared to less than 2% in unsuppressed controls (Figure 3A; Table S1).</Species>
<Species>The proteins encoded by the suppressor genes we identified are summarized in Figure 4.</Species>

<Species>As a more direct assay for dynein activity in the suppressed dhc-1 embryos, we measured spindle length and cytokinesis success: dhc-1 mutant embryos have severe spindle assembly defects and subsequent cytokinesis failures [6,7,10].</Species>

<Species>We shifted dhc-1 adult hermaphrodites from 23 oC to the fully restrictive temperature of 26 oC for 3-5 hours and made time-lapse video micrographs using Nomarski optics to monitor the first embryonic cell division.</Species>
<Species>This procedure results in dhc-1(or195) embryos with P0 spindles 30% the length of wild-type spindles (Figure S1).</Species>
<Species>In the suppressed dhc-1(or195) backgrounds, spindle lengths ranged from 30%-83% of wild-type lengths (Figure S1).</Species>
<Species>Similarly, cytokinesis failed in unsuppressed dhc-1(or195) embryos 89% of the time, but most of the suppressors rescued this phenotype (Figure S1).</Species>
<Species>These results indicate that most of the suppressors influence dynein-dependent cellular processes, as expected given their ability to restore viability when reduced in function.</Species>
<Species>Specificity of Suppression Because RNAi can reduce the function of unintended targets (so-called    off-target effects    </Species>
<Species>[26,27]), we also used available mutations in some of the suppressor genes we identified to reduce their function.</Species>

<Species>We constructed double mutant strains using dhc-1(or195) and viable deletion alleles for two suppressor genes, dylt-1(ok417) and ufd-2(tm1380), and examined embryonic viability (Figure 3B).</Species>

<Species>The deletion alleles of dylt-1 (encoding a Tctex1-type dynein light chain), and ufd-2 (encoding a ubiquitin conjugating enzyme) both recapitulated the suppression produced by RNAi knockdown (Figure 3B).</Species>
<Species>The dpy-3(e27) and dpy-10(e128) point mutation alleles [28] also suppressed embryonic lethality in double mutants (Figure 3B).</Species>

<Species>Based on this small sampling, and because RNAi in C. elegans appears to be highly gene specific in the absence of close paralogs [12,19], we conclude that many of the suppressors we have identified will prove to be suppressor locus specific.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The dsRNA-expressing bacterial clones we used to deplete two of the dynein suppressors (tag-300 and ZK1127.10) probably also knock down expression of one close paralog for each locus [29].</Species>
<Species>We next asked whether the suppressors are specific for dynein function or if their depletion more generally stabilizes ts proteins.</Species>
<Species>We tested for specificity using two conditional mutants with cell fate patterning defects unrelated to dynein function, lit-1(or131) and spn-4(or191).</Species>
<Species>The lit-1 gene encodes a MAP kinase-related protein [30], while spn-4 encodes a protein with an RNA binding motif [31].</Species>

<Species>We found that ten of the dhc-1-interacting genes significantly increased embryonic viability in both lit-1 and spn-4 mutants, while 18 others suppressed one or the other of these two conditional mutants when reduced in function using the same RNAi protocol as that used for dhc-1ts mutants (Figure 4, right two columns; Table S1).</Species>
<Species>Therefore, about half of the suppressors appear to act nonspecifically on multiple ts mutants to restore embryonic viability.</Species>
<Species>From here on, we will refer to the suppressors that only acted on dhc-1, and not on lit-1 and spn-4 ts mutants, as dynein-specific suppressors.</Species>

<Species>Because many ts mutations exert their effect via protein assembly or unfolding mechanisms [32], suppressor genes reduced in function by RNAi might not be expected to exhibit allele specificity with most ts mutations.</Species>
<Species>To determine if the dynein suppressors are either allele or strain specific, we tested the two other conditional dhc-1 strains (containing the or283 and or352 alleles).</Species>
<Species>Although the or283 allele is identical to or195, it provides a useful control for the presence of background mutations because the two strains were isolated independently.</Species>
<Species>In most cases, depletion of the dynein-specific suppressors also restored viability to the other two ts dhc-1 alleles.</Species>

<Species>Y40B1B.5, a putative translation initiation factor, suppressed only one conditional dhc-1 strain, and we consider this as an example of a nonspecific interaction (Figure 4, left three columns; Table S1).</Species>

<Species>Two dsRNAs that do not suppress lit-1 or spn-4 mutants produced suppression in the dhc-1(or195) and dhc-1(or283) strains, but not in the dhc-1(or352) strain, perhaps indicating allele specificity or variability in the RNAi treatments.</Species>
<Species>We conclude that strain background differences are relatively rare, and that the majority of the suppressors are allele-independent.</Species>
<Species>To summarize, we have identified 20 genes that when reduced in function specifically suppress multiple dynein ts strains but not unrelated ts loci.</Species>

<Species>Survey of Putative Dynein Accessory Chains We were surprised to discover that depleting two predicted dynein ACs specifically suppressed the partial loss of HC function, because most dynein accessory subunits are presumed to promote dynein function by aiding dynein complex formation or mediating cargo attachment [3,11,33].</Species>

<Species>Depletion of either dylt-1 (encoding a Tctex1-type light chain) or dyrb-1 (encoding a roadblock-type light chain) suppressed embryonic lethality in all three ts dynein HC mutant strains (Figure 4).</Species>
<Species>To extend this observation, we surveyed all genes encoding predicted dynein components for suppression of the three ts dhc-1 mutants (Figure 5A; Table S2).</Species>
<Species>We reasoned that some dynein subunit genes could have been missed in the primary screening and several dynein AC genes were not represented in the E. coli RNAi library.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>After using RNAi to reduce their function, we found that one of three Tctex1 homologs (dylt-1), one of four LC8 homologs (dlc-1), one of two light intermediate chains (dli-1), as well as the sole roadblock homolog (dyrb-1) each strongly suppressed the three conditional dynein mutants.</Species>
<Species>Lower-level suppression was also seen for the second light intermediate chain, xbx-1, when its function was reduced.</Species>
<Species>Thus, one gene of each of four subunit classes restores viability to the three dhc-1 mutant strains when depleted by RNAi.</Species>
<Species>The only subunit class not found to suppress was the intermediate chain, encoded by a single gene in C. elegans, dyci-1.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>When reduced in function by RNAi, dyci-1 produces a larval arrest phenotype like that observed for dhc-1(RNAi); this phenotype precludes any suppression of the conditional embryonic lethality (shown as    la    in Figure 5A).</Species>

<Species>In contrast, knockdown of either dlc-1 or dli-1 suppresses embryonic lethality in the dhc-1ts mutants, even though reducing their function in otherwise wild-type embryos produces dhc-1-like defects, including embryonic lethality [12,34] (see Figure 5B and Discussion).</Species>

<Species>The suppressing cytoplasmic dynein subunits and DYCI-1 are shown in a putative complex in Figure 5E. We performed several genetic assays to better understand how the suppressor genes may be operating.</Species>

<Species>First, suppression of dhc-1 lethality by reducing AC function may indicate that our dhc-1 alleles express a neomorphic and toxic DHC-1 protein: if the suppressor dynein AC subunits positively function in dynein processes, depleting them might suppress any neomorphic effects.</Species>
<Species>This explanation is perhaps unlikely, because the dhc-1ts alleles are all recessive, but remained a possibility in dhc-1 homozygotes.</Species>
<Species>We therefore reduced dynein function using RNAi in animals that had passed through the larval arrest points for dhc-1(RNAi) and dyci-1(RNAi).</Species>
<Species>Specifically, we transferred dhc-1(or195) L4 hermaphrodites to plates with bacteria expressing dhc-1 or dyci-1 dsRNA.</Species>
<Species>As control we performed dylt-1(RNAi) using the same procedure.</Species>
<Species>We observed substantial suppression with dylt-1 in this assay, but we saw no suppression with the heavy or intermediate chains (Figure 5C).</Species>
<Species>This suggests that the DHC-1ts protein is not toxic and that dyci-1 acts more like dhc-1 than the other suppressing ACs because it does not suppress the heavy chain mutant.</Species>
<Species>To further examine the nature of the AC suppression, we asked if depletion of the suppressor chains could bypass the requirement for dhc-1.</Species>
<Species>We transferred wild-type L4 larvae to plates with bacteria expressing dsRNA corresponding to both the suppressor ACs and dhc-1.</Species>
<Species>We did not observe any suppression in these double RNAi assays (Figure 5D), suggesting that dhc-1ts suppression requires the residual activity of the defective DHC-1 protein.</Species>

<Species>We conclude that the dynein AC suppressors inhibit or somehow oppose the function of the DHC-1ts protein, and that the dhc-1(or195ts) mutation does not produce a toxic gene product but simply reduces DHC-1 activity to a low, but non-null, level.</Species>

<Species>Localization of the Dynein Suppressor Proteins To further explore how the suppressor proteins function, we examined the subcellular localization of nine of them as stably expressed N-terminal GFP::S fusions.</Species>

<Species>We chose to first focus on the suppressor genes that were conserved but poorly characterized in any system, or were conserved but uncharacterized during early C. elegans embryogenesis.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Prior dynein immunocytochemistry-based localization studies serve as a comparison [6,10,35].</Species>
<Species>As in other species, C. elegans DHC-1 is associated with mitotic spindles, centrosomes, the nuclear envelope, the cell cortex, the midbody, and throughout the cytoplasm.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Most of the suppressor proteins we examined localized to sites where DHC-1 is known to act or localize (Figure 6).</Species>

<Species>However, the nearly ubiquitous distribution of DHC-1 in early embryonic cells makes colocalization likely but not necessarily meaningful, and biochemical studies are needed to conclusively address any direct or indirect physical associations.</Species>
<Species>Four suppressor GFP fusion proteins localized to nuclear membranes and to spindle poles or pericentrosomal regions.</Species>
<Species>The DYLT-1 and DYRB-1 dynein light chains were associated with nuclear envelopes and centrosomes, as well as meiotic and mitotic spindle poles (Figure 6A-6H; Videos S1 and S2).</Species>

<Species>The potential coiled-coil protein K04F10.3 was present on the nuclear envelope and in a pericentrosomal position during mitosis, similar to endoplasmic reticulum proteins [36] (Figure 6I-6L; Video S3).</Species>
<Species>K04F10.3 was also highly enriched at meiotic spindle poles (Figure 6I), which has been observed for other endoplasmic reticulum proteins [36].</Species>

<Species>The NPP-22 transmembrane nucleoporin was found at nuclear envelopes (Figure 6M-6P; Video S4), as previously reported for later stage embryos [37], and it also surrounded centrosomes during mitosis.</Species>

<Species>Two splice isoforms of the pleckstrin homology domain-containing EFA-6/Y55D9A.1, an ARF guanine nucleotide exchange factor, were enriched cortically both in the anterior portion of the one-cell zygote and at the blastomere boundary in two-cell embryos (Figure 6Q-6T; Videos S5 and S6).</Species>
<Species>The conserved Mo25 homolog MOP-25.2/Y53C12A.4 was found enriched in a single spot after cytokinesis that appears to correspond to the midbody (Figure 6U-6X; Video S7).</Species>
<Species>F10E7.8, a highly conserved ortholog of S. cerevisiae Far11, appears nuclear (Figure 6Y-6B    and Video S8).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Finally, the nonspecific suppressor protein STAR-2, a predicted RNA binding protein, appears to be associated with P-granules (like its homolog GLD-1), where dynein is neither localized nor known to function (Figure 6C   -6F   ).</Species>

<Species>DLYT-1 and DYRB-1: Dynein Light Chain Localization The C. elegans dynein HC protein weakly localizes to spindle poles during early embryonic cell cycles [6,10], and so did DYRB-1 and DYLT-1 (Videos S9 and S10).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>However, ts mutant forms of the DHC-1 protein (including DHC-1 encoded by the or195 allele) strongly localize to centrosomes when shifted to the non-permissive temperature [10].</Species>
<Species>The mechanism underlying this enhanced localization is not known, but it may represent trapping of the defective protein at a normally transient location.</Species>

<Species>We exploited this behavior of the mutant DHC-1 protein to determine whether redistribution of the putative DYRB-1 and DYLT-1 dynein light chains also occurred in the dhc-1(or195) background.</Species>
<Species>We found that the cellular distributions of DYRB-1 and DYLT-1 were dramatically altered in dhc-1(or195) mutant embryos.</Species>

<Species>After shifting the parental worms to the restrictive temperature for 3-5 h prior to collecting embryos, these two proteins were prominently localized to centrosomes and to spindle poles that did not separate in one-cell stage embryos (Figure 7; Videos S11 and S12).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The spindle pole to cytoplasmic fluorescence ratio during late anaphase was 5-fold higher in both of the dhc-1 homozygous mutant strains when compared to wild-type embryos expressing the GFP fusions.</Species>

<Species>We also assayed localization of the two putative dynein light chains after short temperature shifts to the nonpermissive temperature in the dhc-1(or195) mutant background, which yields mitotic spindles with an overall wild-type appearance and function.</Species>
<Species>These short temperature shifts also resulted in robust localization of these two dynein light chains to centrosomes (unpublished data).</Species>
<Species>Finally, we examined the localization of GFP::DYRB-1 and GFP::DYLT-1 in embryos from dhc-1(or195)    /+</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>worms grown at the dhc-1(or195) permissive temperature of 15 oC.</Species>

<Species>Even though embryos from mothers heterozygous for this recessive mutation are viable and develop normally, even at 26 oC [7], we observed a substantial increase in both GFP fusion proteins at the mitotic spindle poles in early embryos (Figure 7; Videos S13 and S14).</Species>

<Species>Importantly, localization of DYLT-1 and DYRB-1 to centrosomes does not occur in embryos depleted for DHC-1 with RNAi (our unpublished results), indicating that these proteins require the mutant DHC-1 polypeptide for centrosomal targeting in the dhc-1(or195) embryos.</Species>

<Species>In summary, the DYRB-1 and DYLT-1 proteins localize to sites where the DHC-1 HC is also found in wild-type embryos, and all three proteins respond similarly to mutational alterations in DHC-1.</Species>
<Species>Genetic Characterization of the DYLT-1 and DYRB-1 Dynein Light Chains We obtained putative null alleles to determine if dylt-1 and dyrb-1 function in dynein-dependent processes.</Species>
<Species>DYLT-1 is 40% identical to human DYNLT3 and 38% identical to Drosophila Dlc90F</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>(see alignment in Figure 8A).</Species>
<Species>Two other C. elegans genes, dylt-2 and dylt-3, encode more divergent members of this protein family.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>DYRB-1 is 49% identical to both human DYNLRB1 and Drosophila Robl (see alignment in Figure 8A).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>There do not appear to be other Roadblock genes in the C. elegans genome [3].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Deletion alleles for both dylt-1 and dyrb-1 have been isolated (Figure 8B).</Species>
<Species>The dylt-1(ok417) deletion removes the entire DYLT-1 open reading frame and does not affect adjacent coding regions.</Species>
<Species>The dyrb-1(tm2645) deletion removes 69% of the dyrb-1 coding region, leaving 29 predicted N-terminal amino acids, and does not affect adjacent coding regions.</Species>
<Species>Both deletions are currently annotated as homozygous viable [29].</Species>

<Species>However, we found that the dyrb-1(tm2645) strain was in fact heterozygous for the deletion and that most embryos produced by dyrb-1(tm2645) homozygous animals failed to hatch (Figure 8C).</Species>
<Species>Homozygous dyrb-1(tm2645)</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>worms also showed an egg-laying defect and produced small broods (unpublished data).</Species>
<Species>To determine if the dyrb-1 deletion was responsible for the embryonic lethality, we crossed the GFP::dyrb-1 transgene into the deletion background.</Species>

<Species>The presence of the transgene fully rescued the embryonic lethality (Figure 8C), but not the egg-laying defect: the transgene is driven from a germline-specific promoter and so would not be expected to rescue zygotic phenotypes.</Species>
<Species>The embryonic lethality exhibited by dyrb-1(tm2645) mutants is consistent with RNAi studies performed by injection or soaking [12,38].</Species>
<Species>In contrast, homozygous dylt-1 deletion mutants did not exhibit any larval or embryonic lethality (Figure 8C).</Species>

<Species>To determine if these dynein light chain mutants exhibit dynein HC-like phenotypes, we observed the completion of meiotic polar body extrusion and the first two mitotic cell divisions in mutant embryos (Figure 8D).</Species>
<Species>The dylt-1 embryos appeared wild type for completion of meiosis, pronuclear migration, and spindle assembly and function.</Species>

<Species>However, the dyrb-1 embryos occasionally contained extra female pronuclei (observed in four of 12 recordings, Figure 8D), suggesting that polar body extrusion was defective, and pronuclear migration was often slow compared to wild-type embryos.</Species>

<Species>Once formed, spindles appeared functional using Nomarski optics, although they were frequently positioned improperly and had large spindle poles, as has also been observed after RNAi knockdown</Species>
<Species>[12].</Species>
<Species>Thus, these two genes are not strictly essential, but the DYRB-1 protein clearly is required for dynein-dependent processes.</Species>

<Species>Discussion By using the suppressor screening method outlined in Figure 2B, we have isolated and characterized 49 genes that when reduced in function can suppress a partial loss of dynein HC function.</Species>

<Species>This screening procedure takes advantage of sensitized genetic backgrounds using conditional mutants, can be completed for one mutant in less than 5 wk, and is scalable so that many mutants can be screened in parallel.</Species>
<Species>In fact, we have performed 15 such screens in different sensitized backgrounds (unpublished data).</Species>

<Species>By using three dhc-1ts mutant strains, we found that strain background differences and allele specificity are minimal because most of these genes suppress all three dynein mutants when reduced in function using RNAi.</Species>
<Species>Furthermore, by using two unrelated ts mutants to assay for specificity, we found that 57% of the suppressor genes suppress multiple unrelated mutant loci.</Species>
<Species>Thus, it is clear that assaying the specificity of suppression is critical for evaluating the functional significance of these RNAi interactions.</Species>
<Species>Eliminating the analysis of these nonspecific genes in future screens will save time and resources.</Species>

<Species>Most of the specific suppressor proteins we examined appear to overlap in subcellular localization with the dynein HC, based on previous studies of DHC-1, while one nonspecific suppressor protein, STAR-2, localized to germline P-granules, where dynein is not known to function.</Species>
<Species>Many of the 20 genes that specifically suppress multiple dhc-1ts alleles are nonessential in C. elegans but well conserved nonetheless.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Six of eight deletion alleles available for the 20 specific suppressor genes are homozygous viable, and six additional specific genes do not display lethal phenotypes when reduced in function by RNAi in wild-type worms [29].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Thus, our genetic screening has identified roles in an essential process for at least 12 apparently nonessential genes.</Species>

<Species>Fourteen of the specific dynein suppressor genes have human orthologs as determined by best reciprocal BLAST hits (Table 1), while mop-25.2 has a conserved human homolog but also a paralog in C. elegans.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Eleven of these conserved genes are nonessential in C. elegans.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Interestingly, eight of the conserved genes in Table 1 have been implicated in human disease etiology, with three of them identified as the causative gene [39-41].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Thus, using sensitized genetic backgrounds for genome-wide modifier screens can identify roles for nonessential but conserved genes and thereby provide insights into human disease.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Nonspecific Suppression of Conditional Mutants We examined the predicted molecular functions of the suppressor proteins to better understand the basis for the nonspecific suppression phenomenon.</Species>

<Species>Strikingly, many of the nonspecific suppressor genes encode proteins with predicted roles in mitochondrial, ribosomal, and collagen function (18 of 29 genes, or 62%), while only two such genes appeared to specifically suppress dhc-1 (2 of 20 genes or 10%).</Species>
<Species>It is possible that stress produced by RNAi knockdown of these suppressor genes triggers the activity of molecular chaperones that can generally restore function to ts proteins.</Species>
<Species>Indeed, mutation of dpy-10 is known to suppress three other ts mutants: glp-1, emb-5, and mup-1 [42-44].</Species>

<Species>Furthermore, RNAi reduction of dpy-10, star-2, osr-1, or C50D2.1 (all suppressors of dhc-1, lit-1, and spn-4 ts alleles) induces the glycerol biosynthetic gene gpdh-2, while dpy-10 and osr-1 mutants exhibit increased glycerol levels, a condition that promotes protein stability</Species>
<Species>[45].</Species>
<Species>We suggest that partial loss of central metabolic processes can invoke stress responses that nonspecifically alleviate protein-folding problems in ts proteins.</Species>

<Species>Filtering out these nonspecific interactions by testing unrelated conditional mutants increases the likelihood that the remaining suppressor genes are more directly involved with dynein function.</Species>

<Species>However, ts mutants likely differ in their susceptibility to nonspecific suppression mechanisms, and some apparently unrelated ts mutants might share common cofactors such that both mutants are suppressed by depletion of the same cofactor.</Species>
<Species>Nevertheless, we expect that more extensive testing for specificity will prove very useful for judging the significance of modifier interactions.</Species>

<Species>Possible Relevance of Suppressor Proteins to Dynein Function We examined the localization of a number of GFP fusions to suppressor proteins to gain insight into their functional relationship to dynein.</Species>

<Species>In several cases, the subcellular distribution of the suppressor proteins overlapped in different ways with the known and nearly ubiquitous distribution of cytoplasmic dynein in the early C. elegans embryo.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In fact, the only specific suppressor that did not display dynein-like localization was F10E7.8, a homolog of yeast Far11 of unknown function [46], which was nuclear.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The one nonspecific suppressor protein we examined did not show any dynein-like localization patterns.</Species>
<Species>The subcellular localizations of the GFP::suppressor protein fusions are intriguing.</Species>

<Species>However, given the nearly ubiquitous distribution of dynein in early embryonic cells, biochemical tests for direct association are needed to address the significance of any colocalization detected using light microscopy.</Species>

<Species>We are particularly interested in suppressor proteins that localize to mitotic spindle poles: the association of the DYLT-1 and DYRB-1 predicted dynein light chains with centrosomes and spindle poles suggests that they may be components of cytoplasmic dynein in C. elegans.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Localization of cytoplasmic dynein to centrosomes and spindle poles is well established [47,48], and the inhibition of dynein function prevents centrosome separation, centrosome attachment to nuclei, and the formation of bipolar spindles [6,10,49,50].</Species>

<Species>Moreover, the centrosomal localization of DHC-1, DYLT-1, and DYRB-1 are all greatly enhanced in dhc-1ts mutant embryos: this dependence of the light chain distribution on the HC further suggests they reside in the same motor complex (Figure 7 and</Species>
<Species>[10]).</Species>
<Species>Furthermore, roadblock light chains are well-established components of dynein, and all of the roadblock protein in mammalian liver extracts is dynein associated [51,52].</Species>
<Species>Finally, a DYLT-1 homolog in vertebrates is a stoichiometric subunit of cytoplasmic dynein [53].</Species>
<Species>The presence of these two light chains in a dynein complex is consistent with them having either positive or negative roles in the regulation of HC function (see below).</Species>

<Species>Cytoplasmic dynein is found on the nuclear envelope where it is thought to regulate nuclear membrane breakdown during mitosis [54], and dynein plays roles during the trafficking of endoplasmic reticulum components [55,56].</Species>
<Species>Therefore, the nuclear envelope/endoplasmic reticulum proteins NPP-22 and K04F10.3 could couple dynein activity to either of these structures.</Species>
<Species>The anc-1 gene was also isolated in our screening and ANC-1 is localized to the nuclear envelope where it maintains nuclear positioning in postembryonic cells [57].</Species>

<Species>Reducing the function of these three genes may suppress partial loss of dynein HC mutants by reducing the need for dynein during nuclear envelope breakdown, through constitutive partial destabilization of the nuclear envelope.</Species>

<Species>The distribution of the cytoplasmic dynein HC includes sites other than spindle poles and nuclear envelopes in C. elegans, for example, at the cell cortex and at the cell division remnant called the midbody [6,10].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The MOP-25.2 protein was found at the midbody and faintly at spindle poles.</Species>
<Species>The MOP-25.2 ortholog in S. pombe, Pmo25, is also present at the cell division site and on spindle poles [58].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Mammalian MOP-25.2 homologs stimulate the kinase activity of the LKB1 tumor suppressor (the C. elegans ortholog is PAR-4), which in turn activates MARK microtubule-destabilizing kinases [59,60].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The C. elegans MARK ortholog, PAR-1, controls cell polarity during embryogenesis, and orthologs have been implicated in regulation of microtubule dynamics from yeast to humans</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>[61-64].</Species>
<Species>Lastly, the two splice isoforms of EFA-6 were associated with the anterior cell cortex in late one-cell embryos.</Species>

<Species>Cortically localized dynein may have important roles in applying forces to astral microtubules that influence mitotic spindle positioning and chromosome separation during anaphase [10,65,66].</Species>

<Species>EFA6 ARF guanine nucleotide exchange factors require their pleckstrin homology domain for cortical targeting, and are known to regulate cortical actin dynamics in vertebrate cells by promoting guanine nucleotide exchange on ARF6 [67,68].</Species>
<Species>Our results identifying efa-6 as a dynein HC suppressor suggest a functional linkage of the actin and microtubule cytoskeletons at the cell cortex.</Species>

<Species>Interestingly, two yeast pleckstrin homology domain proteins, Num1 and mcp5+, localize to the cell cortex and direct astral microtubule and dynein function, although they do not contain a Sec7 domain like EFA-6 does</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>[69-71].</Species>
<Species>Function of Dynein Intermediate, Light Intermediate, and Light Chains The dynein chains in C. elegans exhibit strikingly different functional requirements.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The DYRB-1 roadblock light chain is required for completion of meiosis and pronuclear migration, but an at least partially functional mitotic spindle forms in the absence of DYRB-1 (Figure 8).</Species>

<Species>The DLI-1 light intermediate chain is required for multiple dynein-dependent functions: pronuclear migration, centrosome separation, and meiotic and mitotic spindle function [12,34].</Species>
<Species>DLI-1 may promote nuclear envelope targeting of both centrosomes and DHC-1 by interacting with the nuclear envelope protein ZYG-12 [35].</Species>
<Species>The second worm light intermediate chain gene, xbx-1, is required for cilia function but not early embryonic development</Species>
<Species>[12,72].</Species>

<Species>RNAi knockdown of DLC-1, one of three LC8 proteins in C. elegans, produces defects similar to dli-1 but knockdown of the other two LC8-related genes does not result in any phenotypes [12].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>RNAi depletion of dyci-1 results in severe meiotic, pronuclear migration, and mitotic spindle assembly defects [12] and in our feeding RNAi regimen dyci-1(RNAi) produces a larval arrest phenotype similar to that observed for dhc-1.</Species>
<Species>Finally, the three Tctex1 proteins in C. elegans, DYLT-1, 2, and 3, are not essential for dynein-related functions [12].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>As the dyrb-1, dlc-1, and dli-1 dynein AC genes display some dhc-1-like requirements, they positively influence dynein function.</Species>
<Species>However, because reducing their function suppresses dhc-1ts mutants, they may also exert negative regulation (along with dylt-1) on the heavy chain.</Species>

<Species>Negative Regulation of Dynein HC by Light Chain Subunits Finding that reducing the function of light and light intermediate dynein chains suppressed the partial loss of HC function was a striking result.</Species>
<Species>One member of each of four subunit classes can suppress the embryonic lethality associated with three dhc-1 ts mutants (Figure 5).</Species>
<Species>We have considered two different models to explain how RNAi-mediated depletion of these dynein ACs can suppress reduced HC function.</Species>
<Species>First, these dynein subunits could be in functional complexes with, and exert negative regulation on, the DHC-1 HC (Figure 5B).</Species>
<Species>The suppression mechanism in this case proposes that removal of the suppressing ACs increases residual mutant DHC-1 activity.</Species>
<Species>The other, nonsuppressing, accessory subunits might then function in nonmitotic cellular processes such as neuronal transport or organelle positioning.</Species>

<Species>In support of this view, physical removal of the intermediate chains of rat cytoplasmic dynein increased HC ATPase activity by about 4-fold (light chains were not monitored in this study but were likely removed as well)</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>[73].</Species>
<Species>Thus, at least with respect to ATPase activity, some dynein ACs do act as biochemical negative regulators of HC function.</Species>

<Species>An Assortment of Essential and Nonessential Dynein Complexes Alternatively, an assortment of dynein complexes (with different ACs) could coexist within early embryonic cells, with only a subset required for the essential mitotic functions that require DHC-1.</Species>

<Species>In this case, suppression might result from the release of DHC-1 HCs from less essential motor complexes, allowing more of the functionally compromised HCs to participate in the essential process of mitosis.</Species>

<Species>We currently disfavor this hypothesis because two of the suppressing light chains (DYLT-1 and DYRB-1) can indeed localize to meiotic and mitotic spindles (Figures 6 and 7), sites where DHC-1 has been shown by others to localize and function.</Species>

<Species>Furthermore, the distribution of DYRB-1 and DYLT-1 closely resembles the distribution of the HC in dhc-1(or195) embryos, suggesting that these two light chains associate with the HC during mitosis (Figure 7 and [10]).</Species>

<Species>Finally, dhc-1-like phenotypes result from mutation or RNAi knockdown of three suppressing ACs in otherwise wild-type worms, indicating that they share at least some common and essential requirements.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Regardless of the suppression mechanism, our identification of ACs that genetically interact with the DHC-1 HC provides a basis for functionally classifying the paralogs of these dynein subunit gene families, and for further investigation of dynein composition and function.</Species>

<Species>Nonessential Dynein Subunits and Negative Regulation of the HC Some ACs are nonessential, supporting the view that some cytoplasmic dynein subunits could function by exerting negative regulation on the HC, rather than positively influencing essential HC function.</Species>

<Species>For example, DYRB-1 is not absolutely required for viability because worms lacking this protein can be propagated, although they are extremely sick and do exhibit two dhc-1-like phenotypes (Figure 8).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Also, homozygous dylt-1 deletion mutants appear fully viable (Figure 8).</Species>

<Species>The two additional Tctex1 C. elegans genes could be functionally redundant with DYLT-1, but simultaneously reducing the function of DYLT-2 and DYLT-3 by RNAi in the dylt-1 deletion strain did not cause lethality (unpublished data).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Because RNAi does not always completely reduce function, the question of redundancy in the Tctex1 C. elegans gene family remains unresolved.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>However, Drosophila contains only a single Tctex1 gene, Dlc90F</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>[74,75].</Species>

<Species>A Dlc90F null allele that deletes 80% of the open reading frame is essential only for sperm production but not for viability of male or female flies, despite the wild-type protein being incorporated into dynein motors and expressed in various Drosophila tissues [74].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Thus, at least in Drosophila, the Tctex1 dynein light chain family is not required for cell division processes like the HC is.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Interestingly, budding yeast does not possess genes for the Tctex1 or roadblock ACs, indicating that functional cytoplasmic dynein does not require these subunits that are conserved in many other organisms.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The AC genes that yeast does posses are not required for HC motility in vitro because dynein purified from yeast with mutations in these genes remains fully active</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>[2].</Species>
<Species>Thus, dynein function in several contexts does not require AC subunits, and we suggest that in some cases they may have negative regulatory roles.</Species>
<Species>Negative regulation of cytoplasmic dynein may be redundant with other modes of HC regulation or only required during special circumstances.</Species>
<Species>Further studies of subunit localization, and in vitro studies of C. elegans dynein motility, may provide further insight into the modes of AC regulation and function.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Materials and Methods C. elegans strains and culture.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Strains were cultured according to standard procedures [28].</Species>
<Species>ts mutants were maintained at 15 oC and GFP-expressing strains in a wild-type background were maintained in a 23 oC incubator.</Species>
<Species>dhc-1(or195) was outcrossed six times to the N2 Bristol wild-type strain and the or283 and or352 dhc-1 mutants were each outcrossed four times with N2.</Species>

<Species>For sequencing mutant dhc-1 loci, genomic DNA was amplified as overlapping  1-kb fragments from the start codon to the stop codon and sequenced at the University of Oregon DNA sequencing laboratory.</Species>

<Species>For double mutant constructions, the dhc-1(or195) mutation was monitored by sequencing or by assaying a restriction fragment length polymorphism caused by the mutation with Hpy188I (New England Biolabs, http://www.neb.com), following PCR amplification of the mutated region.</Species>

<Species>The dylt-1(ok417) and ufd-2(tm1380) alleles were monitored by PCR amplification of genomic sequence encompassing the deletions and assaying product size by agarose gel electrophoresis.</Species>
<Species>GFP imaging.</Species>
<Species>Visualization of GFP fusion protein localization was accomplished by mounting embryos on M9 + 3% agarose pads on microscope slides covered with a coverslip.</Species>

<Species>Time-lapse videos were obtained on a spinning disk Nikon Eclipse TE2000-U microscope (Nikon Instruments, http://www.nikon.com) fitted with an ORCA-ER digital camera (Hamamatsu Photonics, http://www.hamamatsu.com) using a Nikon 60x, 1.4 NA Plan Apo oil objective lens.</Species>
<Species>Videos were adjusted for contrast in ImageJ (National Institutes of Health, http://rsb.info.nih.gov/ij/)</Species>
<Species>[76], images were adjusted for levels in Adobe Photoshop (http://www.adobe.com/).</Species>
<Species>RNAi screening.</Species>
<Species>After obtaining the E. coli RNAi library from the MRC Geneservice (Cambridge, UK)</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>[17,19], we rearrayed it into a 48-well microplate format using a liquid-handling Qiagen BioRobot 8000 (http://www.qiagen.com).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>E. coli strains were thawed from    80 oC storage and inoculated into 1 ml of LB + 100 mg/ml ampicillin-containing 96-well growth plates (Whatman, http://www.whatman.com) and covered with microporous sealing film (USA Scientific, http://www.usascientific.com).</Species>
<Species>Only 48 wells of the 96-well growth plates were filled with media, corresponding to the rearrayed E. coli library.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>After overnight shaking incubation at 37 oC, 20 ul of the cultures were dispensed with a 24-channel electronic repeating pipette (Rainin, http://www.rainin.com) onto 48-well plates (Nunc, http://www.nuncbrand.com/) containing NGM agar, 100 ug/ml ampicillin, and 1 mM IPTG and allowed to dry and induce dsRNA at 37 oC overnight.</Species>

<Species>The 48-well agar plates were filled with a Wheaton Unispense peristaltic pump (http://www.wheaton.com) equipped with a custom-made adaptor (University of Oregon Technical Science Administration) that allowed simultaneous filling of eight wells with the agar solution.</Species>
<Species>Approximately 15 hypochlorite-synchronized L1 mutant larvae were pipetted into each well of the 48-well plates with a multichannel pipette and allowed to produce broods.</Species>
<Species>Screening for F1 viability was performed by visual examination with a dissecting microscope.</Species>
<Species>Phenotypes were recorded on an Excel spreadsheet (http://www.microsoft.com) and organized in a FileMaker Pro (http://www.filemaker.com) database.</Species>

<Species>We qualitatively identified 295 initial positive suppressing E. coli strains, for which we repeated the assay on 60-mm plates with E. coli again thawed from the library (not streak purified).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>If the observed phenotypes reproduced, the assay was performed with three streak-purified E. coli colonies, and a single isolate that again displayed the interaction was kept for further analysis.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Embryonic viability quantitation methods.</Species>
<Species>To quantitate embryonic viability we used the following procedure.</Species>
<Species>Cultures of dsRNA-producing bacteria were grown overnight in LB + 100 ug/ml ampicillin.</Species>
<Species>Cultures (0.2 ml) were seeded onto 60-mm NGM agar plates containing 100 ug/ml ampicillin and 1 mM IPTG and allowed to induce dsRNAs overnight at room temperature.</Species>

<Species>The L4440 control vector-containing strain was used as the bacterial lawn for the experiments shown in Figures 2A and 3B. Approximately 80 synchronized L1 larvae (obtained from hypochlorite-treated worms) were pipetted onto the plates and allowed to grow to young adulthood.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Five gravid worms were transferred to prepared NGM agar plates supplemented with 100 ug/ml ampicillin and 1 mM IPTG containing a small RNAi bacterial lawn produced from  5 ul of overnight E. coli culture.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>After producing broods, the adult worms were removed and the embryos were allowed to develop for at least 24 h. Embryos and larvae were then counted immediately or after storage at 4 oC.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We considered only suppressor dsRNAs that increased embryonic viability greater than 3-fold above the background viability observed with the L4440 control vector (in the dhc-1(or195)) screen to be significant enough for continued study.</Species>
<Species>Molecular biology.</Species>

<Species>We introduced a polylinker site containing six unique restriction enzyme recognition sites into the pIC26 GFP-S protein plasmid by using phosphorylated and PAGE-purified synthetic oligonucleotides [77].</Species>
<Species>Following ligation, the new plasmid was sequence verified.</Species>
<Species>The modified vector, pSO26, allows the use of additional restriction enzymes and directional cloning for inserting genes of interest (Figure S2).</Species>
<Species>The SpeI site was recreated at the 5    end of the polylinker but not at the 3    end.</Species>

<Species>We amplified N2 genomic DNA or cDNA (Invitrogen, http://www.invitrogen.com) with Pfu Turbo polymerase (Stratagene, http://www.stratagene.com), and cloned A-tailed PCR products into either pGEM-T or pGEM-T-easy shuttle vectors (Promega, http://www.promega.com).</Species>

<Species>Inserted genes were sequence verified at the University of Oregon DNA sequencing laboratory prior to cleavage and ligation to pSO26 (see Table S3 for restriction sites and primer sequences used).</Species>

<Species>All of the constructs used in this study were cloned as SpeI-AsiSI or AscI-AsiSI fragments, except for the STAR-2 gene, which was amplified as a SpeI fragment and cloned into pIC26.</Species>

<Species>To construct dynein subunit dsRNA-expressing plasmids not available in the RNAi library, gene fragments were amplified from N2 genomic DNA with the following primers: F41G4.1: 5   -AAGATATCACCCAAAATGGTCCAAAACAAAG-3    and 5   -CGGATATCTCGACTGAAGCTGGTTCTGA-3   , xbx-1: 5   -AAGATATCTACGACGATGGAAGTTTGAAG-3    and 5   -CGGATATCCGTGCCTCTGCAGC-3   , dlc-3: 5   -AAGATATCAATTTCAGGTGGACACTGGC-3    and 5   -CGGATATCAGCACACTTGCATCATCTGAA-3   .</Species>
<Species>The PCR products were cut with EcoRV, ligated to EcoRV-digested L4440, and sequence verified.</Species>

<Species>Non-Unc worms were picked to new plates and allowed to produce broods, which were assayed for GFP fluorescence with a Zeiss axioskop microscope (http://www.zeiss.com/) fitted with an X-Cite 120 illumination system (EXFO life sciences, Mississauga, Ontario, Canada).</Species>

<Species>Structural organization of a 17 KB segment of the alpha 2 collagen gene: evaluation by R loop mapping.</Species>

<Species>Abstract A recombinant phage, SpC3, containing a 17 kb genomic DNA insert representing approximately 60% of the 3' portion of the sheep collagen alpha 2 gene, was evaluated by electron microscopic R loop analysis.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>A minimum of 17 intervening sequences (introns) and 18 alpha 2 coding sequences (exons) were mapped.</Species>
<Species>With the exception of the 850 base pair exon located at the extreme 3' end of the insert, all exons contained 250 base pairs or less.</Species>
<Species>The total length of all the exons in SpC3 was 3,014 base pairs.</Species>
<Species>The length distribution of the 17 introns ranged from 300 to 1600 base pairs; together, all of the introns comprised 14,070 base pairs of SpC3 DNA.</Species>
<Species>Thus, the DNA region required for coding the interspersed 3 kb of alpha 2 collagen genetic information was 5.6 fold longer than the corresponding alpha 2 mRNA coding sequences.</Species>

<Species>Images Nucleic Acids Research Structural organization of a 17 KB segment of the a2 collagen gene: evaluation by R loop mapping Millie P.Schafer, Charles D.Boyd, Paul Tolstoshev and Ronald G.Crystal Pulmonary Branch, National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute, National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, MD 20205, USA Received 13 February 1980</Species>

<Species>ABSTRACT A recombinant phage, SpC3, containing a 17 kb genomic DNA insert rep resenting approximately 60% of the 3' portion of the sheep collagen a2 gene, was evaluated by electron microscopic R loop analysis.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>A minimum of 17 intervening sequences (introns) and 18 a2 coding sequences (exons) were mapped.</Species>
<Species>With the exception of the 850 base pair exon located at the extreme 3' end of the insert, all exons contained 250 base pairs or less.</Species>
<Species>The total length of all the exons in SpC3 was 3,014 base pairs.</Species>
<Species>The length distribution of the 17 introns ranged from 300 to 1600 base pairs; together, all of the introns comprised 14,070 base pairs of SpC3 DNA.</Species>
<Species>Thus, the DNA region required for coding the interspersed 3 kb of a2 collagen genetic information was 5.6 fold longer than the corresponding a2 mRNA coding sequences.</Species>
<Species>INTRODUCTION Type I collagen, composed of two al(I) and one a2 polypeptide chains, is the most abundant of the five known mammalian collagen types.</Species>

<Species>It is a major extracellular constituent of tissues such as bone, tendon, skin and lung where, because of its great tensile strength, it plays an important role in tissue structure and function.</Species>

<Species>The polypeptides comprising type I collagen are synthesized in long, precursor forms, referred to as pro al(I) and pro a2 chains,1 each containing approximately 1500 amino acid residues (1).</Species>
<Species>1</Species>
<Species>The terminology for the primary translation products of the various collagen messenger RNAs is still in a state of flux.</Species>
<Species>It is known that al(I) and a2 chains are synthesized in precursor forms; these are currently termed pro al(I) and pro a2 chains (1).</Species>

<Species>However, recent studies (43,44) have shown that the actual primary translation product of al(I) mRNA is somewhat larger than the pro al(I) chain; this translation product has been termed a "pre-pro al(I) chain."</Species>
<Species>Although the corresponding "pre-pro a2 chain" likely exists, it has not yet been characterized.</Species>

<Species>For simplicity, therefore, until the proper terminology for the primary translation product is clarified, we have chosen to use the terms "al(I)" and "a2" to refer to the type I collagen mRNAs and collagen structural gene sequences. ?)</Species>

<Species>IRL Press Umited, 1 Falconberg Court, London W1V 5FG, U.K. Volurne 8 Number 10 1980 2241 Nucleic Acids Research There is increasing evidence that the quantities of al(I) and a2 chains produced by cells may be regulated, in part, at the genomic level (1).</Species>

<Species>However, to understand the processes which mediate their expression, it is necessary to understand the structural organization of these collagen genes and the various enzymes that modify the collagen chains after its synthesis (1).</Species>
<Species>As an initial approach to this problem, we have recently isolated a recombinant bacteriophage, termed SpC3, containing approximately 60% of the a2 gene for type I collagen.</Species>

<Species>Partial characterization of this a2 gene demonstrated that, like most other structurally evaluated eukaryotic genes, the coding sequences are interspersed with intervening sequences (2).</Species>

<Species>The present study further characterizes this portion of the a2 gene by utilizing electron microscopic R loop analysis to map the coding regions (exons) and intervening sequences (introns) contained within the sheep genomic insert of SpC3.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The data suggests that the structural organization of this portion of the a2 collagen gene represents 3 kb of coding information that is interspersed in a complex fashion with 17 introns over 17 kb of genome.</Species>
<Species>MATERIALS AND METHODS Isolation and characterization of a2 collagen recombinant clone, SpC3.</Species>
<Species>The sheep a2 collagen recombinant clone, SpC3, containing a portion of the sheep a2 gene, was isolated as previously described (2).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Briefly, high molecular weight fetal sheep liver DNA was extracted by the method of Blin and Stafford (3), and 15-20 kb DNA fragments, resulting from partial Eco RI digestion, were isolated and ligated to the left and right arms of Charon 4A. The recombinant DNA was then packaged in vitro and the sheep genomic library amplified (4-6).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Screening of the sheep genomic library was conducted utilizing [32 P]-labeled fetal sheep tendon type I collagen cDNA and several positive recombinant phages were isolated.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>One recombinant, containing a 17 kb sheep genomic insert, was demonstrated to have coding sequences corresponding to 60% of the 3' end of a2 mRNA.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Prior studies showed that the insert in SpC3 was not due to ligation of noncontiguous restriction fragments and/or genetic rearrangement during the cloning process (2).</Species>
<Species>Electron mi croscopy.</Species>

<Species>To visualize the recombinant bacteriophage DNA structure complementary to a2 collagen mRNA, 1 iig of SpC3 DNA was lyophilized with 1 ig or 100 ng of mRNA to give DNA:mRNA ratios of 1:1 and 10:1, respectively.</Species>

<Species>These were then dissolved in 10 i1 of R loop buffer [70% (v/v) deionized formamide, 0.1 N-[tris (hydroxy 2242 Nucleic Acids Research methyl)methyl] glycine (tricine)-NaOH, pH 8.0, 0.5 M NaCl, and 0.01 M ethyl enediaminetetraacetate (EDTA)], incubated in sealed capillary tubes at 520 for 14 hr (7), and then diluted 1:10 with R loop buffer.</Species>
<Species>Two spreading methods were used to subsequently prepare the hybrids for visualization in the electron microscope.</Species>
<Species>70% formamide method.</Species>
<Species>Immediately before spreading onto a deionized water hypophase, the nucleic acid mixtures were diluted an additional 10-fold in R loop buffer and cytochrome c, 100 vg/ml, was added.</Species>
<Species>Urea-formamide method.</Species>
<Species>The nucleic acid solutions were spread using a modification of the method of Westphal and Lai (8,9).</Species>
<Species>The hyperphase contained 55% formamide, 2.6 M urea, 0.009 M EDTA, 0.09 M tricine-NaOH, pH 8.0, and the nucleic acid mixture (approximately 0.1 to 1.0 ig/ml).</Species>
<Species>The mixture was heated at 40?</Species>
<Species>for 30 sec, placed in ice water, and then allowed to reach room temperature.</Species>
<Species>Cytochrome c, 100 pg/ml, was added immediately before spreading onto a deionized water hypophase.</Species>

<Species>The nucleic acid-protein films from both methods were absorbed onto parlodion-coated grids, stained with uranyl acetate (10), dehydrated in 90% ethanol and rotary-shadowed with platinum-palladium (80:20) at an angle of 50.</Species>
<Species>Micrographs were taken with a Siemens Elmiskop 101 electron microscope at an original magnification of 10,000 and an accelerating voltage of 60 kv.</Species>

<Species>Nucleic acid lengths were measured at a final magnification of 43,000 with a Hewlett-Packard 9810A calculator equipped with a 9864A digitizer using pBR322 and fX-174 double and single stranded DNA, respectively, as internal length standards.</Species>
<Species>Approximately 10,000 hybrid molecules were screened for these studies; approximately 200 represented molecules containing unambiguous regions appropriate for quantitative analysis.</Species>
<Species>The mean lengths of each intron and exon were determined for each method and the data expressed as mean ?</Species>
<Species>standard deviation.</Species>
<Species>Nucleic acid lengths of < 50 base pairs could not be accurately determined using the methods outlined above.</Species>
<Species>Thus, in the cases where introns or exons were of this length or less, accurate error estimates could not be made.</Species>
<Species>Bi ohazard precauti ons.</Species>

<Species>The construction and screening of the sheep genomic library together with amplification of pCg45 and preparation of high titre lysates of chimaeric Charon 4A were performed under the physical and biological containment levels specified by the NIH guidelines for recombinant DNA research (11).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>2243 Nucleic Acids Research RESULTS Location and orientation of the intervening and a2 mRNA coding sequences in the SpC3 recombinant DNA.</Species>

<Species>Hybridization of fetal sheep tendon type I collagen mRNA to SpC3 DNA yielded a complex R loop pattern in the region where the sheep genomic insert was expected to be ligated to the arms of the lambda vector, Charon 4A. To confirm that these hybridization events were restricted to the inserted sheep DNA fragment, duplex DNA strands on both sides of this hybridization area were measured.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Using pBR322 as an internal length standard, the left arm of the phage was found to contain 21,780 ? 1500 bp, and the right arm, 11,950 ?</Species>
<Species>1030 bp, corresponding to the report values for the left and right arms, respectively, of Charon 4A DNA (5,6).</Species>
<Species>The hybridization of SpC3 to a2 mRNA resulted in the destabilization of the inserted helical duplex DNA fragment such that one DNA strand was displaced (Figure 1).</Species>
<Species>Occasionally, the displaced DNA strand was mostly absent, probably due to fragmentation induced by accidental mechanical shearing.</Species>
<Species>This event considerably enhanced the visualization and ordering of the introns.</Species>
<Species>As the a2 mRNA annealed to complementary DNA regions present in one DNA strand, numerous single-stranded loops resulted.</Species>
<Species>These loops, referred to as introns, represented DNA sequences not complementary to the mRNA.</Species>

<Species>Although, by convention, introns are usually sequentially labeled 5' to 3', an opposite order had to be employed in this case as SpC3 does not contain the sequences coding for the 5' end of sheep a2 mRNA.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Infrequently, all introns were clearly observed within the same hybrid molecule (Figure 1).</Species>
<Species>The largest introns were towards the left arm of Charon 4A and were more clustered than the introns at the opposite end of the hybrid.</Species>
<Species>Thus, much of the genetic information coding for the a2 mRNA was contained in that half of the hybrid attached to the right arm.</Species>
<Species>A small non-hybridized tail was consistently found in the region where the right arm of the phage was ligated to the sheep genomic insert (Figure 1).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>This tail likely corresponded to the 3' poly A sequence of the a2 mRNA.</Species>
<Species>At the extreme 5' end of the insert, a variable length was often observed for the remaining unhybridized mRNA strand.</Species>
<Species>This was most likely due to the size heterogeneity of the a2 mRNA used in these studies.</Species>
<Species>Size determination and comparative analysis of SpC3 introns.</Species>

<Species>The maps of the a2 collagen gene obtained with both electron micro scopic spreading methods were almost identical (Figure 3), except that the region at the extreme 5' end of the insert could only be mapped with the ureaformamide method.</Species>
<Species>From these measurements we concluded that the length of the a2 collagen genetic regi?on in SpC3 was 17,084 bases long with only 3,014 bases actually coding for a2 mRNA.</Species>
<Species>Therefore, only 18% of the mapped 17 kb sheep genetic insert actually contained a2 structural information.</Species>

text: <Species>DISCUSSION</Species>
<Species>The organizational structure of the a2 collagen gene is complex.</Species>
<Species>A minimum of 17 introns interrupt the 3 kb of ca2 genetic information interspersed as 18 exons over 17 kb of sheep DNA.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>With the exception of exon "a" located at the extreme 3' end of the inserted a2 gene, all other mapped exons are rather small, exhibiting a size distribution range of 50 to 250 bp.</Species>
<Species>In contrast, the intron sizes range from 340 to 1540 bases occupying a total of 14 kb.</Species>
<Species>Thus, the DNA region containing the 3 kb of a2 collagen genetic information is 5.6 fold longer than the corresponding co2 mRNA sequences.</Species>
<Species>Although the total number of introns present within the 60% 3' portion of the a2 sheep gene was determined to be 17, variation in the precise number TRANSRIPTlO</Species>

<Species>The reason for this may be due to size heterogeneity of the a2 mRNA used as a complementary probe.</Species>
<Species>Although the a2 mRNA was extensively purified (2), some degradation was likely present.</Species>
<Species>It is also possible that additional introns exist that are too small to be detected by electron microscopic R loop analysis.</Species>
<Species>The most likely a2 genetic regions containing such introns are exons "g" and "m".</Species>
<Species>Small "protrusions" were sometimes observed within these exons that could represent small introns.</Species>

<Species>Very small introns have been reported for tRNA genes (12,13), and it will be necessary to sequence these regions of SpC3 to determine if such introns are present within the a2 sheep genome.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The existence of mRNAs comprised of sequences complementary to noncontiguous regions in a DNA genome was first described for adenovirus (14,15) and simian virus (16,17) genes.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Similar observations were soon reported for eukaryotic genes, including serum albumin (18), conalbumin (19), fibroin (20), s globin (21,22), growth hormones (23,24), immunoglobulin (25), lysozyme (26), ovalbumin (27-29), ovomucoid (30), rRNA (31-34), tRNA (12,13), and vitellogenin (35).</Species>
<Species>The precise number or occurrence of introns within these genes does not seem to follow any clear pattern.</Species>
<Species>However, the genes for albumin, conalbumin, lysozyme, ovalbumin, and ovomucoid exhibit a structural organization comparable to the a2 collagen gene.</Species>
<Species>All of these genes are composed of numerous small exons, usually less than 250 base pairs, and introns which show a large size variation within an individual gene.</Species>
<Species>Within all of these genomes, the DNA regions required for coding structural formation are 4 to 7 times longer than the corresponding mRNA coding sequences.</Species>
<Species>As with the a2 collagen gene, a large unique exon at the extreme 3' end is also present in the ovalbumin gene (36,37).</Species>
<Species>In the a2 gene, this exon was 800 to 900 nucleotides in length, while in the ovalbumin gene the exon contained 1,030 base pairs.</Species>

<Species>Interestingly, this ovalbumin exon contained 634-650 base pairs ot DNA sequence to the 3' side of the terminator triplet, suggesting the ovalbumin mRNA has a large untranslated region at the 3' end.</Species>

<Species>The consistent appearance of a small non-hybridized tail, approximately 100 nucleotides in length, in the region where the right arm of the phage was ligated to the sheep genomic insert of SpC3 very likely corresponded to the 3' poly A sequence of the a2 mRNA.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>This would suggest that the a2 mRNA coding sequence terminates very near or at this point in the genome.</Species>

<Species>Previously published biochemical evidence (2) obtained from restriction mapping and Southern blot analysis using [32P]-labeled chick a2 cDNA probe supports 2250 Nucleic Acids Research this observation.</Species>
<Species>It is unclear what role introns play in genetic expression.</Species>

<Species>However, it is known that these sequences are tranncribed as part of larger precursor mRNAs and the introns are then excised and the fragmented mRNA chains covalently rejoined (38).</Species>
<Species>Some evidence has recently accumulated demonstrating the existence of precursor a2 mRNAs (39,40).</Species>

<Species>However, if the introns in the a2 gene are transcribed in their entirety, as has been demonstrated for the introns in ovalbumin and globin (41,42), much larger precursor a2 mRNAs may exist than those reported to date.</Species>

<Species>For if the re mainder of the a2 collagen gene has a structural organization comparable to the 60% 3' portion that has been analyzed, it is probable that the a2 collagen gene in its entirety is dispersed throughout a 30 kb DNA segment.</Species>

<Species>p8 inhibits the growth of human pancreatic cancer cells and its expression is induced through pathways involved in growth inhibition and repressed by factors promoting cell growth</Species>

text: <Species>Abstract Background p8 is a stress-induced protein with multiple functions and biochemically related to the architectural factor HMG-I/Y. We analyzed the expression and function of p8 in pancreatic cancer-derived cells.</Species>
<Species>Methods Expression of p8 was silenced in the human pancreatic cancer cell lines Panc-1 and BxPc-3 by infection with a retrovirus expressing p8 RNA in the antisense orientation.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Cell growth was measured in control and p8-silenced cells.</Species>
<Species>Influence on p8 expression of the induction of intracellular pathways promoting cellular growth or growth arrest was monitored.</Species>
<Species>Results p8-silenced cells grew more rapidly than control cells transfected with the empty retrovirus.</Species>
<Species>Activation of the Ras>Raf>MEK>ERK and JNK intracellular pathways down-regulated p8 expression.</Species>
<Species>In addition, the MEK1/2 inhibitor U0126 and the JNK inhibitor SP600125 up-regulates expression of p8.</Species>
<Species>Conversely, p38 or TGFb-1 induced p8 expression whereas the specific p38 inhibitor SB203580 down-regulated p8 expression.</Species>
<Species>Finally, TGFb-1 induction was in part mediated through p38.</Species>
<Species>Conclusions p8 inhibits the growth of human pancreatic cancer cells.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>p8 expression is induced through pathways involved in growth inhibition and repressed by factors that promote cell growth.</Species>
<Species>These results suggest that p8 belongs to a pathway regulating the growth of pancreatic cancer cells.</Species>

<Species>Background While studying the molecular response of the injured pancreas, we identified a new gene, called p8, whose expression is strongly induced during the acute phase of pancreatitis [1].</Species>

<Species>Further experiments have shown that p8 mRNA is activated in almost all cells in response to several stresses [2], including minimal stresses such as after routine change of the culture medium in the absence of any added substance [3], indicating that p8 is a ubiquitous protein induced by cellular stress.</Species>
<Species>The p8 gene was cloned in human, rat, mouse, and Xenopus laevis</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>[1,4-6], conceptually translated from the Drosophila melanogaster genome or deduced from EST libraries (Bos taurus, Xenopus tropicalis, Zebrafish, Orzzias latipes, Bombyx mori and Paralichthys olivaceous).</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species
