text: <Species>The overall degree of homology with human p8 ranged from 81 to 40%.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Secondary structure prediction methods indicated that within the homologous region of the eleven proteins, there is a basic Helix-Loop-Helix secondary structure motif, characteristic of some classes of transcription factors [1].</Species>

<Species>Even though a small protein such as p8 would not need a nuclear localization signal (NLS) to be transported to the nucleus, a clear NLS can be predicted for the eleven proteins comprising a bipartite domain of positively charged aminoacids.</Species>

<Species>In addition, a nuclear/cytoplasmic location has been demonstrated for human p8 upon overexpression of the recombinant protein and immunohistochemistry [4], and for recombinant Xenopus laevis p8 fused to green fluorescent protein [6].</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Homology searching in databases did not reveal significant similarity of p8 with other proteins of known function.</Species>
<Species>However, biochemical properties of the mammalian p8 proteins are shared by some high mobility group proteins (HMG)</Species>
<Species>[7], particularly by the HMG-I/Y family.</Species>

<Species>The overall identity of human p8 with human HMG-I/Y is only about 35%, but the molecular mass, isoelectric point, hydrophilicity plot, the resistance to denaturation after heating at 100oC and the charge separation are very similar</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>[8].</Species>
<Species>The p8 protein seems to bind DNA weakly, as shown by electrophoretic mobility shift assay, without preference for DNA sequences.</Species>

<Species>Finally, human p8 has also been shown to be a substrate for protein kinase A in vitro and phosphorylated p8 has a higher content of secondary structure and binding to DNA is highly increased [8].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>An architectural role in transcription has been proposed for this protein, in analogy with the HMG-I/Y proteins, and a recent work seems to confirm this hypothesis [9].</Species>
<Species>Functions of p8 appear to be multiple and complex.</Species>

<Species>For example, p8 mRNA expression was strongly induced in 3T3 cells upon TGFb-1 treatment which in turn enhances the Smad-transactivating function responsible for TGFb-1 activity [10].</Species>

<Species>We also found that p8 is involved in cell cycle regulation since p8-deficient embryonic fibroblasts grew more rapidly and incorporated more [3H] thymidine and BrdU than p8-expressing cells [11].</Species>
<Species>Moreover, expression of p8 in breast cancer-derived cells seems to mediate the inhibition of cell growth induced by 1,25-Dihydroxyvitamin D3</Species>
<Species>[12].</Species>
<Species>On the contrary, we also reported that p8 may promote cell growth when overexpressed in Cos-7, AR42J and HeLa cells [1,4].</Species>

<Species>In addition, p8 seems to be involved in other intracellular functions such as apoptosis since p8-expressing fibroblasts are more sensitive than p8-deficient fibroblasts to the apoptosis induced by DNA damage.</Species>
<Species>Also, p8 is required for endothelin-induced mesangial cell hypertrophy in diabetic kidney, in a mechanism involving ERK, JNK and PI3 kinase [13].</Species>
<Species>p8 seems to play a functional role in the initiation of LHb gene expression during embryonic cell differentiation [14].</Species>
<Species>Moreover, the Drosophila melanogaster p8 homologue is involved in response to starvation and might be activated to stop cell growth in case of nutrient deprivation [15].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Finally, a particularly attractive role in tumour progression was recently proposed for p8 [16].</Species>

<Species>Fibroblasts obtained from p8-expressing or p8-deficient animals were transformed with a retroviral vector expressing both the rasV12 mutated protein and the E1A adenoviral oncogene.</Species>
<Species>In soft-agar assays, transformed p8-expressing cells formed colonies at high frequency, as expected, but p8-deficient transformed fibroblasts were unable to form colonies.</Species>

<Species>Similarly, transformed p8-expressing cells produced tumours in all athymic nude mice when injected subcutaneously or intraperitoneally, whereas transformed p8-deficient fibroblasts did not.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>On the other hand, studies by another laboratory revealed that expression of the Com1 protein [17], which is identical to human p8, mediates the growth of tumour cells after metastatic establishment in a secondary organ, indicating that activated expression of Com1/p8 in metastatic cells is required for tumour progression.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>These results strongly suggest that p8 is involved in the cellular pathway(s) required for tumour progression and metastasis.</Species>
<Species>Our aim is to check the relevance of p8 to cancer progression in human.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>As a first step, we investigated in the present study the function of p8 in two cell lines derived from human pancreatic cancer.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We observed that inhibition of p8 expression increased the cells growth rate.</Species>

<Species>In addition, activations of the Ras>Raf>MEK>ERK and JNK intracellular pathways, which promote the growth of pancreatic cells, down-regulated p8 expression, whereas activation of p38 or TGFb-1, which inhibit cell growth, induced its expression.</Species>

<Species>It was concluded that i/ p8 inhibits the growth of human pancreatic cancer cell lines, ii/ p8 expression is induced through pathways involved in growth inhibition and, conversely, repressed by factors that promote cell growth.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Results p8 is silenced in pancreatic cancer cells by infection with a retrovirus expressing p8 RNA in the antisense orientation Panc-1 and BxPc-3 pancreatic cells were chosen for this study because, on the one hand, both cells express higher level of p8 (Figure 1) and, on the other hand, because Panc-1 is wild-type for Smad4/DPC4 and mutated for K-ras, while BxPc-3 is Smad4/DPC4 mutated and K-ras wild-type [18,19], therefore representing different mechanisms of transformation and different genetic backgrounds.</Species>
<Species>K-ras and Smad4/DPC4 mutations are the major mechanisms involved in pancreatic cancer development.</Species>

<Species>We inhibited p8 expression in both Panc-1 and BxPc-3 pancreatic cells by infecting cells with a retrovirus expressing the p8 asRNA (antisense RNA) and carrying the puromycin resistance.</Species>
<Species>The antibiotic-selected cells were analyzed by Western blotting to evaluate the intracellular amounts of p8 protein.</Species>

<Species>As shown in Figure 2, the p8 protein was clearly visible in both Panc-1 and BxPc-3 pancreatic cells infected with the empty retrovirus but almost undetectable in cells infected with the retrovirus encoding the p8 asRNA showed, indicating that our anti-sense strategy is efficient to silence p8 gene expression in pancreatic cancer cells.</Species>
<Species>Preliminary studies had been conducted to select the best strategy to inhibit p8 expression.</Species>
<Species>We compared the efficacy of the stable transfection of a siRNA, using a retroviral expression vector to the asRNA strategy described above.</Species>
<Species>In our hands, the antisense strategy worked best, as judged from Western blot assessment of p8 protein expression (data not shown).</Species>
<Species>p8-silenced pancreatic cells grow more rapidly We compared in the two cell lines the influence on growth parameters of blocking p8 expression with the p8 asRNA.</Species>

<Species>Figure 3 shows that both Panc-1 and BxPc-3 cells in which p8 has been silenced grew more rapidly than cells infected with the empty vector suggesting that inhibition by p8 of pancreatic cancer cell growth is independent from the mechanism of transformation and genetic background.</Species>
<Species>Serum-stimulated cellular growth down-regulates p8 expression Fetal calf serum, which contains a complex mix of growth factors, can be used as inductor of cell growth.</Species>

<Species>As shown in Figure 4 expression of p8 mRNA was down-regulated in both Panc-1 and BxPc-3 when the cells were shifted from culture media containing 0.1% fetal calf serum to media containing 10% FCS.</Species>
<Species>p8 protein showed a similar behavior.</Species>
<Species>These results show that p8 expression is down-regulated in growing pancreatic cells.</Species>

<Species>The Ras>Raf>MEK>ERK pathway down-regulates p8 expression in pancreatic cancer cells Most human pancreatic cancers harbor mutations in the K-ras oncogene, which happens relatively early in pancreatic tumorigenesis [20].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The oncogenic mutation of the K-ras gene stabilizes the Ras protein in a GTP-bound form, which is constitutively active and make the cells grow more rapidly.</Species>
<Species>Contrary to the activated Ras protein, p8 inhibits cell growth (Figure 3).</Species>
<Species>We looked whether the Ras>Raf>MEK>ERK pathway was also involved in the regulation of p8 expression, and which step(s) were critical.</Species>

<Species>Figure 5 shown that expression of a mutated form of the Ras protein (rasV12) in BxPc-3 cells, which are wild-type for ras, resulted in decreased p8 mRNA concentration and protein level suggesting that the activated ras inhibits p8 expression.</Species>

<Species>Figure 6 shows that overexpression of Raf, but not of Raf301 (a negative mutant of Raf), and of ERK also inhibited the expression of the p8-CAT construct in Panc-1 as well as in BxPc-3.</Species>
<Species>Finally, the MEK1/2 specific inhibitor U0126 [21] activated p8 mRNA expression in pancreatic cells whether they carry mutated ras (Panc-1) or wild-type (BxPc-3).</Species>
<Species>Similar results were observed when expression of the p8 protein was monitored by Western blotting (Figure 7).</Species>

<Species>Activation of the JNK pathway down-regulates p8 expression in pancreatic cancer cells c-Jun NH2-terminal kinase (JNK) is another major MAPK pathway which converts extracellular signals into expression of specific target genes through phosphorylation and activation of transcription factors.</Species>
<Species>JNK activation has been implicated in various, often opposite cellular responses, such as cell proliferation, transformation and apoptosis.</Species>
<Species>As shown in Figure 8, overexpression of JNK down-regulates the gene reporter activity of the p8-CAT construct in Panc-1 cells.</Species>
<Species>Similar results were found in BxPc-3 cells.</Species>
<Species>Treatment of these cells with the JNK specific inhibitor SP600125 [22] up-regulates expression of the p8 mRNA and p8 protein (Figure 9).</Species>
<Species>These results show that the JNK pathway is involved in the regulation of p8 expression.</Species>

<Species>The p38 pathway up-regulates p8 expression in pancreatic cancer cells The p38 signal transduction pathway also plays an essential role in regulating several cell functions including growth, response to inflammation, differentiation and apoptosis.</Species>
<Species>In fact, in pancreatic cancer cells, p38 is a strong inhibitor of proliferation [23] contrary to the Ras>Raf>MEK>ERK and JNK pathways.</Species>
<Species>We therefore analyzed the putative role of the p38 pathway in regulating p8 expression in pancreatic cancer cells.</Species>
<Species>Figure 10 shows that over-expression of the plasmid encoding p38 significantly increases p8-CAT activity in Panc-1 as well as in BxPc-3 cells.</Species>
<Species>Then, cells were treated with SB203580, a specific inhibitor of p38 [24], and p8 expression was measured.</Species>
<Species>p8 mRNA as well as the encoded protein were down-regulated after inhibition of the p38 activity (Figure 11).</Species>
<Species>These results indicate that the p38 pathway is a positive regulator of p8 expression in pancreatic cancer cells.</Species>

<Species>TGFb-1 up-regulates p8 expression in pancreatic cancer cells The most prominent biological activity of TGFb-1 is its potent inhibition of cell growth in a wide variety of cell types including pancreatic cells.</Species>
<Species>TGFb-1 signals are sent through two types of transmembrane serine/threonine kinase receptors.</Species>
<Species>In fact, TGFb-1 binds and brings together the type I and type II receptors.</Species>

<Species>In the resulting complex, the constitutively active TGFb-1 type II receptor phosphorylates the type I receptor, which then plays a major role in transducing the signal to downstream components to affect gene expression through phosphorylation of SMAD proteins.</Species>
<Species>Phosphorylated receptor-regulated SMADs then form heteromeric complexes with the common partner SMAD4.</Species>
<Species>These heteromeric complexes then move to the nucleus, where SMAD4 will bind DNA and contribute to transcriptional activation.</Species>
<Species>In general, pancreatic cancer cells present with defects in TGFb-1 signaling and are resistant to TGFb-1-mediated growth suppression.</Species>
<Species>Since TGFb-1 and p8 are inhibitors of pancreatic cell growth we analyzed whether p8 could mediate, at least in part, the effect of TGFb-1.</Species>
<Species>First, we found that treatment of Panc-1 cells with TGFb-1 increased p8 mRNA levels and p8 protein as judged by Western blot (Figure 12).</Species>

<Species>Then, to confirm that overexpression is regulated at the transcriptional level, we analyzed the effect of some constructs expressing constitutively activated type I TGFb receptor, dominant negative type II TGFb receptor, a dominant negative of Smad4 and the wild-type Smad4 on the p8-CAT activity.</Species>
<Species>As expected, the constitutively activated type I TGFb receptor but not the dominant negative type II TGFb receptor increased CAT activity.</Species>
<Species>Also, expression of the Smad4, contrary to that of the negative mutant, induced p8 transcription (Figure 13).</Species>
<Species>Together, these results indicate that p8 is positively regulated by TGFb-1.</Species>
<Species>Beside the Smad proteins, TGFb-1 also activates the p38 MAPK pathway in pancreas-derived cells, which may play an important role in TGFb-1 induced genes</Species>
<Species>[25].</Species>
<Species>Therefore, we analyzed the p38-dependent effect of TGFb-1 on p8 transcription.</Species>

<Species>As shown in Figure 13, inhibition of p38 activity with the SB203580 specific inhibitor decreased about 40% the activity of TGFb-1 on the p8 promoter indicating that the effect of TGFb-1 on p8 promoter is mediated by both p38-dependent and p38-independent pathways.</Species>
<Species>Discussion Pancreatic adenocarcinoma is the fourth leading cause of death from malignant diseases [26].</Species>

<Species>The aggressive nature of the neoplasia, the lack of early detection, and the limited response to treatments such as chemotherapy and radiotherapy contribute to the high mortality rate of the disease.</Species>

<Species>Therefore, a better understanding of the molecular mechanism leading to pancreatic cancer remains a major goal because it may help proposing strategies for earlier diagnosis and better treatment.</Species>
<Species>The most commonly altered genes in pancreatic adenocarcinoma are K-ras (75 to 100%),</Species>
<Species>p16INK4a (95%), p53 (50 to 75%) and DPC4 (50%)</Species>
<Species>[27-31].</Species>
<Species>Whereas K-ras is a proto-oncogene all the others are tumour suppressor genes.</Species>
<Species>Additional genes have been found altered at lower frequency.</Species>

<Species>Panc-1 and BxPc-3 pancreatic cells were chosen for this study because they both express high levels of p8 (Figure 1) and because they present with different mechanisms of transformation and genetic backgrounds, Panc-1 being wild-type for Smad4/DPC4 but mutated for K-ras and BxPc-3 mutated for Smad4/DPC4 and wild-type for K-ras</Species>
<Species>[18,19].</Species>

<Species>This work presents evidences that p8 inhibits the growth rate of pancreatic cancer-derived cells and that the intracellular pathways promoting cell growth down-regulate p8 expression whereas those promoting growth arrest up-regulate its expression.</Species>

<Species>Together, these results suggest that p8 is downstream of some cell growth regulators and therefore regulation of p8 expression or its activity could be used as a target for treating pancreatic cancer.</Species>

<Species>Silencing p8 expression was able to strongly promote cell growth in both cell types, Panc-1 and BxPc-3, suggesting that p8 may act downstream of the ras- or Smad4/DPC4-dependent ways.</Species>

<Species>Also, we found that stimulating cell growth by the complex combination of growth factors contained in fetal calf serum down-regulated expression of p8 whereas, on the contrary, treating the cells with TGFb-1, which promotes cell cycle arrest, stimulates p8 expression.</Species>
<Species>Therefore, p8 gene expression seems to be regulated in opposite directions by mechanisms promoting cell growth or cell cycle arrest.</Species>

<Species>It is interesting to note that while p8 expression is under the control of cell growth regulatory pathways such as Ras>Raf>MEK>ERK, JNK, p38 and TGFb-1, p8 can affect cell cycle progression, suggesting that p8 is a target for factors regulating pancreatic cell growth.</Species>
<Species>A mechanism by which p8 could regulate cell cycle progression in embryonic fibroblasts was previously proposed [11].</Species>
<Species>In fact, p8 seems to take action upstream from cyclin-dependent kinases because the intracellular levels and activities of Cdk2 and Cdk4 are decreased when p8 is expressed.</Species>
<Species>Concomitantly, the cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor p27 is expressed at a low level in p8-deficient cells which may explain the increased activity of Cdk2 and Cdk4.</Species>
<Species>The mechanism by which p8 regulates the intracellular level of those proteins remains to be determined.</Species>
<Species>However, because p8 is a transcriptional cofactor, it is possible that regulation of expression of these molecules takes place, at least in part, at the transcription level.</Species>

<Species>Interestingly, expression of p8 mRNA seems to be regulated in a cell type- and stimulus-specific manner since, for example, p38 can induce p8 expression in response to stress in fibroblasts [3] but not in renal mesangial cells treated with endothelin [13].</Species>

<Species>In pancreatic cancer-derived cells p38 seems to play a major role since it is involved in p8 activation as judged by transient transfection assays and using a specific p38 inhibitor (Figures 10 and 11).</Species>
<Species>In addition, p38 is also involved in TGFb-1-induced p8 expression because about 40% of the TGFb-1 effect was abolished when p38 activity was specifically blocked (Figure 13).</Species>

<Species>On the other hand, ERK and JNK are inducers of p8 expression in mesangial cells treated with endothelin, but not involved in the activation of p8 in response to stress in fibroblasts [3], and even repressors in pancreatic cells (Figures 5, 6, 7, 8 and 9).</Species>
<Species>Finally, PI3 kinase is an inducer of p8 expression in both endothelin-mediated p8 activation in mesangial cells [13] and pancreatic cells (data not shown).</Species>
<Species>Based on these observations, overexpression of p8 could be considered a possible goal for treating pancreatic tumours, in order to limit their growth.</Species>
<Species>However, we previously reported that p8 repression would prevent rasV12/E1A transformed fibroblasts from evolving as tumours in nude mice [16].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>This apparent contradiction needs to be resolved before considering p8 as a target for treating cancer progression.</Species>

<Species>Conclusions In conclusion (see Figure 14), we report in this paper that inhibition of p8 expression by an anti-sense strategy increases the growth rate of both Panc-1 and BxPc-3 pancreatic cancer-derived cells.</Species>
<Species>Moreover, ERK- and JNK-mediated pathways down-regulate p8 expression, whereas p38 and TGFb-1 pathways induce p8 expression.</Species>
<Species>Also, cell growth triggered by expression of a RAS mutated protein or by 10% fetal calf serum induces down-regulation of p8 expression.</Species>

<Species>Together, these results indicate that p8 is an intracellular cell growth inhibitor and that it is oppositely regulated by growth-promoting or growth-inhibiting factors in pancreatic cancer-derived cells.</Species>

<Species>Material and Methods Cell lines and cell culture conditions The human pancreatic cancer cell lines Panc-1 and BxPc-3 were a kind gift of Dr C. Susini (INSERM U.531, Toulouse) and A. Hajri (IRCAD, Strasbourg) respectively.</Species>

Expression plasmids Expression plamids encoding p38 (pCEFL HA p38), Erk2 (pcDNAIII HA ERK2), JNK (pcDNAIIIB HA JNK), the wild-type Raf (pcDNA RAF BXB) and the Raf dominant negative (pcDNA RAF 301 K375W) were obtained from O Coso (University of Buenos Aires).</Species>

text: <Species>The retroviral vector was constructed as follows: human p8 cDNA was subcloned in HindIII and XhoI restriction sites of the pLPC plasmid (obtained from S. Lowe) in the antisense orientation.</Species>

<Species>p8 expression in arrested and growing cells One million of Panc-1 or BxPc-3 cells were cultivated on 10-cm Petri plates in standard conditions (with 10% FCS).</Species>
<Species>After 48 h, culture media were changed for fresh media with FCS restricted to 0.1%, in order to stop growth.</Species>
<Species>After 24 hours of growth arrest, culture medium was replaced either by medium with 10% fetal calf serum to resume cell growth or, as control, by medium with 0.1% fetal calf serum.</Species>
<Species>Twenty four hours later cells were recovered and RNA and protein extracted.</Species>
<Species>p8 expression in TGFb-1-treated Panc-1 cells One million of Panc-1 cells were cultivated in 10-cm culture dishes for 48 hours under standard conditions before TGFb-1 treatment.</Species>
<Species>Human recombinant TGFb-1 (5 ng/ml) was added to cells, without changing the culture medium, and cells were collected 12 hours later for RNA and protein preparation.</Species>

<Species>For infections, the culture medium was replaced by an appropriate mix of the viral supernatant and culture medium (V/V), supplemented with 4 ug/ml polybrene (Sigma), and cells were incubated at 37oC. BxPc-3 rasV12-expressing cells were selected with puromycin (1 ug/ml).</Species>

<Species>Cell transfection and gene reporter assays Panc-1 and BxPc-3 (105) were cultivated in 30 mm diameter culture dishes for 24 hours then transiently transfected with 0.5 ug of p8-CAT reporter plasmid and 0.5 ug of pCMV/bgal plasmid (to control transfection efficiency) using the Fugene reagent in accordance with the manufacturer's protocol (Roche Molecular Biochemicals).</Species>

<Species>Reporter activities were measured as previously described [5].</Species>

<Species>[33].</Species>
<Species>CAT activity was normalized to b-galactosidase activity.</Species>

<Species>The mRNA coding for p8 was specifically amplified with sense (5' GAAGAGAGGCAGGGAAGACA 3') and antisense (5' CTGCCGTGCGTGTCTATTTA 3') primers, in positions 72 and 643 of the cDNA (accession # NM_012385), respectively.</Species>

<Species>As control, the transcript coding for the ribosomal protein RL3 was specifically amplified for 22 cycles with sense (5'GAAAGAAGTCGTGGAGGCTG3') and antisense (5'ATCTCATCCTGCCCAAACAC3') primers, in positions 216 and 637 of the cDNA, respectively.</Species>

<Species>A life threatening uterine inversion and massive post partum hemorrhage caused by placenta accrete during Caesarean section in a primigravida: a case report</Species>
<Species>A global gene evolution analysis on Vibrionaceae family using phylogenetic profile</Species>

<Species>Abstract Background Vibrionaceae represent a significant portion of the cultivable heterotrophic sea bacteria; they strongly affect nutrient cycling and some species are devastating pathogens.</Species>
<Species>In this work we propose an improved phylogenetic profile analysis on 14 Vibrionaceae genomes, to study the evolution of this family on the basis of gene content.</Species>

<Species>The phylogenetic profile is based on the observation that genes involved in the same process (e.g. metabolic pathway or structural complex) tend to be concurrently present or absent within different genomes.</Species>
<Species>This allows the prediction of hypothetical functions on the basis of a shared phylogenetic profiles.</Species>
<Species>Moreover this approach is useful to identify putative laterally transferred elements on the basis of their presence on distantly phylogenetically related bacteria.</Species>
<Species>Results Vibrionaceae ORFs were aligned against all the available bacterial proteomes.</Species>
<Species>Phylogenetic profile is defined as an array of distances, based on aminoacid substitution matrixes, from single genes to all their orthologues.</Species>
<Species>Final phylogenetic profiles, derived from non-redundant list of all ORFs, was defined as the median of all the profiles belonging to the cluster.</Species>
<Species>The resulting phylogenetic profiles matrix contains gene clusters on the rows and organisms on the columns.</Species>

<Species>Cluster analysis identified groups of "core genes" with a widespread high similarity across all the organisms and several clusters that contain genes homologous only to a limited set of organisms.</Species>
<Species>On each of these clusters, COG class enrichment has been calculated.</Species>

<Species>The analysis reveals that clusters of core genes have the highest number of enriched classes, while the others are enriched just for few of them like DNA replication, recombination and repair.</Species>

<Species>Conclusion We found that mobile elements have heterogeneous profiles not only across the entire set of organisms, but also within Vibrionaceae; this confirms their great influence on bacteria evolution even inside the same family.</Species>
<Species>Furthermore, several hypothetical proteins highly correlate with mobile elements profiles suggesting a possible horizontal transfer mechanism for the evolution of these genes.</Species>
<Species>Finally, we suggested the putative role of some ORFs having an unknown function on the basis of their phylogenetic profile similarity to well characterized genes.</Species>

<Species>Background Over the past ten years, a great number of microbial genomes have been sequenced covering a wide representation of prokaryots as well as multiple strains of some species.</Species>

<Species>The study of these genomes both by computational and experimental approaches has highly improved our understanding on physiology, phylogenetic relationship and pathogenicity of many organisms.</Species>

<Species>Furthermore, it has provided new knowledge on microbial genome evolution, revealing a gene core shared by the great majority of bacteria, genes characteristic of particular groups and "novel" genes that possibly originated by lateral gene transfer from some unknown source.</Species>
<Species>Analysis performed on closely related genomes revealed that a substantial fraction of genes in any genome seem to be strain specific.</Species>

<Species>These genes might sometime arise by gene duplication followed by a rapid divergence, or by lineage-specific loss of genes in one strain, resulting in a unique gene in other strains.</Species>
<Species>However, there are several lines of evidence indicating that lateral gene transfer may be the main mechanism to acquire novel genes.</Species>
<Species>Indeed, this could be one of the main forces driving bacterial adaptation and evolution.</Species>
<Species>Phage DNA is thought to be one of the main vectors for lateral gene transfer among bacteria [1] and many virulence factors from bacterial pathogen are phage encoded [2].</Species>
<Species>For example, the genes for CT, the most important virulence factor of V. cholerae, are encoded in the genome of phage CTX  , integrated in the bacterial chromosome 1.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Since lateral gene transfer plays a relevant role in bacterial evolution, the reconstruction of phylogeny is very complex and phylogenetic trees built by standard sequence analysis may not lead to a reliable picture of the evolutionary history.</Species>
<Species>In fact, alternative trees can be obtained when different proteins are considered.</Species>
<Species>For many aspects the classification of bacteria on the basis of their global gene content may give a better description of their evolutionary history.</Species>

<Species>This may be particularly important when bacteria of the same group are compared, since newly acquired genes could be relevant to confer peculiar features that allows the exploitation of different ecological niches.</Species>
<Species>In this study we propose a bioinformatic procedure to investigate bacterial genome evolution, taking into account the global gene content, as well as sequence similarity.</Species>

<Species>We based our analysis on modified phylogenetic profiles [3]; however, we do not consider only the presence/absence of orthologue genes, but also their distance, based on a substitution matrix.</Species>
<Species>A phylogenetic profile is a non-sequence-homology-based method developed to infer a possible functional relationship between genes.</Species>

<Species>It is based on the idea that proteins that are involved in the same metabolic pathway or structural complex are likely to evolve in a correlate fashion and during evolution appear phylogenetically linked, showing a tendency to be either preserved or eliminated as a whole.</Species>
<Species>Therefore, genes showing similar phylogenetic profiles are likely to be functionally related.</Species>
<Species>We extended the use of phylogenetic profiles to produce an evolutionary tree based on a hierarchical clusterization of organisms with similar phylogenetic profiles.</Species>

<Species>For this study we took the whole gene dataset of 320 prokaryotic genomes, however, we limited the analysis to the orthologous groups that are present in at least one of the 14 considered species of the Vibrionaceae family.</Species>

<Species>These bacteria belong to the Gammaproteobacteria group and are highly abundant in aquatic environment, they strongly influence nutrient cycling and various species are also devastating pathogens.</Species>

<Species>Since we focused our analysis on this particular group, the aim of this study is not the construction of a global evolutionary tree, but rather a Vibrionaceae perspective of bacterial diversity, based on phylogenetic profiles.</Species>
<Species>Results and discussion Phylogenetic matrix The analysis was performed on 14 bacteria belonging to the Vibrionaceae family (Table 1).</Species>

<Species>The redundant list of Vibrionaceae ORFs was clustered to reduce the number of proteins to analyze and the phylogenetic profile for each cluster was calculated as described in the Method section.</Species>
<Species>Many authors proposed and successfully applied different measure methods to calculate the phylogenetic profile values.</Species>
<Species>Pellegrini et al.</Species>
<Species>[3] firstly proposed a phylogenetic profile described as a string of bits, each bit representing the absence or presence of an homologous gene in a given genome.</Species>
<Species>This method lacks a weighting procedure, giving the same weight (value 1) to all the sequences that are considered homologous given a similarity threshold.</Species>
<Species>Enault and colleagues proposed an improved phylogenetic profile based on a normalized Blastp bit score [4].</Species>
<Species>This method, compared to the approach implemented by Pellegrini, allows weighting each point of the profile proportionally to the length and the quality of the alignment.</Species>

<Species>Jingchun and colleagues optimized the phylogenetic profiles method by integrating phylogenetic relationships among reference organisms and sequence homology information, based on E-value score, to improve prediction accuracy [5].</Species>

<Species>The measure index I proposed in this work is similar to the others described above, taking into account both the quality and the length of the alignment using a substitution matrix.</Species>

<Species>Moreover our approach considers also the total length of the sequences, penalizing good alignments occurring between ORFs having different lengths and taking into consideration that ORFs could differentiate mainly for the presence of functional domains.</Species>

<Species>The final phylogenetic profile for each cluster was defined as the median of all the profiles belonging to the cluster, named "meta-profile", which describes the profile of conserved ORFs belonging to an entire family.</Species>

<Species>Hierarchical cluster analysis A hierarchical cluster analysis was performed on the entire phylogenetic profile matrix and it was calculated a statistical support based on bootstrap method for the nodes of the columns tree (Fig 1).</Species>
<Species>The branch tree colors represent the bootstrap percentage support.</Species>
<Species>This constitutes a phylogenetic tree based on gene content using Vibrionaceae ORFs as a reference.</Species>
<Species>Genomes belonging to the same taxonomic group tend to cluster together and the Vibrionaceae species are closely related.</Species>
<Species>As expected, according to the Vibrionaceae branch lengths it is evident that variability within this group is higher compared to the other groups.</Species>
<Species>The dataset used for phylogenetic matrix calculation is indeed composed by Vibrionaceae ORFs.</Species>

<Species>This implies that the similarity measures between these ORFs and the corresponding orthologues will be nearly zero in most of the other species and significantly higher in the Vibrionaceae family, increasing the variability into this group.</Species>

<Species>Moreover the average percentage of clusters shared by the Vibrionaceae members is only 47.5% (average number of shared clusters divided by the total number of clusters) that again indicates a high variability inside this family.</Species>
<Species>It is also interesting to note that organisms belonging to the same or closely related taxa split into different subgroups.</Species>

<Species>This highlights the existence of a high variability among lineages, due to genetic and evolutionary processes such as lateral gene transfer, concerted evolution and gene duplication [6].</Species>
<Species>In terms of gene content, the organisms more related to the Vibrionaceae belong to the gamma and beta proteobacteria.</Species>

<Species>In particular Altermonadales, Enterobacteriales and Burkholderiales are closely related to Vibrionaceae, and share the higher number of cluster of genes (average percentage of 20%).</Species>
<Species>As expected, Archea are the most distant group sharing just 3.8% of clusters.</Species>
<Species>Clusters and genes distribution, as shown in Fig 2, reveals that the number of clusters and genes shared by the organisms decreases as the number of organisms considered increases.</Species>
<Species>The analysis was performed considering for each cluster profile the number of organisms sharing the same numbers of clusters (and genes).</Species>
<Species>The majority of gene cluster groups no more than 21 species on a total of 320.</Species>
<Species>The highest blue spike corresponds to the higher number of genes shared by 105 groups of 14 organisms.</Species>
<Species>Among these groups, as expected, Vibrionaceae are highly represented.</Species>
<Species>Other species represented are Colwellia psychrerythraea 34H and Shewanella oneidensis, that belong to the Alteromonadales family.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The cluster analysis performed on genes is shown in Fig.</Species>
<Species>3.</Species>

<Species>From now on, to avoid confusing interpretation between clusters derived from the cluster analysis and cluster derived from the ORFs clustering we will use the term "gene" in place of cluster of ORFs.</Species>
<Species>The different gradient of color, from bright to dark red, represents decreasing similarity values.</Species>
<Species>The cluster analysis allows the detection of three main groups of genes.</Species>
<Species>The first one (Fig 3, panel B) contains the most conserved and established genes shared almost by all the organisms.</Species>
<Species>These core genes can be defined as the set of all genes shared as orthologous by all members of an evolutionary coherent group.</Species>
<Species>In our analysis we identify four clusters, for a total of 145 genes, shared by all the 320 organisms.</Species>

<Species>The ORFs belonging to these clusters are predicted to codify for the ATP binding subunit of ABC transporters (annotated as ABC-type polar amino acid transport system, ABC-type antimicrobial peptide transport system, ABC-type histidine transport system and ABC-type transport system involved in lysophospholipase L1 biosynthesis).</Species>
<Species>This finding is surprising since this is the first report where these ORFs are assigned to the core genes.</Species>
<Species>Anyway two different explanations can be traced.</Species>

<Species>First, it is known that the ABC transporters represent an essential transport system in the prokaryotes and that their ATP binding subunits are apparently overrepresented compared to the other two subunits (ligand binding and permease subunit) in all genomes sequenced thus far [7].</Species>

<Species>Second, one organism, Buchnera aphidicola, presents these genes with a similarity just below the cut-off used for the analysis, but they have been considered since it is well known that in this mutualistic endosymbiont the accelerated evolution and AT bias affect all its genes, including the 16S rRNA</Species>
label: Species

<Species>The dataset used for the analysis includes genomes in draft quality (Vibrio cholerae 0395, Vibrio cholerae MO10, Vibrio cholerae RC385, Vibrio cholerae V51, Vibrio cholerae V52, Photobacterium profundum 3TCK, Vibrio MED222, Vibrio splendidus12B01).</Species>

text: <Species>Wrong ORFs prediction or missing genes due to incomplete genome sequences can explain the low number of core genes identified.</Species>
<Species>To avoid such problems we repeated the analysis excluding the draft genomes and thus considering 312 genomes.</Species>

<Species>The results, reported in Table 2, show an increased number of the core genes and in particular ribosomal proteins and tRNA synthetase, as reported by Charlesbois and Doolittle [10].</Species>
<Species>This could be considered as a sort of "minimal genome" containing the group of genes that are necessary to maintain a free-living organism.</Species>
<Species>The low number of genes shared by all the organisms can be due to many factors.</Species>
<Species>First of all we used the Vibrionaceae ORFs as a reference, limiting the number of genes we were able to identify.</Species>
<Species>It was further demonstrated that the core gene size decreases as more genome sequences are analyzed [10].</Species>
<Species>Genes that are considered to belong to the core set when close organisms are compared, are classified as flexible genes when distantly related genomes are analyzed</Species>
<Species>[6].</Species>
<Species>Finally, genes within core genomes might be transferred or replaced, introducing new versions of existing genes into genomes.</Species>
<Species>Such transfers can replace even highly conserved genes by non-homologous counterparts but the advantages provided are difficult to explain.</Species>
<Species>It is also to take into consideration that many symbiotic and parasitic bacteria undergo a reduction of their genomes, loosing many genes required by free-living cell.</Species>
<Species>The second group (Fig 3, panel C) represents genes shared mainly among Vibrionaceae and other gamma proteobacteria (as Altermonadales, Burkholderiales and Enterobactidiales).</Species>
<Species>Finally, the third group (Fig. 3, panel D) is composed by genes that are mainly specific to the Vibrionaceae.</Species>
<Species>k-mean cluster analysis and cluster enrichment We performed a k-means cluster analysis, setting the k value to 14.</Species>

<Species>As shown in Fig. 4, the clusters 3, 4, 11, 13 and 14 contain the higher percentage of genes, accounting for more that 50% of the total genes, while clusters 9 and 10 contain the lower number of ORFs (3% of genes).</Species>
<Species>The variance in each k-means cluster is very low (Fig. 4), meaning that the clusters contain genes with compact and similar profiles.</Species>

<Species>As described in Fig. 4, the majority of the clusters (1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 9, 12, 13) contains genes with a similar profile, with the average values (red line) near zero, except for the presence of some spikes correspondent to an increasing similarity with some isolated organisms.</Species>
<Species>As shown in Table 3, clusters 1, 3, 4, 5, and 9 contains genes that have a high similarity in a small subset of organisms.</Species>
<Species>The majority of these ORFs are annotated as hypothetical proteins or phage related proteins.</Species>
<Species>Clusters 8, 10 and 14 present genes shared among almost all the organisms.</Species>

<Species>In particular cluster 10 is composed by the core genes described before having an high value of similarity widespread among all the organisms; cluster 8 contains genes shared mainly by gamma proteobacteria and cluster 14 is composed of genes in common between Vibrionaceae and Enterobacteriaceae.</Species>
<Species>A functional annotation has been performed on each gene cluster using COG (Cluster of Orthologous Genes), KEGG pathway map and GO databases.</Species>
<Species>For each k-mean cluster the enrichment probability with respect to the total number of clusters has been obtained with the hypergeometric distribution.</Species>
<Species>Fig. 5 shows COG enrichment results for each cluster.</Species>

<Species>As expected clusters represented by conserved genes (cluster 8, 10 and 14) have the higher number of enriched COG codes, while cluster specific of few organisms are characterized by a small number of enriched COGs.</Species>
<Species>The majority of clusters presents COG codes enrichment for S (function unknown), R (poorly characterized) and - (absence of COG code) categories.</Species>
<Species>This is due to the large abundance of unknown and hypothetical proteins presents in the Vibrionaceae proteomes.</Species>

<Species>It is worth noting that cluster 3, mainly represented by Photobacterium profundum SS9 ORFs, is enriched only by C (Energy production and conversion), L (DNA replication, recombination and repair) and M (Cell envelope biogenesis, outer membrane).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Probably the L class overrepresentation is determined by the high number of transposons that are present in the SS9 genome [11].</Species>
<Species>The role played by these transposable elements in the survival of this deep-sea bacterium it is still a matter of debate [12].</Species>

<Species>In addition V. vulnificus YJ016 and V. vulnificus CMCP6 (cluster 13) seem to share genes belonging to the enriched COG classes K (Transcription), L and T (Signal transduction mechanisms).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>It was previously reported an enrichment in genes belonging to the transcription class in the genome of V. vulnificus respect to the V. cholerae genome [13].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>This class is clearly related to the T class and seems to indicate that this organism is able to receive and translate in a transcriptional response specific environmental signals.</Species>
<Species>Despite this, the large majority of the genes in clusters 3 and 13 lacks COG annotation.</Species>
<Species>Cluster 7, as shown in Table 3, accounts organisms with large genome size (see Table 1).</Species>

<Species>This can explain the fact the this cluster contains almost all the COG class enriched and suggests a more complex and flexible life-style of these organisms compared to the other Vibrionaceae members.</Species>
<Species>KEGG annotation is limited to metabolic or structural complex network and so a reduced number of genes have a KEGG entry.</Species>
<Species>This causes the presence of clusters without enriched map (cluster 2-5, 7, 13, see Fig 5).</Species>
<Species>Also in this case, the clusters presenting the higher number of significant KEGG map are those containing the conserved genes.</Species>
<Species>The most enriched KEGG clusters are cluster 14, 10 and 8 accounting for the majority of the metabolic pathways.</Species>
<Species>Cluster 1 is enriched for map3080 (type IV secretion system).</Species>
<Species>In fact V. fischeri genome contains 10 separate pilus gene clusters, including eight type-IV pilus loci.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The presence of multiple pilus gene clusters suggests that different pili may be expressed in different environments or during multiple stages of its development as a symbiont [14].</Species>
<Species>Cluster 11 is enriched for map3090 (type II secretion system).</Species>
<Species>The type II pathway is conserved among gram-negative bacteria, including many pathogens, and secretes a variety of virulence factors and degradative enzymes [15].</Species>
<Species>Cluster 9 is enriched for map 00860 (Porphyrin and chlorophyll metabolism).</Species>
<Species>These genes are involved in the cobalamin (coenzyme B12) biosynthetic pathway [16].</Species>

<Species>Some organisms, such as Salmonella typhimurium and Klebsiella pneumoniae, can synthesize cobalamin de novo [17], while E. coli and large part of the Vibrionaceae perform cobalamin biosynthesis only when provided with cobinamide.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>It is interesting to observe that the genes belonging to the de novo pathway are only shared by Archea, some other organisms like Salmonella, Pseudomonas and Vibrio MED222.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Finally cluster 6 is enriched by map2010 (ABC transporter), map2020 (two-component system), map2030 and map2031 (bacterial chemotaxis), map2040 (Flagellar assembly) and map3090 (type II secretion system).</Species>
<Species>This cluster contains genes shared with a high similarity by all Vibrio and with a lower similarity with Photobacterium profundum species.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Among the Vibrio species the organisms showing the highest similarity (Tab. 3) are V. cholerae strains.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Vibrionaceae specific genes We identify 1940 clusters specific to the Vibrionaceae.</Species>
<Species>All the Vibrionaceae considered in the analysis share 108 clusters.</Species>
<Species>Among these genes we identify ToxR and ToxS genes.</Species>
<Species>ToxR</Species>

<Species>gene encodes a transmembrane regulatory protein firstly identified in V. cholerae, in which it co-ordinates many virulence factors in response to several environmental parameters [18].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>V. cholerae ToxR activity is enhanced by a second transmembrane protein, ToxS, encoded downstream toxR</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>[19].</Species>
<Species>This family of proteins is involved in response to temperature, pH, osmolarity and in Photobacterium profundum SS9, a piezophilic bacterium, to hydrostatic pressure [20].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The widespread presence of these genes among the Vibrionaceae suggests their importance in regulatory mechanisms.</Species>
<Species>We identify two other noteworthy groups of genes composed by 257 and 160 genes respectively shared just by two strains, mainly annotated as "hypothetical protein".</Species>
<Species>The first group of genes is shared between Photobacterium profundum SS9 and Photobacterium profundum 3TCK, while the second is shared between V. vulnificus CMCP6 and YJ016.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>These strains are closely related and this explains the high number of shared genes; while, inside the Vibrionaceae family, the number of specific shared genes highly decreases, showing a high inter-species variability (Fig. 6) Prophages and transposases Prophages recover different biological roles both as quantitatively important genetic elements of the bacterial chromosome, and as vectors of lateral gene transfer among bacteria, due to their characters of mobile DNA elements.</Species>
<Species>Indeed, numerous virulence factors from bacterial pathogens are phage encoded.</Species>

<Species>It was postulated that this role of prophages is not limited to pathogenic bacteria but some adaptations of nonpathogenic strains to their ecological niche might also be mediated by prophages acquisition [21].</Species>

<Species>To better understand the importance of mobile elements within Vibrionaceae family, we performed a hierarchical cluster analysis using gene profiles annotated as "phage protein" and "transposase", for a total of 172 clusters of genes (Fig 7).</Species>
<Species>We found that a high inter-strain genetic variability exists and phages and transposases are both shared by almost all Vibrionaceae, and specific to just some organisms.</Species>
<Species>We identified five major clusters of mobile elements that are specific to a single organism.</Species>
<Species>A group composed by 26 clusters containing both transposase and phage proteins seem to be unique to V. splendiduds 12B01</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>(Fig 7).</Species>
<Species>Another one composed by 16 clusters is specific of V. vulnificus CMCP6 (Fig 7) while V. parahaemoliticus has a cluster of 11 genes (Fig 7).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Moreover there is another group of transposases and phage genes shared mainly by V. cholerae 0395, Shewanella oneidensis and V. cholerae V51 (Fig 7).</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Finally a big cluster of almost 30 genes, all predicted to codify for transposases, was found in P. profundum SS9 genome (Fig. 7).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The high presence of transposases in this bacterium seems to correlate with its deep-sea habitat, a feature presumably shared with other deep-sea microorganisms [12].</Species>
<Species>As shown in Fig 7, many of the clusters well conserved in an organism, are partially shared with a low similarity by other organisms.</Species>
<Species>This agrees with the idea that prophages are not maintained in the genome over a long period of time and part of their genes may be deleted from the chromosome.</Species>
<Species>Moreover, microarray analysis and PCR scanning demonstrated that prophages are frequently strain specific within a given bacterial species</Species>
<Species>[22-24].</Species>

<Species>According to the modular theory of phage evolution, phage genomes are mosaics of modules, groups of genes functionally related, that are free to recombine in genetic exchanges between distinct phages infecting the same cell [21].</Species>
<Species>This can result in the occurrences of different part of phage distributed in far related genomes.</Species>
<Species>Phylogenetic profile of some transposases is similar to the phage ones, suggesting a possible transfer mechanism phage-mediated for such mobile elements.</Species>
<Species>Conclusion In this work we propose an improved phylogenetic profile analysis on 14 Vibrionaceae genomes, to study this family on the basis of gene content.</Species>

<Species>Using a phylogenetic profile for each cluster of genes defined as the median of all the profiles belonging to the cluster (meta-profile) we investigate the evolution of groups of ORFs belonging to the entire family.</Species>
<Species>A two-way cluster analysis allows us to identify similarity structures on the entire phylogenetic matrix composed by 8,239 clusters of genes and 320 organisms.</Species>

<Species>The phylogenetic tree obtained with the cluster analysis does not reflect the global evolutionary tree because of the Vibrionaceae ORFs dataset used for the analysis, but rather can be considered as the Vibrionaceae perspective of bacterial diversity.</Species>
<Species>The phylogenetic tree reflects the evolutionary processes that shape genomes, as lateral gene transfer, genes genesis and loss.</Species>
<Species>In this context, the tree allows to group together genomes on the base of their global gene content.</Species>
<Species>We found that genomes belonging to the same taxonomic group tend to cluster together and that Vibrionaceae species are closely related.</Species>

<Species>Moreover organisms belonging to the same or closely related taxa split into different subgroups, confirming the existence of a high variability among lineages, due to genetic and evolutionary process such as lateral gene transfer, concerted evolution and genes duplication.</Species>
<Species>On the other hand several groups of genes characterised by different homogeneous profiles have been identified.</Species>

<Species>In particular we found, 1) a set of conserved genes (with a high similarity values across all organisms) that reflects the "minimal genome" composition defined in other previous works; 2) a set of genes mainly shared by Vibrionaceae and other Gamma proteobacteria and 3) genes specific to different sets of Vibrionaceae.</Species>
<Species>Finally a further analysis on prophage and transposase has confirmed the high inter-strain genetic variability even among closely related species.</Species>

<Species>The increasing number of genomes included in this type of analysis surely add new sorces of variability and noise, anyway we think that the use of meta-profiles can be useful for complexity reduction and data analysis to study global gene evolution.</Species>
<Species>Methods Datasets</Species>
<Species>The Vibrionaceae species used in this analysis were selected among the freely available complete and draft genome sequences.</Species>

<Species>The proteomes of V. cholerae N16961, V. parahaemolyticus, V. vulnificus YJ016, V. vulnificus CMCP6, V. fischeri ES114, Photobacterium profundum SS9 were downloaded from the NCBI ftp site [25].</Species>

text: <Species>Protein sequences of Vibrio cholerae MO10, Vibrio cholerae 0395, Vibrio cholerae RC385, Vibrio cholerae V51, Vibrio cholerae V52 were downloaded from the NCBI genome database, while sequences of Vibrio MED222, Vibrio splendidus 12B01, Photobacterium profundum 3TCK from the J. Craig Venter Institute web site.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The 320 complete genomes update at 03/06 were downloaded from the NCBI ftp site.</Species>

<Species>Similarity search and phylogenetic profile construction All the Vibrionaceae ORFs were merged generating a redundant list of 59,669 proteins and were compared to all open reading frame from 320 bacterial and archeal genomes using Blastp.</Species>

<Species>To determine the presence of an orthologous we used a combination of three different thresholds; a similarity value equal to or higher than 30%, an alignment length equal or higher than 70% and an Evalue score lower than or equal to e-6.</Species>

<Species>After determining the presence of an orthologous gene, we computed a similarity index I for each pair of orthologous (a point of the phylogenetic profile) as follow: I=SqsSqq   min   (lq,ls)max   (lq,ls) MathType@MTEF@5@5@@532D@ where lq</Species>
<Species>and ls are the query and subject length sequence respectively and Sqs is the similarity score between the query and the subject sequence.</Species>

<Species>Sqs is defined as follow: Sqs=Si=1MaAqi,Asi+GP MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4620@ where M is the match length between the query and subject sequence; Aqi and Asi respectively the query and subject amino acid in position i; a the BLOSUM substitution matrix value for amino acid pair Aqi, Asi and GP the gap penalty.</Species>
<Species>GP is defined as follow: GP = GOP+GEP(k-1) where GOP is the Gap Open Penalty set to -11, GEP the Gap Extension Penalty set to -1 and k the gap length.</Species>
<Species>Sqq represents the score of the self-aligned query sequence.</Species>
<Species>Sqs is always smaller than Sqq and the score S range between 0 and 1.</Species>

<Species>In order to take into account also the different sequence lengths, we multiplied the score S by the ratio between the minimum length between query and subject and the maximum length between query and subjects.</Species>
<Species>In this way the total score is weighted on the base of the length, resulting in a lower similarity value if the lengths of the sequences are different.</Species>
<Species>The phylogenetic profile for each ORF is an array of index I with length equal to the number of genomes considered (320).</Species>
<Species>ORFs clustering The redundant list of 59,669 Vibrionaceae ORFs contained multiple copies of the same genes due to the presence of conserved genes in the considered genomes.</Species>
<Species>In order to reduce the redundancy, we clustered proteins using a two-step approach.</Species>
<Species>The first step is based on COG (Cluster of Othologous Genes) annotation.</Species>
<Species>COG classifies conserved genes according to their homologous relationships.</Species>
<Species>All the Vibrionaceae ORFs were annotated using COG clusters and proteins sharing the same COG code were considered belonging to the same cluster.</Species>
<Species>In particular, the annotation process consists of a similarity search of all the ORFs against the COG proteins using blast and considering the best hit for each protein.</Species>
<Species>43,024 ORFs presented a similarity with a COG entry, producing 2,463 different clusters.</Species>
<Species>In the second step, the remaining 16,645 ORFs without similarity with any COG entry were clustered using CD-HIT software [26].</Species>
<Species>CD-HIT program clusters protein sequence database at high sequence identity threshold and efficiently removes high sequence redundancy.</Species>
<Species>This last clustering process produced 9,613 different groups of similar proteins.</Species>

<Species>Finally from the 12,076 total clusters obtained by this methodology, those composed by ORFs that do not have any ortologous genes (with a phylogenetic profile composed by an array with all zero values except for one position match with itself) were eliminated, resulting in a dataset composed by 8,239 distinct clusters.</Species>
<Species>The final phylogenetic profile for each cluster (meta-profile) was defined as the median of all the profiles belonging to the cluster.</Species>
<Species>At the end of these procedures the final phylogenetic matrix was composed by 8,239 rows (cluster of genes) and 320 columns (organisms).</Species>
<Species>In each cell the median of the index in the cluster was reported.</Species>
<Species>Cluster analysis Several clustering techniques have been used to identify the similarity structure underneath our data.</Species>
<Species>A k-means and a two-way hierarchical cluster analysis with Euclidean distance and complete linkage were performed on the phylogenetic matrix.</Species>

<Species>The goal of a cluster analysis is to partition the elements into subsets without any constrains or a priori information, so that two criteria are satisfied: homogeneity, elements inside a cluster are highly similar to each other; and separation, elements from different clusters have low similarity to each other.</Species>

<Species>The Figure of Merit (FOM) is a measure of fit of the expression patterns for the clusters produced by a particular algorithm that estimates the predictive power of a clustering algorithm.</Species>

<Species>It is computed by removing each sample in turn from the data set, clustering genes based on the remaining data, and calculating the fit of the withheld sample to the clustering pattern obtained from the other samples.</Species>
<Species>On our data FOM analysis identified the best number of k-means clusters between 10 and 15.</Species>
<Species>We decided to set k (in the k-means analysis) equal to 14.</Species>
<Species>In each of these 14 clusters subsequent hierarchical cluster analysis was performed with bootstrap cluster assessment.</Species>
<Species>All the previous analyses were performed with TMEV software [27], freely available at [28].</Species>
<Species>Enrichment categories Each cluster of genes has been annotated according to COG code, GO terms and KEGG pathway maps.</Species>

<Species>Class enrichment (with respect to the entire matrix) has been calculated according to the hypergeometric distribution that was used to obtain the chance probability of observing the number of genes annotated with a particular COG, GO and KEGG category among the selected cluster.</Species>

<Species>The probability P of observing at least k genes of a functional category within a group of n genes is given by: P=Si=kn(fi)(g   fn   i)(gn) MathType@MTEF@5@5@@47C6@ where f is the total number of genes with the same category (in the matrix) and g is the total number of genes in our matrix.</Species>
<Species>Estrogen receptor alpha (ERa) mRNA copy numbers in immunohistochemically ERa-positive-, and negative breast cancer tissues</Species>
<Species>Video analysis of the escape flight of Pileated Woodpecker Dryocopus pileatus: does the Ivory-billed Woodpecker Campephilus principalis persist in continental North America?</Species>
label: Species
