text: <Species>Abstract Background The apparent rediscovery of the Ivory-billed Woodpecker Campephilus principalis in Arkansas, USA, previously feared extinct, was supported by video evidence of a single bird in flight (Fitzpatrick et al, Science 2005, 308:1460-1462).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Plumage patterns and wingbeat frequency of the putative Ivory-billed Woodpecker were said to be incompatible with the only possible confusion species native to the area, the Pileated Woodpecker Dryocopus pileatus.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Results New video analysis of Pileated Woodpeckers in escape flights comparable to that of the putative Ivory-billed Woodpecker filmed in Arkansas shows that Pileated Woodpeckers can display a wingbeat frequency equivalent to that of the Arkansas bird during escape flight.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>The critical frames from the Arkansas video that were used to identify the bird as an Ivory-billed Woodpecker are shown to be equally, or more, compatible with the Pileated Woodpecker.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Conclusion The identification of the bird filmed in Arkansas in April 2004 as an Ivory-billed Woodpecker is best regarded as unsafe.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The similarities between the Arkansas bird and known Pileated Woodpeckers suggest that it was most likely a Pileated Woodpecker.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Background The reported rediscovery of the Ivory-billed Woodpecker in 2004-5 in the Big Woods of Arkansas gave new impetus to efforts to conserve the mature bottomland woodlands of the south-eastern USA.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Several sightings have been reported without photographic evidence being obtained [1].</Species>
<Species>Unless sightings are, however, independently verifiable on the basis of photographic or other recorded evidence, the possibility that mistakes have been made cannot be eliminated.</Species>

<Species>Crucial to the scientific case for the persistence of the Ivory-billed Woodpecker was a 4 s video of a large woodpecker in flight recorded by M.D. Luneau on 25 April 2004 (henceforth referred to as the 'Luneau video') and published in 2005</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>[1], which was claimed to be inconsistent with the plumage patterns of the superficially similar Pileated Woodpecker (a common resident bird of the area).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Both species are large, black-and-white woodpeckers [2].</Species>
<Species>The upperwing of the Ivory-billed Woodpecker is black, with white secondary feathers and white on some inner primary feathers.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Pileated Woodpeckers have a largely black upperwing, with white restricted to the 'wrist' due to white bases to the primary feathers.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The underwing of Pileated Woodpecker has all-white underwing coverts, giving an appearance of a white underwing with a broad black outline (the black flight feathers).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>These plumage differences result in the Ivory-billed Woodpecker having a white trailing edge to the wings (upper and lower sides), whereas the Pileated Woodpecker has a black trailing edge to the wings.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Both species have black wing-tips.</Species>
<Species>These and other plumage characteristics are shown in [1,2].</Species>

<Species>The wingbeat frequency of the bird in the Luneau video was measured at 8.6 beats s-1, similar to that inferred from archival sound recording of a single Ivory-billed Woodpecker, but claimed to be outside the range of Pileated Woodpeckers (which generally have slower wingbeats)</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>[1,3].</Species>
<Species>Sibley et al [4] questioned the video evidence, in particular providing alternative explanations for the plumage patterns of the Luneau bird in flight and at rest.</Species>

<Species>They pointed out individual frames of the Luneau video that appear to show three features that are each inconsistent with Ivory-billed Woodpecker: (1) apparently black secondary feathers on the upper surface of the left wing, (2) particularly bright white primary bases, and (3) a black band curving smoothly round the wing tip (see Figure 3 in [4]).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>They hypothesized that flexing of a Pileated Woodpecker's wings during flight could produce the appearance of white trailing edges on both wings in low-quality videos [4].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>They offered, however, no direct evidence to show that this could cause a video of a Pileated Woodpecker to look like the bird in the Luneau video.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Fitzpatrick et al [5] in turn rebutted some aspects of the hypothesis of Sibley et al [4], publishing video stills of Pileated Woodpeckers, and a model of a Pileated Woodpecker, that appeared to show a black trailing edge to the wings inconsistent with Ivory-billed Woodpecker and the Luneau video.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Fitzpatrick et al [5] neither rebutted nor discussed the three key inconsistencies described above.</Species>
<Species>Without further evidence, this became largely a theoretical debate over interpretation of field characters that were barely visible in the very small images originally obtained.</Species>
<Species>On one hand, as pointed out in Sibley et al [4], some of the frames of the bird in the Luneau video do appear to be inconsistent with Ivory-billed Woodpecker.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>On the other hand, the flight pattern of the bird in the Luneau video is asserted to be atypical for Pileated Woodpecker (but matching anecdotal descriptions of Ivory-billed Woodpecker).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Furthermore, the general impression of the bird in the Luneau video was that there is far too much white in the wings for it to be a Pileated Woodpecker, and that if it was a Pileated, then it must be an aberrant one with abnormally extensive white plumage.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Such birds occasionally occur, and have been observed in the Arkansas study area</Species>
<Species>[6].</Species>

<Species>This study was undertaken to determine whether the flight and plumage of the bird in the Luneau video really was inconsistent with either a normal or partial albino Pileated Woodpecker.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Independent analyses of the plumage patterns and wingbeat frequencies observable in Pileated Woodpeckers are presented, and it is concluded that the identification of the bird in the Luneau video as definite Ivory-billed Woodpecker is probably unsafe.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Results On January 28 and February 5, 2006, David Nolin (DN) video-recorded Pileated Woodpeckers Dryocopus pileatus at a bird-feeder in Dayton, Ohio, USA.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>A Hi-8 Sony Handycam was used, hand-held, at approximately 5 m from the feeder.</Species>
<Species>Birds on the tree trunk were alarmed by movement, and their escape flights recorded.</Species>

<Species>Four escape flights were captured that approximate to that recorded for the putative Ivory-billed Woodpecker Campephilus principalis by Luneau in April 2004 and published in Fitzpatrick et al [1].</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The videos are not directly equivalent because the Pileated Woodpeckers made only short escape flights to nearby trees, whereas the putative Ivory-billed Woodpecker in the Luneau video showed little sign of coming to rest before being lost from view.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Nevertheless, interesting comparisons can be made.</Species>

<Species>Wingbeat frequency of Pileated Woodpecker The woodpecker in the Luneau video maintains a steady rapid wingbeat rate of 8.6 beats s-1 for at least 8 wingbeats [1], a figure that was confirmed by independent analysis during preparation of this paper.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The Pileated woodpeckers in DN's video do not do this - after initial rapid flapping immediately after take-off, they settle into a more relaxed level flight.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>As shown in Tables 1 and 2, although the mean wingbeat frequencies of the Pileated Woodpeckers in DN's video are slower than the 8.6 s-1 recorded for the bird in the Luneau video</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>[1,3,5] the first four wingbeats, the initial escape response, are faster than those claimed for Pileated Woodpeckers in the literature [1,3,5].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>For the four escape flights, the mean frequency values for the first four wingbeats are 7.1, 6.7, 8.6, and 8.0 s-1, respectively.</Species>

<Species>The 8.6 beats s-1 of the bird identified in the Luneau video, while consistent with the limited data (n = 1; see Discussion) for Ivory-billed Woodpecker, is equally consistent with Pileated Woodpecker in its initial escape flight.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The bird in the Luneau video maintains a frequency of 8.6 s-1 for the next four wingbeats too, whereas the Pileated Woodpeckers recorded here all slowed their flight as they prepared to land in nearby trees.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>There are no data to suggest whether Pileated Woodpeckers can maintain a wingbeat frequency approaching 8.6 s-1 for eight or more wingbeats, like the bird in the Luneau video.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>It remains possible that the flight pattern of the bird in the Luneau video is unusual for Pileated Woodpecker, but a frequency of 8.6 s-1 is consistent with a Pileated Woodpecker gaining initial speed and height in escape flight, and by itself cannot be taken as strong evidence that the Luneau video bird was an Ivory-billed Woodpecker.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>This is discussed further below.</Species>
<Species>Plumage pattern of Pileated Woodpeckers in flight The video of Pileated Woodpeckers in flight was obtained in avi format, decompiled and examined frame by frame.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Comparisons of Pileated Woodpecker images with key images of Luneau video are shown in Figures 1 and 2, and suggest a genuine resemblance between the bird in the Luneau video and a Pileated Woodpecker.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Analysis is complicated by the different digital processing of the two videos, and in the case of the Nolin videos it is important to concentrate only on those frames or part-frames where apparent plumage features are not an artifact of blurred images.</Species>
<Species>Thirty-six frames from the fourth example of Pileated escape flight, which most resembled the flight path of the Luneau video bird, were analysed systematically frame by frame.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>They represent seven complete wingbeats (1.20 s from the middle of the second wingbeat to middle of wingbeat 9) and were directly compared frame-by-frame with the equivalent fields (middle wingbeat 2 - middle wingbeat 9) of the Luneau video.</Species>
<Species>This comparison is shown in Figure 3.</Species>

<Species>The images of the birds are not identical, but in every frame of the 36 frames available, there are sufficient similarities to suggest that the bird in the Luneau video is consistent with the known Pileated Woodpecker.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Further comparisons of the Luneau bird with the other three Pileated escape flights recorded are presented in the supplementary material (see Additional file 1).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Key findings of the video analysis are: 1.</Species>
<Species>Pileated Woodpeckers flying near-horizontally away from the observer show much more white in poor-quality video than would be expected from their general plumage pattern.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>They present an appearance of a black-bodied bird with largely white wings and black wingtips, very similar to the bird in the Luneau video; compare in particular Figure 1B, frame 758, with Figure 1A, frame 283.3.</Species>

<Species>The expected appearance of the upperwing of Pileated Woodpecker - mostly black with a small white patch at the base of the primaries - is often not seen, and is only clearly resolvable when birds are flying near-vertically before landing on a tree trunk; something the bird in the Luneau video did not do.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>2.</Species>
<Species>The black trailing edge to the underwing of Pileated Woodpecker is often very inconspicuous and may disappear completely.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Due to motion and flexion of the wing, the black trailing edge is much more obvious towards the wingtips.</Species>
<Species>This produces an apparent plumage pattern that matches the patterns shown by the Luneau video bird (compare Figure 1B, frames 175 and 457 with Figure 1A, frames 300 and 416.7).</Species>

<Species>In many frames of Pileated Woodpecker, a black trailing edge to the wing is discernable (though due to bleeding of white as a video artifact, it appears narrower than it really is).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>However, analysis of the bird in the Luneau video in light of images of known Pileated Woodpeckers confirms that a similar black trailing edge to the wing is discernable in some frames of the Luneau video (compare Figure 1B, frame 775 with Figure 1A, frame 366.7: the apparent plumage patterns are similar, and inconsistent with Ivory-billed Woodpecker).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>It is argued here that the hypothesis put forward in Sibley et al [4] is correct, and that the black trailing edge of the underwing of Pileated Woodpecker can indeed, due to flexion of the wings during the downstroke, be misinterpreted as the black leading edge and wingtips of the upperwing of an Ivory-billed Woodpecker.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>3.</Species>
<Species>Figure 3 shows that the plumage patterns shown by the Luneau bird, throughout several wingbeat cycles, are compatible with Pileated Woodpecker.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The three plumage features described in Sibley et al [4] that are incompatible with Ivory-billed Woodpecker (black secondary feathers on upper surface of left wing, brighter white primary bases, and a black band curling round the wing tip) are seen consistently in the Luneau video and are recapitulated throughout the video of Pileated Woodpecker.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Discussion Evidence is presented here to show that the distinctive plumage features of Pileated Woodpecker are surprisingly difficult to resolve in poor-quality video of birds in escape flight away from the camera, and that they can show apparent plumage patterns that might more readily be associated with Ivory-billed Woodpecker.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Irrespective of the identity of the bird in the Luneau video, this knowledge will be critical to assessment of further claims of Ivory-billed Woodpeckers during the current intensive search effort.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>It is, however, suggested here that critical frames used for identification of the Luneau video woodpecker as an Ivory-billed Woodpecker are also consistent with Pileated Woodpecker.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The wingbeat frequency of the bird in the Luneau video is also perhaps consistent with Pileated Woodpecker, at least for short periods of flight.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Analysis of the videos of Pileated Woodpecker has supported the hypothesised interpretations of key frames of the Luneau video by Sibley et al [4].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Although the rebuttal of that comment in Fitzpatrick et al [5] asserted that flexion and motion of wings of Pileated Woodpeckers could not produce the images seen in the Luneau video, it has been shown here that they can.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The Luneau video as presented in Fitzpatrick et al [1], shows features that are consistent with Pileated Woodpecker, and inconsistent with Ivory-billed Woodpecker.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>It is argued in this paper that, in fact, the black trailing edge of the wing of a Pileated Woodpecker is seen clearly in the Luneau video, during the downstroke of the wingbeat cycle, but that it has been misinterpreted as black wingtips (Figure 1, 2, 3).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>A fuller analysis of the Luneau video by the Cornell University team is presented online</Species>
<Species>[7].</Species>
<Species>Although it is not peer-reviewed, the points this article makes should be taken into account.</Species>
<Species>The authors summarise nine diagnostic traits from their analysis of the Luneau video that identify the bird as Ivory-billed Woodpecker.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>These are listed and discussed point-by point below.</Species>
<Species>1. 'The underwing pattern in flight consistently appears largely white, giving the appearance of having black wingtips but lacking any black along the rear, or trailing edge.'</Species>
<Species>Data presented in this paper show that this statement is not wholly supported, and in any case the underwing of Pileated Woodpeckers can present the same appearance.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>2. 'The upperwing pattern in flight consistently shows a broad, white trailing edge, with no frames demonstrating the conspicuous dark rear border to be expected of normal Pileated Woodpeckers.'</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Notwithstanding that certain frames of the Luneau video (e.g. frame 350) do appear to show a black trailing edge to the upperwing, data presented in this paper shows that, at this angle of view and resolution of video, Pileated Woodpeckers also may fail to show this feature.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>This analysis has shown that the hypothesis presented in Sibley et al [4] is plausible, i.e. that some of the frames interpreted by [1] to show the upperwing of an Ivory-billed Woodpecker may in fact show large amounts of white and the black trailing edge from the underwing of a Pileated Woodpecker.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>3. 'The wings are longer relative to the body diameter than in Pileated Woodpecker and consistent with the wing shape of Ivory-billed Woodpecker.'</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Fitzpatrick et al [5] agreed that accurate measurements were not possible from the video images presented in their original paper</Species>
<Species>[1], and it seems unlikely that much confidence can be placed in the wing-length measurements of the bird in the Luneau video.</Species>
<Species>Comparison of, for example, Figure 1A, frame 283.3 with Figure 1B, frame 578 suggests that any differences will be very difficult to prove.</Species>

<Species>4. 'Reenactment of the scene using life-sized, realistically painted, dynamically flapping models produced images remarkably similar to those of the Luneau video using the Ivory-billed Woodpecker model, and images clearly identifiable as Pileated Woodpecker using a model of that species.'</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Interpretation of model re-enactments is hampered by the fact that the stiff, flat-winged models cannot reflect the wing flexion and curvature of real birds.</Species>
<Species>Reenactment of the scene using real Pileated Woodpeckers has produced images remarkably similar to the Luneau video.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>5. 'The wingbeat frequency is 8.6 beats per second, which is almost identical to that recorded for Ivory-billed Woodpecker (as documented by one acoustic record from 1935).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The wing-beat frequencies of Pileated Woodpecker are not known to exceed 7.5 beats per second, and more typically range between 3 and 6 beats per second.'</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The fact that in only four recorded escape flights of Pileated Woodpecker, two were recorded for which the initial escape flight wingbeat frequency (8.0 s-1 and 8.6 s-1) exceeded that previously recorded for this species shows that previous datasets were too limited to make this conclusion.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Birds flap more rapidly at take off to gain altitude and speed than they do in sustained level flight: Pileated Woodpecker flight data in the literature [1,4,5] was derived from the work of Tobalske [8], which explicitly excluded the initial take-off period, and therefore cannot be used to support the elimination of Pileated Woodpecker in the Luneau video.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Furthermore, the bird in the Luneau video is consistently gaining height from a low position above water and, whatever its species, might be expected to flap more rapidly than if it were in level flight.</Species>
<Species>Tanner [9] noted that Pileated Woodpeckers can maintain extended fast direct flight.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>He was of the opinion that flight pattern was not a useful character for separating the two species in the field, and that Pileated Woodpeckers frequently fly in a manner that was in no way different to Ivory-billed Woodpeckers.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The figure of 8.6 wingbeats per second for the Luneau bird (data reanalysed here) is taken as consistent with Ivory-billed Woodpecker on the basis of analysis of a single archival audio recording [3].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The Ivory-billed Woodpecker in that audio tape is clearly flapping its wings, but without accompanying visual confirmation it is not clear that it is in flight.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In general, larger birds are expected to flap their wings more slowly than smaller birds of comparable wing morphology.</Species>
<Species>Tobalske [8] showed that, across species, smaller woodpeckers tend to flap more quickly than larger ones, and that there was considerable intraspecific variation.</Species>
<Species>The assertion that Ivory-billed Woodpeckers flap their wings more quickly than Pileated Woodpeckers is therefore counterintuitive.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Further comment is conjecture: while the flight pattern and wing posture of the bird in the Luneau video may be unusual, it has not been shown that it is outside the range of variability of Pileated Woodpecker, and cannot therefore be used to eliminate the possibility that it was the commoner species.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>6. 'White plumage on the back is visible on the retreating bird as it begins to gain altitude.</Species>
<Species>Ivory-billed Woodpecker has white on the back; Pileated Woodpecker has entirely black back.'</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>This was discussed by Sibley et al [4], who argued that the images thought to show white on the dorsum were too small to be accepted uncritically.</Species>

<Species>In all the frames of the Luneau video that appear to show white on the dorsum, the bird is distant (dorsal white is not visible on the higher resolution images earlier in the video) and partially obscured, making it difficult to distinguish dorsum from wing.</Species>
<Species>Spurious areas of white pixels appear as artifacts in both videos.</Species>
<Species>Nevertheless, this remains the best evidence that the Luneau bird was not a standard Pileated Woodpecker.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>7. 'The dorsal view of the right wing as it begins to unfold shows a triangle of white that matches in size and position the white on the folded wing of an Ivory-billed Woodpecker beginning to launch into flight.'</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>No further comment is provided here.</Species>
<Species>An alternative explanation was offered by Sibley et al [4] and rebutted by Fitzpatrick et al [5].</Species>
<Species>The statement requires a degree of certainty about the position of the wing.</Species>

<Species>(8) 'The distance between the wrist area and the tip of the tail (32-36 cm, as measured when the bird begins to take flight) is comparable to known measurements of Ivory-billed Woodpecker and considerably larger than even the largest Pileated Woodpecker we measured.'</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>As stated under (3), above, there is general agreement that accurate measurements are not possible from the Luneau video because too many uncontrolled variables are involved [4,5].</Species>

<Species>9. 'Only 20 seconds before the woodpecker flees, a bird with the size and color pattern of an Ivory-billed Woodpecker was perched within 3 m of the site from which the woodpecker took flight.'</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>This would be a strong argument if it could be shown that the object in question was a bird and not, as is now apparently thought likely, a section of branch or tree stump [10].</Species>

<Species>The Luneau video reveals several white triangular patches apparently visible on or around tree trunks, most or all of which must therefore be images of tree topography or video artifacts.</Species>
<Species>This was discussed in the literature (see [4,5]).</Species>
<Species>Central to the identification of the flying bird seen in the Luneau video was the evidence that plumage and flight patterns were inconsistent with Pileated Woodpecker.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>A very basic video analysis presented here has suggested that this may not be the case, and that further research is needed.</Species>

<Species>Any identification of the bird in the Luneau video as an Ivory-bill must take into account the data presented here and in Sibley et al [4], which shows it is largely consistent with Pileated Woodpecker and points out apparent inconsistencies with Ivory-billed Woodpecker.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>This does not of course necessarily imply that the Ivory-billed Woodpecker is extinct, nor indeed entirely rule out the possibility that the bird in the Luneau video was one.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>There appears to be no reason to question the anecdotal sight records of Ivory-billed Woodpecker presented in Fitzpatrick et al</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>[1] (or in many online sources), because some of them appear credible, albeit brief.</Species>
<Species>Audio evidence has since been published [11] although this too is far from conclusive.</Species>

<Species>However, to regard the Luneau video by itself as presenting anything other than an unidentified woodpecker falls below the standards of proof normally required for scientific publication: the images are not good enough.</Species>

<Species>The Ivory-billed Woodpecker may persist in continental North America, and there is enough anecdotal evidence to make this a possibility, but the Luneau video does not support the case.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The balance of evidence would suggest that the bird in the Luneau video is more likely to have been a Pileated Woodpecker, but the search for Ivory-billed Woodpecker should continue.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>While this paper was under review, a report of sight records and sound recordings of Ivory-billed Woodpeckers was published from a location in Florida [12].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>This very exciting claim is strengthened by reports of sighting of the white dorsal stripes on one bird in flight.</Species>
<Species>Unfortunately, several sightings were made without optical aids and cannot be considered proven.</Species>
<Species>The 'kent' calls recorded from the Florida location are spectrographically similar to the 'bleat' calls of young White-tailed Deer, as described in Richardson et al [13].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>A clear photograph will be required from this location too before the presence of Ivory-billed Woodpeckers can be considered confirmed.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>It is hoped that this paper will help with assessment of any further low quality photographs or videos.</Species>
<Species>Conclusion Flight and plumage patterns of the putative Ivory-billed Woodpecker recorded in Arkansas in 2005 are recapitulated by confirmed Pileated Woodpeckers.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The bird in the Arkansas video is best regarded as not fully identified, and is probably a Pileated Woodpecker.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Methods Video recording Pileated Woodpeckers were attracted to a bird feeder containing suet at Grants Trail, Dayton, OH 45459.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The suet feeder was placed approximately 2.1 m high on a tree trunk, and the distance to the suet feeder from the observation point was approximately 5 m. Birds on the feeder were startled by movement of window blinds on January 28 and February 5, 2006, and their escape flights were filmed using a Sony Hi-8 SteadyShot video camera at 29.97 frames s-1.</Species>
<Species>At least two birds feature in the videos, male and female.</Species>
<Species>Analogue tape was converted to digital by connecting the Hi-8 camera directly to a Sony DCR-HC30 digital video camera and recording onto that camera's mini dv cassette.</Species>
<Species>The resulting images were converted to an avi file using Windows Movie Maker on a Windows XP PC.</Species>
<Species>The video is freely available in wmv format [14] and in avi format from the author or David Nolin (via the author).</Species>
<Species>The video was decompiled using Blaze Media Pro (Mystik Media, Hampstead, NC, USA) for a detailed analysis.</Species>

<Species>Import into AvidR Xpress Pro HD for deinterlacing did not reduce the wing flicker seen in the images, and further professional processing could not improve the resolution, so the original decompiled file was used for analysis.</Species>
<Species>Hence some frames contain two overlaid images, which may lower the resolution in some cases.</Species>
<Species>The decompiled file was examined frame by frame and compared to the decompiled images of the putative Ivory-billed Woodpecker presented in Fitzpatrick et al [1].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Wingbeat frequencies were calculated by noting the frame number of the midpoint of the downstroke of each wingbeat (e.g. Figure 1B, frame 758) and calculating the length of time taken per wingbeat as (number of frames between downstroke midpoints)/29.97.</Species>
<Species>Authors' contributions JMC performed the data analysis and drafted the manuscript.</Species>
<Species>Supplementary Material</Species>
<Species>A novel, non-invasive, online-monitoring, versatile and easy plant-based probe for measuring leaf water status</Species>
<Species>Abstract A high-precision pressure probe is described which allows non-invasive online-monitoring of the water relations of intact leaves.</Species>
<Species>Real-time recording of the leaf water status occurred by data transfer to an Internet server.</Species>
<Species>The leaf patch clamp pressure probe measures the attenuated pressure, Pp, of a leaf patch in response to a constant clamp pressure, Pclamp.</Species>
<Species>Pp is sensed by a miniaturized silicone pressure sensor integrated into the device.</Species>

<Species>The magnitude of Pp is dictated by the transfer function of the leaf, Tf, which is a function of leaf patch volume and ultimately of cell turgor pressure, Pc, as shown theoretically.</Species>

<Species>The power function Tf=f(Pc) theoretically derived was experimentally confirmed by concomitant Pp and Pc measurements on intact leaflets of the liana Tetrastigma voinierianum under greenhouse conditions.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Simultaneous Pp recordings on leaflets up to 10 m height above ground demonstrated that changes in Tf induced by Pc changes due to changes of microclimate and/or of the irrigation regime were sensitively reflected in corresponding changes of Pp.</Species>
<Species>Analysis of the data show that transpirational water loss during the morning hours was associated with a transient rise in turgor pressure gradients within the leaflets.</Species>
<Species>Subsequent recovery of turgescence during the afternoon was much faster than the preceding transpiration-induced water loss if the plants were well irrigated.</Species>

<Species>Our data show the enormous potential of the leaf patch clamp pressure probe for leaf water studies including unravelling of the hydraulic communication between neighbouring leaves and over long distances within tall plants (trees).</Species>
<Species>Introduction Optimum water supply, particularly at peak needs of the plants, is an important issue for greenhouse and field vegetable production.</Species>

<Species>In a greenhouse on a sunny day, evaporation and transpiration (so-called evapotranspiration) can occur so rapidly that water loss can cause plant damage before wilting symptoms are visible.</Species>
<Species>Even at lower temperatures the restricted rooting in greenhouses leads frequently to plant water deficiency.</Species>
<Species>Thus, no matter how slight, drought stress will result in a significant reduction in growth and, in turn, of harvest yield.</Species>

<Species>On the other hand, over-irrigation must be avoided and the appropriate method of watering must be selected because wet soils and permanent moisture on plant organs promote the incidence of root mould, grey mould (Botrytis blight), formation of leaf oedema, and other plant diseases (Sherf and MacNab, 1986).</Species>
<Species>Conservation of water is another important issue in semi-arid and arid regions where water is scarce.</Species>

<Species>The advent of (subsurface) drip irrigation has considerably reduced water consumption of agricultural, horticultural, and greenhouse crops, but has also highlighted the need for sensors monitoring water deficiency of plants directly and online (Jones, 2004).</Species>
<Species>In plant physiology and agriculture the pressure bomb technique pioneered by Scholander et al. (1965) is a widely accepted reference technique for measuring leaf water status.</Species>
<Species>However, the method is massively invasive, slow, labour-intensive (and therefore expensive), unsuitable for automation, and gives only spot measurements.</Species>
<Species>Furthermore, interpretation of the data is still a matter of debate (Zimmermann U et al., 2004; Zimmermann D et al., 2007).</Species>
<Species>Leaf thickness is also sometimes used as an indicator for water stress (Burquez, 1987; McBurney, 1992; Malone, 1993).</Species>
<Species>Leaf thickness monitoring devices are commercially available.</Species>

<Species>They are non-invasive and suitable for online measurements, but have the disadvantage that changes in water status are frequently not reflected sensitively in changes of leaf thickness.</Species>

<Species>The pressure probe technique pioneered by Zimmermann, Tomos, and others (Zimmermann et al., 1969, 2004; Tomos, 1988; Balling and Zimmermann, 1990), on the other hand, is a well established technology for measuring turgor and xylem pressure on the levels of individual cells and xylem vessels, respectively.</Species>
<Species>This technique is not suitable for automation.</Species>
<Species>Moreover, the probe technique requires rather sophisticated equipment and a high level of technical skill.</Species>

<Species>These disadvantages are also shared by the ball tonometry, a method which allows non-invasive monitoring of cell turgor pressure by application of an external pressure (Lintilhac et al., 2000; Geitmann, 2006).</Species>

<Species>Other water stress monitoring devices are described in the literature, but all of them have various disadvantages which prevented their implementation for leaf water status measurements in greenhouses or in the field (see, for example, the review article of Jones, 2004, and also Grant et al., 2007).</Species>

<Species>In this communication a novel, non-invasive, online-monitoring plant-based probe is described that meets the demands of controlling horticultural and agricultural water applications.</Species>
<Species>The probe is characterized by high precision, operating convenience, minimum costs, and by automation suitability.</Species>
<Species>Data can be transferred wireless to a personal computer or to an Internet server via a mobile phone network for real-time evaluation and for the automatic regulation of irrigation.</Species>
<Species>The technology includes a miniaturized silicone pressure sensor integrated into a spring clamp that is clamped to a patch of an intact plant leaf.</Species>
<Species>The patch clamp pressure probe measures the attenuated pressure response of the leaf patch upon the application of a constant, clamped pressure.</Species>
<Species>The attenuation of the applied pressure depends on the transfer function of the leaf.</Species>

<Species>The magnitude of the transfer function depends on two terms, a turgor pressure-independent term (related to the compression of the cuticle, cell walls, and other structural elements) and a turgor pressure-dependent term.</Species>

<Species>Theory shows that the turgor pressure-dependent part of the transfer function Tf is a power function of the cell turgor pressure, Pc, and predicts that Tf assumes values close to zero if Pc is high and, vice versa, values close to unity if Pc is low.</Species>
<Species>This could be verified by combined turgor pressure probe and leaf patch clamp pressure probe measurements on leaflets of the liana Tetrastigma voinierianum.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The 10-m tall liana growing in a tropical greenhouse was selected for the first studies because a comprehensive data set about diurnal changes in xylem and turgor pressure gradients under various environmental conditions existed for this greenhouse plant (Benkert et al., 1995; Thurmer et al., 1999; see also Zimmermann et al., 2004).</Species>
<Species>Measurements of diurnal changes of the patch clamp pressure performed here yielded results which were consistent with the previous pressure probe work on the liana.</Species>

<Species>The data also demonstrated that changes in the irrigation regime and in microclimate can be sensed by this novel probe very sensitively and that use of several probes allowed the study of the diurnal water transport at multiple scales from single leaves to the whole organism (Meinzer et al., 2001).</Species>
<Species>This can be done without knowledge of the turgor pressure because the transfer function is a direct measure of leaf water status.</Species>

<Species>Materials and methods Plant material Experiments were performed on two specimens of the liana Tetrastigma voinierianum, growing in the c. 12 m tall tropical greenhouse of the University of Salzburg, Austria.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The ground ascended by about 5 m towards the backstage of the greenhouse.</Species>

<Species>The height of the plant in this area was about 4.5 m, whereas the height of the plant in the front area reached 10 m. However, the stem and the branches of the two plants were considerably longer, because the plants had grown vertically upwards and then part of the way downwards.</Species>
<Species>First measurements were performed during the last week of May, 2007.</Species>
<Species>This week was very sunny and warm.</Species>
<Species>Experiments were repeated during the last week of August and the first week of September, 2007.</Species>
<Species>At this time of the year the weather conditions were quite poor.</Species>
<Species>The weeks were rainy, sunshine occurred only occasionally.</Species>
<Species>On average, the sky was very cloudy.</Species>

<Species>Due to the variable weather conditions the ambient temperature, T, in the greenhouse usually varied between 19 oC and 27 oC. By contrast, during the hot week in May temperatures at the top of the plants could reach up to 44 oC.</Species>
<Species>The greenhouse was illuminated between 07.30 h and 19.00 h (CET=Central European Time).</Species>
<Species>During the day-time, the artificial illumination was switched off automatically once the natural irradiance exceeded about 45 umol photons m   2 s   1 at ground level.</Species>
<Species>At full sunshine, the light intensity was limited by automatically operating blinds.</Species>
<Species>The relative humidity (r.h.) of the air was regulated by overhead misters.</Species>
<Species>Despite attempts to keep the r.h. above 60-70% large axial r.h. gradients along the stem of the liana were observed during sunny days (see below).</Species>
<Species>The ambient temperature and relative humidity at the measuring sites were determined by using thermistors (Tinytag; RS Components GmbH, Morfelden-Walldorf, Germany).</Species>
<Species>Leaf patch clamp pressure probe and data acquisition</Species>
<Species>The pressure sensor chip allows pressure measurements up to 100 kPa.</Species>
<Species>The sensor consists of a miniature piezoresistive Wheatstone bridge.</Species>

<Species>The sensors used in this work were purchased from the company    Raumedic    (Helmbrechts, Germany) and from the company    Keller    (AG, Druckmesstechnik; Winterthur, Switzerland).</Species>
<Species>However, it has to be pointed out that any other miniaturized pressure or force sensor could be used.</Species>
<Species>The sensor chip was integrated into one of the planar circular pads of a spring clamp shown schematically in Fig. 1.</Species>
<Species>The spring clamp consisted of two curved arms bridged by a spring in the middle (Wolfcraft GmbH; microfix S (B3630Fz60), Kempenich, Germany).</Species>

<Species>The clamp pressure exerted by the spring on the leaf, Pclamp, could be varied by a stiff strap (made of synthetic material) spanned between the arms of the spring clip at the handhold site (Fig. 1).</Species>
<Species>The length of the strap and thus the spring load acting on the leaflet between the two pads could be varied by regularly punched holes (as in a belt).</Species>
<Species>Calibration of the sensor chips was performed by pressurization in a pressure chamber equipped with an integrated manometer (LEO 1, Keller AG, Winterthur, Switzerland).</Species>
<Species>The readings of all sensors used in this study increased linearly with pressure in the range between 0 kPa and 100 kPa.</Species>
<Species>The pressure sensitivity of the various sensors was found to be almost identical for all probes.</Species>

<Species>Before use the probes were also tested for temperature-sensitivity in an accessible climate chamber because it is well-known that silicone-embedded sensors tend to become temperature-sensitive during storage.</Species>
<Species>Probes were subject to temperature regimes ranging from 10 oC to 35 oC. Probes were not used if the temperature treatment induced a pressure change larger than 0.5 kPa.</Species>
<Species>The signals of the leaf patch clamp pressure probe were transmitted by a telemetry system (teleBITcom gmbh, Teltow, Germany).</Species>

<Species>The operating distance between the battery-powered wireless telemetric transmitter and the receiver base station was up to 400 m. Each transmitter read, amplified, and converted the analogue signals of the pressure sensor into digitalized signals.</Species>

<Species>The data were sent together with the transmitter ID-code every 90 s via the ISM band of 433 MHz to the receiver base station which logged and transferred the data to a personal computer or to a GPRS modem linked to an Internet server (NTBB Systemtechnik GmbH, Zeuthen, Germany) for analysis and archival storage.</Species>
<Species>For sensor calibration and data recording the SENBIT software (teleBITcom gmbh, Teltow, Germany) was used.</Species>
<Species>The software allowed communication with up to 32 sensors at regular short intervals (90 s to 5 min).</Species>
<Species>In this study, up to 10 sensor/transmitter units were installed at different heights on the two lianas.</Species>
<Species>Data transfer to the Internet server operated without any problem during the entire experimental period.</Species>
<Species>However, for safety reasons hard-wired conventional data acquisition was also performed using dataloggers (Raumedic, Helmbrechts, Germany).</Species>
<Species>The dataloggers were controlled by a computer program that provided functions for data storage and sensor calibration.</Species>
<Species>Data were transferred regularly from the dataloggers to a personal computer.</Species>
<Species>Cell turgor pressure probe Turgor pressure measurements were performed on leaflets of the 10-m tall liana at c. 0.2 m height above the roots.</Species>
<Species>The construction and function of the cell turgor pressure probe has been described elsewhere (Zimmermann et al., 1969, 2004).</Species>
<Species>Briefly, the microcapillary was filled with oil up to the very tip and was then inserted into the upper leaflet surface between the main vein and the leaflet edge.</Species>
<Species>Insertion was made under a small overpressure (about 20 kPa) achieved by appropriate displacement of the metal rod in the probe in order to avoid tip clogging.</Species>
<Species>Penetration was stopped upon reaching the mesophyll cell layer and formation of a stable oil/sap meniscus within the tip region of the microcapillary of the probe.</Species>
<Species>During the measurements it was regularly proved whether the tip was clogged or not by appropriate displacement of the metal rod.</Species>
<Species>Theoretical background</Species>

<Species>The input pressure, Pin, experienced by the cells in a leaf patch is equal to the clamp pressure, Pclamp, only if the pressure signal is transferred lossless to the cells in the leaves.</Species>

<Species>However, losses usually occur due to the compressibility and the deformability of the silicone of the pressure sensor as well as of the compressibility of the cuticle and other structural elements of the leaf.</Species>
<Species>Therefore, theory shows that only a fraction of Pclamp may arrive at the cells, i.e. that the attenuation factor, Fa=Pin/Pclamp, is smaller than unity.</Species>
<Species>Fa depends on the individual leaf properties.</Species>
<Species>Fa can be assumed to be constant (and leaf thickness changes are negligible) if the structural elements are completely pre-compressed by application of an appropriate Pclamp.</Species>

<Species>If Pclamp is kept constant during the following experimental period, Pin is constant and the output pressure, Pp, is only determined by the cell transfer function, Tf(V), where V is the leaf patch volume.</Species>
<Species>In other words, Tf(V) determines the fraction of Pin sensed by the probe.</Species>

<Species>It is dimensionless and assumes values between zero and unity:(1)Tf depends on the volume of the leaf patch, V, at constant ambient temperature, T:(2)dV depends on changes in cell turgor pressure, dPc, as follows:(3)where op is the average volumetric elastic modulus of the clamped tissue (Philip, 1958).</Species>
<Species>op is a very complex parameter and will be dictated by the turgor pressure in the turgescent state.</Species>

<Species>For a first approximation it is assumed that op increases linearly with Pc (support for this assumption is given by Zimmermann and Steudle, 1978; Zimmermann and Husken, 1980; Wendler et al., 1983):(4)where a and b are constants for individual leaf properties.</Species>
<Species>Because of the viscoelastic properties of the cell wall, the magnitude of the constants depends on the duration of the external pressure application (Zimmermann and Husken, 1980).</Species>

<Species>The constants are relatively large if rapid turgor pressure changes are induced (e.g. by using the cell turgor pressure probe), whereas slow turgor pressure changes (e.g. under transpirational conditions) result in small values.</Species>

<Species>Combining equations 2-4 leads to equation 5.(5) Equation 5 can be integrated by assuming for a first approximation that at Pc=0 Tf=1 and that the internal osmotic pressure of the cells remained constant.</Species>
<Species>After appropriate re-arrangements equation 6 is obtained:(6)and, respectively, if the denominator is replaced by equation 4:(7)</Species>
<Species>Introducing equation 6 into equation 1 yields the wanted relationship between the parameters Pp and Pin:(8) Equation 8 can be verified experimentally.</Species>
<Species>Inspection of the equation shows that the patch clamp pressure, Pp, is a power function of the turgor pressure, Pc.</Species>
<Species>The exponent of the function is equal to or smaller than unity.</Species>
<Species>If a=1 and b <<Pc, equation 8 turns into Pp=b/Pc, i.e. both parameters are directly reciprocally coupled with each other.</Species>
<Species>Thus Tf assumes low values if Pc is high and, vice versa, a value close to unity if Pc is close to zero.</Species>
<Species>Using appropriate values for a and b for a given leaf (see below) it can be shown that below Pc=100 kPa, Pp increases dramatically.</Species>
<Species>This means that the transfer function responds very sensitively upon loss of complete turgor pressure.</Species>
<Species>In the derivation of equation 8 it was assumed that op is temperature-independent.</Species>

<Species>However, temperature effects on cell elasticity are well-known, although they are not very large in the temperature range investigated here (see, for example, Petersen et al., 1982; Niklas, 1992; Hogan and Niklas, 2004; Edelmann et al., 2005).</Species>

<Species>Temperature effects on op cannot be excluded if different values for the Pclamp, and, in turn, for the input pressure, Pin, are selected, as well as if significantly different values for the constants a and b are assumed for optimum fitting of the Pp=f(Pc) curves.</Species>

<Species>Therefore, in the case of large temperature gradients as observed here (see Figs 2 and 3) only the relative, but not the absolute changes in Pp measured at the different heights can be compared with each other.</Species>
<Species>However, Pp values measured at the same height are still comparable and give information about the turgescence, i.e. about the water status of the leaf cells.</Species>
<Species>Results The leaf patch clamp pressure probe was clamped about 2 cm away from the edge of a leaflet of the compound leaves.</Species>
<Species>Leaflets of similar size (176+58 cm2, n=12) were used.</Species>
<Species>Inspection of the leaf patches after removal of the probes under the microscope revealed no changes in leaflet appearance beneath the pads, even after several weeks.</Species>
<Species>Lesions on the leaves were never found.</Species>
<Species>Only occasionally were very slight impressions of the pads on the leaflet surface observed.</Species>
<Species>Clamping of the leaves could be performed at any time of the day.</Species>
<Species>Clamp pressures, Pclamp, applied to the leaves were of the order of 80-200 kPa.</Species>
<Species>The optimum value for Pclamp of a given leaf has to be found empirically.</Species>

<Species>Experience shows that Pclamp values could be considered as optimal if the output pressure Pp assumed values between 10 kPa and 25 kPa upon clamping in the early morning (when turgor pressure was high) or between 50 kPa and 70 kPa upon clamping around noon or towards early afternoon (when turgor pressure was usually low).</Species>

<Species>The magnitude of Pp depended on the compressibility and deformability properties of the individual leaves which may vary considerably due to age, morphology, leaf thickness, abiotic factors etc.</Species>
<Species>The magnitude of Pclamp had no effect on the diurnal profiles of Pp, in response to changes in microclimate and/or changes in the irrigation regime.</Species>

<Species>Probes clamped on the same leaflet or nearby leaflets of leaves responded almost identically upon temporary changes in transpiration and/or water supply even if the Pclamp values were different due to different leaf thickness as well as local compressibility and deformability properties (data not shown).</Species>
<Species>This was found over the entire height of the plants.</Species>
<Species>Screening experiments proved further that a high surface roughness prevented a uniform contact between the pads of the probe and the leaf.</Species>
<Species>Non-uniform contact resulted in a reduced pressure response of the probe (data not shown).</Species>

<Species>Thus, in order to obtain maximum resolution of microclimate-induced and/or plant-based effects on the Pp values, it was crucial that the probe was placed on relatively smooth areas, i.e. preferentially between the veins rather than on the veins in order to guarantee a uniform pressure transmission.</Species>
<Species>It also turned out that areas with lesions or covered with dust should be avoided.</Species>
<Species>Probably due to the absence of dust, high resolution results were obtained when the sensor-containing pad faced the abaxial side, but not the adaxial side of the leaf.</Species>
<Species>Diurnal changes in the patch clamp pressure Figure 2A represents Pp recordings conducted on the 10 m tall liana on 24 May and 25 May, 2007.</Species>
<Species>The plant was well-watered before the beginning of the measurements (22 May) and was also watered regularly during the experimental period.</Species>

<Species>The sufficient supply of the leaves with water was indicated by high turgor pressure values of c. 500 kPa at predawn and guttation up to a height of 6 m around sunrise (see also Thurmer et al., 1999).</Species>
<Species>Diurnal changes of the Pp values were recorded simultaneously at 0.2 m, 6 m, and 10 m height.</Species>

<Species>The corresponding diurnal changes in the ambient temperature, T, and relative humidity, r.h., measured close to the sites of the patch clamp pressure probes, are given in Fig. 2B and C. It was very sunny on 24 May resulting in a rapid heating-up of the greenhouse, particularly in the upper part.</Species>
<Species>This led to the development of large vertical gradients in T and r.h. along the stem of the liana (Fig. 2B, C).</Species>
<Species>Because sunlight was dimmed by operation of the automatic blinds at noon (see Materials and methods) the gradients did not reach maximum values before the afternoon.</Species>

<Species>Between 15.30 h and 16.30 h an ambient temperature of 44 oC and a relative humidity of 20% were recorded at the top of the liana, whereas at 0.2 m height T and r.h. were 27 oC and 70%, respectively.</Species>

<Species>The gradients in T and r.h. disappeared at c. 22.00 h. Due to the dense foliage of the plant above c. 7 m and due to light dimming by the blinds, leaves closer to the ground only became exposed to direct sunshine towards the early afternoon.</Species>
<Species>In contrast to 24 May, the following day was cloudy until noon.</Species>

<Species>Thus, leaves in the upper part of the liana became fully exposed to bright sunshine first around 14.00 h as indicated by the rapid increase in T and the corresponding decrease of r.h. above a height of 6 m (Fig. 2B, C).</Species>

<Species>Despite the strongly delayed exposure of the leaves to sunshine, comparable maximum values for T and r.h. at the three measuring sites, as well as vertical gradients in T and r.h. of comparable size, were measured between 15.30 h and 16.30 h as on the day before.</Species>
<Species>Inspection of Fig. 2 shows that the diurnal changes of T and r.h. at the three measuring sites are reflected in corresponding changes of Pp.</Species>
<Species>During the nights the Pp values were low.</Species>
<Species>After sunrise at 04.24 h the Pp values remained low for further 4-5 h, except at 6 m height where a slight and continuous increase in the Pp values was very often recorded.</Species>
<Species>After about 09.00 h the Pp values increased over the entire height of the liana.</Species>
<Species>Peaking of the Pp values occurred between 15.30 h and 16.30 h at all heights when the T and r.h. gradients reached maximum values.</Species>

<Species>Towards the evening the Pp values decreased again in order to reach the original low values at c. 22.00 h. Until peaking in the afternoon, more or less pronounced fluctuations of the Pp values were seen.</Species>

<Species>A part of these fluctuations seemed to be correlated with changes in the local ambient temperature, relative humidity and/or with a temporary exposure of the clamped leaflet to sunshine (compare Fig. 2A with Fig. 2B, C).</Species>
<Species>However, there was also a considerable number of fluctuations which could not be traced back to changes in the microclimate.</Species>
<Species>An example can be found in Fig.</Species>
<Species>2A (arrow).</Species>

<Species>The peaking of the Pp value measured at a height of 0.2 m around 14.00 h is obviously not induced by changes in the local temperature and relative humidity or by exposure to sunshine.</Species>
<Species>Similar diurnal changes in Pp, T, and r.h. were also found for the 4.5 m tall liana in the backstage of the greenhouse (data not shown).</Species>
<Species>Figure 3 shows long-term Pp, T, and r.h. measurements performed at 0.2 m, 6 m, and 10 m height in late summer 2007.</Species>
<Species>In contrast to the experimental conditions in late spring (Fig. 2) the liana had been watered only sporadically during the weeks before the measurements.</Species>
<Species>The soil was extremely dry and no guttation was observed at predawn, even at 0.2 m height.</Species>
<Species>Turgor pressure measurements performed at 0.2 m height yielded values below 250 kPa at predawn.</Species>
<Species>Continuous irrigation was started at 10.00 h on 28 August (c. 400 l d   1).</Species>
<Species>Guttation occurred at 0.2 m height, but not at 6 m height on 1 September.</Species>
<Species>At sunrise (05.25 h), turgor pressures of c. 500 kPa were recorded at the base of the liana.</Species>
<Species>Guttation at 6 m height was still not observed on 3 September indicating that the hydration state of the plant was still less than in the last week of May.</Species>
<Species>The T and r.h. profiles during the end of summer were also different to those in late spring (compare Fig. 2B, C with Fig</Species>
<Species>. 3B, C).</Species>
<Species>On 28 August when irrigation started it was sunny.</Species>
<Species>Similarly to May, peak values of T and r.h. were reached at c. 15.30 h.</Species>
<Species>However, temperatures at the top of the plant did not exceed 35 oC and r.h. did not drop below 40%.</Species>
<Species>Accordingly, the vertical T and r.h. gradients were smaller than those measured at the end of May.</Species>
<Species>On 29 August, when it became very rainy and light irradiance dropped dramatically, gradients in T and r.h. of slightly decreased size were still recorded.</Species>
<Species>Peaking of T and r.h. occurred at c. 14.30 h. T and r.h. gradients did not develop in the following three days which were very cloudy and rainy.</Species>

<Species>An almost constant temperature of c. 25 oC and a relative humidity of 80% were measured on the ground and at the top of the greenhouse throughout the day; light irradiance did not exceed 40 umol photons m   2 s   1.</Species>
<Species>Only on 31 August, did the rain stop and the upper part of the liana was exposed to sunshine for 1-2 h and thus small T and r.h. gradients developed.</Species>
<Species>The following days of 2 and 3 September were partly cloudy and sunny and the peaking of T and r.h. occurred at c. 13.00 h.</Species>
<Species>The upper, but not the lower part of the liana was exposed to sunshine for several hours.</Species>
<Species>This resulted in the formation of T and r.h. gradients.</Species>
<Species>The size of the gradients was similar to that measured on 29 August.</Species>
<Species>Inspection of Fig. 3A indicates that peaking of the Pp values coincided with peaking of r.h. and T in Fig.</Species>

<Species>3B and C. Figure 3A shows further that the peak amplitude of the Pp values recorded at the three measuring sites decreased continuously from 28 August whereas the low Pp values at the nights remained unaltered.</Species>
<Species>The peak amplitude measured on 29 August was only slightly lower than that measured on the day before, the peak amplitude was rather low on 30 August.</Species>

<Species>It remained at this low level until 2 September, except that on 31 August the peak amplitude at the three measuring sites increased slightly, presumably because of the short-time exposure of the upper leaves to sun (see above).</Species>
<Species>Comparison of the diurnal changes in the Pp values with the corresponding T and r.h. changes in Fig.</Species>
<Species>3B and C indicates that part of the changes in the peak amplitude of the Pp values were induced by changes in the environmental parameters.</Species>
<Species>However, part of the changes must obviously be attributed to irrigation.</Species>
<Species>This conclusion can be drawn if, for example, the peaking of Pp on 2 and 3 September is compared with the peaking of Pp on 29 August.</Species>
<Species>Despite the comparable size of the T and r.h. gradients, the peak Pp values were much smaller, particularly at 0.2 m height, on 2 and 3 September compared with 29 August.</Species>

<Species>Plots of the Pp values measured at 6 m and 10 m height on 24 May, 28 August, and 2 September against r.h. (or against T since both parameters were usually closely related) also support the view that the local microclimate is not the only factor which determined the magnitude of the Pp values at the three measuring sites.</Species>

<Species>Figure 4 shows that the Pp values recorded at 6 m and 10 m height increased with decreasing r.h. from c. 09.00 h until r.h. reached the minimum value (and T the maximum value, respectively), when with the progression of the day r.h. increased and T decreased, Pp decreased again.</Species>
<Species>This decrease was much faster than expected in the light of the preceding r.h.-induced increase of Pp if the plant was well-watered (24 May; Fig. 4A, B).</Species>
<Species>Refilling of the leaf cells was apparently enhanced by the high hydration state of the plant.</Species>
<Species>By contrast, when the liana had not been irrigated well (28 August, Fig. 4C, D) both kinetics of the changes of Pp with r.h. were comparable.</Species>
<Species>The low hydration state of the plant apparently delayed cell refilling.</Species>
<Species>After 4 d irrigation (2 September), the low value of Pp recovered at relatively low r.h.</Species>
<Species>as in May at 10 m height (Fig. 4F), but not at 6 m height (Fig. 4E).</Species>
<Species>Recovery of the low Pp values at this height occurred, however, at significantly lower r.h.</Species>
<Species>than on 28 August, indicating that rehydration of the leaves at this height had not been completed.</Species>
<Species>Evaluation of other data sets yielded similar results (not shown).</Species>
<Species>Patch clamp pressure versus cell turgor pressure measurements The leaf patch clamp pressure probe measures the pressure transfer function of a defined leaflet area.</Species>

<Species>The above theoretical considerations have shown that the transfer function is mainly determined by turgor pressure provided that the structural elements do not contribute or constantly contribute to the pressure signal transfer.</Species>
<Species>In order to prove the theory parallel measurements of leaf patch clamp pressure (Pp) and cell turgor pressure (Pc) were performed on a leaflet at 0.2 m height (Fig. 5A).</Species>
<Species>Simultaneously, the Pp values were recorded at 6 m and 10 m height (Fig. 5B, C).</Species>
<Species>Measurements were performed after several days of irrigation.</Species>

<Species>In these experiments, the microcapillary of the turgor pressure probe was inserted into parenchymal cells located close to the main vein on the abaxial side of a leaflet, i.e. c. 10 cm away from the leaf patch clamp pressure probe near the leaflet periphery.</Species>
<Species>Turgor pressure measurements on leaf cells of T. voinierianum were difficult to perform because of the presence of mucilage.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Mucilage resulted in clogging of the tip of the microcapillary of the cell turgor pressure probe.</Species>
<Species>For this reason, measurements with the Scholander pressure chamber were not very reliable.</Species>
<Species>It was extremely difficult to determine exactly the balancing pressure at which water appears at the cut end of the petiole of the leaf.</Species>
<Species>In Fig.</Species>
<Species>5A</Species>
<Species>the average turgor pressure values are plotted which were calculated from 3-8 min long measurements.</Species>
<Species>Inspection of Fig. 5A-C shows that Pc exhibited similar diurnal changes as the Pp values at 0.2 m, 6 m, and 10 m height.</Species>
<Species>Changes in Pc after sunrise preceded changes in Pp, most likely due to the different measuring sites on the leaflets.</Species>

<Species>After the onset of transpiration the loss of turgor pressure of cells located at the periphery of the leaflets (where Pp is recorded) is apparently immediately compensated by water shifting from the xylem and the cells located close to the main vein (where Pc is measured).</Species>

<Species>Consistent with this explanation, towards the afternoon when all cells throughout the leaflets exhibit low turgor pressure, the increase in Pc and the decrease in Pp occurred nearly concomitantly.</Species>

<Species>Interestingly, the delay between the response of Pc and Pp upon changes in T and r.h. in the early morning hours decreased from about 2.5 h at 0.2 m height to 1.5 h at 6 m height, and to 1 h at 10 m height.</Species>
<Species>In Fig. 5D the Pp values measured at the three heights are plotted against the corresponding Pc values (i.e. neglecting the delayed response of Pp).</Species>
<Species>The curves could be fitted quite well by equation 8.</Species>

<Species>Fitting of the curves required the assumption of different values for the constants a and b in equation 4 (see legend to Fig. 5) indicating that the elastic properties of the leaves were different, presumably due to changes of the ambient temperature with height (see above).</Species>
<Species>Turgor pressure measurements at 5 m height failed because of abundant mucilage in the leaflet tissue at this time of the year.</Species>
<Species>Mucilage in the cells and xylem vessels was less abundant when turgor pressure measurements were performed during the summer of 1999.</Species>

<Species>Plot of the Pc data measured by Thurmer et al. (1999) at 5 m height against online recordings of Pp in May 2007 revealed very good agreement between both parameters, even though the microcapillary was inserted into cells located on the upper leaflet surface between the main vein and the leaflet edge (Fig. 6).</Species>
<Species>On both measuring days in 1999 and 2007, similar environmental conditions existed.</Species>

<Species>Inspection of Fig. 6 shows that Pp measured at 6 m height was delayed by c. 1.5 h. A plot of the Pp values against the Pc values according to Fig. 5D could also be fitted very well by equation 8 (see inset of Fig. 6) indicating the validity of equation 8 to describe properly the relationship between Pp and Pc.</Species>
<Species>Discussion</Species>

<Species>The results presented here demonstrate that the novel patch clamp pressure probe is a very sensitive, versatile, and easy-to-handle plant-based tool for online monitoring of the effects of evapotranspiration and/or of irrigation regimes on the water relations of leaves (Figs 2, 3).</Species>
<Species>The probe measures the output signal upon application of a constantly clamped pressure, i.e. the pressure transfer function of leaf patches.</Species>

<Species>Since the application of the probe is not restricted to special leaves, patch clamp pressure measurements will readily show which crop varieties can be grown with the least water for the most yield.</Species>

<Species>It has also been demonstated here that the plant-based data can be sent by small telemetric units connected to the patch clamp pressure probes to a receiver base station which logs and stores the data pending transfer to a GPRS modem linked to an Internet server.</Species>
<Species>The telemetric systems operated faultlessly.</Species>

<Species>This is a very important result because there is agreement between scientists and growers (Jones, 2004) that control of irrigation must be tied to remote sensing devices in order to reduce manpower and to conserve water.</Species>
<Species>The patch clamp pressure probe technique introduced here meets these demands.</Species>
<Species>A further advantage is that the probe is cheap and easy to handle.</Species>
<Species>Some care is required only when clamping the leaf.</Species>
<Species>Leaves must be clean and any rough surface topography must be avoided.</Species>

<Species>This implies that the dimensions of the pads of the spring clamp must be adjusted to the size of the intercostal area since non-uniform contact between leaf surface and pads lowered the output pressure signal.</Species>

<Species>Experience collected with patch clamp pressure measurements on T. voinierianum and on preliminary results of other plants (e.g. grapevines, bananas, Eucalyptus, and Arabidopsis) showed that a smooth intercostal leaf area for clamping can readily be found.</Species>

Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Equally, optimum values for the clamp pressure can also be relatively quickly selected empirically if the guidelines mentioned above are followed.</Species>
<Species>For many purposes calibration of the leaf patch clamp pressure probe against the cell turgor pressure probe is not stringent.</Species>
<Species>It may be sufficient to know that the transfer function assumes small values at full turgescence and is nearly unity at low turgescence.</Species>
<Species>However, for scientific reasons and for the application of the probe in basic research, the dependency of the transfer function on cell turgor pressure might be of great interest.</Species>

<Species>The theoretical considerations have demonstrated that the relationship between the transfer function and the turgor pressure can obviously be described by equation 8, i.e. by a power function.</Species>
<Species>Concomitant measurements of turgor pressure and patch clamp pressure have confirmed the theoretical considerations (Fig. 5).</Species>

<Species>Analogous recordings of turgor pressure and patch clamp pressure on grapevines, bananas, and Eucalyptus trees also yielded results (D Zimmermann, unpublished results) which were consistent with the predictions of equation 8.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Patch clamp pressure measurements allow, therefore, calculation of turgor pressures if the constants a and b defined by equation 4 are known.</Species>
<Species>These parameters can be obtained by numerical fitting of Pp versus Pc curves.</Species>
<Species>Online patch clamp pressure measurements open up new possibilities to unravel the hydraulic communication among leaves, including tall trees.</Species>

<Species>It is shown here that the patch clamp pressure can simultaneously be monitored in shaded or sun-exposed leaflets at different heights under greenhouse conditions by using several probes.</Species>
<Species>It was even possible to measure the turgor pressure at different sites on the leaf.</Species>
<Species>Therefore, water shifting between leaf cells via the apoplastic and symplastic pathways can be studied.</Species>

<Species>Physically sound theories are available (Molz and Ikenberry, 1974; Molz et al., 1979), but experimental facts are not available or are mainly based on speculations (Steudle and French, 1996).</Species>
<Species>The first evidence for the dynamics of the hydraulic communication between leaflets at different height and within leaflets is given here.</Species>

<Species>Thurmer et al. (1999) have shown by using the xylem and turgor pressure probe that the decrease in local xylem pressure after daybreak from positive, sub-atmospheric or slightly above-atmospheric values to negative values was associated with an almost 1:1 decrease in turgor pressure of the cells located close to the main vein of the leaflets (see also Zimmermann et al., 2004).</Species>
<Species>Similarly, in the afternoon, the increase of xylem pressure in non-cavitated vessels towards more positive values correlated with a 1:1 increase in cell turgor pressure.</Species>
<Species>Obviously, changes in transpiration resulted in a very rapid establishment of a new local water equilibrium state between the xylem and the turgor pressure of the adjacent cells.</Species>
<Species>The turgor pressure measurements of Thurmer et al. (1999) were performed at 1 m and 5 m height.</Species>
<Species>No significant differences in the turgor pressure values were found over the day.</Species>

<Species>The turgor pressure measurements at 0.2 m height reported here confirmed the finding of Thurmer et al. (1999) that the turgor pressure in the cells located near the main vein dropped immediately upon daybreak.</Species>

<Species>However, our patch clamp pressure measurements at the periphery of the leaflets imply that the turgor pressure of these cells apparently had a significantly delayed response upon the onset of transpiration.</Species>
<Species>This finding can be taken as evidence that turgor pressure gradients are temporarily generated within the leaf during the early morning hours.</Species>
<Species>This delay in the response of patch clamp pressure after daybreak was c. 1 h for leaves at the top, but c. 2.5 h for leaves at the base.</Species>
<Species>The data suggest that with progression of the day the gradients collapsed first at the top of the liana, where transpiration was high, before it occurred in leaves further down.</Species>
<Species>During the afternoon hours the increase in the turgor pressure values measured close to the main vein coincided with the values measured by the patch clamp pressure probe (Fig. 5).</Species>
<Species>The unbalanced osmotic pressure throughout the leaflets obviously favoured simultaneous turgor pressure regeneration in all leaflet cells.</Species>
<Species>The process seemed to be very similar to the refilling of the cells of the resurrection plant Myrothamnus flabellifolia with water after desiccation (Wagner et al., 2000).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Uniform radial refilling of cells with water in this species is also driven by the unbalanced osmotic pressure throughout the tissue.</Species>
<Species>As indicated by Fig. 4A and B, restoration of full turgescence in T. voinierianum was faster than the preceding turgor pressure loss if the lianas were well-watered.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>By contrast, limitations in water supply resulted in the coincidence of the phases of turgor pressure loss and regeneration.</Species>

<Species>Interestingly, watering of the lianas after non-irrigation seemed to lead preferentially to water shifting to the top of the plant, because, after 3 d of irrigation, turgor pressure regeneration during the afternoon was very fast again at 10 m height (Fig. 4F), but not at 5 m height (Fig. 4E).</Species>

<Species>Rapid water movement to the top is expected if hydrostatic pressure, osmotic pressure, and/or gel-based gradients throughout the vessels exist or are generated rapidly in the afternoon when cavitation has occurred.</Species>
<Species>This was demonstrated by Benkert et al. (1995) and Thurmer et al.</Species>
<Species>(1999)</Species>
<Species>by using the xylem pressure probe.</Species>

<Species>Continuous xylem pressure gradients during the morning hours can also explain why changes in Pp at lower heights were frequently found which could not be correlated with changes in local temperature or relative humidity.</Species>

<Species>Water loss at the top of the plant induces a drop in xylem pressure which is transferred rapidly to the basal leaves where it induces a temporary turgor pressure loss that is soon compensated by water uptake from the roots (arrow in Fig. 2).</Species>

<Species>Even though more work is required, the present study shows that the leaf patch clamp pressure probe is a promising tool to elucidate short- and long-distance water transport in T. voinierianum and other plants.</Species>

text: <Species>SuperCAT: a supertree database for combined and integrative multilocus sequence typing analysis of the Bacillus cereus group of bacteria (including B. cereus, B. anthracis and B. thuringiensis)</Species>
