text: <Species>Abstract The Bacillus cereus group of bacteria is an important group including mammalian and insect pathogens, such as B. anthracis, the anthrax bacterium, B. thuringiensis, used as a biological pesticide and B. cereus, often involved in food poisoning incidents.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>To characterize the population structure and epidemiology of these bacteria, five separate multilocus sequence typing (MLST) schemes have been developed, which makes results difficult to compare.</Species>

<Species>Therefore, we have developed a database that compiles and integrates MLST data from all five schemes for the B. cereus group, accessible at http://mlstoslo.uio.no/. Supertree techniques were used to combine the phylogenetic information from analysis of all schemes and datasets, in order to produce an integrated view of the B. cereus group population.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The database currently contains strain information and sequence data for 1029 isolates and 26 housekeeping gene fragments, which can be searched by keywords, MLST scheme, or sequence similarity.</Species>
<Species>Supertrees can be browsed according to various criteria such as species, isolate source, or genetic distance, and subtrees containing strains of interest can be extracted.</Species>

<Species>Besides analysis of the available data, the user has the possibility to enter her/his own sequences and compare them to the database and/or include them into the supertree reconstructions.</Species>
<Species>INTRODUCTION Multilocus sequence typing (MLST) is a tool that is widely used for phylogenetic typing of bacteria.</Species>

<Species>MLST is based on polymerase chain reaction (PCR) amplification and sequencing of internal fragments of usually seven essential or housekeeping genes spread around the bacterial chromosome.</Species>
<Species>The genetic relatedness among isolates is then determined by comparison of the nucleotide sequence types (1,2).</Species>
<Species>MLST is thus a method that is unambiguous and truly portable among laboratories.</Species>

<Species>Since the initial development of this technique for Neisseria meningitidis in 1998, MLST schemes have been developed for about 30 species including some of the most important bacterial pathogens, e.g. Streptococcus pneumoniae, Streptococcus pyogenes, Haemophilus influenzae, Staphylococcus aureus, Campylobacter jejuni, Enterococcus faecium, Burkholderia pseudomallei, Escherichia coli, Salmonella enterica and the Bacillus cereus group (see (1) for a recent review).</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species
Species
Species
Species
Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>These MLST schemes have been used successfully to explore the population structure of bacteria, to study the evolution of their virulence properties, to identify antibiotic-resistant strains and epidemic clones, and for epidemiological surveillance.</Species>

<Species>The B. cereus group includes bacterial species that are of medical and/or economic importance, such as B. anthracis, an obligate mammalian pathogen causing the lethal disease anthrax, B. cereus, an opportunistic human pathogen involved in food-poisoning incidents and contaminations in hospitals, B. thuringiensis, an insect pathogen and one of the world's most widely used biopesticide and B. weihenstephanensis, a cold-tolerant species known for contaminating dairies.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>These species are genetically very closely related and may be considered as one species based on genetic and genomic evidence (3-5).</Species>

<Species>Unlike other bacterial species that are typed using a single MLST scheme, five separate schemes have been developed for the B. cereus group, based on different sets of genes and isolates (5-10).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The Priest scheme (8) is currently the most widely used.</Species>

<Species>Studies with the various schemes have independently indicated that the B. cereus group population is divided into three main phylogenetic clusters and that species are usually intermixed within the groups.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>One cluster contains the monomorphic B. anthracis isolates and a number of B. cereus and B. thuringiensis strains, many of which are from clinical sources.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>A second heterogeneous cluster includes B. cereus and B. thuringiensis isolates from various origins, while cold-tolerant B. weihenstephanensis and B. cereus isolates belong to the third group.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>The separate MLST analyses have also revealed that the B. cereus group population is weakly clonal overall due to numerous clinical and virulent isolates emerging from different phylogenetic positions (5-8,11-14), with the exception of the    cold-tolerant    cluster that seems to exhibit a panmictic (or sexual) population structure, i.e. with frequent genetic exchanges between strains (9).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Despite the overall congruence between the various MLST studies, the use of separate schemes with no gene overlap and very little strain overlap has produced a confusing situation and makes the results difficult to compare directly.</Species>

<Species>Therefore, we recently proposed a combined scheme based on genes taken from three of the four schemes available by then and for which we created a web-based database accessible at the University of Oslo's MLST server, http://mlstoslo.uio.no/ (5).</Species>

<Species>Here, in order to provide the B. cereus group research community with a common MLST resource, we have developed on the same website a database, SuperCAT, that compiles and integrates MLST data from all the published B. cereus group schemes.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>In addition, we applied supertree reconstruction methods to build an integrated view of the B. cereus group population and phylogeny.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Below we describe the content and main features of the new database as well as the process of supertree building.</Species>
<Species>DATABASE CONTENT</Species>

<Species>AND IMPLEMENTATION The SuperCAT database provides information, sequence and phylogenetic data for all bacterial isolates that have been typed using any of the five published MLST schemes for the B. cereus group (Table 1).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Strain information, when known, includes isolate description, source and geographical location of isolation, and the scheme(s) used for typing.</Species>
<Species>The sequence data include the nucleotide sequences of the MLST loci examined in a given strain.</Species>

<Species>SuperCAT also contains the phylogenetic supertree of the B. cereus group reconstructed by combining the sequence data from all five schemes, as well as supertrees built for individual schemes.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Information and sequences for isolates typed by the Priest and Tourasse-Helgason schemes were retrieved from the databases devoted to these schemes at http://pubmlst.org/bcereus and http://mlstoslo.uio.no/, respectively.</Species>

<Species>MLST data for additional strains not available in the pubmlst.org repository (strains from (15) are missing therein) and for the Helgason, Ko, and Candelon-Sorokin schemes were taken from the published literature and the Genbank nucleotide sequence database (Table 1).</Species>
<Species>In addition, sequences of all MLST loci were extracted from the complete genomes of the 21 sequenced B. cereus group strains available in Genbank.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Altogether, SuperCAT currently contains data for 1029 isolates and 26 gene fragments from 25 different genes.</Species>
<Species>However, since most strains have been typed using only 6 or 7 of the 26 loci, about one-third of the complete set of sequences are included.</Species>
<Species>The 26 loci, only available for the completely sequenced strains, sum up to 10 619 bp.</Species>

<Species>All these genes are located on the chromosome, thus the database provides no information about extrachromosomal plasmids even though most of the strains do carry one or several small and/or large plasmids.</Species>
<Species>Unlike scheme-specific MLST databases, SuperCAT does not contain allele and sequence type (ST) numbers.</Species>

<Species>Since isolates in SuperCAT have been typed by different subsets of loci, complete allelic profiles are unavailable and therefore STs cannot be assigned for most strains, except the fully sequenced ones.</Species>

<Species>Table 1.The five MLST schemes designed for typing bacteria of the B. cereus groupSchemeGenesTotal sequence length (bp)Total number of isolateseUsed in (references)Helgasonadk, ccpA, ftsA, glpT, pyre, recF and sucC2 938120(6,12,46)Candelon-Sorokina,cclpC, dinB, gdpD, panC, purF and yhfL2 850149(9,10)Kob,cgyrB, mbl, mdh, mutS, pycA(1) and rpoB2 00265(7)Priesta,bglpF, gmk, ilvD, pta, purH, pycA(2) and tpi2 829721(8,11,13-15,46-48)Tourasse-Helgasona,b,dadk, ccpA, glpF, glpT, panC, pta and pycA(2)2 658172(5)aSpecific databases for the Priest and Tourasse-Helgason schemes are accessible at http://pubmlst.org/bcereus/ and http://mlstoslo.uio.no/, respectively.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>A BLAST database for the Candelon-Sorokin scheme is available at http://spock.jouy.inra.fr/cgi-bin/bacilliMLSopen.cgi.bWhile the Tourasse-Helgason and Priest schemes use the same gene fragment for the pycA gene, the Ko scheme is based on a different and non-overlapping gene region.cThe B. cereus group-specific transcriptional regulator plcR was originally included in the Candelon-Sorokin and Ko schemes.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>However, plcR follows a phylogeny different from the other MLST loci (7,10) and is no longer used for MLST; therefore, it is not included in SuperCAT.dThe Tourasse-Helgason scheme is a combined scheme based on 3 genes from the Helgason scheme (adk, ccpA, and glpT), 3 genes from the Priest scheme (glpF, pta and pycA(2)), and the panC gene from the Candelon-Sorokin scheme.eIncluding strains with fully sequenced genomes.</Species>
<Species>SuperCAT is built as a relational database using the PostgreSQL management system, and data are accessible through a graphical web interface.</Species>

<Species>User queries and results pages are processed and created on-the-fly via a highly modified version of the mlstdbNet software (16) written in PERL and based on the DataBase Interface (DBI) and Common Gateway Interface (CGI) modules.</Species>
<Species>The database is implemented on a Linux Apache web server maintained through the facilities and support provided by the Norwegian EMBnet node.</Species>
<Species>Some large supertree computations are run on a Linux supercomputer at the University of Oslo.</Species>
<Species>The ATV (A Tree Viewer)</Species>
<Species>Java applet is used for phylogenetic tree display (17).</Species>
<Species>ATV notably supports horizontal and vertical zooming capabilities that are suitable for browsing large trees.</Species>
<Species>The Jalview editor Java applet is also implemented in SuperCAT for advanced multiple sequence alignment display (18).</Species>

<Species>SUPERTREE RECONSTRUCTION Supertree techniques allow to combine the phylogenetic information from different datasets into a common phylogenetic tree and several studies have shown that meaningful supertrees can be obtained even when taxon overlap is very sparse (see (19,20) for reviews).</Species>

<Species>Supertree analysis has thus become increasingly popular for taking advantage and combining the massive amount of sequence data available in public databases for reconstructing large-scale organismal phylogenies with the ultimate goal of building the tree of life (21-24).</Species>

<Species>In this study, the 21 B. cereus group strains that have been completely sequenced, and for which the sequences at all 26 MLST loci are thus available, can be used to join all five schemes and provide the strain overlap necessary for supertree analysis.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The global B. cereus group supertree, containing 1029 isolates, was reconstructed according to the widely used matrix representation by parsimony (MRP) procedure (Figure 1; (19,25,26)).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Scheme-specific supertrees were also reconstructed for each of the five MLST schemes by the same technique.</Species>
<Species>Briefly, a phylogenetic tree is built for every gene separately by the maximum likelihood method with the PHYML_aLRT program (27).</Species>

<Species>Then, each gene tree is recoded into a binary matrix representing the branching order (i.e. the phylogenetic groupings) following standard MRP coding using the SuperMRP.pl script (28).</Species>
<Species>All gene tree matrices are concatenated into a supermatrix, in which isolates missing from a particular tree are coded using the    ?    </Species>
<Species>character representing unknown data.</Species>
<Species>In this supermatrix, the sequence of 0's, 1's and ?'s defines the branching profile of a strain.</Species>
<Species>Closely related strains have similar branching profiles.</Species>
<Species>Supertrees are then generated from the supermatrix by the maximum parsimony technique using the program MIX from the PHYLIP package (29) run with default parameters.</Species>

<Species>The maximum parsimony step infers the trees that would require the minimum number of changes between the branching profiles of all isolates, where the unknown characters can take any of the two possible states 0 or 1 (they are not treated as missing gaps).</Species>
<Species>As many trees were equally parsimonious, the final supertree was taken as the strict consensus of all parsimony trees with the CONSENSE program of PHYLIP.</Species>

<Species>In order to obtain branch lengths that are proportional to the amount of nucleotide changes, we added an additional step in which branch lengths and statistical support for groupings are estimated from the concatenated sequences by the maximum likelihood method employing approximate likelihood-ratio tests (aLRTs) for branches using PHYML_aLRT with Shimodaira-Hasegawa-like support values (27,30).</Species>
<Species>aLRTs provide a fast way of testing branch support without requirement of multiple replicates like traditional bootstrap procedures.</Species>

<Species>The Felsenstein-1984 nucleotide substitution model supplemented with a gamma distribution (F84+  ) was used in maximum likelihood computations for individual gene trees and the supertree (31).</Species>
<Species>This model allows for unequal base frequencies, transition/transversion rate bias, and gamma-distributed substitution rate variation among sites.</Species>

<Species>It was empirically chosen as a consensus from exploratory model testing using ModelTest (32,33), which indicated that models including these three factors were most appropriate for the MLST loci studied, although models for individual loci differed slightly.</Species>
<Species>Note that the maximum likelihood technique also allows for uneven rates of nucleotide substitution between strains, which allows to accommodate slow- and fast-evolving isolates.</Species>

<Species>To reduce the size of the binary supermatrix and speed up computations, individual gene trees and the supertree were built using only one representative from a set of strains having identical sequences.</Species>
<Species>The remaining identical isolates were graphically added to the tree afterwards when drawing the final supertree.</Species>
<Species>Figure 1.Schematic overview of the B. cereus group supertree reconstruction procedure using Matrix Representation by Parsimony (MRP).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>See text for details.</Species>

<Species>It should be noted that the global 1029-strain supertree retains the phylogenetic signals from the individual schemes and contains the three main clusters of the B. cereus group population described in the section    Introduction   .</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The integrated SuperCAT system may also allow to infer new relationships between strains that were analyzed with different gene sets.</Species>
<Species>Even though the 26 loci sequences are available for only 21 isolates, they apparently provide enough overlap information for building the main branches of the supertree.</Species>

<Species>These 21 isolates cover all three clusters, although the majority of them are B. anthracis strains or clinical strains closely related to B. anthracis due to the focus of genome sequencing projects, making the part of the supertree containing these isolates likely to be more accurate than the rest of the tree.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Furthermore, 111 other isolates have been typed by 10 genes or more, providing additional overlap (see the    Gene Distribution    page).</Species>

<Species>Although about two-thirds of the sequence data are missing overall, it has been shown for other organisms that relevant supertrees could be reconstructed with datasets containing more than 90% of missing data, especially when the characters that are present are informative (20,22,23,34).</Species>

<Species>Empirical and simulation studies have indicated that this behavior may be due to the fact that the characters which are present are more important for the tree-building process than those which are absent (see (20,34) and references therein).</Species>
<Species>Precise within-cluster groupings may contain more uncertainty, as indicated by the large number of unresolved multifurcations in the B. cereus group supertree.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Finally, it is also worth mentioning that the branching orders of the scheme-specific MRP supertrees are highly correlated to those of the published trees built with concatenated sequences and other phylogenetic algorithms.</Species>
<Species>DATA ACCESS AND MANIPULATION</Species>
<Species>The complete list of isolates included in SuperCAT (currently 1029) with strain description, source and country of origin is available at the database home page.</Species>

<Species>By default all isolates in the database are used in the analysis tools provided, but the user can select strains of interest by keywords, MLST scheme, entering a list of strain identifiers, or choosing isolates individually via checkboxes.</Species>
<Species>All subsequent analyses will be based on the selected strain subset and their loci.</Species>
<Species>The keyword search will look for matches in any of the strain, description, source, location and scheme fields.</Species>
<Species>Complex keyword queries with several logical operators can be formulated in the    advanced search    page.</Species>

<Species>Note that many isolates were referred by alternative names in different MLST schemes and publications, therefore synonyms have been included in the strain descriptions that allow a particular isolate to be looked up using any of its alternative identifiers.</Species>
<Species>A sequence search is also possible using BLASTN (35), in order to select isolates that have allele sequences identical to user-entered query sequences.</Species>

<Species>Throughout SuperCAT, clicking on a strain name will pop up an isolate-specific window showing all relevant information and giving access to the nucleotide sequences of individual loci for that isolate.</Species>

<Species>Detailed information about the MLST schemes (e.g. loci names and lengths, genomic coordinates, literature references) and their overlap, the distribution of available loci among the isolates, and the supertree reconstruction procedure can be obtained by clicking the relevant links in the header line present at the top of every page.</Species>

<Species>Apart from the basic functions for selecting and accessing strain information and sequence data for all five B. cereus group MLST schemes, the main features of SuperCAT relate to the manipulation of the supertrees constructed by the MRP approach.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The global supertree based on the combination of all five B. cereus group MLST schemes as well as the five scheme-specific supertrees can be browsed according to various user-chosen criteria (Figure 2).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Isolates in the supertrees can be colored by species or source of isolation.</Species>

<Species>It is also possible to specifically mark in red the current subset of strains that has been selected by the user and to extract from the supertrees the subtree containing only those isolates.</Species>
<Species>In the case of the multi-scheme supertree highlighting of the strains can be based on genetic distance.</Species>
<Species>With this option the user can mark on and/or extract from the tree the isolates that are genetically closely related to strains of her/his choice.</Species>
<Species>The user can either select strains that share one or several identical allele sequences with her/his query isolate(s) or that are at a specified genetic distance.</Species>

<Species>Distances between isolates are computed by summing up the lengths of the branches (in average number of nucleotide substitutions per site) connecting the isolates in the supertree (known as patristic distances; (36)).</Species>
<Species>The genetic relatedness search functions are also available in a separate page for the user to find closely related isolates without tree manipulation.</Species>

<Species>SuperCAT allows to compare the scheme-specific MLST supertrees with each other and with the global supertree by using the subset of isolates that are common to all selected schemes.</Species>

<Species>Common isolates can either be highlighted in red or be extracted as subtrees from each supertree, which can be used for comparing the positions of the common strains in the various MLST trees.</Species>
<Species>For all supertree-related options, detailed tree navigation can be achieved using the various functions in the ATV tree window when the trees are displayed (17).</Species>
<Species>Figure 2.Examples of supertree browsing and manipulation in SuperCAT.</Species>

<Species>A, supertree colored by species; B, specific highlighting of user-selected strains (in red); C, extracted subtree containing only the strains highlighted in B. Trees are displayed using ATV (17).</Species>

<Species>Besides the manipulation of the precomputed supertrees, SuperCAT offers the user the possibility to compute new supertrees by MRP using any combination of strains, schemes and genes.</Species>
<Species>Supertree computations may be extremely time consuming, ranging from a few minutes to 2-3 days with the complete database.</Species>
<Species>Users are therefore requested to enter their e-mail addresses and will receive a notification containing a link to the results page when the supertree is ready.</Species>
<Species>Note that when building a supertree for a user-selected subset of strains, the computation will first include all database isolates.</Species>
<Species>A subtree containing only the user-selected isolates will then be extracted from the supertree of all strains.</Species>

<Species>Although more time consuming, this strategy allows: (i) to avoid sampling artefacts as phylogenies built with different isolate sets may vary and (ii) to obtain relationships even if the selected isolates have been typed using non-overlapping gene sets, as the supertree of all isolates can always be built owing to the completely sequenced strains that are common to all schemes.</Species>
<Species>Another main feature of the SuperCAT database is that the user can enter her/his own private sequences and conduct several sequence analyses (Figure 3).</Species>

<Species>These analyses include: (a) building new supertrees containing user isolates and sequences; (b) finding database isolates having sequences most similar to the user's query sequences using an on-line BLASTN (35) service; and (c) aligning user sequences to database genes using the multiple sequence alignment program CLUSTALW (37).</Species>
<Species>For the last option, the Jalview editor (18) is provided for advanced multiple alignment display.</Species>
<Species>All user-entered data must be in FASTA format and can be either copied and pasted into the query forms or uploaded from text files stored locally on the user's computer.</Species>
<Species>Figure 3.Examples of query results in SuperCAT.</Species>

<Species>A, multi-scheme BLAST search with sequence alignment; B, multi-scheme genetic search showing the list of isolates sharing one or more sequences with a query strain; C, multiple sequence alignment using Jalview (18).</Species>
<Species>All strain information data, sequences and phylogenetic trees, including user-made supertrees and extracted subtrees, can be saved and downloaded freely from the database.</Species>

<Species>Users wishing to have their MLST data included as part of the SuperCAT release (and/or the Tourasse-Helgason scheme-specific database) are welcome to contact N.J.T. or A.-B.K. at the e-mail addresses given on the Oslo MLST server front page.</Species>

<Species>DISCUSSION AND FUTURE DEVELOPMENTS SuperCAT is a newly created database devoted to the B. cereus group of bacteria whose main objectives are to provide a common MLST repository and means for building a comprehensive genetic analysis of the group that has been typed by five separate schemes.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The database is publicly and freely available at http://mlstoslo.uio.no/, along with the database specific for the combined scheme of (5).</Species>
<Species>We plan to update SuperCAT quarterly.</Species>
<Species>Future developments of the database may deal with refining the supertree-building procedure.</Species>

<Species>In particular, a new improved method has recently been developed for taking into account both nucleotide substitutions and recombination events in phylogenies, as part of the ClonalFrame software, which has been applied to the B. cereus group and the Priest scheme (38).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>It would therefore be of interest to examine the suitability of ClonalFrame in the supertree context.</Species>

<Species>It is also tempting to extend the supertree analysis beyond MLST data, by incorporating the phylogenies obtained previously from large-scale multilocus enzyme electrophoresis (MLEE; (3,39-41)) and amplified fragment length polymorphism (AFLP; (42-45)) studies.</Species>
<Species>The MRP framework is ideal since it allows to integrate trees that can be built from different methods and data.</Species>
<Species>As MLEE, AFLP and MLST have different levels of resolution, one can hope that combining them might provide an even more robust supertree for the B. cereus group.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>MUC1 alters oncogenic events and transcription in human breast cancer cells</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Abstract Introduction MUC1 is an oncoprotein whose overexpression correlates with aggressiveness of tumors and poor survival of cancer patients.</Species>
<Species>Many of the oncogenic effects of MUC1 are believed to occur through interaction of its cytoplasmic tail with signaling molecules.</Species>
<Species>As expected for a protein with oncogenic functions, MUC1 is linked to regulation of proliferation, apoptosis, invasion, and transcription.</Species>

<Species>Methods To clarify the role of MUC1 in cancer, we transfected two breast cancer cell lines (MDA-MB-468 and BT-20) with small interfering (si)RNA directed against MUC1 and analyzed transcriptional responses and oncogenic events (proliferation, apoptosis and invasion).</Species>

<Species>Results Transcription of several genes was altered after transfection of MUC1 siRNA, including decreased MAP2K1 (MEK1), JUN, PDGFA, CDC25A, VEGF and ITGAV (integrin av), and increased TNF, RAF1, and MMP2.</Species>
<Species>Additional changes were seen at the protein level, such as increased expression of c-Myc, heightened phosphorylation of AKT, and decreased activation of MEK1/2 and ERK1/2.</Species>
<Species>These were correlated with cellular events, as MUC1 siRNA in the MDA-MB-468 line decreased proliferation and invasion, and increased stress-induced apoptosis.</Species>
<Species>Intriguingly, BT-20 cells displayed similar levels of apoptosis regardless of siRNA, and actually increased proliferation after MUC1 siRNA.</Species>

<Species>Conclusion These results further the growing knowledge of the role of MUC1 in transcription, and suggest that the regulation of MUC1 in breast cancer may be more complex than previously appreciated.</Species>

<Species>The differences between these two cell lines emphasize the importance of understanding the context of cell-specific signaling events when analyzing the oncogenic functions of MUC1, and caution against generalizing the results of individual cell lines without adequate confirmation in intact biological systems.</Species>

<Species>Introduction MUC1 is the founding member of the mucin family: proteins characterized by heavy O-glycosylation centering around a variable number of tandem repeats that are rich in serine and threonine residues [1,2].</Species>

<Species>MUC1 is a transmembrane heterodimer with one subunit solely extracellular (MUC1-EX), and the other subunit composed of a short extracellular stem, a single transmembrane domain, and the cytoplasmic tail (together called the MUC1-CT).</Species>

<Species>MUC1 possesses both pro- and anti-adhesive capacities, as the MUC1-EX provides binding sites for a variety of adhesion proteins, while its large size and extended structure prevents cell-cell contact [3-5].</Species>
<Species>Initially described as a tumor antigen overexpressed in >90% of breast cancers, MUC1 is now known to be an oncogene with roles in both tumor formation and progression [1,6].</Species>
<Species>Mouse studies have been integral to the current understanding of MUC1 in cancer.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Muc1 knockout mice (Muc1-/-; MUC1 is human; Muc1 is mouse) show a reduction in tumorigenic phenotype when crossed onto mice overexpressing the Wnt-1 [7] or polyomavirus middle T antigen</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>[8] oncogenes in the mammary gland.</Species>
<Species>In contrast, MUC1 overexpression in the mammary gland drives tumor formation</Species>
<Species>[9], indicating that MUC1 is a true oncogene.</Species>

<Species>Many of the oncogenic effects of MUC1 stem from its cytoplasmic tail, which binds to several proteins implicated in cancer, including c-Src [10,11] and the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) family [12,13].</Species>
<Species>MUC1 stimulates mitogen activated protein kinase (MAPK) signaling through the extracellular signal regulated kinases (ERK1/2)</Species>
<Species>[12,14]; this can occur through MUC1 association with Grb2 and son of sevenless to activate Ras [15].</Species>

<Species>ERK1/2 signaling is commonly stimulated by the Ras-Raf-MEK (MAPK and ERK kinase) cascade downstream of mitogens such as EGFR [16], and regulates transcription via factors like the activator protein-1 complex.</Species>
<Species>Loss of MUC1 can reduce EGFR expression [17], providing another means of affecting MAPK signaling.</Species>

<Species>Our results describe a novel mechanism by which MUC1 regulates the ERK1/2 pathway, through modulating transcription of the genes encoding MEK1, Raf-1, and c-Jun. MUC1 expression correlates with increased survival in response to cytotoxic or oxidative agents</Species>
<Species>[18-21], and can activate the phosphoinositol-3 kinase-AKT pathway as part of an anti-apoptotic response [18].</Species>
<Species>MUC1 has also recently been linked to transcription, as the MUC1-CT localizes to the nucleus</Species>
<Species>[22] and affects transcription by b-catenin [22,23], FOXO3a</Species>
<Species>[21], p53 [24], and estrogen receptor a</Species>
<Species>[25].</Species>
<Species>However, there are indications that the role of MUC1 in oncogenesis is regulated by cell type and signaling context.</Species>
<Species>For example, MUC1 can stimulate Fas-mediated apoptosis [26], while Muc1 is specifically down-regulated in c-neu-induced mammary tumors [27].</Species>
<Species>This report emphasizes the complexity of MUC1 signaling in breast cancer by contrasting results from two established breast cancer cell lines.</Species>

<Species>To understand MUC1 function in cells with high endogenous expression, that is, cells likely to have evolved with active MUC1 signaling, we used small interfering RNA (siRNA) to knock down MUC1 in MDA-MB-468 and BT-20 cells.</Species>
<Species>We then analyzed transcription of 84 genes involved in cancer, as well as the effects upon cellular events linked to oncogenesis, such as apoptosis and proliferation.</Species>

<Species>Though the cell lines show some similarity in transcriptional alterations after transfection with MUC1 siRNA, their phenotypes are quite dissimilar: MDA-MB-468 increases apoptosis and reduces proliferation and invasion, while BT-20 proliferates more rapidly after loss of MUC1.</Species>

<Species>This last may reflect the striking amount of active AKT in BT-20; AKT activity is increased in both cell lines after MUC1 siRNA, which agrees with a previous study of MUC1 siRNA [21], but disagrees with results from 3Y1 fibroblasts [18].</Species>
<Species>Recent studies have emphasized the complex and context-specific regulation of even such classic oncogenes as AKT [28].</Species>

<Species>The differences between the two breast cancer cell lines in this study suggest that MUC1 oncogenic functions are also subject to cell-specific regulation, and stress the need for understanding the cellular signaling context when interpreting results.</Species>

<Species>Materials and methods Cell culture and siRNA transfection MDA-MB-468 and BT-20 cells (American Type Culture Collection) were cultured in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium (Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA, USA) plus 10% fetal calf serum,</Species>
<Species>1% Glutamax (Invitrogen) and 1% penicillin/streptomycin.</Species>
<Species>Stable cell lines (468.Neo and 468.MUC1D8) were selected with 0.5 mg/ml G418.</Species>
<Species>For epidermal growth factor (EGF) stimulation, MDA-MB-468 cells were serum-starved overnight and treated for 10 minutes at 37oC with 100 ng/ml EGF.</Species>
<Species>Transient siRNA transfection was performed with Lipofectamine2000 (Invitrogen) and 100 nM siRNA oligonucleotides.</Species>

<Species>The commercially available siRNA constructs (all from Dharmacon, Lafayette, CO, USA) were scrambled (siCONTROL non-targeting siRNA #1), or directed against firefly luciferase (siCONTROL non-targeting siRNA #2) or MUC1 (siGENOME smartpool).</Species>
<Species>The independent oligonucleotides designed in our laboratory target sequences beginning at MUC1 codons 882 and 956, and have been described previously [29].</Species>
<Species>The scrambled siRNA construct was used only in BT-20 cells as it causes a non-specific knockdown of MUC1 in the MDA-MB-468 line.</Species>

<Species>Cloning of MUC1 WT vector and stable transfection Two silent mutations (G891A and T894C) were introduced into the MUC1 cDNA (called MUC1D8) to make it resistant to the 882 siRNA that targets that region of the mRNA.</Species>
<Species>The mutant cDNA was cloned into the pLNCX.1 vector with neomycin resistance (gift of Joseph Loftus, Mayo Clinic, Arizona, USA).</Species>
<Species>Stable transfection was performed with Lipofectamine2000; cells were selected beginning 24 hours post-transfection and maintained as a polyclonal population.</Species>

<Species>Western blots and antibodies Cells were lysed in buffer (20 mM HEPES pH 8.0, 150 mM sodium chloride, 1% Triton X-100, 2 mM EDTA) with commercial protease (Complete inhibitor cocktail, Roche, Pleasanton, CA, USA) and phosphatase inhibitors (10 mM sodium fluoride, 2 mM sodium vanadate, 50 uM ammonium molybdate).</Species>

<Species>Protein concentration was determined by BCA (Pierce, Rockford, IL, USA); 50 ug of lysate were loaded on SDS-PAGE gels for each experiment, except for the pMEK1/2 blot in MDA-MB-468, where 150 ug were used.</Species>

<Species>Non-commercial antibodies used were: BC2, a mouse monoclonal to the MUC1-EX (gift of Dr McGuckin, Queensland University, Queensland, Australia), and CT2, an Armenian hamster monoclonal to the MUC1-CT developed in our lab [12].</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Antibodies to pMEK1/2, MEK1/2, ERK1/2, Myc, pAKT, AKT, b-tubulin (all Cell Signaling, Danvers, MA, USA), b-actin and dpERK1/2 (both Sigma, St. Louis, MO, USA) were used according to manufacturers' recommendations.</Species>
<Species>All antibodies except b-actin (1:2,500) and dpERK1/2 (1:10,000) were used at 1:1,000 dilution for western blots.</Species>
<Species>Flow cytometric analysis of MUC1 was done with HMPV-FITC, which recognizes the core peptide of the MUC1-EX tandem repeats (Pharmingen, San Diego, CA, USA).</Species>
<Species>Bromodeoxyuridine (BrdU) staining was performed with a fluorescently conjugated antibody to BrdU (BrdU-PE, BD Biosciences, San Diego, CA, USA) as described below.</Species>
<Species>Densitometry was performed using the public domain ImageJ program (developed at the NIH and available at [30].</Species>
<Species>Each band was measured in three places; the results were averaged and normalized to tubulin to control for loading.</Species>
<Species>Transwell invasion assays Cells were serum-starved beginning 24 hours post-siRNA transfection.</Species>

<Species>Cells were re-plated in serum-free medium 48 hours post-transfection at 50,000 cells per insert (sized for 24-well plates), with serum-containing medium in the bottom of the growth well as an attractant.</Species>
<Species>Transwell inserts (BD Biosciences) pre-coated with laminin, fibronectin, collagen IV, or control (no matrix) were used, and cells were permitted to invade for 48 hours.</Species>
<Species>At this point (96 hours post-transfection), visual inspection of the growth wells confirmed that negligible numbers of cells went through to the bottom of the plate.</Species>
<Species>Non-invaded cells were swabbed from the tops of half of the inserts ('samples', containing only invaded cells), and retained in the others ('controls', all cells).</Species>
<Species>Inserts were stained for 10 minutes with crystal violet (0.5% in 20% methanol) and washed with water.</Species>
<Species>Membranes were cut out and destained for 10 minutes in 10% acetic acid in a 96-well plate; membranes were removed and absorbance was read at 570 nm.</Species>
<Species>Percent invasion is defined as (absorbance of samples/absorbance of controls) x 100.</Species>

<Species>[3H]Thymidine incorporation assays Cells were re-plated in quadruplicate 24 hours post-siRNA transfection at 15,000 cells/well (96-well plate) with [3H]thymidine (1 uCi/well), then incubated in normal conditions for 24 hours.</Species>
<Species>At this time (48 hours post-siRNA transfection) excess radioactivity was washed off and the cells were harvested and read on a TopCount plate reader.</Species>

<Species>Statistical analysis was performed using JMP 5.1.2 software (SAS Institute, Inc., Cary, NC, USA); the student's t test was used to determine p values and significance was confirmed with Wilcoxon rank sum and Pearson chi squared analyses.</Species>
<Species>BrdU incorporation BrdU (50 uM) was given to cells 48 hours post-siRNA transfection and permitted to incorporate for 1.5 hours.</Species>
<Species>Cells were then washed with PBS, trypsinized, and washed again.</Species>

<Species>BrdU staining was performed according to an adaptation of the manufacturer's protocol: cells were re-suspended in PBS, mixed 1:1 with -20oC neat ethanol, and incubated 1 hour at -20oC to fix.</Species>
<Species>Fixed cells were then washed gently and denatured in 2 M HCl for 20 minutes at room temperature.</Species>

<Species>Following washing and 2 minute's incubation with 0.1 M Tris to neutralize the acid, cells were re-suspended in FACS buffer (0.5% fetal calf serum in PBS) and stained with Phycoerythrin (PE)-conjugated anti-BrdU according to the manufacturer's protocol for flow cytometry analysis on a FACScan instrument.</Species>

<Species>Apoptosis and trypan blue staining Apoptosis was measured using a kit (BD Biosciences) containing propidium iodide (PI) and FITC-conjugated annexin V. Cells were stained according to the manufacturer's protocol and the level of apoptosis determined by flow cytometry.</Species>
<Species>Quadrants are: early apoptosis (annexin V+/PI-, lower right) late apoptosis (annexin V+/PI+, upper right) and non-apoptotic cell death (annexin V-/PI+, upper left).</Species>
<Species>Treatments for the stress panel were: no treatment (control); DMSO as a control for celecoxib; 20 mM celecoxib, brand name Celebrex  (dissolved in DMSO)</Species>
<Species>[31]; 0.2 mM H2O2</Species>
<Species>[32]; or 1 mg/mL G418 (Pfizer, New York, NY, USA).</Species>

<Species>Real-time PCR arrays Transcriptional analysis using Cancer PathwayFinder RT2 profiler arrays (SuperArray, Frederick, MD, USA) was performed according to the manufacturer's protocol.</Species>

<Species>Briefly, total RNA was isolated using an RNeasy extraction kit (Qiagen, Valencia, CA, USA); 1 ug of RNA was reverse transcribed with the cDNA synthesis kit (SuperArray) and cDNA was subjected to real-time PCR using SYBR green to detect product.</Species>
<Species>Arrays were performed independently at least twice for each cell line; all PCR products were checked on agarose gels.</Species>
<Species>Values were obtained for the threshold cycle (Ct) for each gene and normalized using the average of four housekeeping genes on the same array (HPRT1, RPL13A, GAPD, ACTB).</Species>
<Species>Ct values for housekeeping genes and a dilution series of ACTB were monitored for consistency between arrays.</Species>
<Species>Change (DCt) between MUC1 siRNA and control siRNA was found by: DCt = Ct(MUC1 siRNA) - Ct(control siRNA) and fold change by: Fold change = 2(-DCt)</Species>
<Species>Values are given as fold change; only genes showing two-fold or greater change were considered.</Species>
<Species>Both luciferase and scrambled siRNA controls were used in BT-20; only genes showing consistent alteration with both controls were included in the results reported here.</Species>
<Species>The scrambled siRNA could be not used in MDA-MB-468 as these cells decrease MUC1 expression in response to this construct.</Species>

<Species>Results siRNA transfection decreases MUC1 expression in breast cancer cell lines Two human breast cancer cell lines, MDA-MB-468 and BT-20, were transiently transfected with a pool of four siRNA oligonucleotides directed against the MUC1 mRNA (468.siMUC1 and BT.siMUC1), or a control oligonucleotide directed against luciferase (468.siLuc and BT.siLuc).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Both cell lines express high levels of MUC1, making them promising targets for this analysis.</Species>

<Species>Western blots (Figure 1a) show successful knockdown of both the extracellular domain and cytoplasmic tail fragments of MUC1; luciferase siRNA does not substantially change the level of MUC1 compared to parental cells.</Species>
<Species>468.siMUC1 show a substantial decrease in the amount of MUC1-CT, while BT.siMUC1 show slightly less knockdown of MUC1-CT.</Species>

<Species>Both MDA-MB-468 and BT-20 display a less dramatic decrease of MUC1 extracellular domain compared to MUC1-CT (Figure 1a); this likely represents protein synthesized prior to transfection, and may reflect differences in the turnover rates of the two subunits.</Species>
<Species>Analysis of the MUC1 extracellular domain by flow cytometry confirms that both cell lines substantially decrease MUC1 expression after siRNA (Figure 1b).</Species>
<Species>By flow cytometry, 468.siMUC1 averaged 75% knockdown of MUC1 compared to 468.siLuc; and BT.siMUC1 averaged 50% knockdown relative to BT.siLuc.</Species>

<Species>These effects could be titrated with the concentration of siRNA, were seen as early as 24 hours post-transfection (data not shown) and lasted to at least 96 h post-transfection (Figure 1b).</Species>
<Species>All experiments were conducted within 48 to 96 hours after siRNA transfection.</Species>
<Species>Similar results were obtained using two independent oligonucleotides designed in our lab (data not shown), designated '882' and '956' for the initial codon recognized by each.</Species>

<Species>Transcriptional changes are seen after MUC1 siRNA Recent work indicates that MUC1 may affect transcription both directly via interaction with transcription factors and indirectly (for example, through modulating signaling).</Species>
<Species>To study the effects of MUC1 knockdown in breast cancer cell lines, real-time PCR arrays were used to analyze transcription of 84 genes implicated in cancer.</Species>
<Species>Only genes with greater than two-fold change were considered.</Species>

<Species>Three genes (MAP2K1, VEGF, PDGFA) were altered two-fold or more after MUC1 siRNA in both MDA-MB-468 and BT-20 cells (Figure 2); two genes (ITGAV, MMP2) changed only in 468.siMUC1; and five genes (TIMP3, RAF1, JUN, TNF, CDC25A) only in BT.siMUC1.</Species>
<Species>This list represents all genes affected greater than two-fold after MUC1 siRNA, rather than a select group.</Species>

<Species>Three genes whose transcription was changed by less than two-fold are shown, two of which (PDGFB and ITGB1) are listed because they relate closely to genes altered by two-fold (PDGFA and ITGAV).</Species>

<Species>The third, MYC, is included because western blots confirmed a substantial change at the protein level (Figure 3a) that may reflect both transcriptional and post-transcriptional regulation.</Species>
<Species>Interestingly, transcription of MAP2K1 was decreased in both cell lines after MUC1 siRNA.</Species>
<Species>This gene encodes MEK1, one of the primary regulators of the ERK1/2 MAPK pathway [33], a network that has been linked several times to MUC1 [12,34-36].</Species>

<Species>We examined MEK1 and MEK2 levels by western blot to confirm decreased protein in MUC1 siRNA-treated cells (Figure 3a), and found that not only were total MEK1/2 levels lower in 468.siMUC1 and BT.siMUC1 compared to controls (0.48 and 0.68 relative to siLuc, respectively), but so were the basal amounts of active (phosphorylated) MEK1/2 (pMEK1/2; 0.12 and 0.42 relative to siLuc, respectively).</Species>

<Species>Both 468.siMUC1 and BT.siMUC1 also showed reduced activation of ERK1/2 (dpERK1/2; 0.21 and 0.27 relative to siLuc, respectively), as would be expected with diminished signaling through MEK1/2; total ERK1/2 levels remain unchanged.</Species>
<Species>As both lines have high levels of EGFR and thus activate the MEK-ERK cascade intensely when stimulated with EGF [37], siRNA-transfected cells were treated with EGF.</Species>
<Species>Notably, MUC1 siRNA impairs this important oncogenic pathway in MDA-MB-468 cells, as 468.siMUC1 display less pMEK1/2 in response to EGF than do 468.siLuc (Figure 3b).</Species>
<Species>Interestingly, EGF treatment of BT-20 cells results in slightly higher pMEK1/2 levels in BT.siMUC1 compared to BT.siLuc.</Species>

<Species>Though this result seems paradoxical in light of decreased MAP2K1 transcription in BT.siMUC1, it likely results from differential functions of Raf isoforms in combination with the increased RAF1 transcription (Figure 2) and protein level (Figure 3a) in these cells.</Species>
<Species>Specifically, B-Raf is thought to be the main activator of MEK under normal conditions; Raf-1 activates MEK in response to stimulus [38].</Species>

<Species>Thus, it appears that basal pMEK1/2 levels are not greatly affected by Raf-1 overexpression in BT.siMUC1 cells, likely because MEK is regulated primarily by B-Raf under normal growth conditions.</Species>
<Species>In contrast, when the cells are stimulated (EGF), increased Raf-1 levels in BT.siMUC1 leads to heightened pMEK1/2</Species>
<Species>(Figure 3b).</Species>

<Species>MUC1 siRNA increases apoptosis in MDA-MB-468 but not BT-20 We next examined whether MUC1 knockdown and its associated transcriptional alterations would affect overall cellular events.</Species>

<Species>As several of the genes shown in Figure 2 are important in regulating proliferation and survival, and because of the recently described role of MUC1 in modulating apoptosis in response to cellular stresses [20,21,24], we first analyzed whether MUC1 siRNA would alter apoptosis in these lines.</Species>

<Species>Although there was no change in basal apoptosis in either line (Figure 4a), we observed that the cell lines responded differently when trypsinized for re-plating 24 hours after transfection (Figure 4b).</Species>

<Species>Interestingly, 468.siMUC1 cells show greater apoptosis after trypsinization than do 468.siLuc (49.8% versus 34.0%, respectively), while BT-20 cells from both siRNA treatments display similar levels of apoptosis (around 22%).</Species>

<Species>To examine whether this phenomenon is specific to trypsin treatment or part of a general stress response involving MUC1, we subjected cells to a panel of stresses and measured cell death.</Species>

<Species>In agreement with the patterns seen with trypsinization, BT.siLuc and BT.siMUC1 respond similarly to all treatments (data not shown), while 468.siMUC1 die more readily than 468.siLuc in response to trypsin, G418, hydrogen peroxide, or celecoxib, a chemotherapeutic that targets the cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2) pathway (Figure 4c); these data were confirmed with two independent siRNA constructs (data not shown).</Species>
<Species>Like the MAPK pathway, AKT signaling has been linked to MUC1 in cancer.</Species>
<Species>Although transcription of AKT was not altered in MUC1 siRNA-treated cells, the results of our apoptosis studies prompted us to investigate levels of AKT further.</Species>

<Species>As expected, the total AKT protein level is not greatly changed after MUC1 siRNA in either cell line, though the active form (pAKT) is increased in both 468.siMUC1 and BT.siMUC1 compared to controls (Figure 3a).</Species>
<Species>This result disagrees with MUC1 activation of the AKT pathway in rat 3Y1 cells</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>[18], and may reflect regulation more appropriate to breast cancer cells; this is supported by activation of AKT in response to MUC1 siRNA in other lines [21].</Species>
<Species>In addition, there is a striking difference in the relative amounts of AKT and pAKT in the two cell lines (Figure 4d).</Species>

<Species>When lysates from both lines are exposed to film for the same length of time (overexposure masks the differences between BT.siLuc and BT.siMUC1 that are apparent in Figure 3a), it is clear that pAKT levels are much higher in BT-20 than in MDA-MB-468, despite lower total AKT expression.</Species>
<Species>This difference in AKT activation between MDA-MB-468 and BT-20 likely contributes to the disparity in their sensitivity to the increased apoptosis expected with loss of MUC1.</Species>
<Species>MUC1 siRNA alters proliferation and invasion As MUC1 is involved in apoptosis, we next analyzed its effects on proliferation.</Species>
<Species>BrdU and [3H]thymidine incorporation were used to analyze proliferation after MUC1 siRNA.</Species>

<Species>468.siMUC1 cells show a significant decrease in [3H]thymidine incorporation compared to 468.siLuc, while intriguingly, BT.siMUC1 cells show a significant increase in proliferation (Figure 5a).</Species>
<Species>Growth curves mirror these results, as do experiments with the two independent MUC1 siRNA oligonucleotides (data not shown).</Species>

<Species>Note that these assays require trypsinizing cells 24 hours post-transfection; therefore, the results in the MDA-MB-468 line could stem from the changes in apoptosis described in the previous section, rather than a true effect on proliferation.</Species>
<Species>To control for this, we incubated non-trypsinized, siRNA-transfected cells at similar confluence with BrdU to measure incorporation.</Species>

<Species>The 'clumped' profile of cells (contrast to Figure 4b) is likely a result of the acid denaturation (recommended by the antibody manufacturer), as it occurs uniformly in these experiments.</Species>

<Species>BrdU incorporation (Figure 5b) confirms that the [3H]thymidine results are not solely due to alterations in apoptosis, as 468.siMUC1 cells incorporate less BrdU than 468.siLuc; once again, BT.siMUC1 cells show increased proliferation over BT.siLuc.</Species>
<Species>Given the role of MUC1 in adhesion, we examined whether MUC1 siRNA affects cellular invasion.</Species>
<Species>In transwell assays, BT-20 cells invaded poorly, regardless of the siRNA used (data not shown).</Species>
<Species>However, MDA-MB-468 cells invade more readily, and were analyzed on a panel of three different extracellular matrix proteins.</Species>

<Species>Interestingly, 468.siMUC1 cells display somewhat decreased invasion on collagen IV, laminin, and fibronectin matrices, and on a no-matrix control (Figure 5c), which is in agreement with the trend towards decreased metastasis observed in Muc1-/- x MMTV-PyV MT mice [8].</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Transfection of MUC1 rescues the 468.siMUC1 phenotype To determine if the above effects are specific to MUC1, we created stable transfectants of the MDA-MB-468 line using empty vector (468.Neo) or a full-length MUC1 construct (468.MUC1D8) that is resistant to one of the independent MUC1-directed oligonucleotides ('882').</Species>
<Species>These cells were maintained in G418-containing medium to retain transgene selection.</Species>
<Species>As expected, 468.MUC1D8 cells show higher levels of both the MUC1 extracellular domain and the MUC1-CT than do 468.Neo (Figure 6a).</Species>

<Species>Note that 468.Neo have MUC1 expression comparable to parental MDA-MB-468; the exposures in Figure 6a are lighter than those in Figure 1a, in order to clearly show the relative levels of MUC1 in the stable transfectants.</Species>

<Species>After MUC1 siRNA, 468.MUC1D8 lose some MUC1 (likely endogenous protein, which is not siRNA-resistant) but retain high-level expression, while 468.Neo show a decrease in MUC1 levels similar to parental 468.siMUC1 cells (Figures 6a,b).</Species>
<Species>The difference in the amount of MUC1 knockdown between 468.Neo and 468.MUC1D8 is highlighted by the purple shading in Figure 6b.</Species>

<Species>BrdU incorporation (Figure 6c) indicates that 468.Neo show decreased nucleotide incorporation after MUC1 siRNA compared to control (3.3% versus 25.0%, respectively); this is not seen in 468.MUC1D8 cells, which show similar levels of BrdU incorporation regardless of the siRNA used (21.5% for luciferase, 23.9% for MUC1).</Species>

<Species>468.Neo cells display a more dramatic decrease in BrdU incorporation after MUC1 siRNA than what is seen in parental 468.siMUC1 cells, which may reflect the additional stress of being maintained in G418-containing medium.</Species>

<Species>Similarly, analysis of apoptosis in trypsinized cells indicates that the increased apoptosis seen in parental 468.siMUC1 cells is also present in the 468.Neo line after MUC1 siRNA (Figure 6d; 43.6% in control versus 59.6% in MUC1 siRNA).</Species>

<Species>However, in 468.MUC1D8 cells, the level of apoptosis after luciferase siRNA (34.1%) is lower than that in 468.Neo cells; MUC1 siRNA increases the amount of apoptosis slightly (42.8%), restoring it to a level similar to that seen in luciferase siRNA-treated 468.Neo cells.</Species>

<Species>Together, these studies suggest that the above-described results are specific to MUC1, as stable transfection of an siRNA-resistant MUC1 rescues the phenotype seen in 468.siMUC1 cells.</Species>
<Species>Discussion</Species>

<Species>This report describes both the transcriptional alterations seen after transfection with MUC1 siRNA in human breast cancer cells and the effects on events such as apoptosis and proliferation.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The two cell lines used (MDA-MB-468 and BT-20) were chosen for high expression of MUC1 and a substantial (50% to 75%), consistent decrease in MUC1 expression after siRNA.</Species>
<Species>Both lines have epithelial morphology, form tumors slowly in nude mice [37], have mutant p53</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>[39,40], express EGFR</Species>
<Species>[37], and lack estrogen receptor a</Species>
<Species>[41].</Species>
<Species>One striking difference between these lines, however, is their response to MUC1 siRNA.</Species>
<Species>MDA-MB-468 cells behave as expected for loss of an oncogene: MUC1 siRNA correlates with increased apoptosis in response to stress, decreased proliferation, and reduced invasion.</Species>
<Species>In contrast, BT.siMUC1 cells proliferate more rapidly than BT.siLuc cells with little effect on apoptosis.</Species>
<Species>Much of the phenotype of these cells can be understood in light of protein levels and transcriptional activity after MUC1 siRNA.</Species>

<Species>As mentioned, both MDA-MB-468 and BT-20 display increased pAKT after MUC1 siRNA, but the ratio of active to total AKT is considerably higher in the BT-20 line, which may help these cells resist the increased apoptosis expected with loss of MUC1.</Species>

<Species>Myc levels are also higher in both cell lines after MUC1 siRNA, although the ability of Myc to promote proliferation and apoptosis in different cellular contexts [42] complicates the interpretation of this finding.</Species>
<Species>Both cell lines show reduced transcription of VEGF, PDGFA, PDGFB, and MAP2K1 (MEK1) after MUC1 siRNA.</Species>

<Species>The genes encoding vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) and the A and B chains of platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF-A and PDGF-B) are interesting as these proteins have been heavily implicated in angiogenesis, suggesting a novel function for MUC1 in regulating this process.</Species>

<Species>Vascular endothelial growth factor expression in cancer is linked to tumor growth and metastasis [43,44]; platelet-derived growth factor is also angiogenic, but has an additional role in stimulating desmoplasia</Species>
<Species>[45].</Species>

<Species>Reduced transcription of these genes after MUC1 siRNA suggests that MUC1 may foster angiogenesis and stromal proliferation, although this must be confirmed in a more appropriate model system.</Species>
<Species>Decreased MAP2K1 (MEK1) transcription after MUC1 siRNA provides a novel mechanism by which MUC1 can affect the ERK1/2 MAPK pathway.</Species>

<Species>MUC1 has often been linked to the Ras-Raf-MEK-ERK cascade [12,34-36,46], and at least two mechanisms by which MUC1 can alter MAPK signaling have been described: MUC1 interaction with and phosphorylation by the EGFR family</Species>
<Species>[12,13], and MUC1 binding to the Grb2/Sos complex that activates Ras [46].</Species>

<Species>Reduction of MEK1 levels after MUC1 siRNA agrees with the role of MUC1 in strengthening MAPK signaling, and indicates that MUC1 can regulate both the transcription and activity of members of this pathway.</Species>
<Species>Two additional MAPK pathway members are altered specifically in BT.siMUC1, with no corresponding change in 468.siMUC1 cells.</Species>
<Species>These genes are RAF1 and JUN which are increased and decreased, respectively, after MUC1 siRNA.</Species>

<Species>Raf-1 and c-Jun both function outside of the ERK1/2 MAPK pathway, which may explain the seeming paradox of increased RAF1 transcription with simultaneous decreases in MAP2K1 and JUN.</Species>
<Species>Specifically, Raf-1 can inhibit ASK1 (apoptosis signal-regulated kinase 1) upstream of p38 and JNK (Jun N-terminal kinase)</Species>
<Species>[38].</Species>

<Species>ASK1 phosphorylates JNK in response to stress, resulting in activation of c-Jun and stimulation of apoptosis [47], indicating that the coordinate up-regulation of RAF1 and down-regulation of JUN may provide a potent anti-apoptotic effect in BT.siMUC1.</Species>
<Species>Regulation of life and death is also a hallmark of the CDC25A and TNF gene products.</Species>

<Species>CDC25A is a phosphatase that stimulates cell cycle progression [48], thus the effects of its decrease in BT.siMUC1 are unclear in light of the increased proliferation of these cells.</Species>

<Species>However, the CDC25 proteins (A, B, and C) were recently shown to have greater functional overlap than was previously thought [49], suggesting that the other two isoforms may compensate for reduced CDC25A levels.</Species>
<Species>TNF encodes tumor necrosis factor (TNF)a, known for its potent, cell type-specific control of life and death.</Species>

<Species>In tumor cells, TNFa expression can promote proliferation and inhibit apoptosis [50], suggesting that increased TNF transcription in BT.siMUC1 could contribute to the increased proliferation seen in these cells.</Species>
<Species>Interestingly, the increase in TNF is accompanied by decreased transcription of TIMP3, encoding tissue inhibitor of metalloproteinases (TIMP)3.</Species>
<Species>The TIMP family disrupts the function of matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs), generally resulting in decreased invasion [51].</Species>
<Species>TIMP3 is unique in that it can also inhibit TNFa converting enzyme (TACE), which activates TNFa by cleaving it from the cell surface</Species>
<Species>[50].</Species>
<Species>Reduced expression of TIMP3 would, therefore, foster signaling through TNFa by releasing inhibition of TNFa converting enzyme.</Species>

<Species>In agreement with this, TIMP3 can promote apoptosis [52]; thus, its down-regulation in BT.siMUC1 provides another mechanism by which these cells are able to resist the increased apoptosis expected with loss of MUC1.</Species>

<Species>Another TIMP target responds to MUC1 siRNA, as 468.siMUC1 cells show significantly increased expression of MMP2 (encoding MMP-2/gelatinase A), the product of which degrades type IV collagen [52].</Species>
<Species>In breast cancer, the ratio of active to latent MMP-2 increases with tumor progression; MMP-2 may facilitate both angiogenesis and metastasis [52].</Species>
<Species>Its increase after loss of MUC1 is, therefore, unexpected, but at least two factors may clarify this result.</Species>

<Species>First, though MMP-2 levels are increased in mouse mammary tumors, its expression is confined to the stroma [53], suggesting that increased MMP2 transcription after loss of the epithelium-specific MUC1 might reflect a shift towards a more mesenchymal phenotype.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Second, MMP-2 levels are increased by overexpression of erbB2 [52]; previous studies have shown that erbB2 and Muc1 expression are mutually exclusive in mammary tumors [27], implying that MMP2 might be part of a transcriptional profile linked to low MUC1 levels.</Species>
<Species>It is intriguing that, despite increased MMP2 transcription, invasion is decreased in 468.siMUC1 cells, even on collagen IV.</Species>
<Species>This may reflect insufficient activation of MMP-2, as the precursor protein must be cleaved for enzymatic function [52].</Species>
<Species>Alternatively, the slowed invasion of these cells may relate to impaired adhesion resulting from decreased transcription of ITGAV and ITGB1 (av and b1 integrins, respectively).</Species>
<Species>Integrin signaling is tied to life-or-death decisions in epithelial cells, and integrin expression is vital for processes from wound healing to metastasis [54].</Species>

<Species>Integrin avb3 is implicated in facilitating metastasis of breast cancer cells to bone [55]; decreased transcription of ITGAV after MUC1 siRNA may, therefore, suggest that MUC1 is involved in this lethal process as well.</Species>
<Species>The MUC1 oncogene has been linked to apoptosis [18,20,26], proliferation [17], and transcription [21,23-25] in cancer.</Species>

<Species>However, the two cell lines chosen for our study display very different responses to MUC1 siRNA, indicating that regulation of MUC1 in breast cancer is likely quite complex and cautioning against over-generalization of results from individual cell lines.</Species>

<Species>Previous reports suggest that, though most studies outline a clearly oncogenic role for MUC1 in breast cancer, the exact details may vary depending on factors such as cell type and signaling context.</Species>
<Species>For example, MUC1 stimulates Fas-mediated apoptosis in CHO cells [26], quite unlike the inhibition of apoptosis seen in other cell lines.</Species>

<Species>Similarly, though MUC1 drives mammary oncogenesis in its own right [9] and facilitates tumorigenesis driven by other oncogenes [7,8], Muc1 is selectively down-regulated in c-neu-induced mouse mammary tumors [27], indicating that the context of oncogenic signaling is vital to understanding the function of MUC1.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Thus, it is important to consider the relative levels of knockdown of MUC1 in the two cell lines: BT-20 cells reduce MUC1 expression after siRNA less strongly than do MDA-MB-468 (50% versus 75% knockdown, respectively).</Species>

<Species>As MUC1 serves as a scaffold [11], overexpression of MUC1 relative to its associated signaling proteins might create a dilution effect, sequestering signal transducers away from each other; this would be relieved by MUC1 siRNA.</Species>

<Species>Thus, enough MUC1 may be retained in BT.siMUC1 cells for its oncogenic effects, while signaling complex formation would be enhanced by lowering the amount of MUC1 relative to other signaling proteins.</Species>

<Species>Conclusion The contrast between the MDA-MB-468 and BT-20 lines in response to MUC1 siRNA serves as a reminder that simplified models such as cell lines fail to encompass the complexity of intact biological systems.</Species>

<Species>This report describes transcriptional alterations seen after MUC1 knockdown: decreased transcription of MAP2K1, VEGF, PDGFA, ITGAV, TIMP3, CDC25A, and JUN, and increased transcription of MMP2, TNF, and RAF1.</Species>
<Species>The alterations in MAP2K1, RAF1, and JUN represent a novel means by which MUC1 can affect ERK1/2 signaling: transcriptional regulation of MAPK pathway members.</Species>
<Species>Oncogenic events are also altered in both cell lines after MUC1 siRNA.</Species>

<Species>These results strengthen the growing ties linking MUC1 and transcriptional regulation, and suggest that the role of MUC1 in breast cancer may be more complex than a direct correlation between MUC1 level and oncogenic function.</Species>

<Species>Abbreviations BrdU = bromodeoxyuridine; EGF = epidermal growth factor; EGFR = epidermal growth factor receptor; ERK = extracellular signal regulated kinase; MAPK = mitogen activated protein kinase; MEK = MAPK and ERK kinase; MMP = matrix metalloproteinases; MUC1-CT = MUC1 cytoplasmic tail; MUC1-EX = MUC1 extracellular subunit; PBS = phosphate-buffered saline; PI = propidium iodide; siRNA = small interfering RNA; TIMP = tissue inhibitor of metalloproteinases; TNF = tumor necrosis factor.</Species>
<Species>Competing interests</Species>

<Species>Authors' contributions CLH performed all studies and composed the manuscript.</Species>
<Species>SJG participated in the design and coordination of the studies and contributed strongly to the revision of the manuscript.</Species>
<Species>Both authors have read and approved the manuscript.</Species>
<Species>Molecular polymorphism, differentiation and introgression in the period gene between Lutzomyia intermedia and Lutzomyia whitmani</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Abstract Background Lutzomyia intermedia and Lutzomyia whitmani (Diptera: Psychodidae) are important and very closely related vector species of cutaneous leishmaniasis in Brazil, which are distinguishable by a few morphological differences.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>There is evidence of mitochondrial introgression between the two species but it is not clear whether gene flow also occurs in nuclear genes.</Species>
<Species>Results We analyzed the molecular variation within the clock gene period (per) of these two species in five different localities in Eastern Brazil.</Species>
<Species>AMOVA and Fst estimates showed no evidence for geographical differentiation within species.</Species>
<Species>On the other hand, the values were highly significant for both analyses between species.</Species>
<Species>The two species show no fixed differences and a higher number of shared polymorphisms compared to exclusive mutations.</Species>

<Species>In addition, some haplotypes that are "typical" of one species were found in some individuals of the other species suggesting either the persistence of old polymorphisms or the occurrence of introgression.</Species>
<Species>Two tests of gene flow, one based on linkage disequilibrium and a MCMC analysis based on coalescence, suggest that the two species might be exchanging alleles at the per locus.</Species>
<Species>Conclusion Introgression might be occurring between L. intermedia and L. whitmani in period, a gene controlling behavioral rhythms in Drosophila.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>This result raises the question of whether similar phenomena are occurring at other loci controlling important aspects of behavior and vectorial capacity.</Species>
<Species>Background The Phlebotominae sand flies Lutzomyia intermedia Lutz & Neiva 1912 and Lutzomyia whitmani Antunes & Coutinho 1912 are vectors of cutaneous leishmaniasis in Brazil.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>These are closely related species that can be only distinguished by a few morphological differences [1] and both show high anthropophily and reported natural infections with Leishmania in different regions of Brazil [2].</Species>
<Species>Despite their importance as vectors, only a handful of studies have been carried out in these two species using molecular techniques [3-6].</Species>
<Species>One of the most important findings from an epidemiological perspective is the evidence obtained for introgression between the two species using mitochondrial DNA [4].</Species>

<Species>This was particularly interesting because apparently, only lineages of L. whitmani sympatric with L. intermedia have been involved in cutaneous leishmaniasis transmission in the peridomestic environment [4], which suggests that genes controlling aspects of vectorial capacity could be passing from one species to the other.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>In fact, mitochondrial introgression has been reported in other sand fly species [7,8] suggesting that might be a common phenomenon in these insect vectors.</Species>

<Species>However, because mitochondrial genes can introgress relatively easily between closely related species [9], it becomes important to examine whether introgression can occur with nuclear genes.</Species>
<Species>The Drosophila period (per) gene homologue was isolated in sand flies by Peixoto et al.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>[10].</Species>

<Species>This circadian clock gene was originally identified using mutagenesis by Konopka and Benzer [11], but is also known to control the differences in the "lovesong" rhythms between D. melanogaster and D. simulans</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>[12], that are important to the sexual isolation between these two species [13-15].</Species>

<Species>In addition, per was implicated in the control of species-specific circadian mating rhythms in Drosophila and Bractocera, which might also constitute a reproductive isolation mechanism [16-18].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Thus per may possibly represent an example of a Drosophila speciation gene [19], and in fact it has been used as a molecular marker in a number of speciation and evolutionary studies, not only in Drosophila (reviewed in [20]) but also in other insects (e.g. [21]) including sand flies</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>[22-24].</Species>

<Species>Because per controls the circadian clock in different insects [25], it is almost certainly involved in the rhythms of activity and biting of sand flies [26], which are very important to leishmaniasis transmission.</Species>
<Species>In addition, per might be involved in reproductive isolation in sand flies, via mating rhythms, or via their "lovesongs"</Species>
<Species>[2,27].</Species>
<Species>per is thus a particularly interesting marker, among the few available, for an introgression analysis in L. intermedia and L. whitmani.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Evidence for introgression in per might suggest that gene flow between these two vector species is occurring at other genes controlling important aspects of behavior and vectorial capacity.</Species>
<Species>It might also suggest that per does not have a strong role in their reproductive isolation.</Species>
<Species>In the current study, we analyzed the molecular variation within the per gene of L. intermedia and L. whitmani in five different localities in Eastern Brazil.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Results Polymorphism and divergence between L. intermedia and L. whitmani</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>A total of 68 sequences from L. intermedia and 53 from L. whitmani homologue to a fragment of the period gene were analyzed from populations of five localities in Eastern Brazil (Fig 1).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The alignment of 72 variable sites is shown in Fig 2.</Species>

<Species>Although most of the changes are either synonymous or occur within the 58 bp intron, non-synonymous substitutions are observed causing 9 amino acid differences among the sequences (Fig 2).</Species>

<Species>Table 1 shows the number of sequences of each population of the two species, the number of polymorphic sites (S) and the estimates of molecular polymorphism O (based on the total number of mutations) and p. Table 1 also shows the Tajima's [28] and Fu & Li's [29] statistics.</Species>
<Species>Within each species, all populations present similar levels of polymorphism with the exception of L. whitmani from Ilheus, which seems to be less polymorphic than the others.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>This population was also the only one presenting a significant value in the Fu & Li test but only at the 5% level.</Species>
<Species>Finally, the last column of Table 1 presents the recombination estimator g</Species>
<Species>[30] indicating that both species show evidence of intragenic recombination in the per gene.</Species>
<Species>To investigate the level of intra and interspecific differences, initially an AMOVA was carried out as shown in Table 2.</Species>
<Species>The results show a non-significant within species and a significant between species molecular variation at the per locus.</Species>
<Species>Table 3 shows a more detailed analysis of the intraspecific differentiation among populations of L. intermedia and L. whitmani.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>None of the pairwise and overall fixation indexes (Fst) are significant in the case of L. intermedia and only one (Posse x Ilheus) has a borderline significant value in L. whitmani.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The results therefore show that no significant geographical heterogeneity was detected among the populations of the two species.</Species>
<Species>The estimated number of migrants per generation, based on the overall Fst values, is 20.683 for L. intermedia and 23.125 for L. whitmani.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Table 4 shows measures for DNA divergence between species (Dxy and Da), as well as the Fst and Nm values considering each species as a unique population.</Species>

<Species>Dxy is the average number of nucleotide substitutions per site between alleles from two different populations and Da is the number of net nucleotide substitutions between two populations.</Species>

<Species>Table 4 also shows the number of polymorphisms exclusive for each species (Sint and Swhit), the number of shared polymorphisms (Ss) and the number of fixed differences (Sf) between species.</Species>

<Species>As one can note, there is a high number of shared polymorphisms between species, and no fixed differences between them suggesting either the persistence of ancestral polymorphisms or the occurrence of introgression.</Species>

<Species>In fact, there is one shared haplotype between the two species (IPO13, WPO10 and WPO19) and three L. whitmani sequences (WAC02, WPO13 and WPO14) which show only one nucleotide difference to "typical" L. intermedia haplotypes (see also below).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Genealogy of period sequences A phylogenetic analysis of the period gene sequences from L. intermedia and L. whitmani was carried out with the Minimum Evolution method using the Kimura 2-parameter distance (Fig 3).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>A sequence from L. umbratilis, a related species from the same subgenus Nyssomyia, was used as outgroup [24].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The tree shows L. intermedia and L. whitmani as non-monophyletic.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>However, despite the low bootstrap values, which are below 50% in most cases, there is a large group that contains most L. intermedia sequences and a second large group with most L. whitmani sequences.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>A few other sequences are clustered outside these two main groups.</Species>

<Species>It is interesting to note that there are three L. whitmani alleles (WAC2, WPO13 and WPO14) inside L. intermedia main group, as well as one L. intermedia allele (ICP16) inside the L. whitmani main group.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>In addition, a second L. intermedia allele (IPO13) is a shared haplotype between the two species as mentioned above.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Again, the results suggest either the persistence of ancestral polymorphisms or the occurrence of introgression between the two species.</Species>
<Species>Very similar results were obtained using the maximum likelihood algorithm as implemented in PAUP 4.0b10 software [31] (data not shown).</Species>

<Species>As mentioned before, there is evidence of intragenic recombination in the per gene fragment of both species (see Table 1) and for that reason the bifurcating tree shown in Fig 3 has to be viewed with caution, as different regions of the gene might have different phylogenetic histories [32].</Species>

<Species>Therefore, we constructed Minimum Evolution trees with the two most polymorphic non-recombining blocks of the per gene fragment identified using the Hudson and Kaplan [33] method available in the DNAsp 4.1 program [34].</Species>
