<Species>Comparison of strategies for identification of regulatory quantitative trait loci of transcript expression traits</Species>

<Species>Abstract In order to identify regulatory genes, we determined the heritability of gene transcripts, performed linkage analysis to identify quantitative trait loci (QTLs), and evaluated the evidence for shared genetic effects among transcripts with co-localized QTLs in non-diseased participants from 14 CEPH (Centre d'Etude du Polymorphisme Humain) Utah families.</Species>
<Species>Seventy-six percent of transcripts had a significant heritability and 54% of them had LOD score > 1.8.</Species>

<Species>Bivariate genetic analysis of 15 transcripts that had co-localized QTLs on 4q28.2-q31.1 identified significant genetic correlation among some transcripts although no improvement in the magnitude of LOD scores in this region was noted.</Species>
<Species>Similar results were found in analysis of 12 transcripts, that had co-localized QTLs in the 13q34 region.</Species>
<Species>Principal-component analyses did not improve the ability to identify chromosomal regions of co-localized gene expressions.</Species>
<Species>Background There is a breadth of information being generated by the Human Genome Project and the interpretation of these data has been a major area of research.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>For simple Mendelian disorders, the identification of genetic effects is fairly straightforward due to understanding the biology that drives these disorders.</Species>

<Species>However, for complex oligogenic or polygenic disorders, understanding all the interconnections between genes influencing a trait is a difficult task because the understanding of the biology of many of these disorders is still evolving.</Species>
<Species>Multiple gene x gene and gene x environment interactions can influence the expression of phenotypes.</Species>
<Species>Genes can interact by modifying the expression of other genes and therefore function as regulatory genes [1].</Species>

<Species>In an effort to dissect some of these complexities, we performed linkage analysis of gene expression transcripts of members of Centre d'Etude du Polymorphisme Humain (CEPH) Utah families to determine the heritability of transcripts and the evidence for regulatory quantitative trait loci (QTLs) and we performed pairwise bivariate linkage analysis and principal-component analysis (PCA) for data-reduction to evaluate the evidence for shared genetic effects.</Species>

<Species>The ability to assess gene expression traits simultaneously and to link them to QTLs offers the possibility of identifying previously unknown underlying molecular processes for future investigation.</Species>
<Species>Methods Population and phenotypes We used the Genetic Analysis Workshop 15 (GAW 15)</Species>
<Species>Problem 1 microarray gene expression profiles for the analyses.</Species>
<Species>Data were available for 14 three-generation CEPH Utah families.</Species>
<Species>Expression levels of genes were obtained from lymphoblastoid cells using the Affymetrix Human Focus Arrays [2].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We were provided with data on 3554 transcripts that showed greater variation between individuals than within the same individual.</Species>
<Species>Family members were genotyped for 2882 autosomal and X-linked single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNP) generated by the SNP Consortium .</Species>

<Species>Genetic map positions were obtained using the SNP Mapping web application developed by the University College Dublin Conway Institute of Biomolecular and Biomedical Research , which uses the Rutgers Combined Linkage-Physical Map of the Human Genome and data taken from the NCBI dbSNP Build 123 (in Kosambi centimorgans).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>This information was used to calculate multipoint identity by descent matrices (MIBDs) with Merlin and Minx</Species>
<Species>[3], after removal of Mendelian inconsistencies and double recombinants with Preswalk (based on Simwalk mistyping probabilities)</Species>
<Species>[4].</Species>
<Species>MIBDs were used for linkage analyses.</Species>
<Species>Transcript distributions were normalized using an inverse normalization transformation of z-scores of individual transcripts regressed on the mean individual transcript level.</Species>
<Species>We further adjusted for the effects of age, age2, sex, age x sex and age2 x sex interaction using predictive linear regression models in SAS 9.1 (Cary, NC).</Species>
<Species>We generated these residuals as part of our processing of the transcripts for linkage analyses.</Species>
<Species>Heritability estimation and linkage analysis Heritability was estimated using maximum likelihood variance decomposition methods in SOLAR [5,6].</Species>

<Species>Genome scans were performed using multipoint variance-components models that test for linkage between traits and genetic variants by partitioning the variance of the expression level into its additive genetic and environmental variance components [7].</Species>
<Species>For transcripts with co-localized QTLs, we performed bivariate linkage analysis to identify shared genetic effects.</Species>
<Species>The bivariate polygenic model estimates correlations caused by residual additive genetic effects (pG) and correlations caused by random environmental effects (pE)</Species>
<Species>[8].</Species>

<Species>To test for additive genetic correlation among pairs of traits, the log likelihood of a model in which pG is constrained to 0 (null hypothesis, no correlation) or pG = 1 (null hypothesis, complete shared genetic effect) is compared to that of a model in which pG is estimated for the traits.</Species>
<Species>Significant differences among the models (pG     0) suggest that some of the same genes influence both traits.</Species>
<Species>We also performed linkage analysis using the factors obtained from the PCA in a sample of transcripts with co-localized QTLs.</Species>

<Species>Principal-component analysis PCA was used to reduce the number of expression profiles into statistically meaningful groups while retaining the original total variance using all the expression profiles</Species>
<Species>[9,10].</Species>
<Species>We selected two different chromosomal regions of a length of 10 to 12 MB in which the QTLs of at least 10 transcripts were co-localized.</Species>
<Species>Only transcripts of genes that were not located in these selected chromosomal regions were included in the analyses (trans-regulatory genes).</Species>
<Species>Because of the small number of individuals in the study and concerns of overfitting the model, a maximum sample of 50 transcript values were considered at one time [11].</Species>
<Species>The number of factors was determined using the eigenvalue-one requirement [11].</Species>
<Species>Factors are interpreted by examining the varimax-rotated factor loadings, which are the correlations between each phenotype and the factor in question.</Species>

<Species>Factor loadings greater than or equal to 0.40 in absolute value were used to interpret factors and to characterize the factor structures; this criterion ensures that the individual factor variables share at least 15% of their variance with the given factor [9].</Species>
<Species>The principle components were obtained by calculating the eigenvalues of the sample covariance matrix, which represent the amount of variance contributed by each factor.</Species>
<Species>Only factors with eigenvalues higher than 1 were considered for linkage analysis.</Species>

<Species>Integrating data from linkage analysis for gene co-expression Linkage signals of individual transcript expressions were recorded and the location of QTLs was compared to the location of the transcript gene in order to identify trans-regulatory sites.</Species>

<Species>In addition, the location and LOD scores of QTLs identified in single individual transcript analysis (univariate analysis) were compared with the location of the QTLs identified using bivariate analysis or factors of the PCA.</Species>

<Species>This allowed a determination of whether the bivariate analysis or PCA data reduction analysis improved our evidence for linkage, and if so, a more in-depth examination of the transcripts included in the principal components needs to be examined for biologic interactions on complex disorders.</Species>
<Species>Results Among 194 individuals from 14 families, 17 individuals with missing information on age were excluded.</Species>
<Species>Seventy-six percent (n = 2688) of the transcripts had significant heritability (p < 0.05) and were considered for the linkage analysis.</Species>
<Species>Of this, 1448 (54%) transcripts displayed suggestive evidence of linkage (had a maximum LOD score > 1.8</Species>
<Species>[12]).</Species>
<Species>The QTLs of 1661 transcripts (759 of which with LOD > 1.8) were localized in a different region than the gene transcript (trans-regulatory sites).</Species>
<Species>We used two different chromosomal regions with co-localized transcript QTLs, chromosomes 4q28.2-q31.1 and 13q34, for more in-depth analyses.</Species>
<Species>Chromosome 4q28.2-q31.1 region Table 1 reports the results for the chromosome 4q28.2-q31.1 region.</Species>
<Species>Fifteen transcripts co-localized in this region in the univariate linkage analysis, and the LOD scores ranged from 1.17 to 3.72.</Species>
<Species>The strongest linkage signals were observed for the transcripts of the MX2, NUCB2, and SNX4 genes.</Species>
<Species>Using PCA, we obtained five factors from the 15 transcripts with eigenvalues greater than 1.</Species>
<Species>Only one factor, with a high positive loading for the MX2 gene transcript, had a significant heritability and a LOD score > 1.8.</Species>

<Species>The linkage analysis using this factor identified the chromosome region for the MX2 gene, but the LOD score was lower than the one obtained by single linkage analysis of the MX2 transcript.</Species>

<Species>We then performed bivariate analysis of all pairwise co-localized transcripts on 4q28.2-q31.1 and found evidence for genetic correlation of co-localized genes, although without much increase in the magnitude of the LOD score (Figure 1).</Species>
<Species>This analysis identified two networks of gene expressions (Figure 1).</Species>
<Species>We obtained two factors using PCA of the first network (Group 1, SNX4, YWHAQ, ASS, MX2, and ISGF3G gene transcripts).</Species>

<Species>Both factors had significant heritability; however, only Factor 1, loading heavily on the MX2 gene, localized to the 4q28.2-q31.1 region (Table 1), and the magnitude of the LOD score was lower than that of the univariate MX2 gene transcript analysis (LOD = 2.28).</Species>
<Species>The heritability of one factor obtained using PCA for Group 2 transcripts was not significant and further analysis was not performed.</Species>
<Species>Chromosome 13q34 region We performed analysis in an additional chromosome region of co-localized transcripts, 13q34 region, and noted similar results.</Species>
<Species>Using univariate analysis, 12 transcripts co-localized in this region; and bivariate analysis revealed an intricate network of correlated traits (Table 2 and Figure 2).</Species>
<Species>Using PCA, we obtained five factors, three of them with significant heritability.</Species>
<Species>Similar to our previous findings on chomosome 4, PCA factors did not improve the magnitude of the LOD scores when compared to univariate analysis.</Species>

<Species>Discussion In this study, we identified co-localized QTLs of individual transcripts and compared the univariate and bivariate linkage results using single transcripts to those using factors obtained from PCA.</Species>

<Species>By using factors that accounted for the variance of multiple transcripts with co-localized QTLs, we attempted to reduce the number of linkage analyses performed as well as possibly identifying previously unknown patterns of associated gene expression profiles.</Species>

<Species>The PCA did in fact reduce the number of linkage analyses performed, but it did not improve the magnitude of signals in the target QTLs as compared with univariate or bivariate analyses.</Species>
<Species>In fact, in at least one case, PCA was unable to detect a linkage signal for the main gene transcript loading in the factor (Table 1, Group 1, Factor 2).</Species>

<Species>We also performed pairwise bivariate genetic analysis on those transcripts that co-localized to the same genomic region, presumably because this area of the genome harbored genes involved in the regulation of these transcripts [2].</Species>
<Species>We detected significant genetic correlation of these co-localized transcripts, indicating potential gene networks operating in these regions.</Species>
<Species>However, in most cases, bivariate linkage analysis did not improve the magnitude of the LOD score compared to univariate analysis.</Species>
<Species>Most traits were highly correlated (pG > 0.60), and therefore they may provide redundant information that may reduce the power for detection of the bivariate signal [8].</Species>

<Species>In addition, because pG is a test of the overall additive genetic correlation among two traits and not the QTL-specific pleiotropy, it is possible that the co-localized linkage signals are not in fact genetically correlated.</Species>
<Species>Further analysis is required to address these issues.</Species>
<Species>The chromosome regions selected for detailed analyses were arbitrarily chosen as we identified multiple other regions with co-localized linkage of gene expressions.</Species>
<Species>The results from our univariate genome scan differ markedly from those reported by Morley et al.</Species>
<Species>[2] because we included a smaller sample of individuals so that adjustment for covariate effects of age could be made.</Species>
<Species>Our analysis strategy also adjusted for the effects of age and sex, which could also add to the observed differences [13].</Species>
<Species>Finally, our definition of genome window size for co-localized gene expressions was twice larger than the one described in the study of Morley et al.</Species>
<Species>Conclusion We identified several chromosomal regions of co-localized trans-regulatory genes with significant heritability.</Species>
<Species>Some of these regulatory genes displayed strong additive genetic correlations, and may be part of genetic networks.</Species>

<Species>However, when compared to univariate analysis, linkage analysis of bivariate phenotypes and factor scores obtained from PCA did not improve the ability to identify chromosomal regions of co-localized gene expressions.</Species>

<Species>List of Abbreviations CEPH: Centre d'Etude du Polymorphisme Humain GAW: Genetic Analysis Workshop H2: heritability LOD: logarithm of the odds MIBD: multipoint identity-by-descent matrices N/A: not apply NCBI: National Center for Biotechnology Information PCA: principal-component analysis QTL: quantitative trait loci SE: standard error of the mean SNP: single-nucleotide polymorphism SOLAR:</Species>
<Species>Sequential Oligogenic Linkage Analysis Routines Competing interests</Species>
<Species>The author(s) declare that they have no competing interests.</Species>
<Species>Neurogenin2 Directs Granule Neuroblast Production and Amplification while NeuroD1 Specifies Neuronal Fate during Hippocampal Neurogenesis</Species>

<Species>Abstract The specification and differentiation of dentate gyrus granule neurons in the hippocampus require temporally and spatially coordinated actions of both intrinsic and extrinsic molecules.</Species>
<Species>The basic helix-loop-helix transcription factor Neurogenin2 (Ngn2) and NeuroD1 are key regulators in these processes.</Species>
<Species>Based on existing classification, we analyzed the molecular events occurring during hippocampal neurogenesis, primarily focusing on juvenile animals.</Species>
<Species>We found that Ngn2 is transiently expressed by late type-2a amplifying progenitors.</Species>
<Species>The Ngn2 progenies mature into hippocampal granule neurons.</Species>
<Species>Interestingly, the loss of Ngn2 at early stages of development leads to a robust reduction in neurogenesis, but does not disturb granule neuron maturation per se.</Species>

<Species>We found that the role of Ngn2 is to maintain progenitors in an undifferentiated state, allowing them to amplify prior to their maturation into granule neurons upon NeuroD1 induction.</Species>

<Species>When we overexpressed Ngn2 and NeuroD1 in vivo, we found NeuroD1 to exhibit a more pronounced neuron-inductive effect, leading to granule neuron commitment, than that displayed by Ngn2.</Species>
<Species>Finally, we observed that all markers expressed during the transcriptional control of hippocampal neurogenesis in rodents are also present in the human hippocampus.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Taken together, we demonstrate a critical role of for Ngn2 and NeuroD1 in controlling neuronal commitment and hippocampal granule neuroblast formation, both during embryonic development and in post-natal hippocampal granule neurogenesis.</Species>
<Species>Introduction Neurons are born not only during development of the central nervous system, but neurogenesis also continues into adulthood.</Species>

<Species>In both rodent and human adult brain, neurogenesis is active in two distinct zones of the forebrain: the subventricular zone (SVZ) of the lateral ventricle and the subgranular zone (SGZ) of the hippocampal dentate gyrus (DG)</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>[1]-[5].</Species>
<Species>The molecular mechanism underlying neurogenesis in the DG is not fully understood.</Species>

<Species>Clearly, a cascade of transcriptional events controls the specification of neuronal identity in the DG [3], [6]-[8], but details of the expression pattern and function of each transcription factor remain elusive.</Species>

<Species>The paired-box homeodomain transcription factor Pax6 and the bHLH transcription factors Ngn2 and NeuroD1 are important when cells acquire a pan-neuronal character and a specific neuronal subtype</Species>
<Species>[9], [10].</Species>
<Species>In the developing neocortex, Pax6 is expressed in dividing radial glial cells at the ventricular surface [9].</Species>
<Species>In the adult hippocampus, Pax6 is expressed in astrocytes in the SGZ and are considered to be the true stem cells [9], [11].</Species>
<Species>Loss- and gain-of-function studies indicate that Pax6 is involved in regulating the proliferation of neocortical and hippocampal progenitors</Species>
<Species>[9], [12]-[16].</Species>
<Species>During neocorticogenesis, high concentrations of Pax6 induce the expression of the bHLH transcription factor Neurogenin2 (Ngn2)</Species>
<Species>[17].</Species>
<Species>In turn, Ngn2 causes cell cycle exit [18], an event that takes place when NeuroD1 starts to be expressed [19].</Species>
<Species>In the developing hippocampus, the absence of Ngn2 leads to a reduced number of granule neurons [20].</Species>
<Species>NeuroD1, on the other hand, is essential for the differentiation and survival of hippocampal granule neurons</Species>
<Species>[10].</Species>
<Species>Interestingly, in the absence of Ngn2, NeuroD1 can still be activated and neuronal differentiation can still take place</Species>
<Species>[20].</Species>
<Species>This has led to the idea that the primary role of Ngn2 is not to direct neuronal differentiation.</Species>
<Species>Only a small number of studies have addressed the role of Ngn2 and NeuroD1 in hippocampal neurogenesis [10], [20], [21].</Species>
<Species>Therefore, we now re-examine their roles in hippocampal neurogenesis in detail, using gain- and loss-of-function experiments.</Species>

<Species>We first establish a hierarchy of transcriptional events that occur during neurogenesis in the DG and then define the place that Ngn2, NeuroD1 and other transcription factors have in this cascade.</Species>
<Species>We find that a lack of Ngn2 expression result in a markedly smaller hippocampus and an almost complete absence of the DG.</Species>
<Species>We show that Ngn2 is required for granule neuroblasts production/amplification.</Species>
<Species>Gain-of-function of NeuroD1 during development of the DG results in an efficient generation of granule neuroblasts, an effect that we do not observe when we overexpress Ngn2.</Species>
<Species>Finally, we demonstrate that the same transcription factors and cellular markers seen in mouse and rat tissue are also present in the human hippocampus.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Results Expression of transcription factors and cellular markers define different phases of postnatal hippocampal granule neuron maturation</Species>

<Species>We first analyzed in detail the chronology of expression of different transcription factors and cell-specific markers during DG granule neuron formation and correlated our findings to the previously established classification of adult hippocampal neurogenesis [3].</Species>
<Species>The current classification describes hippocampal stem cells and progenies into three categories (type-1, -2 and -3 cells) depending on the markers they express as they mature.</Species>
<Species>In the adult mouse DG, only a very small proportion of cells undergo mitosis at any one given time [22].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Consequently, in adult animals it is difficult to analyze which transcription factors are involved in the transition phase from one cell category to the next.</Species>
<Species>Therefore, we studied 2 week-old rodents which have higher numbers of maturing granule neurons in the DG.</Species>
<Species>We performed triple immunohistochemistry for all markers of interest and compared results from 2 week- and 2 month-old mice (Figure 1 and figure S1).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We first confirmed that stem cells in the SGZ exhibit characteristics of radial glia [3], [11], [16].</Species>
<Species>They extend radial processes from the SGZ to the apex of the subgranular layer (SGL) and the basal molecular layer.</Species>
<Species>Moreover, they express the intermediate filament protein nestin, glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) and glial glutamate transporter (GLAST)</Species>
<Species>[16] (Figure 1A and B and figure S1A and S1B).</Species>
<Species>The GFAP- and GLAST+ cells are defined as type-1 cells [3].</Species>
<Species>They also express the paired-homeodomain transcription factor Pax6 (Figure 1B).</Species>
<Species>These radial glia-like stem cells divide relatively infrequently, and are believed to undergo symmetric division (giving rise to two identical stem cells) under some conditions.</Species>
<Species>They can also divide asymmetrically and give rise to a new stem cell and one neuronal progenitor, which usually is defined as a type-2 cell (Figure 2B)</Species>
<Species>[3].</Species>
<Species>Type-2 cells are divided into two different populations: type-2a expressing nestin and type-2b co-expressing nestin and doublecortin (Dcx)</Species>
<Species>[23].</Species>
<Species>Based on a previous report [24], we examined the expression pattern of the T-domain transcription factors Tbr1 and Tbr2.</Species>
<Species>We found that Tbr2 is expressed in type-2a cells, in agreement with a recent report [25].</Species>
<Species>In the SGZ of 2 week-old mice, we found an average of 50-70 Tbr2+ cells per 30 um-thick section throughout the rostro-caudal axis of the dorsal hippocampus.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>This number was reduced by 35% in 2 month-old mice (Figure 1C with figure S1C and data not shown).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>As opposed to Tbr1 (Figure 1D and figure S1D), Tbr2+ cells did not co-express Dcx or PSA-NCAM (Figure 1C and figure S1C).</Species>
<Species>We observed that Tbr1-immuoreactivity gradually decreased as neurons matured and started to express NeuN (Figure 1H and figure S1H).</Species>
<Species>Thus, Tbr2 labels type-2 cells, while Tbr1 is expressed by immature granule neurons.</Species>
<Species>We then examined the molecular phenotype of type-3 cells, a cell type that transiently expresses Calretinin [26].</Species>

<Species>We hypothesized that hippocampal type-3 cells might also express the bHLH transcription factor NeuroD1, known to partially overlap with Tbr2 and Tbr1 in different brain regions [24].</Species>

<Species>We found that NeuroD1 expression in the hippocampus starts in Tbr2+ cells and extends to post-mitotic Tbr1+ cells, which also express the hippocampal granule identity transcription factor Prox1</Species>
<Species>(Figure 1G and 1I and figure S1G and S1I).</Species>
<Species>While Tbr1 expression ceases during granule maturation, that of NeuroD1 is weakly maintained when NeuN expression starts (Figure 1G and 1H and figure S1G and S1H).</Species>
<Species>We found that calretinin expression decreased during granule neuron maturation, before NeuroD1 was reduced (Figure 1F).</Species>
<Species>Thus NeuroD1 is expressed in type-2b and type-3 cells, as well as immature granule neurons.</Species>
<Species>Finally, we found that NeuroD2 starts to be expressed just after NeuroD1 and, unlike NeuroD1, continues to be highly expressed in mature neurons (Figure 1J and data not shown).</Species>

<Species>Mash1 and Ngn2 define the early versus late type-2a stage in 2 weeks old mice Having established the hierarchy of transcription factors and cellular markers appearing during hippocampal neurogenesis, we set out to clarify the position of the two bHLH transcription factors Ngn2 and Mash1, in this process.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We found that more than 90% of Ngn2-immunoreactive cells are Pax6 positive (Figure 2A), and almost all co-express Tbr2 (Figure 2B).</Species>
<Species>Thus, Ngn2 appears to be expressed by type-2a cells.</Species>
<Species>As our antibodies against Ngn2 and NeuroD1 were made in the same species, we could not determine if there was an overlap between these two proteins.</Species>

<Species>However, by comparing their overlapping expression pattern with that of Tbr2, we propose that some Ngn2+ cells co-express NeuroD1, and that they appear at the onset of NeuroD1 expression and downregulation of Ngn2.</Species>
<Species>We base this assumption on the facts that more than 50% of the Tbr2+ cells are Ngn2+ and more than 50% of Tbr2+ cells also express NeuroD1.</Species>
<Species>The expression of Ngn2 in adult hippocampus was hard to detect using immunohistochemistry due to the low expression of the protein (data not shown).</Species>
<Species>However, it is present, as previously described using reporter mice and as revealed by in situ hybridization [21].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We next examined the expression of Mash1 and compared it with that of Ngn2, Pax6 and Tbr2.</Species>
<Species>We found some Mash1+ cells (10-20 cells per section) in the dorsal hippocampus.</Species>
<Species>Almost all of them co-expressed Pax6 (Figure 2C).</Species>
<Species>Only few cells co-expressed Tbr2 (Figure 2D) or Ngn2 (Figure 2E), suggesting that Mash1 is downregulated when these two proteins are expressed.</Species>
<Species>None of the Mash1-expressing cells were positive for NeuroD1 (Figure 2F).</Species>
<Species>Mash1+ cells were still undergoing mitosis (Figure 2C) and consequently over 90% of them co-labeled with the cell-cycle marker Ki67 (Figure S1J).</Species>

<Species>Taken together, we show that Mash1 and Ngn2 are expressed in early and late stages of maturation of type2a progenitors, respectively, and that both transcription factors are co-expressed briefly when cells transit from early to late phase type2a cells.</Species>
<Species>Ngn2</Species>
<Species>progenies become hippocampal granule neurons Previous work has shown that in Mash1 null mutant mice hippocampal neurogenesis is not reduced and the hippocampus is not malformed</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>[20].</Species>
<Species>Therefore we focused our initial analysis on the role of Ngn2 in hippocampal neurogenesis.</Species>
<Species>We characterized the fate of Ngn2-expressing cells using Ngn2 Knock-in green fluorescent protein (GFP) mice (Ngn2+/GFP)</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>[27].</Species>

<Species>In the SGZ of 2 week-old hippocampi, we found bright GFP-expressing cells that were positive for Tbr2 (Figure 2H), the immature neuronal marker PSA-NCAM (Figure 2I) and NeuroD1 (Figure 2J).</Species>
<Species>Furthermore, Prox1+, NeuroD2+ and calretinin+ cells were also weakly positive for GFP.</Species>
<Species>We made similar observations in 2 month-old mice (data not shown) confirming earlier published results [21]).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We did not observe Mash1+/GFP+ and NeuN+/GFP+ cells (Figure 2G).</Species>

<Species>These data from Ngn2+/GFP mice are entirely consistent with our earlier observations using immunocytochemistry to label Ngn2-expressing cells and with GFP undergoing slow degradation after the expression of Ngn2 has ceased.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Importantly, none of the GFP-expressing cells, including those only weakly fluorescent, residing in the SGL expressed the astrocytic marker GFAP or the oligodendrocytic markers CNPase (data not shown).</Species>
<Species>Taken together, the data show that Ngn2 progenies become neurons and never generate astrocytes or oligodendrocytes.</Species>

<Species>Marked reduction of hippocampal granule neurons in absence of Ngn2 To determine the role of Ngn2 during the initiation of hippocampal granule neurogenesis, we analyzed the hippocampus of mice lacking Ngn2 (Ngn2GFP/GFP).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In contrast to the mice use by Galichet and coworkers, our mice have a lifespan of only 2 weeks after birth.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Therefore, we analyzed 2 week-old and younger mice.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Consistent with previous observations [20], the hippocampus in Ngn2GFP/GFP mutants is clearly malformed (Figure 3A).</Species>
<Species>In two week-old Ngn2GFP/GFP mice, the ventral blade of the DG is completely absent.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Already on postnatal day 1-2, the ventral blade of the DG is malformed along its whole rostro-caudal axis (Figure 3B).</Species>

<Species>As neither migration defects nor cell death cause the reduced number of hippocampal neurons in Ngn2 null mice [20], we asked if Ngn2 is necessary for production of hippocampal granule neuroblasts.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We first injected 2 day-old mouse pups with BrdU 2 hours prior to sacrifice, allowing us to evaluate cell proliferation and ongoing neurogenesis.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We also injected BrdU into female mice on their final day of pregnancy and examined the brains of their pups 48 hours later (corresponding to P1-P2 old pups).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>This allowed us to assess the number of neurons derived from the last day of intrauterine development.</Species>

<Species>Regardless of whether the mice were WT or hetero/homozygous mutant pups, we found cells that had incorporated BrdU in the hippocampal subventricular zone (hSVZ), fimbria and the DG (Figure 4A and B; [28]), suggesting that progenitors originating in the hSVZ divide while migrating towards the DG.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Most of them were organized in chains typical of migrating cells (Figure 4A and B and figure S2).</Species>
<Species>In Ngn2GFP/GFP mutant mice injected with BrdU 2 hours prior to sacrifice, we observed a decrease in the number of BrdU+ cells compared to heterozygous littermates.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Thus, the numbers of newborn cells were reduced in the hSVZ/fimbria (133.3+7.5 for Ngn2+/GFP vs 69.7+5.0 for Ngn2GFP/GFP) and DG (132.0+9.1 for Ngn2+/GFP vs 42.6+2.2 for Ngn2GFP/GFP)(Figure 4C and D).</Species>
<Species>We also examined the number of newborn cells differentiating into neurons, and identified them by the co-expression of BrdU and NeuroD1.</Species>
<Species>As expected, they were relatively few in numbers because the short delay (2 hours) between BrdU administration and sacrifice in this first experimental paradigm.</Species>

<Species>In Ngn2GFP/GFP null mutants, we found the number of cells differentiating into neurons to be reduced by 60% and 71% in the hSVZ/fimbria (8.6+1.4 for Ngn2+/GFP vs 3.4+0.5 for Ngn2GFP/GFP) and DG (9.7+1.1 for Ngn2+/GFP vs 2.8+0.6 for Ngn2GFP/GFP), respectively, (Figure 4E and F).</Species>
<Species>As a result, the number of NeuroD1+ cells in the DG was reduced by 80% (580.3+27.7 for Ngn2+/GFP vs 116.2+7.3 for Ngn2GFP/GFP; Figure 4G).</Species>

<Species>We obtained similar results in the second paradigm, i.e. in mice that we sacrificed 48 hours after BrdU administration and in which a larger number of the newborn cells had time to mature into neurons.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In this case, the number of BrdU+/NeuroD1+ cells in the DG was reduced by 73% of Ngn2GFP/GFP mutant animals (91.5+24.1 for Ngn2+/GFP vs 26.4+3.3 for Ngn2GFP/GFP) (Figure 4J).</Species>
<Species>We found no differences in the proportion of BrdU+ cells that expressed NeuroD1 in Ngn2+/GFP and Ngn2GFP/GFP mice (14.2+1.0% and 17.4+1.8% respectively; Figure 4K).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>This shows that the few cells that manage to proliferate in the Ngn2 null mice have the same ability to differentiate into neurons as those in mice with one Ngn2 allele.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Interestingly, the absence of Ngn2 did not alter the identity of neurons in the DG granule layer in 2 week-old Ngn2 null mice.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The maturing granule progenitors sequentially expressed Pax6, Tbr2 (Figure S3A and S3B), NeuroD1 and Calretinin (Figure 4L), PSA-NCAM (Figure 4N), Tbr1 (data not shown) and Prox1 (Figure 4M).</Species>

<Species>We confirmed that the same transcriptional cascade is active in the 20% (compared to mice with one Ngn2 allele) residual granule neurons that are formed two day-old in Ngn2GFP/GFP mice (Figure S3D-G and data not shown).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>We next investigated if the cells that failed to develop into neurons in Ngn2GFP/GFP mutant mice, became glial cells.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We found that cells expressing GFP never co-labeled with the astrocyte marker GFAP (Figure 4N) or the oligodendrocyte marker CNPase (data not shown).</Species>

<Species>Altogether, our results show that Ngn2 plays an important role during the production/amplification of hippocampal granule neuroblasts, but not the acquisition of the granule neuron identity (Figure S7).</Species>
<Species>Ngn2 controls the amplification of granule neuron progenitors We next monitored the mitogenic activity of Ngn2+ cells in the DG of 2 week-old WT mice.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We observed that over 50% of Ngn2+ cells in the DG of WT mice co-expressed the mitosis marker Ki67 (Figure 5A).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Inspired by this finding, we injected BrdU into 2 week-old WT and Ngn2GFP/GFP mice and compared cell proliferation in the DG.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We observed 92% reduction in number of proliferating cells in the SGZ of Ngn2 null mutant mice (6.7+0.5) compared to WT (83.6+1.2) and heterozygotic (data not shown) littermates (Figure 5B-C).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>This data confirm the importance of Ngn2 during the amplification of granule progenitor.s.</Species>

<Species>To further explore whether Ngn2+ cells become post-mitotic or still proliferate after Ngn2 is downregulated, we performed immunohistochemistry on sections through the DG of Ngn2+/GFP mice.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We stained them with the mitosis marker Phospho-histone 3 (PH3) and NeuroD1, which is downstream of Ngn2 in the transcriptional cascade controlling neurogenesis.</Species>

<Species>Thus, in the same sections we could identify whether cells that had initiated Ngn2 expression (GFP labeled), continued to divide (PH3+) or committed to neuronal differentiation (NeuroD1+).</Species>
<Species>We observed some GFP+ cells that co-expressed PH3.</Species>
<Species>They all exhibited morphological characteristics of one of the five mitotic phases: prophase, metaphase, anaphase, telophase and cytokinesis (Figure 5D and data not shown).</Species>
<Species>Unexpectedly, cells that colabeled for GFP, PH3 and NeuroD1 (Figure 5E and figure S4A and S4B) were rare.</Species>
<Species>This indicates that Ngn2+ cells undergo division/amplification and that they mature into post-mitotic neurons upon NeuroD1 expression.</Species>
<Species>In mice lacking Ngn2, we found the cells expressing GFP localized to the malformed ventral blade of the DG (Figure 5F and G).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>All of these cells were Ki67+</Species>

<Species>and they only very rarely expressed PH3 (Figure 5F and G, and figure S4C) in the absence of Ngn2 most of the cells are arrested in the cell cycle prior to entering the M phase and their mitosis is impaired.</Species>
<Species>These data suggest that the mechanism of action of Ngn2 is conserved from development of the DG to postnatal hippocampal neurogenesis.</Species>
<Species>Our findings suggest that Ngn2 regulates amplification and cell cycle exit of DG granule progenitors.</Species>

<Species>To examine this hypothesis, we compared the effects of Ngn2 and NeuroD1 on mitotic activity in embryonic cortico-hippocampal neurosphere-derived progenitors, 5 days upon transduction, in vitro.</Species>
<Species>In cultures transduced with Ngn2 retrovirus, we found that 27.2% (+4.1%) of the PH3+ cells had been transduced (Figure I1-J).</Species>
<Species>These cells were immunopositive for MAP2 (Figure 5I1 and I2) and therefore represented dividing neuroblasts.</Species>
<Species>By contrast, in NeuroD1 transduced cultures, only 7.3% of PH3+ cells were GFP+ (Figure 5H1, H2 and J).</Species>
<Species>All of the NeuroD1-transduced cells became MAP2+</Species>
<Species>(Figure 5H).</Species>
<Species>To confirm this data we pulse-labeled transduced cultures with chlorodeoxyuridine (CldU) for 48 hours, five days after differentiation.</Species>
<Species>In contrast to NeuroD1-transduced cultures, we observed dividing cells transduced with Ngn2 retrovirus that were positive for PH3 and that had incorporated CldU (Figure 5K-L2).</Species>
<Species>As the number of cells PH3+/CldU+/GFP+ we observed was low, we did not quantify this finding.</Species>
<Species>Collectively, we have shown that Ngn2 is required for granule neuroblast production and amplification and that in the absence of Ngn2 the progenitors arrest in the cell cycle.</Species>
<Species>NeuroD1, on the other hand, induces cell cycle exit and promotes rapid neuronal maturation.</Species>

<Species>NeuroD1 directs neuronal differentiation and maturation Based on our previous observations we proposed that Ngn2 primarily controls amplification of granule neuroblasts and NeuroD1 directs neuronal differentiation.</Species>
<Species>To test this hypothesis, we overexpressed Ngn2 or NeuroD1 in E14.5 cortico-hippocampal neurospheres and compared their effects after 5 days of differentiation of the progenitors.</Species>
<Species>All cortico-hippocampal progenitors expressed Pax6 prior to differentiation (Figure S5).</Species>
<Species>After 5 days, both factors suppressed Pax6 and Sox2 (Figure S5, figure 6C) and induced expression of Tbr1, Map2, NeuroD1 and PSA-NCAM (Figure 6D and E).</Species>
<Species>Interestingly, all Ngn2-overexpressing cells co-expressed NeuroD1.</Species>
<Species>Based on these findings, we next explored whether Ngn2 overexpression induces NeuroD1 expression, and if NeuroD1 in turn directs neuronal differentiation.</Species>
<Species>We compared the effects of both transcription factors in progenitors that either do or do not normally express them.</Species>

<Species>Thus, we expressed Ngn2 in E14.5 neural progenitors isolated from three different brain regions: cortex/hippocampus, lateral ganglionic eminence (LGE) and ventral mesencephalon (VM).</Species>
<Species>Ngn2</Species>
<Species>expression in the developing forebrain is normally limited to the neocortex, and it does not appear in LGE tissue [29].</Species>
<Species>In the developing VM, both Ngn2 and NeuroD1 are expressed, but not when neural progenitors from this region are cultured in vitro</Species>
<Species>[30], [31].</Species>
<Species>In our experiments, cortico-hippocampal progenitors could differentiate into neurons, although they did not normally express NeuroD1 (Figure 6E).</Species>
<Species>When we overexpressed Ngn2 in VM and LGE progenitors, the cells started to express both NeuroD1 and PSA-NCAM (Figure 6F and G).</Species>
<Species>We then overexpressed NeuroD1 in the same types of cultured progenitors and found that the cells became immunoreactive for PSA-NCAM (Figure 6G and data not shown).</Species>
<Species>Thus, NeuroD1 is sufficient to direct neuronal differentiation in cortico-hippocampal-, LGE- and VM-derived progenitors.</Species>

<Species>Our results from in vitro cultures and the analysis of the DG of Ngn2 mutant animals collectively show the neuron-inducing effect of NeuroD1 in hippocampal granule cell progenitors [32].</Species>

<Species>NeuroD1 directs exclusive neuronal differentiation of hippocampal granule neuron progenitors As the next step, we tested the effects of NeuroD1 in vivo and compared them with those of Ngn2.</Species>
<Species>We injected retroviruses carrying the gene for either Ngn2</Species>
<Species>[33] or NeuroD1, and the reporter gene eGFP into the ventricles E15.5 rat embryos, in utero (Figure 7A).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Three weeks later, when the rats were about two weeks old, we examined their hippocampi and analyzed the eGFP+ cells.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The rats injected with control vector exhibited eGFP+ cells within the hippocampus that were either star-shaped, progenitor/glial-like cells (14.8+3.4%) or neuron-like cells with long neurites (85.3+3.4%) (Figure 7B).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In rats that we had injected with the vector encoding Ngn2, the eGFP-labeled, the transduced hippocampal cells were composed of 31.9% (+5.7%) progenitor/glia-like cells and 69.4% (+6.1%) neuron-like cells (Figure 7B).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The glia-like subpopulation was immunopositive for the astrocytic marker GFAP (Figure 7C-D).</Species>
<Species>In contrast, virtually all of the transduced cells in rats injected with the NeuroD1 vector became neuron-like cells (99.9%+0.1; Figure 7B).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>None of these cells stained for GFAP (Figure 7E and F).</Species>
<Species>They were positioned in the external layers of both the ventral and dorsal blades of the DG (Figure 7B3, E and I and figure S6A).</Species>

<Species>When we examined neuronal maturation of Ngn2- and NeuroD1-transduced cells, we observed that only a few of those transduced with the NeuroD1 vector expressed the early mature neuronal marker Tbr1 (3.1+1.4%; Figure 7I and J).</Species>
<Species>They were located within the basal layers, near the SGL, of the ventral and dorsal blades of the DG.</Species>

<Species>In contrast, a greater proportion of the cells transduced with Ngn2 still expressed Tbr1 (19.6%+3.3%; Figure 7H and J), indicating that they were less mature than the vast majority of the NeuroD1-transduced cells.</Species>
<Species>Immunohistochemistry for NeuN confirmed these data (Figure 7M and O, and figure S6A).</Species>
<Species>Indeed, when we overexpressed Ngn2 the proportion of hippocampal progenitors that became NeuN+ was no greater than in rats transduced with the control virus (Figure 7F).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>As a whole, our in utero injection experiments confirm that NeuroD1 has a stronger neuron-inducing effect than Ngn2 when overexpressed in hippocampal progenitors.</Species>

<Species>Involvement of Mash1, Ngn2, Tbr and NeuroD proteins during human hippocampal neurogenesis Finally, we examined whether the transcription factors and cellular markers that are expressed in rodents are also expressed in human hippocampus.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>We performed immunohistochemistry on aged human hippocampal DG and found GFAP-, Sox2-, Pax6-, Nestin-, Prox1- and NeuN-immunopositive cells.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>This indicates that radial glia-like stem cells, neural progenitors and mature granule neurons are present in the aged human hippocampus (Figure 8A-E).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>While Prox1 is found mainly in granule neurons, Sox2 and Pax6 are exclusively localized to cells in the SGZ (Figure 8D and E).</Species>
<Species>As for aged rodents, we did not observe the presence of Mash1, Ngn2, Tbr2, Tbr1 and NeuroD1 proteins in aged human hippocampus, using immunohistochemistry.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>However, we could identify the presence of the transcripts, using RT-PCR (Figure 8F).</Species>
<Species>In addition, we detected mRNA for Prox1, Calbindin1 and Calbindin2/Calretinin (Figure 8F).</Species>

<Species>Interestingly, we also observed Sonic Hedgehog and Wnt-3A transcripts, indicating that they are present in the human DG and supporting previous claims that they are important for the regulation of adult hippocampal neurogenesis (Figure 8F;</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>[34], [35]).</Species>

<Species>Finally, we also found mRNA for GLAST, Pax6 and GFAP which suggests that radial glia-like stem cells are present in the adult human hippocampus, and may play a role in adult human hippocampal neurogenesis (Figure 8F;</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>[8]).</Species>
<Species>Overall, our data show that different proteins known to play key roles in rodent hippocampal granule neurogenesis are present in the adult human hippocampus.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Discussion In this study we determine the functions of Ngn2 and NeuroD1 during hippocampal neurogenesis.</Species>
<Species>First, we map the hierarchy of molecular markers of neurogenesis in the DG.</Species>
<Species>Second, we describe that Ngn2 is necessary for granule progenitor production/amplification.</Species>
<Species>Third, we demonstrate that NeuroD1 directs neuronal differentiation of granule progenitors.</Species>
<Species>Finally, we show that different cellular markers expressed during hippocampal neurogenesis in rodents are present in human.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Sequential expression of different transcription factors and cellular markers during hippocampal neurogenesis We clarified the pattern of expression of various markers expressed during postnatal and adult hippocampal granule neurogenesis in detail.</Species>
<Species>We found that the transcription factor Pax6 is initially expressed by both radial glia stem cells (type-1) and early amplifying progenitors (type-2a).</Species>
<Species>The next transcription factor to appear in chronology is Mash1.</Species>
<Species>Mash1 expression characterizes the early stage of hippocampal progenitor amplification (early type-2a).</Species>
<Species>The role of Mash1 during hippocampal granule neurogenesis is still unclear.</Species>
<Species>Mash1 null mutant mice do not display any clear malformation of the DG [20].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>However, overexpression of Mash1 alone in the DG leads to the generation of oligodendrocytes [36].</Species>
<Species>Based on these observations, we hypothesize that Mash1-expressing cells are not yet committed towards a granule cell fate.</Species>
<Species>They may still have the potential to generate both neurons and oligodendrocytes, as is the case in the SVZ [37].</Species>

<Species>In agreement with different developing brain regions, we found that Ngn2 starts to be expressed in Mash1-positive transiently amplifying progenitors, i.e.    late type-2a cells    according to the classification we propose.</Species>
<Species>We observed that Pax6 expression persisted longer than that of Mash1, in Ngn2-expressing cells (late type-2a cells), in juvenile but not adult DG (Fig. 1 and figure S1).</Species>
<Species>Later on, Ngn2 is downregulated, whilst Tbr2 expression persists (type-2b cells).</Species>
<Species>The transition from amplifying progenitor to neuroblast is defined by the expression of NeuroD1.</Species>
<Species>Thus, Ngn2 is expressed at the beginning of the transiently amplifying progenitor phase while NeuroD1 marks the end of that period.</Species>
<Species>This applies both to the juvenile and adult rat brain [21], [25].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>After NeuroD1 is turned on the progenitors leave the cell cycle, gradually mature, express PSA-NCAM, NeuroD2, Calretinin, Prox1, Tbr1 and, finally, NeuN. NeuroD1 expression persists at low levels in mature neurons (Figure 9;</Species>
<Species>[10]).</Species>
<Species>We found the sequential expression of these markers conserved in juvenile (P2 and 2 weeks) and adult rodent brains.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Importantly, we observed that the same transcription factors and neuronal markers are also present in the adult human hippocampus and arranged spatially in a manner reminiscent with what we saw in rodents.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>It is possible, however, that some of these markers are expressed for longer or shorter periods at postnatal and adult stages of hippocampal progenitor maturation.</Species>
<Species>Moreover, one can ask to which extent the number of divisions occurring during neuroblasts maturation is conserved at postnatal and adult stages of neurogenesis.</Species>

<Species>A new function for Ngn2 in maintenance of a progenitor state for granule neuron production/amplification during embryonic and postnatal hippocampal neurogenesis In agreement with earlier work, we confirm that Ngn2 is indispensable for hippocampal development and plays a vital role in postnatal hippocampal granule neurogenesis.</Species>
<Species>Ngn2 null mutant animals display a reduced size of the cornu ammonis and a malformed DG (Figure 3 and 4; [20]).</Species>
<Species>We show that the number of newborn neurons (incorporated BrdU) is decreased in absence of Ngn2, but hippocampal granule neuron subtype specification is not affected, post-nataly.</Species>
<Species>Likewise, neurons from other brain regions, e.g. ventral midbrain dopamine neurons, can be generated in the absence of Ngn2</Species>
<Species>[30], [31].</Species>
<Species>The reduced numbers of mature neurons in the hippocampus and ventral midbrain of Ngn2 null mutant animals does not appear to be due to cell death or migration defects [20], [31].</Species>
<Species>Instead it may be due to a defect in the generation and/or amplification of neuronal progenitors.</Species>
<Species>Indeed, in the hippocampus of postnatal animals, we observed that cells lacking Ngn2 arrest in the cell cycle, maintain Pax6 expression and cease to proliferate.</Species>

<Species>When overexpressed in neural progenitors in vitro, Ngn2 lead to up-regulation of NeuroD1 and caused neuronal differentiation (Figure 6), which was not always the case when we overexpressed the same factor in vivo (Figure 7L, N and O).</Species>
<Species>We also saw that Ngn2 does not always efficiently induce cell cycle exit.</Species>

<Species>Typically some mitotically active eGFP+ cells were present in the DG of rats injected with the Ngn2 retrovirus (Figure 7P), and we observed that cultured Ngn2-transduced cells are still capable of dividing.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Thus, Ngn2 does not always promote cell cycle exit and neuronal commitment, but depending on the state of the cells, Ngn2 may instead promote alternate cellular fates [38]-[40].</Species>
<Species>Indeed, an earlier study has shown that Ngn2-overexpressing progenitors generate oligodendrocytes when grafted to the adult spinal cord [40].</Species>
<Species>We have also seen that Ngn2-overexpressing neural progenitors from the embryonic midbrain form astrocytes when grafted to the striatum (unpublished observations).</Species>
<Species>Probably, Ngn2 cannot influence already committed cells, but rather would control neuroblasts production.</Species>
<Species>One could speculate that Ngn2 oscillates during granule neuron formation, as recently demonstrated during neocorticogenesis [41], [42].</Species>

<Species>NeuroD1, but not Ngn2, is obligatory for granule neuron progenitor differentiation Hippocampal granule progenitors can mature and express Tbr1 and Prox1, both during the development and postnatally, even in the absence of Ngn2.</Species>
<Species>Because neuronal differentiation still occurs in Ngn2 null mice, it is clear that compensatory, Ngn2-independent mechanisms induce NeuroD1 expression.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>One candidate is Ngn1, which is expressed during neocorticogenesis, the specification of olfactory sensory neurons and during embryonic rat hippocampal development [43]-[47].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Both Ngn1 and Ngn2 regulate NeuroD1</Species>
<Species>[19], [48].</Species>

<Species>The introduction of two mutant forms of Ngn1, a deletion of the basic region of Ngn1 and a substitution of two amino acids in the C-terminal basic region, prevents NeuroD1 expression and neuronal differentiation [48].</Species>
<Species>The double null Ngn1/Ngn2 mutant displays a more severe phenotype than single gene (Ngn1 or Ngn2) mutant mice.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>For example, the total brain size of the double mutants is much smaller</Species>
<Species>[10], [32].</Species>

<Species>If the role of Ngn1 during hippocampal neurogenesis is to activate NeuroD1 and that of Ngn2 is to control granule neuroblasts production/amplification, the DG of double Ngn1/Ngn2 knockout mice should resemble that of NeuroD1 null mutant mice.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>We demonstrated that NeuroD1 directs neuronal differentiation both in vitro and in vivo.</Species>
<Species>In progenitors isolated from different embryonic brain regions and cultured in vitro, we found that overexpression of NeuroD1 induced neuronal differentiation.</Species>
<Species>The neurons generated expressed PSA-NCAM, Dcx and MAP2.</Species>
<Species>After in utero retroviral vector-mediated gene delivery, virtually all cells transduced with NeuroD1 became neurons.</Species>
<Species>In contrast, progenitors transduced with Ngn2 or control retroviruses adopted a neuron-like morphology in only 70-85% of cases.</Species>
<Species>Under in vitro cell culture conditions, when we overexpressed Ngn2 in progenitors derived from the LGE we observed robust expression of NeuroD1 and neuronal differentiation.</Species>
<Species>These in vitro results differ from those we obtained when we transduced the embryonic brain with a viral vector expressing Ngn2.</Species>
<Species>In this latter case, Ngn2 did not induce neurons and the transduced cells did not express NeuroD1.</Species>
<Species>Therefore, Ngn2 appears to direct non-neuronal cell type specification in vivo [38]-[40].</Species>
<Species>Taken together, we have confirmed that NeuroD1 plays a key role in neuronal differentiation in the hippocampus, both during development and in the adult brain.</Species>
<Species>Concluding remark We present a detailed classification of different stages in hippocampal neurogenesis.</Species>

<Species>Our detailed molecular mapping of hippocampal neurogenesis allows for a more accurate analysis of how new factors stimulate neurogenesis at different steps in the development of granule neurons.</Species>
<Species>Thereby we hope to facilitate the development of new agents, which stimulate endogenous progenitors in the treatment of diseases.</Species>
<Species>Materials and Methods Animal tissue preparation</Species>
<Species>The creation of the Ngn2 transgenic mice was reported elsewhere (ref guillemot).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Heterozygote male and female mice were crossed to obtain WT, heterozygote (Ngn2+/GFP) and null mutant (Ngn2GFP/GFP) animals.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Tails of the Ngn2 offspring were used to obtain DNA for determination of the genotype using a polymerase chain reaction (PCR) assay as previously reported [31].</Species>

<Species>As null mutant Ngn2GFP/GFP do not survive longer than 2.5-3 weeks after birth, Ngn2GFP/GFP and their littermates were sacrificed at the postnatal ages of two days (P2) or two weeks for this study.</Species>
<Species>Neurogenesis was assessed in two weeks or two months old WT mice.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Sprague Dawley pregnant rats were ordered from B&K Universal Ltd, Sollentuna, Sweden (hppt://www.bku.com).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>All animals were housed in groups with ad libitum access to food and water at a 12-h light/dark cycle.</Species>
<Species>All experimental procedures conducted in this study had been approved by the Ethical Committee at Lund University.</Species>

<Species>For immunohistochemical analysis, mice (from two weeks old and adult stage) and juvenile rats were sacrificed by transcardial perfusion with saline for 5-10 minutes, followed by 4% paraformaldehyde (PFA) for 10 minutes.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Brains were kept in PFA overnight at 4oC and subsequently cryopreserved in a 20-30% sucrose/0.1 M phosphate buffer solution until sectioning on a microtome apparatus (30 um thickness sections, Microm Zeiss).</Species>
<Species>Seven series of coronal sections were cut throughout the brain.</Species>
<Species>Free-floating sections were preserved in antifreeze solution until immunohistochemistry was performed.</Species>

<Species>Heads of postanatal two days old mice were decapitated and soaked in PFA 4% for 24 hours, at 4oC and transferred into sucrose solution until sectioning on cryostat apparatus (16 um thickness; Leica CM3000).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Sections were mounted on Superfrost glass slides and stored at    80oC until immunohistochemistry was performed.</Species>

<Species>Cloning, subcloning, virus production and titer measurement The Moloney leukemia-derived retroviral vectors used in this study, pCMMP-IRES2eGFP-WPRE and pCMMP-Ngn2-IRES2eGFP-WPRE were previously described [40], [49].</Species>

<Species>To generate the construct pCMMP-NeuroD1-IRES2eGFP-WPRE, mouse NeuroD1 cDNA was amplified from a pCS2+mtNeuroD1 plasmid (kindly provided by Professor Jackie Lee, Denver university, Boulder, USA) by PCR to introduce the restriction sites PmeI in 5    and XhoI in 3   .</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Amplification of cDNA was performed as previously described [49].</Species>
<Species>The construction was verified by enzymatic restriction and by DNA sequencing using BigDye 3.1 (ABI).</Species>
<Species>All infectious particles were produced using the producer cell line 293VSV-G and as previously described [49].</Species>

<Species>The titer of each retrovirus was measured by flow-cytometry based on eGFP expression, four days following infection of HT1080 cells and ranged from 0.5x109   2.1x109 TU/ml (All details on how to produce infectious particles can be provided upon request).</Species>

<Species>Neurosphere generation, transduction and differentiation Pregnant female Sprague-Dawley rats (B & K Universal, Sollentuna, Sweden) were terminally anesthetized by an overdose of sodium pentobarbital (i.p., 60 ng/ml).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Embryos at stage embryonic day E14.5 (Plug day as day 0) were collected and cortical-hippocampal neurospheres were generated following dissection of the dorso-posterior part of the cortical tissue, and generated as previously described [49].</Species>
<Species>In this study, second passage (P2) neurospheres were used to study the effect of the overexpression of Ngn2 and NeuroD1 on neuronal differentiation.</Species>

<Species>Each well, containing an equal starting population of 200,000 cells/ml, corresponding to 15-25 neurospheres, was transduced independently with each retrovirus at a multiplicity of infection (MOI) of 1, in proliferation medium supplemented by protamine-sulfate (4 mg/ml, Sigma).</Species>
<Species>To induce differentiation, the medium was replaced with normal basic differentiation medium two days post-transduction and subsequently changed every other day until fixation.</Species>
<Species>Immunocytochemistry, immunohistochemistry and microscopy The antibodies used in this study are: rabbit anti-GFAP (1   1000; DAKO), mouse anti-Nestin (1   100; BD PharMingen),</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>guinea pig anti-Glast (1   500; Chemicon), rabbit anti-Prox1 (1   1000; Covance), goat anti-Ngn2</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The remainder of the procedure was performed as previously described [49].</Species>

<Species>Specimen analyses were performed using a Leica confocal microscope (Leica software, equipped with a GreNe and a HeNe laser, using the following lines of excitation: 488 nm, 594 nm and 647 nm).</Species>
<Species>Samples were analyzed using 20x, 40x and 63x objectives, sometimes zoomed.</Species>
<Species>Figures were composed in CANVAS-X software.</Species>

<Species>Bromo-deoxyuridine (BrdU) and Cloro-deoxyuridine (CldU) pulse labeling and immunohisto- and immunocyto-chemistry To assess cell proliferation and ongoing neurogenesis in vivo, animals were injected with BrdU (100 mg/kg, Sigma), two hours prior to sacrifice (for both P2 and two weeks old Ngn2 mice).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>To assess neurogenesis, BrdU (100 mg/kg) was injected 48 hours prior to sacrifice (for P2 animals, BrdU was injected in pregnant dams half day prior to give birth).</Species>

<Species>Immunohistochemistry was carried on as described above using a rat anti-CldU/BrdU primary antibody (1   200, monoclonal, Immunologicalsdirect, Oxfordshire, UK), with an additional denaturation in 1 M HCl for 30 minutes prior to pre-incubation with serum.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>To assess the neuronal-inducing activity of Ngn2 and NeuroD1, transduced cultures were incubated with CldU (20 uM, Sigma) for 2 days, after a period of differentiation of five days.</Species>

<Species>For immunocytochemistry, cultures were fixed with 4% paraformaldehyde at day 7, rinsed with PBS three times, treated with 1 M HCl at 65oC for 5-10 min, pre-incubated and then incubated with a rat anti-CldU/BrdU antibody and other primary antibodies.</Species>

text: <Species>The remainder of the procedure was performed according to the protocol for immunohistochemistry already mentioned.</Species>
<Species>In utero surgery Timed pregnant female Sprague Dawley rats with embryos at gestational age E15.5 were anesthetized with halothane.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The mother was placed in the lower level of a two-level wooden stage.</Species>
<Species>The abdomen was shaved with an electric razor and then cleaned with 70% alcohol.</Species>
<Species>A 2-3 cm midline laparotomy was performed.</Species>
<Species>Each uterine horn was carefully taken out individually and the number of embryos recorded.</Species>
<Species>One horn was then placed back inside the mother, whilst the other horn was prepared for injection.</Species>
<Species>The embryos were kept moist with constant application of warm saline to prevent dehydration.</Species>
<Species>Approximately 2 ul of viral suspension (1x10   9TU/ml) was injected into the lateral ventricle of each embryo, except for the embryo closest to the vagina.</Species>
<Species>After the injections, the uterine horns were placed back into the abdomen.</Species>
<Species>The abdominal wall and the overlying skin were then sutured.</Species>
<Species>Care was taken not to damage abdominal muscles so that normal delivery of the pups was possible at term.</Species>
<Species>The entire surgery generally took about 45 minutes to one hour.</Species>
<Species>Each mother was allowed to recover in her cage before being returned to the animal stable.</Species>
<Species>Shredded paper was added to each cage to encourage nesting and special care was taken not to stress the mothers.</Species>
<Species>Following normal delivery, the pups were allowed to develop to adulthood up to two weeks.</Species>
<Species>Quantification For the in vivo experiment, manual cell counting was performed on 18 and 30 um thick brain sections for two days and two weeks old animals, respectively.</Species>
<Species>The brain of P2 animals was cut into 10 series of coronal sections; the brain of two-weeks old animals was cut into 7-8 series of coronal sections.</Species>

<Species>For each staining, one-two series from three to five different individuals were analyzed per genotype using a confocal microscope with 1, 2 or 3 lines of excitation, in sequential scanning in order to avoid false positives.</Species>
<Species>When two series were analyzed, only one series was counted.</Species>
<Species>The mean number of cells per hippocampus expressing the markers of interest, was calculated for each brain, based on the analysis of 6-8 consecutive dorsal hippocampal sections.</Species>
<Species>The final mean number of cells per section was calculated by adding the mean number from each individual.</Species>
<Species>We expressed the data as the mean number of positive cells+standard error of the mean (SEM).</Species>
<Species>In this study, more than 25 Ngn2 null, >45 Ngn2 heterozygotes, and >60 WT individuals (including rats injected with retroviruses) were analyzed, in total.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Statistical comparison was performed using one-factor analysis of variance (ANOVA) with transcription factor, cellular marker, genotype or time as variables, followed by post-hoc analysis when significant differences were observed, using Statview 5.0 software (SAS institute Inc.).</Species>
<Species>For cell culture experiments, three independent experiments were performed, each in duplicate.</Species>
<Species>The counting was based on seven randomly chosen different fields of view.</Species>
<Species>For each diagram, the level of significance (p-value) is represented as follows: P<0.05 = *; P<0.001 = **; P<0.0001 = ***.</Species>
<Species>All data are expressed as+standard error of the mean (SEM).</Species>
<Species>Human sample and RT-PCR The brain from a 64 year-old male was provided by the Harvard Brain Tissue Resource Center.</Species>

text: <Species>The frozen tissue block was cut into 20 series of coronal sections, using a cryostat.</Species>
<Species>Every 10 sections, one section was placed in an Eppendorf tube, on dry ice.</Species>
<Species>Pooled sections were used for RT-PCR.</Species>
<Species>Total RNA was prepared using Trizol and RNAeasy, supplemented with RNAGuard as previously described [49].</Species>
<Species>The RNA was digested with shrimp DNAse before cDNA synthesis, which was performed using a mix of oligo-dT and random hexamer primers and SuperscriptII reverse transcriptase.</Species>

<Species>Advantage2 polymerase mix (Clontech/BRL) was used for PCR, with the following cycling conditions: 10 cycles of 94o C for 30 seconds, 68oC for 2 minutes, 30 cycles of 94oC for 30 seconds, 60oC for 1 minute, 68oC for 1 minute and 30 seconds, one cycle of 68o C for 2 minutes, soak at 16oC. Primers marked * were designed by PrimerBank.</Species>
