label: Species

text: <Species>We have analyzed the formation of foamy macrophages (FMs), a granuloma-specific cell population characterized by its high lipid content, and studied their interaction with the tubercle bacillus.</Species>

<Species>Within our in vitro human granuloma model, M. tuberculosis long chain fatty acids, namely oxygenated mycolic acids (MA), triggered the differentiation of human monocyte-derived macrophages into FMs.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>In these cells, mycobacteria no longer replicated and switched to a dormant non-replicative state.</Species>

<Species>Electron microscopy observation of M. tuberculosis-infected FMs showed that the mycobacteria-containing phagosomes migrate towards host cell lipid bodies (LB), a process which culminates with the engulfment of the bacillus into the lipid droplets and with the accumulation of lipids within the microbe.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Altogether, our results suggest that oxygenated mycolic acids from M. tuberculosis play a crucial role in the differentiation of macrophages into FMs.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>These cells might constitute a reservoir used by the tubercle bacillus for long-term persistence within its human host, and could provide a relevant model for the screening of new antimicrobials against non-replicating persistent mycobacteria.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Introduction Tuberculosis caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis (M.tb) remains one of the leading causes of mortality in the world, with around 2 million deaths each year [1].</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Most individuals remain asymptomatic after the primary infection with only 10% at risk of developing an active disease during their life [2].</Species>
<Species>In asymptomatic individuals, the bacilli are not cleared but rather persist in a dormant state, from which they may reactivate and induce clinical disease at later stages [3].</Species>
<Species>The prognosis of the disease depends on the host's efficiency to constrain the bacilli at the site of infection.</Species>
<Species>When inhaled M.tb reach the lungs, they are internalized by lung macrophages.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The latter trigger the accumulation at the infectious site of macrophages, lymphocytes and dendritic cells, to form a granuloma, which is a major histo-pathological feature of TB.</Species>
<Species>Within granulomas, macrophages differentiate into epithelioid cells (differentiated macrophages), and/or fuse to form multinucleated giant cells (MGC).</Species>

<Species>Macrophages with large numbers of lipid-free vacuoles, as well as macrophages filled with lipid-containing bodies, also called foamy macrophages (FM) are also found within granulomatous structures in both experimental animal models and human disease [4],[5].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The above cells are surrounded by a rim of lymphocytes, and at later stages, a tight coat of fibroblasts encloses the structure [6].</Species>

<Species>Although the structure and cell composition of granulomas are well known, the biology of these inflammatory structures and, more specifically, the role of granuloma-specific cell types, remain largely unknown.</Species>
<Species>We have previously developed an in vitro model of human tuberculous granulomas to gain insight into the survival strategies of the tubercle bacillus within its human host.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>This model now enables the characterization of granuloma-specific cell types, and their modulation by M.tb [7].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The main advantage of this model over in vivo animal models or ex vivo human biopsy samples, is the availability of live granuloma cells which facilitates analysis of their cell biology.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Using this model we have recently shown that, within granulomas, large multinucleated giant cells, also known as Langhans giant cells, result from the induction of granuloma macrophage fusion by M.tb glycolipids [8].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We have shown that these cells have lost the ability to mediate bacterial uptake upon maturation, but have conserved their ability to mediate antigen presentation [9].</Species>
<Species>The differentiation of macrophages into FMs has been particularly well described in individuals developing a postprimary, also known as secondary or adult, TB.</Species>
<Species>These postprimary infections are considered to be the result of re-infection or reactivation of a primary TB [10].</Species>
<Species>FMs have been described in leprosy patients or M. avium-infected AIDS (Acquired ImmunoDeficiency Syndrome) patients, and in chronic stages of M.tb infection in mice [4],[11],[12].</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>The foamy aspect of these macrophages is the result of intracellular lipid accumulation within lipid bodies, also called lipid droplets or lipid vacuoles [13],[14],[15].</Species>

<Species>In an experimental model of leukocyte infection, it was recently suggested that BCG (Bacille Calmette Guerin) infection can induce, in a TLR2-dependent fashion, the rapid formation of lipid bodies carrying out part of the eicosanoid biosynthesis that usually accompanies the infection, thus pointing to an active role for lipid bodies during the course of infection [16].</Species>
<Species>However, the mechanisms regulating this lipid accumulation during mycobacterial infection and their significance in the physiopathology of tuberculosis are not understood.</Species>

<Species>Most of the studies on TB granulomas have focused on the contribution of host components, but very little is known about the role played by bacterial constituents in terms of granuloma formation and progression.</Species>
<Species>The present work was aimed at deciphering the role of FMs in M.tb survival within human granulomas.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>To test our working hypothesis according to which FMs constitute a nutrient-rich reservoir for M.tb persistence, we used our in vitro model of human granulomas to analyze the formation of FMs and their role during M.tb infection.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>We showed that only highly virulent mycobacteria (M.tb, M. avium) and not saprophytic ones (M. smegmatis) could induce the formation of FMs in mature granulomas.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Moreover, we demonstrated that oxygenated mycolic acids specifically produced by the above pathogenic species were responsible for FMs formation.</Species>
<Species>Once differentiated, FMs were unable to mediate phagocytosis of new bacilli and their microbicidal activity was reduced.</Species>
<Species>M.tb was not killed in FMs but instead persisted in a non-replicating state, and over-expressed dormancy genes.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Noteworthy, in foamy macrophages, M.tb-containing phagosomes were shown to migrate towards lipid bodies which they progressively surrounded and engulfed.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>As a result, bacteria were freed into lipid bodies, thus favoring the bacilli's access to nutrients.</Species>
<Species>From these data, we propose that FMs could form a secure reservoir for the tubercle bacilli.</Species>

<Species>Methods Human samples Human blood samples, purchased from the French National Blood provider of Toulouse, were collected from fully anonymized non-tuberculous control donors, an ethical committee approval was, therefore, not necessary.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>This study was conducted according to the principles expressed in the Helsinki Declaration, with informed consent obtained from each donor.</Species>
<Species>We chose to work on lymph node samples rather than lung biopsies, which are usually only paraffin-embedded, because staining for lipids can only be performed on frozen samples.</Species>
<Species>Lymph node biopsies were taken for diagnosis purposes, in ten non-HIV patients.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>For each biopsy, a fragment was sent to the microbiology laboratory, another was frozen in liquid nitrogen and the main part was fixed in formalin and paraffin-embedded for histological examination.</Species>
<Species>M.tb was identified in 9 lymph node biopsies and from the lung aspiration in the last patient.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>This latter case showed no signs of necrosis, and no FMs were found in the lymph node biopsy.</Species>
<Species>This study complies with the guidelines of the declaration of Helsinki.</Species>

<Species>Bacterial strains and culture conditions Wild-type M. smegmatis and M. smegmatis/hma strains were previously described [17], M. tuberculosis-GFP were a kind gift from Dr. C. Guilhot (CNRS-IPBS, Toulouse France).</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Bacilli were grown in Middlebrook 7H9 medium (Difco) supplemented with 10% albumin-dextrose-catalase (Difco).</Species>
<Species>Fluorescent M. smegmatis and M. smegmatis/hma were obtained by FITC labelling as described in [18].</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Isolation of RNA from intraphagosomal M.tb Six and 12 days post-infection (MOI 10), macrophages and FMs (5x106) were washed twice with PBS, scraped off the cell dishes and recovered by centrifugation.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The cell pellets were lysed with lysis buffer (RNEasy mini kit, Quiagen) and transferred to 2 ml Eppendorf-tubes containing a 0.5 ml suspension of 0.1 mm-diameter glass beads (Biospec).</Species>

<Species>Mycobacteria were disrupted using a bead beater (Retsch) followed by a 5 min centrifugation at 14 000g. RNA contained in the supernatant was then column-purified according to the manufacturer's conditions using the RNEasy mini kit (Qiagen) and quantified.</Species>
<Species>Quantitative Real-Time RT-PCR In RNA samples DNA contamination was excluded by DNAse I treatment (Ambion).</Species>
<Species>1 ug total RNA was reverse-transcribed using random hexamer primers (Ambion) and Superscript III reverse transcriptase (Invitrogen).</Species>
<Species>Real-time PCR was performed on cDNA using the SYBR green essay (Applied Biosystems).</Species>
<Species>Reverse and forward primers used are listed below in Table 1.</Species>
<Species>Fluorescence was measured by ABIPrism 7300 (Applied Biosystems).</Species>

<Species>The calculated threshold cycle (Ct) value for each gene of interest was normalized to the Ct value for 16S and the fold expression was calculated using the formula: fold change = 2   D.(DCt)</Species>
<Species>[19].</Species>
<Species>Real-time PCR conditions include initial activation at 94oC for 5 min, followed by 40 cycles of denaturation at 94oC for 30 sec, annealing and extension at 65oC for 1 min.</Species>
<Species>The gene induction ratios were obtained by comparing gene expression levels in intracellular bacilli with those of log-phase in vitro-grown bacilli.</Species>
<Species>RNAs were isolated from two independent macrophage infections.</Species>
<Species>In vitro human granuloma formation In vitro granulomas were obtained as previously described [7].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Briefly, 1x106 freshly isolated Peripheral Blood Mononuclear Cells (PBMCs) were incubated with 1x104 viable M.tb, or 1x103 viable M. smegmatis or M. smegmatis/hma.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>The culture medium was RPMI-1640+Glutamax (Difco), containing 7.5% human AB serum (Sigma-Aldrich).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Macrophage differentiation 2.5x106</Species>
<Species>PBMCs prepared in RPMI-1640+Glutamax (Difco) were plated over coverslips in 24-well plates.</Species>
<Species>After 2 h culture at 37oC, cells were washed 3 times with PBS and then refed with RPMI-1640+Glutamax (Difco), containing 7.5% human AB serum.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>After 6 days of culturing, macrophages were differentiated.</Species>
<Species>Respiratory burst assay with Nitroblue tetrazolium (NBT)</Species>
<Species>Human monocyte derived macrophages were stimulated with M. smegmatis/hma for 2 h at 37oC, washed and reincubated in mycobacterium-free medium.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>After 2 days of differentiation into FMs, macrophages were co-stained with NBT (2 mg/ml Sigma-Aldrich) and Nile red (Sigma-Aldrich) for 30 min at 37oC. Stained cells were fixed and then analysed with an inverted microscope (Nikon TE 300).</Species>

<Species>Phagocytosis and Survival test For phagocytosis assays, differentiated macrophages were incubated with M. smegmatis/hma mycolic acids for 2 days and then infected with 1x108 labeled mycobacteria per well for 90 min, washed 3 times with PBS and chased for 3 h in fresh culture medium.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>For survival experiments, macrophages were infected with M. tuberculosis-GFP (10 bacteria/cell), washed 3 times with PBS (Gibco) and re-incubated in fresh culture medium.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>At selected time points thereafter (1, 3, 6, 10 and 14 days) cells were labeled with Nile red (Sigma-Aldrich), fixed and observed under a confocal microscope.</Species>
<Species>The amount of mycobacteria per cells was evaluated.</Species>
<Species>(100 cells were analyzed for each time point).</Species>

<Species>Lipid body staining and immunostaining Granuloma cells were collected and plated onto glass coverslips with a cytospin (Thermo Shandon) fixed for 30 min in PBS-PFA 4% and stained with Oil red-O (Sigma-Aldrich) as described [20].</Species>
<Species>The slides were then counterstained with haematoxylin (Dako Cytomation) and observed under an inverted microscope (Nikon TE 300).</Species>

<Species>For fluorescence analysis, granuloma cells or macrophages were collected in PBS, lipid bodies were stained with Nile red (Sigma-Aldrich, 0.1 ug/ml, from a stock solution in methanol) for 15 min washed with PBS, fixed for 30 min in PBS-PFA 4%, mounted with the fluorescent mounting medium (Dako Cytomation) and observed under a confocal microscope.</Species>

<Species>In order to distinguish the lipids contained within lipid bodies, from those of the cell membrane, we used the fluorescent emission spectrum properties of Nile red which depend upon the kind of lipid associated with Nile red, i.e. for triacylglycerol: rmax em = 590 nm, for phospholipids: rmax em =</Species>
<Species>640 nm (Molecular Probes handbook).</Species>
<Species>On confocal microscopy pictures, the phospholipid background of both macrophages and FM appears in red and the triacylglycerol-rich lipid bodies appear in white.</Species>
<Species>Cells were considered to be positive for Nile red staining when more than 50% of the cell surface was stained (see Figure S2).</Species>

<Species>Mycolic acid isolation Bacterial residues obtained after lipid extraction with organic solvents [17] were saponified with a mixture of 40% KOH aqueous solution and methoxyethanol (1   7, v/v) at 110oC for 3 hours in a screw-capped tube.</Species>

<Species>After acidification, fatty acids were extracted with diethylether, derivatised into methyl esters with diazomethane and analyzed by analytical thin-layer chromatography on silica Gel 60 (Silica Gel 60 Macherey-Nagel) using either dicholoromethane or petroleum ether/diethylether (9   1, v/v, five runs).</Species>
<Species>Visualization of lipid spots was performed by spraying the plates with molybdophosphoric acid (10% in ethanol), followed by charring.</Species>

<Species>Processing for electron microscopy Granulomas were fixed for 1 hour at room temperature with 2.5% glutaraldehyde in 0.1 M cacodylate buffer, pH 7.2, containing 0.1 M sucrose, 5 mM CaCl2 and 5 mM MgCl2.</Species>

<Species>After two successive 15-min washes with the same buffer, the granulomas were postfixed for 1 hour at RT with 1% osmium tetroxide (Electron Microscopy Science) in the same buffer devoid of sucrose.</Species>
<Species>The granulomas were scraped off the culture dishes with a rubber policeman and concentrated in 1% agarose in the same buffer.</Species>
<Species>After a one hour treatment at room temperature with 1% uranyl acetate in Veronal buffer, the samples were dehydrated in a graded series of ethanol and embedded in Spurr resin.</Species>
<Species>Thin sections were stained with uranyl acetate and lead citrate.</Species>
<Species>Image acquisition in confocal microscopy The images were obtained using a Leica confocal fluorescence microscope (SP2) equipped with a Plan Apo</Species>
<Species>40x1.4 Ph 6 objective (Olympus Optical) and CoolSNAP-Pro CF digital camera in conjunction with Image-Pro Plus version 4.5.1.3 software (Media Cybernetics).</Species>
<Species>The images were edited using Adobe Photoshop CS2 9 software (Adobe Systems).</Species>

<Species>Results Foamy macrophages are strongly associated with necrotic lesions and often contain M. tuberculosis We analyzed lymph node biopsies from 10 tuberculous patients as a first step for evaluating the role of FMs within tuberculous granulomas.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>A section through a representative biopsy is shown in Figure 1.</Species>
<Species>Well-circumscribed and -differentiated granulomatous structures were observed in all the samples (Figure 1A).</Species>
<Species>Classically, lesions display a necrotic center (N), an interface area between the necrotic center and the histiocytes (I), and some peripheral granulomas (G).</Species>
<Species>Only seven out of ten patients presented lesions displaying central necrosis (Table 2).</Species>

<Species>Staining of the histology samples with Oil red-O, a classic lipid stain, confirmed the presence of FMs within the granulomatous structures in six out of seven samples presenting necrosis (Figure 1B), whereas no FMs were found in the three non-necrotic lesions (Table 2).</Species>
<Species>Noteworthy, in samples with necrotic areas, FMs were always found in the interface region flanking the central necrosis (Figure 1B).</Species>

<Species>These observations firstly confirmed the presence of FMs in most TB patients' lesions thereby suggesting that these cells play an important role in the formation/maintenance of such lesions.</Species>

<Species>Second, FMs seem to be associated with necrosis, which is a hallmark of TB lesions, since they were observed only in lesions with a necrotic center and preferentially located around the necrotic area.</Species>

<Species>Interestingly, staining, in parallel, of serial thin sections from a patient's lesion biopsy with Oil red-O (Figure 1C) and Ziehl Nielsen (Figure 1D), showed that most of the bacilli (arrow) were located in the same area as FMs, thus suggesting a strong association between the persisting tubercle bacilli and FMs within granulomas.</Species>

<Species>M. tuberculosis induces the formation of FMs within in vitro human tuberculous granulomas To further characterize the role of FMs in the granulomatous response, we assessed whether FM formation in granulomatous structures was triggered only by pathogenic mycobacterial species (M.tb), or by low virulent ones (M. smegmatis) as well.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>PBMCs from non-tuberculous control individuals were infected with M.tb or M. smegmatis, following the procedure previously described for the induction of granulomatous structures ([7],[9] and Figure S1).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Granuloma cells collected at days 3 and 11 were stained with Oil red-O to visualize the lipid droplets within FMs under the light microscope (Figure 2).</Species>
<Species>At day 3, several M.tb-induced granuloma cells already showed lipid bodies (Figure 2A).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In contrast, the cells collected from M. smegmatis-induced granulomas were seldom (5%) positively stained (Figure 2B).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Interestingly, M. avium induced FM formation in a similar way to M.tb (not shown).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>By day 11, the amount of positively stained cells had increased in M.tb-induced granulomas, but not in M. smegmatis-induced ones.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>In addition, the number of lipid bodies per cell increased dramatically with time, as depited in the enlarged views (Figures 2A, C).</Species>

<Species>The quantitative evaluation of the percentage of FMs within granulomas induced by both strains confirmed the differences observed under the light microscope, and showed a seven-fold difference (44% vs 6% respectively) between M.tb and M. smegmatis in terms of their ability to induce FM formation (Figure 2D).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Our results therefore show that virulent species such as M.tb and M. avium, contrary to poorly or avirulent ones such as M. smegmatis, are able to induce the formation of FMs within our experimental model.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Oxygenated mycolic acids induce the maturation of macrophages into FMs Mycolic acids from M.tb incorporated into liposomes were recently shown to trigger the differentiation of mice peritoneal macrophages into foamy-like cells [21].</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Interestingly, both M.tb and M. avium, which induce FM formation, express a family of oxygenated mycolic acids, especially ketomycolic acids, which are not produced by M. smegmatis (Figure 3A).</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>In this context, inactivation of the M.tb hma gene (mmaA4-Rv0642c) was shown to abolish the synthesis of oxygenated keto- and hydroxyl-mycolic acid in the mutant strain [17].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Conversely, transforming M. smegmatis with the hma gene induced the production of both keto- and hydroxyl-mycolic acids [22], (Figures 3B, C).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In the light of both data, we anticipated that oxygenated mycolic acids specifically produced by M.tb and M. avium, under the control of hma, are responsible for FM formation within human granulomas.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>To test this hypothesis, we compared FM formation after infection of PBMCs with either the wild-type, or the hma-expressing M. smegmatis strain (M. smegmatis/hma).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Granulomas cells were collected 3 days later and stained with Oil red-O to visualize lipid bodies.</Species>

<Species>Wild-type M. smegmatis-induced granulomas displayed only 5.5% of FM, whereas the hma gene-expressing strain induced granulomas bearing a majority (67%) of brightly stained Oil red-O positive cells (Figures 4A, B, C).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Induction of FM formation was even greater if isolated macrophages were directly infected with either strain.</Species>

<Species>After only 4 hours of infection, M. smegmatis/hma had already transformed 64% of the infected macrophages into lipid body-positive cells (see Figure S2 for Nile red positive cells), whereas only 9% of the cells contained lipid bodies after infection with the wild-type strain (Figures 4D, E, F).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>To confirm the specific role of hma-dependent oxygenated mycolic acids in FM formation, and to rule out a possible combined effect of oxygenated mycolic-acids with other mycobacterial components, mycolic acids isolated from wild-type M. smegmatis or M. smegmatis/hma were incubated with isolated macrophages.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>With mycolic acids isolated from the wild-type strain, only 13% of the macrophages were transformed into FM whereas 66% of the macrophages incubated with mycolic acids isolated from M. smegmatis/hma were strongly stained for lipid bodies (Figures 4G, H, I).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>These results therefore indicate that oxygenated mycolic acids play a leading role in M.tb-induced FM formation.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The phagocytic and bactericidal activities are arrested in FMs To assess the function of granuloma FM, we first evaluated the ability of such cells to mediate phagocytosis.</Species>
<Species>For this purpose, macrophages isolated from PBMCs were exposed to M. smegmatis/hma-derived mycolic acids to induce FM formation.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Two days later, the cell population contained a mixture of FM (50-70%) and macrophages (30-50%), as assessed by Nile red staining (not shown).</Species>
<Species>The mixed cell population was infected with FITC-labelled M. smegmatis.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Intracellular bacilli were found only within Nile red-negative macrophages thereby indicating that FMs are unable to ingest bacteria (Figure 5A).</Species>
<Species>This result was reproduced using other mycobacterial strains, such as M.tb and M. bovis BCG, for infection (not shown).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>These results further suggest that the bacilli found in granuloma FMs were internalized by macrophages prior to their transformation into FMs.</Species>

<Species>To assess whether FMs are able to develop a respiratory burst, which is a major intracellular bactericidal activity, the ability of Nile red positive cells (i.e. FMs) to mediate NBT reduction was determined.</Species>
<Species>As shown in Figure 5D, only 8% of the NBT-positive cells (Figure 5B) were Nile red positive FMs (Figure 5C).</Species>
<Species>This strongly suggests that once macrophages have differentiated into FMs, they lose the ability to mediate intracellular bactericidal activity.</Species>
<Species>We postulate that FMs could, therefore, form a secure reservoir for the tubercle bacilli.</Species>
<Species>M. tuberculosis persists in a dormant non-replicative state in FMs To evaluate the validity of the above hypothesis, we analyzed the ability of M.tb to replicate within FMs.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>For this purpose, isolated macrophages were infected with M.tb.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>At selected intervals post-infection, the amount of bacilli per cell was compared in both non-differentiated macrophages and FMs (Figure 5E).</Species>
<Species>Until day 6, M.tb replicated in a similar fashion in both cell types.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In contrast, after day 6 post-infection, the amount of bacilli remained stationary in FMs, whereas it continued to increase in macrophages.</Species>
<Species>It is interesting to note that arrest of bacterial replication coincided with completion of macrophage differentiation into FM, i.e. starting from day 3 post-infection.</Species>

<Species>Our data suggest, that the bacilli found in granuloma FMs were internalized by macrophages prior to their differentiation into FMs and also that bacilli can terminate their replication cycle while macrophages are being transformed into FM, but that replication comes to a halt as soon as the maturation process is complete.</Species>
<Species>We next determined whether the non-replicative bacilli observed in FMs were still alive.</Species>
<Species>For this purpose, we analyzed the expression of a series of genes known to be up-regulated when bacilli are in a persistent non-replicating state [23],[24].</Species>
<Species>RNA was, therefore, prepared from both in vitro-grown M.tb and intracellular bacilli at day 6 and 12 post-infection.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The respective amounts of RNA corresponding to isocitrate lyase, a-cristallin, a very hypothetical 7.6 kDa protein, CHP and DosR proteins were then quantified by RT-PCR.</Species>
<Species>As shown in Table 3, the dormancy genes were all strongly up-regulated in intracellular bacilli at day 12 post-infection.</Species>
<Species>These results further demonstrate that the bacilli are not killed in FMs, but rather persist in a dormant, and therefore non-replicative stage [25].</Species>
<Species>Interestingly, the dormancy genes were not as strongly expressed at day 6, time at which bacteria were still able to replicate in macrophages undergoing differentiation into FMs.</Species>

<Species>Characterization of M.tb survival within FMs and interaction with lipid bodies To gain further insight into the morphological appearance of M.tb within FM and into the interactions between FM lipid bodies (LB) and M.tb-containing phagosomes, granulomas were fixed and processed for conventional electron microscopy at days 3 and 11 post-infection.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Whatever the time point at which granuloma cells were observed, bacteria were all enclosed in phagosomes, most of which contained a single bacterium.</Species>
<Species>None of them (over a thousand which were examined under the electron microscope) were free in the cytoplasm and only one was enclosed in a classical autophagic vacuole.</Species>

<Species>At day 3 post-infection, FMs profiles (thin sections) were scarce, representing at most 9% of the total population of macrophage profiles observed under the electron microscope (Figure 6A).</Species>
<Species>In addition, 86% of the FM profiles displayed at most 5 small LBs (Figure 6B).</Species>
<Species>At this stage of granuloma formation, bacteria were infrequent in FM, but were found in other types of macrophages.</Species>
<Species>One of these displayed large numbers of vacuoles containing flocculent material and often one or two LBs.</Species>
<Species>Over 95% of the bacteria located in the different granuloma macrophages were morphologically intact, and therefore alive [26].</Species>
<Species>Intact bacteria present no breaks in the cell wall or cytoplasmic membrane and their cytoplasm has preserved its ultrastructural organization and electron opacity.</Species>
<Species>Furthermore, they display no electron translucent intracytoplasmic lipid inclusions (ILI).</Species>
<Species>Bacteria were also observed in between cells, probably as a result of cell lysis within granulomas.</Species>
<Species>These bacteria were also morphologically intact and devoid of ILI (not shown).</Species>
<Species>At day 11 post-infection, M.tb-containing macrophages displaying large numbers of vacuoles with flocculent material were less frequently observed.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Interestingly, the amount of such vacuoles had strongly decreased in most of these cells while the number of LBs had increased.</Species>
<Species>The percentage of FM had increased to reach 41% of the total population of macrophage profiles within the granulomas (Figure 6A).</Species>
<Species>From these observations, it is tempting to assume that the highly vesiculated macrophages give rise to FMs.</Species>

<Species>Within FMs, the size and amount of LBs had also increased with time since 48% of the FM profiles now displayed more than 5 LB per FM thin section (Figure 6B), randomly distributed within the cells (Figure 6C).</Species>
<Species>About 30% of the FM profiles displayed between 1 and 20 bacteria, which were morphologically intact and enclosed within phagosomes (Figure 6C, enlarged view).</Species>
<Species>The interaction between these bacteria and the cellular LBs was next examined at day 11.</Species>
<Species>Sixty percent of the bacilli were scattered throughout the FMs and displayed no obvious signs of interaction with the cellular LBs.</Species>
<Species>A small fraction of the bacteria (21%), however, were observed in the close vicinity of cellular LBs.</Species>

<Species>The membrane of the phagosomes in which they were enclosed clearly interacted with cellular LBs (Figures 6C, 7A, 7B, arrows) and became tightly apposed to an increasingly larger surface area of the LB.</Species>
<Species>As a result, the phagosomes started to surround LBs in a zippering fashion (Figures 7E, F).</Species>
<Species>Ultimately, bacilli (19%) were translocated to cellular LBs (Figure 7C).</Species>
<Species>From these observations, it is tempting to assume that M.tb-containing phagosomes engulf cellular LBs rather than fusing with them.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>This process, which is reminiscent of autophagy, resulted in the transfer of free bacteria into the lumen of cellular LBs (Figure 7C), some of which displayed up to 21 bacteria (Figure 7G).</Species>

<Species>Interestingly, only altered M.tb found within FM lipid bodies exhibited electron translucent ILIs (Figures 7D, G), thereby suggesting that they are able to accumulate host cell lipids.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In previous work, the term altered bacteria had been used to define live bacteria that had acquired ILIs</Species>
<Species>[26].</Species>
<Species>Since the presence of ILIs within the cytoplasm of M.tb is typical for non-replicating bacteria in a state of dormancy [27], this further confirms that these bacteria are dormant.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Discussion Studies carried out several decades ago suggested that postprimary tuberculosis starts as a lipid pneumonia [28],[29].</Species>

<Species>Indeed, following a first inflammatory process leading to exudates of mononuclear cells within alveolar spaces, early pathologists observed an accumulation of lipid droplets in alveolar macrophages of TB patients.</Species>
<Species>Tubercle bacilli were shown to reside in these lipid-rich macrophages which were named foamy macrophages (FMs)</Species>
<Species>[30].</Species>
<Species>Recently, histo-pathological analysis of biopsies from patients with untreated tuberculosis confirmed the century-old histological descriptions of postprimary tuberculosis [10].</Species>

<Species>In this study, Hunter et al showed that postprimary tuberculosis begins as a lipid pneumonia with the accumulation of large amounts of lipid-rich FMs, accompanied by bronchial obstruction.</Species>
<Species>It was also shown that in alveolar foamy macrophages, the bacilli were mainly found within lipid droplets.</Species>

<Species>All these observations underline the important, yet often neglected, role of lipid accumulation, and more precisely FM formation, at the infectious site in the physiopathology of TB.</Species>
<Species>In murine experimental models, FMs accumulate within the outermost layer of granulomatous structures occupying the alveolar spaces during the chronic phase of infection.</Species>
<Species>This strongly suggests that FMs could be involved in lesion cleaning via phagocytic uptake of cellular debris generated by the local inflammatory response.</Species>
<Species>Once filled with debris, FMs would leave the parenchyma through the alveolar spaces up to the superior bronchial tree, to be finally swallowed and digested in the stomach [31].</Species>
<Species>In fact, this process is very well known, and is a crucial factor for TB diagnosis in children.</Species>

<Species>As infants do not usually generate cavitary lesions, and because it is difficult to detect bacilli in the sputum, the diagnosis is linked to the detection of bacilli in the gastrointestinal lavage [32].</Species>
<Species>We show that M.tb-induced the transformation of in vitro-grown human granuloma macrophages into FMs within 6 days, and even more rapidly (3-4 hours) in cultured macrophages.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Although this event occurs more quickly than in vivo, or in animal models, our data are consistent with the above in vivo observations.</Species>
<Species>Within FMs, bacilli and LBs were often tightly linked, to the point that a non-negligible amount of bacteria were ultimately observed within LBs.</Species>

<Species>Interestingly, some of the bacilli transferred into lipid bodies displayed their own intracytoplasmic lipid inclusions, which are considered to be one of the hallmarks of non-replicating (dormant) M.tb [27].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The recent observation of persistent ILI-containing tubercle bacilli within adipocyte LBs [33] is in good agreement with our observations.</Species>
<Species>Since bacilli residing in phagosomes that do not interact with cellular lipid bodies do not display ILIs, it is tempting to assume that lipids within ILIs are of cellular origin.</Species>
<Species>The accumulation of lipids within bacilli [47], via interaction with FM lipid bodies could, therefore, be crucial to M.tb persistence.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>It is indeed known that M.tb accumulates lipids, and more precisely triacylglycerols, during dormancy [34],[35] from which it derives both carbon and energy for its own metabolism.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Intracellular persistence of M.tb is also critically linked to the acquisition of host cholesterol through the Mce4 transporter system [36].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The question that arises is how do bacteria gain access to lipids from LB?</Species>
<Species>Direct fusion of phagosomes with FM lipid bodies seems unlikely as the membranes of both structures are quite different from one another.</Species>

<Species>Our observations suggest instead that once M.tb-containing phagosomes have established close contact with a lipid body, they surround and engulf the latter by a process that remains to be deciphered.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>This phenomenon is somewhat reminiscent of autophagy, as observed under conditions of cholesterol depletion in macrophages infected with M. avium [37].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>After degradation of the resulting inner membrane, bacteria would be freed within the lipids of the engulfed LB, and therefore be in direct contact with cellular lipids.</Species>
<Species>How bacilli translocate the cellular lipids to their own cytoplasm remains to be established.</Species>

<Species>Another important phenomenon underlined by our study is the strong correlation between the presence of FMs in the granulomatous structures and the development of necrosis within the lesion, as suggested by Pagel over 80 years ago [29].</Species>
<Species>Interestingly, FMs were systematically located at the interface region between the histiocytes and the central necrosis area of the biopsied lesions.</Species>

<Species>Although necrosis formation could depend on an indirect effect of the global immune response, our data indicate that the formation of FMs is an important factor favoring the appearance of necrosis.</Species>

<Species>Analysis of larger series of biopsy samples are, however, needed to definitely demonstrate our actual hypothesis according to which FMs play a direct and unique role in necrosis formation.</Species>

<Species>Consistent with this hypothesis, we observed that FMs induced from M.tb-infected macrophages displayed permanent TNF-a secretion, a potent pro-necrotic factor, whereas M. smegmatis-infected macrophages were poor producers of TNF-a. At day 4 post-infection, TNF-a secretion was indeed twofold higher in macrophages (of which 70% had differentiated into FMs) infected with M.tb than in those infected with M. smegmatis, as measured both by ELISA and RNA quantification (Peyron, unpublished observations).</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>However, one must keep in mind that the association of FMs and necrosis may be the consequence of the FM cleaning process of lipoproteins released into the necrotic tissue, as observed in atherosclerosis lesions</Species>
<Species>[38].</Species>
<Species>It is thus tempting to propose that M.tb mycolic acids may be responsible for the development of necrotic lesions, due to their ability to induce TNF-a production by FMs.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Whether mycolic acids are directly involved in TNF-a production, or only indirectly by inducing FM formation, remains a matter of debate currently under study.</Species>

<Species>Our observations are strikingly similar to the phenomena described for postprimary tuberculosis, that seems to begin as localized foci of pneumonia followed by massive necrosis leading to the formation of pulmonary cavities [10].</Species>

<Species>If this proves to be the case, then the traditionally admitted phenomenon of cavitation arising from the erosion of caseating granulomatous structures from bronchi can be ruled out [39].</Species>

<Species>In our study, we successfully induced FM formation from isolated macrophages infected with M.tb, i.e. outside a granulomatous structure, which is consistent with Hunter's recent proposal.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Until now, mycolic acids have been considered to be indirectly involved in virulence mechanisms as being part of complex molecules of the mycobacterial envelope.</Species>

<Species>The most widely studied mycolic acid-containing mycobacterial compound trehalose 6,6    dimycolate (TDM), has been extensively analyzed for its role in virulence since the mid-fifties [40].</Species>
<Species>Recently, it was shown to interfere with the host granulomatous response [41].</Species>
<Species>Overall, TDM was mainly shown to mediate macrophage activation and a Th1-type response to M.tb infection (for review, see [25]).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Our results demonstrate a direct role of oxygenated mycolic acids for FM formation, independently from the appearance and stage of the disease.</Species>
<Species>M.tb-specific mycolic acids indeed trigger the transformation of both isolated and granuloma macrophages, into FM.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Given the absence of FM formation in M. smegmatis-induced granulomas, despite the induction of a comparative inflammatory response, ascertained by the similar induction of granulomas, this phenomenon clearly depends upon a direct contact with the bacilli, and not to the inflammatory response.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Mycolic acids are major and hallmark components of the mycobacterial cell wall.</Species>
<Species>They constitute 40-60% of dry weight of the envelope [42].</Species>

<Species>All members of the complex (e.g. M.tb, Mycobacterium africanum, Mycobacterium bovis and Mycobacterium microti) are able to synthesize the same combination of mycolic acids, i.e. cyclopropanated a-mycolic acids, ketomycolic and methoxymycolic acids [17], which are not synthesized by non-pathogenic mycobacterial species [43].</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>These structural specificities probably account for part of the pathogenicity of these species, as shown by the impaired virulence of mutant strains deprived of keto and methoxyl groups in experimental infections [17],[44],[45].</Species>
<Species>Our study, therefore, gives the first proof of a direct role of isolated mycolic acids in the interplay between M.tb and host cells.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Interestingly, this effect is expressed both by whole bacilli and isolated lipids, suggesting that oxygenated mycolic acids are either secreted by the bacilli, or exposed at the cell wall surface in a manner enabling their bioactivity.</Species>
<Species>According to our results, mycolic acids trigger the formation, within granulomas, of FMs in which bacilli can hide and survive.</Species>
<Species>Oxygenated mycolic acids, either free, as constituents of TDM [44], or linked to the cell wall arabinogalactan</Species>
<Species>[46],[47], should, therefore, be considered as major virulence factors enabling M.tb survival for long periods of time in a persistent state.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Being an inducer of host lipid accumulation, and FM formation at the site of infection, these oxygenated mycolic acids could, therefore, also be responsible for the induction of necrosis within lesions, thus favoring M.tb dissemination.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Interestingly, deletion of the mmaA4 (Rv0642c) gene also drastically decreased the ability of M.tb to induce the differentiation of macrophages into FMs (data not shown).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>However, the residual ability of this mutant to induce FMs suggests that other mycobacterial factors might partially trigger the formation of FM.</Species>
<Species>With regard to the mycolic acid methyltransferases, given that (i) mmaA2 (Rv0644c) and mmaA3 (Rv0643c) are pseudogenes in M. leprae and (ii)</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>mmaA4 KO present no trans cyclopropanation</Species>
<Species>[45], thus excluding the involvement of the cmaA2 (Rv0503c) gene, we expect that at least pcaA (Rv0470c), which introduces cis-cyclopropane, may play the same role.</Species>

<Species>Consistent with this hypothesis, a pcaA null mutant is unable to persist within infected mice [46], thus demonstrating the role of a mycolic acid methyltransferase in the chronic stage of infection.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Overall, our study has shed light on a previously uncharacterized cell population participating in human tuberculous granulomas, namely foamy macrophages.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We propose that the specific induction of FM by M.tb would create a favourable environment for persistent bacteria.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In our opinion, FMs could be a safe shelter because they preserve bacilli from a direct contact with granuloma lymphocytes and histiocytes, they lose one of the major macrophage bactericidal activities and they constitute an important source of nutrients for the bacilli thanks to the fatty acids accumulated in their lipid granules.</Species>
<Species>Supporting Information</Species>
<Species>Tissue remodeling: a mating-induced differentiation program for the Drosophila oviduct</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Abstract Background In both vertebrates and invertebrates, the oviduct is an epithelial tube surrounded by visceral muscles that serves as a conduit for gamete transport between the ovary and uterus.</Species>
<Species>While Drosophila is a model system for tubular organ development, few studies have addressed the development of the fly's oviduct.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Recent studies in Drosophila have identified mating-responsive genes and proteins whose levels in the oviduct are altered by mating.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Since many of these molecules (e.g. Muscle LIM protein 84B, Coracle, Neuroglian) have known roles in the differentiation of muscle and epithelia of other organs, mating may trigger similar differentiation events in the oviduct.</Species>
<Species>This led us to hypothesize that mating mediates the last stages of oviduct differentiation in which organ-specific specializations arise.</Species>

<Species>Results Using electron- and confocal-microscopy we identified tissue-wide post-mating changes in the oviduct including differentiation of cellular junctions, remodeling of extracellular matrix, increased myofibril formation, and increased innervation.</Species>
<Species>Analysis of once- and twice-mated females reveals that some mating-responsive proteins respond only to the first mating, while others respond to both matings.</Species>

<Species>Conclusion We uncovered ultrastructural changes in the mated oviduct that are consistent with the roles that mating-responsive proteins play in muscle and epithelial differentiation elsewhere.</Species>
<Species>This suggests that mating triggers the late differentiation of the oviduct.</Species>

<Species>Furthermore, we suggest that mating-responsive proteins that respond only to the first mating are involved in the final maturation of the oviduct while proteins that remain responsive to later matings are also involved in maintenance and ongoing function of the oviduct.</Species>
<Species>Taken together, our results establish the oviduct as an attractive system to address mechanisms that regulate the late stages of differentiation and maintenance of a tubular organ.</Species>

<Species>Background Most internal organs, including the vascular and respiratory systems and the gastro-intestinal and urinary-genital tracts are comprised of a single epithelial tube or a network of tubes.</Species>
<Species>Tubular organs serve as conduits for the transport of gases, liquids, or solutes, and serve as barriers between biological compartments.</Species>
<Species>To create tubes with specific flow and barrier properties, the morphology of the tube must be precisely specified during development and modulated by physiology.</Species>
<Species>To accommodate specific physiological roles, tissue-specific programs for differentiation are employed at the last stages of development.</Species>

<Species>While much is known about the molecular and cellular basis of tube formation [1-6], little is known about the mechanisms that regulate the late stages of differentiation in which organ-specific specializations arise.</Species>
<Species>The conservation of genes and similarity in tubular organ design across taxa make Drosophila an excellent model for understanding organogenesis in higher animals.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In Drosophila, the best understood tubular organs from a developmental point of view are the trachea and salivary gland.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Studies of these organs reveal a general program for tubular organ development, in which combinatorial expression of global patterning genes specifies positions within the embryo for the subsequent activation of tissue-specific early genes and transcription factors.</Species>

<Species>This program results in the activation of downstream genes involved in terminal differentiation of organ-specific specializations such as the cuticle that lines the tracheal lumen [1,2,4,7-9].</Species>
<Species>The Drosophila female reproductive tract is another tubular system, consisting of the uterus and a common oviduct (the main tube) that branches into two lateral oviducts.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Regional differences in function are observed along the length of the tract, with egg activation occurring largely at the proximal end, in the lateral oviducts, and fertilization occurring at the distal end, in the uterus [10,11].</Species>
<Species>Unlike other tubular organs, little is known about the development of the female reproductive tract.</Species>
<Species>However, regional differences in function suggest the presence of region-specific differentiation programs within the female reproductive tract.</Species>
<Species>In Drosophila, mating induces changes in female behavior and physiology via molecules transmitted in the seminal fluid.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>These changes are rapid and lead to a mated female state which is profoundly different from the unmated female state.</Species>
<Species>While an unmated female lays few eggs and readily accepts the courtship efforts of a male, a mated female exhibits increased egg-laying and actively rejects males [12-19].</Species>
<Species>Microarray studies of whole flies reveal that the changes in egg-laying rate are accompanied by a change in gene expression.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Within three hours of mating there is an increase in expression of a small number of genes [20,21].</Species>
<Species>Rapid changes in gene expression, as well as protein abundance, have also been observed in the female reproductive tract [22,23].</Species>

<Species>In the upper reproductive tract (lateral and common oviducts, hereafter, oviduct), mating induces an increase in immune related transcripts and down regulates transcription factors involved in cell growth and differentiation.</Species>

<Species>At the protein level mating induces increased abundance of proteins associated with muscle assembly and function and cytoskeletal proteins associated with epithelial morphogenesis [23].</Species>

<Species>Since many of these mating-responsive proteins act in late differentiation pathways of muscle and epithelia elsewhere (e.g. Bent, Muscle LIM protein 84B(Mlp84B), Neuroglian (Nrg), Coracle (Cora)), we hypothesize that mating triggers similar differentiation in the oviduct.</Species>
<Species>To test our hypothesis we characterized the ultrastructure of oviduct epithelia and muscle, as well as the pattern of innervation before and after mating.</Species>
<Species>We then examined the effect of different mating regimes on oviduct mating-responsive cytoskeletal proteins and on female reproductive output.</Species>
<Species>Our results suggest that active tissue remodeling takes place in the oviduct epithelia and musculature in response to mating.</Species>
<Species>Furthermore, we found a striking increase in innervation of the oviduct after mating.</Species>
<Species>Our results show that the reproductive tract is an attractive system to address mechanisms that regulate the late stages of tissue differentiation in a tubular organ.</Species>
<Species>Unlike other tubular organs, the last differentiation stage of the oviduct is triggered by an extrinsic cue (mating).</Species>
<Species>This makes it possible to experimentally control the onset of differentiation, with an opportunity to independently examine the effects of mating and age.</Species>
<Species>In addition, it allows us to examine processes essential for reproduction.</Species>

<Species>Results Mating induces changes in oviduct lumen Our previous molecular profiling showed that mating promotes changes in actin-based cytoskeletal molecules and suggests that mating triggers molecular changes and tissue remodeling in the female reproductive tract that mediate its progression to a mature functional stage [23].</Species>

<Species>To gain insight into the mechanisms that underlie this progression, we used light and electron microscopy to determine the morphological status of the oviduct in unmated and mated 3-day old females.</Species>

<Species>In nearly all mated reproductive tracts processed for microscopy (8/9), an egg was located in one of the lateral oviducts, whereas an egg was never observed in the oviduct of unmated reproductive tracts (5/5) (Figure 1).</Species>
<Species>This observation is consistent with previous studies that report increased ovulation and egg-laying at 6 h post-mating [24].</Species>

<Species>In all unmated reproductive tracts examined, the region between the lateral oviducts and the middle of the common oviduct was either tapered or constricted, whereas this region appeared relaxed in the mated reproductive tract (Figure 1A and 1D).</Species>
<Species>These observations raise the possibility that the lumen is narrow in the unmated oviduct and larger in the mated oviduct.</Species>

<Species>To address this possibility, we collected serial 1 um longitudinal sections through the reproductive tracts of unmated and mated females and stained these sections with toluidine blue to survey the appearance of the lumen along the entire length of the oviduct (Figure 1B and 1E).</Species>
<Species>Our examination reveals that, in unmated reproductive tracts, the lateral oviduct lumen has an irregular shape, while the common oviduct lumen appears straight.</Species>
<Species>Moreover, in all the unmated reproductive tracts sectioned, we detected patches of darkly stained material in the lumen of the lower common oviduct.</Species>

<Species>In the mated reproductive tract, the lumen of the upper oviduct (defined as the lateral oviduct and upper part of the common oviduct) has an irregular shape, and the lumen of the lower oviduct (defined as the lower part of common oviduct) appears straight.</Species>
<Species>In addition, the lumen of the lower oviduct appears wider in mated than unmated reproductive tracts (Figure 1C and 1F).</Species>
<Species>Interestingly, darkly stained material was not detected in the oviduct lumen of mated females.</Species>
<Species>This observation appears to be consistent with the description made by Mahowald et al.</Species>
<Species>[25], who reported that the oviduct lumen of unmated females is nearly filled with an intima-like matrix and that this matrix is reduced after mating.</Species>

<Species>Because 3-day-old mated females lay eggs, it is unclear whether the lack of lumenal material and increase in lumen size in mated females occurred before or after the passage of eggs.</Species>
<Species>We suggest that mating directly or indirectly induces morphological changes in the oviduct that facilitate egg passage through the duct.</Species>

<Species>Taken together, our observations lead us to propose that the oviduct lumen is closed and/or obstructed in the unmated reproductive tract, and that mating induces changes in the epithelia and/or muscle that "open" the oviduct lumen.</Species>

<Species>Initial formation of cell-cell junctions in oviduct epithelia is mating-independent To determine whether mating induces specific morphological changes in the oviduct epithelia post-mating, we next examined the ultrastructure of the oviduct epithelia in unmated and mated reproductive tracts.</Species>

<Species>Since molecular profiling demonstrates that proteins associated with cellular junctions such as a- and b-Spectrin (Spec), Cora, and Nrg [23] increase post-mating, we first determined the status of the cellular junctions in the oviduct epithelia of unmated females, and whether these junctions change post-mating.</Species>

<Species>In Drosophila, most ectodermally derived epithelia (such as the epidermis and trachea), with a few exceptions, are joined apically by a belt-like adherens junction called the zonal adherens junction (ZA) followed basally by a septate junction (SJ)</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>[26].</Species>
<Species>Our analysis reveals that the oviduct is lined, along its entire length, by a monolayered epithelium comprised of squamous-type cells.</Species>

<Species>Although region-specific differences in morphology were observed, all oviduct epithelia examined, in both unmated and mated females, are joined along their lateral membranes by an extensive SJ and lack an apical ZA (Figure 2).</Species>
<Species>SJs and ZAs form complete belts that surround the epithelial cell, thus making these junctions easily visible in transverse sections through the epithelium.</Species>
<Species>Because ZAs were not detected in our transverse sections through the oviduct, this implies that ZAs never formed, or developed earlier and were lost (Figure 2D).</Species>

<Species>Interestingly, we did not detect any ultrastructural differences in the SJs at 6 h post-mating, but we did uncover differences in SJ ultrastructure in different regions of the oviduct.</Species>
<Species>Based on their ultrastructure, two types of SJs, smooth and pleated, can be distinguished in Drosophila [26].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Smooth SJs are distinguished by the lack of visible septae and the appearance of electron dense material in the intercellular space, while pleated SJs are distinguished by the ladder-like appearance of septae.</Species>
<Species>In the lateral oviducts and upper common oviduct, septa were not detected in the SJ, thus these SJs represent smooth SJs or an immature stage of pleated SJ (Figure 2A, 2A', 2A").</Species>
<Species>In contrast, a ladder-like arrangement of septae was often visible in the SJs of the lower common oviduct (Figure 2C'), thus these SJs can be classified as pleated.</Species>

<Species>Unlike the smooth-like SJs of the upper oviduct, the pleated SJs of the lower oviduct are followed basally by spot type adherens junction (spot AJs) (Figure 2B, 2B'; additional file 1).</Species>
<Species>Further analysis is necessary to determine if the SJs of the upper and lower oviduct represent different types or different developmental stages.</Species>
<Species>Our findings demonstrate that the initial formation of SJs, as well as spot AJs in the lower oviduct, are mating-independent.</Species>
<Species>This raises an interesting question.</Species>
<Species>Why are SJ proteins such as Cora and Nrg up-regulated post-mating if SJs are formed prior to mating?</Species>
<Species>It is possible that the increased expression of SJ proteins is associated with functional changes in polarized secretion post-mating.</Species>
<Species>Recent studies have shown that SJs play an unexpected role in regulating the apical secretion of specialized extracellular matrix molecules in the trachea</Species>
<Species>[27,28], and that these molecules are important regulators of lumen size.</Species>

<Species>Mating modulates apical secretory activity in the oviduct Given the presence of extensive SJs in the oviduct and the role of SJs in regulating apical secretion of extracellular matrix molecules in other epithelia (e.g. trachea), we asked if mating modulates apical secretion in the oviduct epithelia.</Species>

<Species>Our ultrastructural analysis reveals that different regions of the oviduct display different apical membrane morphology (i.e microvilli or pleats) (see Figures 2 and additional file 2A and 2A), but all epithelia are covered by an electron dense apical extracellular matrix (AECM) and a thin layer of cuticle.</Species>
<Species>We found that mating induces ultrastructural changes in the AECM and cuticle in both the upper and lower oviduct.</Species>
<Species>In the upper oviduct of the unmated female, the AECM varies in thickness along the apical surface (Figure 3A).</Species>
<Species>Some areas have little AECM, while other areas are covered by a distinct layer of AECM (~1-2 um in thickness; Figure 3B).</Species>
<Species>However, the AECM of mated females is more evenly distributed along the apical surface, (~2 um in thickness; Figure 3E).</Species>
<Species>Strikingly, the AECM and cuticle of mated females have a ruffled appearance, suggesting that the AECM and cuticle have increased in surface area (Figure 3F).</Species>
<Species>Electron dense granules up to ~1.5 um in diameter were occasionally observed in both the AECM and cell cytoplasm (Figure 3F).</Species>

<Species>Although further analysis is needed to determine the role of these granules in the oviduct epithelia, it is possible that these granules participate in the secretion and deposition of the AECM.</Species>
<Species>Taken together, our findings suggest that polarized secretion via the AECM, while ongoing in the upper oviduct of the unmated female is enhanced and/or modulated post-mating.</Species>
<Species>Post-mating changes in AECM ultrastructure are also observed in the lower common oviduct.</Species>
<Species>However, unlike the AECM of the upper oviduct, the AECM of the lower oviduct is well developed prior to mating.</Species>

<Species>In the lower oviduct of the unmated female, the AECM consists of an amorphous electron dense material and is unevenly distributed, forming a thick, bulbous layer above the plasma membrane in some regions (additional file 2).</Species>
<Species>Matrix-like material is also observed in the lumen, but this material is more electron dense than the AECM (additional file 2A and 2A).</Species>
<Species>In the mated female, the AECM is flattened against the plasma membrane and is uniformly distributed along the apical surface (additional file 2B and 2B).</Species>

<Species>Matrix-like material was not observed in the center of the lumen, but small pools of very electron dense material were detected in the spaces between the epithelial folds (additional file 2C and 2C).</Species>
<Species>This may explain why lumenal matrix was not detected at the light microscopic level in the mated female oviduct (see Figure 1E and 1F).</Species>

<Species>Taken together, our observations suggest that the lower common oviduct is a site of active apical secretion in both mated and unmated females, and that matrix secretion, particularly in the lumen, is reduced post-mating.</Species>
<Species>These findings raise the intriguing possibility that the AECM and lumenal matrix function as a plug in the lower oviduct, and that mating induces the breakdown of this plug.</Species>
<Species>Mating induces changes in hemi-adherens junctions in upper oviduct In addition to modulating secretion at the apical membrane, mating induces changes at the basolateral membrane.</Species>

<Species>In many epithelia, one of the last steps of differentiation is the development of a layer of extracellular matrix (ECM) called the basal lamina that covers the apical and/or basal membranes and the concomitant development of hemi-adherens junctions (HAJs).</Species>
<Species>HAJs connect the cell cytoskeleton with the ECM and are formed at virtually all cell surfaces that contact an ECM.</Species>
<Species>HAJs can be distinguished at the ultrastructural level as a patch-like, electron dense undercoat of the plasma membrane that opposes the basal lamina ([26]; Figure 3G, 3H).</Species>
<Species>In the Drosophila embryo, the HAJs and basal lamina are formed at the same time [26].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Because the basal lamina is established at a time when the majority of extracellular matrix molecules are actively secreted [26,29], this suggests that the formation of HAJs is tightly coordinated with the secretion of the ECM.</Species>
<Species>One of the most striking post-mating changes observed in the oviduct epithelia was the appearance of numerous HAJs along the basolateral membrane in the upper oviduct (Figure 3).</Species>

<Species>The importance of HAJs, particularly in the upper oviduct, is underscored by the extensive infolding of the basolateral membrane that is observed in both unmated and mated females (Figure 3A and 3E).</Species>
<Species>The infolded membrane gives rise to a highly branched intercellular space that is filled with an ECM (Figure 3C and 3G).</Species>
<Species>This ECM is contiguous with the basal lamina that surrounds the epithelia.</Species>

<Species>Few HAJs were observed in the upper oviduct of the unmated female, and these were largely restricted to the basal membrane, and not observed along the basolateral infolding (Figure 3C).</Species>
<Species>In contrast, numerous HAJs appear along the basolateral infolding post-mating in this region of the oviduct (Figure 3F-3H).</Species>

<Species>In addition, the intercellular space appears wider post-mating (Figure 3C-3D and 3G-3H), suggesting that mating induces increased secretion and/or deposition of the ECM in this cellular compartment and brings the ECM to a threshold concentration that can support the development of HAJs.</Species>
<Species>HAJs were also detected along the basal membrane, but they were not detected along the apical membrane even though this membrane was covered by an ECM.</Species>

<Species>Interestingly, while the basolateral membrane forms very shallow folds in the lower oviduct (see additional file 2), HAJs were observed along this membrane in unmated reproductive tracts (data not shown), thus suggesting that the epithelia is more differentiated in this region of the oviduct, and that the differentiation of the upper and lower oviduct may be under different control.</Species>

<Species>Muscle differentiation is enhanced post-mating While we uncovered post-mating changes in the oviduct epithelia that might facilitate its transition to a high egg-laying state, this transition may also be mediated by changes in oviduct muscle properties and/or activity.</Species>
<Species>The oviduct is lined by circular muscle fibers with supercontractile characteristics [30].</Species>

<Species>Our previous studies showed that mef2 and mlp84B genes that regulate muscle differentiation, are expressed and increased post-mating in the oviduct, as well as in the sperm storage regions of the reproductive tract [22,23].</Species>
<Species>This suggests that mating induces muscle differentiation in the reproductive tract.</Species>
<Species>Muscle differentiation is characterized by the assembly of myofilaments into bundles called myofibrils.</Species>
<Species>As muscles differentiate, myofibrils and z-bodies appear simultaneously, and increase in number until the cytoplasm is filled with myofibrils</Species>
<Species>[31].</Species>
<Species>Like epithelia, one of the last steps of muscle differentiation is the secretion of a basal lamina that surrounds the muscle fiber.</Species>
<Species>To determine if mating induces structural changes in muscles (such as increased myofibrils)</Species>
<Species>we examined the ultrastructure of muscle fibers in the upper and lower parts of the oviduct.</Species>

<Species>Our analysis revealed that, in both unmated and mated reproductive tracts, the muscles of the lower oviduct are highly differentiated as evidenced by the high density of myofibrils, well developed and aligned z-bodies, and secretion of a thick, electron dense basal lamina (Figure 4E and 4F).</Species>

<Species>In contrast, muscle fibers in the lateral oviducts and upper common oviduct appear less differentiated than muscles in the lower common oviduct, as evidenced by the lesser density of myofibrils and z-bodies, and little or no basal lamina (Figure 4A and 4B).</Species>
<Species>Moreover, the muscles of the upper oviduct appear more differentiated in the mated than in unmated reproductive tracts (Figure 4A-4D).</Species>

<Species>Interestingly, we observed neighboring muscle fibers in different states of differentiation in the lateral oviducts in both unmated and mated reproductive tracts, but not elsewhere in the oviduct (Figure 4B).</Species>

<Species>These results suggest that mating enhances the rate of muscle differentiation in the upper oviduct, and that muscle differentiation is delayed in the upper as compared to the lower oviduct.</Species>
<Species>The increased muscle differentiation in the upper oviduct is not dramatic and likely reflects the short post-mating period examined in this study.</Species>

<Species>The delayed differentiation of the upper oviduct muscles resembles the delay in the onset of development between the adult thoracic muscles and abdominal muscles during metamorphosis [32].</Species>
<Species>Since the ovaries and the other parts of the reproductive tract are known to have different segmental origins</Species>
<Species>[33], we hypothesize that different parts of the oviduct develop at different rates or begin development at different times.</Species>

<Species>Increased innervation in the oviduct post-mating Nerve-muscle interactions play an important role in regulating adult muscle development and refining the final pattern of innervation [34,35].</Species>
<Species>Given that oviduct muscle differentiation is enhanced post-mating, we predicted that mating either directly or indirectly induces changes in innervation.</Species>
<Species>To address this prediction, we quantified the number of nerve terminals or boutons innervating the lateral oviducts and common oviduct in unmated and mated reproductive tracts.</Species>
<Species>Studies of oviduct innervation in Drosophila reveal that the fly's oviduct receives aminergic, peptidergic and glutamatergic input</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>[30,36-39].</Species>
<Species>In both larval and adult Drosophila, different types of boutons are formed by neurons that express different neurotransmitters and modulators [40-42].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>By similarity to the boutons described at the larval and adult neuromuscular junction, Middleton et al.</Species>
<Species>[30] report that the fly's oviduct is innervated by glutamatergic type I boutons and tyraminergic/octopaminergic type II boutons.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Rodgriguez-Valentin et al.</Species>
<Species>[43] further report that the oviduct type II boutons co-express octopamine and glutamate.</Species>
<Species>The neurons that give rise to the type I innervation have not been identified.</Species>
<Species>However, it is well established that type II innervation arises from octopaminergic neurons located in the abdominal ganglion [30,43].</Species>
<Species>In addition, it has been shown that some or all of these neurons express a GAL4 insertion line for the bullwinkle (bwk) gene [43].</Species>
<Species>Bwk encodes a HMG-box containing putative transcription factor [44].</Species>

<Species>To determine if mating induces any changes in the number of type I and II boutons innervating the oviduct muscles, we used the pan-neural marker, anti-HRP to label all oviduct boutons in unmated and mated females.</Species>
<Species>To distinguish between type I and II boutons we used an antibody against the Disc Large (DLG) protein [45].</Species>
<Species>Type I boutons were identified by their DLG postsynaptic staining and large size (> 8 um in diameter)</Species>
<Species>(Figure 4G), while type II boutons were distinguished by their absence of DLG staining and smaller size (< 2 um) (Figure 4H).</Species>

<Species>We find that type I and II boutons innervate the lateral oviducts and common oviduct, and that the type I innervation is restricted to a few axons that run parallel to the length of the oviduct, while the type II innervation is more widespread.</Species>

<Species>We quantified the number of boutons in the lateral oviducts and common oviduct and observed a 74% increase in bouton number in the lateral oviduct and a 66% increase in the common oviduct post-mating (Figure 4I).</Species>
<Species>More over, we observed no significant change in the number of type I boutons in the lateral oviduct and common oviduct.</Species>
<Species>However, we detected a 1.5-fold increase in the number of type II boutons in the lateral oviduct and a 1.8-fold increase in type II innervation in the common oviduct.</Species>
<Species>Dramatic increases in bouton growth are also observed during development.</Species>
<Species>For example, a ten-fold increase in bouton number is observed at the neuromuscular junction during the larval period [46].</Species>

<Species>To determine if the increase in type II innervation was specific to mating or reflected normal growth in 3 day-old females, we quantified type I and II innervation in the oviducts of 5 day-old unmated females.</Species>

<Species>We found no significant difference in type I and II innervation in unmated 3 day-old and 5-day-old females, indicating that mating, either directly or indirectly, induces a dramatic increase in type II innervation (Figure 4I).</Species>
<Species>To determine if the post-mating increase in innervation is unique to the oviduct, we asked if mating induces a global change in innervation.</Species>
<Species>We quantified bouton number in the adult ventral midline muscles of the 5th abdominal segment.</Species>
<Species>These muscles are innervated by boutons that increase in number during metamorphosis [47].</Species>
<Species>No significant difference in bouton number was detected at these muscles in unmated and mated females (additional file 3).</Species>
<Species>Though further analysis is needed, this suggests that the post-mating increase in innervation is oviduct-specific.</Species>
<Species>Because the type II boutons are octopaminergic, the increased type II innervation may result in increased octopamine (OA) release in the oviduct.</Species>
<Species>In support of this possibility, we have preliminary evidence that OA is released in the oviduct post-mating (Heifetz and Wolfner, in preparation).</Species>
<Species>Studies in locust and Drosophila demonstrate that OA inhibits oviduct contraction, while glutamate activates oviduct contraction [30,43,48].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In Drosophila, electrical stimulation of the posterior abdominal nerve gives rise to a series of muscle contractions in the oviduct followed by a period of muscle fatigue or relaxation [43].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>This pattern of muscle contraction and relaxation may facilitate the proper movement of the egg through the oviduct.</Species>
<Species>In their study of bwk expressing neurons that innervate the oviduct, Rodriguez-Valentin et al.</Species>
<Species>[43] show that OA and glutamate interact to produce the pattern of oviduct contraction and relaxation described above.</Species>

<Species>It is therefore possible that the post-mating increase in type II innervation in the oviduct plays an important role in the increased rate of ovulation and egg-laying observed post-mating.</Species>

<Species>Female mating history affects the enrichment of cytosekeletal proteins in the oviduct To gain insights into the role of cytoskeletal protein enrichment ([23]; additional file 4) in mediating the morphological changes detected in this study, we examined the effect of different mating regimes on cytoskeletal protein abundance.</Species>
<Species>We focused on a subset of mating-responsive cytoskeletal proteins with well established roles in the differentiation of muscle and epithelia.</Species>

<Species>These include: (i) Mlp84B which regulates the late differentiation pathway of muscle [49]; (ii) Cora and Nrg which are required for the formation of septate junctions in epithelia [50], and (iii) Hu-li tai shao (Hts), also known as adducin-like protein, which functions in assembly of the cytoskeletal network.</Species>
<Species>Na+ pump a subunit (ATPa), another protein associated with septate junctions in epithelia, is not a mating-responsive protein and was used as a control.</Species>
<Species>Using western blots, we first determined the abundance of the cytoskeletal proteins in oviducts of 3-day-old unmated and mated females at 6 hrs post-mating.</Species>
<Species>We confirmed the proteomic results of Kalpenikov et al.</Species>
<Species>[23] and found that mating increases the abundance of all proteins, except ATPa in mated oviducts relative to their abundance in unmated oviducts (Figure 5A).</Species>

<Species>To determine whether the increased abundance of mating-responsive proteins persists for longer times post-mating, we examined oviducts of 10-day-old females that mated once at 3 days of age, and calculated the abundance of the mating-responsive proteins relative to their level in oviducts of 3-day-old unmated females.</Species>
<Species>We found no change or a slight increase in the relative abundance of all cytoskeletal proteins except Mlp84B at 7 days post-mating (Figure 5A).</Species>
<Species>Strikingly, the level of Mlp84B declines by 7 days post-mating to the level observed prior to mating.</Species>
<Species>Thus Mlp84B levels rise and fall after mating, while the epithelial-related proteins rapidly rise and are maintained at a high level after mating.</Species>
<Species>This raises the possibility that a second mating might trigger an increase in Mlp84B protein expression as observed in 3-day-old females at 6 h post-mating.</Species>
<Species>To test this possibility, females were mated twice (once at day 3, and once on day 10 of age), and their oviducts were examined at 6 hrs after the second mating.</Species>
<Species>We calculated the abundance of the cytoskeletal proteins in the twice mated oviducts relative to their abundance in oviducts of 3-day-old unmated females.</Species>
<Species>Our results show that a second mating has little or no effect on Mlp84B abundance.</Species>
<Species>Thus, Mlp84B may represent a class of mating-responsive proteins that is only needed after the first mating.</Species>
