<Species>Interestingly, the effect of the second mating on the epithelial-related mating-responsive proteins appears to be different for each protein.</Species>
<Species>While Cora levels drop to the level observed in 3-day-old unmated females, Nrg and Hts are maintained at a high level.</Species>
<Species>To determine if the changes in cytoskeletal protein abundance are mating-dependent we measured their abundance in the oviducts of unmated 5- and 10-day-old females.</Species>
<Species>We calculated their abundance relative to their level in oviducts of unmated 3-day-old females (Figure 5B).</Species>
<Species>We rationalized that if the change in cytoskeletal protein abundance is mating-dependent we will not see similar changes in unmated females.</Species>
<Species>We observed a slow increase in the relative abundance of all mating-responsive proteins with time post-eclosion (Figure 5B).</Species>

<Species>Because unmated females lay more eggs as they age (see additional file 5C) one possible interpretation of the increased level of cytoskeletal proteins in unmated females is that these proteins are associated with an intrinsic program for oviduct maturation and that mating accelerates this process to maximize egg-laying efficacy.</Species>
<Species>Alternatively, it is possible that the slow increase in protein abundance observed in unmated females is due to the passage of eggs through the oviduct.</Species>
<Species>Taken together, our results suggest that mating is essential to fine-tune the levels of the mating-responsive proteins examined in this study.</Species>
<Species>Because the changes in cytoskeletal protein abundance are different in unmated and mated females, this suggests that the post-mating changes are mating-dependent.</Species>
<Species>Furthermore, we suggest that these post-mating changes are linked to changes in oviduct function.</Species>
<Species>Early or prior mating increases fecundity In Drosophila, female fecundity decreases with age [51-54].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>It has been proposed that this decrease is due, in part, to the loss of germline and somatic stem cells [55].</Species>
<Species>Since the expression of the oviduct cytoskeletal proteins examined in this study change with age and mating experience, the state of the oviduct may also play a role in fecundity.</Species>

<Species>To separate the effects of age and mating, we measured the fecundity of females that mated twice, first at 3 days post-eclosion and again at 10 days, and compared that to the fecundity of females that mated once at 3 days and females that mated once at 10 days.</Species>
<Species>Fecundity was measured as the number of eggs laid per day per female during the first three days after mating.</Species>
<Species>Once-mated 3-day-old females laid nearly twice as many eggs as once-mated 10-day-old females during the three days examined (24.5 + 0.7 versus 13.3 + 0.9, p < 0.0001).</Species>

<Species>Twice-mated 10-day-old females also laid about 50% more eggs than once-mated females of the same age (19.3 + 0.9 versus 13.3 + 0.9, p < 0. 0001), but about 20% fewer than laid by once-mated 3-day-old females during the three days examined (19.3 + 0.9 versus 24.5 + 0.7, p < 0.0001) (Figure 6A, see also additional file 5A and 5B).</Species>
<Species>Thus, the difference in fecundity between once-mated 10-day-old and once-mated 3-day-old females is not a result of age alone.</Species>
<Species>Rather the main determinant of fecundity at 10 days is whether there had been a prior mating at 3 days.</Species>
<Species>We also calculated the fertility (number of adults eclosed) of once- and twice-mated females.</Species>

<Species>Once-mated 3-day-old females are more fertile than once-mated 10-day-old females (69.5 + 1.6% versus 56.1 + 3.0%, p < 0.0001) and slightly more fertile than twice-mated 10-day-old females (69.5 + 1.6% versus 62.7 + 2.4%, p < 0.015)</Species>
<Species>(Figure 6B, see also additional file 5D).</Species>

<Species>Because there is no significant difference in fertility between once-mated and twice-mated 10-day-old females, this suggests that (1) a prior mating has no significant effect on the fertility of 10-day-old mated females and (2) fertility decreases with age.</Species>
<Species>One intriguing interpretation of these results is that an early mating increases fecundity which partially compensates for the age-related decrease in fertility.</Species>
<Species>Thus, cytoskeletal mating-responsive protein changes may be associated with structural changes in the oviduct that result in increased fecundity.</Species>
<Species>This may counteract the effects of decreased fertility on the reproductive output.</Species>

<Species>Discussion Despite the use of Drosophila as a model system for organ-level biology and the emerging parallels between mammalian and Drosophila reproductive biology [56], this is the first integrative tissue-wide study of post-mating changes in the Drosophila oviduct.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Our results provide several lines of evidence at the molecular, morphological and physiological levels suggesting that mating induces tissue-wide differentiation in the oviduct.</Species>

<Species>Moreover, we identify ultrastructural changes in the mated oviduct that are consistent with the roles that some of the mating-responsive proteins examined in this study (e.g. Mlp84B, Cora, Nrg) are reported to play in muscle and epithelial differentiation elsewhere.</Species>

<Species>For example, the increased abundance of Mlp84B, a major regulator of the late differentiation pathway of muscle [49] is consistent with the increased muscle differentiation in the upper oviduct post-mating (Figure 4A-4F).</Species>

<Species>Similarly, the increased abundance of Cora and Nrg, molecules that are essential for SJ development and function [50] is consistent with the observation that SJs in the upper oviduct are immature and/or that mating induces changes in the apical extracellular matrix whose secretion may be regulated, in part, by SJs as occurs in the trachea</Species>
<Species>[27,28].</Species>
<Species>Other post-mating changes that indicate that mating induces tissue-wide differentiation include increased HAJs along the basolateral membrane and increased innervation.</Species>

<Species>Analysis of protein abundance following different mating regimes (unmated, once-mated, twice-mated) gave us further insights into the possible roles that mating-responsive proteins play in the oviduct.</Species>
<Species>For example, Mlp84B is only responsive to the first mating, while the epithelial proteins examined (Cora, Nrg and Hts) are responsive to the first and second mating.</Species>
<Species>Furthermore, the response to the second mating is different from the response to the first mating.</Species>

<Species>Taken together, these results suggest that Mlp84B is required for the final maturation of the oviduct, while the epithelial proteins examined are required for both the maturation and maintenance of the oviduct at a high functional state.</Species>
<Species>Moreover, the post-mating pattern of Mlp84B supports the idea that the first mating induces the final maturation of the oviduct.</Species>

<Species>The rise and fall of Mlp84B abundance after the first mating (Figure 5) parallels the expression pattern of Mlp84B during development where peaks in Mlp84B transcription occur during periods of embryogenesis and metamorphosis when muscle is differentiating [49].</Species>
<Species>Using different mating regimes we tested whether the first/early mating is essential for maintenance of high reproductive output in the second mating.</Species>
<Species>Our results suggest that mating at an early age is essential to achieve maximum reproductive output (i.e. high fecundity and fertility).</Species>

<Species>Since the first mating increases reproductive output (evidence from our mating regime experiments), it is likely that the ultrastructural changes detected in mated 3-day-old females lead to a highly functional oviduct.</Species>
<Species>We suggest that the final maturation of the oviduct includes a mating-dependent stage.</Species>

<Species>We propose that during the first few days post-eclosion, the oviduct undergoes the first phase of differentiation, after which the oviduct is developmentally poised for a rapid response to an extrinsic cue (mating).</Species>
<Species>Mating then triggers the second phase of maturation (tissue remodeling and modulation) which is essential for proper oviduct function (Figure 7).</Species>

<Species>We further propose that the second phase of maturation consists of processes that are mating-independent and -dependent, and that both of these pathways are essential to produce a functional oviduct.</Species>
<Species>For example, initial formation of SJs occurs prior to mating (mating-independent) while the increased apical secretion and development of HAJs are mating-dependent.</Species>
<Species>The oviduct musculature is an example where both mating-independent and -dependent processes play a role.</Species>
<Species>Muscles are highly differentiated in the lower oviduct prior to mating, while muscle differentiation is ongoing in the upper oviduct and increases after mating.</Species>
<Species>Although the onset of muscle differentiation in both regions is mating-independent, the further differentiation of muscle in the upper oviduct is mating-dependent.</Species>

<Species>Another possible interpretation of the role of mating on oviduct maturation is that mating accelerates and synchronizes processes that are essential for the functional maturation of the oviduct.</Species>
<Species>It will therefore be interesting to examine the oviducts of older females to determine the status of oviduct maturation.</Species>
<Species>What is the benefit of mating-induced differentiation of the oviduct tissues?</Species>
<Species>Unmated females are capable of laying eggs, albeit at a reduced rate as compared to mated females of the same age.</Species>
<Species>One possible interpretation is that reproduction is energetically costly, thus delaying oviduct maturation until sperm is available is advantageous to the female.</Species>
<Species>This may reflect the evolution of a mechanism to optimize reproductive capacity in early adulthood in short-lived animals.</Species>
<Species>In summary, we have identified events at the cellular, molecular and physiological levels that are part of an efficient and specific program for reproduction.</Species>
<Species>Drosophila affords us the opportunity to uncover the signaling pathways that coordinate these events to produce a physiologically functional organ.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Methods Flies Wild-type Canton-S flies were used for the fecundity/fertility experiments and confocal analysis.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Wild-type Canton-S5</Species>
<Species>[57] flies were used for electron microscopy.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>All flies were kept in a 12 hrs light/dark cycle at 23 + 2oC. Upon eclosion, females and males were collected on ice and held separately until 3 (females and males) or 10 (females) days of age.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Sample preparation For all assays (unless described differently) unmated females were placed with 3-day-old unmated males and observed until mating initiated.</Species>
<Species>At the end of mating, females were aspirated into fresh vials and held for 6 hrs.</Species>
<Species>At 6 hrs after the start of mating, females were placed on ice for dissection.</Species>
<Species>Previous molecular studies indicate changes in protein abundance at 3 hrs post-mating.</Species>
<Species>We hypothesize that these molecular changes will translate into morphological changes in the next few hours.</Species>

<Species>We chose to analyze the morphology of mated females at 6 h post-mating as opposed to later times post-mating because the changes observed at later times may be due, in part, to the high rate of eggs passing through the oviduct.</Species>
<Species>Electron microscopy Reproductive tracts were dissected in Schneider's Drosophila medium (Sigma) on ice and processed for electron microscopy as described in [42].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Tracts were flat-embedded between two sheets of Aclar (Electron Microscopy Sciences), which allowed us to image the entire tract at the light microscopic level prior to sectioning.</Species>
<Species>Sections were cut on a Reichart Ultracut microtome.</Species>
<Species>One-um thick sections were stained with 1% toluidine blue, and viewed with a Zeiss Axoplan microscope.</Species>

<Species>Ultrathin sections (~100 nm) were mounted on formvar grids, stained with lead citrate, and viewed with a Philips/FEI Morgagni 268 TEM at 80 kV. Our analysis is based on 4 unmated samples and 3 mated samples.</Species>

<Species>Two unmated samples were cut in the longitudinal plane and two additional unmated samples were cut in the transverse plane, while one mated sample was cut in the longitudinal plane and two additional mated samples were cut in the transverse plane.</Species>
<Species>For longitudinal sections, the entire tract was re-embedded and cut.</Species>

<Species>For samples cut in the transverse plane, the flat-embedded reproductive tract was divided into three regions: (1) lateral oviducts and upper common oviducts, (2) middle common oviduct, and (3) lower common oviduct.</Species>
<Species>Each region was re-embedded and sectioned.</Species>
<Species>It is beyond the scope of this paper to describe all three regions, and our analysis focuses on the uppermost and lowermost regions.</Species>

<Species>Immunocytochemistry Reproductive tracts were dissected in Yamamoto's Ringer (10 mM MOPS; 80 mM NaCl; 10 mM KCL; 0.2 mM MgCl2; 0.1 mM CaCl2) with 5% (w/v) sucrose on ice, fixed in 4% paraphormaldehyde in PBS (phosphate-buffered saline; 0.85% NaCl, 1.4 mM KH2 PO4, 8 mM Na2</Species>
<Species>HPO4, pH 7.4) for 45 min and then washed in PBS.</Species>
<Species>The reproductive tracts were then incubated in blocking solution (0.5% Triton x-100, 3% NGS, 0.1% BSA) for 2 hrs at room temperature.</Species>
<Species>The following primary antibodies, reagents, and dilutions were used: Cy3-conjugated goat anti-HRP, 1:200 (Jackson Immunochemicals, West Grove, PA); mouse anti-Disc Large (DLG),</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>1:1000 (Developmental Hybridoma Bank), Alexa Fluor 488-phalloidin, 1:200 (Invitrogen, Molecular Probes, Scotland).</Species>
<Species>Secondary antibodies were Alexa Flour 488-conjugated Goat anti-mouse, 1:200 and Alexa Flour 546-conjugated Goat anti-rabbit, 1:200 (Invitrogen, Molecular Probes, Scotland).</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Reproductive tracts were incubated with the different primary antibodies (diluted in PBS + 0.2% Triton x-100) for 2 hr at room temperature, washed with PBST, incubated with secondary antibodies for 2 hrs at room temperature and washed with PBS.</Species>
<Species>Reproductive tracts of the different treatments were mounted with Antifade media [58] on a multi-well glass slide (Hendley-Essex, UK).</Species>

<Species>For each treatment (unmated, mated) and antibody/reagent (HRP, DLG, phalloidin) a minimum of ten reproductive tracts from at least two independent biological replicates were prepared.</Species>
<Species>Confocal microscopy Reproductive tracts were viewed with a Zeiss 510 laser scanning confocal microscope using 20x and 60x objective with additional zooming.</Species>

<Species>Optical sections from different focal plans of each reproductive tract region (lateral oviducts, common oviduct, uterus) were collected and projected as a reconstructed three-dimensional image using LSM image browser (version 3,5,0,376) software.</Species>
<Species>Image collections were identical for each of the different reproductive tract regions analyzed.</Species>

<Species>Quantitation of bouton number To quantify the number of boutons in the lateral and common oviducts we used ImageJ software (1.37b, National Institutes of Health) to analyze confocal images of anti-HRP and anti-DLG labeled boutons in the oviduct.</Species>
<Species>The number of boutons per unit area was quantified with the Particle Analysis Tool.</Species>

<Species>Briefly, to differentiate between the boutons, the particle analysis tool requires the image to be a "binary" image (i.e., black or white), thus we first converted the images to gray scale.</Species>
<Species>We then set a "threshold" range so that pixels in the image whose value lies in this range are converted to black; pixels with values outside this range are converted to white.</Species>
<Species>We next defined a region of interest (ROI) within the oviduct to count particles (i.e. count boutons).</Species>
<Species>This ROI was saved and served to measure the number of boutons per unit area in each treatment.</Species>
<Species>For each oviduct we counted the number of anti-HRP and anti-DLG labeled boutons in two ROIs within the lateral oviducts and two ROIs in the common oviduct.</Species>
<Species>One-way ANOVA (SPSS 15.0) was used to measure the difference in bouton number per unit area in different regions of the oviducts, in both unmated and mated females.</Species>

<Species>Quantitation of cytoskeleton proteins Sample preparation To evaluate the effect of mating on the abundance of the cytoskeleton proteins tested, females were: (i) aged for 3 days, mated with 3-day-old unmated males and their oviducts were dissected after 6 hrs post-mating (Once3); (ii) aged for 3 days, mated with 3-day-old unmated males and their oviducts were dissected after 7 days (Once3 day10); (iii) aged for 3 days, mated first with 3-day-old unmated males and held singly for 7 days.</Species>
<Species>At 10 days of age, female were mated again with 3-day-old unmated males.</Species>
<Species>Oviducts were dissected at 6 hrs post-second mating (Twice3&10).</Species>
<Species>We also examined 5-day-old and 10-day-old unmated females (UM5, UM10 respectively).</Species>

<Species>SDS polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE) and Western blotting For each mating regime, sixty oviducts were pooled and 30 ul of SDS-PAGE sample buffer was added as described in [59].</Species>
<Species>Samples were boiled, and then frozen at -20oC until loading.</Species>
<Species>SDS-PAGE was performed on 12% polyacrylamide gels and western blotted as in [60].</Species>
<Species>Proteins were cross-linked to the filter.</Species>

<Species>The following primary antibodies and dilutions were used: mouse anti-Neuroglian (kindly provided by M. Hortsch) 1:250; Guinea pig anti-Coracle (kindly provided by R.G. Fehon) 1:2500; rabbit anti-Mlp84B (kindly provided by M. Beckerle) 1:1000; mouse anti-hts (1B1, Developmental Studies Hybridoma Bank, DSHB) 1:75; mouse anti-Na, K-ATPase (a5, DSHB) 1:100.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Secondary antibodies included: anti-Guinea pig IgG (peroxidase conjugated), anti-Rabbit IgG and anti-Mouse IgG (developed in goat, Sigma, Israel) 1:10,000.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Proteins were visualized using an enhanced chemiluminescence (ECL) detection system (Amersham Piscataway, NJ).</Species>
<Species>Analysis The developed film was scanned and the signal intensity (protein abundance) of each band was determined using ImageJ software (1.37d, National Institutes of Health).</Species>
<Species>We evaluated protein abundance by measuring the mean gray value of a specific band and the background.</Species>
<Species>The mean gray value of the background was then subtracted from that of the measured band.</Species>
<Species>Relative protein abundance in mated oviduct vs. 3-day-old unmated oviduct was then calculated.</Species>
<Species>Four independent biological replicates were prepared for each mating status.</Species>
<Species>The reported abundance (see Figure 5) is the relative ratio (mated/unmated or unmated/unmated) of at least three replicates that showed the same trend.</Species>

<Species>Examination of female reproductive output Mating regimes To evaluate the effect of mating on reproductive output females were treated as follows: (i) aged for 3 days and mated with 3-day-old unmated males (Once3); (ii) aged for 10 days and mated with 3-day-old unmated males (Once10); (iii) aged for 3 days, mated first with 3-day-old unmated males, held for 7 days and mated again with 3-day-old unmated males (Twice3&10).</Species>
<Species>In all cases male and female pairs were observed to record mating initiation and termination.</Species>
<Species>Analysis Following mating, females were aspirated into fresh vials, held singly and allowed to lay eggs for 6 hrs, then transferred daily (each 24 hrs) to fresh vials.</Species>
<Species>The number of eggs laid and the number of eclosed adults were counted from vials created at 6 hrs, 1, 2 and 3 days post-mating.</Species>
<Species>To ascertain the baseline of female egg-laying, we also included in our experiment unmated females that were kept in the same conditions as mated females.</Species>
<Species>The number of eggs laid by unmated females was counted from vials created at 6 hrs, 1, 2 and 3 days after placing the females in the holding vials.</Species>
<Species>In addition, we also recorded the pattern of unmated female egg-laying for 10 days.</Species>
<Species>To determine the effect of different mating regimes on female reproductive output (i.e. fecundity and fertility), we used One-way ANOVA (SPSS 15.0).</Species>

<Species>Abbreviations Nrg: Neuroglian; Cora: Coracle; Spec: a- and b-Spectrin; SJ: septate junction; SSJ: smooth septate junction; PSJ: pleated septate junction; ZA: zonal adherens junction; AJ: adherens junction; AECM: apical extracellular matrix; ECM: extracellular matrix; HAJ: hemi-adherens junction; SAJ: spot adherens junction; OA: Octopamine; Hts: Hu-li tai shao; ATP a: Na+ pump a subunit; Mlp84B: Muscle LIM protein at 84B; DLG: Disc Large; HRP: horseradish peroxidas; UM: unmated; M: mated.</Species>
