<Species>Also because of this design, the effect of sex and age could not be studied.</Species>

<Species>It has to be noted, however, that for all other research questions on the effect of genetic and acquired risk factors on the risk of venous thrombosis, this design has no limitations and the close matching of cases and controls renders confounding by, for instance, lifestyle and socioeconomic class less likely than in previous unmatched studies (see also Protocol S1).</Species>
<Species>Another advantage of this approach is the minimization of recall bias, as the cases and controls would generally fill in the questionnaire together.</Species>
<Species>Many questions are still left unanswered that necessitate more research.</Species>
<Species>First of all, our study results apply only to people younger than 70 y of age.</Species>

<Species>Furthermore, it is likely that other characteristics exist that also increase the risk   person-specific (e.g., other drug use), behavioral (e.g., use of sleeping pills or alcohol consumption), and flight-specific (e.g., class or seating)   that need to be identified.</Species>
<Species>These further variables are part of our ongoing study as part of the World Health Organization Research Initiative into the Global Hazards of Travel (WRIGHT study).</Species>
<Species>For those who have an increased risk, such as oral contraceptive users and individuals with factor V Leiden, prevention may be warranted.</Species>
<Species>Prevention may vary from simple measures, such as exercises during the flight, to measures that carry a risk themselves, such as anticoagulants.</Species>
<Species>Specific studies are needed to assess the efficacy of these measures and their risk-benefit ratio.</Species>
<Species>It can be concluded that the risk of venous thrombosis is 2-fold increased for all travelers and to the same extent for all modes of travel.</Species>

<Species>In individuals who use oral contraceptives, are carriers of the factor V Leiden mutation, or are particularly tall, short, or obese, this risk is considerably higher, to such an extent that studies into the efficacy of prophylactic measures are required.</Species>
<Species>Supporting Information</Species>
<Species>IL-5 drives eosinophils from bone marrow to blood and tissues in a guinea-pig model of visceral larva migrans syndrome</Species>

<Species>Abstract This study was undertaken to evaluate the role of IL-5 in eosinophil migration and in the maintenance of eosinophilia in a guinea-pig model of visceral larva migrans syndrome.</Species>

<Species>The results show that the infection of animals with Toxocara canis induced an early increase in serum IL-5 levels that might be essential for eosinophil differentiation and proliferation and for the development of eosinophilia.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>When infected guinea-pigs were treated with mAb anti-IL-5 (TRFK-5) given at the same time or 1 or 3 days after infection, there was a high percentage of reduction of eosinophil counts 18 days after infection.</Species>

<Species>However, when the mAb was administered during the peak of eosinophilia, there was high inhibition in blood, no inhibition in bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (BALF) or peritoneum and an increase in eosinophil numbers in bone marrow.</Species>
<Species>Thus, a basic level of IL-5 may be essential to drive eosinophils from bone marrow to blood and tissues, and for the maintenance of eosinophilia in infected animals.</Species>

<Species>We may also conclude that when eosinophils have already migrated to the lungs, TRFK-5 has no power to inhibit eosinophilia, which is also under control of local lung cells producing IL-5.</Species>

<Species>In this way, only one later TRFK-5 treatment may not be sufficient to modify the lung parenchyma microenvironment, since T. canis antigens had already stimulated some cell populations to produce IL-5.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>When infected guinea-pigs were treated with mAb anti-11-5 (TRFK-5) given at the same time or 1 or 3 days after infection, there was a high percentage of reduction of eosinophil counts 18 days after infection.</Species>

<Species>However, when the mAb was administered during the peak of eosinophilia, there was high inhibition in blood, no inhibition in bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (BALF) or peritoneum and an increase in eosinophil numbers in bone marrow.</Species>
<Species>Thus, a basic level of 11-5 may be essential to drive eosinophils from bone marrow to blood and tissues, and for the maintenance of eosinophilia in infected animals.</Species>

<Species>We may also conclude that when eosinophils have already migrated to the lungs, TRFK-5 has no power to inhibit eosinophilia, which is also under control of local lung cells producing 11-5.</Species>

<Species>CACorresponding Author Key words: Eosinophil, Eosinophilia by Toxocara canis, IL-5 in eosinophilia, Toxocara canis Introduction treatment in mice infected with Eosinophilia has been associated with parasitic diseases, particularly when the parasites invade the tissues or injure the mucosal surfaces.</Species>

text: <Species>Toxocara canis is an intestinal parasite of dogs, and is the most common aetiologic agent of visceral larva migrans syndrome (VLMS).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>In humans, VLMS results from the ingestion of embryonated eggs of T. canis, that eclode in the small intesfine.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The infective larvae invade the mucosa, move into the liver via the portal circulation, and from there to the lungs.</Species>
<Species>2 Beaver et al., 3 who were the first to describe this syndrome, noted the intense eosinophilia which reaches more than 90% of total leucocyte counts.</Species>
<Species>However, there are few studies regarding the mechanisms involved in the blood and tissue eosinophilia obseeeed in VLMS.</Species>
<Species>Several investigators have suggested a direct correlation between eosinophilia and interleukin5 (IL-5) in human helminth infections4'5 and in experimental animal models.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>67 Inhibition of eosinophilia has been demonstrated by anti-IL-5 24 Mediators of Inflammation Vol 5 brasiliensis, 8 $chistosoma mansoni, Toxocara canis7 and Heligmosomoidespolygyrus.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>1 IL-5 has also been shown to support the terminal differentiation, proliferation of eosinophil precursors 11'12 and eosinophil activation.</Species>
<Species>13</Species>

<Species>Although IL-5 does not demonstrate eosinophil chemotactic activity in vivo14 there is some evidence suggesting that this cytokine may modulate a selective eosinophil accumulation at the site of inflammation.</Species>
<Species>Moreover, Sehmi et a/.15 reported that IL-5 has a selective priming effect on eosinophil migratory response to nonselective chemoattractant mediators in vitro.</Species>
<Species>Also, Moser et a/. 16 have demonstrated that in order to acquire the ability to transmigrate, eosinophils must be primed with IL-5, IL-3 and GM-CSF.</Species>
<Species>Thus, the involvement of IL-5 in eosinophilia is not fully understood.</Species>

<Species>In the present study we have used a guinea-pig model of VLMS to investigate the involvement of IL-5 in eosinophil migration and in the maintenance of eosinophilia in blood, bone marrow, lung and peritoneal cavity.</Species>

text: <Species>However, the treatment of animals with TRFK-5 at the same time of infection, or 1 day or 3 days later ted to a complete inhibition of eosinophil infiltration in the lung parenchyma (Fig. 6C).</Species>
<Species>By contrast, the mononuclear cell infiltration in the lungs was not modified.</Species>

<Species>When the infected guinea-pigs received TRFK-5 1 day before sacrifice (or 17 days post-infection), eosinophil infiltration in the lung parenchyma was also inhibited (Fig. 6D) but not to the same extent as observed in the group receiving TRFK-5 given at the time of infection or 3 days later.</Species>

<Species>Thus, the histological determination of eosinophil infiltration in these lungs corroborates a reduction but not a sizeable inhibition of eosinophil numbers as observed in the BALF of the same infected animals, poorly defined, although T lymphocytes and mast cells appear to be involved in eosinophilia.</Species>

<Species>9'2 IL-5, a T cell-derived factor that regulates B cell functions, is an eosinophil differentiation factor11 as well as a stimulating and survival-prolonging factor specific for eosinophils in vitro.</Species>
<Species>2 Also, several investigators have demonstrated that sTstemic eosinophilia in mice infected with parasites is mediated by IL-5 produced in response to the infection.</Species>

<Species>In the present study, the i.p. administration of the TRFK-5 antibody markedly inhibited the widespread eosinophilia observed in T. canis-infected guinea-pigs, indicating that IL5 participated in a guinea-pig model of VLMS eosinophJlia.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Most of the T. canis larvae which penetrated the intestinal wall had migrated into the liver within 72h after inoculation as demonstrated here and elsewhere.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>2</Species>

<Species>It is apparently during this interval that the worm provides the signals to cytokine-producing cells, which in turn trigger increased serum levels of specific cytokine as demonstrated here for IL-5, 24 to 72 h after infection.</Species>
<Species>The signals may be provided directly by the invading parasite or by cells in response to the parasite.</Species>

<Species>The cytokine pattern that develops at this early stage, probably induced by a T-cell independent pathway, may also influence the pattern of T cell differentiation into a Th2 type, which may be responsible for the second peak of IL-5 observed in our experimental model (Fig. 3), although a second cycle of larval invasion (Fig. 2) with a rapid peak of IL-5 liberation cannot be ruled out.</Species>
<Species>Discussion</Species>

<Species>The results of the present study show that in our experimental model widespread eosinophilia follows the infection of guinea-pigs with second stage eggs from T. canis, as also noted in humans and in other experimental animals.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>7'7 T. canis is a potent stimulus for systemic eosinophilia, since blood, BALF, peritoneum and all tissues examined (kidney, eyes, spleen, thymus, Thus, our results suggest that the eosinophilia against helminth larvae may be initiated by the release of IL-5 when the parasites migrate from the intestine to the liver by stimulation of specific cell populations.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Then, an early release of IL-5 quickly induces eosinophil recruitment, probably first from the stored mature eosinophil pool from vascular endothelium or by the mobilization of eosinophils from extravascular sites to the blood.</Species>
<Species>This fact could explain why we found increased eosinophils first in blood and later in other compartments.</Species>
<Species>The early IL-5 release may also serve as a signal for eosinophil differentiation and maturation in bone marrow.</Species>

<Species>The time inteeeal observed between the first peak of IL-5 release and the increase of eosinophils in blood coincides with that reported to be necessary for eosinophil differentiation and maturation in vitro.</Species>

(A) photomicrographs of lung parenchyma from guinea-pigs infected for 18 days with T. cani,, (B) infected animals which were treated with irrelevant antibody at the time of infection; (C) infected animals which were treated with the mAb TRFK-5 at 3 days after infection; (D) mAb administration 17 days after infection.</Species>

text: <Species>The animals were sacrificed 18 days after infection.</Species>
<Species>Note the intense eosinophil infiltration into the lung in A and B, the inhibition of eosinophils in C and the reduction of eosinophils in D. thereafter.</Species>
<Species>Thus, early and later IL-5 release provides a necessary level of this cytokine, which is involved in the maintenance of eosinophilia.</Species>
<Species>We may assume that the inhibition of the first peak of IL-5 release by TRFK-5 does not permit the subsequent T cell stimulation and differentiation.</Species>
<Species>This may explain the long-lasting effect of TRFK5 treatment observed here and also reported by others.</Species>
<Species>8</Species>

<Species>In agreement with our results, there is an important observation of Svetic et al. 24 showing that a specific and highly reproducible IL-5 gene expression pattern is detectable in Peyer's patches by 6 to 12h after Heligmosomoides polygyrus infection.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The early increase in IL-5 gene expression after infection was probably T cell-independent, inasmuch as it was obseeeed in Peyer's patches of congenitally athymic mice and of conventional mice treated with anti-CD4 30 Mediators of Inflammation Vol 5 and anti-CD8 mAb.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Moreover, Kusama eta/. 25 have observed two peaks of eosinophilia in normal and athymic mice, and suggested that IL-5 observed in the first peak was produced by cells other than CD4 T cells, since anti-CD4 and anti-CD3 mAb reduced only the second peak of eosinophilia in normal mice and slightly reduced the first peak of eosinophilia in both normal and nu/nu mice.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>The local lung cells producing IL-5 may also help us to explain the reason why 12, 17 or 18 days post-infection TRFK-5 treatment only partially inhibits, or does not inhibit eosinophil infiltration into the lungs, as demonstrated in Figs 5 and 6.</Species>

<Species>We may suggest that when eosinophils have already migrated to the lungs, TRFK-5 has no power to inhibit eosinophilia, which is also under control of local lung cells producing IL-5.</Species>

<Species>In this way, only one later TRFK 1996  IL-5 drives eosinophils in guinea-pig 5 treatment may not be sufficient to modify the lung parenchyma microenvironment, since T. canis antigens have already stimulated some cell populations to produce IL-5, as demonstrated by Kusama et aL25These results suggest that eosinophilia in lungs is under the control of different factors when compared to that observed in blood and the peritoneal cavity.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>One of the most important results obtained here was the inhibition of circulating eosinophil numbers by the different mAb treatments, even when the antibody was given at the peak of blood eosinophilia, which was accompanied by an increase of mature eosinophils in bone marrow.</Species>

<Species>This suggests that IL-5, apart from being required for the terminal differentiation of eosinophils in bone marrow, 26 is also likely to drive eosinophils from the bone marrow to the blood and then to the tissues, probably by upregulating VLA-4 expression in eosinophils.</Species>

<Species>Moser et aL have demonstrated that in order to acquire the ability to transmigrate, eosinophils must be primed with cytokines such as IL-5, IL-3 or GM-CSF for expression of adhesion molecules such as VI-4.</Species>

<Species>Recently, Pretolani et al. 27 have indeed shown that an anti-VLA-4 antibody suppresses eosinophil recruitment to lung in the guinea-pig and, as a consequence, inhibits the accompanying bronchopulmonary hyperresponsiveness.</Species>

<Species>In spite of medical help: the puzzle of an eighteenth-century Prime Minister's illness.</Species>
<Species>Abstract Medical History, 1990, 34: 178-184.</Species>
<Species>IN SPITE OF MEDICAL HELP:</Species>

<Species>THE PUZZLE OF AN EIGHTEENTH-CENTURY PRIME MINISTER'S ILLNESS by MARJORIE BLOY * Charles Watson Wentworth, second Marquis of Rockingham, died suddenly and unexpectedly on 1 July 1782, when he was only 52 years old.</Species>
<Species>He had suffered-or enjoyed-ill health all his life but in 1782 appeared to be no worse than he had ever been.</Species>
<Species>His death in London terminated his second period of office as Prime Minister, to which he had been appointed only 14 weeks earlier.</Species>

<Species>In May he had reported to the Duke of Portland that he had "for some weeks past undergone much Pain and much inconvenience from something similar to my old Complaint in my Side and Stomach" but that he felt much better than he had.'</Species>
<Species>By 17 June he was recovering from both influenza and his "old complaint".2 On 1 July he died and on the 20th he was interred in York Minster.</Species>
<Species>The first recorded bout of illness suffered by the marquis, then Lord Higham, was in July 1741 when the 11-year-old was "a little indisposed,</Species>
<Species>something Feaverish</Species>
<Species>I guess it proceeds from Worms and will Soon be removed".3 He also had a rash and it was thought that the cause of the problem was that the boy had overheated himself.4</Species>

<Species>He was still ill at the beginning of August: he had been "much out of order" for a long time but had been recommended to take warm baths by Dr Wilmot and Mr Ranby when they were consulted in London.5 Charles's aunt, Lady Isabella Finch, was sure that the baths "and other Things They'll prescribe will in a short Time entirely Cure his Complaints w[hic]h neither of Them thought proceed from any dangerous</Species>
<Species>Causes".6 In spite of Lady Isabella's hopes, Charles did not greatly improve, even though his mother believed that he continued mending every day.</Species>
<Species>The main reason that Higham and his mother had gone to London to consult Dr Wilmot and Mr *Marjorie Bloy, Ph.D., 18 Farm View Road, Kimberworth, Rotherham, S. Yorks.</Species>
<Species>S61 2BA.</Species>
<Species>The Rockingham Papers are in the holdings of the Wentworth Woodhouse Muniments at Sheffield City Archives Department, Sheffield City Library.</Species>
<Species>I am grateful to Dr R. S. Morton for his advice and help with the diagnostic sections of this essay.</Species>
<Species>'</Species>

<Species>An eighteenth-century Prime Minister's illness Ranby was his mother's concern about a "swelling in a certain part which was larger than when we left Wentworth".</Species>

<Species>The doctors hoped that it would burst outwards "which they assure me will be the safest way and give the poor Monkey but very little pain' 7 On 20 August Lord Winchelsea, Higham's uncle, surprised to see the boy so well and brisk, hoped that Charles was "now safe from this complaint"-the same one from which he had suffered in 1738-39-but thought that he would never be safe "if he continues the practice of overheating himself and then drinking Cold Water".</Species>
<Species>He said that Charles was of a "pretty healthy strong Constitution";8</Species>
<Species>Lady Malton was not so sure.</Species>

<Species>The same day she wrote a progress report to her husband saying that Charles's swelling continued to grow, as did the pain "in that part (but not the lease [sic] trouble in making Water or going to Stool) & less Fever than c[oulJd be imagined where Matter is as they now imagine certainly gathering and must end in an operation".</Species>

<Species>In spite of it all, Charles was in fine spirits.9 Lady Malton dosed the boy with cinchona bark, which removed the pains in his legs and reduced his fever, and she was convinced that they would soon have "a clear Stage to act in a proper manner a[bou]t his other Complaints w[hic]h the Learned assure me are to be conquered also".</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>10 Charles was soon allowed to eat meat and Mr Ranby still assured her that the swelling would break outwards.</Species>
<Species>1 " Three days later he decided to lance it, even though Dr Bourne disagreed.</Species>
<Species>The boy's mother was puzzled because the swelling "sometimes pushes forward very fast then retires a little" but the doctor and Ranby seemed happy with his condition.'2</Species>

<Species>At this point the letters cease, presumably because Malton arrived in London with his daughters, to have them inoculated against smallpox, but a later letter states that surgery to open the swelling was not undertaken.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>13</Species>
<Species>By the end of October the correspondence had recommenced.</Species>
<Species>Charles was ill again.</Species>

<Species>He was just the same as when he left Kensington, so John Bourne had bled him and the child had started on Sir Edward Hulse's prescription, unfortunately not defined in the letter, but which was apparently as bad as the last one, if not worse.</Species>

<Species>Lady Malton thought that "with such a State of Blood the Continuation of Health cannot be expected" but was hopeful that the "Cinnabar may prove a more Efficacious remedie than any than has been tryed yet""."4</Species>
<Species>That night she applied "a Blister ... without the least Symptom or tendency to anything like Strangury".</Species>

<Species>He bore the treatment well, as he had done three years previously, and it seemed so successful that Lady Malton was "determined to keep it running full as long as I did last time by the help of John Borne</Species>
<Species>[sic] with much ease to the Dear Child".'5</Species>

<Species>179 Marjorie Bloy continued with the blister and applied "ointment with flyes", apparently some sort of irritant potion, with no sign of strangury.</Species>
<Species>Charles found her treatment "not near the pain he expected" and she was "full of hopes that he will rec[eiv]e great benefit from it".1</Species>

<Species>Apart from his other troubles, one of Charles's knees had swollen but this had much abated since the application of the blisters which Lady Malton believed "must be acting upon the whole Mass of Blood" since it had "reached the remote part".</Species>
<Species>She thought that Sir Edward Hulse's powders were too slow in taking effect although the boy took them very quietly.'7</Species>

<Species>Sir Edward did not "apprehend any great danger from the Siziness [thickness] of Charles' blood"; Lady Malton thought that the condition was the cause of all the child's problems, which would not end until it was set to rights.</Species>
<Species>At any rate, he was fit enough to go hunting.</Species>
<Species>'8 Charles continued in the same state of health.</Species>
<Species>He slept well at night, ate more than his mother thought was good for him, and was able to exercise strenuously without tiring.</Species>
<Species>He put on no weight though, and "as for them swellings at his throat, they are almost gone one day and rise the next".</Species>
<Species>His mother did not expect a speedy recovery and "if the D[octo]rs think him in a good state of health now, I s[houl]d be glad to see him in a better".'9</Species>

<Species>He began to improve and by the end of November even she thought he was on the mend and gaining weight.20 Unfortunately, Lady Malton again had cause for concern over his health in January 1742 when he began to suffer from an intermittent hoarseness.2'</Species>
<Species>Otherwise he was as well as one could expect, with no other complaints.22</Species>
<Species>It was not to last.</Species>
<Species>In May 1742 Charles and his mother were again in Bristol, taking the waters because he had been indisposed.</Species>
<Species>Lady Malton thought the waters were doing them good because they were both being violently sick.23</Species>
<Species>However, Charles had had no dinner on 25 or 26 May and was hot, lazy, and inclined to stir, "from which I conclude he is not well, . . .</Species>
<Species>and therefore Intend to give him a gentle Vomit ... and to let him take his old Remedie the Salt Draughts for a few Daies which I dare say will set him quite to rights".24</Species>
<Species>By 29 May Dr Boume had bled the boy "which succeeded very well but ... found it [his blood] as bad as ever".</Species>
<Species>The waters were not working "but there is a great deal for them to do which grant God they may effect".</Species>

<Species>The weather had turned warm so Lady Malton had "shorn him ... which has display'd a most scabby head and indeed several other untoward Blotches he has out upon other parts of his Body", which made her uneasy.25</Species>
<Species>The blotches on his head were not numerous "yet they made up in quality for so virulent a Corrosive Humour is not easily conceived without seeing it".</Species>
<Species>The pustules on his body were of the same sort 16 WWM, M7-17.</Species>
<Species>Lady to Lord Malton, 4 November 1741.</Species>
<Species>7 WWM, M7-18.</Species>

<Species>180 An eighteenth-century Prime Minister's illness and his mother intended to put plasters on them to prevent them from spreading.</Species>

<Species>Charles was also feverish; his glands were swollen and his pulse was erratic "but out of compassion to you I must tell you that he is with me as Brisk and lively as you ever Saw him".</Species>
<Species>Lady Malton had called in two eminent Bristol men, Dr Logan and Mr Pye, to treat the boy; Mr Pye prescribed "the Precipitate Per se" as the cure for the "hectic".</Species>
<Species>Pye made it himself and said that it was the only remedy that would work.</Species>
<Species>Clearly Charles was impatient to be cured because he told his mother to give him the medicine "to cure me which I am sure it will do or shoot me through the head at once".</Species>
<Species>She thought that this attitude was "odd from one of his Age and [it] does not a little disturb".26</Species>

<Species>The blotches began to burst and indent but the doctor thought that all would be well in the end.27 Meanwhile, Charles was still losing weight even though "he had none to spare before" and he was inclined to be lazy which was not his natural turn.</Species>
<Species>His father recommended some unknown cure which he called Gascoin's Powder-a dose of five grains made up with syrup into a pill-every night.</Species>
<Species>To make matters worse, the doctors disagreed about the treatment.</Species>

<Species>"Dr Pye is Vehemently for the P. Per se, Dr Logan saies that it is a Medicine that may prove too rough in its operation for his Constitution & therefore begs a tryal of Beazor mineral</Species>
<Species>[gall stones from a goat] and Viper Broth".</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The Bristol water had not yet acted "because his case is of too obstinate a Nature" and Lady Malton herself was satisfied that since nothing else had worked to cure the boy, the time had come to try mercurials, even though she knew that they were "powerful and perhaps in some cases hazardous</Species>
<Species>medicines".28 She wanted to see some remedy succeed but was "afraid of violent ones and at the same time vastly distrustfull</Species>
<Species>[sic] of mild ones".</Species>
<Species>It would appear that the "precipitate Per se", probably mercury-based, could be a kill-or-cure remedy.</Species>

<Species>Her "terrors" did not arise from any immediate danger to her son, and her "perfect Knowledge" of his disorder convinced her that whatever remedies he took, the cure was in the hands of God.29 To add to Charles' disorders, on 12 June he developed a "very inflamed bad Eye ... the same Eye that ... he did not see so well of [as] the other ...</Species>
<Species>He sais</Species>
<Species>[sic] that from that eye Alone he can Scarcely distinguish anything".</Species>

<Species>The doctors suggested bathing the eye: Lady Malton knew that the "frightful symptoms" which were "shocking to behold" were a result of "the Same as produces all the rest of his complaints in whichever Shape they appear".</Species>
<Species>30 The eye was very bloodshot and inflamed; the eyelid was swollen so he could hardly open it.</Species>

<Species>The other eye was dull and "he had very little sight of it".31 By 14 June the eye problem had eased somewhat but Lady Malton could find no cause to attribute the improvement to any of the "cures".</Species>

<Species>Charles was still being subjected to Bristol water, Beazor mineral, Viper broth, cinnabar and the precipitate per se.32 She decided to take the boy home to Wentworth because he was 26 WWM, M7-38.</Species>
<Species>Lady to Lord Malton, 1 June 1742.</Species>
<Species>27 WWM, M7-39.</Species>

<Species>1742.</Species>
<Species>181</Species>
<Species>Marjorie Bloy more likely to recover there than anywhere else.33</Species>
<Species>He still ate and slept well and was "pretty cheerful but his looks are bitter bad still.</Species>
<Species>The flesh he lost in the Accidental Feavour he has not Recover'd and his complexion is of the most sickly sort his hands of the same Hue his legs are tollerable</Species>
<Species>[sic] well".34 They returned to Wentworth in short stages and by 6 September Higham was "perfectly recovered . . .</Species>

<Species>after the long and successful Care that Lady Malton has taken" of him.35 In May 1743 he was inoculated against smallpox and made a perfect recovery after which he caught cold "by stripping when He was hot".36 Lord Higham does not seem to have been seriously ill after that until, at the age of 19, he undertook his Grand Tour in 1749.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In July 1750, by then Lord Malton, he had cause to consult Nicolo Scanagati in Padua for the treatment of gonorrhoea.</Species>

<Species>Scanagati produced a lengthy medical report of Malton's treatment, presumably for his English doctor's enlightenment.37 The initial treatment was an "electuary, consisting of three ounces of emollient, three drams of powdered jalap, a half [dram] of purified nitre, bound together with lemon juice taken twice a day".</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The result was satisfactory: "The dark greenish poison was oozing slowly from his penis, which was all contracted and the sharp and constant pain extended from the perineum up to the urinary bladder, producing small swellings now in this place, now in that."</Species>
<Species>There was a fierce burning sensation in the glands, which prevented him from sleeping.</Species>

<Species>Because of this, it seemed reasonable to bathe that part in tepid water and milk, and to apply poultices to the areas affected by swelling and contractions, together with cold drinks and a few grains of laudanum at night.</Species>

<Species>Malton was blooded regularly besides being given purgatives; the treatment then moved on to the administration of mercury, both internal and on the gums, since it was widely believed at the time that gonorrhoea and syphilis were steps of the same disease, "the Venereal".</Species>
<Species>Scanagati at this point ruled out the suggestion of syphilitic chancre because Malton's urine was fine and light with a pungent odour.</Species>
<Species>Scanagati did ask if Malton had previously ever had a similar peculiarity of his urine.</Species>

<Species>Malton replied that when he was very young and still inexperienced sexually, for some time following a fever he had had the same unusual urine, and indeed that on one occasion this symptom coincided with certain tumours on the testicles.</Species>

<Species>It was only by chance that he had not had recourse to surgery, the reason being that he was also afflicted with a throat infection-to which he was prone-and therefore had his vein opened four times.</Species>
<Species>Thereupon the inflammation subsided, and equally the tumours and sediment disappeared.</Species>

<Species>He told me that as a youth he had sometimes experienced some difficulty and a burning sensation when urinating, which subsided when his blood was let and with the application of poultices.</Species>

<Species>I observed that from time to time his face and body were covered with purplish spots, which, having produced a little fluid, would disappearas indeed happened in the course of the cure, at the end of which his face was entirely 33 WWM, M7-47.</Species>
<Species>Lady to Lord Malton, 15 June 1742.</Species>

<Species>36 WWM, M2-135.</Species>

text: <Species>What does all this add up to in terms of diagnosis?</Species>
<Species>The early illness is a mystery.</Species>
<Species>Did he have an inguinal hernia; or perhaps mumps or epididymitis?</Species>
<Species>His was a childless marriage.</Species>
<Species>He seems to have been too fit for the illness to have been rheumatic fever.</Species>
<Species>Cystitis was not uncommon and this could certainly lead to "strangury".</Species>

<Species>Perhaps Rockingham suffered from a congenital defect of his urinogenitary system which would result in recurrent attacks of cystitis and might cause long-term damage to the urinary tract and eventual destruction of the kidneys, precipitating sudden and unexpected death.</Species>
<Species>Another possibility might be diabetes.</Species>

<Species>Rockingham had a urinary infection and certainly suffered from recurrent skin infections, although it appears from Scanagati's report that these cleared up when mercury was administered.</Species>
<Species>Certainly the marquis complained often about pains in his side and stomach and made no secret of his "old complaint".</Species>

<Species>He was noticeably less physically active as he moved into his thirties and only occasionally exerted himself by riding any distance, even though he had enjoyed hunting when he was younger.</Species>

<Species>He found the pains caused by his "old complaint" made him feel so ill that he was unable to concentrate on "any Manner of Business" and on occasion it seemed likely to prevent him from attending Parliament.38</Species>

<Species>He may well have suffered from a problem with gallstones from an early age.39 He appears to have suffered from a nervous disorder which manifested itself in severe palpitations, trembling, and other types of physical discomforts such as boils and headaches with which he was frequently afflicted.40</Species>
<Species>He probably had constipation too, since he was always dosing himself with purgatives.</Species>

<Species>In fact in April 1772 the Duke of Richmond decided that Rockingham's real problem was a "surfeit of physick"41 although Edmund Burke noted in June 1772 that the marquis had had a long and severe illness.42 Whatever his many and varied ailments, Rockingham survived until he was 52 in spite of the attentions of both doctors and quacks and that, for the mid-eighteenth century, was a good age.</Species>
<Species>The mystery still remains, however.</Species>

<Species>Emergence of Delayed Methylmercury Toxicity after Perinatal Exposure in Metallothionein-Null and Wild-Type C57BL Mice</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Abstract Background Although a long latency period of toxicity after exposure to methylmercury (MeHg) is known to exist in humans, few animal studies have addressed this issue.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Substantiation of delayed MeHg toxicity in animals would affect the risk evaluation of MeHg.</Species>

<Species>Objectives Our goal in this study was to demonstrate the existence of a latency period in a rodent model in which the toxicity of perinatal MeHg exposure becomes apparent only later in life.</Species>
<Species>Our study included metallothionein (MT) knockout mice because studies have suggested the potential susceptibility of this strain to the neurodevelopmental toxicity of MeHg.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Methods Pregnant MT-null and wild-type C57Bl/6J mice were exposed to MeHg through their diet containing 5 ug Hg/g during gestation and early lactation.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We examined behavioral functions of the offspring using frequently used paradigms, including open field behavior (OPF), passive avoidance (PA), and the Morris water maze (MM), at ages of 12-13 and 52-53 weeks.</Species>
<Species>Results At 12 weeks of age, behavioral effects of MeHg were not detected, except for OPF performance in MeHg-exposed MT-null females.</Species>
<Species>At 52 weeks of age, the MeHg-exposed groups showed poorer performance both in PA and MM, and their OPF activity differed from controls.</Species>
<Species>These effects of MeHg appeared exaggerated in the MT-null strain.</Species>
<Species>The brain Hg concentration had leveled off by 13 weeks of age.</Species>

<Species>Conclusions The results suggest the existence of a long latency period after perinatal exposure to low-level MeHg, in which the behavioral effects emerged long after the leveling-off of brain Hg levels.</Species>
<Species>Hence, the initial toxicologic event responsible for the late effects should have occurred before this leveling-off of brain Hg.</Species>
<Species>Methylmercury (MeHg) poses serious and practical concerns for human populations regarding perinatal exposure.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Fish, especially large predator (carnivore) fish species, accumulate high concentrations of MeHg through the marine food chain, and exposure of pregnant women to MeHg through the consumption of fish has evoked widespread concern due to potential effects on offspring.</Species>

<Species>Two large-scale cohort studies in fish-eating populations of Seychelles and Faroe islanders are being conducted; although the former has not found consistent adverse developmental effects of MeHg (Myers et al. 2007), the latter has reported adverse effects (Debes et al. 2006).</Species>
<Species>Fundamental reasons for this discrepancy have not been completely elucidated, and many questions remain regarding the neurotoxicity of MeHg, despite extensive study.</Species>

<Species>Among the unanswered questions is whether there is a long latency period for behavioral manifestations after exposure to MeHg (Clarkson and Magos 2006; Landrigan et al. 2005; Rice 1996; Weiss et al. 2005a, 2005b).</Species>
<Species>Typical examples of latent toxicity in humans, including both acute and chronic MeHg exposures, have been described in detail elsewhere (Weiss et al. 2005a).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Davidson et al. (2006) recently suggested that effects of perinatal exposure to MeHg may emerge 9 years after birth in the Seychelles cohort.</Species>

<Species>Consequently, risk assessments of MeHg exposure could be inaccurate because studies (human or animal) usually do not focus on later stages of life and therefore could miss delayed effects.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The possibility of delayed toxicity is exemplified by the expanded Barker hypothesis, which posits that the origin of some neurodegenerative diseases such as Parkinson and Alzheimer diseases lies in early exposure to environmental chemicals (Landrigan et al. 2005).</Species>

<Species>Although epidemiologic evidence would be ideal for exploring the possibility of delayed toxicity (and, indeed, data from epidemiologic studies form the basis of current risk assessment for developmental toxicity of MeHg), considering the complex effects of numerous potential confounders and the existence of multiple exposures in human populations, animal models would likely make important contributions to this field.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Although numerous animal studies have described the developmental neurotoxicity of MeHg (Watanabe and Satoh, 1996), few have addressed the latency issue.</Species>
<Species>Few studies have evaluated the neurobehavioral effects in rodents longitudinally beyond 6 months after perinatal exposure.</Species>

<Species>Spyker (1975) addressed this issue in her pioneering work, reporting the late development of behavioral toxicity in mice prenatally exposed to MeHg; it appeared, however, that the substantial mortality and retarded growth among the exposed mice were apparent before weaning, indicating that the doses used (even though some lower dose levels were included) exerted severe toxicity.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Using a relatively complex schedule-controlled operant behavior method, rats whose parents were exposed to MeHg (0.5 or 6.4 mg/L) from 4 weeks before mating and continuing to postnatal day (PND) 16 were shown to be less sensitive to a change in the reinforcement schedule than were their nonexposed counterparts at 28-32 months of age (Newland et al. 2004).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Mice that were perinatally exposed to 1 or 3 mg/L MeHg in drinking water did not show significant deviation from controls in behavioral performance (motor performance, memory, and learning) at 5, 15, or 26 months of age, but the lifetime-exposed groups did show a significant deviation (Weiss et al.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>2005c).</Species>

<Species>The existence of a latency period (i.e., the absence of effects earlier in life followed by the emergence of effects at a later stage of life) has not been demonstrated in any rodent study.</Species>
<Species>In nonhuman primates, delayed emergence of the signs of neurotoxicity was observed several years after the cessation of a 7-year postnatal exposure (Rice 1996).</Species>
<Species>Metallothionein (MT) protects against the toxicities of a variety of metals.</Species>

<Species>We examined the neurotoxicity and developmental toxicity of metallic Hg in MT I/II-knockout mice (Yoshida et al. 2004) and demonstrated the susceptibility of this genetically manipulated strain to the toxicity of metallic Hg.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In contrast to metallic Hg, MeHg does not induce MT, and MT would not substantially influence the kinetics of MeHg (Yasutake et al. 1998).</Species>
<Species>Several reports, however, have demonstrated protective effects of MT against MeHg toxicity, which was ascribed to the radical scavenging effect of MT (Yao et al. 2000).</Species>

<Species>We also showed that perinatal exposure to MeHg results in altered metabolism of thyroid hormones in neonates that was more distinct in MT-null strains than their wild-type counterparts (Mori et al. 2006).</Species>
<Species>The vulnerability of the MT-null strain suggests that delayed neurobehavioral toxicity due to MeHg, if it does exist, might be more distinctive in this strain.</Species>

<Species>By utilizing the MT-null strain, we aimed to answer the following two questions: First, could we generate a model in which the toxicity of MeHg would emerge or at least become exaggerated later in life as opposed to earlier in life (i.e., at 3-6 months, which was the timing for most of the earlier studies that used behavioral evaluations)?</Species>
<Species>Second, would the MT-null strain be affected more than its parent C57BL strain?</Species>

<Species>Answering either of these questions not only could influence the risk evaluation of MeHg, but it could also lead to a better understanding of the mechanism of toxicity for perinatal MeHg exposure.</Species>

<Species>To address these issues, we used three behavioral paradigms, the open field (OPF), passive avoidance (PA), and Morris (water) maze (MM) tests, which are often used in this field and which we used in our previous studies on the effects of Hg vapor (Yoshida et al. 2004, 2006).</Species>
<Species>Performances in the MM and PA are said to be the most sensitive to aging (Gower and Lamberty 1993).</Species>
<Species>We used a dose of 5 ug MeHg/g in the diet, which resulted in a brain Hg level relevant to human risk assessment.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We evaluated the behavioral end points twice, once around 3 months of age and the other time around 1 year; the latter time roughly corresponds to the period when many behavioral performances, including OPF (Acevedoa et al. 2006; Carrie et al. 1999;</Species>
<Species>Gower and Lamberty 1993), PA (Gower and Lamberty 1993), and MM (Bach et al. 1999; Carrie et al. 1999), show alterations in this mouse strain.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Materials and Methods Animals and MeHg exposure OLA129/C57BL/6J strain mice (wild type) and MT I/II-knockout mice (MT-null) of this strain were provided by K.H. Choo of the Murdoch Institute, Parkville, Australia (Michalska and Choo 1993) and were of a mixed genetic background of 129/Ola and C57BL/6 strains.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>F1 hybrid mice were mated with C57BL/6 mice for six generations at the National Institute for Environmental Studies (Tsukuba, Japan).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>At 10 weeks of age, single male and female mice were allowed to cohabit; every female mouse was checked each morning for the presence of a vaginal plug.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>When a plug was confirmed, the day was designated as day 0 of gestation (GD0).</Species>

<Species>The diet, NIH-07PLD formula (CLEA Japan, Inc., Tokyo, Japan), contained vitamins and trace elements as follows (per kilogram diet): 3.2 mg CuSO4, 88 mg FeSO4, 149 mg MnSO4, 25 mg ZnCO3, 1.6 mg Ca(IO3)2, 11 mg vitamin B1, 4.7 mg vitamin B2, 1.9 mg vitamin B6, 44 mg vitamin E, in addition to 5 ug MeHg/g.</Species>
<Species>This diet was fed to the pregnant mice starting from GD0 through 10 days after delivery (i.e., PND10).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Thereafter, we switched mice to a diet that did not contain MeHg.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We chose GD0 as the beginning of exposure because exposures that started before conception often resulted in fairly high Hg concentrations in fetal/neonatal brains (Kakita et al. 2003), and we chose PND10 to cover the early neonatal period, in which considerable brain growth occurs.</Species>
<Species>In our experimental setting, the neonatal mice started to eat from the diet bucket and drink from the water bottle from PND10 onward.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Control mice were kept on the same diet but without MeHg (< 0.01 ug</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Hg/g).</Species>

<Species>On PND1, to avoid the confounding effects due to different litter size, we reduced each litter to six pups (three males and three females when possible), and on PND10, two males and two females from each litter were killed for chemical analyses.</Species>

<Species>The remaining male and female offspring per litter were weaned on PND28 and used for subsequent behavioral analyses (either at 12-13 weeks or 52-53 weeks, depending on the litter) as described below.</Species>
<Species>We measured body weights of the weaned mice every 2 weeks.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Thus, four experimental groups were used (with or without MeHg exposure for two strains), and each group consisted of 12-13 litters.</Species>

<Species>For half of the litters, the behavioral analyses were conducted at 12-13 weeks of age, and upon completion of the behavioral analyses, the animals were killed under ether anesthesia.</Species>
<Species>We then dissected the organs (brain, liver, and kidneys) for Hg analyses.</Species>
<Species>For the remaining half of the litters, we conducted the behavioral tests at 52-53 weeks of age.</Species>

<Species>The mice were treated humanely and with regard to alleviation of suffering according to the National Institute for Environmental Studies    Guidelines for Animal Welfare and the guidelines of St. Marianna University.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Behavioral evaluations The details of each behavioral procedure have been described elsewhere (Yoshida et al. 2006).</Species>
<Species>Brief descriptions follow.</Species>
<Species>For the OPF test, we used an OPF apparatus (Ohara Co., Ltd., Tokyo, Japan) with a 60 x 60-cm floor surrounded by walls 60 cm high.</Species>
<Species>The experimental room light was turned off, and a dim light of 80 lux was lit during the experiment.</Species>
<Species>We placed a mouse in the center of the floor and monitored its behavior for 10 min using a CCD camera connected to a computer.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The position of the center of gravity was calculated by image-analyzing software, which was used to calculate the total distance traveled by the mouse as well as the positional preference (either center or peripheral, where peripheral was defined as the area within 10 cm from the wall).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We cleaned the OPF apparatus with 70% ethanol between trials.</Species>
<Species>The apparatus for the PA test (Ohara Co. Ltd.) consisted of a light compartment that illuminated by a 400-lux light and a dark compartment with black opaque walls and lids.</Species>
<Species>The two compartments were separated by a mobile guillotine door.</Species>
<Species>On the first day (training trial), we placed each mouse in the light compartment facing away from the guillotine door, which was closed.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>After 30 sec of introduction, the door was opened; when the mouse entered the dark compartment, a brief electric shock (4 mA for 2 sec) was delivered through the metal grid floor.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>This would force the mouse back to the light component.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The interval between the opening of the door and the entry to the dark room (in seconds) was recorded and defined as the latency.</Species>
<Species>On the next day, the same procedure was repeated, but without the electric shock (retaining trail).</Species>
<Species>In this PA paradigm, aversive learning was assumed to be established in the training trial, and we used its retention in the retaining trail as the index of learning.</Species>
<Species>Between each individual trial, we cleaned the apparatus with ethanol.</Species>
<Species>The cutoff time of the retention session was 300 sec.</Species>
<Species>The MM test apparatus (Ohara Co., Ltd.) was a round-shaped water pool with a diameter of 120 cm.</Species>
<Species>A small platform was submerged in the water, which provided a place for mice to escape from the water (i.e., an aversive stimulus, water temperature = 23 + 1oC).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The water was made opaque by adding white paint so that the mouse could not see the submerged platform.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In each trial, we released a mouse into the pool from a determined position along the wall, and the performance of the mouse was monitored by a CCD camera/image analyzer.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The time required to reach the platform was recorded.</Species>
<Species>If a mouse could not find the platform within 60 sec after release, it was led to the platform and placed on it for 20 sec before being removed.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In these cases, a latency of 60 sec was recorded.</Species>
<Species>We conducted the trial once a day up to the fifth day for each mouse, and the order of each mouse was counterbalanced across the day.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>On the sixth day, a transfer test (or probe test), which is a trial without the platform, was conducted; in this procedure, we counted the number of times that the mouse crossed the position where the platform had been.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Tissue Hg concentration The tissue samples were homogenized (10% weight/volume) in distilled water using a Polytron homogenizer (Kinematica GmbH, Littau, Switzerland).</Species>

<Species>We determined Hg levels in the homogenates by the oxygen combustion-gold amalgamation method (Ohkawa et al. 1977) using an atomic absorption Hg detector MD-1 (Nippon Instruments, Co. Ltd., Osaka, Japan).</Species>

<Species>To ensure the accuracy of the measurement, we included reference material from a dogfish (DORM-2; National Research Council of Canada, Ottawa, Ontario, Canada) with a certified value of 4.64 + 0.26 ug/g in the analyses; the observed values fell within the certified range.</Species>
<Species>The detection limit of the measurement was 0.1 ng Hg.</Species>
<Species>Statistics We analyzed behavioral data for OPF and PA by analysis of variance (ANOVA), taking sex, strain, and MeHg exposure as the factors.</Species>
<Species>All the interactions among these factors were put into the model.</Species>

<Species>When any of the interactions was highly significant, we analyzed the data separately in an appropriate way; for example, if sex x Hg was significant, the data for males and females were separately analyzed for the effects of strain and Hg.</Species>
<Species>Whenever appropriate, ANOVAs were followed by Mann-Whitney U or Student   s t-tests, depending on the nature and distribution of the variables.</Species>
<Species>We analyzed data for the MM by repeated-measures ANOVA, taking the exposure as between-group and trials as within-group variables.</Species>
<Species>The test was performed for each of the four sex and strain combinations separately.</Species>
<Species>The significance level was set at p < 0.05.</Species>
<Species>Results Body weight Up to 20 weeks of age, the body weight values of the control and MeHg-exposed groups were not different, regardless of strain or sex.</Species>
<Species>After 28 weeks, except for the wild-type female groups, the MeHg-exposed groups weighed significantly less than the controls (Figure 1).</Species>
<Species>OPF</Species>

<Species>At 12 weeks of age, a three-way ANOVA of the locomotion distance revealed that only strain was a significant factor (p < 0.001), reflecting the longer distance traveled by the MT-null mice (Figure 2A).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Strain was also a significant factor for the proportion of the central-area locomotion (Figure 3A), and Hg exposure marginally affected this outcome.</Species>

<Species>In MT-null females, the proportion of central-area locomotion was higher in MeHg-exposed mice than in the controls; this difference was not observed in any other strain-sex combination.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>At 52 weeks of age, the strain x Hg interaction was highly significant (p < 0.001) in an ANOVA of locomotion distance (Figure 2B); MeHg exposure was associated with decreased locomotion distance in wild-type mice and with increased distance in MT-null mice.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>A strain-wise two-way ANOVA (with sex and Hg as the factors) revealed that only Hg was significant in both strains (p < 0.01).</Species>

<Species>Regarding the proportion of the central-area locomotion, the effects of MeHg appeared to depend on sex [i.e., sex x Hg was highly significant (p < 0.001) in the three-way ANOVA; Figure 3B].</Species>
<Species>Indeed, a sex-wise two-way ANOVA showed significant effects of Hg only in females (p < 0.001).</Species>

<Species>PA At 12 weeks of age, all the groups showed prolonged latency in the second (retention) trial, and no consistent effect of MeHg was recognized regardless of strain or sex (Figure 4A).</Species>

<Species>At 52 weeks of age, a three-way ANOVA revealed a significant interaction between strain and Hg (p < 0.05); strain-wise two-way ANOVAs revealed a significant effect of Hg on learning in MT-null mice of both sexes; these groups of mice showed significantly shorter (less than half) latency times compared to control mice (Figure 4B).</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>A notable difference between the results at 52 weeks of age and those at 12 weeks was that many of the tested mice exceeded the cutoff time in the retention trials at 52 weeks, except for the MT-null groups.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>MM</Species>
<Species>At 13 weeks of age, repeated-measures ANOVA did not indicate any effects of MeHg (Figure 5A).</Species>
<Species>At 52 weeks of age (Figure 5B), wild-type males and MT-null females shared the same statistical results;</Species>
<Species>Hg as well as the Hg x trial interaction were statistically significant.</Species>
<Species>Thus, in both cases, the MeHg groups showed a longer latency, hampering learning performance.</Species>
<Species>Tissue Hg concentration At PND10, which was immediately after the exposure, brain Hg concentrations of the neonatal mice were approximately < 0.5 ug/g (Table 1).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Although the MT-null mice and females showed slightly higher brain Hg concentrations than the corresponding wild-type group and males, respectively, neither of these differences was significant.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>At 13 weeks, when the behavioral tests were completed, the brain Hg concentration was comparable to the control (nonexposed) level (approximately 5 ng/g in both the exposed and control brains).</Species>
<Species>Interestingly, MT-null mice had a significantly lower brain Hg concentration than the corresponding wild-type groups.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Discussion Results of the present study demonstrate the delayed emergence of neurobehavioral toxicity due to perinatal MeHg exposure, which presumably developed after brain MeHg concentrations had leveled off.</Species>
<Species>This emergent toxicity was exaggerated in MT-null mice and was more distinct in females.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>To our knowledge, our findings show the first clear-cut demonstrations of a long latency period of MeHg neurobehavioral toxicity in rodents and possible genetic susceptibility for the emergent toxicity.</Species>
<Species>The exposure level should be considered before discussing the end points.</Species>
<Species>On PND10, immediately after the cessation of MeHg exposure, the brain Hg concentration was approximately 0.5 ug/g, regardless of the strain or sex.</Species>

<Species>In a previous study, the brain Hg concentration in mice perinatally exposed to 6 mg MeHg/L (via water) peaked between PND0 and PND4 and was approximately three times higher than on PND21</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>(Goulet et al. 2003).</Species>

<Species>Therefore, the peak brain Hg concentration, which is presumably observed around birth, can be estimated as about 3-fold higher than that on PND10 and would be approximately 1.5 ug/g (0.5 ug/g x 3), which is one of the lowest levels among recent rodent studies.</Species>

<Species>As shown by Sakamoto et al. (2002) in their Figure 2, prenatal exposure of rats to MeHg showed a peak brain Hg concentration around PND1 that was four to five times greater than the level on PND10.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Also, Newland and Rasmussen (2000) reported a slight alteration of a complex operant behavior in rats at ages < 2 years at brain Hg concentrations as low as 0.5 ug/g at birth, although statistical significance of this particular effect was not clear.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>It should be noted that rats have different Hg kinetics (Hirayama and Yasutake 1986; Yasutake and Hirayama 1990) due to the high affinity of rat hemoglobin for MeHg (Clarkson and Magos 2006).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The most important observation of the present study was that the effects of low-level MeHg exposure were detected only at later stages in the lives of the mice.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Except for the central-area occupancy in OPF in MT-null females, no statistically significant effects of MeHg were observed in any of the three behavioral tests at 12 weeks of age.</Species>
<Species>In contrast, significant effects were observed in all three tests at 52 weeks of age.</Species>

<Species>The brain Hg concentration of the exposed groups had leveled off and was not distinguishable from the non-exposed group at 13 weeks of age, immediately after the first phase of the behavioral testing.</Species>
<Species>Therefore, in the present study, there was a latency period in which the dose and effects could not be detected, although effects were observed 9 months later.</Species>

<Species>Another notable observation was that the emergent manifestation of toxicity was also recognized in the suppression of body weight (except for wild-type females), which only became apparent on or after 28 weeks of age.</Species>
<Species>The existence of a latency period of as long as several years after chronic (7 years from birth), low-level exposure to MeHg has been described in nonhuman primates (Rice 1996).</Species>
<Species>In that case, however, the Hg concentration in the brain remained elevated, presumably as a result of the long exposure.</Species>
<Species>Indeed, Rice (1996) argued that the minute amount of residual brain Hg could have caused the delayed toxicity.</Species>
<Species>This was clearly not the case in the present study because the Hg concentration leveled off around the time of the first phase of the behavioral study.</Species>
<Species>The absence of behavioral effects at 12 weeks of age ruled out the possibility that the residual behavioral effects were due to elevated Hg early in life.</Species>

<Species>Therefore, the behavioral toxicity that surfaced at 52 weeks of age must have had its origin before the brain Hg concentration leveled off (at or before 13 weeks of age), although the redistribution of Hg to the brain from other sites of deposition, such as the liver, cannot be completely excluded.</Species>
<Species>The long silent period before the manifestations of toxicity emerged suggests that a slow process plays a role in this latent toxicity.</Species>

<Species>Although an example of a slow process is aging, 52 weeks of age might not be sufficiently old for a mouse to be considered aged in the physiologic sense because C57BL/6 mice have a relatively long life span among mouse strains [median survival of 27-31 months (Gower and Lamberty 1993)] and a survival rate at 18-19 months as high as 90% (Institute on Aging HP) (National Institute on Aging 2008).</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Nevertheless, various behavioral examinations have shown age-related changes in the performance of mice at approximately 1 year of age in the OPF (Acevedoa et al. 2006; Carrie et al. 1999), MM (Bach et al. 1999; Carrie et al. 1999), and PA (Gower and Lamberty 1993) tests.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The observed effects of MeHg, including the deterioration in the PA and MM and suppression in the OPF (in wild-type mice), were consistent with these reported effects of aging on behavioral function (in the sense described above), except for the increased OPF activity in the MT-null mice.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Regardless of its neural basis, the basis of neurobehavioral toxicity should be sought in early life stages when the brain Hg concentration is highly elevated (approximately 1.5 ug/g at its peak).</Species>

<Species>Some in vivo experiments have demonstrated several candidate mechanisms of perinatal exposure to MeHg, including abnormal migration of neurons and/or glias (Kakita et al. 2003; Rodier et al. 1984), but at higher Hg concentrations.</Species>

<Species>Using exactly the same exposure protocol as the present study, we found suppressed activity of type III iodo-thyronine deiodinase, a thyroid hormone-metabolizing enzyme, in the brains of PND10 mouse neonates (Mori et al. 2006), consistent with our previous study of higher MeHg doses (Watanabe et al. 1999).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>This perturbation could be one of the candidate mechanisms responsible for the later anomalous behaviors because even a transient change in thyroid hormones during the critical period of perinatal life exerts long-term consequences (Auso et al. 2004).</Species>
<Species>The effects of MeHg at 52 weeks of age were influenced by two potential modifying factors, sex and strain.</Species>
<Species>In the OPF, while the locomotion was affected in both strains (although the direction was opposite), center occupancy was significantly increased only in the MT-null mice.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In addition, the effects on PA were significant only in MT-null mice, whereas MeHg at a higher dose was reported to worsen PA performance in rats (6-8 weeks of age; Sakamoto et al. 2002).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>In addition, body weight gain was suppressed in both male and female MT-null mice, whereas in wild-type mice the suppression was observed only in males.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Taken together, the MT-null strain appeared to be slightly more susceptible to the late-emergent effects of MeHg.</Species>

<Species>Several lines of evidence have shown that MT-I,II is protective against the toxicity of MeHg (Leiva-Presa et al. 2004; Yao et al. 2000), and the present results were basically consistent with these reports.</Species>
<Species>We have also reported the susceptibility of the MT-null strain to the neurotoxic effects of metallic Hg (Yoshida et al. 2004, 2006).</Species>
<Species>The difference in the susceptibility to MeHg between sexes is still debated (Clarkson and Magos 2006; National Research Council 2000; Vahter 2007).</Species>
<Species>In the present study, some responses to MeHg were different between the sexes, including OPF performance at 12 and 52 weeks of age and MM performance at 52 weeks.</Species>
<Species>The fact that the MT-null female group was the only group affected by MeHg at 12 weeks may suggest the particular susceptibility of females in this strain.</Species>
<Species>This point needs to be clarified in further experiments.</Species>
<Species>The question remains of why MT-null mice are susceptible to the delayed neurotoxicity of perinatal MeHg.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Apparently kinetics play only a minor role because the strain did not show distinct effects on the brain Hg concentration at PND10.</Species>

<Species>The significantly lower brain Hg concentration in MT-null mice compared with corresponding wild-type mice at 13 weeks of age indicated that MT-I,II might play a significant role in the retention of Hg (or MeHg).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>This is consistent with the results of studies of metallic Hg exposure (Yoshida et al. 2004, 2005); a lower brain Hg concentration may not guarantee lower toxicity, supporting the protective role of the protein.</Species>
<Species>Earlier studies suggest that brain MT-I,II has an important role both in the response to oxidative injury (Potter et al. 2007) and in the process of aging (Kojima et al. 1999).</Species>
<Species>Therefore, the lack of MT can exaggerate the toxicity of MeHg by enhancing the initial effects due to oxygen radicals and/or by accelerating functional aging.</Species>

<Species>Apart from this, an intriguing possibility is that the brain-specific isoform, MT-III, might contribute to the results we obtained because the expression of MT-III, together with MT-I, is increased in the brain of old rats, resulting in the low availability of free zinc for synapses (Mocchegiani et al. 2004).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The age-dependent expressions of MT isoforms might be modified in MT-null mice.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Results of the present study might allow the possibility of alternative interpretations due to some potentially confounding factors.</Species>
<Species>For example, except for the wild-type females, we observed significant differences in body weight between MeHg-exposed and non-exposed groups.</Species>
<Species>Because these differences only became clear later in life, they might be associated with the toxicity that also emerged later in life.</Species>

<Species>Manipulation of body weight in rodents alters activity levels, although the reported results are not always consistent with each other (Harrison and Archer 1987; Samuelsson et al. 2008).</Species>
<Species>Also, the differential performance in PA could be related with the potential effects of MeHg on (electric) shock sensitivity, which we did not examine.</Species>
<Species>At least one high-dose study with adult rats showed reduced electric sensitivity due to mercury exposure (Wu et al. 1985).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>These possibilities need to be addressed in future studies.</Species>

<Species>To summarize, the present results suggest that an initial (or triggering) toxicologic event occurs before the brain Hg concentration stabilizes and that the nature of this event should be either an acceleration of the aging process or interaction with the aging process.</Species>
<Species>Thus, by identifying the physiologic events associated with the functional aging of the examined behavioral tasks, the fundamental toxicologic scar might be revealed.</Species>
<Species>The Caenorhabditis elegans genome contains monomorphic minisatellites and simple sequences.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Abstract Many species have been shown to contain tandemly repeated short sequence DNA known as minisatellites and simple sequence motifs.</Species>
<Species>Due to allelic variation in the copy number of the repeat unit these loci are usually highly polymorphic.</Species>
<Species>Here we demonstrate the presence of sequences in the genome of the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans which are homologous to two sets of short sequence DNA.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>However, when two independent strains were compared no polymorphism for these sequences could be detected.</Species>

<Species>Images Volume 17 Number 23 1989 Nucleic Acids Research The Caenorhabds elegans genome contains monomorphic minisatellites and simple sequences Andrd G.Uitterlinden, P.Eline Slagboom, Thomas E.Johnsonl and Jan Vijg Department of Molecular Biology, TNO Institute for Experimental Gerontology, PO Box 5815, 2280 HV Rijswijk, The Netherlands and lInstitute for Behavioral Genetics, University of Colorado, Boulder, CO 80309, USA Received October 27, 1989; Accepted November 3, 1989 ABSTRACT Many species have been shown to contain tandemly repeated short sequence DNA kinown as minisatellites and simple sequence motifs.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Due to allelic variation in the copy number of the repeat unit these loci are usually highly polymorphic.</Species>
<Species>Here we demonstrate the presence of sequences in the genome of the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans which are homologous to two sets of short sequence DNA.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>However, when two independent strains were compared no polymorphism for these sequences could be detected.</Species>
<Species>INTRODUCTION</Species>
<Species>The genome of many species, including lower organisms, contain minisatellite sequences and so-called simple sequence motifs (1,2,3).</Species>

<Species>Due to extensive variation in the number of repeat units, many of these loci have been shown useful as polymorphic markers, e.g. for genetic linkage studies and identification purposes.</Species>

<Species>Here we demonstrate that the genome of the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans contains sequences that are homologous to the minisatellite core sequence 33.6 (1) and to the simple sequence motif (AGC)n.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Surprisingly, these sequences did not display polymorphism when two independent C. elegans strains, Bristol and Bergerac, were compared.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>MATERIALS AND METHODS Genomic DNA from nematodes Genomic DNA was isolated according to standard procedures from the two strains Bergerac (BO) and Bristol (strain N2).</Species>
<Species>These strains are derived from two different individual worms isolated in France and England, respectively.</Species>

<Species>Southern blotting Genomic DNA digests (5 Ag) were separated in a 1 % agarose gel in 1 x TAE (40 mM Tris.HCl, pH 7.4/20 mM sodium acetate/I mM NaEDTA) by electrophoresis at 75 V for 16 h. Separation patterns were transferred to Zetaprobe membrane (BIORAD) in 0.4 N NaOH, 0.6 M NaCl in a vacu-blot apparatus (LKB) according to the manufacturer's instructions.</Species>
<Species>The minisatellite and simple sequence probes used were prepared essentially as described (5).</Species>
<Species>The Tcl probe is a plasmid containing an insert of the transposable element Tcl (4).</Species>
<Species>All probes were labelled by random-priming.</Species>

<Species>Hybridization was performed for 12 h in 7 % SDS, 0.5 M phosphate buffer, 1 mM Na2EDTA at 650C. Blots were washed twice in 2.5 x SSC at 650C and exposed to Kodak XAR-5 film with intensifying screens.</Species>
<Species>Exposure times are indicated in Fig.</Species>

label: Species

<Species>Ill a Nucleic Acids Research RESULTS In Figure 1 the hybridization patterns are shown of C. elegans genomic DNA digested with Hae II, Rsa I and Eco RI, and subsequently hybridized to minisatellite core probe 33.6, the simple sequence probe (AGC)n and Tcl.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The latter probe contains a member of the Tcl family of transposable elements which is present in different copy numbers in the two different strains (4).</Species>

<Species>The hybridization patterns of probes 33.6 and (AGC)n obtained after Hae Im and Rsa I digestion and the differences in intensities of the hybridizing bands is reminiscent of DNA-fingerprint patterns obtained with these probes in other species (1,2,3).</Species>
<Species>However, identical hybridization patterns for the two strains with the three enzymes tested indicated that in C. elegans these sequences are monomorphic (Fig. 1).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Based on the number of hybridizing bands we estimate the C. elegans genome to contain about 30 33.6 homologous loci and about 20 (AGC)n homologous loci.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Rehybridization of the same blot with a Tcl probe revealed extensive RFLPs due to the different copy number of the transposon in the two strains, a phenomenon which has been described previously by others (4).</Species>
<Species>DISCUSSION</Species>
<Species>The findings presented in this paper indicate that polymorphism of minisatellite sequences and simple sequence motifs, is not a general phenomenon in animal species.</Species>
<Species>So far, only some species of whales have displayed similar high levels of monomorphism (6).</Species>
<Species>In other species thus far tested both minisatellites and simple sequences display high to very high levels of polymorphism.</Species>

<Species>It should be noted, however, that at least in humans, a substantial part of the minisatellites detected by core probes also displays high levels of monomorphism as analysed by cloning (1) or by two-dimensional DNA fingerprinting (5).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The fact that nematodes are hermaphrodites, and thus inbred, might be a contributing factor to the observed lack of polymorphism.</Species>
<Species>However, the high levels of polymorphism detected by the Tcl probe do not indicate a general absence of events causing genetic variation.</Species>
<Species>Indeed, Eide and Anderson (7) showed that tandemly repeated duplications in the unc-54 gene of C. elegans revert at high frequencies.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Since in all cases the revertants had the normal genomic configuration this suggests that unequal crossing-over does occur in the nematode.</Species>
<Species>A more likely explanation for the monomorphic nature of the sequences detected with 33.6 and (AGC)n in C. elegans is selection against sequence variants at these loci.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>This might be the result of the presence of a particular subset of minisatellites and/or simple sequences at sites in the genome of this organism, e.g. in coding sequences, in which variation in copy number of repeat units cannot be tolerated.</Species>
<Species>An example of such a coding sequence could be the High Mobility Group proteins which usually have stretches of identical (acidic) amino acids (2,8).</Species>

<Species>An interesting observation in this respect is the demonstration of the absence of any protein polymorphisms in electrophoretic comparisons for 24 different enzymes between the Bristol and Bergerac strains (9).</Species>

<Species>An important step in understanding this phenomenon will therefore be the isolation and analysis of individual homologous minisatellite and simple sequence loci from a genomic library of C. elegans.</Species>
label: Species
