<Species>Human growth hormone (GH1) gene polymorphism map in a normal-statured adult population</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Abstract Objective GH1 gene presents a complex map of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in the entire promoter, coding and noncoding regions.</Species>
<Species>The aim of the study was to establish the complete map of GH1 gene SNPs in our control normal population and to analyse its association with adult height.</Species>

<Species>Design, subjects and measurements A systematic GH1 gene analysis was designed in a control population of 307 adults of both sexes with height normally distributed within normal range for the same population:    2 standard deviation scores (SDS) to +2 SDS.</Species>
<Species>An analysis was performed on individual and combined genotype associations with adult height.</Species>

<Species>Results Twenty-five SNPs presented a frequency over 1%: 11 in the promoter (P1 to P11), three in the 5   UTR region (P12 to P14), one in exon 1 (P15), three in intron 1 (P16 to P18), two in intron 2 (P19 and P20), two in exon 4 (P21 and P22) and three in intron 4 (P23 to P25).</Species>
<Species>Twenty-nine additional changes with frequencies under 1% were found in 29 subjects.</Species>
<Species>P8, P19, P20 and P25 had not been previously described.</Species>

<Species>P6, P12, P17 and P25 accounted for 6.2% of the variation in adult height (P = 0.0007) in this population with genotypes A/G at P6, G/G at P6 and A/G at P12 decreasing height SDS (   0.063 + 0.031,    0.693 + 0.350 and    0.489 + 0.265, Mean + SE) and genotypes A/T at P17 and T/G at P25 increasing height SDS (+1.094 + 0.456 and +1.184 + 0.432).</Species>
<Species>Conclusions This study established the GH1 gene sequence variation map in a normal adult height control population confirming the high density of SNPs in a relatively small gene.</Species>
<Species>Our study shows that the more frequent SNPs did not significantly contribute to height determination, while only one promoter and two intronic SNPs contributed significantly to it.</Species>
<Species>Studies in larger populations will have to confirm the associations and in vitro functional studies will elucidate the mechanisms involved.</Species>

<Species>Systematic GH1 gene analysis in patients with growth delay and suspected GH deficiency/insufficiency will clarify whether different SNP frequencies and/or the presence of different sequence changes may be associated with phenotypes in them.</Species>

<Species>Introduction Human skeletal growth and final height attainment are a result of a multifactorial regulation involving systemic and local hormones, growth and nutritional factors, lifestyle and genetic factors.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Heritability estimates1 and genome-wide linkage analysis2 have shown that genetic factors play a major role in determining stature.</Species>

<Species>Among these factors, the GH-IGF-I axis plays an important role during postnatal life, and associations between structural variations in its genes and height are currently under study.3 Although growth hormone (GH) deficiency is a well-known cause of growth retardation, which responds to GH replacement therapy, the diagnosis and physiopathological mechanisms for the so-called    idiopathic isolated GH deficiency    (IIGHD) require further clarification.</Species>

<Species>In addition, GH secretion levels and markers of GH biological activity have been demonstrated to be specific and sensitive only in major deficiency states.4,5 Genetic causes of GH deficiency within the GH1 gene have been established; however, they are rarely recognized and only sought in major GH deficiency states during childhood and in family studies.3 GH1 gene, located at 17q22-24, is a component of the GH gene cluster in which five genes evolving from a common ancestor are 91-99% sequence conserved (paralogues).6 GH1 is more abundantly expressed in pituitary cells, while the other four genes are expressed in placental tissue.</Species>

<Species>Large deletions within the GH1 gene cluster were described first followed by point mutations, the majority of which affect introns 3 or 4, provoke skipping of exon 3 product and exert a dominant effect.3,7,8 More recently, the presence of single nucleotide polymorphic points (SNPs) in the promoter region or in intron 4 of the GH1 gene have been described9-12 and associations with promoter allele activities or with GH secretion efficacy and circulating IGF-I levels in growth-retarded patients have also been described.11,12 Other studies have analysed several GH1 gene SNP genotypes as related to the incidence of neoplasia, with a positive association with colorectal neoplasia for intron 4 SNP,13 a negative result for breast carcinoma14,15 or a positive one for breast cancer risk.16,17 In addition, a recent study in a cohort of adults over ages 60 years detected a significant association between genotypes at one SNP in the GH1 gene promoter region and at the intron 4 SNP described by Hasegawa et al.11 with baseline bone density and accelerated bone loss together with an interaction with weight at 1 year.18 Intron 4 SNP described by Hasegawa et al.11 has also been associated, in women, with shorter body height and reduced mortality,19 whereas another intron 4 SNP (T1169A) has been associated in both sexes with a favourable metabolic profile.20</Species>

<Species>A systematic SNP study was conducted by Adkins et al.21 in GH1 promoter, coding and noncoding regions in DNAs from placental tissues, and analysis of associations between genotypes and birth weight revealed an association between an alternate nucleotide at    1 and +3 of translation initiation site and fetal growth restriction.</Species>

<Species>However, no systematic GH1 gene analysis in the entire promoter, coding and noncoding regions has been conducted in adults to establish the map of structural variation and its possible association with height.</Species>

<Species>The relatively short size of the entire gene permits a complete analysis which is, nevertheless, hampered by the need to avoid amplification of any other of the GH cluster genes (paralogues) and the high density of sequence variations.</Species>

<Species>To obtain normative data for subsequent analysis of GH1 gene contribution to IIGHD in children, a systematic GH1 gene structural analysis was designed in a normal adult control population to establish the GH1 gene SNP map in adults from our population with heights within the normal range, determine the genotype frequencies and analyse possible associations between individual and combined SNPs with height.</Species>

<Species>Subjects and methods Subjects A total of 307 adult subjects of both sexes (164 women and 143 men) were recruited from hospital personnel and parents of patients with no history of growth retardation.</Species>
<Species>Subjects had to fulfil the following criteria: Iberian Peninsular (except Basque) family origin and no family history of pathological short stature.</Species>
<Species>A single subject per family was included.</Species>
<Species>The protocol was approved by the Hospital Vall d   Hebron Ethics Committee and written informed consent was obtained from each participant.</Species>

<Species>Height standard deviation scores (height SDS) were calculated according to sex-specific reference growth charts for the Spanish population (Carrascosa et al.22 charts were used for subjects under ages 30 years and Hernandez et al.23 for subjects aged 30-50 years).</Species>

<Species>Only individuals with height SDS between    2 and +2 SDS were included in the study (mean    0.016; 32 women and 28 men between    2.000 and    1.010; 99 women and 80 men between    1.000 and +0.910; 33 women and 35 men between +1.010 and +1.980) and sample size was adjusted for normal sex and height SDS distribution.</Species>
<Species>Height and weight were recorded in the morning by a single observer.</Species>
<Species>Height was measured with a Harpenden stadiometer.</Species>
<Species>Four millilitres of peripheral venous blood were drawn into EDTA-containing tubes for molecular genetic analysis.</Species>

<Species>Genomic DNA study Genomic DNA was obtained from peripheral blood following the method described by Lahiri and Nurnberger.24 DNA was amplified by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) using a nested strategy.</Species>

<Species>Briefly, 50 ng of genomic DNA were added to a 10 ul reaction mixture of 1 mm Mg(OAc)2, 0.6 mm dNTPs, 0.3 um of each primer, and 0.4 U r Tth DNA polymerase XL (Applied Biosystems, Foster City, CA, USA).</Species>

<Species>The sense and antisense primers used corresponded to nucleotides 4156-5   ACGGTCCGCCACTACGCCCAGC-3    and the complement of 6948-5   TGCAGTGAGCCAAGATTGTGCC-3    of the GH gene cluster.6</Species>
<Species>The PCR reaction mix was denatured for 5 min at 94 oC and cycled 40 times (94 oC, 1 min; 72 oC, 3 min 30 s) followed by a 7-min extension at 72 oC.</Species>

<Species>The resulting GH1 PCR products (2893 bp) were used as templates for five nested reactions (AN, BL, CK, DI, FP), carried out as follows: 1 ul of each GH1 PCR product was added to a 20 ul reaction mixture of 1.5 mm MgCl2, 0.2 mm dNTPs, 0.3 um of each primer and 0.4 U Eco Taq DNA polymerase (Ecogen S.R.L., Barcelona, Spain).</Species>

<Species>Reaction mixtures were denatured for 5 min at 94 oC, cycled 40 times (94 oC, 1 min; 58 oC, 1 min; and 72 oC, 1 min), followed by a 7-min extension at 72 oC. Sense and antisense primers were as follows: Sequencing from both ends was performed by the dideoxy method using ABI PRISM BigDye Terminator version 3.1 Cycle Sequencing Kit (Applied Biosystems, Foster City, CA, USA).</Species>
<Species>GH1 gene nucleotide sequence published by Chen et al.6 was used as control.</Species>

<Species>For each DNA, the five segments from the nested PCR were assembled with the SeqEscape programme (Applied Biosystems) and interpretation was made visually and simultaneously by two observers.</Species>

<Species>Antisense sequencing was performed to confirm each nucleotide sequence change up to the establishment of the more frequent SNP map (frequency over 1%), whereas less frequent single or multiple nucleotide changes were reconfirmed in each DNA by antisense sequence and resequencing after a new nested PCR from original DNA was performed.</Species>

<Species>Single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) genotyping The sequences for the five genes of the GH cluster identified by Chen et al.6 and reported as the GI sequence 183148 were aligned using the Multalin program.25 SNPs and other sequence changes identified were indicated using their position corresponding to GH1.</Species>
<Species>Genotypes were deduced by the combination of genetic variation at the polymorphic positions.</Species>
<Species>Statistical analysis Standardized height was investigated for normal distribution (Kolmogorov-Smirnov test:</Species>
<Species>c2 = 2.882, P = 0.4733).</Species>
<Species>Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium was tested for SNPs presenting three alternate genotypes according to standard procedures using X2-analysis.</Species>

<Species>anova test was applied to investigate individual and combined SNP association with adult height SDS; significance assessment was adjusted for multiple testing using Fisher's PLSD test setting Pcritical = 0.05 or the Bonferroni-Dunn test setting Pcritical = 0.05/n (n = number of comparisons carried out).</Species>
<Species>Stepwise regression analysis was applied to predict the contribution of SNPs to adult height SDS.</Species>
<Species>Statview 4.5 program (Abacus Concepts Inc., Berkeley, CA, USA) was used for statistical analyses.</Species>
<Species>Results GH1 gene sequence variation GH1 gene sequence comparison with the GI-183148 sequence published by Chen et al.6 yielded a total of 54 single or multiple nucleotide changes.</Species>
<Species>Twenty-five SNPs presented a frequency over 1% (genotypes and frequencies are listed in Table 1).</Species>
<Species>SNPs which presented the three alternate genotypes (P2 to P4, P6, P7, P10 and P24) were in Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium (data not shown).</Species>
<Species>Twenty-nine additional changes were found with a frequency under 1% or involving more than one nucleotide and thus could be considered as rare variant SNPs (R1 to R29) (Table 2).</Species>
<Species>These changes were found in 29 of 307 subjects (9.4%), all in heterozygosity.</Species>
<Species>GH1-paralogue alignment A sequence alignment was performed to study possible sequence recombinations among paralogues of the five GH1-gene cluster (Fig. 1).</Species>
<Species>This alignment showed that 9 of 25 SNPs (36%) in the GH1 gene did not correspond to any of the paralogues.</Species>

<Species>Among the 29 rare SNPs found, six (20.7%) did not correspond to any of the paralogues: two were located in the 5   UTR region (R9 and R10), two in intron 1 (positions 5300 = R14 and 5302 = R17), one in intron 2 (position 5679 = R21) and one in intron 4 (position 6344 = R23) (Table 2).</Species>
<Species>Equivalence with previously reported GH1 changes Equivalence with changes and SNPs previously reported by other authors are shown in Table 3.</Species>

<Species>The majority found a high density of SNPs in the promoter and 5   UTR regions in control populations.10,12,21 Several sequence changes have been reported in patients with familial or idiopathic short stature,11,26,27 whereas P8, P19, P20 and P25 (at positions 5165, 5681, 5686 and 6358, respectively, in the Genebank accession GI 183148) located in the promoter, intron 2 and intron 4 regions, respectively, had not been previously described.</Species>

<Species>GH1 genotypes and associations with height SDS Associations between genotypes and standardized height were first studied in the subpopulation of 278 controls carrying only the 25 most frequent SNPs in the GH1 gene (c2 = 2.59; P = 0.5458 for normality of height distribution).</Species>
<Species>Three individual SNPs showed a statistically significant association with height SDS: at positions 5286 (P16), 5290 (P17) and 6358 (P25).</Species>

<Species>Subjects with heterozygous genotypes presented statistically significant taller stature than the corresponding homozygous genotypes (P = 0.016 for P16, P = 0.015 for P17 and P = 0.023 for P25) (Fig. 2a,b,c).</Species>
<Species>P16 and P17 were in linkage disequilibrium (LD) (r2 = 0.831), while P25 was carried by six subjects homozygous at P16 and P17.</Species>
<Species>GH1 gene genotypes were defined by genetic variation in the 25 polymorphic positions.</Species>
<Species>We found 163 different combinations.</Species>
<Species>Only two genotypes presented a frequency over 5% (Table 4).</Species>
<Species>Height SDS in the two more frequent genotypes did not differ significantly and covered the whole height range.</Species>
<Species>Genotype 1 presented four heterozygous variations and Genotype 2 was the corresponding homozygous genotype.</Species>
<Species>Heterozygous positions corresponded to SNPs with the highest frequency variation (4886 (P4), 5107 (P7), 5157 (P10) and 6331 (P24)).</Species>
<Species>In addition, DNAs exhibited a different genotype in each of 129 subjects (46.4%).</Species>
<Species>The 11 SNPs found in the promoter region (Table 1) were grouped in 94 genotypes and analysed for association with adult height SDS.</Species>
<Species>The four more frequent combinations are listed in Table 4: height SDS of these four genotypes did not differ statistically although Genotype 3 tended to have a shorter height.</Species>
<Species>Genotype 3 differed from Genotype 1 in the SNP located at position 5089 (P6), corresponding to Pit 1 proximal responsive element for GH1 gene promoter.</Species>
<Species>Genotype 4 is heterozygous at positions 4856 (P2), 4863 (P3) and 5107 (P7).</Species>
<Species>In addition, 19% of cases exhibited a genotype in the promoter region carried by only one subject.</Species>
<Species>Combination of the three SNPs in the 5   UTR region of GH1 gene resulted in five different genotypes.</Species>
<Species>SNPs at positions 5178 (P12) and 5187 (P13) were in LD (r2 = 0.88).</Species>

<Species>Mean height SDS comparison among these genotypes was not statistically significant, although mean height SDS of alternate nucleotide carriers at position 5178 (P12) tended to be shorter (Table 4).</Species>
<Species>An anova analysis was conducted to investigate the interaction between two or more SNPs and height SDS.</Species>
<Species>SNPs at positions 5286 (P16) and 5290 (P17) were in LD (r2 = 0.83): the heterozygous genotype AG/AT for these SNPs was associated with taller stature (shown above).</Species>
<Species>SNP at position 6358 (P25) increased the expected height SDS for individual carriers of the G allele at 5089 (P6) SNP as shown in Fig. 2(d):</Species>

<Species>subjects heterozygous at 6358 (P25) were taller than the mean, and mean height SDS of subjects with GG/TG combined genotype was significantly higher than the corresponding GG/TT genotype (P = 0.0021), suggesting an interaction between these two SNPs as they were not in LD.</Species>
<Species>Analysis of height SDS association with the most frequent single and combined SNPs and with rare variant SNPs was performed in the 29 individuals carrying the rare SNPs (Table 2).</Species>
<Species>None of them carried any of the three SNPs (P16, P17 and P25) related to taller stature in the population of 278 controls with only the frequent SNPs.</Species>
<Species>In these 29, mean height SDS (0.000 + 0.987, from    1.930 to +1.870) did not differ from that of the 278 controls (   0.018 + 1.041, from    2.000 to +1.980).</Species>

<Species>Analysis of associations between individual SNP genotypes and height SDS revealed that SNPs at positions 5089 (P6), 5178 (P12) and 5187 (P13) were associated with significantly shorter stature (Fig. 2e).</Species>
<Species>Only two sequence changes considered as rare SNPs were carried by individuals in the lower normal height range (between    1.500 and    2.000 SDS)</Species>
<Species>(Table 2): R4 (4979 C > T) in the promoter region and R14 (5300 C > T) in intron 1.</Species>
<Species>Predicted single amino acid changes located in exon 5 (R25 to R27) were not associated with short stature.</Species>

<Species>In the entire population of 307 controls, stepwise regression analysis between height SDS and genotypes at the 25 SNPs showed that genotypes at 5089 (P6), 5178 (P12), 5290 (P17) and 6358 (P25) were significantly correlated with height SDS (r2 = 0.062, P = 0.0007) with genotypes A/G at P6, G/G at P6 and A/G at P12 decreasing height SDS (   0.063 + 0.031,    0.693 + 0.350 and    0.489 + 0.265, respectively, Mean + SE) and genotypes A/T at P17 and T/G at P25 increasing height SDS (+ 1.094 + 0.456 and +1.184 + 0.432, respectively).</Species>

<Species>Discussion Genetic variations within human GH1 gene have been described by several authors.9-12,21 The populations described to date comprised small numbers of normal-stature individuals,9 male adults with narrow height range12 or growth-retarded patients with/without GHD before achievement of adult height.9,11,12</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Our study was designed to characterize the GH1 gene sequence variation in individuals within the whole range of normal adult height (between    2 and +2 SDS) according to the standards for our population.</Species>
<Species>Height was normally distributed, both sexes were equally represented and the GI-183148 homozygous sequence6 was used for comparison.</Species>
<Species>A nested PCR with specific primers for GH1 gene was designed, thus avoiding amplification of any other GH gene paralogue of the GH gene cluster.</Species>

<Species>Our results establish a map of 25 SNPs as present in over 1% of individuals, whereas 29 other sequence changes (single or multiple nucleotide) are present in less than 1% of subjects.</Species>

<Species>More than 50% (n = 14) of SNPs are located in the promoter and 5   UTR regions, thus confirming previous reports: Giordano et al.9 reported eight SNPs in the promoter and 5   UTR regions, Wagner et al.10 16 SNPs from the promoter to intron 1 and Horan et al.12 identified 36 haplotypes in control subjects of the British population, which would result from the combination of 15 of the previously reported SNPs.</Species>

<Species>Our results confirm the presence of 13 of those points; SNP at 5165 (R11 in the present study and +3 in references9,12) was present in less than 1% of subjects and a new SNP is described (P8 at 5116 in the VDR/RA/T3 responsive element sequence).</Species>

<Species>The remaining SNPs (from P15 to P25, n = 11) are distributed in introns 1, 2 and 4, and among coding regions only exon 1 and exon 4 bear a total of three SNPs, two of which predict an amino acid change (P15 and P21).</Species>

<Species>These two latter SNPs had been described by Millar et al.26 and the more frequent SNP in intron 4 (P24) has been described by Hasegawa et al.11 together with the two more frequent SNPs in the promoter region (P4 and P7 in our map).</Species>
<Species>Three new SNPs are described (P19 and P20 in intron 2 and P25 in intron 4), all outside the splice sites.</Species>

<Species>Only SNPs presenting high frequency are present in homozygous alternate state and this accounts mostly for the majority of the promoter and 5   UTR SNPs and in the intron 4 more frequent SNP (P24) described by Hasegawa et al.11</Species>
<Species>In conclusion, in the entire coding and noncoding GH1 gene sequence, only P24 is present in homozygous alternate state.</Species>

<Species>Our results show that the GI 183148 homozygous sequence is present in our population except for SNP P14 in the 5   UTR region which is only present as the alternate nucleotide in homozygous or heterozygous states.</Species>

<Species>As described by several authors9,10,12,21 several promoter SNPs affected functional sequences and P6 is located in the Pit 1 proximal responsive element, P7 and P8 in the VDR/RA/T3 responsive element and P9 (G del) in the TATA box.</Species>

<Species>The mechanisms by which the high density of SNPs in the GH1 gene is generated has been proposed to be recombination and gene conversion with any other(s) of the GH cluster genes.9,12,28</Species>
<Species>Alignment of the 25 SNPs with the other GH1 gene paralogues demonstrated in our results that this mechanism is possible for 64% of SNPs.</Species>
<Species>Familial SNP transmission pattern analysis will be of interest to support the hypothesis of GH gene recombination.</Species>
<Species>In addition, 29 of 307 individuals (9.4%) bore additional GH1 sequence changes with frequencies under 1%.</Species>
<Species>As for SNPs, they are located along the whole gene with higher density in the promoter and 5   UTR regions.</Species>
<Species>Interestingly, intron 3 and exon 5 present several of these less frequent changes.</Species>
<Species>Intron 3 has been shown to carry the majority of single nucleotide mutations causing the dominant form of GH deficiency.3</Species>

<Species>The two single nucleotide changes detected in intron 3 (R15 at 6056 and R16 at 6061) are in perfect LD (r2 = 1.0) and located within the enhancer splice site element (ESE) described by Ryther et al.29,30 Studies in additional normal or growth-retarded populations will permit description of their possible clinical implications.</Species>

<Species>Five single nucleotide changes are located in exon 5; of these five, three predict an amino acid change, and one of the three (Ile179Met) has been described by Lewis et al.27 in a paediatric patient with familial short stature and the other two, as yet undescribed, are contiguous in a single individual (Pro133Hys and Arg134Leu).</Species>
<Species>Polynucleotide changes are mostly located in the promoter region corresponding to the VDR/RA/T3 response element.</Species>

<Species>As for frequent SNPs, the majority of the sequence changes with frequencies under 1% may have been generated by recombination within the GH gene cluster as 19 of 24 (79%) may correspond to one or more of the GH1 gene paralogues.</Species>
<Species>Our results now show the diversity and complexity of SNP genotypes, as previously highlighted by other authors9,10,12,21 in a normal adult height control population.</Species>

<Species>Our initial aim when designing the present study was to establish the map of GH1 gene SNPs in our adult control population with heights normally distributed within the entire normal range for further comparison with genotypes in our paediatric population with growth delay, variable response to GH secretion tests and adequate response to GH therapy.</Species>
<Species>Analysis of SNP association with adult height was subsequently performed to establish a body of knowledge useful for comparing patient genotypes and phenotypes.</Species>
<Species>This analysis was first performed in controls bearing only frequent SNPs (90.5% of the total population).</Species>

<Species>We demonstrate that the four SNPs with the highest allelic variation frequencies (P4, P7, P10 and P24) do not significantly contribute to adult height determination, with the heterozygous genotype being the most frequent followed by the corresponding homozygous genotype in the whole sequence, and heights are normally distributed over the entire height range.</Species>

<Species>The third most frequent combined genotype in the promoter region in our population presented, in addition, in heterozygosity, the SNP at P6 in the sequence regulated by Pit 1 and although mean height of individuals (6.1%) bearing this genotype was around    0.5 SDS, this was not statistically significant.</Species>
<Species>Analysis of single SNP genotype association with adult height yielded few clues as to the contribution of GH1 gene variation to adult height determination.</Species>

<Species>Only three SNPs (P16, P17 and P25), present with low frequency and only in heterozygous state, were individually significantly associated with taller stature and none was individually associated with shorter stature.</Species>
<Species>P16 and P17 (in LD, r2 = 0.83) are located in intron 1 and P25 in intron 4.</Species>

<Species>The resulting sequence for the presence of P16 and P17 corresponded to the paralogue GH2 and generated a responsive element for a core-binding protein (Matinspector Programme, Geometrix Software GmbH, Munchen, Germany) with three Kruppel-type zinc fingers which could increase the efficacy of GH1 gene</Species>

<Species>transcription;31,32 moreover, Kruppel-like proteins have recently been described in the brain.33 Stepwise regression analysis demonstrated that P17 and P25 contribute, separately, to an increase of almost 1.0 height SDS.</Species>
<Species>P16 and P17 had been described by Adkins et al.21 although they found no association with fetal growth, whereas P25 had not previously been described.</Species>
<Species>The mechanisms by which they may determine taller final height should be established by in vitro studies analysing GH1 gene transcription and GH protein translation efficiencies.</Species>
<Species>Analysis of interaction effect between SNPs detected that variation at P25 masked an effect of P6.</Species>

<Species>Individuals homozygous at P25 (TT) present a significant association between P6 genotype and height with the homozygous alternate genotype at P6 (GG) being associated with shorter stature.</Species>

<Species>This was further confirmed in the subpopulation of 29 individuals bearing rare SNPs who, in the absence of heterozygous change at P25, presented significantly shorter stature in the heterozygous alternate nucleotide change at P6 (AG).</Species>

<Species>P6, located at Pit 1 proximal responsive element of the GH1 gene promoter, was first described by Wagner et al.10 and Giordano et al.9 and further by Horan et al.12 Six of nine GH1 gene promoter haplotypes bearing the alternate G at P6 presented lower transcriptional activities and electrophoretic mobility shift assays (EMSA) detected differential protein binding strength, although in vitro studies were unable to identify this SNP as a major determinant of GH1 gene expression level.12 A recent study from Giordano et al.34 has shown a twofold reduced luciferase activity for the G nucleotide bearing promoter haplotype in transfected rat pituitary cells.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Genotypes at P6 had also been associated with decreased breast cancer risk through its association with lower GH secretion and IGF-I circulating levels.16,17</Species>

<Species>In our results, GH1 gene polymorphic structural variation accounted for only 6.2% of adult height determination in the entire adult population studied and genome-wide linkage analysis of stature in multiple populations revealed no linkage with chromosome 17 GH gene cluster.2,35</Species>

<Species>As only some of the less frequent SNPs are statistically associated with height, and in view of the high density of SNPs, our study may be hampered by selection bias36 and would ideally have required a wider sampling of some 2 000 individuals; however, this was a highly laborious strategy when the complete sequencing technique is applied.</Species>
<Species>The high density of SNPs and their proximity hamper other genotyping strategies for rapid determination of the complete GH1 SNP map in large control and patient populations.</Species>

<Species>Individual SNP associations with height or other GH secretion-related phenotypic traits will require further confirmation by studies in larger populations and by in vitro functional studies.</Species>
<Species>In conclusion, our study established the GH1 gene sequence variation map in an adult control population with heights normally distributed within the normal range.</Species>

<Species>SNPs and other sequence change contributions to skeletal growth as observed at adult height demonstrated that, despite the high frequency of variation and diversity and complexity of combinations, only some of the less frequent SNPs were associated with taller stature (P17 in intron 1 and P25 in intron 4), even masking the SNP contribution to a shorter one (P6 in the promoter and P12 in the 5   UTR regions, respectively).</Species>

<Species>Systematic GH1 gene analysis in patients with growth delay and suspected GH deficiency/insufficiency will clarify whether different SNP frequencies and/or the presence of different sequence changes may be associated with phenotypes in them.</Species>
<Species>Rap1p and other transcriptional regulators can function in defining distinct domains of gene expression</Species>

<Species>Abstract Barrier elements that are able to block the propagation of transcriptional silencing in yeast are functionally similar to chromatin boundary/insulator elements in metazoans that delimit functional chromosomal domains.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We show that the upstream activating sequences of many highly expressed ribosome protein genes and glycolytic genes exhibit barrier activity.</Species>
<Species>Analyses of these barriers indicate that binding sites for transcriptional regulators Rap1p, Abf1p, Reb1p, Adr1p and Gcn4p may participate in barrier function.</Species>
<Species>We also present evidence suggesting that Rap1p is directly involved in barrier activity, and its barrier function correlates with local changes in chromatin structure.</Species>
<Species>We further demonstrate that tethering the transcriptional activation domain of Rap1p to DNA is sufficient to recapitulate barrier activity.</Species>
<Species>Moreover, targeting the activation domain of Adr1p or Gcn4p also establishes a barrier to silencing.</Species>
<Species>These results support the notion that transcriptional regulators could also participate in delimiting functional domains in the genome.</Species>
<Species>INTRODUCTION</Species>
<Species>The eukaryotic genome is organized into discrete functional domains in which gene expression is either permitted or repressed.</Species>
<Species>Domains permissive for gene expression are usually defined as euchromatin or active chromatin, and domains that repress gene expression heterochromatin or silent chromatin.</Species>
<Species>The HML and HMR loci in Saccharomyces cerevisiae are silent chromatin domains (1).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Compared to active chromatin, silent chromatin is more compact and its histone components are hypoacetylated (2).</Species>
<Species>The SIR complex consisting of Sir2p through Sir4p is an integral part of yeast silent chromatin.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Sir3p</Species>
<Species>and Sir4p interact with the N-terminal tails of histones H3 and H4 providing the structural basis of silent chromatin (1).</Species>
<Species>Sir2p was recently found to be an NAD-dependent histone deacetylase and was suggested to be responsible for histone hypoacetylation in silent chromatin (3).</Species>
<Species>Silent chromatin is initiated at small cis-acting DNA elements known as the E and I silencers flanking each of the HM loci (4).</Species>
<Species>Increasing evidence indicates that histone deacetylation is key to the propagation of silent chromatin (4).</Species>

<Species>In vertebrates and fission yeast, spread of silent chromatin involves a chain of events of histone H3 deacetylation > H3 methylation > binding of methylated H3 by HP1 (heterochromatin protein 1) or swi6 (4).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In S.cerevisiae, there is evidence that Sir3p (hence the SIR complex) has much higher affinity to unacetylated histone H4 than acetylated H4 (5).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Based on this and the fact that Sir2p is a histone deacetylase, a refined model for the propagation of silent chromatin can be proposed.</Species>
<Species>In this model, Sir2p recruited to the silencer deacetylates histones in an adjacent nucleosome enabling it to bind another SIR complex with high affinity.</Species>
<Species>The nucleosome-bound SIR complex in turn deacetylates the neighboring nucleosome allowing it to recruit a new SIR complex.</Species>
<Species>In this manner, the SIR complex promotes its own propagation along an array of nucleosomes (4).</Species>
<Species>The fact that transcriptionally silent chromatin can encroach upon active chromatin poses the question of how interspersed domains of silent and active chromatin are demarcated.</Species>
<Species>Studies of the Drosophila and vertebrate genomes demonstrated that some domains are delimited by boundary or insulator elements (6).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>These elements are specialized DNA sequences that act as barriers to enhancers and/or silent chromatin.</Species>
<Species>One of the best characterized insulators is the chicken HS4 insulator at the b-globin locus.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Histones surrounding this insulator are hyperacetylated indicating the presence of histone acetyltransferase (HAT) activity at the insulator (6).</Species>
<Species>Recently, sequences that could block the spread of silent chromatin have been discovered in S.cerevisiae (7,8).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>These sequences (referred to as silent chromatin barriers) include sub-telomeric anti-silencing regions (STARs), the right boundary of HMR, and the upstream activating sequence (UAS) of the highly expressed TEF2 gene (9-11).</Species>
<Species>The mechanisms underlying barrier functions in yeast are not known.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>TEF2-UAS contains three tandem repressor activator protein 1 (Rap1p)-binding sites that are necessary and sufficient for its barrier function (11).</Species>
<Species>Rap1p is an abundant sequence-specific DNA-binding protein (12).</Species>

<Species>Variants of the 13 bp consensus sequence for Rap1p binding (ACACC CRYACAYM) (13) lie not only in the UASs of numerous genes but also in the silencers of the HM loci and in telomeric C1-3A repeats.</Species>
<Species>Accordingly, Rap1p functions as a global regulator of transcriptional activation and repression, silencing, as well as telomere length (12).</Species>
<Species>Rap1p performs these diverse functions by interacting with different factors in respective contexts.</Species>
<Species>As an activator, Rap1p binds to the promoters of 362 ORFs (13) and can function via at least three mechanisms.</Species>
<Species>First, Rap1p binding can    open up    local chromatin structure at a promoter to help another activator to bind (14).</Species>
<Species>Secondly, Rap1p bound to DNA can help Gcr1p bind to an adjacent site in the promoter through physical interaction (15).</Species>
<Species>Thirdly, Rap1p is involved in the recruitment of the NuA4 HAT complex and TFIID to ribosome protein genes (RPGs) (16,17).</Species>
<Species>As a silencing factor, Rap1p binds to silencers or telomeric repeats and recruits Sir3p/</Species>
<Species>Sir4p through direct interactions (18).</Species>
<Species>Rap1p also interacts with telomere-specific proteins in executing its role in regulating telomere length (19).</Species>
<Species>It is puzzling that a protein that helps establish silent chromatin could also act as a barrier to its propagation.</Species>
<Species>In this study, we found that in addition to TEF2-UAS, UASs of many yeast genes exhibit barrier activity.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Analyses of these UASs indicate that binding sites for transcriptional regulators Abf1p, Reb1p, Adr1p, Gcn4p, as well as Rap1p, may participate in barrier function.</Species>
<Species>These UASs are dispersed across the genome and might play a role in defining functional chromosomal domains.</Species>
<Species>Moreover, we demonstrated that targeting the activation domain of Rap1p, Adr1p or Gcn4p alone, led to barrier function.</Species>

<Species>Since the activation domain of an activator was usually involved in interacting with co-activators and/or components of the transcriptional machinery, these data indicated that other factors might also be involved in barrier function.</Species>
<Species>MATERIALS AND METHODS Plasmids and strains Plasmids 1-53 were used to make strains 1-53, respectively (see Figs 1-6).</Species>
<Species>Plasmid 1 was previously named pMB22-a that contained a HindIII-BamHI fragment of chromosome III (coordinates 14838-16263) with a URA3 gene inserted at its EcoRV site (20).</Species>
<Species>Plasmid 2 was derived from 1 by inserting TEF2-UAS (-511 to -407 bp relative to the translation start codon) at the SnaBI site.</Species>
<Species>Plasmids 3-38 were identical to 2 except that different fragments from various promoters (see Figs 1 and 2) were inserted at the SnaBI site.</Species>
<Species>Plasmid 29 had a sequence of chromosome III (295327-295713) containing the HMR-tRNA gene (21) inserted at the SnaBI site of plasmid 1.</Species>
<Species>Plasmids 39 and 40 were previously named pYXB26 and pYXB59, respectively (11).</Species>

<Species>Plasmid 41 was identical to pYXB59 except bearing mutations illustrated in Figure 3A. Plasmids 42-48 were previously described as pYXB29, 48, 28, 27, 59, 31 and 37, respectively (11).</Species>

<Species>Plasmid 50 was derived from plasmid 1 by inserting two copies of a sequence bearing the consensus binding sequence of LexA (bold) (22), GGGGTACGTACTGTATGTACATACAGGATATCGGGG, at the SnaBI site.</Species>
<Species>Plasmid 51 was identical to 50 except having only one copy of the LexA-binding sequence.</Species>
<Species>Plasmid 52 was derived from pYXB26 (11) by inserting a SpeI-ADE2-AvrII sequence at the SpeI site.</Species>
<Species>Plasmid 53 was derived from plasmid 52 by inserting TEF2-UAS (-511 to -407 bp relative to the translation start codon) at the SpeI site.</Species>
<Species>Plasmid L1 (see Fig. 5A) was made by inserting LEU2 into pBTM116 (23) carrying the LexA gene flanked by the promoter and terminator of ADH1.</Species>
<Species>L2 through L8 were derived from L1 by fusing various sequences to LexA (see Fig. 5A and B).</Species>
<Species>Plasmid pRS425 (24) carried the 2 um origin and LEU2.</Species>
<Species>Strain YXB76 was MATa ura3-52 leu2-3,112 ade2-1 lys1-1 his5-2 can1-100, E-HMLa-Iinverted (20).</Species>
<Species>Y2047b was MATa HMRa HMLa ED79-113::SUP4-o ID242 LEU2-GAL10-FLP1 ura3-52 ade2-1 lys1-1 his5-1 can1-100 [cir0] (25).</Species>
<Species>Strain 1 was made by transforming YXB76 to Ura+ with HindIII + BamHI digested plasmid 1.</Species>
<Species>Strains 2-38, 50 and 51 were similarly made with corresponding plasmids, respectively (e.g. strain 2 was made with plasmid 2).</Species>
<Species>Strains 39, 40 and 42-48 were previously described as YXB26, 48, 29, 48, 28, 27, 59, 31 and 37, respectively (11).</Species>
<Species>Strains 41, 52 and 53 (see Figs 3C and 6) were made by transforming Y2047b to canavanine-resistant by BamHI-digested plasmids 41, 52 and 53, respectively.</Species>
<Species>Strains 40   -48    were sir3::URA3 derivatives of strains 40-48, respectively.</Species>
<Species>The relevant genotypes of all the strains were confirmed by Southern blotting.</Species>
<Species>Quantitative mating assay Quantitative mating was performed as described (11).</Species>
<Species>Electrophoresis mobility shift assay (EMSA) Rap1p was expressed in Escherichia coli BL21 (DE3) from pL3S5, a pET vector carrying the RAP1 gene downstream of a T7 promoter (26).</Species>

<Species>Western blotting revealed that Rap1p protein was present in the induced extract but not the uninduced one (data not shown).</Species>

<Species>RESULTS UASs of many highly expressed genes can function as barriers to the spread of silencing We have previously shown that TEF2-UAS was able to block the spread of silencing in a silencer-blocking assay (11).</Species>
<Species>Such an assay tested if a sequence had the ability to prevent a silencer from silencing a reporter gene when it was positioned between the silencer and the reporter.</Species>
<Species>In this report we used a new silencer-blocking assay to identify more barrier elements.</Species>
<Species>This assay employed the URA3 gene and an inverted HML-I that could silence sequences to the right of HML (20) (Fig. 1, strain 1).</Species>
<Species>URA3 expression makes cells sensitive to 5-fluoroorotic acid (FOA) thus URA3 silencing could be measured by cell growth on FOA medium (Fig. 1, strain 1).</Species>

<Species>As expected, TEF2-UAS and another known barrier element, HMR-tRNA gene (21) exhibited barrier activity in this assay as indicated by the lack of silencing of URA3 in strains 2 and 29 (Fig. 1).</Species>
<Species>TEF2 encoding translation elongation factor 1a is one of the most highly expressed genes in yeast (27).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Other highly expressed genes include ribosome protein genes (RPGs) and genes coding for glycolytic enzymes (27).</Species>
<Species>The coordinated regulation of most of these genes requires the so-called general regulatory factors Rap1p, Abf1p and Reb1p (28,29).</Species>
<Species>Using the above silencer-blocking assay, we tested if the UASs of other highly expressed genes could also block URA3 silencing (Fig. 1).</Species>
<Species>Seventeen new barrier elements were identified from a total of 26 UASs tested.</Species>
<Species>These 17 elements were UASs of eight RPGs (see Fig. 1, strains 3-10), eight glycolytic genes (strains 18-25) and the HIS3 gene (strain 26).</Species>
<Species>All 17 elements except ADH2-UAS and HIS3-UAS exhibited very strong barrier activity as evidenced by the absence of URA3-silencing in strains 3-10 and 18-24 (Fig. 1).</Species>
<Species>Seven of the eight RPG-UASs that had barrier activity, contained a single or a pair of tandem Rap1p-binding sites (Fig. 1, strains 3-9).</Species>
<Species>Three of them also contained an Abf1p or Reb1p site (strains 6, 8 and 9).</Species>
<Species>One barrier RPG-UAS (strain 10) had only a predicted Abf1p site.</Species>
<Species>Of the seven RPG-UASs that had no barrier activity (Fig. 1, 11-17), only two bore no site for Rap1p, Abf1p or Reb1p (11 and 12).</Species>
<Species>The remaining five each contained one to three Rap1p sites (strains 13-17).</Species>
<Species>RPL15A-UAS (17) also contained an Abf1p site.</Species>

<Species>For most of the 15 RPG-UASs tested (3-17), the presence or absence of predicted Rap1p sites correlated with the presence or absence of Rap1p association in vivo as previously examined by chromatin immunoprecipitation assays (13).</Species>
<Species>Exceptions were the UASs of RPS24B, RPS28A and RPL15A (13).</Species>

<Species>Of the eight UASs of glycolytic genes tested (Fig. 1, strains 18-25), seven exhibited strong barrier activity (18-24) and one had weaker but detectable barrier activity (strain 25).</Species>
<Species>Glycolytic genes are among the most highly expressed genes and their high expression depends on the functions of Rap1p, Abf1p or Reb1p as well as Gcr1p (29,30).</Species>
<Species>The seven strong glycolytic barriers all consist of one or two Rap1p sites plus one or two Reb1p or Abf1p sites (Fig. 1, strains 18-24).</Species>
<Species>In addition, one or more Gcr1p-binding sites are found adjacent to each Rap1p site.</Species>
<Species>It was proposed that the function of Rap1p was to facilitate the binding of Gcr1p to the UAS (15).</Species>
<Species>Abf1p or Reb1p was shown to play a role similar to that of Rap1p in activating glycolytic genes (31-33).</Species>

<Species>Although the above data reinforced the notion that certain Rap1p-binding UASs could serve as barriers to silencing, they raised new questions about the essential components of a barrier element.</Species>

<Species>For example, some of the UASs that contained only a single Rap1p site had barrier activity (e.g. RPL19B-UAS, strain 3) whereas others that contained two or three sites had no activity (e.g. RPL39, strain 16).</Species>
<Species>One explanation was that sequences flanking the Rap1p site(s) in a particular UAS could positively or negatively influence barrier function.</Species>
<Species>Moreover, the presence of Abf1p or Reb1p sites in 11 of the 17 new barriers made us wonder if they also participated in barrier function.</Species>
<Species>We began to address these issues by analyzing three new barrier elements (Fig. 2).</Species>
<Species>RPS10A-UAS containing an Abf1p-binding site and a pair of Rap1p sites was divided into three fragments that were tested in a silencer-blocking assay (Fig. 2, strains 30-32).</Species>
<Species>It was clear that only the fragment containing Rap1p sites functioned as a barrier (strain 31).</Species>
<Species>TPI1-UAS bearing a Reb1p site and a Rap1p site was divided into two parts with one containing the Rap1p site (Fig. 2, strain 34) and the other Reb1p site (strain 33).</Species>
<Species>Neither of these fragments alone retained barrier activity indicating that concerted action of Reb1p and Rap1p was required for barrier activity.</Species>
<Species>Duplicating the Reb1p-bearing part of TPI1-UAS didn   t restore barrier activity (strain 35).</Species>
<Species>However, triplicating the Rap1p-containing part did re-create barrier function (strain 36).</Species>
<Species>RPS28A-UAS bore, in addition to a Rap1p site, an Abf1p site and an adjacent T-rich region that are required for efficient transcription of RPS28A (34).</Species>
<Species>A sequence of RPS28A-UAS deleted for a fragment bearing the Rap1p site lost the barrier activity (Fig. 2, strain 37).</Species>
<Species>However, duplicating this sequence restored barrier activity (strain 38).</Species>
<Species>The above results indicated again that Rap1p sites could form barriers (strains 31 and 36).</Species>

<Species>On the other hand, they also suggested that synergistic actions of Abf1p sites (strain 38), Reb1p site + Rap1p site (strain 18), or Abf1p site + Rap1p site (strain 16) could all lead to barrier function.</Species>
<Species>This was not very surprising since Rap1p, Abf1p and Reb1p could perform similar and sometimes interchangeable functions in gene regulation (16,35,36).</Species>
<Species>Note, however, we haven   t ruled out the possibility that other factors (e.g. Gcr1p) or structure features of DNA (e.g. T-tracks) were also involved in barrier function.</Species>
<Species>It was interesting that ADH2-UAS and HIS3-UAS bearing no site for Rap1p, Abf1p or Reb1p exhibited detectable barrier activity (Fig. 1, strains 25 and 26).</Species>
<Species>However, binding sites for other transcriptional activators existed in these UASs.</Species>
<Species>The major regulator that binds to ADH2-UAS is Adr1p (37).</Species>
<Species>On the other hand, Gcn4p binds to multiple sites in HIS3-UAS and activates HIS3 transcription (38).</Species>
<Species>The possible involvement of Adr1p or Gcn4p in barrier function was examined below.</Species>

<Species>Note Adr1p function was subject to glucose repression (37), which might explain why ADH2-UAS only exhibited limited barrier activity since glucose was used in the media used in our assay.</Species>

<Species>Effect of mutating Rap1p-binding sites in TEF2-UAS on barrier function Although we had shown that the three Rap1p-binding sites in TEF2-UAS were necessary and sufficient for its barrier activity (11), we had not shown if binding of Rap1p to these sites was required.</Species>
<Species>To address this we performed mutational analysis of TEF2-UAS.</Species>
<Species>As shown in Figure 3A and B, the three Rap1p-binding sites in TEF2-UAS (designated as R1, R2 and R3) were all able to bind Rap1p in an EMSA (Fig. 3B).</Species>
<Species>Single or double C>A mutations were introduced into R1, R2 and R3 resulting in m1, m2 and m3, respectively (Fig. 3A).</Species>

<Species>The m2 and m3 sites had both lost the ability to bind Rap1p, whereas m1 still bound Rap1p (Fig. 3B), which could be predicted from the specific mutations in each site (Fig. 3A, compare m1, m2 and m3 to the consensus sequence).</Species>
<Species>We then tested a mutated TEF2-UAS containing m1, m2 and m3 in a silencer-blocking assay using the HML-E silencer and the HMLa genes (Fig. 3C).</Species>
<Species>In this assay, the HML-I silencer was deleted but the HML-E silencer was sufficient to silence the HMLa genes (Fig. 3C, strain 39) (11).</Species>
<Species>Silencing in strain 39 (a-type) was measured by its ability to mate with an a-type strain (Fig. 3C).</Species>
<Species>As predicted, the wild-type TEF2-UAS blocked HMLa silencing (11) (Fig. 3C, strain 40).</Species>
<Species>On the other hand, the mutated TEF2-UAS containing m1, m2 and m3 had lost barrier activity (Fig. 3C, compare the mating efficiencies of strains 41 and 40).</Species>

<Species>Therefore, mutations that prevented Rap1p from binding two of the three sites in TEF2-UAS abolished its barrier activity, indicating that association of Rap1p with TEF2-UAS at more than one site was required for barrier function.</Species>
<Species>The barrier TEF2-UAS alters local chromatin structure In eukaryotic cells, the topology of local DNA reflects the chromatin structure in which it resides.</Species>

<Species>We had previously developed a DNA topology-based assay to examine chromatin structure in vivo, which involved excising a chromosomal region of interest from its genomic location as a circle using site-specific recombination (39).</Species>
<Species>Using this strategy, we demonstrated that DNA in silenced chromatin was more negatively supercoiled than that in active chromatin (39).</Species>
<Species>In this report we used the topology assay to address if barrier elements altered local chromatin structure as Drosophila or chicken insulators did (40,41).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Various sequences (designated X) from UASs of TEF2, AgTEF (TEF gene from Ashbya gossypii) and ADE2 were inserted between HML-E and HMLa at HMLDI (HML locus deleted for the I silencer) flanked by the FRT sites for the Flp1p site-specific recombinase (Fig. 4A and B).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The FLP1 gene was under the control of the inducible GAL10 promoter (39).</Species>
<Species>The mating efficiency of each strain measured silencing of HMLa (Fig. 4C).</Species>
<Species>In strains 40, 42, 44 and 47, silencing was restricted to the left of the X insertions and HMLa was derepressed (Fig. 4C).</Species>

<Species>Consistently, the proportion of silent chromatin in the region flanked by the FRT sites in each of these strains was decreased, as indicated by the reduced negative supercoiling of the excised circle (11) (data not shown).</Species>

<Species>Note that the above effect of a barrier on HML chromatin reflected both change in the scope of silencing caused by the barrier activity and alteration (if any) in chromatin structure at the barrier independent of the silencing state of the locus.</Species>
<Species>To exclusively examine the latter, we analyzed the topology of HML DNA in a silencing-deficient background.</Species>
<Species>The SIR3 gene in strains described in Figure 4B was disrupted rendering them defective in silencing (strains 40   -48    in Fig. 4D).</Species>
<Species>Recombination mediated by Flp1p in these strains led to the excision of a group of chromosomal circles that differed only in the X insertion.</Species>
<Species>The supercoiling of these circles was analyzed as a function of the length of the insertion (Fig. 4D).</Species>

<Species>If an insertion simply lengthened a circle without causing abnormal changes in nucleosomal structure and/or density, the topoisomers of this circle would migrate slower relative to those of a similar circle with a smaller size.</Species>
<Species>Otherwise, migration of the topoisomers would deviate from that predicted based on the size of the circle.</Species>

<Species>As shown in Figure 4D, the circle from strain 40    bearing a 104 bp barrier element migrated faster rather than slower than the circle from strain 46    bearing a 91 bp non-barrier element.</Species>
<Species>Circles bearing other barrier elements also exhibited unexpected faster migration (compare strains 44    to 45   , 47    to 43   , 42    to 48   , respectively).</Species>
<Species>Therefore, these data indicated that barrier function correlated with altered topology of local DNA.</Species>

<Species>This was further demonstrated by that mutations in TEF2-UAS that abolished its barrier activity also abolished its effect on DNA topology (Fig. 4D, compare 41    to 40   ; note that circles from both strains had the same size).</Species>

<Species>Since in our gel assay more negatively supercoiled DNA migrate slower, we concluded that every fragment with barrier activity caused a reduction in negative supercoiling of approximately one to two turns in HMLDI DNA (Fig. 4D, compare the centers of distributions of topoisomers in pairs of lanes, e.g. 40    and 41   ).</Species>
<Species>The topology of eukaryotic DNA reflects mainly the wrapping of DNA into nucleosomes (approximately one negative superhelical turn is associated with each nucleosome) (42).</Species>
<Species>Therefore, removal of one nucleosome would eliminate approximately one turn.</Species>
<Species>On the other hand, histone acetylation can reduce negative supercoiling associated with a nucleosome by approximately 0.2 turns (43).</Species>
<Species>Therefore, acetylating five nucleosomes would reduce negative supercoiling by approximately one turn.</Species>

<Species>Consequently, the linking number change of one to two brought about by TEF2-UAS can be accounted for by either the loss of one to two nucleosomes or acetylation of five to 10 nucleosomes.</Species>
<Species>Further experiments are under way to clarify the nature of change in chromatin induced by a barrier.</Species>

<Species>Targeting the transcription activation domain of Rap1p recapitulates its barrier activity The multifunctional Rap1p can be divided into at least four functional domains (Fig. 5A) (12).</Species>
<Species>We were interested in defining which of these domains might be involved in the barrier activity of Rap1p.</Species>

<Species>To this end, we fused various parts of Rap1p to the bacterial LexA protein and tested if targeting any of the fusion proteins to LexA-binding sites could re-create a barrier to silencing (Fig. 5A).</Species>
<Species>The LexA-RAP1 fusion genes were carried on 2 um based plasmids marked by LEU2 (designated L1-L6, Fig. 5A).</Species>

<Species>When introduced into strain 50 in which two LexA-binding sites had been inserted between the inverted HML-I and URA3, LexA alone had no effect on URA3 silencing (Fig. 5A, plasmid L1).</Species>
<Species>Targeting the DNA binding domain, DNA bending domain, silencing domain, or the activating + silencing domain of Rap1p also did not affect URA3 silencing (L2-L5).</Species>
<Species>On the other hand, targeting the activation domain alone recapitulated the barrier activity of Rap1p (L6).</Species>
<Species>These results indicated that the activation domain of Rap1p was involved in barrier activity.</Species>

<Species>The inability of the Rap1p-silencing domain to block URA3 silencing in our assay did not necessarily mean that this domain had no barrier function, since such a function might be suppressed by much stronger silencing activity associated with the silencing domain.</Species>
<Species>Was the lack of barrier function of fusion constructs L2-L5 due to a lack of expression of these proteins?</Species>

<Species>To address this possibility, we examined the levels of L1-L6 proteins as well as L7 and L8 proteins described in Figure 5B by western blotting using an antibody against LexA. As shown in Figure 5C, L5 was expressed at a level comparable to L6, and L4 was expressed at a higher level than L6.</Species>
<Species>Therefore, the lack of barrier function of L4 and L6 was not the result of their lack of expression.</Species>
<Species>On the other hand, the level of L2 or L3 was significantly lower than that of L6, hence the lack of barrier function of L2 and L3 might be due to their insufficient expression.</Species>

<Species>As an important control for the above targeting experiments, we showed that plasmids L1-L6 (Fig. 5A) as well as L7 and L8 (Fig. 5B) bearing LexA-fusion genes had no effect on URA3 silencing in strain 1 (Fig. 1) in which there was no binding site for LexA present between HML-I and URA3 (data not shown).</Species>

<Species>Hence, the effect of the fusion proteins on URA3 silencing was the result of their targeting to specific loci, not the consequence of non-specific, indirect functions (if any) of these proteins.</Species>
<Species>Targeted activation domain of Adr1p or Gcn4p can also act as a barrier factor We have shown above that ADH2-UAS bearing Adr1p-binding sites and HIS3-UAS bearing Gcn4p</Species>
<Species>sites both had detectable barrier activity (Fig. 1, strains 25 and 26).</Species>

<Species>Given that tethering the activation domain of Rap1p is sufficient for barrier function, we tested if targeting the activation domain of Adr1p or Gcn4p could also establish a barrier.</Species>
<Species>Adr1p contains four separate activation domains (TADI-TADIV) that can contact Ada2p, Gcn5p and/or TFIIB (45).</Species>
<Species>TAD III (415-467) interacts with only Gcn5p but not Ada2p or TFIIB.</Species>
<Species>We fused this domain of Adr1p and the activation domain of Gcn4p (102-149) to LexA, respectively (Fig. 5B, L7 and L8).</Species>
<Species>Targeting these fusion proteins to two LexA-binding sites between HML-I and URA3 in strain 50 dramatically reduced URA3 silencing (Fig. 5B, compare L7 and L8 to L1).</Species>
<Species>Therefore, like LexA-Rap1p (627-695), both LexA-Adr1p (415-467) and LexA-Gcn4p (102-149) also had barrier activity.</Species>

<Species>Barrier function of these fusion proteins was significantly decreased in strain 51 in which only one LexA site was inserted between HML-I and URA3 (compare strains 50 and 51 carrying plasmid L7), indicating that the potency of such barriers was dependent on the amount of tethered fusion proteins.</Species>
<Species>DISCUSSION We have shown in this report that UASs of many highly expressed genes could function as barriers to the spread of transcriptional silencing.</Species>

<Species>These newly identified barrier elements together with previously described barrier elements (STARs, HMR-tRNA gene, TEF2-UAS and CHA1-UAS) (9-11,21) are scattered across the yeast genome and may play a role in dividing the genome into functional domains.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Analyses of the barrier UASs suggest that binding sites for transcriptional regulators Rap1p, Abf1p, Reb1p, Adr1p and Gcn4p can participate in barrier function.</Species>
<Species>Barrier activity often requires concerted actions of more than one factor-binding site.</Species>
<Species>Our mutational analysis of TEF2-UAS suggests a direct involvement of Rap1p in its barrier function.</Species>
<Species>It is noteworthy that not all UASs of highly expressed genes have barrier activity.</Species>
<Species>Many non-barrier UASs also consist of multiple regulator binding sites, therefore other unknown factors might determine whether a UAS could act as a barrier.</Species>
<Species>How Rap1p and the other transcriptional regulators act to block silencing is not clear.</Species>
<Species>Since they can all act as transcriptional activators, one natural explanation is that they may overcome the silencing effect of a silencer and directly activate the reporter gene.</Species>

<Species>However, it has been well documented that Rap1p and the other transcriptional regulators usually act at relatively short distances (less than  600 bp upstream of the translation start codon) (28,29,46), but the binding sites for these regulators were >800 bp from the translation start codon in most of the silencing-blocking tests in this report (Figs 1 and 2).</Species>
<Species>In the test shown in Figure 6, TEF2-UAS blocked ADE2 silencing when it was  2 kb downstream from the translation start codon of the gene.</Species>
<Species>Moreover, Fourel et al. (44) demonstrated that the barrier function (or anti-silencing function) of an activator was independent of its role in activating transcription.</Species>
<Species>Therefore, it is unlikely that the ability of a UAS to prevent gene silencing is due to its direct activation of the gene.</Species>
<Species>In light of this, our results are in agreement with the notion that transcriptional regulators can also participate in defining the boundaries of functional chromosomal domains.</Species>
<Species>A few models have been proposed for the barrier functions of transcriptional regulators.</Species>
<Species>One model proposed that binding of a regulator to a barrier led to the formation of a nucleosome-free region thereby disrupting a continuous nucleosome array (11).</Species>

<Species>Since the SIR complexes spread by self-interaction and interacting with adjacent nucleosmes in a stepwise fashion (4), a nucleosome-free gap could present a barrier to the spreading SIR complex.</Species>

<Species>This    nucleosome gap    hypothesis is consistent with that certain barrier factors such as Rap1p and Reb1p could indeed prevent nucleosome formation around their binding sites (14) and the barrier function of TEF2-UAS correlated with its ability to alter local chromatin structure (this report).</Species>
<Species>In fact, many insulator/boundary elements in higher organisms have also been shown to alter local chromatin structure.</Species>

<Species>For instance, the chicken b-globin insulator was linked to changes in nucleosome positioning, and the Drosophila scs and scs    boundary elements are associated with unusual chromatin structures that are hypersensitive to nucleases (40,41).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>However, it is not clear whether any chromatin change associated with barrier function in yeast or insulator function in higher cells is the cause or effect of the function.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Another model for barrier action proposed by R. Kamakaka and colleagues (21) proposed that barrier factors recruit chromatin modifying and/or remodeling complexes to counteract the more compact, hypoacetylated silent chromatin.</Species>
<Species>In agreement with this hypothesis, targeted HATs SAS2, GCN5 and ESA1 all had barrier activity (21; Y.-H. Chiu, Q. Yu and X. Bi, unpublished results).</Species>
<Species>Interestingly, Rap1p, Adr1p, Gcn4p</Species>
<Species>and Abf1p share the ability to recruit HAT complexes NuA4 and/or SAGA to target genes (16,45,47-49).</Species>
<Species>Therefore, these factors that are capable of binding to the newly identified barriers may function as barrier factors by recruiting HAT complexes.</Species>

<Species>In fact, recruitment of HAT activity has also been suggested to be the mechanism underlying the function of the chicken b-globin insulator (6), although it was not known what HAT might be involved.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Our demonstration that tethering the activation domain of Rap1p, Adr1p or Gcn4p alone recapitulates barrier activity is consistent with the above HAT model for barrier function, since at least the activation domain of Adr1p has been shown to directly interact with HAT complexes (45).</Species>

<Species>However, we haven   t ruled out the possibility that the barrier function of the targeted activation domain of Rap1p, Adr1p or Gcn4p is not related to the barrier function of the native protein.</Species>

<Species>Note that the    nucleosome gap    model and the HAT model are not mutually exclusive since the nucleosome gap could result from destabilization of nucelosomes caused by HAT function.</Species>

<Species>A recent intriguing study showed that targeting proteins of the nuclear pore complex (NPC) could also establish a boundary for silent chromatin, and that tethering to NPC was required for boundary activity (50).</Species>
<Species>This led to a revisit to the looping model for the function of boundary/insulator elements (51).</Species>
<Species>However, an alternative explanation was that the NPC compartment could simply be rich in transcriptional activating factors or poor in silencing factors like the SIR proteins (50).</Species>

<Species>In summary, results from this and other studies indicate that factors previously identified as positive and/or negative regulators of gene activation could also function in demarcating distinct domains of gene activity.</Species>
<Species>How these factors carry out their boundary function is not resolved but recruitment of other factors (e.g. chromatin modifying complexes) is likely to be involved.</Species>
<Species>NOTE</Species>
<Species>ADDED IN PROOF After this work was completed and submitted for publication the first time, Fourel et al.</Species>
<Species>(52) reported that targeted activation domains of Rap1p and Abf1p had insulating capacity.</Species>
<Species>Cytotoxic Activity of Silyl- and Germyl-Substituted 4,4-Dioxo-3a,6a-Dihydrothieno[2,3   d]isoxazolines-2</Species>
<Species>Abstract The [2+3] dipolar cycloaddition of nitrile oxides to the double C = C bonds of thiophene-1, 1-dioxides leads to formation of the fused isoxazolines-2 (1, 2).</Species>

<Species>Tumor growth inhibition of these compounds strongly depends on the nature of group IV A element increasing from slightly active tert-butyl derivatives to silicon and germanium containing analogues.</Species>

<Species>The products of benzonitrile oxide cycloaddition have greater cytotoxic effect than the compounds obtained from the cycloaddition reaction of 2, 5-disubstituted thiophene-1, 1-dioxides with acetonitrile oxide.</Species>
<Species>Fused silyl substituted isoxazolines-2 are stronger NO-inducers than their germyl and tert-butyl analogues.</Species>
<Species>CYTOTOXIC ACTIVITY OF SILYL- AND GERMYL-SUBSTITUTED 4,4-DIOXO-3a,6a-DIHYDROTHIENO</Species>

<Species>[2,3-d] ISOXAZOLINES-2 E. Lukevics*, P. Arsenyan, I. Shestakova, O. Zharkova, I. Kanepe, R. Mezapuke, and O. Pudova Latvian Institute of Organic Synthesis, Aizkraukles 21, Riga, LV-1006, Latvia ABSTRACT The</Species>
<Species>[2+3] dipolar cycloaddition of nitrile oxides to the double (3=(3 bonds of thiophene-l,l-dioides leads to formation of the fused isoxazolines-2 (1, 2).</Species>

<Species>Tumor growth inhibition of these compounds strongly depends on the nature of group IV A element increasing from slightly active ert-butyl derivatives to silicon and germanium containing analogues.</Species>

<Species>The products of benzonitdle oxide cycloaddition have greater cytotoic effect than the compounds obtained from he cycloaddition reaction of 2,5-disubstituted thiophene-l,l-dioxides with acetonitrile oxide.</Species>
<Species>Fused silyl substituted isoxazolines-2 are stronger NO-inducers than their germyl and tert-butyl analogues.</Species>
<Species>INTRODUCTION</Species>

<Species>The interest in silyl substituted thiophene-l,l-dioxides stems from the fact that they are useful synthetic intermediates for the preparation of various types of organic compounds by Diels-Alder cycloaddition [1], amine induced ring-opening reaction [2], or coupling of bromothiophene-l,l-dioxides with thienyl stannanes in the presence of a palladium (0) catalyst [3].</Species>
<Species>It has been shown that unsubstituted thiophene-l,l-dioxide prepared in situ is a quite reactive dipolarophile in the [2+3] cycloaddition reactions with N,o-diphenylnitrone</Species>
<Species>[4], benzonitrile [4, 5] and mesitonitrile [4, 5] oxides yielding mono- and diisoxazolines-2 and N-substituted isoxazolidines.</Species>

<Species>Moreover, our recent studies indicate that silyl- and germylcontaining isoxazolines have gained a great deal of attention as compounds possessing a wide spectrum of the biological properties.</Species>
<Species>The vasodilating, anticoagulant and cardioprotective activity of 5-Si-(Ge)substituted isoxazolines-2 has been studied in vitro and in vivo [6, 7].</Species>
<Species>The most active isoxazoline -3-(5"-triethylgermyl-3"-isoxazolino)pyridine hydrochloride protected the heart from rhythm disturbances and lethality during ischemiareperfusion [7].</Species>
<Species>It has been shown that silylisoxazolines-2 are more potent in protection against hypoxia and corazole convulsions than germanium analogues.</Species>
<Species>However, germylisoxazolines-2 are stronger tumor growth inhibitors and NO-inducers than their silicon analogue [8].</Species>
<Species>This work presents the results of cytotoxic activity for fused isoxazolines-2 bearing a group 14 element as substituent (1, 2) in function of the nature of the group 14 element.</Species>
