<Species>Presence of antibodies against cyclic citrullinated peptides in patients with 'rhupus': a cross-sectional study</Species>
<Species>Abstract 'Rhupus' is a rare condition sharing features of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).</Species>
<Species>If rhupus is a distinctive entity, an overlap between RA and SLE or a subset of SLE is currently debated.</Species>
<Species>This study was performed to explore the prevalence of antibodies against cyclic citrullinated peptides (anti-CCP antibodies) in rhupus.</Species>
<Species>Patients meeting American College of Rheumatology criteria for RA, SLE, or both were included.</Species>

<Species>Clinical and radiographic features were recorded and sera were searched for anti-CCP antibodies, rheumatoid factor, antinuclear antibodies, anti-extractable nuclear antigens, and antibodies against double-stranded DNA (anti-dsDNA antibodies).</Species>
<Species>Seven patients for each group were included.</Species>
<Species>Clinical and serological features for RA or SLE were similar between rhupus and RA patients, and between rhupus and SLE patients, respectively.</Species>
<Species>Values for anti-CCP antibodies obtained were significantly (p < 0.05) higher in RA (6/7) and rhupus (4/7) than in SLE patients (0/7) and healthy subjects (0/7).</Species>

<Species>Our data support the possibility that rhupus is an overlap between RA and SLE, because highly specific autoantibodies for RA (anti-CCP) and for SLE (anti-dsDNA and anti-Sm) are detected in coexistence.</Species>

<Species>Introduction The clinical coexistence of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) was first described in 1969 by Kantor and was termed 'rhupus syndrome' by Schur (both cited in [1]).</Species>
<Species>Since then, fewer than 100 cases of rhupus have been published [1-3].</Species>
<Species>In an epidemiological study including about 7,000 new patients, the prevalence of RA was 15% and for SLE it was 8.9%.</Species>
<Species>The expected coincidence of RA and SLE by chance would therefore be 1.2%.</Species>
<Species>However, the observed prevalence of rhupus was 0.09%, less than one-tenth of that expected [1].</Species>

<Species>Previous reports have shown that the patients with rhupus display an array of autoantibodies including anti-double-stranded DNA (anti-dsDNA), anti-Sm (both highly specific for SLE), anti-SSA, anti-SSB, anti-ribonucleoprotein, antinuclear antibodies (ANA), anti-cardiolipins, and rheumatoid factor (RF) [1,2].</Species>

<Species>However, no study has yet been performed to investigate the presence of antibodies against cyclic citrullinated peptides (anti-CCP antibodies), which have a specificity for RA of 96 to 98% (for second-generation assays (anti-CCP2))</Species>
<Species>[4,5].</Species>
<Species>Recent data have confirmed that these antibodies are rarely if ever present in other autoimmune diseases such as SLE, Sjogren's syndrome (SS), scleroderma and myositis</Species>
<Species>[6].</Species>

<Species>Nowadays, it is a matter of debate whether rhupus is a clinically and immunologically distinctive entity [2], a true overlap between SLE and RA [7], or a subgroup of patients with lupus [8].</Species>
<Species>This descriptive, cross-sectional study was performed to investigate the frequency of anti-CCP antibodies in a cohort of patients with rhupus.</Species>
<Species>Materials and methods We included all patients fulfilling American College of Rheumatology (ACR) classification criteria for both RA</Species>
<Species>[9] and SLE [10] who belonged to our cohorts of patients with RA and with SLE.</Species>
<Species>Comparisons were made with age- and gender-matched patients with RA and with SLE, and healthy subjects.</Species>
<Species>The study was approved by the local ethics committee, and informed consent was obtained.</Species>
<Species>Serum samples were obtained and stored at -75oC until use.</Species>
<Species>Sera were analyzed for anti-CCP2 antibodies by ELISA (Inova Diagnostics, San Diego, CA, USA) with a cutoff value of 60 U/ml.</Species>

<Species>Fine antinuclear reactivities (ELISA; Inova Diagnostics), RF (nephelometry), ANA (indirect immunofluorescence on HEp-2 slides), and anti-dsDNA (indirect immunofluorescence on Crithidia luciliae substrate) antibodies were also determined.</Species>
<Species>Except for healthy individuals, standard radiographs of hands were available.</Species>
<Species>For statistical analysis, ANOVA and the Mann-Whitney U test were performed as appropriate with GraphPad Prism 4.0 software (GraphPad Inc, San Diego, CA, USA).</Species>
<Species>Results Seven female patients with a median age of 44 years (range 25 to 64) met our inclusion criteria.</Species>
<Species>The major clinical and laboratory findings are presented in Table 1.</Species>
<Species>Healthy individuals and all patients belonged to cohorts from the same ethnic group (Hispanic mestizo).</Species>
<Species>No differences in demographic data were found between groups.</Species>
<Species>Mean ACR criteria for SLE were 5.57 (range 4 to 8) in the SLE group, and 5.57 (4 to 8) in the rhupus group.</Species>
<Species>In the same way, mean ACR criteria for RA were 6 (4 to 7) in the RA group, and 5.14 (4 to 6) for the patients with rhupus.</Species>
<Species>In all patients with rhupus, RA was presented as the initial disease, as has been described previously [2].</Species>
<Species>In accordance with another report, in two patients the disease started during their childhood as juvenile chronic arthritis [1].</Species>

<Species>Anti-CCP antibodies were found in four of seven (57%) patients with rhupus, and in six of seven (86%) patients with RA, whereas neither patients with SLE nor healthy individuals showed reactivity.</Species>
<Species>When the concentrations in each group were compared, a statistical significant difference between groups was found (ANOVA, p < 0.05).</Species>

<Species>The mean concentration of anti-CCP antibodies was 584 U/ml (range 0 to 1,237) in patients with rhupus (Figure 1), 875 U/ml (0 to 1,178) in the RA group (not significant compared with rhupus), 1 U/ml (0 to 10) for SLE individuals (p < 0.05 compared with rhupus), and 0 U/ml (0 to 2) for healthy controls (p < 0.05 compared with rhupus).</Species>

<Species>Two of three patients with rhupus who were negative for anti-CCP antibodies were also negative for anti-dsDNA antibodies, RF and anti-extractable nuclear antigen antibodies, although both patients met RA and SLE classification criteria, including ANA and erosive arthritis.</Species>
<Species>Differences in ANA, anti-dsDNA and anti-extractable nuclear antigen autoantibodies between patients with rhupus and those with SLE were not found.</Species>
<Species>We also found no difference in the prevalence of RF between patients with rhupus and those with RA.</Species>
<Species>Surprisingly, one healthy subject was positive for RF, ANA and anti-SSA antibodies, although she was asymptomatic and no features of any disease were found.</Species>
<Species>Discussion The close association between different type II human leukocyte antigen (HLA) molecules and the risk of RA is well established.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>These major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class II molecules share the same amino acid sequence (QKRAA or QRRAA) in positions 69 to 74 of the b-chain, namely the 'shared epitope'.</Species>
<Species>Recent works have demonstrated that this 'shared epitope' preferentially binds peptides containing the non-standard amino acid citrulline (deiminated arginine)</Species>
<Species>[11].</Species>

<Species>In addition, an abnormally increased function of the enzyme peptidylarginine deiminase 4 (PAD4; responsible for the deimination of arginine) and an elevated anti-CCP autoantibody production in patients with RA have been demonstrated [12].</Species>

<Species>These facts have built the first bridge between cellular and humoral autoimmunity in a major rheumatic disease, supporting a pathogenetic role for an abnormal metabolism of citrulline in the development of RA [13,14].</Species>

<Species>Patients with SLE are often part of the control group when determining the specificity of anti-CCP antibodies for RA [15], although some studies have been performed specifically on patients with SLE.</Species>
<Species>These studies contribute some clues to the role of anti-CCP antibodies in rhupus.</Species>

<Species>Mediwake and colleagues [16], in a study exploring the predictive value of anti-CCP antibodies to distinguish erosive arthritis in SLE, found ten patients (out of 231) with erosive arthritis, two of whom had anti-CCP antibodies.</Species>

<Species>In concord with this, Hoffman and colleagues [15] demonstrate that three patients with erosive arthritis, included in a cohort of 235 patients with SLE, were positive for anti-CCP antibodies.</Species>
<Species>These authors suggest that the presence of anti-CCP antibodies can predispose for a chronic RA-like arthritis in patients with SLE.</Species>
<Species>Additionally Weissman and colleagues</Species>
<Species>[17] demonstrated that patients with SLE can display radiographic abnormalities similar to those of RA, although the presence of marginal erosions is a rare finding.</Species>

<Species>In the present study we demonstrate that the patients with rhupus show a very similar arthritis pattern (including erosive disease) and similar autoantibody production (RF and anti-CCP antibodies) to those in patients with RA.</Species>
<Species>In addition, patients with rhupus display a clinical and serological profile indistinguishable from patients with SLE.</Species>

<Species>Moreover, the presence of other coexistent autoimmune diseases was similar in all groups of patients (two patients with rhupus, three patients with RA, and three patients with SLE also had SS).</Species>
<Species>We found high titers of anti-CCP antibodies in four of seven (57%) patients with rhupus, a frequency similar to that reported for RA [4].</Species>
<Species>This finding, together with the clinical similarity, supports the contention that rhupus belongs to the RA spectrum.</Species>

<Species>The high prevalence of anti-CCP antibodies in RA found in our study could be explained by a selection bias because only patients with RA with an aggressive disease (namely erosive arthritis and RF+) were included.</Species>

<Species>In contrast, the mean ACR criterion for SLE was similar between patients with rhupus and those with SLE, including the 'robust' features of SLE such as renal and neurological involvement, and anti-dsDNA and anti-Sm antibodies.</Species>
<Species>These clinical and serological features shared between patients with rhupus and those with SLE also place rhupus in the SLE spectrum.</Species>
<Species>Titration of anti-CCP antibodies in the rhupus group clearly shows a bimodal distribution, suggesting the existence of two different subpopulations.</Species>
<Species>Because of the small number of patients, we are unable to define the differential features underlying each subset.</Species>
<Species>However, two of three patients negative for anti-CCP antibodies were also negative for both RF and anti-dsDNA antibodies.</Species>

<Species>Conclusion On the basis of the presence of shared clinical features of RA (mainly erosive arthritis) and SLE (including renal and neurological involvement) along with the presence of anti-dsDNA and anti-CCP autoantibodies in our patients with rhupus, our findings strongly support the contention that rhupus is a true overlap between RA and SLE, not merely a part of the clinical spectrum of the articular involvement seen in SLE.</Species>

<Species>Moreover, on the basis of the mean ACR criteria for both diseases, we have confirmed that patients with rhupus have more RA-associated and less SLE-associated damage, an issue that has been suggested previously [2].</Species>
<Species>To our knowledge, this is the first report exploring the prevalence of anti-CCP antibodies specifically in patients with rhupus.</Species>
<Species>More studies are needed to expand the pathogenetic knowledge of this overlap syndrome.</Species>

<Species>Abbreviations ANA = antinuclear antibodies; anti-CCP antibodies = antibodies against cyclic citrullinated peptides; anti-dsDNA antibodies = antibodies against double-stranded DNA; ELISA = enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay; RA = rheumatoid arthritis; RF = rheumatoid factor; SLE = systemic lupus erythematosus; SS = Sjogren's syndrome.</Species>

<Species>HP1 modulates the transcription of cell-cycle regulators in Drosophila melanogaster</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Abstract Heterochromatin protein 1 (HP1) was originally described as a non-histone chromosomal protein and is required for transcriptional gene silencing and the formation of heterochromatin.</Species>
<Species>Although it is localized primarily at pericentric heterochromatin, a scattered distribution over a large number of euchromatic loci is also evident.</Species>

<Species>Here, we provide evidence that Drosophila HP1 is essential for the maintenance of active transcription of euchromatic genes functionally involved in cell-cycle progression, including those required for DNA replication and mitosis.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Depletion of HP1 in proliferating embryonic cells caused aberrant progression of the cell cycle at S phase and G2/M phase, linked to aberrant chromosome segregation, cytokinesis, and an increase in apoptosis.</Species>
<Species>The chromosomal distribution of Aurora B, and the level of phosphorylation of histone H3 serine 10 were also altered in the absence of HP1.</Species>

<Species>Using chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis, we further demonstrate that the promoters of a number of cell-cycle regulator genes are bound to HP1, supporting a direct role for HP1 in their active transcription.</Species>
<Species>Overall, our data suggest that HP1 is essential for the maintenance of cell-cycle progression and the transcription of cell-cycle regulatory genes.</Species>
<Species>The results also support the view that HP1 is a positive regulator of transcription in euchromatin.</Species>
<Species>INTRODUCTION Chromatin in higher eukaryotes is subdivided into different functional compartments termed heterochromatin and euchromatin (1).</Species>

<Species>Heterochromatin differs from euchromatin in its DNA composition, replication timing, condensation throughout the cell cycle, and its ability to silence euchromatic genes placed adjacent to or within its territory, often described as position-effect-variegation (PEV) (2).</Species>

<Species>Heterochromatin protein 1 (HP1) was the first protein identified in Drosophila melanogaster as a heterochromatin-associated protein (3); the corresponding gene has been cloned from a number of organisms and is highly conserved from yeast to human (4).</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Polytene chromosome staining showed that, in Drosophila, HP1 is distributed mainly in pericentric heterochromatin, telomeric heterochromatin, the banded small fourth chromosome (5-8), as well as  200 individual loci scattered throughout the euchromatic chromosomal arms (5).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The gene encoding HP1 in D.melanogaster, Su(var)2-5, was isolated as a suppressor of PEV (9-11).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The protein contains a highly conserved motif, the chromo (chromatin organization modifier) domain, similar to Polycomb (Pc), a repressor of homeotic genes (12).</Species>

<Species>The association between HP1 and pericentric heterochromatin is believed to occur via the chromo domain of HP1 and the N-terminal tail of histone H3 methylated at lysine 9 (13,14), generated by histone methyltransferase-Su(var)3-9, a partner of HP1 in pericentric heterochromatin (15).</Species>
<Species>The C-terminal chromo    shadow    domain of HP1 interacts with other silencing complexes to suppress local transcriptional activity (15-18).</Species>

<Species>However, studies of HP1 chromosomal distribution also showed that HP1 does not always co-localize with lysine 9 methylated histone H3 or Su(var)3-9, especially in euchromatic regions (19-21); in some cases, HP1 is found directly bound to DNA (22,23).</Species>
<Species>All these features argue for distinct roles for HP1 in chromatin and in epigenetic gene regulation.</Species>
<Species>HP1 is believed to be an essential structural protein protecting the integrity of chromosomes during cell division (8,24).</Species>
<Species>Swi6, the homolog of HP1 in fission yeast, is dispensable for survival, but its deletion results in lagging chromosomes during anaphase, and a high rate of chromosome loss (25,26).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Mutations of HP1 in D.melanogaster result in late larval lethality, chromosome breakages/loss, telomere fusion and a high frequency of cells with abnormal anaphase (8,27).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Null alleles of the HP1 functional partner in mice (SUVAR39) also showed various chromosomal defects (28), supporting a conserved role for heterochromatin proteins in the regulation of chromosome dynamics during cell-cycle progression.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>However, the mechanism(s) involved remains to be understood.</Species>

<Species>In this study, we utilized Drosophila embryonic Kc cells and an RNA interference (RNAi)-based approach to demonstrate that HP1 plays an important role at S phase and G2/M phases during the cell cycle.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We further show that nearly one-third of known/predicted cell-cycle regulators require HP1 to maintain their active transcription.</Species>
<Species>These genes include MCMs, Orc4, CDC45L, INCENP, Aurora B, CAF1, Bub1, Bub3 and a few other cell-cycle regulators.</Species>
<Species>ChIP analysis suggests that HP1 plays a direct role in their transcription.</Species>
<Species>Therefore, the results of this study provide an alternative explanation for the specific role of HP1 in the regulation of chromatin dynamics and in cell-cycle progression.</Species>

<Species>MATERIALS AND METHODS RNAi in Kc cells Drosophila Kc cells were routinely cultured at 25oC in Schneider Drosophila medium (GIBCO) supplemented with 10% fetal calf serum, 160 ug/ml penicillin, 250 ug/ml streptomycin, and 4 mM l-glutamine.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Double-stranded RNA (dsRNA) of HP1 was generated by incubation of single-stranded RNA in annealing buffer (100 mM potassium acetate, 30 mM HEPES-KOH, pH 7.4, 2 mM magnesium acetate) for 3 min at 95oC and then placed in a beaker with water at 75oC and allowed to cool slowly to room temperature.</Species>
<Species>The detailed procedure of RNAi was carried out according to the established protocols ().</Species>
<Species>Briefly, Kc cells were seeded in a six-well dish using serum-free medium at 1 x 106 cells/ml.</Species>
<Species>HP1 dsRNA (5 ug/ml) was added to the cultured Kc cells.</Species>
<Species>After 60 min at room temperature, 2 ml of medium containing 10% serum was added to each well and the plates transferred to 25oC for up to 8 days.</Species>
<Species>Western blotting and RT-PCR were carried out using the extract/total RNA isolated from control and dsRNA-treated cells on days 2, 6 and 8.</Species>
<Species>Cell-cycle and apoptosis analysis The procedure for flow cytometric analysis of Kc cells followed that in the manual provided with the BrdU flow kit (BD PharMingen).</Species>
<Species>The cells were fed with BrdU for 4 h, then scraped and collected.</Species>
<Species>Fluorescence was measured using a FACSCalibur (Becton Dickinson).</Species>
<Species>Data collection and analysis were performed using CellQuest software.</Species>

<Species>Electrophoresis and immunoblotting Cell extracts (15 ug) were fractionated by 10% SDS-PAGE, then transferred to Hybond-P PVDF membranes (Amersham) and probed with primary antibodies (CIA9), and secondary antibodies (anti-rabbit or anti-mouse horseradish peroxidase-conjugated IgG), obtained from Jackson Immunoresearch Laboratories.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Enhanced chemiluminescence reagents (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) were used for signal detection.</Species>
<Species>For the analysis of H3 ser10 phosphorylation, we used whole-cell extracts from 700 000</Species>
<Species>Kc cells (control and RNAi at day 8).</Species>
<Species>Western blotting was performed using polyclonal antibodies against ser10-phosphorylated histone H3 at a dilution of 1:1000 (Upstate).</Species>
<Species>Kc control cells arrested in mitosis by incubation in 25 uM colchicine (Sigma) for 24 h were also analyzed for comparison.</Species>
<Species>Immunofluorescence Kc cells were seeded onto polylysine slides, fixed with 4% formaldehyde for 15 min and permeabilized with 0.5% Triton X-100 for 5 min.</Species>

<Species>The incubation with primary antibodies was carried out in blocking solution for 1 h. For staining of mitotic cells, the cells were permeabilized using PBST (PBS containing 0.3% Triton X-100) and stained with polyclonal antibody against Drosophila Aurora B at 1:200 dilution and monoclonal mouse at anti-b-tubulin 1:300 dilution (Chemicon International) as primary antibodies.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Secondary antibodies were anti-rabbit coupled with Alexa 488 (1:500) and anti-mouse coupled to Alexa 546 (1:500) (Molecular Probes, Eugene, Oregon).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Images were acquired using a confocal LSM510 META microscope (Zeiss).</Species>
<Species>Stacks of images were analyzed using the IMARIS 4.0 program (Media cybernetics, Carlsbad, CA).</Species>
<Species>Antibodies Affinity-purified polyclonal antibodies of HP1 (rabbit #192 and #187, 5 ug) and 5 ug of polyclonal anti-HA antibodies (Sigma) were used in each ChIP reaction.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The specificity of the HP1 polyclonal antibodies was determined using various approaches, including western blotting assay, immunofluorescence staining and immunoprecipitation to pull down HP1 (data not shown).</Species>
<Species>The monoclonal antibody HP1-CIA9 (5) was used at a dilution of 1:20 in immunoblotting assays.</Species>
<Species>Microarray analysis and RT-PCR Total RNA was isolated from control and HP1-depleted Kc cells at day 8 using an RNeasy kit (Qiagen).</Species>
<Species>RNA labeling and microarray data analysis followed the standard protocol from Affymetrix.</Species>
<Species>We used ANOVA (P < 0.001) to assess the expression confidence for each gene.</Species>
<Species>For RT-PCR analysis, poly(A)+ mRNA was purified with the Oligotex Direct mRNA kit (Qiagen) according to the manufacturer's instructions.</Species>
<Species>The purified poly(A)+ RNA was reverse transcribed using the Thermoscript kit (Invitrogen).</Species>
<Species>The cDNA was then used for PCR amplification for 35 cycles with gene-specific primers.</Species>

<Species>PCR products were scanned after electrophoretic separation with a Typhoon Scanner, quantified using ImageQuant software (Amersham Biosciences) and normalized for amplification of the Actin5c transcript.</Species>
<Species>The sequence of primers used for RT-PCR and ChIP analysis are provided in the Supplementary Material.</Species>
<Species>ChIP ChIP was performed according to Orlando et al.</Species>
<Species>(29)</Species>
<Species>and the protocol provided by Upstate () with some modifications.</Species>
<Species>In brief, 1-2 x 108 Kc cells were prepared and fixed in 1% formaldehyde.</Species>

<Species>Nuclei were isolated according to a standard procedure in Current Protocols (), then resuspended in 1.7 ml of lysis buffer (50 mM Tris, pH 8.0, 10 mM EDTA, 1% SDS and protease inhibitors) and sonicated using a Branson sonifier 250.</Species>
<Species>Chromatin fractions in the size range 0.2-0.8 kb were used to perform immunoprecipitation experiments.</Species>

<Species>We used 5 ug affinity-purified polyclonal antibodies (#192 and #182 for HP1; HA antibody for control) and 1 ml of salmon sperm DNA/protein-A-agarose (Upstate) pre-cleared chromatin lysate in each reaction.</Species>

<Species>The mixture was then rotated at 4oC overnight and the recovered beads were washed twice with 1 ml of Low salt buffer (Upstate), once with High salt buffer (Upstate), once with LiCl buffer (Upstate) and twice with TE at 4oC for 8 min. ChIP DNA was extracted according to the standard procedures (29).</Species>
<Species>RESULTS Depletion of HP1 in Drosophila Kc cells Various chromosomal defects in the cell cycle have been observed in embryos or larval tissues of Drosophila HP1 mutants (8,27).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>However, the presence of maternally loaded HP1 in embryos and the lethality of HP1 mutants at late larval stages have so far precluded a systematic study of the role of HP1 in cell-cycle regulation.</Species>
<Species>Therefore, we used Drosophila Kc cells, a cell line derived from Drosophila embryos, as a model system to address this problem.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>HP1 transcripts were depleted using an RNAi-based approach (see Materials and Methods).</Species>
<Species>The reduction in HP1 expression was measured both by RT-PCR and by western blotting analysis (Figure 1A).</Species>
<Species>A significant reduction in the HP1 expression was already evident after 2 days treatment with HP1 dsRNA.</Species>
<Species>Cells at day 8 showed a reduction in HP1 of  90% (Figure 1A) and were therefore used in all subsequent experiments.</Species>

<Species>Cell-cycle progression at S and G2/M phase is altered in the absence of HP1 The impact of HP1 loss on the cell cycle of Kc cells was determined using cell-cycle profile analysis of HP1-depleted and control cells.</Species>
<Species>The percentage of cells in S phase was determined by BrdU incorporation, and total DNA content by 7-amino-actinomycin (7-AAD).</Species>

<Species>The results showed that the depletion of HP1 (day 8) caused a decrease in S-phase cells of at least 4-fold, and a 2-fold decrease in G2/M-phase cells (Figure 1B), although no significant effect was found at the G1 phase.</Species>
<Species>In addition, depletion of HP1 caused a greater than 7-fold increase in the number of apoptotic cells.</Species>
<Species>These results, therefore, confirm that HP1 is an important regulator during the cell cycle, especially at the S and G2/M phases.</Species>

<Species>Cell-cycle regulators require HP1 to maintain their active transcription To ask whether the cell-cycle defects were due to changes in the transcription of genes functionally involved in S phase and the G2/M phase, we next assessed global changes in gene transcription following depletion of HP1.</Species>
<Species>Expression profile analysis was performed using total RNA isolated from both HP1-depleted Kc cells and control Kc cells, and an Affymetrix Drosophila chip.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>For each experiment, we used total RNA isolated from two independent HP1-depleted and control samples, and at least two independent experiments were performed.</Species>

<Species>The microarray analysis showed that loss of HP1 function in Kc cells resulted in alterations in transcription of >500 genes:  400 genes were down-regulated and  120 genes were up-regulated (>1.5-fold, ANOVA).</Species>

<Species>The function of these genes ranged from cellular enzymes, signal transduction molecules, and membrane and cell structural proteins, to nucleic acid-binding proteins and cell-cycle regulators (Figure 2A).</Species>

<Species>At the chromosomal level, the genes targeted by HP1 appeared to be distributed along all euchromatic chromosomal arms (data not shown), supporting a global role of HP1 in euchromatic gene regulation (20).</Species>
<Species>Among 60 known/predicted genes associated with DNA replication function, 15 were down-regulated in the absence of HP1 (Figure 2B).</Species>
<Species>These included McM2, McM5, McM6 and CDC45L, which are required for processive DNA replication and correct chromosome condensation (30-32).</Species>

<Species>Other genes involved in DNA replication, such as components of the origin recognition complex (Orc)   Orc4, Caf1, Gnf1, Dref1, DNA polymerase-g and Tam   were also down-regulated (Figure 2B).</Species>

<Species>Aurora B and inner centromere protein (INCENP), known to be required for kinetochore assembly, chromosome condensation and bipolar chromosome attachment during mitosis (33), also showed a reduction in transcription.</Species>
<Species>A similar loss of transcription was observed in Bub1 and Bub3 (Figure 2B), encoding mitotic checkpoint control proteins (34,35).</Species>

<Species>Loss function of Bub1 has been shown to cause chromatin bridges to extend between the two separating groups of chromosomes, and extensive chromosome fragmentation in anaphase cells (35).</Species>
<Species>We confirmed the changes in the transcription of cell-cycle regulators using semi-quantitative RT-PCR, which gave results consistent with the microarray analysis.</Species>
<Species>In addition, cell-cycle regulator genes, such as McM3, McM7 and Asp (abnormal spindle), were also confirmed to be down-regulated (Figure 2C).</Species>
<Species>Collectively, these results demonstrate that HP1 is indeed involved in the regulation of transcription of cell-cycle regulators.</Species>

<Species>HP1 is required for Aurora B distribution and histone H3 phosphorylation INCENP is localized to the centromeric region of chromosomes at metaphase and the spindle midzone at anaphase, which then targets Aurora B, a kinase essential for histone H3 ser10 phosphorylation, to these sites (36).</Species>
<Species>Loss of function of both these    chromosomal passenger    proteins causes abnormal chromosomal segregation at metaphase, as well as certain cytokinesis defects (36,37).</Species>

<Species>The loss of transcription of both INCENP and Aurora B after depletion of HP1, therefore, raised the possibility that localization of Aurora B (Figure 3 and data not shown) may be altered.</Species>

<Species>Staining of HP1-depleted Kc cells with anti-Aurora B antibodies indeed revealed an altered localization of Aurora B and, in a number of cases, a complete loss of Aurora B (Figure 3A).</Species>

<Species>Consistent with the loss function of Aurora B, the spindles in the metaphase cells were also disorganized, with a large number of cells showing an altered prometaphase chromosome alignment (Figure 3A).</Species>
<Species>Some showed extensive chromosome fragmentation (Figure 3B), or the presence of a third spindle pole-like structure as indicated by beta-tubulin (Figure 3A).</Species>
<Species>At telophase, we observed defective separating cells with an extra cell envelope-like structure without nuclei (Figure 3A).</Species>

<Species>Chromatin bridges or lagging chromatids at telophase were also evident in some cells (Figure 3C); however, in some cases, localization of Aurora B appeared not to be affected, arguing that other pathways are possibly involved.</Species>

<Species>We next analyzed changes in histone H3 serine 10 phosphorylation, since the loss of transcription of INCENP is known to affect localization of Aurora B (33), which is essential in the regulation of histone H3 phosphorylation (36).</Species>
<Species>Total cell extracts from HP1-depleted Kc cells were analyzed by western blotting (Figure 3D).</Species>

<Species>The results indeed showed a severalfold reduction in H3 ser10 phosphorylation after depletion of HP1, consistent with the functional disruption of INCENP and Aurora B in the absence of HP1.</Species>

<Species>HP1 directly targets genes encoding cell-cycle regulators in euchromatin To test whether the loss of transcription of genes involved in DNA replication and mitosis was a direct effect of the loss of HP1, we performed a ChIP analysis to determine whether HP1 is physically associated with these genes.</Species>

<Species>Chromatin lysates from formaldehyde-fixed Kc cells were sonicated into small chromatin fragments (0.2-0.8 kb) and immunoprecipitated with polyclonal antibodies against Drosophila HP1.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>As a control, we used a mock precipitation (beads only) and polyclonal antibodies against HA.</Species>

<Species>Our ChIP results showed that known transposable elements distributed in heterochromatin, such as F-element, TART and 1360 (7,38), were all enriched in HP1 binding (Figure 4), which is also consistent with a previous study (20).</Species>
<Species>Using the same ChIP DNA material, we then attempted to determine whether HP1 was enriched in genes involved in DNA replication.</Species>
<Species>Primers were designed to cover the promoter regions of selected genes.</Species>
<Species>The results showed that McM3, McM5 and Tam were all enriched in HP1 binding (Figure 4).</Species>
<Species>However, McM7 appeared to be HP1-negative, although its transcription was also affected by the loss of HP1 function.</Species>
<Species>Genes essential for mitosis, such as Aurora B, were also HP1-positive (Figure 4).</Species>
<Species>These results demonstrate that these cell-cycle regulator genes are directly targeted by HP1 in their promoter regions.</Species>
<Species>DISCUSSION</Species>
<Species>In this study, we used microarray and RT-PCR techniques to demonstrate that transcription of cell-cycle regulators is misregulated in the absence of HP1.</Species>

<Species>Certain defects in S phase may be a direct consequence of the loss of transcription of DNA replication genes such as McM2, McM5, McM6, CDC45L, Orc4 and others, since these genes have been functionally implicated in the initiation of DNA replication and/or the progression of replication forks (39).</Species>

<Species>Depletion or mutation of these genes has been shown to result in DNA damage (32), the blockage of replication forks (39), increased chromosome loss/genome instability, and defective condensation (30).</Species>
<Species>The reduction in the number of cells in G2/M phase may be a consequence of the reduction in transcription or functional disruption of INCENP, Aurora B, Bub1, and Bub3 (34,36).</Species>

<Species>Chromosome segregation defects, such as chromosome fragmentation and chromatin bridges in anaphase/telophase cells, and certain cytokinesis defects in HP1-depleted cells, mimic the phenotype of cells with loss function of INCENP, Aurora B or Bub1 (35-37).</Species>

<Species>The mislocalization of Aurora B in the absence of HP1 is also consistent with the loss of transcription and functional disruption of INCENP (37), and the reduction in Aurora B transcription may be partially responsible for the observed chromosomal defects, including loss of histone H3 phosphorylation at serine 10.</Species>

<Species>HP1 is also known to physically interact with certain components of replication complexes such as ORCs and MCMs (30,40,41), with the inner centromere protein INCENP (42) and the chromatin assembly factor CAF1 (43) promoting delivery of HP1 to heterochromatin sites (44).</Species>

<Species>Loss of HP1 is, therefore, expected to cause disruption to such HP1-associated complexes, and will partially contribute to the chromatin/chromosomal defects in HP1 mutants (8,27) and HP1-depleted Kc cells.</Species>

<Species>It is therefore well possible that the loss of transcription of these cell-cycle regulator genes, and consequent disruption of HP1 functional complexes or heterochromatin structure, all contributed to the cell-cycle defects observed.</Species>
<Species>The ChIP assay supports the hypothesis that the loss of transcription of cell-cycle regulator genes is a direct effect of the lack of HP1.</Species>

<Species>Aurora B, McM3, and McM5 were all bound by HP1 at their promoter regions, although other cell-cycle regulators, such as McM7, were HP1-negative, implying that the altered transcription in these genes might be a secondary effect of the loss of HP1.</Species>

<Species>A previous study in Drosophila Kc cells (20) employed an approach based on the ectopic expression of a fusion protein of HP1 with a prokaryotic DNA adenine methyltransferase and identified a number of methylated targets in the genome.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In this study, MCM3 and MCM5 were not found to be methylated, indicating lack of association with HP1.</Species>
<Species>On the other hand, heterochromatin repeats, such F-element and 1360, were consistently found to be HP1-enriched both here and in the previous study.</Species>
<Species>It remains to be determined whether these discrepancies are due to the different experimental systems used.</Species>
<Species>However, we note that the previous study was performed using a cDNA array, while we observe binding of endogenous HP1 at the promoter of these genes.</Species>
<Species>Similarly, another study using chromatin immunoprecipitation in larvae also showed few HP1-positive genes that were not detected in Kc cells by the Dam ID approach (21).</Species>
<Species>A large number of genes affected by the loss of D.melanogaster HP1 in larval tissues (21) seem to be different from that in embryonic Kc cells.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The change in the transcription of Aurora B and few cell-cycle regulators reported in this study is also not found among the HP1-affected genes at larval stage (21).</Species>
<Species>This may be due to specific role(s) of HP1 in different stages of development.</Species>

<Species>Alternatively, it is also possible that the impact of HP1 in the transcription of cell-cycle regulators in proliferating cells is underestimated when performing the analyses on larval tissues, and thus on mixed populations of both proliferating and differentiating/differentiated cells.</Species>

<Species>HP1 is generally known as a transcriptional repressor, as supported by several lines of evidence: silencing of a euchromatic reporter gene in heterochromatin requires HP1 (10,11), tethering of HP1 next to a euchromatic reporter gene causes silencing (45), and the repression of genes within euchromatic region 31 bound by HP1 is relieved in the absence of HP1 (46).</Species>
<Species>In contrast, genes in heterochromatin, known as heterochromatic genes, such as light and rolled, seem to require HP1 to maintain their active transcription (47,48).</Species>
<Species>The level of transcription of heterochromatic genes was dramatically reduced in a mutated HP1 background (47-49).</Species>
<Species>It was therefore proposed that HP1 may function as a positive regulator of transcription of these genes (50,51), although the exact regulation mechanism remains unclear.</Species>
<Species>A study of heat-shock genes found that HP1 is associated with RNA transcripts in the coding region, and is also a positive regulator of their transcription (52,53).</Species>

<Species>The chromatin association of HP1 at the promoter region of active euchromatic genes demonstrated from this work and others, and its independence from histone H3K9 methylation (21), all suggest that mechanism whereby HP1 modulates transcription of euchromatic genes is potentially distinct from its role in heterochromatin formation.</Species>

<Species>Collectively, the results of this study demonstrate that HP1 plays an essential role in cell-cycle progression, and support the view that HP1, in addition to its role in heterochromatin, can act as a positive transcriptional regulator of euchromatic genes.</Species>
<Species>SUPPLEMENTARY MATERIAL Supplementary Material is available at NAR Online.</Species>
<Species>Supplementary Material</Species>
<Species>Structural organization and interactions of transmembrane domains in tetraspanin proteins</Species>

<Species>Abstract Background Proteins of the tetraspanin family contain four transmembrane domains (TM1-4) linked by two extracellular loops and a short intracellular loop, and have short intracellular N- and C-termini.</Species>
<Species>While structure and function analysis of the larger extracellular loop has been performed, the organization and role of transmembrane domains have not been systematically assessed.</Species>
<Species>Results Among 28 human tetraspanin proteins, the TM1-3 sequences display a distinct heptad repeat motif (abcdefg)n.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In TM1, position a is occupied by structurally conserved bulky residues and position d contains highly conserved Asn and Gly residues.</Species>
<Species>In TM2, position a is occupied by conserved small residues (Gly/Ala/Thr), and position d has a conserved Gly and two bulky aliphatic residues.</Species>

<Species>In TM3, three a positions of the heptad repeat are filled by two leucines and a glutamate/glutamine residue, and two d positions are occupied by either Phe/Tyr or Val/Ile/Leu residues.</Species>
<Species>No heptad motif is apparent in TM4 sequences.</Species>
<Species>Mutations of conserved glycines in human CD9 (Gly25 and Gly32 in TM1; Gly67 and Gly74 in TM2) caused aggregation of mutant proteins inside the cell.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Modeling of the TM1-TM2 interface in CD9, using a novel algorithm, predicts tight packing of conserved bulky residues against conserved Gly residues along the two helices.</Species>

<Species>The homodimeric interface of CD9 was mapped, by disulfide cross-linking of single-cysteine mutants, to the vicinity of residues Leu14 and Phe17 in TM1 (positions g and c) and Gly77, Gly80 and Ala81 in TM2 (positions d, g and a, respectively).</Species>

<Species>Mutations of a and d residues in both TM1 and TM2 (Gly25, Gly32, Gly67 and Gly74), involved in intramolecular TM1-TM2 interaction, also strongly diminished intermolecular interaction, as assessed by cross-linking of Cys80.</Species>
<Species>Conclusion Our results suggest that tetraspanin intra- and intermolecular interactions are mediated by conserved residues in adjacent, but distinct regions of TM1 and TM2.</Species>
<Species>A key structural element that defines TM1-TM2 interaction in tetraspanins is the specific packing of bulky residues against small residues.</Species>

<Species>Background Tetraspanins constitute a large family of integral membrane proteins, characteristically containing 4, 6 or 8 conserved cysteine residues in the large extracellular loop (including the CCG and PxxCC motifs), which form disulfide bonds, and several conserved polar residues in the intracellular loop and transmembrane regions [1,2].</Species>
<Species>There are 32 putative tetraspanin family members in mammals, 37 in Drosophila melanogaster and 20 in Caenorhabditis elegans.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Tetraspanins play diverse roles in cell adhesion, migration and fusion processes, cellular activation and signaling (reviewed in refs.</Species>
<Species>[2-4]).</Species>

<Species>Mammalian tetraspanins such as CD9, CD63, CD81, CD82, CD151, rds/peripherin, and uroplakins Ia and Ib have been most extensively studied, with mouse knock-out models available for CD9 [5-7], CD81</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>[8,9], CD151 [10] and a few others.</Species>
<Species>However, the majority of tetraspanins are characterized very little, if at all, at genetic, biochemical or structural levels.</Species>
<Species>The large extracellular loop (LEL) of tetraspanins has received most attention, since it contains functionally important sites.</Species>

<Species>Sequence QRD (194-196) in CD151 is important for association with integrins, which has functional consequences for integrin-dependent cell spreading and multicellular cable formation [11].</Species>
<Species>A site in the LEL of CD9, SFQ (residues 173-175), is essential for CD9 function in sperm-egg fusion [12].</Species>
<Species>The crystal structure of tetraspanin CD81 LEL revealed five a-helixes, A-E [13].</Species>
<Species>Helices A, B and E form a relatively conserved region in tetraspanins, whereas the region between helices B and E is the most variable</Species>
<Species>[14].</Species>
<Species>Interestingly, the variable region contains most of the functionally important sites involved in tetraspanin protein-protein interactions.</Species>

<Species>A remarkable biochemical property of tetraspanin molecules is their ability to associate with a large number of other transmembrane proteins, including integrins, membrane-associated growth factors and receptors, MHC class II molecules, Ig superfamily proteins, and each other [2,3,15].</Species>
<Species>Several of these lateral associations of tetraspanins are detected in "mild" detergents (Brij series, CHAPS), but are disrupted by "strong" detergents such as Triton X-100 or SDS.</Species>
<Species>Multiprotein complexes of tetraspanins and associated molecules, also called the "tetraspanin web" [16], may represent a distinct tetraspanin-enriched membrane microdomain</Species>
<Species>[17,18].</Species>
<Species>The formation of this microdomain is influenced by palmitoylation of several conserved juxtamembrane cysteine residues in tetraspanins [19-21].</Species>
<Species>The transmembrane domains, encompassing nearly half of a tetraspanin protein, are the most conserved part of the molecule (Stipp et al.</Species>
<Species>[1] and this study).</Species>
<Species>However, very little functional information is available on these domains.</Species>
<Species>The differential detergent sensitivity of tetraspanin-tetraspanin associations suggests that hydrophobic interactions between TM helices may play a role.</Species>
<Species>Indeed, when the large extracellular loop (LEL) of CD151 is deleted, the molecule is still able to associate with other tetraspanins [22].</Species>
<Species>Thus, TM domains are strong candidates for mediating tetraspanin-tetraspanin interactions.</Species>

<Species>The importance of TM domain interactions in intramolecular organization was demonstrated in a study showing that CD82 fragment TM2-4, lacking TM1, was retained in the endoplasmic reticulum, but was transported to the cell surface upon co-expression of TM1 [23].</Species>
<Species>This in vivo reconstitution experiment demonstrated a strong interaction between TM1 and the rest of the molecule.</Species>

<Species>Expression of a truncated CD9 molecule (TM3-LEL-TM4) results in intracellular accumulation of the protein and significant misfolding of the LEL, as judged by inappropriate disulfide formation and diminished antibody reactivity (our unpublished data).</Species>
<Species>Similarly, a CD9 epitope in the LEL is lost in molecules lacking either TM2+TM3 or just TM4 [24].</Species>
<Species>Thus, TM domain interactions and packing are crucial for proper folding, stability and transport of tetraspanin molecules.</Species>
<Species>In a previous study, we showed that covalent cross-linking of membrane-proximal cysteine residues can be used as a tool for detection of tetraspanin-tetraspanin associations [25].</Species>

<Species>Inhibition of cysteine palmitoylation by 2-bromopalmitate (2-BP) made cysteines available for cross-linking and enabled demonstration of specific tetraspanin homodimerization and low levels of heterodimerization.</Species>
<Species>We concluded that tetraspanin homodimers, formed in the Golgi, may be a fundamental structural unit within tetraspanin microdomains.</Species>
<Species>In this study, we carried out detailed sequence analysis of human tetraspanin TM domains.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We show that a heptad repeat containing conserved glycine, asparagine and large hydrophobic residues occurs in TM1 and TM2 domains, and predict tight intramolecular association of these two domains by packing of the large residues against the small residues.</Species>

<Species>Moreover, by using cysteine cross-linking we map a dimerization interface in the human CD9 protein, and show that conserved heptad motif glycine residues are also important for intermolecular CD9 associations.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Results Sequence analysis of tetraspanin transmembrane domains: presence of the heptad repeat motif We focused our attention on 28 human tetraspanins identified from the SWISS-PROT and GenBank databases.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>All tetraspanins have in common four hydrophobic stretches (TM domains) of 20-25 residues, and contain highly conserved residues in the second extracellular loop, in particular the Cys-Cys-Gly (CCG) motif.</Species>
<Species>Detailed analysis of the large extracellular loop sequences [14], and dendrograms based on full-length alignment can be found in earlier studies [26,27].</Species>
<Species>The length of each transmembrane domain was established based on previous sequence analysis of tetraspanin sequences [27,28], and on annotations to the database entries.</Species>
<Species>Manual adjustments based on sequence homology and hydrophobicity profiles were done to fully delineate the TM domains.</Species>
<Species>The resulting lengths of TM domains were: TM1 - 23 residues; TM2 - 21 residues; TM3 - 25 residues; TM4 - 25 residues.</Species>

<Species>Two more residues could be added onto the N-terminal part of TM2; however, relatively small sequence conservation of these residues among tetraspanins and occurrence of polar/charged side chains in some tetraspanins precluded us from doing so for the global alignment.</Species>
<Species>Figures 1 and 2 show a multiple sequence alignment of four TM domains of 28 human tetraspanins.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>For each position within the domains, consensus residues were determined and classified (with individual color code) in 4 categories: 1) large hydrophobic residues (including Val, Met, Leu, Ile, Phe, Tyr, Trp), 2) small residues (Gly, Ala, Ser and Thr), 3) Cys, and 4) Asn.</Species>
<Species>When more than two types of residues occupied a given position in a TM, a dual-color pattern that reflected the prevalence of the particular residue type was used (Figure 1).</Species>
<Species>Cysteine residues were shown separately due to their importance as palmitoylation target sites.</Species>
<Species>The highly conserved asparagine residue in TM1 was considered separately.</Species>
<Species>No proline residues are found in TM domains 1-3 of human tetraspanins.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>An inspection of the multiple sequence alignment reveals a repeating heptad amino acid pattern, (abcdefg)n, in TM1, 2 and 3 (Figure 1, 2).</Species>
<Species>Heptad repeats promote helical coiled coil interactions in multiple soluble and membrane-spanning proteins [29-31].</Species>

<Species>In the heptad repeat, hydrophobic residues in positions a and d are of special importance, as they directly mediate interhelical contacts by creating a tight knobs-into-holes packing in the coiled coil structure [32].</Species>

<Species>For instance, in the leucine zipper of the yeast transcription factor GCN4, positions a and d contain Val and Leu residues, respectively, with an Asn residue in a single a position forming a hydrogen bond across the GCN4 dimer interface [33].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In TM1 of tetraspanins, highly conserved Asn, Gly and Gly residues (numbers 18, 25 and 32 in the CD9 sequence) appear at d positions of the heptad repeats, and residues 14, 21 and 28 are at a positions (Figure 1).</Species>
<Species>In TM2, residues 67, 74 and 81 (consensus Gly, Gly and Ala, respectively) occupy a positions, whereas residues 63, 70 and 77 are at d positions.</Species>
<Species>Another highly conserved glycine, Gly80, occupies the 3rd g position in TM2.</Species>
<Species>In TM3, the conserved pattern consists of two leucine residues (Leu89 and Leu96) and a glutamate/glutamine residue (Glu/Gln103) in a positions (Figure 2).</Species>
<Species>Two d positions are also conserved - Phe/Tyr92 and Ile/Val/Leu99.</Species>
<Species>TM4 lacks a conserved heptad pattern and has only a single conserved position, Glu/Gln209 (with four exceptions).</Species>
<Species>These features of TM1-4 of tetraspanins are displayed on helical wheel diagrams (Figure 3).</Species>
<Species>Analysis of TM1 sequences The conserved Asn-Gly-Gly motif, occupying designated d positions of the heptad repeat, is the most prominent structural feature of TM1.</Species>

<Species>We also compared sequences of CD9 orthologs from 10 different organisms (the most available for any tetraspanin) to gain further insight into conservation and variability of the TM1 sequence.</Species>

<Species>As shown in Figure 4, positions a, d and g in TM1 are among the most conserved (0, 1 and 1 substitution, respectively), while interspecies variability tends to occur in other positions: b (5 substitutions), c (4 substitutions), e (4 substitutions) and f (4 substitutions).</Species>
<Species>Thus, the positions typically involved in coiled coil interactions (a and d) are the most conserved.</Species>
<Species>When residues of TM1 are plotted as a helical wheel, additional structural features are revealed (Figure 3).</Species>

<Species>There are highly conserved aliphatic and aromatic residues in the first three a positions of the heptad motif (Phe15, Trp22 and Leu29 in CD9), as well as in g positions (Leu14, Phe21, Val28 in CD9).</Species>
<Species>The "ridges" formed by these bulky residues are flanking the "groove"-forming Gly residues of the Asn-Gly-Gly position d motif.</Species>
<Species>In contrast, b, c, e and f positions show an overall higher variability among tetraspanins, as also seen in the comparison of CD9 orthologs described above.</Species>
<Species>Analysis of TM2 sequences A landmark feature of TM2 in tetraspanins is the presence of highly conserved glycine residues (Gly67, 74, 77 and 80 in CD9, Figure 1).</Species>
<Species>Other substitutions at these positions are almost exclusively small residues, such as Ala or Ser.</Species>
<Species>In addition, Ala, Ser or Thr occupy position 81.</Species>
<Species>This residue, together with Gly67 and Gly74, forms face a of the helix.</Species>
<Species>Residue Gly77 (position d) is preceded by conserved, chiefly large hydrophobic residues on the same helical face (Leu63 and Met70 in CD9).</Species>
<Species>Extremely conserved Gly80 falls into heptad position g (Figure 3).</Species>

<Species>Among CD9 orthologs, heptad positions a and d are absolutely conserved, whereas other positions have the following number of substitutions: b - 3; c - 2; e - 1; f - 3; g - 1 (Figure 4).</Species>
<Species>Two of the f position residues in TM2 (65 and 79) also show higher variability among different tetraspanins (Figures 1, 3).</Species>
<Species>Cysteine residues are frequently found near the cytoplasmic end of TM2 helix at positions 78 and 79; these cysteines are likely to be palmitoylated.</Species>
<Species>Analysis of TM3 and TM4 sequences The TM3 domain provides another example of the heptad repeat pattern.</Species>
<Species>Position a is occupied by two highly conserved leucine and a glutamate/glutamine residue (Leu89, Leu96 and Glu/Gln103 in CD9).</Species>
<Species>Furthermore, two d positions are conserved - Phe/Tyr92 (aromatic residue) and Ile/Val99 (b-branched aliphatic residue; Figures 2, 3).</Species>
<Species>In addition, residue 100 in position e is generally Phe or Leu.</Species>
<Species>Among CD9 orthologs, position a has 1 substitution, positions b, c and f each have 6, positions d and e each have 2, and g has 4.</Species>
<Species>Thus, as for TM1 and TM2, positions a and d are among the most conserved, but overall TM3 has more variable positions than TM1 or TM2 (Figure 3).</Species>
<Species>Less than half of TM3 sequences contain cysteine residues, and those tend to occur at the internal positions of the helix (Figure 2).</Species>
<Species>TM4 shows less conservation among various tetraspanin family members than the other TM domains (Figures 2, 3).</Species>
<Species>The only highly conserved feature is the glutamate/glutamine residue in position 209.</Species>

<Species>In addition, one or two cysteine residues can be found at the C-terminal end of TM4 in some tetraspanins (e.g. CD9, CD81, CD151), and many sequences contain additional polar residues (Arg, Lys, His, Asn, Gln).</Species>
<Species>No conserved heptad motif was identified in TM4, as also confirmed by analysis of substitutions in CD9 orthologs (data not shown).</Species>
<Species>Mutational analysis of conserved glycine residues in TM1 and TM2 The conserved nature of the Asn and Gly residues in TM1 and TM2 prompted an analysis of their functional role.</Species>
<Species>To this end, we have probed whether mutations of these residues destabilize the protein molecule.</Species>

<Species>We expressed a construct of the first and second TMs of CD9, connected by the small extracellular loop, and tagged with a C-terminal green fluorescent protein (TM(1+2)-GFP molecule).</Species>
<Species>In human rhabdomyosarcoma RD cells, the wild-type fusion protein localized mostly in a reticular, intracellular pattern, without forming any large aggregates (Figure 5, panel A).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Remarkably, when double mutants Gly25Leu + Gly32Leu and Gly67Leu + Gly74Leu were expressed, the protein formed distinct large aggregates in a high proportion of cells (Figure 5, panels C and E).</Species>
<Species>In contrast, double mutant Gly77Leu +</Species>
<Species>Gly80Leu did not form such aggregates (Figure 5, panel G).</Species>

<Species>Results with respective single mutants were similar to that with double mutants, with the aggregation being somewhat more pronounced for Leu substitutions of Gly67 and Gly74 compared to Gly25 and Gly32 mutations.</Species>
<Species>No aggregation was observed for Asn18Ser and Asn18Tyr mutants (data not shown).</Species>
<Species>Also, nearly identical results were obtained with human HT1080 cells (data not shown).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We interpret these results as an indication that aggregating mutants are destabilized or misfolded while non-aggregating mutants retain the wild-type conformation.</Species>
<Species>Intriguingly, mutations to the conserved GG7 motifs caused protein aggregation while the mutation of other glycines had no detectable effect.</Species>

<Species>These results also suggest that wild-type GFP, which has weak tendency to self-associate, could enhance non-specific interactions of destabilized mutant TM(1+2) CD9 moieties, leading to their aggregation.</Species>
<Species>Consistent with this hypothesis, the aggregation of Gly25Leu + Gly32Leu and Gly67Leu + Gly74Leu double mutants was suppressed when monomeric GFP molecule, Leu221Lys</Species>
<Species>[34] was used (Figure 5, panels D and F).</Species>
<Species>The use of monomeric GFP did not affect intercellular localization of wild-type CD9 TM(1+2) (Figure 5, panel B), or a Gly77Leu +</Species>
<Species>Gly80Leu double mutant (Figure 5, panel H).</Species>

<Species>In summary, Leu substitutions of Gly residues that are part of the Asn-Gly-Gly (NGG7) motif in TM1, or Gly-Gly-Ala (GGA7) motif in TM2, resulted in destabilization and aggregation of GFP-fused TM(1+2) proteins, whereas substitutions of Gly77 or Gly80, which are not part of these motifs (Figure 3), failed to show such aggregation.</Species>
<Species>Prediction and modelling of interaction between TM1 and TM2 Consecutive helices in polytopic membrane proteins frequently interact [35].</Species>

<Species>Sequence analysis of TM1 and TM2 helices of tetraspanins reveals a remarkable complementarity in the distribution of large and small residues at heptad positions a and d along the helical axis (Figure 3), suggesting that these residues may interact.</Species>

<Species>To further elucidate the potential for TM1-TM2 interaction, the putative interface was modeled using a novel algorithm that considers mutational data during each step of a Monte Carlo simulated annealing cycle (see Methods for details).</Species>

<Species>Specifically, Gly25Leu, Gly32Leu, Gly67Leu and Gly74Leu were scored as disruptive mutations, while Asn18Ser, Gly77Leu and Gly80Leu were scored as silent mutations, based on their effects on protein stability (Figure 5 and data not shown).</Species>
<Species>The resulting model predicts left-handed crossing of TM1 and TM2 helices at an angle of +28o.</Species>

<Species>The key element of the structure is the apposition of bulky and small heptad position a and d residues, as follows: Gly32-Leu63; Gly67-Leu29; Gly25-Met70; Gly74-Trp22; Asn18-Gly77; Ala81-Phe15 (Figure 6).</Species>
<Species>Our model predicts that each of these residue pairs are in van der Waals contact.</Species>
<Species>Additionally, two potential H-bonds are predicted in this model, indicating close packing: Gly67 Ca to Gly25 carbonyl oxygen, and Trp22 Ca to Met70 carbonyl oxygen.</Species>
<Species>The packing is tighter in the ectodomain-proximal portion of the helices (Figure 6, panel B), as determined by Ca-Ca distances between interacting residue pairs.</Species>

<Species>The key elements of the model are corroborated by the presence of apparently complementary substitutions in TM1 and TM2 sequences of different tetraspanins (Figure 1, boxed residues).</Species>
<Species>For example, Gly74 is predicted to interact with Trp22.</Species>
<Species>In 8 of the 10 tetraspanins that contain a substitution for Gly74, a compensatory substitution occurs at the Trp22 position (Figure 1).</Species>
<Species>Thus, a larger non-glycine side chain at position 74 may necessitate a less bulky non-Trp side chain in position 22.</Species>

<Species>Likewise, the presence of a Cb at position 25, typically occupied by glycine, necessitates a non-b-branched amino acid at position 70, which is occupied by a b-branched residue in nearly half of all cases.</Species>
<Species>Indeed, we find that in each of 5 cases in which position 25 contains a Cb, a leucine residue occurs in position 70.</Species>
<Species>This analysis is consistent with our molecular model that suggests Leu70 will pack most favorably against a Cb at position 25 than a b-branched residue or a methionine.</Species>
<Species>Role of TM1 and TM2 heptad motif residues in CD9 dimerization To probe CD9 dimerization, we used a cysteine-mediated cross-linking approach.</Species>
<Species>We established previously a simple and efficient method for cysteine-mediated cross-linking [25].</Species>

<Species>After cells are pre-treated with 2-BP for 16-24 hours to expose normally palmitoylated cysteines, the cysteines can be cross-linked using any of the following methods: a) Spontaneous oxidation in Brij97 lysates (a condition that preserves tetraspanin-tetraspanin associations), b) In situ cross-linking, by pre-lysis oxidation of cells with Cu2+-phenanthroline (CuP) to promote disulfide bond formation.</Species>
<Species>c)</Species>
<Species>In situ cross-linking with thiol-reactive cross-linking agents of defined length (e.g. DTME, BMB).</Species>
<Species>The first two approaches produce in essence "zero-length" disulfides, indicative of close proximity of target cysteines and presumably high specificity of interaction.</Species>
<Species>In contrast, chemical cross-linkers with 6-20 A spacer arm may cross-link with higher efficiency, but not necessarily higher specificity.</Species>
<Species>However, they provide advantages such as variable membrane permeability, and potential linkage cleavability.</Species>
<Species>For tetraspanins such as CD9, membrane-permeable cross-linker DTME (13.3 A-long, reducible) provides highly specific and efficient cross-linking [25].</Species>

<Species>Here we have used a cysteine cross-linking strategy, in combination with cysteine-scanning mutagenesis, to map the residues from TM1 and TM2 contributing to the CD9 dimerization interface.</Species>
<Species>For subsequent cross-linking experiments using CD9 TM(1+2)-GFP protein, the non-dimerizing form of GFP was used.</Species>
<Species>This avoids potential GFP-dependent dimerization and aggregation that can be observed with wild-type GFP, especially when fusions with transmembrane proteins are studied [36].</Species>
<Species>Importantly, the Leu221Lys mutation in GFP prevented aggregation of mutant forms of CD9 TM(1+2), which was observed with wild-type GFP fusion (Figure 5).</Species>
<Species>The TM(1+2) fragment of CD9 contains three native cysteines - Cys9, Cys78 and Cys79.</Species>

<Species>Single-cysteine mutants of TM(1+2) were constructed, in which a cysteine was placed at various faces of TM1 or TM2 while all of the wild-type cysteines were simultaneously replaced by serines.</Species>
<Species>The mutant proteins were transiently expressed in RD cells (having little endogenous CD9), which were then treated for 16-18 hours with 2-BP.</Species>
<Species>To achieve maximal specificity in cross-linking we used a "zero-length" agent, CuP.</Species>
<Species>First, single-cysteine replacements were constructed for residues Leu14, Phe15, Gly16, Phe17 and Asn18, covering just over one complete helical turn at the beginning of TM1.</Species>

<Species>While residue Asn18 is highly conserved, positions 14, 15 and 17 are occupied by bulky hydrophobic residues in most tetraspanins, whereas position 16 shows less conservation (Figures 1, 4).</Species>
<Species>All of the single-cysteine mutants showed diffused pattern of protein localization, without any signs of aggregation.</Species>

<Species>As shown in Figure 7A, the highest level of intermolecular cross-linking was observed for Leu14Cys and Phe17Cys mutants, a lower level for Phe15Cys and Gly16Cys mutants, and very little cross-linking for Asn18Cys substitution.</Species>

<Species>These results indicate that: a) the first two transmembrane domains of CD9 alone can mediate its dimerization, and b) the g and c residues of TM1 (e.g. Leu14 and Phe17, Figure 3) are likely to be part of the intermolecular interface.</Species>

<Species>Similarly, single-cysteine substitutions were made for residues Gly77, Gly80 and Ala81 in TM2; in addition, proteins carrying a single wild-type cysteine, Cys9, Cys78 or Cys79, were tested.</Species>
<Species>No protein aggregation was observed for any of these single-cysteine mutants.</Species>

<Species>As shown in Figure 7B, the relatively low level of intermolecular cross-linking of wild-type CD9 TM(1+2)-GFP protein was enhanced dramatically in single-cysteine TM2 mutants Gly80Cys</Species>
<Species>and Ala81Cys.</Species>
<Species>The Gly77Cys mutant also had an elevated level of cross-linking.</Species>
<Species>In contrast, any of the three native cysteines (9, 78 and 79) produced level of cross-linking not much greater than the wild-type TM(1+2) protein.</Species>
<Species>Similar results were obtained with cysteine-reactive cross-linker BMB (data not shown).</Species>
<Species>Likewise, comparable results were obtained with single-cysteine mutants of untagged, full-length CD9, using CuP (Figure 7C) as well as DTME cross-linker (data not shown).</Species>
<Species>These cross-linking results for TM1 and TM2 are consistent with our model that places residues Leu14, Phe17 and Gly80 on the same side of the TM1-TM2 pair (Figure 6, panel C).</Species>

<Species>The strong cross-linking with Leu14Cys, Phe17Cys and Gly80Cys places the intermolecular interface toward the c and g phases of the TM1 helix, and the g phase of the TM2 helix, away from its e and f faces containing wild-type cysteines 78 and 79.</Species>
<Species>Critical residues at the TM1-TM2 interface also affect dimerization indirectly.</Species>
<Species>To assess specific CD9 dimerization, we used a Gly80Cys substitution at the intermolecular interface for cross-linking.</Species>

<Species>As shown in Figure 8A, single replacements of conserved heptad residues in positions 18, 25, 32, 67 and 74 (Asn18Ser, Gly25/32/67/74>Leu) strongly decreased the cross-linking mediated by Cys80.</Species>
<Species>The effect was most pronounced for mutations of residues, Gly32 and Gly67, located in the tightly packed extracellular end of TM helices (Figure 6).</Species>
<Species>In contrast, mutations of residues closer to the cytoplasmic end of TM2 (Gly74 and especially Ala81) had only modest to very little effect on cross-linking.</Species>

<Species>Relatively low efficiency of intermolecular cross-linking via native residues Cys9, 78, and 79 (Figures 7B,C) correlates well with the predicted location of Cys78 and 79 away from the dimeric interface (Figure 3), and suggests that the extramembrane N-terminal part of CD9 (residues 1-13) does not self-associate.</Species>
<Species>We next examined whether mutations of conserved Asn and Gly residues in TM1 and TM2 decreased low-level background cross-linking via native cysteines.</Species>
<Species>As expected, these mutations had virtually no effect on dimer formation of CD9 TM(1+2)-GFP (Figure 8B).</Species>
<Species>The level of covalent dimer formed was not diminished for triple Asn18Ser + Gly25Leu +</Species>
<Species>Gly32Leu and double Gly67Leu +</Species>
<Species>Gly74Leu mutants, compared to wild-type TM(1+2) CD9 molecule.</Species>
<Species>Similarly, the same triple and double mutations in the context of full-length CD9-GFP protein (with six cysteines) produced wild-type levels of cross-linking (Figure 8C).</Species>

<Species>We interpret these findings as evidence for at least two types of associations between CD9 molecules: primary, involving residues 14, 17 and 80, and dependent on integrity of conserved heptad residues in TM1 and TM2, and less efficient secondary interactions, probably representing random collision events, and independent of the heptad residues (see Discussion for more details).</Species>

<Species>TM3 and TM4 cysteine residues in CD9 dimerization After identifying the roles of conserved TM1 and TM2 residues in CD9 dimerization, we next probed whether residues proximal to TM domains 3 and 4 are also involved.</Species>

<Species>To this end, disulfide cross-linking of full-length CD9 molecules containing 3 C-terminal cysteines (87, just before TM3; 218 and 219 in TM4) or 3 N-terminal cysteines (9, 78 and 79) was compared (Figure 9).</Species>
<Species>We found that the C-terminal cysteines were only slightly better than N-terminal cysteines with respect to detection of CD9 dimers.</Species>
<Species>However, markedly more trimers and tetramers were detected using C-terminal cysteines.</Species>
<Species>Thus, residues 87, 218 and 219 at TM3 and TM4 in CD9 can together form contacts across the dimeric interface and also additional contacts with other neighboring CD9 molecules.</Species>
<Species>Discussion Here we provide the first detailed analysis of tetraspanin protein transmembrane domains.</Species>

<Species>First, we show 1) the presence of a heptad repeat motif in TM1 and TM2, containing highly conserved Asn and Gly residues, 2) a leucine and glutamate/glutamine-containing heptad motif in TM3, and 3) high variability and absence of heptad repeats in TM4 sequences.</Species>

<Species>Second, we provide evidence for a specific, intramolecular interaction between TM1 and TM2 domains, in which bulky hydrophobic residues pack against GG7 motif, and present a molecular model for this interaction.</Species>
<Species>Third, experimental mapping of the CD9 dimerization interface firmly establishes an additional role for conserved TM1 and TM2 residues in dimeric intermolecular interactions.</Species>
<Species>Fourth, preliminary evidence is provided to suggest that TM3 and TM4 domains contribute to expansion of CD9 dimers into higher order multimers.</Species>

<Species>Conserved residues in TM1 and TM2 of tetraspanins: role in intramolecular packing We hypothesized that the first two transmembrane domains of tetraspanins might interact with each other because: a) consecutive TM domains frequently associate in known protein 3D structures [35], and b) they both contain a series of highly conserved amino acids - several Gly residues and an Asn residue (Figure 1).</Species>
<Species>Conserved Gly residues are a frequent theme in the organization of interacting transmembrane domains.</Species>

<Species>Analysis of 3D helix packing in polytopic membrane proteins reveals that Gly residues tend to localize in buried positions, especially at the helix-helix interfaces and helix crossing points</Species>
<Species>[37,38].</Species>
<Species>Due to the absence of a side chain, Gly provides a flat surface for packing of a side chain from another residue, without loss of side-chain entropy upon interaction.</Species>
<Species>The most common Gly-containing motif is GxxxG [39,40].</Species>

<Species>In glycophorin A (GpA), the major glycoprotein in erythrocyte cell membranes, Gly79 and Gly83 are part of the LIxxGVxxGVxxT sequence that promotes homodimerization of parallel transmembrane a-helixes [41,42].</Species>
<Species>In the GpA dimerization motif, Gly residues allow for tight packing in the right-handed helical crossing [43].</Species>
<Species>There are also examples of left-handed helical crossing in the context of a GxxxG motif [44].</Species>
<Species>Other membrane proteins that use the GxxxG motif for homo- or heterodimerization include bacteriophage M13 coat proteins [45], yeast alpha factor receptor</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>[46], integrin a IIb subunit [47], and ErbB1 receptor tyrosine kinase</Species>
<Species>[48].</Species>
<Species>Other small residues, such as Ala and Ser, can substitute for Gly in this motif [49].</Species>

<Species>A protein motif in which Gly residues are separated by 6 other residues (GG7) is also common in transmembrane helices, especially in transporter/channel-like membrane proteins [50].</Species>
<Species>However, the structural features associated with this motif are not well known.</Species>
<Species>In particular, it is unclear whether left-handed GG7 heptad repeat motif (as opposed to the "classic" right-handed GxxxG motif) can drive membrane helix association.</Species>
<Species>In a recent work addressing this issue, Lear et al.</Species>
<Species>[51] showed that a synthetic peptide containing Gly at heptad positions a and d could self-associate in vitro, likely in an antiparallel orientation.</Species>
<Species>Heptad repeats containing conserved Gly residues occur in TM domains of a and b chains of MHC class II proteins, and mutations of the Gly residues disrupt the ab heterodimer</Species>
<Species>[52].</Species>
<Species>These examples demonstrate that Gly-based heptad motifs may be used for both intra- and intermolecular associations.</Species>
<Species>In this work, we identified a highly conserved GG7 motif in the first two tetraspanin TM domains.</Species>
<Species>The GG7 sequence in tetraspanins is a part of a larger motif that also includes a conserved Asn residue in TM1 (NGG7) and an Ala/Ser/Thr residue in TM2 (GGA7).</Species>

<Species>The seven-residue periodicity of these motifs strongly suggests their involvement in left-handed coiled coil packing reminiscent of the leucine zipper, rather than right-handed packing of the GpA-like GxxxG motif.</Species>
<Species>For antiparallel helices, the left-handed crossing is in fact predominant over the right-handed in known TM domain structures [44].</Species>

<Species>In our model, heptad Gly residues in NGG7 and GGA7 sequences provide specific packing between antiparallel tetraspanin TM1 and TM2 helices by allowing tight van der Waals interactions with large hydrophobic residues (Figure 6).</Species>
<Species>Highly efficient packing of bulky side chains against glycine residues is observed in known transmembrane protein 3D structures [38,53,54].</Species>

<Species>An example includes packing of helices M1 and M2 in potassium channel KcsA, where Val91 in M2 is paired with Gly43 in M1, and Leu36 in M1 contacts Ala98 and Gly99 in helix M2 [54,55].</Species>
<Species>In addition to facilitating helix-helix packing, Gly residues frequently provide additional CaH...</Species>
<Species>O hydrogen bonds between two helices [44].</Species>
<Species>In our model, two Ca-backbone carbonyl H-bonds are predicted - between residues Gly27-Gly67, and Trp22-Met70.</Species>
<Species>Although polar and charged amino acid residues (such as Asn in the TM1 heptad motif) are infrequent in transmembrane domains, they are functionally important.</Species>
<Species>Polar residues such as glutamine, glutamic acid, aspartic acid and asparagine can promote strong oligomerization of model membrane-associated helices</Species>
<Species>[56-58].</Species>
<Species>Ruan et al.</Species>

<Species>[59] used asparagine scanning mutagenesis to probe the interface of self-associating polyleucine helices by detecting their enhanced self-interaction in vitro and in the E. coli-based ToxR assay.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Thus, a hydrogen bond in an apolar environment can result in strong, though not necessarily specific, association of transmembrane helices.</Species>
<Species>In fact, mutations to polar residues in transmembrane proteins are commonly associated with disease [60].</Species>
<Species>Because of this potential for non-specific interactions, polar residues tend to localize at buried positions in TM domains.</Species>

<Species>In our case, the conserved Asn18 residue in CD9 is predicted to be a part of the TM1-TM2 interface, though our model does not predict any electrostatic interaction between Asn18 and TM2 (Figure 6).</Species>
<Species>Consistently, substitution such as Asn18Tyr (and Gly77Leu) in TM(1+2)-GFP protein was not destabilizing as analyzed by protein aggregation.</Species>

<Species>Curiously, the full-length Asn18Ser CD9 migrated slightly slower on SDS-PAGE gel (data not shown), suggesting that Asn18 does play a role in maintaining conformation of the molecule.</Species>
<Species>The Asn18Cys single-cysteine mutant shows very little intermolecular cross-linking (Figure 7A), supporting the proposed location of this residue at the intramolecular interface.</Species>

<Species>It is tempting to speculate that the "pocket" between TM1 and TM2 lined by Asn18 and Gly77 might be important for accommodating palmitate moieties that target Cys78 and Cys79 residues, and/or important for access by the putative palmitoyl transferase to those residues.</Species>
<Species>Understanding the exact role of these highly conserved Asn18 and Gly77 residues in tetraspanins awaits further investigation.</Species>
<Species>In summary, we identified conserved glycine residues of TM1 and TM2 of tetraspanins as key elements required for intramolecular packing.</Species>
<Species>Mutations of these key residues (Gly25, Gly32, Gly67 and Gly74 in CD9) resulted in protein destabilization and aggregation.</Species>
<Species>There is ample evidence in the literature for mutations in transmembrane proteins that lead to protein destabilization, misassembly and pathologic conditions [61].</Species>
<Species>Thus, we have identified conserved heptad Gly residues in TM1 and TM2 of tetraspanins as plausible targets of destabilizing mutations with potential functional consequences.</Species>
<Species>Intermolecular interactions in tetraspanins Tetraspanin CD9 forms mostly homodimers, but also a low level of heterodimers with CD81 and CD151 [25].</Species>
