<Species>Thus, mapping the dimerization interface is an important next step in structure-function analysis of tetraspanins.</Species>

<Species>Disulfide-mediated cross-linking, often in combination with cysteine-scanning mutagenesis, is a common strategy to probe oligomerization or intersubunit interactions of transmembrane proteins such as histidine kinase EnvZ</Species>
<Species>[62], M(3) muscarinic acetylcholine receptor [63], E. coli lactose permease [64], synaptobrevin [65], integrins [66] and many others.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In tetraspanins such as CD9, membrane-proximal cysteine residues are especially useful targets for disulfide trapping, as their linkage can be enhanced by pre-treating cells with 2-BP.</Species>

<Species>While the ability of wild-type cysteines in CD9 to be cross-linked may indicate that they are close to the dimerization interface, more precise mapping was achieved here using cysteine-scanning mutagenesis.</Species>
<Species>Our data clearly identify regions, near the cytoplasmic face of TM1 and TM2, important for dimerization.</Species>

<Species>Intermolecular zero-length cross-linking was highest when single cysteines were placed in positions 14, 17, 77, 80 and 81 in TM(1+2)-GFP molecule, or at positions 77, 80 or 81 in the full-length CD9 protein.</Species>
<Species>Positions 14, 17 and 80 are distinct from the intramolecular interface and are on the same side of the TM1-TM2 pair (Figure 6).</Species>
<Species>Thus, they are well-positioned to participate in an interaction with another molecule.</Species>
<Species>At the same time, the model predicts that wild-type cysteines (Cys78, 79), which do not yield very efficient zero-length cross-linking, are on the other side of TM1-TM2 pair.</Species>

<Species>While using the cysteine at position 80 as the dimeric interface probe, mutations of conserved residues in TM1 and TM2 (especially Gly32 and Gly67 to Leu) clearly reduced intermolecular cross-linking.</Species>
<Species>We do not suggest that those residues are directly involved in intermolecular interaction.</Species>

<Species>Rather, we propose that destabilization of the intramolecular TM1-TM2 interaction by Gly to Leu substitutions (discussed above) causes an overall conformational change that reduces dimer formation.</Species>
<Species>An Ala81Leu mutation did not reduce cross-linking via Cys80, even though single-cysteine Ala81Cys molecules themselves produced a high level of cross-linking.</Species>

<Species>These results, together with data on Gly32Leu and Gly67Leu mutations, are consistent with our model predicting that helices 1 and 2 interact more tightly near the extracellular end and less at the cytoplasmic end.</Species>
<Species>This would give more flexibility to a cysteine at position 81 and also limit the effect of an Ala81Leu mutation.</Species>

<Species>Location of this residue at the membrane/cytoplasmic border could also make it more accessible to CuP reagent as compared to residues buried in TM domain, thus elevating the efficiency of disulfide formation of the Ala81Cys mutant.</Species>

<Species>Multiple interfaces in tetraspanin molecules In the full-length CD9 molecules, the 3 C-terminal cysteines (Cys87, 218 and 219) located at or in TM3 and TM4 promoted efficient dimer and even more efficient oligomer formation compared to the 3 N-terminal cysteines (Figure 9).</Species>
<Species>Cys87 alone can be used to capture CD9 dimers [25].</Species>
<Species>These results suggest the existence of two dimeric interfaces in CD9 molecule - the TM 1-2/1-2 interface and the TM 3-4/3-4 interface (Figure 10).</Species>
<Species>In a TM(1+2) molecule, the destabilization of 1-2 interaction, e.g. by Gly>Leu mutations, would affect the 1-2/1-2 interface, as discussed above.</Species>
<Species>However, these mutations would not interfere with the 3-4/3-4 interface in a full-length molecule, which includes Cys87, 218 and 219.</Species>
<Species>Thus, cross-linking of full-length molecules, containing all 6 cysteine residues, would be unaffected, as seen in Figure 8C.</Species>
<Species>Furthermore, wild-type Cys9, Cys78 and Cys79 are apparently not at the primary 1-2/1-2 interface.</Species>
<Species>Their relative inefficiency in cross-linking CD9 TM(1+2) protein likely reflects weak secondary contacts between the molecules, or possibly random collision events.</Species>
<Species>Such events should be independent of mutations in the conserved Gly residues in TM1 and TM2, as was demonstrated in Figure 8B.</Species>
<Species>The potential existence of two interfaces in tetraspanin molecules, 1-2/1-2 and 3-4/3-4, should provide enhanced flexibility for forming additional intermolecular contacts.</Species>

<Species>Current understanding of tetraspanin microdomains assumes a few strong, primary homotypic and heterotypic tetraspanin complexes (e.g. CD9-CD9, CD9-CD81, CD151-a3 integrin, CD81-EWI2) that help bring together various other proteins, forming secondary-type associations.</Species>
<Species>Such properties of tetraspanins may bring signaling molecules such as protein kinase C or phosphatidylinositol 4-kinase to the vicinity of integrins [67,68].</Species>
<Species>The organization of the TM3 domain points to a potential role in protein-protein interactions.</Species>
<Species>A motif of Leu-Leu-Glu(Gln) spaced 7 residues apart (heptad positions a), with highly conserved residues in two consecutive positions d, poses as a likely interaction module.</Species>
<Species>If responsible for heterologous protein-protein interactions, it would form another distinct interface of tetraspanin molecule.</Species>

<Species>Our preliminary data indicate that replacing the Leu and Glu residues in TM3 of CD9 with Ala has no effect on cell surface expression of the protein and its dimerization (data not shown).</Species>
<Species>It remains to be tested if interactions with other proteins will be affected.</Species>
<Species>Similarly, the TM4 domain may provide additional contributions to lateral tetraspanin associations.</Species>
<Species>Much higher sequence variability, and the lack of a distinct heptad pattern suggests that TM4 is a major contributor to diversity among tetraspanin complexes.</Species>
<Species>Structure-function analysis of TM3 and TM4 domains in tetraspanins is the subject of ongoing investigation.</Species>

<Species>Conclusion We have defined the TM1-TM2 intramolecular interface in tetraspanin CD9, providing evidence for glycines (Gly25 and Gly32 in TM1, Gly67 and Gly74 in TM2) packing against apposing bulky aliphatic residues.</Species>
<Species>Second, we mapped an intermolecular CD9 interface (involved in CD9 homodimer formation) to the vicinity of residues Leu14 and Phe17 in TM1 and Gly77, Gly80 and Ala81 in TM2.</Species>
<Species>Finally, we provide preliminary evidence that TM3 and TM4 in CD9 may contribute to a second intermolecular interface.</Species>

<Species>Key CD9 residues involved in intra- and intermolecular interactions are highly conserved throughout the tetraspanin family, thus suggesting that our findings will apply to most tetraspanins.</Species>
<Species>Methods Materials Cell culture reagents were from Invitrogen (Carlsbad, CA).</Species>

<Species>2-bromopalmitate was from Fluka (Milwaukee, WI), N-ethylmaleimide (NEM) and 1,10-phenanthroline were from Sigma-Aldrich (St. Louis, MO), and chemical cross-linkers dithio-bis-maleimidoethane (DTME) and 1,4-Bis-maleimidobutane (BMB) were purchased from Pierce Endogen (Rockford, IL).</Species>
<Species>Triton X-100, protease inhibitor cocktail and FuGENE 6 transfection reagent were obtained from Roche (Indianapolis, IN).</Species>
<Species>Restriction endonucleases and Pfu DNA polymerase were obtained New England Biolabs (Beverly, MA) and Stratagene (Carlsbad, CA), respectively.</Species>
<Species>All other chemicals were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich or Fisher Scientific (Pittsburg, PA).</Species>
<Species>Sequence analysis Tetraspanin sequences were obtained from SWISS-PROT and GenBank databases.</Species>
<Species>Locus designations, accession numbers and the most commonly used protein names are summarized in Tables 1 and 2.</Species>

<Species>TM segments were delineated by inspection of hydrophobicity profiles, using database annotations and previous analyses of TM sequences as a guide ([28], M. Hemler, unpublished), and aligned manually.</Species>
<Species>Residue numbers in human CD9 sequence are used a reference point throughout the study.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>DNA cloning and mutagenesis Sequence encoding CD9 protein was cloned into vector pcDNA3 (Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA) and pEGFP-N1 (Clontech, Palo Alto, CA), for expression of untagged and C-terminally GFP-tagged CD9, respectively.</Species>
<Species>pEGFP-N1 encoding CD9 TM(1+2)</Species>

<Species>-GFP fusion protein was constructed by subcloning DNA for residues 1-83 of CD9 into HindIII and PstI sites of the vector; to introduce the PstI site, codon GTG for Val82 was changed to CTG (coding for Ala).</Species>
<Species>In the resulting fusion protein, there is a 13-amino acid linker (with no cysteines) between CD9 and GFP.</Species>
<Species>To minimize the low inherent ability of GFP to homodimerize, which could potentially influence the results of CD9 cross-linking, we used a monomeric GFP mutant, Leu221></Species>
<Species>Lys</Species>
<Species>[34], for cross-linking experiments.</Species>
<Species>Mutations were introduced in full-length and TM(1+2) CD9 proteins by a PCR-based strategy using mutagenic primers and Pfu DNA polymerase.</Species>
<Species>All mutations were confirmed by DNA sequencing.</Species>

<Species>Protein expression, microscopy, cysteine disulfide cross-linking and Western blotting DNA constructs encoding TM(1+2)-GFP or full-length CD9 proteins were transfected into human rhabdomyosarcoma RD cells using the FuGENE 6 reagent.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Cells expressing GFP fusion proteins were analysed by fluorescence microscopy 18-28 hours post-transfection.</Species>
<Species>Images were captured using Spot 1.4.0 camera (Diagnostic Instruments, Sterling Heights, MI) attached to Nikon Eclipse TE300 microscope.</Species>
<Species>For experiments involving cysteine-mediated cross-linking, cells were treated with 50 uM 2-BP starting 24-26 hours post-transfection and continuing for 16-18 hours.</Species>

<Species>Cross-linking was carried out by incubating cells in HBSM buffer (25 mM Hepes-NaOH, pH 7.2, 150 mM NaCl, 2 mM MgCl2) containing either a) 0.6 mM CuSO4 and 1.8 mM 1,10-phenanthroline (CuP complex) or b) 0.2 mg/ml homobifunctional cysteine-reactive cross-linker (e.g. DTME), diluted from fresh 10 mg/ml solution in DMSO.</Species>

<Species>After incubation for 10-15 minutes (with CuP) or 30-45 minutes (with cross-linker), cells were washed twice for 10 minutes with HBSM containing 10 mM NEM to block residual free cysteines.</Species>
<Species>Cells were lysed in HBSM containing 1% Triton X-100, 0.1% SDS and a cocktail of protease inhibitors with 1 mM EDTA at 4oC for 45-60 minutes.</Species>

<Species>Cell lysate was clarified by centrifugation at 14,000 x g for 15 minutes, an aliquot was removed, and proteins from it were precipitated by addition of trichloroacetic acid to 10% on ice followed by centrifugation at 14,000 x g for 10 minutes.</Species>
<Species>After two washes with ice-cold acetone, protein pellet was solubilized in SDS-PAGE sample buffer without a reducing agent (50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 6.8, 1% SDS, 8% glycerol).</Species>
<Species>In some experiments, CD9 protein was immunoprecipitated using monoclonal antibody Alb6 (Immunotech, Marseille, France).</Species>
<Species>Proteins were separated by SDS-PAGE and analyzed by Western blotting using monoclonal antibody JL-8 (Clontech) for GFP or Alb6 for CD9.</Species>
<Species>Bands from X-ray films were quantitated using GeneTools  software from Syngene (Frederick, MD).</Species>
<Species>Modeling of TM1-TM2 interaction An atomic model of the CD9 TM1-TM2 dimer was constructed with a Monte Carlo-simulated annealing (MCSA) algorithm [69].</Species>

<Species>Two idealized a-helices corresponding to TM1 residues Tyr12 through Leu35 and TM2 residues Gly59 through Val82 were docked with six orthogonal parameters: three rigid body translations and three rotations.</Species>
<Species>During each step of a MCSA cycle, there was an equal probability of changing either one parameter or all six parameters to random values.</Species>
<Species>A conformation's energy was calculated in vacuo with the AMBER united-atom force field for van der Waals interactions [70].</Species>
<Species>The van der Waals term was modified as described by Kuhlman and Baker [71].</Species>
<Species>If a structure had favorable dimerization energy, the energies of select mutants were calculated.</Species>

<Species>Structures were selected with a novel scoring function that maximizes the Boltzmann probability of dimerization for silent mutations while minimizing the probability for disruptive mutations.</Species>
<Species>Asn18Ser, Gly77Leu, and Gly80Leu were scored as silent mutations while Gly25Leu, Gly32Leu, Gly67Leu, and Gly74Leu were considered to be disruptive.</Species>

<Species>Each MCSA cycle consisted of 50,000 steps with an exponential temperature decay from 10,000 to 10 K. Ten MCSA cycles through global sample space were used to restrict the search area.</Species>
<Species>Parameters were restricted to + 2 standard deviations from their mean value for structures within 10 kcal of the best structure.</Species>

<Species>MCSA cycles were repeated as described above with additional optimization of X values: rotamers at the protein-protein interface were optimized with Dead End Elimination [72], and X values were further optimized with Monte Carlo.</Species>

<Species>All MCSA cycles converged upon structures that were within a root mean squared deviation (RMSD) of 1.5 A with the best structure, and structures that scored within 5 kcal of the best score had an RMSD of less than 0.5 A with the best structure.</Species>

<Species>List of abbreviations 2-BP, 2-bromopalmitate; CuP, Cu2+-phenanthroline; DTME, dithio-bis-maleimidoethane; LEL, large extracellular loop; NEM, N-ethylmaleimide; TM, transmembrane (domain).</Species>
<Species>Authors' contributions OVK carried out sequence comparisons, mutational analysis and cross-linking experiments, and drafted the manuscript.</Species>
<Species>DGM built the TM1-TM2 interaction model and contributed to the manuscript.</Species>
<Species>WFD supervised DGM's work.</Species>
<Species>MEH coordinated the whole study and prepared the final manuscript.</Species>
<Species>Organization and structure of the mouse interleukin-2 gene.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Abstract We have cloned a chromosomal DNA segment which covers the entire sequence for the murine interleukin-2 gene and analysed the structure of the gene.</Species>
<Species>The coding regions are separated into four blocks by three introns each of which is located similarly to the corresponding human gene.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The exon sequences can be aligned perfectly with the previously cloned cDNA sequence.</Species>
<Species>Of particular interests is the presence of sequences within the 5'-flanking region which are highly conserved between mouse and man.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The conserved region which spans more than 400 base pairs may play a role in the regulation of IL-2 gene expression.</Species>

<Species>Images Volume 12 Number 24 1984 Nucleic Acids Research Organization and structure of the mouse interleukin-2 gene Akira Fuse*, Takashi Fujita, Hidetaro Yasumitsu, Nobukazu Kashima+, Katsushige Hasegawa and Tadatsugu Taniguchi?</Species>

text: <Species>Department of Biochemistry, Cancer Institute, Japanese Foundation for Cancer Research, Toshimaku, Tokyo 170 and Institute for Molecular and Cellular Biology, Osaka University, Suita-shi, Osaka 565, Japan Received 10 October 1984;</Species>
<Species>Revised and Accepted 20 November 1984</Species>
<Species>ABSTRACT We have cloned a chromosomal DNA segment which covers the entire sequence for the murine interleukin-2 gene and analysed the structure of the gene.</Species>
<Species>The coding regions are separated into four blocks by three introns each of which is located similarly to the corresponding human gene.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The exon sequences can be aligned perfectly with the previously cloned cDNA sequence.</Species>
<Species>Of particular interests is the presence of sequences within the 5'flanking region which are highly conserved between mouse and man.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The conserved region which spans more than 400 base pairs may play a role in the regulation of IL-2 gene expression.</Species>
<Species>INTRODUCTION Interleukin-2 (IL-2) is a lymphokine produced by T cells upon antigenic or mitogenic stimulation and is required for the proliferation of T cells (1,2).</Species>
<Species>Several other biological activities of IL-2 which appear to be crucial in the immune regulation have also been reported (3, 4. 5. 6. 7.) .</Species>
<Species>We previously reported isolation and sequence analysis of the cDNA for human IL-2 (8), as well as the chromosomal gene (9).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>More recently, we have isolated a cDNA which encodes murine IL-2 (Kashima et al., submitted for publication).</Species>
<Species>The cDNA contains a unique tandem repeat of CAG sequence which would encode 12 consecutive glutamine residues in the active IL-2 molecule.</Species>

<Species>In order to study the structure of the murine IL-2 chromosomal gene and its controlling region, we isolated and analysed a A phage clone containing the gene and its flanking sequences.</Species>
<Species>MATERIALS AND METHODS Southern blotting of total mouse DNA Mouse chromosomal DNA was extracted from liver of BALB/c6 ?</Species>
label: Species
Species

<Species>Nucleic Acids Research Volume 12 Number 24 1984 9323 Nucleic Acids Research mouse as described before (10).</Species>

text: <Species>High molecular genomic DNA was digested with various restriction enzymes and electrophoresed on 0.8% agarose gel.</Species>
<Species>Blotting analysis of DNA was carried out by the method of Southern (11).</Species>

<Species>Hybridization was carried out as described previously and filters were washed either in 3 x SSC at 650C (lower stringent condition) or in 0.1 x SSC at 650C (higher stringent condition).</Species>

<Species>Screening of genomic DNA library A bacteriophage XCharon 4A/mouse genomic DNA library prepared with partial EcoRI digests of mouse DNA from MPC 11 plasmacytoma cells was kindly provided by Dr. T. Honjo.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Mouse IL-2-specific clones were screened by the method of Benton and Davis (12), using 700 bp PstI-AccI fragment of a cDNA clone, pMIL2-45 as the probe (Kashima et al., submitted for publication).</Species>
<Species>Hybridization was performed as described previously(13).</Species>
<Species>Positive clones were rescreened at least twice.</Species>
<Species>Subcloninq and sequencing of the mouse IL-2 gene Two EcoRI fragments of 3.3 Kbp and 2.8 Kbp from the positive recombinant X phage were subcloned into EcoRI site of plasmid pBR322.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>DNA segments derived from subcloned 3.3 Kbp and 2.8 Kbp fragments were labelled at either 3' end or 5' end, and subjected to sequence analysis by the chemical degradation method (14).</Species>
<Species>The 0.8 Kbp EcoRI fragment from the same X phage clone was directly subjected to sequence analysis by the dideoxy chain termination method (15).</Species>

<Species>RESULTS Total DNA blotting analysis In order to study structural organization of the mouse IL-2 gene, we first subjected total mouse DNA to the blotting analysis by using various probes specific for IL-2 gene.</Species>

<Species>Those results suggest the presence of highly conserved sequences between human and mouse DNA either in the flanking regions or in the introns of the IL-2 gene, since the coding regions apparently show lower degree of sequence homology as evidenced in this series of blotting analysis (see below).</Species>

text: <Species>When the PstI insert of a mouse IL-2 cDNA clone, pMIL2-20, was used as the probe, a simple pattern was 9325 Nucleic Acids Research obtained at higher stringent condition (lane 13-17).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>While the EcoRI-digested DNA gave rise to two positive bands (2.8 kb and 0.8 kb)(Fig. 1, lane 14) by this analysis, one additional band of 3.3 kb also appeared when the same DNA was probed with a longer cDNA insert from another clone, pMIL2-45 (Fig. 1, lane 17).</Species>
<Species>The 3.3 kb band was similar in its size with the positive band which became detectable by probing the same DNA with the 7.0 kb human DNA probe (Fig. 1, lane 2).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Since this band appeared with the cDNA probe extending further upstream, it is likely that the 5' region of the gene is located within this DNA segment (see below).</Species>
<Species>Indeed, this 3.3 kb band did not appear even after longer exposure of lane 14 (result not shown).</Species>
<Species>BamHI digest of the mouse DNA (Fig. 1, lane 1, 13) constantly gave a very faint signal which would correspond to a DNA larger than 15 kb.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Taken together, the results suggested the presence of a single copy gene for murine IL-2.</Species>

<Species>On the other hand appearance of the multiple positive bands at lower stringent washing condition (lane 9-12) indicates the presence of IL-2 related sequences within the mouse genome.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Screening of recombinant phaqe libraries We next screened a gene library from partial EcoRIdigested DNA from MPC 11 cells and by using 0.8 Kbp SacI-AccI cDNA fragment as the probe and isolated 14 positive clones containing sequences specific to the mouse IL-2 gene.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Three of the clones analysed all contained three EcoRI fragments whose size is in agreement with the result of blotting analysis of the chromosomal DNA as shown in Fig.</Species>
<Species>1 (lane 17).</Species>
<Species>One of these is designated MIL-2G70.</Species>
<Species>Nucleotide sequence analysis Two DNA fragments of 3.3 Kbp and 2.8 Kbp were excised from the phage clone MIL-2G70 by EcoRI digestion and they were subcloned into pBR322.</Species>
<Species>DNA sequences were determined for selected regions of both inserts and compared to the known cDNA sequences (Kashima et al., submitted for publication).</Species>
<Species>The strategy used for sequence analysis of the genomic DNA is presented in Fig. 2.</Species>
<Species>Comparison of the mouse genomic IL-2 sequence with mouse IL-2 cDNA sequence revealed that, like the human gene, the gene is divided into four exons.</Species>

<Species>capping site or the transcription initiation site was located 32 bp downstream from a TATAAA consensus promotor sequence (Fig. 3).</Species>
<Species>The first ATG triplet was located 79 bp downstream from the TATA box.</Species>
<Species>As seen also in the murine IL-2 cDNA, there is an unusual repeat of CAG triplet coding for 12 glutamine residues in a row in the first exon.</Species>
<Species>The second exon (60 bp) is separated from the first exon by a short intron consisting of 97 bp.</Species>
<Species>The second, the third and the fourth exons are interrupted by longer introns whose size is about 2.3 Kbp and 1.6 Kbp, respectively.</Species>

<Species>As far as the available sequence data are concerned, it seems that, despite their identical location, intron sequences are distinctly dissimilar except for the junction regions between the human and mouse IL-2 genes.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>There are two potential poly (A) addition signals within the mouse gene (nucleotide positions 793 - 798 and 924 - 929 in Fig. 3 ) and, based on our sequence data for various cDNA clones, both signals seem to function and give rise to heterogeneous termini of the mRNA in the LBRM-33 cells (16).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We have also determined the sequence of about 500 bp of 5'-flanking region of mouse IL-2 gene, since (i) promoter/regulatory sequences are located in this region in many other genes of eukaryotes and (ii) this region appeared to contain sequences which show strongest cross-hybridization between human and mouse DNA around the IL-2 gene (Fig. 1).</Species>

text: <Species>In aligning the sequences for both genes, gaps were introduced to maximize homology.</Species>
<Species>Dots indicate identical nucleotide sequences.</Species>
<Species>Number 1 indicates putative transcription initiation site.</Species>

<Species>4.</Species>
<Species>The nucleotide sequence homology from the TATA box to -470 is 85%.</Species>
<Species>The highest region of homology was observed between the TATA box and position -97 (60 bp matches out of 64 bp) of both genes.</Species>

<Species>DISCUSSION We have isolated recombinant clones for mouse IL-2 gene from a phage Charon 4A/mouse genomic DNA library and determined the entire sequence of the gene except for the sequence of the internal portion of the second and third introns.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The mouse IL-2 cDNA sequence was aligned with the genomic sequence and both sequences matched completely each other.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The unusual CAG repeats encoding 12 glutamines which was found previously in the cloned cDNA was shown to be present also in the chromosomal gene.</Species>
<Species>This finding further excludes the possibility that the unique repeat is generated by artifacts during the cDNA cloning process.</Species>

<Species>Although we can not rule out the possibility for the deletion of this sequence in the human IL-2 gene, it is more likely that the CAG repeat has been generated in the mouse genome rather recently.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The repeat could have been generated either by a direct insertion of the sequence or by the duplication after insertion of a unit sequence.</Species>
<Species>9329 Nucleic Acids Research Organization of the mouse IL-2 gene resembles to that of the human gene (Fig. 2., ref.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>9)</Species>
<Species>.</Species>

<Species>There seems to be little sequence homology between corresponding introns of mouse and human IL-2 genes, except for the intron-exon junctions part of which is thought to be necessary for the RNA splicing (17, 18).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Dissimilarity of the intron sequences among the genes which are derived from a common ancestor has been reported in other genes (19, 20).</Species>
<Species>In spite of the divergence in sequence of introns, the size and position of the introns are very similar between the murine and human IL-2 genes.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Of particular interests is the presence of highly conserved sequences in the 5' -flanking region of the human and mouse IL-2 gene (Fig. 4).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Whereas the coding region shows nucleotide sequence homology of 72% between the two genes, the 5' upstream region spanning about 500 bp (Fig. 4) shows 85% homology which was readily detectable by the blotting analysis (Fig. 1, lane 1-4).</Species>
<Species>Since we have not yet determined the nucleotide sequence further upstream of the mouse gene, we do not know whether or not this similarity extends further.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>It is likely that such sequences are involved in the controlled expression of the IL-2 genes in activated T-lymphocytes.</Species>
<Species>Work is in progress to identify such DNA sequences by introducing the cloned genes into various lymphocytic cell lines.</Species>

<Species>Our preliminary results indicate that the 5 '-flanking sequence of the human IL-2 gene mediates mitogen induced expression of the gene in T-lymphocytic cells (Fujita & Taniguchi, unpublished observation).</Species>
label: Species

<Species>Enp1, a yeast protein associated with U3 and U14 snoRNAs, is required for pre-rRNA processing and 40S subunit synthesis</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Abstract ENP1 is an essential Saccharomyces cerevisiae gene encoding a 483 amino acid polypeptide.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Enp1 protein is localized in the nucleus and concentrated in the nucleolus.</Species>
<Species>An enp1-1 temperature-sensitive mutant inhibited 35S pre-rRNA early processing at sites A0, A1 and A2 as shown by northern analysis of steady state levels of rRNA precursors.</Species>

<Species>Pulse-chase analysis further revealed that the enp1-1 strain was defective in the synthesis of 20S pre-rRNA and hence 18S rRNA, which led to reduced formation of 40S ribosomal subunits.</Species>
<Species>Co-precipitation analysis revealed that Enp1 was associated with Nop1 protein, as well as with U3 and U14 RNAs, two snoRNAs implicated in early pre-rRNA processing steps.</Species>
<Species>These results suggest a direct role for Enp1 in the early steps of rRNA processing.</Species>
<Species>INTRODUCTION Ribosome biogenesis is one of the major cellular activities in eukaryotic cells.</Species>
<Species>It takes place primarily in a specialized subnuclear compartment, the nucleolus (1,2).</Species>

<Species>In the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae, each rRNA gene is transcribed by RNA polymerase I into a 35S rRNA precursor, consisting of 18S, 5.8S and 25S rRNA sequences flanked by two external transcribed spacers (ETS) and separated by two internal transcribed spacers (ITS) (Fig. 1).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>This 35S precursor goes through a series of modifications and processing steps to generate the mature 18S, 5.8S and 25S rRNAs.</Species>
<Species>The processing occurs first at sites A0, A1 and A2, resulting in the 20S pre-rRNA and 27SA2 pre-rRNA.</Species>
<Species>The 20S pre-rRNA is then cleaved, leading to the mature 18S rRNA found in the 40S ribosomal subunit.</Species>
<Species>The 27SA2 pre-rRNA is processed through two alternative pathways.</Species>
<Species>The majority of 27SA2 pre-rRNA is cleaved at sites A3 and B2 to form the 27SA3 pre-rRNA, which is subsequently processed to produce 27SBS.</Species>
<Species>Alternatively, 27SA2 pre-rRNA can be processed at sites B1L and B2 to generate 27SBL pre-rRNA.</Species>

<Species>Both 27SBS and 27SBL pre-rRNAs are then cleaved at sites C1 and C2 to generate the mature 25S rRNA, and 7SS or 7SL intermediates, which are then processed to mature 5.8SS or 5.8SL rRNAs (Fig. 1).</Species>
<Species>The 25S rRNA and 5.8S rRNA are the RNA components of the 60S ribosomal subunit (3).</Species>
<Species>During the course of rRNA modification and processing, many of the ribosomal proteins are assembled onto the rRNA molecules to form the ribosome complex.</Species>

<Species>Ribosome biogenesis needs a large number of trans-acting factors, including small nucleolar RNAs (snoRNAs), protein components of the snoRNP complexes, rRNA modifying enzymes, endo- and exonucleases, putative RNA helicases and other protein factors (3,4).</Species>
<Species>In yeast cells there are more than 100 different snoRNAs playing important roles in rRNA modification and processing.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>On the basis of their structure, the snoRNAs can be divided into two groups: the box C/D family and box H/ACA family.</Species>
<Species>Only one snoRNA, MRP RNA, belongs to neither family (5-7).</Species>

<Species>While the majority of the snoRNAs participate in RNA pseudouridylation and 2   -O-ribose methylation, a few of them, including MRP snoRNA, box C/D snoRNAs U3 and U14, and box H/ACA snoRNAs snR10 and snR30, are required for processing of the pre-rRNA (8-12).</Species>

<Species>Not only are U3, U14, snR10 and snR30 essential for early cleavages of 35S pre-rRNA to 18S rRNA, the proteins associated with them, including Nop1, Nop5, Gar1 and Nop10, have also been shown to be required for 18S rRNA synthesis (13-16).</Species>
<Species>The ENP1 (Essential Nuclear Protein 1) gene was identified in a genetic screen for suppressors of an ost4 mutation (oligosaccharide transferase 4) (17).</Species>
<Species>However, in subsequent studies it was found not to be involved in OST4 function (18).</Species>
<Species>ENP1 is an essential gene encoding a 483 amino acid polypeptide.</Species>
<Species>The Enp1 protein is highly conserved and homologs are found in all eukaryotes.</Species>
<Species>The yeast protein was localized to the nucleus in a previous study (18).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>On the other hand, an Enp1 human homolog, called bystin, was reported to localize to the cytoplasm and was proposed to be involved in cell adhesion (19).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In this study, we report that the Enp1 protein not only is nuclear but is enriched in the nucleolus.</Species>
<Species>We also found that Enp1 is required for the synthesis of 40S ribosomal subunits, and its presence is necessary for the pre-rRNA processing to form 20S pre-rRNA and 18S rRNA.</Species>
<Species>An association between Enp1 and U3 and U14 snoRNAs, and with the nucleolar protein Nop1, was established.</Species>
<Species>We also found that human Enp1, expressed in yeast, was located in the nucleus and the nucleolus, suggesting that the function of this protein is conserved.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>MATERIALS AND METHODS Yeast strains and media</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The S.cerevisiae strains used in this study are all derivatives of a wild-type diploid strain W303 (MATa/MATa ura3-1/ura3-1 leu2-3,112/leu2-3,112 trp1-1/trp1-1 his3-11,15/his3-11,15 ade2-1/ade2-1 can1-100/can1-100) except for strain RS1938.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Strain JBY45 (MATa/MATa ENP1/Denp1::his5+) was constructed by replacing one copy of the ENP1 open reading frame (ORF) with the Schizosaccharomyces pombe his5+ gene (18).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Strain JBY46</Species>
<Species>[MATa Denp1::his5+/pJB23 (ENP1, URA3, CEN6)] is a haploid strain derived from JBY45 with wild-type ENP1 on a low copy number plasmid.</Species>
<Species>Strain JBY48</Species>
<Species>[MATa Denp1::his5+/pJB19 (enp1-1, TRP1, CEN6)] and strain JBY49</Species>
<Species>[MATa Denp1::his5+/pJB39 (enp1-2, TRP1, CEN6)] have plasmids with enp1 temperature-sensitive (ts) mutations.</Species>
<Species>Strain JBY51 (MATa Denp1::his5+ TRP1::enp1-1) is an enp1 ts strain generated by integrating the enp1-1 gene at the chromosomal trp1-1 locus.</Species>
<Species>Strain CWY13</Species>
<Species>[MATa Denp1::his5+/pJB24 (pMET25-GFP-ENP1, URA3, CEN6)] has GFP-ENP1 under control of the MET25 promoter.</Species>
<Species>Strain CWY14 (MATa ENP1-TAP) was created by fusing sequences encoding a Tandem Affinity Purification (TAP) tag (20,21) to the 3    end of ENP1.</Species>
<Species>Strain YRH39</Species>
<Species>(MATa HST2-TAP) was created by fusing sequences encoding a TAP tag to the 3   end of HST2.</Species>

<Species>Strain RS1938 (Dnop1::URA3 pUN100-ProtA-NOP1) was created by transforming RS1935 (MATa/a leu2/leu2 ura3/ura3 lys2/lys2 ade2/ade2 Dnop1::URA3/NOP1) with pUN100-ProtA-NOP1 (strain and plasmid supplied by T. Schafer), followed by tetrad dissection.</Species>
<Species>Strain CWY15</Species>
<Species>[MATa/pCW109 (pMET25-GFP-hENP1, URA3, CEN6)] has a human homolog of Enp1 expressed in W303-1a.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The media used were prepared as described (22).</Species>
<Species>Cloning of ENP1 pRS426-MEG1 (The original name of ENP1) was a gift from Dr William J. Lennarz.</Species>
<Species>It contains the ENP1 gene within a 2.6 kb EcoRI genomic fragment cloned into pRS426 (18).</Species>
<Species>The EcoRI fragment was subsequently cloned into pRS314 (TRP1, CEN6), pRS316 (URA3, CEN6) and pRS424 (TRP1, 2u) to create pJB20, pJB23 and pJB21, respectively.</Species>
<Species>pGFP-N-FUS is a centromeric plasmid for fusing green fluorescence protein (GFP) to a polypeptide   s N-terminus under control of the MET25 promoter (23).</Species>
<Species>Cloning the ENP1 ORF into pGFP-N-FUS via XbaI and SalI sites generated plasmid pJB24. pJB19 (enp1-1, TRP1, CEN6) contains the enp1-1 mutant gene.</Species>

<Species>The human homolog of yeast Enp1 was PCR amplified from a human cDNA clone BC007340 (Research Genetics), then cloned into pGFP-N-FUS, p415-ADH, p415-GPD and p415-TEF (24) via XbaI and SalI sites to generate pCW109, pCW113, pCW115 and pCW117, respectively.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>The fragment of the human Enp1 homolog (amino acids 152-437) was also cloned into these vectors to generate pCW110, pCW114, pCW116 and pCW118.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Random mutagenesis of ENP1 to generate enp1 ts mutants The enp1 ts mutants were generated with a protocol introducing random mutations by PCR (25).</Species>
<Species>The PCR was performed with oligonucleotides ENP1-MUT5    (5   -GGTGGTGTCAGT AGGGGA-3   ), ENP1-MUT3    (5   -CAGTCTGCAATATA TGGAC-3   ) and plasmid template pJB20 (see above).</Species>
<Species>The nucleotide concentrations in the reaction were 1 mM each for dATP, dGTP, dCTP and dTTP.</Species>

<Species>After strain JBY46 was transformed with the PCR product and with pJB20 gapped by NheI and NsiI, the transformants were replica-plated onto two plates containing 5-FOA synthetic medium without tryptophan; one replica was incubated at 23oC and the other at 37oC. Colonies growing at 23oC but not at 37oC were picked as candidates.</Species>
<Species>Since approximately 10% of the colonies were inviable at both temperatures, we knew that 10% of the ENP1 PCR products lost their function after the PCR mutagenesis.</Species>
<Species>This confirmed the effectiveness of the mutagenesis procedure.</Species>
<Species>Two candidates showed good growth at 23oC but no growth at 37oC. They were named strains JBY48 and JBY49 and contained plasmids with the enp1-1 and enp1-2 mutations, respectively.</Species>
<Species>The mutated enp1-1 gene on pJB19 was cloned into an integration vector, pRS304, as an EcoRI fragment.</Species>
<Species>The plasmid was subsequently linearized with SnaBI within the TRP1 marker and was integrated at the chromosomal trp1-1 locus of strain JBY46.</Species>
<Species>Selection on 5-FOA was used to remove plasmid pJB23, creating strain JBY51.</Species>
<Species>Sucrose gradient analysis Polyribosome preparation and analysis were carried out essentially as described (26).</Species>
<Species>Cells grown in YPD were collected at mid-log phase (OD600 0.8-1.0) and were broken with glass beads.</Species>

<Species>The lysate was frozen immediately in liquid N2 and was stored at -80oC. Lysate (30 U of absorbance at OD260) was layered over a 7-47% (w/v) sucrose gradient, which was centrifuged at 28 000 r.p.m.</Species>
<Species>for 5 h at 4oC in a SW28 rotor and was analyzed with an ISCO UA-5 gradient UV detection system on absorbency at 254 nm.</Species>
<Species>Immunofluorescence Immunofluorescence analysis was carried out essentially as described (27).</Species>

<Species>Cells were fixed with 3.7% formaldehyde at room temperature for 1.5 h. Antibodies included a mouse monoclonal anti-Nop1 (a gift from John P. Aris, University of Florida, Gainesville, Florida) and a Texas-red-conjugated donkey-anti-mouse antibody (Jackson Lab), both used at 1:500 dilution.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Images were taken on a Zeiss Axioplan2 microscope equipped with a Zeiss AxioCam camera.</Species>
<Species>Pulse-chase labeling analysis of rRNA For [methyl-3H]methionine pulse-chase analysis</Species>

<Species>, cells were grown in synthetic medium without methionine at room temperature or 37oC for 2 h. When the OD600 reached 1.0, 6 ml of the culture were pulse-labeled with 250 uCi [methyl-3H]methionine (Amersham Pharmacia) for 3 min and chased with cold methionine (500 ug/ml) for 2, 4 or 12 min.</Species>
<Species>For each time point of the chase 1.25 ml of culture was mixed with ice and collected.</Species>
<Species>The pellets were frozen immediately in liquid N2 and stored at -80oC before total RNA was purified using a hot phenol method (28).</Species>
<Species>The RNAs were separated on a 1.2% agarose formaldehyde gel and transferred onto Hybond-N+ nylon membranes (Amersham Pharmacia).</Species>
<Species>After being sprayed with EN3HANCE (Du Pont), the membranes were exposed to film at -80oC (29).</Species>
<Species>Northern analysis Cells were grown inYPD at room temperature or 37oC for 2-4 h. When the OD600 reached 1.0, 10 ml of cells were collected and frozen immediately.</Species>
<Species>Total RNA was extracted as described (28).</Species>

<Species>Five micrograms of RNA were separated on 1.2% agarose formaldehyde gels (for high molecular weight RNA) or on 6% polyacrylamide 7 M urea denaturing gels (for low molecular weight RNA) for each sample.</Species>
<Species>The RNA was then transferred to Zeta-Probe GT nylon membranes (Bio-Rad).</Species>
<Species>Probes for hybridyzation were specific oligonucleotides end-labeled using [g-32P]ATP.</Species>
<Species>After hybridization and washes, membranes were exposed to phosphorimager screens or X-ray films (29).</Species>

<Species>Oligonucleotides specific for various regions of 35S pre-rRNA are: 1, GGTCTCTCTGCTGCCG GAAATG; 3, AATGAGCCATTCGCAGTTTCACTG; 4, GCTCTCATGCTCTTGCCAAAAC; 5, TGTTTGTTACCT CTGGGCCCCG; 6, TCCAGTTACGAAAATTCTTG; 7, CGTATCGCATTTCGCTGCGTTC; 8, GTTCGCCTAGAC GCTCTCTCTTC; 9, GCGAGATTCCCCTACCCAC.</Species>
<Species>The regions complementary to these oligonucleotides are shown in Figure 6A.</Species>
<Species>The oligonucleotides probing box C/D snoRNAs are: U3, TTCGGTTTCTCACTCACTCTGGGGTAC; U14, GGAACCAGTCTTTCATCACCGTG.</Species>
<Species>The oligonucleotides probing box H/ACA snoRNAs are: snoRNA10, CCTTG CAACGGTCCTCATCCGGG; snoRNA30, GTCCGAAGC GCCATCTAGATGA.</Species>

<Species>RNA and protein precipitation analysis Cells were grown in YPD (1 l) to OD600 1.0, then collected, washed once in ice-cold PBS and broken using glass beads in 10 ml IPP150 buffer (10 mM Tris pH 8.0, 150 mM NaCl and 0.1% NP-40) with protease inhibitors.</Species>

<Species>The lysates were mixed with 200 ul IgG agarose beads for 2 h at 4oC. After several washes with 50 ml IPP150 buffer, the IgG beads were collected and the RNA associated with the beads extracted by the hot phenol method (28).</Species>
<Species>One-tenth of the precipitated RNA was then separated on 6% polyacrylamide 7 M urea denaturing gels and electro-transferred to Zeta-Probe GT nylon membranes.</Species>
<Species>They were probed with [g-32P]ATP labeled oligonucleotides.</Species>
<Species>For the lanes showing total RNA, 2 ug RNA prepared from exponentially growing cultures were loaded.</Species>
<Species>For co-precipitation analysis of proteins, the IgG beads were resuspended in 2x Laemmli sample buffer, boiled for 5 min and separated by SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis.</Species>
<Species>Approximately 1% of the precipitate was loaded onto each lane.</Species>
<Species>For the total protein, 0.1% of the extract prior to precipitation was loaded onto each lane.</Species>

<Species>Following electrophoresis, the proteins were transferred to nitrocellulose membranes and detected using anti-Nop1 antibody at 1:3000 dilution (provided by J. Aris) and anti-L3 antibody (provided by J. Warner) at 1:3000 dilution followed by peroxidase-conjugated anti-mouse secondary antibody at 1:5000 dilution.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The antibody complexes were detected using ECL-Plus reagents (Amersham Pharmacia) as specified by the manufacturer.</Species>
<Species>RESULTS Construction and analysis of ENP1 temperature-sensitive alleles ENP1 is an essential yeast gene conserved among eukaryotes (18).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>To study its functions, we first created a diploid strain, JBY45, heterozygous for the Denp1 mutation.</Species>
<Species>Then two enp1 ts mutant alleles (enp1-1 and enp1-2) were generated by random PCR mutagenesis, as described in Materials and Methods.</Species>
<Species>Both mutant alleles were recessive to the wild-type ENP1 gene.</Species>
<Species>The enp1-1 gene was integrated into the chromosomal trp1-1 locus to create strain JBY51 and all subsequent experiments were done with this enp1 allele.</Species>
<Species>At 23oC the growth of JBY51 was comparable to that of W303-1a (ENP1), but at 37oC it did not grow (Fig. 2).</Species>
<Species>Sequence analysis revealed that enp1-1 contains two point mutations, resulting in substitutions of two amino acids: W242>G and V415>A.</Species>
<Species>No attempt was made to determine whether both mutations were required for the ts phenotype.</Species>

<Species>Flow cytometry of strain JBY51 showed DNA content profiles similar to those of the wild-type strain at the non-permissive temperature (data not shown), suggesting that ENP1 is not involved in cell cycle regulation.</Species>
<Species>Enp1 is enriched in the nucleolus Enp1 tagged at the C-terminus with the myc epitope was previously found to localize to the nucleus (18).</Species>

<Species>To expand this analysis, we fused GFP to the N-terminus of Enp1, and expressed the tagged Enp1 protein under control of the MET25 promoter as the sole source of Enp1 protein in the cells.</Species>
<Species>Cells of strain CWY13 (pMET25-GFP-ENP1) were grown in media with methionine (transcription partially repressed) or without methionine (transcription not repressed).</Species>
<Species>Growth of CWY13 was comparable to that of wild-type cells in both media (data not shown), indicating that the GFP tagged Enp1 protein was functional.</Species>

<Species>In cells cultured in medium without methionine, in which the ENP transcription was not repressed, the GFP-Enp1 protein was expressed at a high level and showed strong green fluorescence distributed throughout the nucleus (data not shown), consistent with the original observation (18).</Species>

<Species>With methionine added to the medium, however, the fluorescent signal of GFP-Enp1 was weaker and surprisingly showed crescent or cap-like patterns typical of nucleolar proteins (Fig. 3A).</Species>
<Species>This nucleolar enrichment was confirmed by its co-localization with the nucleolar protein Nop1</Species>
<Species>(Fig. 3B).</Species>
<Species>ENP1 mutation leads to reduced levels of 40S ribosomal subunits The nucleolar enrichment suggested that Enp1 might play some role in ribosome synthesis.</Species>

<Species>To test this possibility, cells of W303-1a (ENP1), JBY51 (enp1-1) and a top2 ts strain RS191 (30) were grown in YPD at 23 or 37oC and their ribosome profiles analyzed after separation on sucrose gradients.</Species>
<Species>At 23oC, enp1-1 cells showed polysome profiles similar to those of the wild-type and top2-1 strains (Fig. 4A-C).</Species>

<Species>In contrast, after incubation at the non-permissive temperature (37oC) for 40 min (data not shown) and 2 h, enp1-1 cells had reduced levels of 40S ribosomal subunits, 80S monosomes and polysomes, along with a dramatic increase in the free 60S subunit peak (Fig. 4F), while the wild-type and top2-1 cells showed little change in polysome profile at 37oC (Fig. 4D and E).</Species>

<Species>These results demonstrate that the changes of the enp1-1 polysome profile were due to specific defects caused by the enp1-1 mutation, and not due simply to the shift to 37oC for a wild-type or ts strain.</Species>

<Species>The processing of pre-rRNA for 18S rRNA is impaired in enp1 mutants In most cases reductions in ribosomal subunit levels are the results of defects in pre-rRNA processing or ribosome assembly or both (3).</Species>
<Species>To study the mechanism by which Enp1 affects the 40S subunit, we analyzed the effects of enp1 mutations on processing of the pre-rRNA using pulse-chase labeling.</Species>
<Species>[methyl-3H]methionine is preferred for labeling rRNAs in pulse-chase analysis because rRNAs are specifically methylated during the early steps of the processing.</Species>

<Species>Cells of W303-1a (ENP1) and JBY51 (enp1-1) were grown at 23 or 37oC for 2 h before they were labeled with [methyl-3H]methionine for 3 min and chased with cold methionine for 2, 4 and 12 min.</Species>

<Species>In wild-type cells, the labeled 35S rRNA precursor, 27S and 20S rRNA intermediates were rapidly chased into mature 25S and 18S rRNAs (Fig. 5), at 23 or 37oC. In contrast, enp1-1 cells showed dramatic changes after incubation at 37oC.</Species>

<Species>Although at 23oC the synthesis and processing were comparable to those of wild-type cells, cells cultured at 37oC for 2 h had neither 20S pre-rRNA nor 18S rRNA, while 25S rRNA was generated at normal levels.</Species>
<Species>The 37oC grown enp1-1 cells also had low levels of aberrant 23S and possibly 21S intermediates (Fig. 5).</Species>
<Species>The defect in 18S rRNA synthesis was further supported by pulse-chase experiments carried out using [5,6-3H]uracil.</Species>
<Species>The results obtained were essentially the same; no 20S pre-rRNA or 18S rRNA was produced, while processing to 25S rRNA was not affected (data not shown).</Species>

<Species>Taken together, these results suggested that the enp1 mutation leads to specific defects in the processing pathway for 20S pre-rRNA and 18S rRNA, resulting in reduced 40S subunit synthesis and a lowered level of the 40S subunit.</Species>

<Species>Enp1 is required for pre-rRNA processing at A0, A1 and A2 sites To define the processing steps affected by the enp1 mutation, the steady state levels of rRNA precursors and mature RNAs were analyzed by northern blotting.</Species>

<Species>Total RNAs were isolated from cells of W303-1a (ENP1) and JBY51 (enp1-1) grown at 37oC for 2 or 4 h. After separation on formaldehyde agarose, RNAs were transferred onto nylon membranes and probed with radiolabeled oligonucleotides specific to various regions of the 35S pre-rRNA (Fig. 6A).</Species>
<Species>After incubation at 37oC, enp1-1 cells had wild-type levels of 25S rRNA, but reduced levels of 18S rRNA</Species>
<Species>(Fig. 6B).</Species>
<Species>A probe specific to ITS1 (P5) further revealed that enp1-1 cells incubated at the non-permissive temperature accumulated two aberrant rRNAs, 23S and 21S (Fig. 6C).</Species>
<Species>Aberrant rRNA processing products of similar sizes have been described in numerous studies (14,31-34) and result from defects in processing at A0, A1 and A2.</Species>
<Species>Additional probes were used to verify the origins of the 23S and 21S RNAs in the enp1-1 strain.</Species>
<Species>The 23S product was detected by oligos 1, 2, 4 and 5, but not by oligos 6, 7 or 8 (Fig. 6D, E, C, F, G and data not shown).</Species>
<Species>Thus this RNA extends from the 5    end of the 35S rRNA to the A3 site.</Species>
<Species>The 21S product was detected by oligos 4 and 5, but not by oligos 1, 2, 6, 7 and 8 (Fig. 6E, C, D, F, G and data not shown), indicating that it extends from the A1 to the A3 site.</Species>
<Species>At 37oC the enp1-1 cells also had less 32S and 20S rRNA intermediates (Fig. 6B and E).</Species>
<Species>These results suggest that the enp1 mutation led to complete or nearly complete inhibition of processing at site A0 and A2, and partial inhibition of processing at site A1.</Species>
<Species>As a consequence, the 35S pre-rRNA was cleaved at site A3 instead, producing 23S and 21S rRNA products.</Species>

<Species>Consistent with this theory, the 27SA2 rRNA intermediate level was greatly reduced in enp1 cells at 37oC (Fig. 6C) due to the inhibition of processing at A2, while the 27SB pre-rRNA level was similar to wild-type cells (Fig. 6G).</Species>
<Species>Moreover, no difference in the 5.8 rRNA level was observed between the wild-type cells and enp1 cells (Fig. 6H).</Species>

<Species>Enp1 is associated with U3 and U14 snoRNAs and with Nop1 It has previously been shown that mutations in the U3, U14, snR10 and snR30 snoRNAs and in their associated proteins affect processing of 35S pre-rRNA at A0, A1 and A2.</Species>
<Species>Because of the similarity with the processing defects of enp1-1 strains, we tested the association between Enp1 and snoRNAs.</Species>
<Species>To do this, we created a strain in which a TAP tag was fused to the C-terminus of Enp1.</Species>
<Species>The TAP tag contains Staphylococcus aureus Protein A as well as calmodulin-binding peptide sequences, so the tagged Enp1 binds IgG beads with high specificity.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Cells grew well with the TAP-tagged Enp1 as the only source of Enp1 protein, showing that it was functional.</Species>
<Species>As a control, we used a TAP tag on an unrelated cytoplasmic protein, Hst2.</Species>
<Species>Strain CWY14 (ENP1-TAP) and the Hst2-TAP tagged strain were grown in YPD to mid-exponential phase before being harvested.</Species>
<Species>Extracts were prepared and mixed with IgG agarose beads to precipitate Enp1-TAP and associated RNAs.</Species>
<Species>Total RNAs were extracted from washed IgG beads, separated on 6% polyacrylamide denaturing gels, transferred to nylon membranes and probed with radiolabeled oligonucleotides.</Species>
<Species>Northern analysis revealed that Enp1-TAP precipitates were enriched with U3 and U14 snoRNAs relative to precipitates from the Hst2-tagged strain (Fig. 7A).</Species>
<Species>The Enp1-TAP samples were not enriched with snR30 snoRNA (Fig. 7A), nor with U24 or U18 snoRNAs (data not shown).</Species>
<Species>We found no change in the levels of U3, U14, snR10 and snR30 snoRNAs in the enp1 mutant, indicating that the mutation did not affect snoRNAs levels (Fig. 6I).</Species>
<Species>The results indicate that Enp1 associates in vivo with U3 and U14 snoRNAs.</Species>
<Species>Much less U3 RNA co-immunoprecipitated with Enp1-TAP than with Protein A-tagged Nop1, which is known to associate with U3 and U14 snoRNAs (Fig. 7A).</Species>
<Species>However, Protein A-Nop1 was much more efficiently precipitated than was the Enp1-TAP protein (data not shown).</Species>
<Species>Therefore, it is likely that similar amounts of RNAs are associated with the two proteins and that the proteins are part of the same complex.</Species>
<Species>To address this further, we checked for the presence of Nop1 in the Enp1-TAP immunoprecipitates.</Species>
<Species>Figure 7B shows that Nop1 indeed is in the Enp1 precipitate but not in the Hst2 control, whereas an abundant ribosomal protein, L3, is in neither precipitate.</Species>
<Species>U3 and U14 snoRNAs have been shown to interact with rRNA precursors and these interactions are required for pre-rRNA processing (35-37).</Species>
<Species>Using an in vitro system, U3 was also shown to be associated with its rRNA substrate and processing product (38).</Species>
<Species>This raised the possibility that Enp1 might also be associated with rRNAs since its function in rRNA processing appeared linked to those of U3 and U14 snoRNAs.</Species>
<Species>To test this possibility, we further analyzed the RNAs that co-precipiate with TAP-tagged Enp1.</Species>

<Species>The RNAs were separated on 1.2% agarose formaldehyde gels or on polyacrylamide denaturing gels, transferred to nylon membranes and probed with radiolabeled oligonucleotides for pre-rRNAs.</Species>
<Species>A probe (P4; see Fig. 6) specific to 20s and its precursors revealed that pre-rRNAs 35S, 33S, 32S and 20S specifically co-precipitated with Enp1-TAP (Fig. 7C).</Species>
<Species>No such enrichment was found using a probe (P8; see Fig. 6) specific for 27S RNAs or a probe for 5.8S RNA (Fig. 7C).</Species>
<Species>These results clearly demonstrated that Enp1 is associated with substrates and products of the early steps of 18S rRNA processing.</Species>
<Species>Comparison of Enp1 with homologs in other organisms Homologs of Enp1 protein in human, Drosophila and Caenorhabditis elegans have been reported (18).</Species>

Species

text: <Species>A previously described human homolog, bystin, was only 306 amino acids in length, and lacked sequences corresponding to the N-terminal 163 amino acids of yeast Enp1 (19).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>In contrast, we identified a human expressed sequence tag (EST), BC007340 in a Blast search that revealed an ORF of 1311 nucleotides encoding a 437 amino acid polypeptide (39).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Comparison of this 437 amino acid polypeptide with human bystin (19) showed that they were encoded by the same gene on human chromosome 6.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The reported sequence for human bystin is a fragment of the 437 amino acid human Enp1 protein, due to a truncated cDNA sequence.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Also, a sequence discrepancy at the C-terminus is due to inaccurate DNA sequence of the human bystin, as confirmed by available human genome and EST sequences.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Searches of the database of other organisms identified Enp1 homologs in S.pombe, Arabidopsis thaliana, C.elegans, Drosophila melanogaster and mouse.</Species>

text: <Species>The alignment of the homologs showed that they shared homology from the N-terminus to the C-terminus, with the C-terminal half extremely well conserved, with close to 90% similarity (Fig. 8).</Species>
<Species>One interesting observation is that the two amino acids changed in the enp1-1 mutant, W242 and V415, are conserved among all homologs.</Species>
<Species>The human Enp1 homolog was cloned and expressed in yeast and tested for function.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Expressed under the control of ADH, TEF or GPD promoter, the human Enp1 homolog did not complement a yeast enp1 null mutant.</Species>

text: <Species>However, a GFP fusion to the N-terminus of human Enp1 homolog localized to the nucleus and was enriched in the nucleolus (data not shown).</Species>

text: <Species>DISCUSSION ENP1 is a yeast gene first identified in a genetic screen for complementation of mutations in ost4, which encodes a subunit of oligosaccharide transferase (17), although subsequent work showed that it is unlikely that Enp1 has any connection to oligosaccharide transferase (18).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>ENP1 was shown to be essential for viability and the Enp1 protein localized to the nucleus (18).</Species>
<Species>When we re-examined the localization of Enp1, we observed that the protein was enriched in the nucleolus.</Species>
<Species>This finding led us to test for a role of Enp1 in ribosome synthesis.</Species>
<Species>Using an enp1 ts mutant, we found that depletion of Enp1 caused a 40S ribosomal subunit deficiency.</Species>
<Species>Further analysis revealed that this deficiency was not due to a change of the subunit   s stability, but to a defect in the synthesis of the subunit   s 18S rRNA component.</Species>

<Species>Pulse-chase analysis of RNA synthesis in an enp1-1 strain revealed that no 20S pre-rRNA or 18S rRNA was made at the non-permissive temperature, while levels of 25S rRNA appeared normal.</Species>
<Species>Low levels of precursors to 18S rRNA were detected in the mutants, and they were extremely unstable.</Species>

<Species>Northern analysis of steady state RNA levels demonstrated that the enp1 mutation specifically inhibited the pre-rRNA early cleavages at sites A0, A1 and A2, which are required for the production of the 20S pre-rRNA and the 18S rRNA.</Species>

<Species>These defects of the enp1 mutation on rRNA processing are very similar to those caused by mutation of KRR1, another essential nucleolar gene required for synthesis of the 40S, but not the 60S subunit (40).</Species>
<Species>Co-precipitation analyses provided strong evidence that Enp1 is directly involved in pre-rRNA processing.</Species>
<Species>In these experiments, TAP-tagged Enp1 bound to IgG beads specifically co-precipitated with two snoRNAs, U3 and U14, and with the 35S, 33S, 32S and 20S pre-rRNAs.</Species>
<Species>Among the more than 100 snoRNAs in yeast cells, U3, U14, snR10, snR30 and MRP RNA are the only ones required for rRNA processing.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>It has been shown that mutations in U3, U14, snR10 and snR30 snoRNAs and protein components of the snoRNPs affect processing at sites A0, A1 or A2 (15,16,41,42).</Species>
<Species>Enp1   s interaction with U3 and U14 snoRNAs suggests that Enp1   s function in rRNA processing involves these two snoRNAs.</Species>

<Species>The fact that the nucleolar protein, Nop1, known to bind to U3 and U14 RNAs, also was found in the Enp1 precipitate, provides additional evidence that Enp1 is part of a complex involved in processing of rRNA.</Species>
<Species>Recently, a genome-wide study of yeast protein complexes, using a TAP tag method similar to ours, reported a number of proteins that co-immunoprecipitated with Enp1 (43).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>These proteins included Imp4, Kre31, Kre33, Mpp10, Nop1, Nop14 and Sof1, all of which have been implicated in 18S RNA processing or 40S biogenesis.</Species>
<Species>Very recently (after the studies in this manuscript were concluded)</Species>
<Species>Grandi et al. published an analysis of components of the 90s preribosomal particle, which include the 35S pre-rRNA, U3 snoRNP and rRNA processing factors for the 40S subunit (44).</Species>
<Species>In agreement with our findings, they found that Enp1 is a component of this 90s complex and also of a smaller complex containing the 20S pre-rRNA.</Species>

<Species>Surprisingly, none of the other proteins involved in processing of pre-rRNAs that were tested associated with the 20S rRNA, suggesting that those proteins, but not Enp1, are released prior to 20S pre-rRNA formation (44).</Species>
<Species>The authors also showed co-precipitation of Enp1 with dimethylated 20S pre-rRNA, which is formed after export of 20S to the cytoplasm.</Species>
<Species>These results of Grandi et al.</Species>
<Species>suggest that Enp1 may also be involved in later steps of processing or nuclear export.</Species>
<Species>A previous study on the Enp1 human homolog, bystin, reported that the protein was localized in the cytoplasm of mammalian cells and might be involved in cell adhesion (19).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Our discovery of the 437 amino acid human Enp1 homolog revealed that the bystin studied previously was from a truncated library cDNA encoding only the C-terminal 306 amino acids.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Although the human homolog of Enp1 did not complement a yeast Denp1 mutant, we did show that it was localized to the nucleus and enriched in the nucleolus (data not shown).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>This strongly suggests that the conserved function of Enp1 is in rRNA processing.</Species>
<Species>The cytoplasmic localization of bystin and its proposed function in cell adhesion are unlikely to reflect the actual function of the human Enp1 homolog.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>It will be important to study the nature of the associations between Enp1 and U3 and U14 snoRNPs, and to learn more about the exact role of Enp1 in ribosomal RNA processing.</Species>
