<Species>radioactivity on the scale envisioned for a large sequencing project is undesirable for reasons of safety.</Species>
<Species>The relatively long exposure times required (6 to 24 hours) and the short half lives of the probes might also be inconvenient.</Species>

<Species>It has been shown that a biotin/streptavidin/alkaline phosphatase based detection system used in conjunction with a chemiluminescent dioxetane substrate overcomes these disadvantages (24, 25, 26).</Species>
<Species>We utilized a different bridging system with similar results.</Species>
<Species>Digoxigenin (DIG) labelled oligonucleotide probes were detected using anti-DIG antibody-alkaline phosphatase conjugates and a chemiluminescent dioxetane substrate.</Species>
<Species>Exposure times of 10 to 15 minutes were typically required, following a one hour preincubation period (Figure 3).</Species>

<Species>In our hands the DIG bridging system was similar in sensitivity to the streptavidin based system (24), and the practical lower limit of template ssDNA required in order to obtain an easily interpretable sequencing ladder was estimated to be in the range of 20 to 50fmols per reaction.</Species>
<Species>However, the sensitivity of detection was limited only by enzymaticallytriggered background luminescence, and not by the level of signal obtained.</Species>
<Species>The nonradioactive methods described have been used successfully in an 8-plex system.</Species>
<Species>DISCUSSION</Species>

<Species>Although the original multiplex protocol was based on a set of tagged vectors (3), tagged primers have also been used or proposed for various forms of multiplex DNA sequencing (George Church, personal communication; 2, 27).</Species>

<Species>For example, a proposal was recently put forward for multiplex sequencing using sequence-labelled primers and fluorophor-labelled probes (1), similar in principle to the methods used here.</Species>

<Species>However, we use tagged primers and the superposition of the four sequencing reactions to address the problem of reading DNA sequence films; a part of this solution is to utilize M13 dideoxynucleotide sequencing, thereby improving the quality of the data to be analyzed.</Species>

<Species>In addition, the proposal for fluorophor-labelled probes does not take into consideration any of the practical sequencing problems addressed here, and, in the version described, remains a promising but unproven scheme for large scale DNA sequencing.</Species>
<Species>There are several advantages to tagging primers instead of vectors.</Species>
<Species>Firstly, there is no need to prepare multiple libraries of clones in special vectors.</Species>

<Species>This means that workers can use vector/host combinations that yield good results in their hands, and an increased depth of multiplexing can easily be accomodated by synthesizing more primers.</Species>
<Species>This should make multiplexing more accessible to workers undertaking smaller projects.</Species>

<Species>A theoretical disadvantage of tagged primers is that the procedure can only be multiplexed following primer annealing (1), or following the sequencing reactions (this paper; in practice, pooling immediately after the annealing step might lead to increased backgrounds if one or more primers were present in excess over their template DNAs).</Species>
<Species>This is a relatively late stage.</Species>
<Species>In the original procedure (3), clones were pooled prior to amplification by growth, an early step.</Species>
<Species>However, we do not believe the sacrifice to be of practical importance when using phage vectors.</Species>

<Species>In our experience, recombinant M13 phage have variable growth rates and the effects of competition are likely to severely limit the number of clones that can usefully be pooled for growth.</Species>
<Species>In contrast, by growing clones individually, the depth of multiplexing is only really limited by probe sensitivity.</Species>
<Species>We have not investigated the factors influencing variability in phage growth rates.</Species>

<Species>It is worth noting that reliable protocols have been developed for growing large numbers of individual M13 clones and preparing high quality ssDNA templates in microtitre trays (28, 21).</Species>
<Species>It is relatively simple to prepare manually two microtitre trays of ssDNA templates (192 clones) in a day.</Species>
<Species>Sufficient clones can be prepared in a week to sequence a 20kb fragment to a redundancy of 10 (Victoria Smith, personal communication).</Species>
<Species>In this laboratory, ssDNA is now prepared with the aid of a commercially available robotic workstation (21).</Species>

<Species>As sequencing reactions are also carried out in microtitre trays, manually or robotically (20, 29), the entire M13-based dideoxynucleotide sequencing procedure is amenable to automation (29).</Species>
<Species>For these reasons we see little practical advantage in pooling clones early.</Species>

<Species>Finally, by not pooling clones early, the ability to easily retrieve individual clones is retained, which may facilitate directed sequencing later in a project should this become necessary.</Species>

<Species>Multiplex DNA sequencing is currently limited by the lack of a robust computer program which can correct for the large variety of gel and sequencing artefacts that are normally encountered.</Species>
<Species>The foundation of a film reading program is the ability to bring into register precisely vertical arrays of base-specific bands.</Species>
<Species>This requires the ability to track lanes, correct for distortions, and order bands based on their relative spacing.</Species>
<Species>A method of sequencing which has successfully overcome the problem of sequence reading uses real-time detection of fluorescently labelled DNA samples migrating through the gel (2).</Species>
<Species>This system also utilizes the principle of running the four base reactions down the same lane (2).</Species>
<Species>However, bands are detected at a fixed location in space, and their detection is separated in time.</Species>

<Species>Hence the Nucleic Acids Research, Vol. 19, No. 12 3305 problem of gel distortion is essentially avoided, although corrections for the different mobilities of the four dyes must be carried out.</Species>
<Species>In contrast, we utilize the advantages of single lane electrophoresis to address the problem of superimposing four relatively large and complex two-dimensional images.</Species>

<Species>Furthermore, by using sequence-tagged oligonucleotides which are detected by hybridization, a much greater depth of multiplexing can realistically be achieved than by real-time detection.</Species>

<Species>The use of two-dimensional colour traces to depict the processed output of a film reader is consistent with the method of displaying fluorescence traces, and should facilitate the checking and editing of sequence databases in which both kinds of data have been entered.</Species>

<Species>The sequence compilation programs used in this laboratory, which are already capable of handling large shotgun databases (8, 31), have recently undergone extensive improvements (Rodger Staden, personal communication).</Species>

<Species>There is now an interactive database editor which allows the graphical display of fluorescence traces, and it is envisaged that this feature could be extended to allow the handling of data from a film reader when a suitable machine is developed.</Species>

<Species>Recombinant activated protein C in sepsis: endothelium protection or endothelium therapy?</Species>
<Species>Abstract Endothelium dysfunction is one of the hallmarks of sepsis.</Species>
<Species>Looney and Mattay, in the previous issue of Critical Care, highlight the role of activated protein C (APC) as a protective endothelial drug in septic situations.</Species>
<Species>Nevertheless, the results of in vivo studies are less explicit and it remains uncertain whether these properties are relevant in human septic shock.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Before considering recombinant APC (rAPC) as a therapeutic drug for the endothelium, we have to demonstrate its efficiency to protect or to reduce endothelium injury when infused a long time after the septic challenge.</Species>
<Species>Nevertheless, if rAPC is efficient when infused in the early phase of septic challenge, we thus need to treat our patients earlier.</Species>
<Species>At the least, genetically engineered variants have been designed with greater anti-apoptotic activity and reduced anticoagulant activity relative to wild-type APC.</Species>
<Species>Further studies are needed to demonstrate the usefulness of these variants in septic shock therapy.</Species>
<Species>The use of recombinant activated protein C (rAPC) is one of the hottest topics in septic shock therapy.</Species>

<Species>The pivotal phase 3 placebo-controlled Protein C Worldwide Evaluation in Severe Sepsis (PROWESS) clinical trial demonstrated a 19.4% relative risk reduction in 28-day mortality (6.1% absolute risk reduction) with an increased risk (3.5% versus 2.0%) of serious bleeding events compared with placebo.</Species>
<Species>Two recent and important articles have highlighted the role of APC as a protective endothelial drug [1] and as a cyto-protective drug [2].</Species>

<Species>Beneficial effects of rAPC in the PROWESS study were thought to be related to a reduction in coagulation and, to a lesser extent, to a reduction in inflammatory response to sepsis [3].</Species>

<Species>Post-PROWESS investigations have been associated with a myriad of cellular or animal studies demonstrating that rAPC, through reactions mediated by endothelial protein C receptor and the effector receptor, protease activated receptor-1, acts directly on cells to exert multiple cytoprotective effects including: down regulation of pro-inflammatory gene expression [4]; anti-inflammatory activities [5]; anti-apoptotic activity [6]; and protection of endothelial barrier function [1,2].</Species>
<Species>Endothelium dysfunction is one of the hallmarks of sepsis [7].</Species>

<Species>Sepsis, per se, may induce phenotypic modulations of the endothelium through direct or indirect interaction of the endothelial layer with components of the bacterial wall, inducing a myriad of host-derived factors from endothelial cells.</Species>

<Species>Phenotypic modifications include changes in pro-coagulant and proadhesive properties, increased endothelial permeability, endothelial cell apoptosis and changes in vasomotor properties; the last of these is crucial since vasoplegia is directly related to septic shock mortality.</Species>

<Species>Recent animal and human data have suggested that rAPC may improve both vascular and myocardial dysfunction and vascular reactivity to catecholamine during endotoxin and/or septic challenge [8,9].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>From bench to bedside Experimental evidence supports a role of APC in maintaining the integrity of the endothelium through both direct and indirect mechanisms.</Species>
<Species>Nevertheless, the results of in vivo studies are less explicit.</Species>

<Species>In a retrospective study of septic shock in humans, Monnet and colleagues [9] demonstrated that APC infusion was associated with a decrease in the amount of delivered norepinephrine.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Wiel and colleagues [10] demonstrated in a rabbit model of endotoxin induced shock that APC decreased aorta endothelial injury.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>By contrast, in a lung model of endotoxin induced inflammation, Robriquet and colleagues [11] demonstrated a trend to an increased vascular permeability using high doses of human APC.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>This last result was in sharp contrast with the results obtained by Nick and colleagues [12] in a human model of pulmonary endotoxin administration.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>APC appears to improve mortality in septic shock with a high APACHE 2 score and is potentially detrimental in severe sepsis.</Species>
<Species>In rats, APC markedly decreased tumour necrosis factor concentrations whereas they remained unchanged in either human septic shock or endotoxemia.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The question arises, therefore, as to whether it is truly possible to reconcile all these discrepancies?</Species>
<Species>Moreover, can these stirring laboratory data be translated into clinical practice?</Species>

<Species>Limitations of experimental studies: endothelium protection versus endothelium therapy Clearly, in cellular and animal models, rAPC has been given either as a pre-treatment or concurrent with septic challenge.</Species>

<Species>This mode of administration favours the anti-inflammatory effects of rAPC, which are particularly efficient in murine models in protecting the endothelium from cytokine-mediated apoptosis or upregulation of endothelial adhesion molecules.</Species>

<Species>Thus, studies using post-injury treatment are needed in models that mimic septic shock, such as experimental pneumonia or peritonitis treated by antibiotics and volume resuscitation, and where the effects of rAPC would be investigated 16 to 24 hours after septic challenge.</Species>

<Species>If we can demonstrate the efficiency of rAPC to protect or to reduce endothelium injury in these conditions, we can ultimately postulate that rAPC is also a therapeutic drug for the endothelium.</Species>
<Species>The earlier the better If rAPC is efficient when infused in the early phase of septic challenge, we thus need to treat our patients earlier.</Species>

<Species>At least two studies suggest that treatment with rAPC within 24 hours may carry a larger survival advantage for patients with severe sepsis, compared with those treated more than 24 hours after organ dysfunction [13].</Species>
<Species>Interventions directed at specific endpoints, when initiated early in the 'golden hours' of a patient's condition, seem to be promising [14].</Species>
<Species>The beneficial effects of earlier administration of rAPC to appropriate patients may fit into this paradigm.</Species>

<Species>The future Extensive in vivo and in vitro studies have focused on the cytoprotective effects of APC and most authors agree that its anticoagulant and cytoprotective effects are mediated by distinct APC structural features.</Species>
<Species>Positively charged residues in surface loops in the APC protease domain have been identified as participating in the anticoagulant activity but not in cellular effects.</Species>
<Species>Hence, variants have been designed with greater anti-apoptotic activity and reduced anticoagulant activity relative to wild-type APC [2].</Species>
<Species>Whether these genetically engineered variants actually provide superior pharmacological properties remains to be elucidated in vivo.</Species>

<Species>Such investigations may allow the design of therapeutic APC variants with decreased anticoagulant activity to reduce the risk of bleeding on the one hand, but also with normal cytoprotective properties in order to retain full beneficial effects on sepsis outcome.</Species>
<Species>Abbreviations PROWESS =</Species>
<Species>Protein C Worldwide Evaluation in Severe Sepsis; rAPC = recombinant activated protein C. Competing interests BL has received reimbursements and funding from Eli Lilly, France.</Species>

<Species>Gene expression studies in isolated mitochondria: Solanum tuberosum rps10 is recognized by cognate potato but not by the transcription, splicing and editing machinery of wheat mitochondria</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Abstract The complex gene expression mechanisms that occur in plant mitochondria, such as RNA editing and splicing, are not yet well understood.</Species>
<Species>RNA editing in higher plant mitochondria is a highly specific process which modifies mRNA sequences by C-to-U conversions.</Species>
<Species>It has been suggested that in some cases this process is required for splicing.</Species>
<Species>Here, we use an experimental model based on the introduction of DNA into isolated mitochondria by electroporation to study organellar gene expression events.</Species>

<Species>Our aim was to compare processing and editing of potato small ribosomal protein 10 gene (rps10) transcripts in heterologous (wheat mitochondria) and homologous (potato mitochondria) contexts.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>rps10 is a suitable model because it contains a group II intron, is absent in wheat mitochondria but is actively expressed in potato mitochondria, where transcripts are spliced and undergo five C-to-U editing events.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>For this purpose, conditions for electroporating isolated potato mitochondria were established.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>rps10 was placed under the control of either potato or wheat cox2 promoters.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>We found that rps10 was only transcribed under the control of a cognate promoter.</Species>
<Species>In wheat mitochondria, rps10 transcripts were neither spliced nor edited while they are correctly processed in potato mitochondria.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Interestingly, a wheat editing site grafted into rps10 was not recognized by wheat mitochondria but was correctly edited in potato mitochondria.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Taken together, these results suggest that editing might occur only when the transcripts are engaged in processing and that they would not be available to editing factors outside of a putative RNA maturation machinery complex.</Species>

<Species>INTRODUCTION Gene expression in plant mitochondria is a complex process involving multiple steps such as transcription, cis- and trans-splicing, RNA trimming and RNA editing on the way to translation (1).</Species>

<Species>RNA editing has been found in a variety of organisms and occurs through different mechanisms such as insertion or deletion of nucleotides, or base conversions [for details see reference (2)].</Species>
<Species>In higher plant organelles, RNA editing is an important post-transcriptional event characterized by C-to-U changes via a deamination mechanism (3-5).</Species>
<Species>In Arabidopsis thaliana 456 C-to-U editing events have been described (6).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>RNA editing occurs mostly in the coding regions which alter the identity of the encoded amino acid, but some editing events occur in highly structured regions of introns (7,8).</Species>

<Species>Like other maturation processes, RNA editing is an essential post-transcriptional event in plant mitochondrial gene expression (9-11) required for the synthesis of functional proteins (12,13).</Species>

<Species>The introduction of foreign DNA into isolated mitochondria is a novel experimental model which has provided important information on RNA editing and RNA splicing enabling the use of a site-directed mutagenesis approach (14,15).</Species>
<Species>Using a cognate cox2 chimeric gene construct, the cis-recognition elements required for plant mitochondria RNA editing have been determined (16,17).</Species>

<Species>Using the same approach, Staudinger and Kempken (18) have reported that transcripts from A.thaliana cox2, but not Sorghum bicolor atp6, are edited when the genes are introduced into maize mitochondria.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Interestingly, higher plant mitochondrial genomes differ in their gene contents due to an evolutionary information transfer from the organelle to the nucleus (19).</Species>

<Species>Of particular interest is the situation of the small ribosomal protein 10 gene (rps10), a group II intron-bearing gene which is encoded in Solanum tuberosum mitochondrial DNA but is absent from the wheat mitochondrial genome (20).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Higher plant mitochondria contain group II introns either in cis- or trans- configuration (1) which can be folded in a characteristic secondary structure (21).</Species>
<Species>Intron removal in plant mitochondrial mRNAs is not well documented because such introns are unable to self-splice.</Species>
<Species>Previously, we described that electroporated cox2 constructs were a good model for the study of the splicing process.</Species>
<Species>Using this model, we found that editing and splicing of cox2 transcripts were not linked in wheat mitochondria (15).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>To challenge the ability of mitochondrial gene expression machinery to recognize genetic information which has been lost during evolution, we decided to introduce the S.tuberosum non-cognate rps10 gene into wheat mitochondria.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Five C residues are changed to U in potato mitochondria rps10 transcripts by editing.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Two of them have been postulated as being necessary for acquisition of a proper secondary and/or tertiary structure for splicing.</Species>
<Species>To test this hypothesis, it was necessary to set up the conditions for electroporation of foreign DNA into S.tuberosum mitochondria.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Here, we show that a potato rps10 construct is transcribed when introduced into wheat mitochondria, but transcripts are not recognized by the post-transcriptional processing machinery.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>In contrast, a rps10 construct is correctly expressed and processed in cognate potato mitochondria.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Moreover, we present evidence that transcript editing might be linked to overall RNA processing.</Species>
<Species>This is the first report on DNA electroporation into potato mitochondria.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>MATERIALS AND METHODS Plasmids</Species>
<Species>All plasmids used in this study are based on the previously described pCOXII vector (14).</Species>
<Species>An NsiI restriction site was introduced at the initiation codon of the wheat cox2 open reading frame (ORF).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Then, NsiI was used in combination with a SpeI restriction site present in the original vector after the stop codon, to produce the chimeric vectors.</Species>
<Species>S.tuberosum</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>cox2 gene, including a 727 bp non-coding upstream region, was isolated by PCR from total DNA using the primer A designed from partial sequences reported by Loessl et al.</Species>
<Species>(22), accession no.</Species>
<Species>AF096321, containing the KpnI restriction sequence, and primer B derived from Triticum timopheevi cox2 (AF336134).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>A fragment of 2888 bp was obtained and cloned on pGEM-T vector.</Species>
<Species>The complete sequence of the S.tuberosum cox2 was determined (accession no.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>DQ18064).</Species>

<Species>To generate the plasmid pCOXIISt containing the S.tuberosum cox2 gene, a KpnI/SpeI fragment containing the 727 bp upstream region and the complete coding region was used to replace the wheat gene from pCOXII.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>As for pCOXII, a NsiI site was inserted at the ATG start codon and a 23 bp fragment was inserted at position    20.</Species>
<Species>This 23 bp insertion provides a specific sequence allowing isolation of potato cox2 transcripts originating from the introduced DNA by RT-PCR.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The chimeric wheat/potato cox2 gene was constructed by replacing 727 bp KpnI/NsiI promoter sequence from pCOXIISt with the 880 bp wheat upstream region from pCOXII.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>The vectors pRPS10W and the pRPS10St derivative, containing wheat and potato cox2 promoters, respectively, were constructed by inserting the 1178 bp rps10 sequence containing two exons separated by a 777 bp intronic sequence [(23), accession no. X74826].</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The coding region was isolated from total S.tuberosum DNA by PCR using primers D1 and D2 containing the restriction sites NsiI and SpeI, respectively.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The fragment NsiI/SpeI was purified and cloned into pCOXII and pCOXIISt, replacing the respective cox2 coding regions.</Species>
<Species>Since all vectors used here were based on pCOXII, they contain the downstream region from the wheat cob gene (Ir-cob) (accession no.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>AF337547) (14).</Species>
<Species>This sequence, combined with the 23 bp upstream insert sequence served to distinguish, using primers 1a and 1b, foreign from endogenous transcripts.</Species>
<Species>All mutants were obtained using QuickChangeR Site-Directed Mutagenesis kit (Stratagene).</Species>
<Species>PCR product purifications were carried out with the WizardR Clean-Up System (Promega).</Species>
<Species>PCR primers used Oligonucleotides sequences are in 5    to 3    orientation.</Species>

<Species>(1a), GCGGTGCAGTCATACAGATCTGC; (1b), TATCCAGATTTGGTACCAAAC; (2a), GCAGTCATACAGATCTGCCAAAG; (2b), AGATTTGGTACCAAACCCGGG; (A), TATAGGTACCTCTCAGGTGTCAAAGTGTGGATTT; (B), TATAACTAGTTTAAGCTTCCCCG; (D1), TATAATGCATAGACAAAGGAGAGCACTTA; (D2), TATAACTAGTTCAGGAAAGGGTCAACGCAA.</Species>

<Species>Single C2, C3 and C2+C3 double mutant plasmids were constructed with primers (C2) AAGAAGTTCTTTTGGTTAAAACGCC and (C3) CGCCGTGCGACTTGGAGGACATAAG.</Species>
<Species>NsiI-pCOXII:</Species>
<Species>GGAAATCCAATGCATCTTCGTTCATT and NsiI-pCOXIISt: CCAAACCAAATGCATGTTCTAGAATG.</Species>

<Species>Construct pCOXIISt containing a 23 nt insertion in the promoter region, was carried out into two consecutive insertions using primers: TGGGGGGAGCAGAGCAGTGCGGTGCAGTCACAAAGAATGAACCAAACC and GCAGTGCGGTGCAGTCATACAGATCTGCCAAAGAATGAACCAAACC.</Species>
<Species>For constructs MA and MAB containing the wheat cox2 C259 editing site, two consecutive insertions were carried out using primers:</Species>

text: <Species>GGAAGATTGGATTACTATCGAAATTGCCCTGAATCA and TACTATCGAAATTATTCGGACCATGCCCTGAATCA.</Species>
<Species>For ME6 and ME6b constructs, primers CCGCGAGGAATCAACTACTATCGAAATTATTGCCGGTGCTGAC and CAACTACTATCGAAATTATTCGGACCATATTGCCGGTGCTGAC were used.</Species>

<Species>Mitochondria purification S.tuberosum cv.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Rosevalt tubers and T.aestivum var Fortal seeds were used.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Potato mitochondria were prepared from 2 kg of tubers in batches of 200 g with 200 ml of a homogenization buffer containing 0.4 M mannitol, 25 mM MOPS (pH 7.8), 1 mM EGTA, 8 mM cysteine and 1 mg/ml fatty acid-free BSA.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Homogenization was carried out for 15 s in a Waring blendor at full speed.</Species>
<Species>Homogenate was centrifuged in a Sorvall GSA rotor at 1500 g for 10 min at 4oC. Supernatant was centrifuged in a GSA rotor at 12 000 g for 15 min.</Species>
<Species>The mitochondrial pellet was resuspended in 50 ml of homogenization buffer and centrifuged at 1500 g.</Species>

<Species>The supernatant was centrifuged in a Sorvall SS-34 rotor at 15 000 g for 10 min, the pellet was resuspended in 12 ml of homogenization buffer and mitochondria were purified by centrifugation on a sucrose gradient essentially as described for wheat embryo mitochondria (14).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Electroporation Electrotransfer experiments were carried out with 1 mg of purified wheat embryo or potato tuber mitochondria in 50 ul of 0.33 M sucrose and 1 ug of recombinant plasmid as described (14).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The electroporated mitochondria were incubated for 18 h at 25oC, then recovered by centrifugation in a Sigma No 12024 rotor (Sigma 1K15 refrigerated centrifuge) at 15 000 g for 15 min at 4oC.</Species>
<Species>In the case of potato mitochondria the incubation mixture was supplemented with 1 mg/ml of fatty acid-free BSA.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>RNA was purified with 200 ul of TRIzol  reagent (Gibco-BRL) according to the supplier's protocol.</Species>

<Species>DNAse I protection assay and DNA purification After electroporation and centrifugation, the mitochondrial pellet was resuspended in 100 ul of buffer [10 mM Tris-HCl (pH 7.5), 2 mM magnesium acetate and 0.33 M sucrose] containing 60 U of DNase</Species>
<Species>I (Gibco-BRL) and incubated for 1 h at room temperature.</Species>

<Species>The DNase reaction was stopped by adding 4 ul of 0.5 M EDTA and then heating for 10 min at 65oC. Mitochondria were incubated with 100 ug of Proteinase K (Merck) for 4 h at 37oC. One microliter of 20% SDS was added to achieve mitochondrial lysis and the DNA was extracted with phenol/chloroform, precipitated with 0.1 vol of 3 M Sodium Acetate (pH 5.2), 3 vol of 100% ethanol and 100 ng of carrier yeast tRNA and left overnight at    20oC. After centrifugation, the DNA pellet was resuspended in TE buffer [10 mM Tris-HCl (pH 8) and 1 mM EDTA].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>RT-PCR RNA (1 ug) was treated with 2 U of Amplification grade DNase I (Promega).</Species>
<Species>cDNA</Species>
<Species>synthesis was performed with 200 U of Superscript II RT using 100 ng of random hexamers.</Species>

<Species>The PCR were performed with primers 1a and 1b using AdvantageR 2 Polymerase Mix (Clontech) as follows: 95oC, 1 min; 5 cycles at 95oC for 30 s and 68oC for 1 min; 30 cycles at 95oC for 30 s, 58oC for 30 s and 68oC for 30 s, and finally 68oC for 1 min.</Species>
<Species>Primers 2a and 2b were used for nested PCR from 1 ul of the first PCR.</Species>
<Species>No RT-PCR amplification products were obtained with RNA from non-electroporated mitochondria.</Species>

<Species>DNA sequencing Sequence analyses were performed directly on the RT-PCR product using an automatic DNA sequencing equipment with the BigDyeR Terminator Cycle Sequencing Kit (Applied Biosystem).</Species>
<Species>RESULTS S.tuberosum</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>rps10 transcripts are not processed in wheat mitochondria</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The S.tuberosum rps10 construct under control of a wheat cox2 promoter (Figure 1A) was incorporated into purified wheat mitochondria by electroporation as indicated in Materials and Methods.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>After electroporation and incubation in expression medium, mitochondrial RNA was extracted and analysed by RT-PCR.</Species>
<Species>The primers used allowed detection of the transcripts generated by the constructs introduced and excluded any product from endogenous cox2 (or rps10 in the potato system).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Two bands of 1204 and 427 bp were expected from precursor and mature rps10 mRNAs, respectively.</Species>
<Species>Only precursor rps10 molecules were detected (Figure 1B).</Species>
<Species>As a control, a cognate cox2 construct (16) was used.</Species>
<Species>In this case, the 2048 and 827 bp RT-PCR bands representing the precursor and spliced cox2 products, respectively were observed (Figure 1B).</Species>
<Species>In all cases, the PCR bands actually represent transcription products since when PCR was performed without the RT step we observed no amplification products.</Species>
<Species>Previously, five C residues, two in exon 1, one in the intron and two in exon 2 have been reported to be changed to U by editing in potato mitochondria (23).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>To determine if the non-cognate transcript could be recognized by the wheat RNA editing machinery, the 1204 bp RT-PCR product was sequenced.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>While wheat cox2 editing sites were correctly edited in control as expected (Figure 1C, only site C77 is shown), all five editable residues in potato rps10 transcript remain unchanged.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>cox2 C77 editing sites are identical in potato and wheat.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Failure of rps10 transcript splicing in wheat mitochondria is not linked to the absence of editing It has been suggested that residues C2 and C3 participate in the secondary structure of the intron necessary for splicing (23).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>A possible explanation to the failure observed in precursor rps10 splicing could be that the absence of edition of C2 and C3 prevent the intron from organizing itself in a catalytically competent conformation.</Species>

<Species>To test this hypothesis, single C2 and C3 mutants and a C2+C3 double mutant were constructed by changing the C residues to T. Neither single nor double mutants were able to undergo splicing (Figure 2).</Species>
<Species>Electroporation of S.tuberosum mitochondria</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Since two important post-transcriptional processes, RNA editing and splicing, were inoperative when S.tuberosum rps10 was expressed in wheat mitochondria, we decided to verify whether the negative results were inherent to the rps10 chimeric constructs or due to the lack of trans-recognition elements in wheat mitochondria.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>For this purpose, it was necessary to set up an electroporation protocol adapted to S.tuberosum mitochondria.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Purified organelles were prepared from potato tubers as indicated in Materials and Methods.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Electric pulses in the range between 8 and 20 kV were performed.</Species>
<Species>Internalization of exogenous DNA was measured by DNAse protection assays (14).</Species>
<Species>Potato mitochondria show a broad range response with a maximum around 13 kV</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>(Figure 3).</Species>
<Species>This voltage setting was therefore used for further experiments.</Species>
<Species>S.tuberosum</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>mitochondria does not recognize the wheat cox2 promoter To ascertain the ability of electroporated mitochondria to perform expression of the exogenous gene construct, we used a plasmid containing the potato cox2 gene controlled either by T.aestivum or S.tuberosum promoters.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>As shown in Figure 4, the construct containing the wheat or potato promoters was transcribed only in cognate mitochondria.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>In potato, the mature product is barely detectable.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In contrast to wheat mitochondria, the 821 nt mature transcript was only detected when the electroporated potato mitochondria were incubated in the presence of fatty acid-free BSA.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>A cognate rps10 construct is correctly expressed, edited and processed in potato mitochondria</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The construct expressing potato rps10 under the control of potato cox2 promoter was introduced into S.tuberosum isolated mitochondria.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>After incubation, the precursor and mature transcripts were amplified by RT-PCR (Figure 5A) and sequenced.</Species>
<Species>As shown in Figure 5B, the four editing sites C1, C2, C4 and C5, described previously in endogenous transcripts, were found edited in mature mRNA.</Species>
<Species>The presence of spliced molecules containing unedited residues (Figure 5B) indicates that rps10 transcripts could be spliced before editing.</Species>
<Species>To confirm this observation, the PCR product was cloned and sequenced.</Species>
<Species>One half of the individual clones were found edited at sites C1 and C2; 65% were edited at site C4 and 25% were edited at site C5.</Species>

<Species>A cognate editing site in a non-native context is not recognized by wheat mitochondria but is recognized in heterologous mitochondria To test whether wheat mitochondria are able to edit a cognate site when placed in the context of a potato transcript, we introduced the C259    16/+6 region from wheat cox2 into potato rps10 exon 1 or intron (Figure 6A, construct MA and ME6, respectively).</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>As reported previously, the 23 nt region forming the C259 editing site from wheat cox2 was efficiently edited when grafted into a different context in a wheat transcript (17).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Wild-type rps10 (pRPS10W) and the MA and ME6 mutants were expressed in wheat mitochondria but no splicing was observed (Figure 6B).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Unexpectedly, wheat mitochondria appear to be unable to edit the cognate C259 site when the    16/+6 region is located on a potato rps10 precursor.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The control CM construct, containing the C259 site grafted in a different context but in its own cox2 gene, was expressed, spliced and edited as expected [(17), Figure 6B and D].</Species>
<Species>To compare the editing status of RNAs at the same stage of processing, the editing status of the inserted C259 site in precursor cox2 transcripts is shown (Figure 6D).</Species>

<Species>The analogous MAb and ME6b constructs, containing the S.tuberosum cox2 promoter and the C259 region inserted into rps10 exon 1 and intron were used to electroporate potato mitochondria.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>As shown in Figure 6C, MAb and ME6b were expressed and spliced at the same level as the control in the homologous context, indicating that insertion does not affect the splicing process.</Species>
<Species>Interestingly, while C259 insertion was not recognized in wheat mitochondria (Figure 6D), the potato RNA editing machinery edited the inserted C259 region (Figure 6E).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The C259 region inserted in the rps10 intron (construct ME6b) was also edited, although at a very low level, showing that editing may precede intron removal (not shown).</Species>
<Species>DISCUSSION Plant mitochondria undergo complex expression mechanisms which are poorly understood.</Species>
<Species>Most studies are based on analysis of in vivo mature or intermediate gene products giving clues on possible mechanisms and suggesting pathways operating in gene expression.</Species>
<Species>Direct tests using in vitro approaches have been fruitful (4,5,24), but are hampered by the difficulty of obtaining active mitochondrial extracts.</Species>
<Species>Previously, we devised an experimental model based on electroporation of isolated mitochondria that allows us to test gene expression of wild-type and mutant genes.</Species>
<Species>This approach has been very useful in elucidating the process of RNA maturation in plant mitochondria, in particular splicing and editing (14,15).</Species>
<Species>The aim of this work was to analyse different gene expression events when a foreign gene was expressed in a heterologous context.</Species>
<Species>rps10 was chosen precisely because this genetic information is lacking in wheat mitochondria but is active in potato mitochondria (20,23,25).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Moreover, rps10 transcripts undergo five C-to-U editing events in potato mitochondria and rps10 contains an intron, thus facilitating the analysis of post-transcriptional processing.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>To best evaluate the expression of rps10 in the non-cognate mitochondria, it was necessary to set up electroporation conditions for introducing foreign DNA into S.tuberosum mitochondria.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Potato tuber mitochondria were able to incorporate DNA essentially under the same conditions described for wheat embryo organelles (14), except that the optimal voltage range was larger.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>A major difference to wheat was that isolated potato mitochondria were viable for 3-4 h as measured by oxygen consumption (data not shown).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Thus, to observe transcript maturation after electroporation the incubation mixture needed to be supplemented with fatty acid-free BSA (see Figure 4).</Species>
<Species>This behaviour probably reflects the uncoupling of oxidative phosphorylation by fatty acids during incubation of potato mitochondria (26).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In fact, previously we found that proper gene expression in isolated mitochondria requires a functional organelle able to generate ATP from ADP and succinate (14).</Species>
<Species>An interesting observation was that neither the wheat nor the potato cox2 promoters were recognized in a heterologous context (Figure 4A and B).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>This situation might by explained by the fact that potato and wheat promoter sequences have no recognizable homologous motifs.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Plant mitochondria promoters are characterized by a conserved core CRTA sequence with differences in the extent and the composition of sequences around the consensus motif (27,28).</Species>
<Species>While the transcription initiation site in wheat mitochondria is located at position    170 (29), the potato promoter has not yet been described.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Transcription may be initiated at numerous sites suggesting a relaxed promoter recognition by the transcription machinery (28).</Species>

<Species>However, the lack of crossed recognition of cox2 promoters in wheat and potato is not a general situation since the A.thaliana cox2 gene is expressed and spliced when introduced into maize mitochondria, indicating that the Arabidopsis gene shares some signals with maize cox2 promoter that are sufficient for transcription (18).</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>The sites required for transcript initiation have been recently described in A.thaliana mitochondrial genes (28).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Three regions were described as important for transcription initiation.</Species>
<Species>We found no such homologous sequences in the potato cox2 upstream region indicating that the two dicot promoters do not have the same origin.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>This in turn may reflect the natural history of this particular mitochondrial gene evolving in its own context.</Species>

<Species>It should be mentioned that the presence of a conserved sequence is not sufficient for expression since a region that acts as promoter in Arabidopsis, potato and Oenothera is inactive in vivo in pea (30).</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Further studies will be required to understand the transcriptional events in plant mitochondria.</Species>
<Species>Electroporation of foreign DNA into isolated mitochondria provides an interesting functional model, complementary to in vitro transcription assay, for answering these questions.</Species>
<Species>The potato rps10 gene controlled by a T.aestivum promoter (Figure 1A) was transcribed as a 1204 nt precursor in wheat mitochondria, but no traces of mature RNA were observed.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Moreover, the five C residues reported as RNA editing targets in vivo (23) remain unchanged, indicating that rps10 transcript was not recognized by the wheat splicing and editing machinery.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>A control using the cognate cox2 construct demonstrates that electroporated organelles were competent for splicing and editing (Figure 1B and C).</Species>
<Species>Some editing events occur in highly structured domains of introns.</Species>

<Species>Because in some cases, editing corrects A-C mispairing improving conformation of the intron, it has been proposed that the C-to-U change might be necessary for efficient splicing (8,9,23,31).</Species>

<Species>Based on the canonical structure of group II mitochondrial introns (21), two editing sites, C2 located at the Intron Binding Site 2 (IBS2) and C3 located in the intron, nine residues downstream from the end of exon 1 in S.tuberosum rps10 are of particular interest.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>It has been predicted that both edited residues participate in base-pair interactions in the putative secondary structure.</Species>
<Species>Of particular interest is the site C3 located in intron domain I (23).</Species>
<Species>This position may be crucial for splicing as inferred from mutants of a yeast mitochondrial intron (32).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We addressed this question by introducing rps10 mutant genes presenting C2, C3 or both positions in the edited form into mitochondria.</Species>
<Species>As shown in Figure 2, transcription was as efficient as for the cognate cox2 construct but neither wild-type rps10 nor the C-U mutants underwent splicing.</Species>

<Species>These results clearly demonstrate that C2 and C3 editing is not sufficient for splicing of rps10 precursor in wheat mitochondria and lead us to conclude that splicing failure is probably linked to the lack of trans-recognition elements.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>One may speculate that these trans-acting factors, for instance nuclear-encoded maturases, were lost after rps10 was transferred to the nucleus in monocots (20,25).</Species>

<Species>The C-to-U mutants were also tested in potato mitochondria; no significant differences were detected in splicing efficiency when compared to the unedited construct (D. Choury, unpublished data).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>It should be noted that the lack of splicing in wheat mitochondria is not a general feature of potato introns, since the potato cox2 intron is removed efficiently (Figure 4B).</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>This is consistent with the hypothesis that potato and wheat mitochondria have similar trans-acting factors for cox2 intron removal.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>A possible link between intron removal and editing has been proposed for splicing of nad1e and nad5III trans-introns where domain six may require editing to be structured in a catalytic competent secondary conformation (8).</Species>
<Species>In rice, failure of RNA maturation and editing has been correlated with cytoplasmic male sterile phenotype.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In this model, the absence of the nuclear gene Rf-1 affects B-atp6 RNA cleavage and editing (33).</Species>
<Species>In organello studies have shown that S.bicolor atp6-1 gene was transcribed but not edited when introduced into maize mitochondria (18).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>However, partially edited molecules were detected in sorghum-maize atp6 chimeric transcripts when they included the maize atp6 5   -untranslated sequence, suggesting that the 5    non-coding region provides a structural motif or binding site for a transcript-specific editing factor (34).</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Unfortunately, no data on atp6 processing was reported to determine whether this region is directly involved in editing or some other maturation event.</Species>

<Species>Since wheat mitochondria do not have rps10 encoded in the mitochondrial genome (20), it was interesting to test whether wheat mitochondria were able to recognize editing sites which had been lost during evolution.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>In other words, whether the mitochondrial trans-recognition elements are specific for each site or whether they are operating on a subset of editing sites.</Species>
<Species>This question is important since to date the factors responsible for RNA editing in plant mitochondria remain unknown.</Species>
<Species>Solving this issue may provide clues to uncover such factors.</Species>
<Species>As described above, the rps10 transcript was not processed in wheat but it was correctly spliced in cognate mitochondria (Figure 5A).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Indeed, the mature transcript had identical exon1 and exon2 junction as found in endogenous rps10 mRNA (data not shown).</Species>
<Species>More importantly, all editing sites, C1, C2, C4 and C5 were significantly converted to Us (Figure 5B).</Species>

<Species>The fact that the four editing sites were found either edited or unedited in spliced rps10 mRNA is an indication that editing does not precede splicing as was previously found for cox2 in wheat (15).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>It may be argued that the absence of splicing precluded editing.</Species>
<Species>This possibility can be discarded since potato rps10 precursor mRNA was found to be edited in vivo (23).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>These data clearly show that splicing is not required for rps10 editing, similar to previous findings for cox2 mRNA and also in cox2 mutant derivatives unable to remove the intron (15).</Species>

<Species>This led us to postulate that the inability of wheat mitochondria to recognize rps10 editing sites is likely due to the fact that wheat mitochondria have lost the editing trans-recognition elements which become dispensable after transfer of rps10 to the nucleus.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>To test this possibility, rps10 chimeric plasmids containing editing site C259 from wheat cox2 inserted either in exon1 or the intron were constructed.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Site C259 is formed by 23 nt corresponding to the    16/+6 sequence embedding the target C. Previously we found that this small region could be recognized by the RNA editing machinery when placed outside of its natural context (16,17).</Species>
<Species>The wheat C259 editing site in the chimeric construct was correctly edited by potato mitochondria.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>This result is not unexpected since the corresponding region in endogenous potato cox2 mRNA, which presents two differences at positions    3 (C instead of A) and    7 (G instead of A), is edited.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Furthermore, these positions were not crucial for editing of C259 (17).</Species>
<Species>Surprisingly, the C259 editing site grafted in rps10 was not recognized by the wheat editing machinery.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We cannot exclude the possibility that editing efficiency in precursor molecules is very low and so is undetectable when sequencing RT-PCR products representing a pool of transcripts.</Species>
<Species>However, analysis of the same region in cox2 precursors indicates that this was not the case since significant C-to-U conversion was observed (Figure 6D).</Species>

<Species>These observations lead us to postulate that editing is occurring only when the transcript is engaged in post-transcriptional processing, suggesting that rps10 transcripts are not available to editing factors independently of the RNA maturation machinery.</Species>
<Species>The fact that the wheat editing site C259 inserted in chimeric rps10 transcripts was not recognized by wheat mitochondria is a strong argument for this hypothesis.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>One might speculate that in plant mitochondria, transcripts have to be engaged in a kind of multiprotein processing complex.</Species>
<Species>A failure to be recognized at some early stage will lead to their accumulation as unmodified precursors.</Species>
<Species>Comparison of age-specific cataract prevalence in two population-based surveys 6 years apart</Species>
<Species>Abstract Background In this study, we aimed to compare age-specific cortical, nuclear and posterior subcapsular (PSC) cataract prevalence in two surveys 6 years apart.</Species>

<Species>Methods The Blue Mountains Eye Study examined 3654 participants (82.4% of those eligible) in cross-section I (1992-4) and 3509 participants (75.1% of survivors and 85.2% of newly eligible) in cross-section II (1997-2000, 66.5% overlap with cross-section I).</Species>
<Species>Cataract was assessed from lens photographs following the Wisconsin Cataract Grading System.</Species>
<Species>Cortical cataract was defined if cortical opacity comprised > 5% of lens area.</Species>
<Species>Nuclear cataract was defined if nuclear opacity > Wisconsin standard 4.</Species>
<Species>PSC was defined if any present.</Species>
<Species>Any cataract was defined to include persons who had previous cataract surgery.</Species>
<Species>Weighted kappa for inter-grader reliability was 0.82, 0.55 and 0.82 for cortical, nuclear and PSC cataract, respectively.</Species>
<Species>We assessed age-specific prevalence using an interval of 5 years, so that participants within each age group were independent between the two surveys.</Species>
<Species>Results Age and gender distributions were similar between the two populations.</Species>
<Species>The age-specific prevalence of cortical (23.8% in 1st, 23.7% in 2nd) and PSC cataract (6.3%, 6.0%) was similar.</Species>
<Species>The prevalence of nuclear cataract increased slightly from 18.7% to 23.9%.</Species>

<Species>After age standardization, the similar prevalence of cortical (23.8%, 23.5%) and PSC cataract (6.3%, 5.9%), and the increased prevalence of nuclear cataract (18.7%, 24.2%) remained.</Species>

<Species>Conclusion In two surveys of two population-based samples with similar age and gender distributions, we found a relatively stable cortical and PSC cataract prevalence over a 6-year period.</Species>
<Species>The increased prevalence of nuclear cataract deserves further study.</Species>
<Species>Background Age-related cataract is the leading cause of reversible visual impairment in older persons [1-6].</Species>
<Species>In Australia, it is estimated that by the year 2021, the number of people affected by cataract will increase by 63%, due to population aging</Species>
<Species>[7].</Species>
<Species>Surgical intervention is an effective treatment for cataract and normal vision (> 20/40) can usually be restored with intraocular lens (IOL) implantation.</Species>
<Species>Cataract surgery with IOL implantation is currently the most commonly performed, and is, arguably, the most cost effective surgical procedure worldwide.</Species>
<Species>Performance of this surgical procedure has been continuously increasing in the last two decades.</Species>
<Species>Data from the Australian Health Insurance Commission has shown a steady increase in Medicare claims for cataract surgery [8].</Species>
<Species>A 2.6-fold increase in the total number of cataract procedures from 1985 to 1994 has been documented in Australia [9].</Species>
<Species>The rate of cataract surgery per thousand persons aged 65 years or older has doubled in the last 20 years [8,9].</Species>

<Species>In the Blue Mountains Eye Study population, we observed a one-third increase in cataract surgery prevalence over a mean 6-year interval, from 6% to nearly 8% in two cross-sectional population-based samples with a similar age range [10].</Species>

<Species>Further increases in cataract surgery performance would be expected as a result of improved surgical skills and technique, together with extending cataract surgical benefits to a greater number of older people and an increased number of persons with surgery performed on both eyes.</Species>
<Species>Both the prevalence and incidence of age-related cataract link directly to the demand for, and the outcome of, cataract surgery and eye health care provision.</Species>

<Species>This report aimed to assess temporal changes in the prevalence of cortical and nuclear cataract and posterior subcapsular cataract (PSC) in two cross-sectional population-based surveys 6 years apart.</Species>
<Species>Methods The Blue Mountains Eye Study (BMES) is a population-based cohort study of common eye diseases and other health outcomes.</Species>
<Species>The study involved eligible permanent residents aged 49 years and older, living in two postcode areas in the Blue Mountains, west of Sydney, Australia.</Species>
<Species>Participants were identified through a census and were invited to participate.</Species>

<Species>The study was approved at each stage of the data collection by the Human Ethics Committees of the University of Sydney and the Western Sydney Area Health Service and adhered to the recommendations of the Declaration of Helsinki.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Written informed consent was obtained from each participant.</Species>
<Species>Details of the methods used in this study have been described previously [11].</Species>
<Species>The baseline examinations (BMES cross-section I) were conducted during 1992-1994 and included 3654 (82.4%) of 4433 eligible residents.</Species>
<Species>Follow-up examinations (BMES IIA) were conducted during 1997-1999, with 2335 (75.0% of BMES cross section I survivors) participating.</Species>
<Species>A repeat census of the same area was performed in 1999 and identified 1378 newly eligible residents who moved into the area or the eligible age group.</Species>
<Species>During 1999-2000, 1174 (85.2%) of this group participated in an extension study (BMES IIB).</Species>
<Species>BMES cross-section II thus includes BMES IIA (66.5%) and BMES IIB (33.5%) participants (n = 3509).</Species>
<Species>Similar procedures were used for all stages of data collection at both surveys.</Species>
<Species>A questionnaire was administered including demographic, family and medical history.</Species>

<Species>A detailed eye examination included subjective refraction, slit-lamp (Topcon SL-7e camera, Topcon Optical Co, Tokyo, Japan) and retroillumination (Neitz CT-R camera, Neitz Instrument Co, Tokyo, Japan) photography of the lens.</Species>
<Species>Grading of lens photographs in the BMES has been previously described [12].</Species>
<Species>Briefly, masked grading was performed on the lens photographs using the Wisconsin Cataract Grading System [13].</Species>
<Species>Cortical cataract and PSC were assessed from the retroillumination photographs by estimating the percentage of the circular grid involved.</Species>
<Species>Cortical cataract was defined when cortical opacity involved at least 5% of the total lens area.</Species>
<Species>PSC was defined when opacity comprised at least 1% of the total lens area.</Species>
<Species>Slit-lamp photographs were used to assess nuclear cataract using the Wisconsin standard set of four lens photographs [13].</Species>
<Species>Nuclear cataract was defined when nuclear opacity was at least as great as the standard 4 photograph.</Species>
<Species>Any cataract was defined to include persons who had previous cataract surgery as well as those with any of three cataract types.</Species>
<Species>Inter-grader reliability was high, with weighted kappa 0.82 for cortical cataract, 0.55 (simple kappa 0.75) for nuclear cataract and 0.82 for PSC grading.</Species>
<Species>The intra-grader reliability for nuclear cataract was assessed with simple kappa 0.83 for the senior grader who graded nuclear cataract at both surveys.</Species>
<Species>All PSC cases were confirmed by an ophthalmologist (PM).</Species>

<Species>In cross-section I, 219 persons (6.0%) had missing or ungradable Neitz photographs, leaving 3435 with photographs available for cortical cataract and PSC assessment, while 1153 (31.6%) had randomly missing or ungradable Topcon photographs due to a camera malfunction, leaving 2501 with photographs available for nuclear cataract assessment.</Species>

<Species>Comparison of characteristics between participants with and without Neitz or Topcon photographs in cross-section I showed no statistically significant differences between the two groups, as reported previously [12].</Species>

<Species>In cross-section II, 441 persons (12.5%) had missing or ungradable Neitz photographs, leaving 3068 for cortical cataract and PSC assessment, and 648 (18.5%) had missing or ungradable Topcon photographs, leaving 2860 for nuclear cataract assessment.</Species>
<Species>Data analysis was performed using the Statistical Analysis System (SAS, SAS Institute, Cary, NC, USA).</Species>
<Species>Age-adjusted prevalence was calculated using direct standardization of the cross-section II population to the cross-section I population.</Species>
<Species>We assessed age-specific prevalence using an interval of 5 years, so that participants within each age group were independent between the two cross-sectional surveys.</Species>
<Species>Results Characteristics of the two survey populations have been previously compared [14] and showed that age and sex distributions were similar.</Species>
<Species>Table 1 compares participant characteristics between the two cross-sections.</Species>
<Species>Cross-section II participants generally had higher rates of diabetes, hypertension, myopia and more users of inhaled steroids.</Species>
<Species>Cataract prevalence rates in cross-sections I and II are shown in Figure 1.</Species>
<Species>The overall prevalence of cortical cataract was 23.8% and 23.7% in cross-sections I and II, respectively (age-sex adjusted P = 0.81).</Species>
<Species>Corresponding prevalence of PSC was 6.3% and 6.0% for the two cross-sections (age-sex adjusted P = 0.60).</Species>
<Species>There was an increased prevalence of nuclear cataract, from 18.7% in cross-section I to 23.9% in cross-section II over the 6-year period (age-sex adjusted P < 0.001).</Species>
<Species>Prevalence of any cataract (including persons who had cataract surgery), however, was relatively stable (46.9% and 46.8% in cross-sections I and II, respectively).</Species>
<Species>After age-standardization, these prevalence rates remained stable for cortical cataract (23.8% and 23.5% in the two surveys) and PSC (6.3% and 5.9%).</Species>
<Species>The slightly increased prevalence of nuclear cataract (from 18.7% to 24.2%) was not altered.</Species>
<Species>Table 2 shows the age-specific prevalence rates for cortical cataract, PSC and nuclear cataract in cross-sections I and II.</Species>
<Species>A similar trend of increasing cataract prevalence with increasing age was evident for all three types of cataract in both surveys.</Species>
<Species>Comparing the age-specific prevalence between the two surveys, a reduction in PSC prevalence in cross-section II was observed in the older age groups (> 75 years).</Species>
<Species>In contrast, increased nuclear cataract prevalence in cross-section II was observed in the older age groups (> 70 years).</Species>

<Species>Age-specific cortical cataract prevalence was relatively consistent between the two surveys, except for a reduction in prevalence observed in the 80-84 age group and an increasing prevalence in the older age groups (> 85 years).</Species>
<Species>Similar gender differences in cataract prevalence were observed in both surveys (Table 3).</Species>

<Species>Higher prevalence of cortical and nuclear cataract in women than men was evident but the difference was only significant for cortical cataract (age-adjusted odds ratio, OR, for women 1.3, 95% confidence intervals, CI, 1.1-1.5 in cross-section I and OR 1.4, 95% CI 1.1-1.6 in cross-section II).</Species>

<Species>In contrast, men had slightly higher PSC prevalence than women in both cross-sections but the difference was not significant (OR 1.1, 95% CI 0.8-1.4 for men in cross-section I and OR 1.2, 95% 0.9-1.6 in cross-section II).</Species>

<Species>Discussion Findings from two surveys of BMES cross-sectional populations with similar age and gender distribution showed that the prevalence of cortical cataract and PSC remained stable, while the prevalence of nuclear cataract appeared to have increased.</Species>
<Species>Comparison of age-specific prevalence, with totally independent samples within each age group, confirmed the robustness of our findings from the two survey samples.</Species>

<Species>Although lens photographs taken from the two surveys were graded for nuclear cataract by the same graders, who documented a high inter- and intra-grader reliability, we cannot exclude the possibility that variations in photography, performed by different photographers, may have contributed to the observed difference in nuclear cataract prevalence.</Species>
<Species>However, the overall prevalence of any cataract (including cataract surgery) was relatively stable over the 6-year period.</Species>

<Species>Although different population-based studies used different grading systems to assess cataract [15], the overall prevalence of the three cataract types were similar across different study populations</Species>
<Species>[12,16-23].</Species>
<Species>Most studies have suggested that nuclear cataract is the most prevalent type of cataract, followed by cortical cataract</Species>
<Species>[16-20].</Species>
<Species>Ours and other studies reported that cortical cataract was the most prevalent type [12,21-23].</Species>

<Species>Our age-specific prevalence data show a reduction of 15.9% in cortical cataract prevalence for the 80-84 year age group, concordant with an increase in cataract surgery prevalence by 9% in those aged 80+ years observed in the same study population [10].</Species>
<Species>Although cortical cataract is thought to be the least likely cataract type leading to a cataract surgery, this may not be the case in all older persons.</Species>
<Species>A relatively stable cortical cataract and PSC prevalence over the 6-year period is expected.</Species>
<Species>We cannot offer a definitive explanation for the increase in nuclear cataract prevalence.</Species>

<Species>A possible explanation could be that a moderate level of nuclear cataract causes less visual disturbance than the other two types of cataract, thus for the oldest age groups, persons with nuclear cataract could have been less likely to have surgery unless it is very dense or co-existing with cortical cataract or PSC.</Species>

<Species>Previous studies have shown that functional vision and reading performance were high in patients undergoing cataract surgery who had nuclear cataract only compared to those with mixed type of cataract (nuclear and cortical) or PSC [24,25].</Species>

<Species>In addition, the overall prevalence of any cataract (including cataract surgery) was similar in the two cross-sections, which appears to support our speculation that in the oldest age group, nuclear cataract may have been less likely to be operated than the other two types of cataract.</Species>

<Species>This could have resulted in an increased nuclear cataract prevalence (due to less being operated), compensated by the decreased prevalence of cortical cataract and PSC (due to these being more likely to be operated), leading to stable overall prevalence of any cataract.</Species>
<Species>Possible selection bias arising from selective survival among persons without cataract could have led to underestimation of cataract prevalence in both surveys.</Species>
<Species>We assume that such an underestimation occurred equally in both surveys, and thus should not have influenced our assessment of temporal changes.</Species>
<Species>Measurement error could also have partially contributed to the observed difference in nuclear cataract prevalence.</Species>

<Species>Assessment of nuclear cataract from photographs is a potentially subjective process that can be influenced by variations in photography (light exposure, focus and the slit-lamp angle when the photograph was taken) and grading.</Species>

<Species>Although we used the same Topcon slit-lamp camera and the same two graders who graded photos from both surveys, we are still not able to exclude the possibility of a partial influence from photographic variation on this result.</Species>
<Species>A similar gender difference (women having a higher rate than men) in cortical cataract prevalence was observed in both surveys.</Species>
<Species>Our findings are in keeping with observations from the Beaver Dam Eye Study [18], the Barbados Eye Study [22] and the Lens Opacities Case-Control Group [26].</Species>
<Species>It has been suggested that the difference could be related to hormonal factors [18,22].</Species>
<Species>A previous study on biochemical factors and cataract showed that a lower level of iron was associated with an increased risk of cortical cataract [27].</Species>
<Species>No interaction between sex and biochemical factors were detected and no gender difference was assessed in this study [27].</Species>
<Species>The gender difference seen in cortical cataract could be related to relatively low iron levels and low hemoglobin concentration usually seen in women [28].</Species>
<Species>Diabetes is a known risk factor for cortical cataract but in this particular population diabetes is more prevalent in men than women in all age groups [29].</Species>

<Species>Differential exposures to cataract risk factors or different dietary or lifestyle patterns between men and women may also be related to these observations and warrant further study.</Species>
<Species>Conclusion In summary, in two population-based surveys 6 years apart, we have documented a relatively stable prevalence of cortical cataract and PSC over the period.</Species>
<Species>The observed overall increased nuclear cataract prevalence by 5% over a 6-year period needs confirmation by future studies, and reasons for such an increase deserve further study.</Species>
