<Species>Down-regulation of the M6P/IGF-II receptor increases cell proliferation and reduces apoptosis in neonatal rat cardiac myocytes</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Abstract Background The mannose 6-phosphate/insulin-like growth factor-II receptor (M6P/IGF2R) is a multi-functional protein that has been implicated in regulation of cell growth and apoptosis.</Species>

<Species>Cardiac myocytes express relatively high levels of M6P/IGF2R, and cardiomyocyte apoptosis has been identified in a variety of cardiovascular disorders, such as myocardial infarction and heart failure.</Species>
<Species>However, involvement of M6P/IGF2R in the pathogenesis of these conditions has not been determined.</Species>
<Species>Thus, the objective of this study was to determine the role of M6P/IGF2R in regulation of cardiac myocyte growth and apoptosis.</Species>
<Species>Results We down-regulated the expression of M6P/IGF2R in neonatal rat cardiac myocytes and examined the effect on cell proliferation and apoptosis.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Infection of neonatal cardiomyocytes with an adenovirus expressing a ribozyme targeted against the M6P/IGF2R significantly reduced the level of M6P/IGF2R mRNA, as determined by RT-PCR and Ribonuclease Protection Assay (RPA).</Species>

<Species>M6P-containing protein binding and endocytosis as well as the M6P/IGF2R-mediated internalization of 125I-IGF-II were lower in the ribozyme-treated cells than the control myocytes, indicating that the number of functional M6P/IGF2R in the ribozyme treated cells was reduced.</Species>
<Species>Accordingly, a marked increase in cell proliferation and a reduced cell susceptibility to hypoxia- and TNF-induced apoptosis were observed in the ribozyme-treated cells.</Species>
<Species>Conclusions These findings suggest that M6P/IGF2R may play a role in regulation of cardiac myocyte growth and apoptosis.</Species>
<Species>Down regulation of this gene in cardiac tissues might be a new approach to prevention of cell death or promotion of mitogenesis for certain heart diseases.</Species>

<Species>Background The mannose 6-phosphate/insulin-like growth factor-II receptor (M6P/IGF2R) is a unique protein that interacts with multiple ligands, some of which are important growth regulatory factors [1].</Species>
<Species>The M6P/IGF2R participates in internalization and lysosomal degradation of IGF-II, a mitogen normally acting through the IGF-I receptor to stimulate cell proliferation [2].</Species>
<Species>The M6P/IGF2 receptor is required for the activation of TGF-b [3], a potent growth inhibitor for many cell types.</Species>

<Species>This receptor is also involved in the binding, transport and activation of newly-synthesized lysosomal enzymes, such as cathepsins [4,5], which have been recently implicated in the induction of apoptosis [6].</Species>
<Species>On the basis of these functions, the M6P/IGF2R has been proposed to play a significant role in regulation of cell growth and apoptosis [7].</Species>

<Species>Apoptosis, or programmed cell death, is a tightly regulated process used to remove excess, hazardous or damaged somatic cells, and is crucial for the development, maintenance and survival of an organism.</Species>
<Species>However, alterations in the control of apoptosis have also been shown to contribute to human diseases.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In fact, morphological and biochemical markers of apoptosis have been identified in a wide variety of cardiovascular disorders, including myocardial infarction and heart failure.</Species>
<Species>This suggests that activation of apoptotic pathways contributes to cardiomyocyte loss and subsequent cardiac dysfunction in these conditions.</Species>

<Species>A number of factors involved in cardiomyocyte apoptosis are currently known and include insulin-like growth factor-I (IGF-I), stress-activated protein kinases (SAPKs) and the anti-apoptotic Bcl-2 family</Species>
<Species>[8].</Species>
<Species>There are indications that other factors may be involved in induction and regulation of cardiac apoptosis.</Species>
<Species>However, these potential factors and their corresponding mechanisms have not been identified.</Species>
<Species>Several lines of evidence point to the potential involvement of M6P/IGF2R in cardiac myocyte proliferation and apoptosis.</Species>

<Species>Cardiac myocytes express relatively high levels of M6P/IGF2R and transgenic mice containing a homologous deletion of the M6P/IGF2R gene manifest ventricular hyperplasia due to an increase in cell number [9,10], suggesting that the M6P/IGF2R normally acts to suppress cardiac myocyte cell growth.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>It has also been shown that TGF-b, a potent growth suppressor whose activation requires the binding of latent TGF-b to M6P/IGF2R [3], is commonly upregulated in chronic heart failure [11].</Species>
<Species>Additional evidence for the involvement of M6P/IGF2R in regulation of apoptosis comes from studies of tumorigenesis.</Species>

<Species>It has been shown that M6P/IGF2R expression is significantly reduced in a variety of tumors and loss of heterozygocity (LOH) at the M6P/IGF2R gene locus 6q26 have been found in breast, liver cancers and squamous cell carcinoma of the lung [12-15].</Species>

<Species>Although several studies have examined the effect of M6P/IGF2R over-expression on cell growth [7], it is not known whether down-regulation of this receptor protein leads to cellular protection against apoptosis.</Species>
<Species>Ribozymes are catalytic RNA molecules that cleave a complementary mRNA sequence</Species>
<Species>[16], thereby inactivating specific mRNAs and suppressing gene expression in vitro and in vivo [17,18].</Species>
<Species>Ribozymes have been shown to be highly specific, efficient and stable.</Species>
<Species>They can be packaged into viral vectors to enhance transfer into cells and to achieve longer expression compared with naked oligonucleotides.</Species>
<Species>In the present study, we employed ribozyme technology to study the role of M6P/IGF2R in regulation of cardiac myocyte cell growth.</Species>
<Species>A hammerhead ribozyme against the M6P/IGF2R mRNA was constructed and packaged in an adenoviral vector.</Species>
<Species>We then examined the effect of ribozyme-mediated down-regulation of M6P/IGF2R expression on cell growth and hypoxia- and TNF-induced apoptosis.</Species>

<Species>Results Cleavage reaction of the ribozyme in vitro The M6P/IGF2R ribozyme we constructed has 13-bp binding arms complementary to the target site of M6P/IGF2R mRNA, and a catalytic core (Fig. 1A).</Species>
<Species>To evaluate the bioactivity of the ribozyme and the accessibility of the target site, a cleavage reaction was performed in vitro.</Species>

<Species>The substrates, [a-32P] labeled RNA transcripts containing 45 bp of M6P/IGF2R mRNA or an unmatched sequence, were incubated with the ribozyme as described (see Materials and Methods).</Species>
<Species>The ribozyme cleaved only the specific M6P/IGF2R mRNA into the expected products.</Species>

<Species>In the assay of time course, the hammerhead ribozyme was able to cleave 24.2% of the M6P/IGF2R target within 10 minutes of incubation, 50.3% of the M6P/IGF2R target within 40 minutes of incubation, and by 640 minutes, 80.8% of the M6P/IGF2R target was converted to the expected products (Fig. 1B).</Species>
<Species>This ribozyme did not digest the unmatched sequence (Fig. 1B).</Species>
<Species>These results indicate a high efficiency and specificity of the ribozyme in vitro.</Species>

<Species>Ribozymes down-regulate M6P/IGF2R expression in cardiac myocytes To examine the ability of the ribozyme to reduce levels of M6P/IGF2R mRNA in cultured cardiac myocytes, total RNA was extracted from cells infected with Ad-GFP/IGF2R-Rz or Ad-GFP, and subjected to RT-PCR using M6P/IGF2R-specific primers.</Species>
<Species>Primers specific for b-actin were added to a parallel reaction to serve as an internal standard.</Species>
<Species>Cells were used 4 days after infection, with average infection efficiency of 70-80% (for which a viral dose used had minimal cytotoxicity).</Species>
<Species>The RT-PCR product of M6P/IGF2R was 856 bp, and the b-actin product was 285 bp.</Species>
<Species>As shown in Fig. 2A, the Ad-GFP/IGF2R-Rz-infected cells exhibited a significantly lower level of M6P/IGF2R mRNA than Ad-GFP-infected cells, with a reduction of about 50%.</Species>
<Species>This result was confirmed by ribonuclease protection assay (RPA), in which GAPDH was used as a control (Fig. 2C &2D).</Species>

<Species>There was no significant difference in the level of M6P/IGF2R mRNA between Ad-GFP-infected cells and uninfected cells (data not shown), indicating that infection with the adenovirus itself did not alter the endogenous M6P/IGF2R mRNA level.</Species>
<Species>The results demonstrated that the ribozyme was highly effective in suppressing M6P/IGF2R expression in cultured cardiac myocytes.</Species>

<Species>Effect of ribozyme expression on the functional activity of M6P/IGF2R To determine the effect of the ribozyme on the functional activity of M6P/IGF2R, binding and internalization of exogenous 125I-IGF-II was measured in cells infected with Ad-GFP/IGF2R-Rz.</Species>
<Species>As shown in Fig. 3A, cells infected with Ad-GFP/IGF2R-Rz showed a 54% reduction in 125I-IGF-II internalization when compared with the control cells (infected with Ad-GFP).</Species>
<Species>We also examined the effect of the ribozyme on the M6P-binding activity of the M6P/IGF2R using the M6P-bearing lysosomal enzyme, b-glucuronidase, as a probe.</Species>
<Species>The results showed that the maximal M6P-binding capacity of cells treated with the ribozyme was about 50% less than that of controls (Fig. 3B).</Species>
<Species>Furthermore, we assessed the ability of cells to internalize exogenous b-glucuronidase after treatment with ribozyme.</Species>
<Species>Similarly, the M6P-inhibitable endocytosis of b-glucuronidase by ribozyme-treated cells was about 52% less than that of control cells (Fig. 3C).</Species>
<Species>These results confirm that the number of functional M6P/IGF2R in ribozyme-treated cells was reduced.</Species>
<Species>Adenoviral delivery of ribozymes increases the proliferation of cardiac myocytes We examined the effects of the ribozyme on the growth of cultured neonatal rat cardiac myocytes.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Morphological evaluation showed a remarkable difference in growth pattern between Ad-GFP/IGF2R-Rz-infected cells and the control cells: the ribozyme-expressing cells formed larger and more spread colonies (Fig. 4).</Species>

<Species>Assessment of cell proliferative activity by the MTT assay and counts of viable cells showed that the number of cardiac myocytes in ribozyme-expressing cultures was significantly higher than in control cultures (Fig. 5).</Species>
<Species>These results indicate that treatment with M6P/IGF2R-ribozyme can promote cardiac myocyte proliferation.</Species>

<Species>Effect of M6P/IGF2R-ribozyme expression on apoptosis of cardiac myocytes We examined the effects of ribozyme expression on TNF-a and hypoxia-induced apoptosis of cultured cardiac myocytes.</Species>

<Species>After a 24 hr challenge with hypoxia, the number of apoptotic cells in M6P/IGF2R-Rz expressing cultures was 38% lower than in control cultures as determined by Hoechst staining (which highlights the nuclei of apoptotic cells) and ELISA (Fig. 6A, 7A).</Species>
<Species>MTT analysis showed that the number of viable cells in ribozyme-treated cultures was 40% higher than in control cultures (Fig. 7A).</Species>

<Species>After treatment with TNF-a, as shown in Fig. 6B, a large number of control cells underwent apoptosis, as indicated by morphological changes (small round shape) and bright blue nuclear staining.</Species>
<Species>There were significantly more apoptotic cells in control cultures than in cultures expressing the Ad-GFP/IGF2R-Rz.</Species>

<Species>The number of apoptotic cells, as measured by the cell death ELISA assay, in cultures infected with Ad-GFP/IGF2R-Rz was significantly (about 40%) lower than in cultures infected with Ad-GFP (Fig. 7B).</Species>

<Species>Accordingly, the number of viable cells, as measured by MTT analysis, in cultures infected with Ad-GFP/IGF2R-Rz was significantly (about 45%) higher than in cultures infected with Ad-GFP (Fig. 7B).</Species>
<Species>These results are consistent with the hypothesis that decreasing M6P/IGF2R expression by ribozyme treatment can reduce cell apoptosis.</Species>
<Species>Discussion Some 62,000,000 Americans have one or more types of cardiovascular disease (CVD) and CVD is the leading cause (40.1%) of death in the United States.</Species>

<Species>Myocardial infarction and heart failure, conditions accompanied by cardiac myocyte apoptosis, represent 23% of all CVDs and are a growing clinical challenge in need of novel therapeutic strategies.</Species>
<Species>In this study, we investigated the M6P/IGF2R as a potential new therapeutic target for reduction of cardiac apoptosis and cardiac injury in these conditions.</Species>
<Species>Using ribozyme technology we down-regulated the expression of the M6P/IGF2R in neonatal cardiac myocytes.</Species>

<Species>We then examined cell proliferation and apoptosis under normal conditions and post challenge with either hypoxia, a model of ischemia-reperfusion, or TNF-a, a cytokine implicated in the pathogenesis of chronic heart failure [19].</Species>

<Species>Our results demonstrate an association of a decrease in the expression and function of the M6P/IGF2R with increased cell proliferation and decreased cell susceptibility to hypoxia- and TNF-induced apoptosis.</Species>

<Species>Expression of the ribozyme targeted against the M6P/IGF2R in cardiomyocytes resulted in down-regulation of M6P/IGF2R expression, as measured by RT-PCR and RPA, and of M6P/IGF2R function, as indicated by a decrease in internalization of 125I-IGF-II, and b-glucuronidase binding and endocytosis.</Species>

<Species>MTT analysis and viable cell counts showed that ribozyme-mediated down-regulation of M6P/IGF2R resulted in a marked increase in cell proliferation of cardiomyocytes, which normally express high levels of M6P/IGF2R [20] and have limited proliferative capabilities [21].</Species>
<Species>These results are consistent with the findings of previous knockout studies [9,10].</Species>
<Species>Since the M6P/IGF2R has multiple actions on cell growth, its proliferative effect on the heart cells observed in this study might involve multiple mechanisms.</Species>
<Species>However, it is likely that unchecked IGF-II stimulation plays a key role in the effect.</Species>

<Species>Because the M6P/IGF2R is believed to sequester and degrade IGF-II [2], a decrease in M6P/IGF2R expression and function could result in decreased degradation and hence increased bioavailability of IGF-II to the IGF-I receptor, which mediates the growth-promoting effect of IGF-II.</Species>
<Species>Supporting evidence for the involvement of IGF-II in the proliferative effect resulting from loss of M6P/IGF2R function comes from studies of M6P/IGF2R knock-out mice.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>M6P/IGF2R-null mice display global hyperplasia that coincides with elevated levels of IGF-II.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Most importantly, however, the lethal nature of an M6P/IGF2R-null phenotype is reversed in an IGF-II-null background [9].</Species>
<Species>Our results showing that ribozyme-mediated down-regulation of M6P/IGF2R lead to a decrease in IGF-II internalization support the above possibility.</Species>
<Species>However, further investigation to confirm this mechanism is warranted.</Species>
<Species>More importantly, our results also showed that M6P/IGF2R down-regulation resulted in decreased sensitivity of cardiomyocytes to hypoxia- and TNF-induced apoptosis.</Species>
<Species>There is evidence that lysosomal enzymes, such as cathepsins B and D contribute to hypoxia- and TNF-induced apoptosis in vitro [22-25] and in vivo [26,27].</Species>
<Species>The M6P/IGF2R has been shown to be involved in binding, transport and activation of lysosomal enzymes, including cathepsins [4,5].</Species>
<Species>Therefore, it is possible that down-regulation of the M6P/IGF2R results in improper trafficking and activation of cathepsins.</Species>

<Species>This, in turn would eliminate the apoptotic cascades triggered by these enzymes under hypoxia and TNF stimulation and result in decreased sensitivity of cardiomyocytes to apoptosis.</Species>

<Species>It has also been shown that TNF stimulation involves the activation of TGF-b [28-30], a ligand of M6P/IGF2R that has been implicated in the progression of chronic heart failure [11,31].</Species>

<Species>Therefore, down-regulation of M6P/IGF2R expression could also lead to a decreased bioavailability of activated TGF-b, thereby decreasing the sensitivity of cardiomyocytes to the TNF/TGF-b apoptotic pathway.</Species>
<Species>The detailed mechanism of the observed effects is unknown and requires further investigation.</Species>

<Species>Conclusions The present study demonstrates that ribozyme-mediated down-regulation of expression and functional activity of the M6P/IGF2R results in a decrease in the susceptibility of cardiac myocytes to apoptotic stimuli.</Species>
<Species>These findings suggest that this receptor might be involved in cardiac cell growth and apoptosis.</Species>

<Species>The ability of the M6P/IGF2R ribozyme to reduce M6P/IGF2R expression and function in transfected cells verifies the utility of the ribozyme in studying the role of M6P/IGF2R in cardiomyocyte growth and apoptosis.</Species>

<Species>In addition to its utility as a research tool, the ribozyme, with further exploration and development, might have potential application as a therapeutic agent to prevent cell death or promote mitogenesis for certain clinical conditions, such as, myocardial infarction and chronic heart failure.</Species>

<Species>Methods Construction of recombinant M6P/IGF2R-RZ adenoviral vector The nucleotide numbers of the rat M6P/IGF2R sequence targeted by the hammerhead ribozyme is 1147-1160 after coding site (exon 9).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The structure of the M6P/IGF2R hammerhead ribozyme is shown in Fig.</Species>
<Species>1.</Species>
<Species>A 49 bp M6P/IGF2R ribozyme oligonucleotide, 5'-GAATTCCCC ACACTG ATGAGCCGCTTCGGCGGCGAAACATTCAAC GCGT-3' and the corresponding reverse complementary strand were synthesized.</Species>

<Species>The fragments were subcloned to produce a plasmid containing a ribozyme against M6P/IGF2R. For construction of the recombinant adenovirus containing the M6P/IGF2R-ribozyme (pAd-GFP/IGF2R-Rz), the segments containing the ribozymes were amplified by PCR and cloned into a pAdTrack-CMV vector and then recombined homologously with an adenoviral backbone pAdEasy 1 vector to generate (pAd-GFP/IGF2R-Rz), following the protocol described by He et al.</Species>
<Species>[32].</Species>
<Species>The pAd-GFP/IGF2R-Rz carries both the IGF2R-Rz and GFP (as reporter) genes, each under the control of separate cytomegalovirus (CMV) promoters.</Species>
<Species>Another viral vector, pAd-GFP, which carries the GFP gene only under the control of the CMV promoter, was generated and used as a control vector.</Species>

<Species>The adenoviral vector DNA were linerized with Pac I and transfected into the replication-permissive 293 cells (E1A transcomplementing cell line) by using Lipofectamine (Life Technologies) to produce E1-deleted, replication-defective recombinant adenovirus as described previously [33].</Species>
<Species>Large-scale amplification of recombinant adenovirus in 293 cells was followed by purification using a discontinuous CsCl gradient.</Species>
<Species>The constructs were confirmed by enzymatic digestion and DNA sequencing.</Species>

<Species>Transcription and cleavage reaction of ribozyme in vitro Plasmids containing the ribozyme or the substrate (either 45 bp of M6P/IGF2R mRNA or an unmatched sequence 5'-GTGCTGTCTGTATG-3') were linearized with MluI, respectively.</Species>
<Species>All transcripts were generated with T7 RNA polymerase (Promega).</Species>
<Species>Substrate transcripts were labeled by incorporation of [a-32P] UTP (NEN Life Science Products, Inc.).</Species>
<Species>Specific activity of the [a-32P] UTP (10 uCi/ul) and the base composition of each substrate molecule were used to calculate the substrate concentration.</Species>
<Species>Ribozyme transcripts were quantified spectrophotometrically.</Species>
<Species>(The half-life of the M6P/IGF2R target is about 280 minutes).</Species>
<Species>Cleavage reaction mixture contained substrate RNA (40 nM), increasing amounts of ribozyme (60 nM), 20 mM MgCl2 and 20 mM Tris-HCl, pH8.0, in a final volume of 10 ul.</Species>

<Species>The mixture was incubated at 37oC for a time-course of cleavage reaction from 0, 5, 10, 20, 40, 80, 160, 320, to 640 minutes and the cleavage reaction was stopped by addition of loading buffer (80% formamide, 10 mM Na2EDTA, pH 8.0, and 1 mg/ml each bromophenol blue and xylene cyanol).</Species>
<Species>Cleavage products were analyzed on a 15% polyacrylamide and 8M urea gel.</Species>
<Species>Product and substrate fragments were quantitated by using NIH Imager.</Species>

<Species>Cell cultures and infection with Ad-GFP/Rz-IGF2R and Ad-GFP Cardiac myocytes were isolated from 1-day-old newborn rats using the Neonatal Cardiomyocyte Isolation System (Worthington).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The isolated cells were plated in 6-well plates and cultured in F-10 medium containing 5% (vol/vol) FBS and 10% (vol/vol) horse serum at 37oC in a tissue culture incubator with 5% CO2 and 98% relative humidity.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Cells were used for experiments after 2-3 days of culture.</Species>
<Species>Viral infections were carried out by adding viral particles at various concentrations (usually, 2 x 108 virus particles/ml) to culture medium containing 2% (vol/vol) FBS.</Species>
<Species>Initially, optimal viral concentration was determined by using Ad-GFP to achieve an optimal balance of high gene expression and low viral titer to minimize cytotoxicity.</Species>
<Species>After 24 hours of incubation, the infection medium was replaced with normal (15% vol/vol serum) culture medium.</Species>
<Species>For treatment with IGF-II, cells were incubated with 50 ng/ml IGF-II after 24 hours infection with Ad-GFP/IGF2R-Rz or Ad-GFP.</Species>
<Species>Four days after infection, cells were used for analysis of gene expression of M6P/IGF2R and its effect on cell growth and apoptosis.</Species>
<Species>Analysis of gene expression in cardiac myocytes The M6P/IGF2R transcripts were determined by both RT-PCR and Ribonuclease Protection Assay (RPA).</Species>
<Species>RT-PCR was performed using the GeneAmp EZ rTth RNA PCR kit (Roche).</Species>
<Species>Total RNA was extracted from cultured cells using an RNA isolation kit (Qiagen,), according to the manufacturer's protocol.</Species>

<Species>M6P/IGF2R transcripts were amplified using the primers (5'-GACAGGCTCGTTCTGACTTA-3') and (5'-CTTCCACTCTTATCCACAGC-3') specific to the M6P/IGF2R. Each RT-PCR assay was performed in triplicate and product levels varied by less than 3.2% for each RNA sample.</Species>
<Species>Primers specific for b-actin cDNA were added to a parallel reaction to standardize for variations in PCR between samples.</Species>
<Species>PCR products were resolved on a 1.0% agarose gel, visualized under UV light and quantitated using NIH Imager.</Species>
<Species>RPA was performed using the RPA III kit (Ambion, Austin, TX).</Species>
<Species>Briefly, total RNA was extracted from cultured cells using a total RNA isolation reagent (TRIzol, Gibco BRL) according to the manufacturer's protocol.</Species>
<Species>The plasmid containing the rat M6P/IGF2R gene was linearized and used as a transcription template.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Antisense RNA probes were transcribed in vitro using [33P]-UTP, T7 polymerase (Riboprobea System T7 kit, Promega), hybridized with the total RNA extracted from the rat cardiomyocytes, and digested with ribonuclease to remove non-hybridized RNA and probe.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The protected RNA.RNA was resolved on a denaturing 5% sequence gel and subjected to autoradiography.</Species>
<Species>A probe targeting the GAPDH gene was used as an internal control.</Species>

<Species>Measurement of 125I-IGF-II internalization Cells were incubated at 37oC for 2 hrs in serum-free F-10 culture medium containing 125I-labeled IGF-II (0.5 ng/ml) with or without excess unlabeled IGF-II (2 ug/ml).</Species>
<Species>Following the incubation, the cells were washed three times with ice-cold PBS, and cell-associated radioactivity was determined by a g counter.</Species>

<Species>Specific internalized 125I-IGF-II was calculated by subtracting the count of samples with excessive unlabeled IGF-II from that without unlabeled IGF-II, and normalized to protein contents.</Species>
<Species>Beta-glucuronidase binding assay Binding of b-glucuronidase was assayed as described previously [34,35].</Species>

<Species>Briefly, cells were permeabilized with 0.25% saponin in 50 mM Hepes (pH 7.0), 150 mM NaCl, 5 mM b-glycerophosphate, 0.5% human serum albumin, and 10 mM mannose-6-phosphate (M6P) for 30 minutes on ice.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The cells were washed three times with ice-cold PBS containing 0.05% saponin.</Species>

<Species>They were incubated with 20,000 units/ml b-glucuronidase from bovine liver (Sigma) in 50 mM Hepes (pH 7.5) containing 150 mM NaCl, 5 mM b-glycerophosphate, 0.5% human serum albumin, 0.5% saponin with or without 10 mM M6P overnight on ice.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Cells were washed five times with ice-cold PBS containing 0.05% saponin and sonicated in 100 mM sodium acetate (pH 4.6).</Species>

<Species>The protein concentration of solubilized cell extract was measured and enzyme activity was assayed as follows: for each reaction 50 ul cell extract were added to 500 ul of 100 mM sodium acetate (pH 4.0) containing 1 mM paranitrophenyl (PNP)-b-glucuronide (Sigma) as substrate.</Species>
<Species>After an incubation period of 3 hours at 37oC, 500 ul 1 M Na2CO3 were added to each reaction and the absorbance was measured at 400 nm.</Species>
<Species>Experimental values were compared to a standard curve that was constructed using 1-100 nM solutions of PNP (Sigma) in 500 ul 100 mM sodium acetate and 500 u1 1 M Na2CO3.</Species>
<Species>Specific activity was calculated as nM of PNP produced/hour/mg of protein.</Species>
<Species>Beta-glucuronidase endocytosis assay Beta-glucuronidase endocytosis assay was carried out as described previously [36].</Species>

<Species>Briefly, confluent cell cultures were washed twice with pre-warmed serum-free DMEM followed by incubation with DMEM containing 5 mg/ml human serum albumin and 10 mM M6P for 20 minutes.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Following incubation cells were washed 3 times with pre-warmed DMEM.</Species>

<Species>Cells were then incubated in DMEM containing 5 mg/ml human serum albumin alone or 4000 units b-glucuronidase with or without 10 mM M6P for 2 hours at 37oC. Following the incubation, the cells were washed 5 times with ice-cold PBS and subjected to enzyme activity assay as described above.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Cell proliferation assay (MTT assay and cell counts)</Species>

<Species>Cardiac myocytes were grown in culture plates (tissue culture grade, 12 wells, flat bottom) in a final volume of 1 ml serum-containing culture medium per well, in a humidified atmosphere (37oC and 5% C02) for 3 days.</Species>
<Species>After infection with Ad-GFP/IGF2R-Rz or Ad-GFP, cells were incubated with or without 50 ng/ml IGF-II for 4 days.</Species>

<Species>Following supplementation with IGF-II, 100 ul MTT labeling reagent (Roche) were added to each well and cells were incubated for 4 hours, followed by addition of 1 ml solubilization solution into each well.</Species>
<Species>The plate was placed in an incubator at 37oC overnight.</Species>
<Species>Spectrophotometrical absorbency of the samples was measured using an UV-visible Recording Spectrophotometer with wavelength of 550-690 nm.</Species>
<Species>In addition, the total number of viable cells in each treatment was counted by trypan blue exclusion method using a hemocytometer.</Species>

<Species>Induction and analysis of cell apoptosis Cells were infected with Ad-GFP or Ad-GFP/IGF2R-Rz. Seventy-two hours post infection, cells were treated with TNF (0.1 ng/ml) for 24 hrs or subjected to hypoxia.</Species>

<Species>For induction of apoptosis by hypoxia, cell culture medium was changed to serum-free F-10 saturated with 95% N2/5% CO2 and cells were placed in a 37oC airtight box saturated with 95% N2/5% CO2 for 24 hrs.</Species>
<Species>For normoxic controls, culture medium was changed to F-10/5%F BS/10% HS and cells were placed in a 37oC/5% CO2 incubator for 24 hrs before analysis.</Species>
<Species>Apoptotic cells were identified by Hoechst staining using the Vybrant  Apoptosis Kit #5 (Molecular Probes) according to the manufacturer's protocol.</Species>

<Species>In addition, after infection with Ad-GFP or Ad-GFP/IGF2R-Rz and challenge with either TNF or hypoxia, cell viability was assessed using the MTT assay Kit (Roche Molecular Biochemicals) and cell apoptosis was determined using the Cell Death Detection ELISA Kit assay (Roche Molecular Biochemicals) according to the manufacturer's protocol.</Species>
<Species>Statistical analysis Students' t-test was used to evaluate the difference between two values.</Species>
<Species>Each experiment was repeated at least three times.</Species>
<Species>Statistical significance was accepted at the level of p < 0.05.</Species>

<Species>List of abbreviations used Ad-GFP, adenovirus carrying GFP gene; Ad-GFP/IGF2R-Rz, adenovirus carrying both the ribozyme against M6P/IGF2R and the GFP gene; GFP, green fluorescent protein; IGF-II, insulin-like growth factor II; M6P/IGF2R, mannose 6-phosphate/insulin-like growth factor II receptor; Rz, ribozyme.</Species>
<Species>Authors' contributions ZC carried out construction of the ribozyme, production of the viruses, cellular experiments, biochemical assays and data analysis.</Species>
<Species>YG carried out the RPA assay and participated in the molecular biological studies.</Species>
<Species>JXK conceived of the study, participated in its design and coordination, and drafted the manuscript.</Species>

<Species>Drug information resources used by nurse practitioners and collaborating physicians at the point of care in Nova Scotia, Canada: a survey and review of the literature</Species>
<Species>Abstract Background Keeping current with drug therapy information is challenging for health care practitioners.</Species>
<Species>Technologies are often implemented to facilitate access to current and credible drug information sources.</Species>
<Species>In the Canadian province of Nova Scotia, legislation was passed in 2002 to allow nurse practitioners (NPs) to practice collaboratively with physician partners.</Species>
<Species>The purpose of this study was to determine the current utilization patterns of information technologies by these groups of practitioners.</Species>

<Species>Methods Nurse practitioners and their collaborating physician partners in Nova Scotia were sent a survey in February 2005 to determine the frequency of use, usefulness, accessibility, credibility, and current/timeliness of personal digital assistant (PDA), computer, and print drug information resources.</Species>
<Species>Two surveys were developed (one for PDA users and one for computer users) and revised based on a literature search, stakeholder consultation, and pilot-testing results.</Species>
<Species>A second distribution to nonresponders occurred two weeks following the first.</Species>
<Species>Data were entered and analysed with SPSS.</Species>
<Species>Results Twenty-seven (14 NPs and 13 physicians) of 36 (75%) recipients responded.</Species>
<Species>22% (6) returned personal digital assistant (PDA) surveys.</Species>
<Species>Respondents reported print, health professionals, and online/electronic resources as the most to least preferred means to access drug information, respectively.</Species>

<Species>37% and 35% of respondents reported using "both print and electronic but print more than electronic" and "print only", respectively, to search monograph-related drug information queries whereas 4% reported using "PDA only".</Species>

<Species>Analysis of respondent ratings for all resources in the categories print, health professionals and other, and online/electronic resources, indicated that the Compendium of Pharmaceuticals and Specialties and pharmacists ranked highly for frequency of use, usefulness, accessibility, credibility, and current/timeliness by both groups of practitioners.</Species>
<Species>Respondents' preferences and resource ratings were consistent with self-reported methods for conducting drug information queries.</Species>
<Species>Few differences existed between NP and physician rankings of resources.</Species>
<Species>Conclusion The use of computers and PDAs remains limited, which is also consistent with preferred and frequent use of print resources.</Species>
<Species>Education for these practitioners regarding available electronic drug information resources may facilitate future computer and PDA use.</Species>
<Species>Further research is needed to determine methods to increase computer and PDA use and whether these technologies affect prescribing and patient outcomes.</Species>
<Species>Background Challenges with knowledge management for health care professionals In 1986, Haynes et al.</Species>

<Species>published a series of 6 articles entitled "how to keep up with the medical literature" in an effort to help clinicians with information management, but this challenge has not decreased in last two decades</Species>
<Species>[1-6].</Species>
<Species>Alper et al.</Species>

<Species>suggest that maintaining currency with relevant literature in primary care would "require 627.5 hours per month, or about 29 hours per weekday, or 3.6 full-time equivalents of physician effort" [7].</Species>
<Species>The volume of information associated with keeping up to date is frequently cited as a barrier [8].</Species>
<Species>It is estimated that annually there are approximately 10,000 new randomized trials in MEDLINE and over 450,000 clinical trials identified by the Cochrane Collaboration [9,10].</Species>

<Species>Keeping up to date has been described with several analogies including clinicians attempting to drink water from a fire hose and swimming in rivers of clinical research with unprecedented depth, velocity, and turbulence [11,12].</Species>

<Species>Difficulties with dissemination of research evidence and keeping up to date on pharmacotherapeutic interventions are reported despite the development of tools such as clinical practice guidelines and systematic reviews that are intended to reduce the need for practitioners to evaluate original research [13].</Species>
<Species>To complicate matters further, there are often issues of credibility, timeliness, and volume of clinical practice guidelines and reviews.</Species>
<Species>Many guidelines are criticized for their methodological development.</Species>
<Species>Shaneyfelt et al. reviewed 279 guidelines for methodological standards from peer reviewed medical literature [14].</Species>

<Species>These authors found that only 51%, 33.6%, and 46% adhered to standards on guideline development and format, evidence identification and summary, and formulation of recommendations, respectively [14].</Species>
<Species>A Canadian review on drug therapy guidelines found significant variation in quality depending on the developer [13].</Species>
<Species>Approximately 25% of guidelines were not recommended for use in practice by the appraisers' criteria [13].</Species>
<Species>As an example of the volume of clinical practice guidelines available, eleven recent guidelines on community acquired pneumonia exist [15].</Species>

<Species>To add to the complexities involved with keeping current with pharmacotherapeutic management strategies, as of 2000, there were over 22,000 drug products approved for sale in Canada for human use [16].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>There is also considerable debate regarding what constitutes "evidence" in practice, which contributes to confusion for clinicians [17,18].</Species>

<Species>Sim et al. succinctly describe the gap between evidence and action as difficulties with obtaining, systematically reviewing, applying in context, and measuring the outcome following application of evidence [19].</Species>

<Species>Maintaining competence - nurse practitioners as a new group of prescribers Competencies for nurse practitioners (NPs) on a local and international level include critically appraising and applying literature and research findings in practice [20-23].</Species>

<Species>The Canadian Nurses Association (CNA) has developed the Canadian Nurse Practitioner Core Competency Framework that describes the knowledge, skills, judgment, and attributes required for practice.</Species>
<Species>Evidence based practice is integral to pharmacotherapeutic interventions and prescribing competencies [23].</Species>

<Species>The National Prescribing Centre, an organization of the National Health Service in the UK, describes several competencies around information needs relevant to prescribing and emphasis is placed on using relevant and up to date information in various formats (e.g. print, electronic, verbal).</Species>
<Species>Several related competencies include understanding advantages and disadvantages of information sources and the currency of resources [21].</Species>
<Species>Researchers in the US developed NP informatics competencies for integration into advanced nursing practice curricula [24].</Species>

<Species>Competencies related to informatics knowledge include critical analysis of data and information for use in evidence based practice, evaluating and applying relevant information, synthesizing best evidence, and using optimal search strategies to locate clinically sound and useful studies from information resources [24].</Species>
<Species>Achieving and maintaining competence in these domains as well as a solid foundation in pharmacology is necessary to support NPs in their relatively new role as a prescriber</Species>
<Species>[25-27].</Species>
<Species>Knowledge management and information seeking behaviours among nurse practitioners and physicians Information seeking behaviours of physicians are better documented than NPs [11].</Species>
<Species>Information related to diagnosis is important to both groups but drug therapy queries may occur more frequently with NPs</Species>
<Species>[28-33].</Species>
<Species>Research on nurses' behaviours related to information seeking is available from the hospital setting</Species>
<Species>[33-35] but the generalizability of these behaviours to NPs with a prescribing role is unclear.</Species>
<Species>Differences in nursing roles, responsibilities, and legislation, including prescriptive authority, exist depending on the country of practice.</Species>
<Species>Nurse practitioners and their collaborating physician partners in Nova Scotia Nova Scotia is a Canadian province with a population of approximately 942,000 [36].</Species>
<Species>The province is divided into six health zones that include nine district health authorities, one of which includes the provincial capital and is considered to be urban [37,38].</Species>
<Species>Health care service delivery is challenging due to many factors including the rural nature of the province, which is estimated to be 60% of population [37,39].</Species>
<Species>Starting in 1998, the Nova Scotia Department of Health led an initiative to explore different methods of delivering, managing, and funding primary care services.</Species>

<Species>The Strengthening Primary Care in Nova Scotia Communities Initiative (SPCI) was established with the selection of four primary care demonstration sites where a primary health care NP was hired to practice collaboratively with one or more family/general physicians and other members of an interdisciplinary team.</Species>
<Species>Each demonstration site adopted alternative (non fee-for-service) physician payment mechanisms and used electronic patient records (EPRs) to support service delivery [41].</Species>

<Species>Demonstration sites participated in project evaluation components that included, but were not limited to, NP roles, alternative fee structures, consumer satisfaction, and implementation and integration of EPRs</Species>
<Species>[41,42].</Species>
<Species>Legislation to allow NPs to practice collaboratively with physicians in Nova Scotia was passed in 2002, part way through the SPCI project [39].</Species>
<Species>Prescriptive authority granted through legislation authorizes NPs to prescribe from a schedule of drugs [43,44].</Species>
<Species>At the time of conducting this research project, 16 primary health care NPs were in active practice [43].</Species>
<Species>The EPR component of the SPCI project evaluation provided information on the use of technologies in the community context.</Species>
<Species>Results from the implementation process indicated that considerable attention is required for technology literacy, time for training, and selection of software for EPRs [41].</Species>

<Species>Although the majority of community-based, non-institutional clinical practice settings in Nova Scotia primarily operate with paper-based charting systems, there is a movement toward integrating electronic technologies, including the EPR, in practice among health care providers, administrators, and the provincial government.</Species>
<Species>In addition to recording patient visit information, a component of the EPR package serves to provide drug information resources.</Species>
<Species>Drug therapy information resources for NPs and nurse prescribers have frequently been described as essential in supporting practice [25,28,29].</Species>

<Species>The role of NPs is relatively new in Canada [39] and there is limited information available to indicate the type of resources (e.g. print, electronic, EPR based) these prescribers use for drug and therapeutic information queries at the point of care.</Species>
<Species>It is unknown as to whether differences exist regarding types of resources used, drug information needs, and utilization patterns among NPs and collaborating physician partners.</Species>

<Species>Some research has suggested that the degree of multidisciplinary team functioning relates to the adoption of technology or innovations in practice but more research is required to determine the extent of these relationships [45,46].</Species>

<Species>The use of EPR technology is increasing in Nova Scotia but little information is available regarding the readiness of practitioners for use of specific features such as drug information resources.</Species>
<Species>Based on the EPR related results of the SPCI evaluation, use of these functions could be challenging without proper facilitation.</Species>
<Species>The purpose of the survey for this research was to describe drug information resources used by NPs and their collaborating physician partners at the point of care.</Species>

<Species>The results of the survey will be used to guide further technology implementation strategies and stimulate further discussion around drug information resource usage at the point of care.</Species>
<Species>Methods Survey development Survey development involved three stages including identification of important content areas, development of draft questions, and survey refinement.</Species>

<Species>Identifying important content areas for inclusion in the survey involved conducting a comprehensive English language literature search, consultation with relevant stakeholders (e.g. members of the Nova Scotia Department of Health), and input from subject matter experts at Dalhousie University.</Species>

<Species>The literature review was conducted using the following bibliographic databases: PubMed, Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature (CINAHL), International Pharmaceutical Abstracts (IPA), and Web of Science Citation Databases.</Species>
<Species>Hand and electronic searching of relevant journals was also conducted.</Species>

<Species>Broad search terms were used without limits on publication date or place as nurse practitioner titles, roles and scopes of practice, and terminology regarding technology vary nationally and internationally.</Species>

<Species>Some examples of terms used included nurse practitioner, nurse prescriber, nurse clinicians, district nurse, health visitor, drug information resources, drug information services, information needs, and information technology.</Species>
<Species>The draft survey was reviewed by the research team to reduce the number of items and improve clarity.</Species>
<Species>The layout of the questionnaire was carefully examined to ensure that it was easy to follow and complete.</Species>
<Species>Research results from a previous investigation of Nova Scotian physicians' behaviours regarding drug information were also used to further revise the survey [47].</Species>
<Species>This draft questionnaire was pilot tested by two out of province NPs and one physician.</Species>
<Species>The results of the pilot were used to make final revisions to the survey.</Species>
<Species>Based on pilot-testing feedback and investigator consensus, the final survey was divided into 2 versions, one for personal digital assistant (PDA) users and one for computer users.</Species>
<Species>The 10 page surveys for PDA and computer users had 5 or 6 sections, respectively, and 37 questions, many with multiple parts.</Species>

<Species>The survey content included demographics, computer or PDA use and experience, drug and therapeutic resource use and preferences, PDA future use, perceived barriers and facilitators to PDA use, and technology training preferences.</Species>
<Species>Section one contained demographic questions such as gender, age, job title, volume of patients, and EPR availability in the practice setting.</Species>
<Species>Section two was designed to determine PDA or computer use and experience in the practice setting with questions regarding length of use, costs, and work versus home usage.</Species>
<Species>This section also addressed usage and rating of different drug information resources.</Species>
<Species>Resource ratings were based on the frequency of usage, usefulness, accessibility, credibility, and current/timeliness.</Species>
<Species>Resources were grouped as print (i.e. books, journals, and clinical practice guidelines), online/electronic resources, and health professionals and other.</Species>
<Species>Respondents used 5-point Likert scales (strongly agree to strongly disagree) for rating opinions related to resources.</Species>
<Species>A rating of 6 (not applicable, I do not use this resource) was also included for respondents who did not use a particular resource.</Species>
<Species>Frequency of searching for specific information was rated on a 3-point Likert scale (frequently to never).</Species>

<Species>The final sections of the survey included categorical, open-ended, and Likert scale questions regarding preferred resources, technology barriers, PDA future use, and technology training preferences.</Species>

<Species>Copies of the surveys are attached as an appendix in PDF format [see additional file 1 and 2] or can also be accessed from the Initiative for Medication Management, Policy Analysis, Research & Training (IMPART) website [48].</Species>
<Species>Ethics approval for the survey was granted through Dalhousie University Research Ethics Board on February 3, 2005.</Species>
<Species>Survey population Licensed, actively practicing, primary health care NPs (n = 16) and their collaborating physician partners (n = 21) were eligible to participate.</Species>
<Species>Survey procedures The survey recruitment procedures were based on the methods of Dillman [49] and</Species>
<Species>Salant and Dillman</Species>
<Species>[50].</Species>
<Species>Survey packages contained a cover letter, separate surveys for PDA and computer users, and a return self-addressed stamped envelope.</Species>
<Species>The covering letter instructed respondents to self-select the appropriate survey (either PDA or computer) based on their drug information seeking behaviours.</Species>
<Species>Participants who had used a PDA at any time were instructed to complete the PDA version of the survey.</Species>
<Species>Those who had never used a PDA for drug information were instructed to complete the computer version of the survey.</Species>

<Species>Several strategies were used to optimize response rate and included: personalized cover letters, coloured paper for surveys, stamped return envelopes, follow-up mailing, and a priority post mailing [51].</Species>

<Species>The covering letter included coloured logos of Dalhousie University and the Nova Scotia Department of Health representing the investigator affiliations and endorsement of the project.</Species>
<Species>A master mailing list with names and addresses of NPs and their collaborating physician partners was created.</Species>
<Species>To maintain confidentiality of respondents, a number placed on the bottom right corner of each survey corresponded to a name on the confidential master mailing sheet.</Species>

<Species>The postage paid return envelopes were addressed to the research coordinator at the School of Nursing, Dalhousie University, who matched respondents to the mailing list from the first distribution.</Species>
<Species>The cross-referenced mailing list was not accessible to those entering or analysing data.</Species>
<Species>The research coordinator sent the second distribution to those who had not initially responded.</Species>
<Species>A fluorescent coloured page was included in the second mailing to notify recipients of the second and final mailing status.</Species>
<Species>The second mailing followed 2 weeks after the initial mailing (February 2005).</Species>
<Species>The surveys were sent via Xpresspost  through Canada Post.</Species>
<Species>Data analyses Quantitative Data were entered and analysed in Statistical Package for Social Sciences (SPSS) (version 11.5 for Windows).</Species>
<Species>Five surveys were randomly selected as a check for accuracy of data entry.</Species>
<Species>Descriptive statistics were used to describe resource usage by practitioners.</Species>

<Species>Chi Square (Fisher's Exact when cell count less than 5) analyses were used to determine differences in computer or PDA use based on predetermined variables (e.g. high speed Internet connection, number of patients per day).</Species>
<Species>Mann Whitney U tests were used to compare physician and NPs Likert scale ratings (1 = strongly agree to 5 = strongly disagree) of resource use.</Species>

<Species>Physician and NP rankings of all resources (print, online/electronic, and health professionals and other) were determined from means of Likert scale ratings (1 = strongly agree, 5 = strongly disagree) for each of the pre-specified characteristics (e.g. frequency of use, accessibility, etc.) and the frequency of use of the resources.</Species>
<Species>The best rankings were assigned for the lowest mean scores and the largest number of the sample using a resource.</Species>
<Species>These rankings (ranks based on mean and ranks based on sample) were then entered into a formula to calculate an overall rank.</Species>
<Species>The formula includes: rank =</Species>
<Species>[(rank according to % of sample using the resource + rank based on mean score)    2].</Species>
<Species>This formula was used to account for mean scores based on small samples as these numbers could potentially over or underestimate the value of a resource.</Species>
<Species>Ratings of 6 (i.e. not applicable, I do not use this resource) were excluded from the analyses.</Species>
<Species>Qualitative Comments were entered in a word-processing program and organized by type of respondent (PDA versus computer) and question number.</Species>
<Species>The coded survey number and respondent type (NP or physician) were also included next to comments.</Species>
<Species>Investigators determined themes and categorized comments based on previous experience, knowledge, and familiarity with the topic.</Species>
<Species>Results Surveys were completed and returned by 75% of eligible participants (27 of 36).</Species>
<Species>One physician survey was undeliverable.</Species>
<Species>The response rates from within the NP and physician samples were 88% and 65%, respectively.</Species>
<Species>Complete demographic information is available in Table 1.</Species>
<Species>Methods for accessing resources and self-reported resource use Resource use was similar amongst practitioners.</Species>

<Species>Respondents indicated that print resources (mean 4.56, SD 0.80), health professionals (mean 3.26, SD 0.90), and online/electronic resources (mean 2.70, SD 1.20) were the preferred method (1 = least preferred to 5 = most preferred) for accessing drug information.</Species>

<Species>Thirty-seven percent of respondents reported that searching for specific questions related to drug information (e.g. usual dosage, duration of therapy) was conducted using both print and electronic resources (but print use greater than electronic) (Table 2).</Species>
<Species>The preferred means (i.e. print) to access resources was consistent with the most common means of conducting searches for specific drug information queries.</Species>

<Species>Respondents' ratings for pre-specified print, online/electronic, and professional resources and other, based on means from Likert scales and number of respondents using the resources, are presented in Tables 3, 4, and 5.</Species>
<Species>Of all resources within the print, online/electronic, and health professionals or other categories, NPs and physicians rated the Compendium of Pharmaceuticals and Specialties (CPS)</Species>
<Species>[52] and pharmacists as the top two most frequently used resources for providing drug and therapeutic information.</Species>
<Species>Physicians rated other physicians as the third most frequently used resource.</Species>
<Species>The book Therapeutic Choices [53] ranked third for NPs.</Species>
<Species>Based on written feedback, physicians and NPs consulted pharmacists and other physicians most frequently.</Species>
<Species>The CPS and pharmacists were also ranked as the top two resources overall in terms of usefulness, accessibility, credibility, and current/timeliness for physicians.</Species>
<Species>Rankings by NPs were similar for usefulness, accessibility, and credibility.</Species>
<Species>NPs ranked pharmacists, Therapeutic Choices, and academic detailing first and the CPS as second for current/timeliness.</Species>
<Species>Within the online/electronic category, electronic clinical practice guidelines (eCPGs) were rated the highest for all characteristics (e.g. usefulness, credibility).</Species>
<Species>Although eCPGs were highly ranked, approximately 30% of the sample reported not using this resource.</Species>
<Species>Other resources in this category were infrequently used based on respondents' self-reports.</Species>
<Species>Pharmaceutical industry representatives were used as a source of drug information by 85% and 86% of physicians and NPs, respectively (Table 5).</Species>
<Species>This was higher than regional drug information services (used by 23% of physicians and 50% of NPs).</Species>

<Species>After exclusion of traditional health professionals (i.e. physicians, nurses, pharmacists, allied health) in the health professionals and other category, pharmaceutical industry representatives received rankings for second or third for frequency of use, usefulness, accessibility, credibility, and current/timeliness, based on means and number of respondents using this resource (data not shown).</Species>

<Species>Differences between nurse practitioners and physicians A series of Mann Whitney U tests were used to compare the responses of NPs and physicians on their use of print, online/electronic, and health professional resources.</Species>
<Species>In total 95 statistical tests were conducted.</Species>
<Species>The large number of tests increases the likelihood of a type I error as five significant differences would be expected by chance alone at an alpha threshold of 0.05.</Species>
<Species>It is therefore important to treat these results with caution.</Species>
<Species>A limited number of statistically significant (p < 0.05)</Species>
<Species>differences were identified between physicians and NPs and are reported in Table 6.</Species>
<Species>Therapeutic Choices differed significantly for frequency of use with more NPs making use of this resource.</Species>

<Species>Allied health professionals significantly differed between NPs and physicians for accessibility and current/timeliness while NPs were more in agreement with these characteristics of the resource.</Species>
<Species>Nurse colleague credibility and current/timeliness was rated significantly higher by NPs versus physicians.</Species>

<Species>Factors influencing electronic technology use at the point of care Factors such as gender, age, practitioner type (NP vs physician), accessibility, technical support, Internet connection speed, patient volume, presence of an EPR, and home computer use were examined to determine if they were associated with the use of a work computer to search for drug information at the point of care.</Species>
<Species>No statistically significant associations were found (Fisher's Exact).</Species>

<Species>Additional resources from respondent comments Respondents indicated other resources and programs, such as clinical calculators, that they would like to access from their computer or PDA.</Species>
<Species>The top three resources that were desired included Canadian clinical practice guidelines, patient education information, and ability to track clinical activities/statistics.</Species>
<Species>Further comments from two NP computer survey respondents revealed that a resource on drug interactions and dosages would be desired.</Species>
<Species>One other NP also indicated "up to date info [sic] on drugs to treat various illnesses ie doseage</Species>
<Species>[sic], length of use etc."</Species>

<Species>Computer or personal digital assistant use in practice Approximately 50% of computer survey respondents reported using their work computers for searching drug or therapeutic information related to patient care.</Species>
<Species>Of those respondents, just over half (54%) also reported using their home computer for this purpose.</Species>
<Species>Sixty-seven and 17% of PDA survey respondents reported using their PDA for searching drug or therapeutic information related to patient care at work and home, respectively.</Species>

<Species>Searching on a weekly basis for specific information related to drugs Of the 24 specified categories of drug information included in the survey, the majority were reported as infrequently searched and a smaller percentage as never searched by respondents (data not shown).</Species>
<Species>The top three categories rated as frequently searched were side effects, adult or usual drug dosage, and most appropriate drug for an indication.</Species>
<Species>(Table 7) Issues related to personal digital assistants Respondents reported their level of agreement with statements related to how PDAs may influence their practice.</Species>
<Species>The statements included aspects of workload (organization and paper work), convenience, and improving quality of care and patient outcomes.</Species>
<Species>(Table 8) Respondents agreed that PDAs are a convenient resource but indicated that PDAs would not decrease paperwork or improve patient health outcomes.</Species>

<Species>Barriers and facilitators to personal digital assistants: themes from written comments Peer support from colleagues, convenience, standardized usage, and financial and technical support were the main perceived facilitators to PDA use reported by respondents.</Species>
<Species>The main perceived barrier to PDA use reported by respondents (n = 10) included cost.</Species>

<Species>Other factors such as technology literacy, time, lack of peer support, no high speed internet for downloads, lack of needed resources, keeping up to date on resources, and searching speed were also reported.</Species>
<Species>Future use of personal digital assistants Fifty-two percent, including current PDA users, reported that they would use a PDA in the future.</Species>
<Species>Twenty two percent were uncertain and 19% reported that they would not use a PDA in the future.</Species>
<Species>Two people did not respond.</Species>
<Species>Confidentiality Fifty two percent of respondents indicated that patient confidentiality with PDAs was no more concerning compared to use of other technologies.</Species>
<Species>Forty-four percent did not know if they had a policy on patient confidentiality with regard to technologies.</Species>

<Species>Technology training and reimbursement Respondents rated (1 = least preferred to 5 = most preferred) one on one instruction and group learning led by an expert facilitator as the most preferred (mean 4.32, SD 0.99) means by which to receive instruction on a new technology.</Species>

<Species>Least preferred methods included online discussions/chatrooms (mean 1.52, SD 1.04), internet videos (live: mean 1.70, SD 1.10, or static: mean 1.87, SD 1.14), video cassettes (mean 2.30, SD 1.55), trial and error learning (mean 2.32, SD 1.28), and written manuals (mean 2.92, SD 1.44).</Species>
<Species>Paid leave for attendance at technology training sessions was the preferred means (mean 1.77, SD 0.86; 1 = strongly agree to 5 = strongly disagree) of remuneration for respondents.</Species>

<Species>Respondents also indicated that if financial remuneration was to occur, it should correspond to the amount of time for training that is required (versus a flat rate) (mean 1.96, SD 1.08).</Species>
<Species>Continuing education credits were not viewed as an incentive (mean 2.69, SD 1.44).</Species>

<Species>Discussion Preferred resources In our study, printed materials (e.g. compendia, journals, textbook resources) and professionals (e.g. pharmacists) were the most preferred and frequently used means to access information.</Species>
<Species>Physician reliance on text and compendia relative to online/electronic resources has been frequently reported [11].</Species>

<Species>In a study examining family doctors' use of information sources to answer clinical questions, human resources (e.g. doctor, pharmacist), non-prescribing print information (e.g. textbooks and journal articles), and prescribing texts were used 36%, 32%, and 25% of the time, respectively [54].</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Books from the workplace were reported by approximately 79% of UK primary care nurses as a commonly used source of knowledge and information used to support practice [55].</Species>
<Species>Fewer than one-third (31%) reported using electronic resources (e.g. Internet, electronic journals) for this purpose [55].</Species>

<Species>Results of a postal questionnaire to NPs demonstrated that 61% and 51% of respondents reported using drug reference manuals and textbooks, respectively, a few times a week or more [29].</Species>
<Species>These frequencies were second and third only to consulting with their physician supervisor (63%).</Species>

<Species>Data from structured interviews of a sample of 22 community nurse prescribers reported by Hall et al. revealed that the majority relied on print materials to access information, namely the British National Formulary [32].</Species>

<Species>A survey of a primary care practice-based research network in the US that included physicians, physician assistants, and nurse practitioners, revealed that interpersonal and rapidly accessed print resources were preferred.</Species>

<Species>Sixty-one and 58% of respondents reported using drug reference sources such as the Physician's Desk Reference (PDR) and medical textbooks, respectively, a few times a day or daily [56].</Species>
<Species>The clinicians in our sample perceived the Canadian compendium, the CPS, to be useful, accessible, credible, and current/timely.</Species>

<Species>The CPS, is described as "the Canadian drug reference for health professionals" and is intended to provide a central source of drug information on drug products available in Canada [52].</Species>
<Species>It is available in print (English and French) and became available online in June 2004.</Species>
<Species>The CPS includes drug monographs for commonly used products approved for use in Canada, but it does not include all drugs available on the Canadian market [57].</Species>
<Species>The majority of these product monographs are based on monographs submitted by pharmaceutical manufacturers and approved by Health Canada.</Species>
<Species>Some of the monographs are written by the Canadian Pharmacists Association and are described as being evidence-based [52].</Species>
<Species>The CPS also includes more than 100 pages of clinical tools [52].</Species>
<Species>The CPS has been criticized for including pharmaceutical company advertising and requiring manufacturer payment for inclusion of product monographs [58].</Species>
<Species>The accuracy of particular components of CPS monographs has also been investigated.</Species>

<Species>A review of overdose management in 119 monographs from the 2001 CPS revealed considerable variability in the utility of information with 50% of the monographs containing misleading or dangerous advice [59].</Species>
<Species>Since 2004, the CPS has included an alert box in the overdose section of monographs notifying users to contact Poison Control Centres for overdose management information.</Species>
<Species>Some authors have criticized references that are similar to the CPS as being inadequate with regard to inclusion of evidence based information [60].</Species>
<Species>The NPs in our sample also rated Therapeutic Choices highly for all characteristics.</Species>
<Species>This finding is most likely attributable to the fact that it is a recommended resource for coursework associated with the Dalhousie NP university program curriculum.</Species>
<Species>Therapeutic Choices is a concise therapeutics reference text published by the Canadian Pharmacists Association.</Species>
<Species>The text contains approximately 120 extensively referenced chapters with a disease management approach including easy to use algorithms and tables.</Species>
<Species>An editorial board is responsible for extensively reviewing the content to ensure unbiased and objective information is presented [53].</Species>

<Species>Health professionals Reliance on other health professionals, especially pharmacists and physicians, as a resource for information was evident from our study and concurs with the findings of others [28,32,55,61].</Species>
<Species>Nurse practitioners have reported that collaborative relationships with pharmacists increase NP role satisfaction [61].</Species>

<Species>NPs frequently consult with allied health care professionals in their primary health care provider role and this is supported by written feedback from our sample regarding frequently consulted health professionals.</Species>
<Species>Nursing colleagues are also likely to be rated highly by NPs due to their affiliation with peers from the same profession.</Species>

<Species>Some investigators have shown that non-human references (e.g. textbook) are sought for more technical aspects of prescribing (e.g. dose), whereas guidance regarding selection of agents (i.e. right drug for an indication) is sought from human resources (e.g. pharmacists or physicians)</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>[62].</Species>
<Species>We were unable to determine what kinds of resources were used for specific purposes from our study.</Species>

<Species>Online and electronic resources, computers, and personal digital assistants From our study, computer survey respondents ranked online/electronic resources third in preference following print and health professionals.</Species>
<Species>Various barriers and facilitators to accessing information online/electronically or via the Internet have been described in the literature</Species>
<Species>[55,63-66].</Species>

<Species>Variables that have been described by others as barriers such as accessibility, high speed internet access, patient volume, age, practitioner type, and technology support did not appear to influence computer searching for information on drugs or therapeutics related to patient care in our results.</Species>
<Species>Some qualitative feedback does however support this notion.</Species>
<Species>As an example, in response to a request for a rationale for not using computers one physician commented: "Retro tech [sic]/old fashion.</Species>
<Species>I still like to use my mind and have always been a fan of pen and paper".</Species>
<Species>Barriers that were identified with our sample regarding the use of handheld technologies such as PDAs included cost, time, and issues related to technology literacy.</Species>
<Species>Several people questioned the value of PDAs.</Species>
<Species>One GP stated when referring to a PDA: "So far I have not discovered a use for one".</Species>
<Species>Other respondents reinforced their preferences for other resources (e.g. books) and resistance to technology.</Species>
<Species>When responding to barriers for the use of PDAs, one NP commented, "My huge dislike for machinery that frequently requires updating and patience".</Species>
<Species>A physician responded, "as stated, I like to use my own mind, and can get all the info I need from books relatively quickly".</Species>
<Species>Facilitators to the use of PDAs mainly included convenience factors such as having resources all in one place, faster means to get information, and portability.</Species>
<Species>Our sample was not in agreement with some convenience factors in that they did not feel that PDAs would decrease paperwork.</Species>
<Species>Practitioners from our sample felt relatively neutral about PDAs improving patient's health outcomes with 41% responding in this manner.</Species>

<Species>Results from a sample of primary care practitioners in the US revealed that 76% agreed that the use of handheld devices for electronic prescribing would substantially reduce medical errors and improve the quality of health care [67].</Species>
<Species>Our study also suggests that resources such as the Cochrane Library and its Database of Systematic Reviews were not frequently used.</Species>
<Species>This finding is similar to that of other investigators</Species>
<Species>[30,35,64].</Species>
<Species>Despite the desire of some clinicians to use these resources, lack of confidence and ability to use them appropriately has been found [30,64,68,69].</Species>
<Species>Our study suggests that although this resource is perceived as credible, current/timely, and useful, it is also perceived to be somewhat inaccessible.</Species>

<Species>The Cochrane Library is available to the health professionals (e.g. nurses, physicians, pharmacists, occupational therapists, physiotherapists, etc.) in our sample through professional bodies via the Atlantic Health Knowledge Partnership [70].</Species>

<Species>Technology training: preferences and incentives With regard to receiving training for a new technology, our study demonstrates that in person conferences or one on one training sessions are the preferred means to receive continuing education.</Species>
<Species>Person to person interaction has been reported as the preferred and most frequently used means to access continuing education or training by other investigators</Species>
<Species>[55,71].</Species>

<Species>Our study also indicates that this group of practitioners may benefit from accessing resources [72-80] that provide guidance on useful drug information resources available for devices such as PDAs.</Species>
<Species>This is exemplified by one respondent's statement "knowledge regarding good software programs" as a barrier to the use of PDAs.</Species>
<Species>Pharmaceutical industry</Species>
<Species>The influence of the pharmaceutical industry on physician prescribing and research outcomes has been documented [81,82].</Species>
<Species>Although NP use of industry representatives as a source of pharmacological information has been documented, the influence on prescribing is largely uninvestigated</Species>
<Species>[32,61,83-85].</Species>
<Species>The CNA competency framework includes a statement regarding prescribing and industry relations [23].</Species>
<Species>In our study, the physician and NP rankings of industry representatives were similar.</Species>

<Species>Within the health professionals and other category, pharmaceutical representatives were used as a resource by more of the sample than regional drug information services and comparably to academic detailing services.</Species>

<Species>Academic detailing is a form of continuing medical education where a trained health professional visits prescribers for a fifteen to twenty minute session to provide objective information regarding a therapeutic topic based on best available evidence [86,87].</Species>

<Species>Following academic detailing, physician and NP rankings of pharmaceutical industry representatives were second or third for frequency of use, usefulness, accessibility, credibility, and current/timeliness.</Species>
<Species>Limitations</Species>
<Species>We do not have demographics or information regarding the reasons why survey recipients did not respond.</Species>

<Species>As per ethical requirements to maintain confidentiality of respondents, we were not able to match respondents from their respective place of practice and therefore cannot conclude whether the practitioners within a practice setting influenced the others' responses.</Species>
<Species>The sample size of the survey is small although it includes 88% response from community based NPs in Nova Scotia.</Species>
<Species>The generalizability of the results is limited due to the variations in NP scopes of practice nationally and internationally.</Species>

<Species>It is unknown whether the findings are generalizable to nonresponding physicians within Nova Scotia collaborating with NPs or to physicians not in collaborative practices with NPs as they were not included as a part of the sample.</Species>
<Species>Due to multiple statistical comparisons (Mann Whitney U), the results comparing NP and physician ratings of results should be interpreted with caution.</Species>
<Species>Conclusion Respondent ratings of resources and preferences for resource use were consistent with self-reported means of conducting searches for specific drug information queries.</Species>
<Species>The use of computers and PDAs remains limited and also matches preferences and resource ratings.</Species>
<Species>Education to this group of practitioners regarding available drug information resources may facilitate use of computer and PDA resources.</Species>
<Species>Further research is needed to determine methods to increase the use of computers and PDAs and if use of these technologies affects prescribing and patient outcomes.</Species>
